webTitle: Our bid looks dead in the water

fields.headline: Our bid looks dead in the water
fields.standfirst: The fighting on the streets caught the headlines. But the real battle was to stage the World Cup and harvest billions
fields.trailText: The fighting on the streets caught the headlines. But the real battle was to stage the World Cup and harvest billions.
fields.body:
Seventy-five minutes in a hotel last Sunday capped one of English football's darkest days since the tragedies of Heysel, Bradford and Hillsborough. Uefa, European soccer's ruler, warned that England would be expelled from Euro 2000 if there was any repeat of the drunken brawling their fans had indulged in over the previous 48 hours.

Uefa's threat also shattered any pretence that the English game had thrown off its hooligan past. The images that flashed round the world were of fans fighting, throwing chairs and attacking policemen. The country that invented the world's most popular sport was once again in danger of becoming a pariah.

However, an Observer investigation into the turmoil that engulfed English football last weekend has revealed the crisis was even more serious than previously acknowledged. We have established that Uefa seriously considered throwing England out of Euro 2000 on the spot, and that the Football Association decided to pull Kevin Keegan's team out before they were kicked out if there was more violence.

Inquiries at the highest levels of football have also discovered that, having allowed England to stay in the showcase competition, Uefa was then antagonised even further by some English football officials who suggested that its members were part of a cynical, German-inspired plot to scupper England's chances of staging the 2006 World Cup.

Senior football figures believe the combination of rioting in Belgium and this 'xenophobic' response to England's punishment, will ensure Germany or South Africa, England's main rivals in the five-country race to host 2006, emerge triumphant when the vote is taken on 6 July.

The emergency session of Uefa's executive committee, in a meeting room of the Holiday Inn in Liege, northern Belgium, was always going to spell trouble for England. That morning Uefa president Lennart Johansson and general secretary Gerhard Aigner were appalled at the mayhem that had erupted on the Friday night and Saturday afternoon in Brussels and Charleroi, the venue for the England-Germany showdown.

When they assembled at five o'clock that afternoon, the mood of the Uefa representatives was grim. 'They were furious that English fans were spoiling what was fast becoming a memorable footballing competition,' explained one Uefa source. As member after committee member offered opinions, they discussed whether England should be expelled immediately.

FA insiders later claimed that the people arguing most strongly for this to be considered were Aigner and Uefa treasurer Egidius Braun, who are both German. However, neither formally asked their colleagues to sanction it and a consensus was reached that a warning was enough. In fact the most damning evidence of English misbehaviour came from a Scot and a Belgian.

Ernie Walker, the Scottish chairman of Uefa's stadiums committee, gave a vivid account of the violence he had witnessed at first-hand in Charleroi on Saturday a few hours before the 7.45pm kick-off. His damning observations about the behaviour of English fans were backed up by Michel D'Hooghe, president of the Belgian FA. It is understood that D'Hooghe, under huge pressure from the Belgian authorities, would have accepted England's instant ejection.

'Everyone at the meeting realised that, whatever trouble there had been at the tournament, English fans had been the common denominator and the aggressors,' explained one of those around the table. 'Uefa people well remember the trouble that English fans have caused before in places like Marseilles and Dublin. The general view was: we're not putting up with this any more.'

In their discussions, Uefa had a nightmare scenario very firmly in mind: that England would get the point they needed from their final group game with Romania two nights later and therefore play Italy last night in the King Baudouin stadium in Brussels - the renamed Heysel arena where rioting by Liverpool fans in 1985 led to the deaths of 39 people, mostly followers of the Italian side Juventus.

Sir Brian Hayes, the FA's security adviser, was given barely five minutes to argue England's case. But his attempts to persuade Uefa that English fans were not exclusively to blame for starting the trouble, and that Belgians, Belgian-Turks and others had played their part fell on deaf ears.

In a statement, Uefa lambasted English hooligans as 'a disgrace to their country and a blight on the national team'. It was so angry at the latest outbreaks of 'the English disease' that some in the FA decided that Kevin Keegan's team should be withdrawn from Euro 2000 before they were formally expelled, believing that such a move would shock England's troublemakers into behaving properly abroad.

Senior FA figures are appalled that some of their colleagues managed to antagonise Uefa even further by briefing journalists that the European body had 'taken advantage of a perfect opportunity to stuff England over 2006'.

In the complicated and often fractious world of global football politics it is well-known that the FA and Uefa have a frosty relationship. Uefa has eight representatives on the 24-strong executive of Fifa, football's global governing body, which will decide in 11 days' time who gets 2006.

There is now a strong chance England's £10 million, high-profile campaign to land 2006 may attract as few as two votes when Fifa meets.

Nelson Mandela is expected to travel to Zurich on 5 July to help put South Africa's case to the Fifa executive the day before they decide between his country, Germany, England, Morocco and Brazil. His charisma may not be needed, as South Africa is already strong favourite.

There are no plans for Blair to fight England's corner in Switzerland. England had been hoping that South Africa's high crime rate would help sway the vote in their favour. Ironically, England's own problem of apparently intractable violence is likely to prove crucial instead.

fields.headline: Classy Wasim wins it
fields.standfirst: Pakistan beat Sri Lanka by an innings and 163 runs
fields.trailText: Some fiery bowling after a classic batting display gives Pakistan victory over Sri Lanka.
fields.body:
Pakistan's superb all-round display enabled them to thrash Sri Lanka by an innings and 163 runs at the Galle International Stadium and take an unbeatable 2-0 lead in the three-Test series.

Sri Lanka, requiring a mammoth 419 runs to avoid an innings defeat after four Pakistan batsmen logged centuries in their formidable 600 for eight declared, were dismissed for 256 in the final session of the fourth day.

It was another poor batting performance by the Sri Lankan batsmen to follow their first-innings 181 all out on an excellent batting pitch.

Only opener Marvan Atapattu, who scored 59 in 249 minutes with nine fours, and former captain Arjuna Ranatunga, who slammed 65 off 80 balls with 13 fours, held up Pakistan's progress towards a crushing victory.

Sri Lanka had resumed at 45 for one and moved promisingly to 123 for two at lunch before things started to fall apart for them.

Off-spinner Arshad Khan snapped up the wickets of Atapattu and Aravinda de Silva (11) within 13 balls in the afternoon session as Sri Lanka slid to 189 for six at tea.

Ranatunga, with the support of Chaminda Vaas (20), put together a stand of 43 for the seventh wicket before Wasim Akram broke through by trapping the former skipper leg before wicket with a swinging yorker.

Azhar Mahmood then accounted for Vaas and Rangana Herath in one over to speed up the victory.

Last man Muttiah Muralitharan hit out boldly for 22 off 10 balls which included five fours before Waqar Younis ended the innings and the match by clattering his stumps.

Waqar finished with figures of four for 40 and a match haul of seven wickets but Wasim Akram, who scored 100 and took three wickets, was named man of the match.

The third Test commences in Kandy on Wednesday.

The Intenational Cricket Council summit will discuss the promotion of Bangladesh into a full Test nation tomorrow, but the English-speaking countries are suspicious of allowing a power-bloc of four Asian nations to be formed, and they are believed to be doubtful about the standard of cricket they are producing.

Also, there is sure to be much debate on the television rights for the next two World Cups, with the threat of a breakaway if some companies do not secure rights and stage their own international competitions and matches.

The topic of a World Cup tournament every two years is on the agenda, therefore reducing the number of one-day internationals, and the possibility of a World Test championship will also be given an airing.

A resolution will be tabled that the 2003 World Cup will comprise of the 11 countries with one-day international status (Australia, Bangladesh. England, India, Kenya, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, West Indies and Zimbabwe), plus the three top countries from the 2001 ICC Trophy.

fields.headline: A sad farewell for Hagi
fields.trailText: England would have played Italy here in Brussels last night, had they been any good. Judging by this performance, Kevin Keegan's side would have been embarrassed.
fields.body:
England would have played Italy here in Brussels last night, had they been any good. Judging by this performance, Kevin Keegan's side would have been embarrassed.

The result suggests a comfortable Italian victory, but there were two classy teams on show. Romania had most of the play before and after trailing by two goals at half-time and suffered for lacking an edge in front of Italy's goal and paid for lapses in concentration in front of their own.

Italy, though, unlike England, are masters at letting teams attack them before punishing them on rapid counter-attacks and they deservedly won thanks to their superior organisation both defending and going forward.

Romania, even with three players suspended and key midfielder Gica 'the leader' Popescu out injured, still had the ability to pass the ball in and around Italy's midfield. Italy did not mind that, but it was different when the ball was nearer their penalty area, where they defended like a liquid metal wall, forever moving, forever impenetrable.

As in past tournaments, Italy are improving with every game and, although he will be concerned by the injuries which put Paolo Maldini and Antonio Conte out of this game, manager Dino Zoff seems to know his best team now.

The only pre-match debate in the Italian camp concerned whether Francesco Totti or Alessandro Del Piero should partner Filippo Inzaghi in attack. Zoff went with the former and was repaid when Totti clinically struck Italy's opening goal. Inzaghi's finish was just as emphatic for their second.

Any hope for a Romania comeback disappeared when their inspirational captain, Gheorghe Hagi, was sent off. He kicked Conte out of the game and tried to cheat the referee into awarding a penalty so he had to go, but it was not a fitting way for one of the best players of his generation to end an international career.

Italy look capable of going all the way now, and will not feel daunted should they have to play Holland in Amsterdam. It's all over for Hagi and his mates - unless they want to stay and follow the example of some England supporters whose vocal chords could still be heard outside the ground before kick-off. Hopefully, they had come to see how football should be played at this level.

fields.headline: Italy set for final
fields.trailText: The shirts look a paler blue than usual but there is still a rich hue to these Azzurri. Italy came to Euro 2000 with few fancying them to achieve anything significant but now they will fancy themselves against Holland or Yugoslavia in Amsterdam on Thursday.
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at the King Baudouin stadium
fields.body:
The shirts look a paler blue than usual but there is still a rich hue to these Azzurri. Italy came to Euro 2000 with few fancying them to achieve anything significant but now, first-half goals by Francesco Totti and Filippo Inzaghi having swept them into the semi-finals last night, they will fancy themselves against Holland or Yugoslavia in Amsterdam on Thursday.

Their passage was aided when the Romanians - but a silhouette of the side that ran England ragged to qualify for the last eight, the Italians never allowing them the same freedom to create - were reduced to 10 men with the dubious 58th-minute dismissal of their talisman Gheorghe Hagi. Having already been booked for a foul that saw Antonio Conte carried off on a stretcher, minutes later he was deemed to have dived under challenge from Gianluca Zambrotta and the referee, Vitor Melo Pereira of Portugal, brandished a second yellow card.

Television replays showed that Zambrotta had indeed tugged Hagi as he closed on goal but the theatrics had harmed the Romanian's case. Hagi railed and raged against the injustice but there was no going back. It was a poignant way for one of the great international careers to end, Hagi - the Maradona of the Carpathians - having announced his retirement at the age of 35.

He was only just back after suspension - he was missing against England. In the manner of Samson shorn of his strength, he was shaven-headed, as promised if his team-mates won that match, but he was clearly not chastened. He had also been sent off for Galatasaray in the Uefa Cup final against Arsenal, to be followed by yellow cards in the first two games of this tournament. There is rage within him at the dying of the light.

As he failed to go gently into this good night, with him went any faint hopes that Romania might recover the deficit. They weren't playing England, after all. The Italians never subsequently looked likely to surrender their lead. For this is a traditional, back-to-basics Italy team, based on their traditional strengths of sound, solid defending, industrious midfield play and the odd moment of inspiration in attack.

Injuries before the tournament to their first-choice goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon and the £23 million striker Christian Vieri almost seem to have helped bond them in adversity.

It showed even in their attitude during their national anthem, the Fratelli D'Italia, as they linked arms. They were Italian brothers indeed.

By contrast, the Romanians grew frustrated at being confronted this time by a less porous side and ended the match dispirited. Though they had some moments of touch and promise from Hagi, the absence of the injured Gica Popescu and three suspended players, including Dan Petrescu, proved too much for them.

Had Inzaghi's finishing been sharper, they might even have been more soundly beaten. The erratic Juventus striker wasted a good through ball by Totti - preferred to Alessandro Del Piero in the starting line-up - early on by shooting wide and in the second half did similarly when well placed to wrap up proceedings.

Fortunately for Italy, the chance to unlock what was initially a cagey, staccato match fell to Totti. From Demetrio Albertini's free-kick on the right, Paolo Maldini headed back across goal, a weak clearance then falling for Stefano Fiore to clip the ball back into the penalty area for Totti, having stolen space, to guide past Bogdag Stelea.

It was the goal the game needed to spark it into life.

Soon after, Constantin Galca sprayed a ball wide to Hagi wide on the right and Francesco Toldo, making probably his first error of judgement of the tournament, rushed from his line, only to see Hagi's shot, a rare right-footer, bounce gently off a post before being cleared by Mark Iuliano.

It soon proved costly. Albertini, a quiet inspiration in the heart of the Italian midfield, picked out Inzaghi's run with a threaded ball that saw Iulian Filipescu playing him onside, and this time he stroked the ball home. Coming so close to half-time, it looked decisive. Duly it was - after Hagi's departure. They huffed, with Ioan Ganea, England's executioner, seeing a close-range shot blocked by Luigi Di Biagio but Italy came closer to scoring again, Stelea turning Inzaghi's shot on to a post.

Enter the superstar Del Piero for a run-out in Totti's place. Exit Gheorghe Hagi. His exquisite left foot, touch and vision will be much missed from the international stage.

fields.headline: Top headteacher attacks 'Posh-and-Becks' culture
fields.trailText: One of the country's most influential educationists has launched a withering attack on philistine English culture.
fields.body:
One of the country's most influential educationists has launched a withering attack on philistine English culture.

Dr Martin Stephen, High Master of independent Manchester Grammar School, who is consulted by both Labour and Conservative politicians on secondary education, says teenagers are encouraged to harbour a deep mistrust of intellectuals. Beauty, wealth and celebrity are valued above brains in England in a way unknown in other countries, including Scotland, he says. His comments reignited the debate over 'dumbing down' and sparked a furious reaction from fellow academics.

Speaking to The Observer last night, Stephen said the Government's recent attacks on elitism were hypocritical. The introduction of tuition fees and ending of the university grant sent the wrong message to young people. 'In the Sixties, graduates were a national resource to be cultivated. Now they are seen as an asset to be taxed.'

He said idolatry of celebrities such as 'Posh and Becks' was disproportionate to what they had achieved: 'I think David Beckham is a superb footballer and I admire him immensely for that. But it's where I place him in my canon of admiration that really matters.'

His attack appears in an article for the parliamentary House magazine, in which he says: 'Our culture encourages young people to worship bodies, not brains. It is the culture of the celebrity. It is not cool to be clever. It is cool to be beautiful, rich and famous. I have only met two Nobel prizewinners. Neither was beautiful, neither was rich and both became famous only after a lifetime slaving away at research.'

David Reynolds, professor of education at Exeter University, said Stephen was wrong: 'The worship of popular culture is hardly a recent phenomenon. The older generation also had its pop, sporting and fashion icons. More people read books than ever, more people visit libraries and more people listen to classical music. Perhaps Dr Stephen just doesn't like people with trainers going to the opera.'

The Government has adopted many of Stephen's radical ideas about education, most of which encourage direct links between top private schools such as his own, and local comprehensives. He recently cut a deal with Trinity College, Oxford, and Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge, to pay for coaching classes for sixth-formers from local comprehensives.

He said English people began losing respect for academics and intellectuals after the war. 'People became increasingly suspicious of the classic Victorian idea of bettering yourself. In Scotland, the culture is completely different. As a relatively poor nation, education is always seen as a way out of poverty. There has always been a respect for learning.'

Dr Richard Hoggart, author of the classic work on class and culture, The Uses of Literacy, said that Stephens was exaggerating the problem: 'We live in a populist society. There is an enormous industry devoted to making young people buy what the producers what them to. They become bewitched by it, but many of them also grow out of it.'

Conservative education spokeswoman Theresa May said: 'As a nation, we tend not to have clever role models.'

Dr Martin Stephen, High Master of independent Manchester Grammar School, who is consulted by both Labour and Conservative politicians on secondary education, says teenagers are encouraged to harbour a deep mistrust of intellectuals. Beauty, wealth and celebrity are valued above brains in England in a way unknown in other countries, including Scotland, he says. His comments reignited the debate over 'dumbing down' and sparked a furious reaction from fellow academics. Speaking to The Observer last night, Stephen said the Government's recent attacks on elitism were hypocritical. The introduction of tuition fees and ending of the university grant sent the wrong message to young people. 'In the Sixties, graduates were a national resource to be cultivated. Now they are seen as an asset to be taxed.' He said idolatry of celebrities such as 'Posh and Becks' was disproportionate to what they had achieved: 'I think David Beckham is a superb footballer and I admire him immensely for that. But it's where I place him in my canon of admiration that really matters.' His attack appears in an article for the parliamentary House magazine, in which he says: 'Our culture encourages young people to worship bodies, not brains. It is the culture of the celebrity. It is not cool to be clever. It is cool to be beautiful, rich and famous. I have only met two Nobel prizewinners. Neither was beautiful, neither was rich and both became famous only after a lifetime slaving away at research.' David Reynolds, professor of education at Exeter University, said Stephen was wrong: 'The worship of popular culture is hardly a recent phenomenon. The older generation also had its pop, sporting and fashion icons. More people read books than ever, more people visit libraries and more people listen to classical music. Perhaps Dr Stephen just doesn't like people with trainers going to the opera.' The Government has adopted many of Stephen's radical ideas about education, most of which encourage direct links between top private schools such as his own, and local comprehensives. He recently cut a deal with Trinity College, Oxford, and Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge, to pay for coaching classes for sixth-formers from local comprehensives. He said English people began losing respect for academics and intellectuals after the war. 'People became increasingly suspicious of the classic Victorian idea of bettering yourself. In Scotland, the culture is completely different. As a relatively poor nation, education is always seen as a way out of poverty. There has always been a respect for learning.' Dr Richard Hoggart, author of the classic work on class and culture, The Uses of Literacy, said that Stephens was exaggerating the problem: 'We live in a populist society. There is an enormous industry devoted to making young people buy what the producers what them to. They become bewitched by it, but many of them also grow out of it.' Conservative education spokeswoman Theresa May said: 'As a nation, we tend not to have clever role models.'

webTitle: Lovable screen father David Tomlinson dies aged 83

fields.headline: Lovable screen father David Tomlinson dies aged 83
fields.trailText: The film star David Tomlinson, who became the jovial face of Edwardian fatherhood following roles in the children’s musicals Mary Poppins and Bedknobs and Broomsticks, died yesterday aged 83.
fields.body:
The film star David Tomlinson, who became the jovial face of Edwardian fatherhood following roles in the children’s musicals Mary Poppins and Bedknobs and Broomsticks, died yesterday aged 83.

The death of the veteran actor in hospital near his Buckinghamshire home followed a series of strokes.

In 1964 Tomlinson appeared as the father in the Walt Disney film version of PL Travers’s books about the nanny Mary Poppins, starring opposite Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke. The film, which blended animation with live action and brought the word ‘supercalifragilisticexpialidocious’ into common use, won five Academy Awards and is still one of Disney’s most popular.

Tomlinson’s career took off in the late 1960s and, while he appeared in more than 50 films, he specialised in children’s comedies, including the first Herbie film, The Love Bug, in 1969.

In 1971, Disney turned to Tomlinson for his genial qualities once again and he was cast opposite Angela Lansbury in Bedknobs and Broomsticks, another musical with animation.

Only eight years later, Tomlinson decided to give up acting after making his last film, The Fiendish Plot of Dr Fu Manchu with Peter Sellers.

He wanted to spend more time with his wife Audrey, 68, to whom he was married for 47 years. Among his close friends was the actor Robert Morley, who died eight years ago. Tomlinson was also friends with the comedian Griff Rhys Jones and Ian Hislop, the writer and editor of Private Eye .

One of Tomlinson’s four sons, James, said his father, was warm and loyal: ‘He was a very unusual man who had many talents. He was good with his eyes and talked very well. He had a passion for acting.’

webTitle: Garland's ex-husband in Oscar sale row

fields.headline: Garland's ex-husband in Oscar sale row
fields.trailText: The final scene of a Hollywood drama will be played out in a US courthouse tomorrow when a decision is announced on the fate of a small, mass-produced, metal statuette. The winner is expected to be the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences; the loser, an 83-year-old man who holds the key to one of movieland's great mysteries.
fields.body:
The final scene of a Hollywood drama will be played out in a US courthouse tomorrow when a decision is announced on the fate of a small, mass-produced, metal statuette. The winner is expected to be the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences; the loser, an 83-year-old man who holds the key to one of movieland's great mysteries.

Behind the legal action is a story that has all the hallmarks of a Hollywood classic - a long-dead star, estranged children, drugs, cover-ups, lost heirlooms and money.

The statuette is a mini-Oscar, less than 1ft high, won by Judy Garland for her role in The Wizard of Oz . In 1958, her then husband and manager, Sid Luft, reported the Oscar lost or stolen and she was given a replacement. Two weeks ago, 31 years after Garland's drug overdose death, the missing Oscar turned up on an internet auction site, being sold by Luft at a starting price of $3 million (about £2m).

The Garland Oscar is prized for two reasons: it is a unique 'junior' Oscar - awarded when the star was 16; and it has the cachet of the Garland name - last month one of five pairs of ruby slippers she wore playing Dorothy was sold for £500,000. Luft refuses to discuss where the Oscar has been for over 40 years. When Garland died at the age of 47, she had huge debts. As her ex-husband and ex-manager, Luft could still face ownership challenges from her creditors.

The academy seeks to ensure Oscars do not slip on to the collectors' market. Tomorrow it will learn whether it has been successful in obtaining a restraining order on Luft and the website owner, Nate Sanders, preventing any sale.

Luft's action came six years after he was stopped from selling Garland's replacement Oscar. After a legal tussle, the gold-plated copy was given to the couple's daughter, singer Lorna Luft. Lorna, 46, and her half-sister, Liza Minnelli, both inherited their mother's drug problems.

One clue to the reappearance of the Oscar now could lie in the increased interest in the actress. A new biography is out this year and Lorna's autobiography is being made into a film.

According to a family friend, Luft and his daughter, one of two children he had with Garland, no longer speak to each other. Luft, who lives in Los Angeles, recently had a heart bypass operation.

Academy spokesman John Pavlik told The Observer it was Luft who approached the academy in 1958 asking for his then wife's replacement Oscar. Pavlik told him that if the original turned up he should give it to his daughter. 'We own the statuette and when someone dies we would expect it to be given to their heirs. It is a thing for posterity, not for making money out of,' said Pavlik. 'If Sid Luft has suddenly found this original Oscar, the best thing would be for him to hand it over to Lorna. We have obtained a temporary restraining order on Mr Luft and expect to hear the permanent restraining order has been granted on Monday.'

The legal situation surrounding the original statuette is not clear. The academy began issuing contracts with Oscars in 1951. The 'winners' agreement' had to be signed by all recipients; it stated that they or their heirs could not sell an Oscar, except back to the academy for a token fee of $1.

By 1951 some 500 or so had been handed out to tearful thespians. Among them was Garland's in 1940. Academy lawyers say Garland signed the winners' agreement when she got her replacement and that both gongs are covered. The MGM studio star called it her 'Munchkin' award. Despite being one of the most popular stars of her day and having two further nominations, she never won another.

Luft, a former boxer, was married to Garland for eight years. He lasted the longest of her five husbands and was still very much tied up with her financial affairs. Garland's biographer, George Clarke, whose book is to be published in the UK in November, said: 'Sid is a charmer, but he always has his eye out for his next chance to make a dollar.'

Garland's life spiralled out of control after they split. Addicted to uppers and downers, she married and remarried within three years. Most of her money was taken by the taxman, who also seized her home. For the 16-year-old who enchanted the world, it was a yellow brick road to tragedy.

fields.headline: Chinese bairns
fields.standfirst: It's not easy being a village schoolteacher. Especially if you're only 13
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: Zhang Yimou has not gone quiet without his muse. He has merely tried another path...
fields.body:
The wonder of cinema is that, just occasionally, it can take you somewhere you could never go to and sit you down as equals - concerned, involved observers - among people you could never otherwise meet. Say a primary school class deep in rural China, where poverty is making a box of chalk last a month.

There's one stooped schoolmaster called Gao and he needs a month off with his dying mum. Can the 'mayor' - grand title for a gap-toothed farmer who never pays his bills - find a supply teacher to fill in? Only a 13-year-old from a neighbouring village. But she doesn't stand a chance of getting paid unless she keeps the dwindling class intact. Lose one more and she has nothing. That's the 'not one less' of the title.

Zhang Yimou, from Red Sorghum and Raise the Red Lantern, is a great director. When he lived and worked with the amazing Gong-Li, their films found a world audience and an emotional power that rattled China's rulers in their office cages. But he and Gong-Li have parted now, the end of a prolifically creative affair, and Zhang has changed course utterly.

Not One Less has an almost documentary simplicity. No professional actors and the children all use their real names, the mayor is a real mayor, Teacher Gao chalks real blackboards for a living. The decrepit shack of a school in the flyblown scatter of a village is rural depopulation waiting to happen. Zhang doesn't need art to make you believe: immediate authenticity.

Wei Minzhi, the 13-year-old in the firing line, is a thin, gawky girl with a stubborn face. At first she sits outside, stunned, as her rabble class run wild, but gradually she gets the hang of things, until the cheeky chappie of indiscipline, 10-year-old Zhang Huike, is suddenly dispatched to the city to scrape a living and send what cash he can back to his sickly mum. Not one less? Teacher Wei has somehow to bring him back. The second half of the film is the odyssey of her search for him among the neon lights and bewildering harshness of urban civilisation.

This is not, it should be said clearly, a movie with any global ambitions. Its core audience must be basically inside China. It grows didactic towards the close and the sunny ending, featuring Beijing's answer to Esther Rantzen, seems perfunctorily contrived. But that's not really the point. A film that tells China (and us) that a million children a year have to drop out of school every year in desperate impoverishment and shows us what that means has a fine cinematic heritage, from Bicycle Thieves to Los Olvidados. Better still, if you can identify with the people involved, you can feel for them, too.

There's nothing far away about Wei Minzhi's dogged determination or about her class's giggling boredom. One blackboard jungle is much like another, from Yanqing County to Yeovil. Nor is the awful lure of the city, the draining of resource and hope from the countryside, a phenomenon that ends at the Great Wall. The aim may not be universal and the rattling of bureaucratic cages may be more modestly cautious than heretofore: but its targets arise naturally wherever you are.

Zhang Yimou has not gone quiet without his muse. He has merely tried another path, and if you come to remember the moment in triumph when Wei Minzhi's sullen face splits into a smile, you'll remember the final eagerness to learn and the strength of leadership discovered along that human trek.

fields.headline: Hero today, but gone tomorrow?
fields.standfirst: Sean Connery will collect his knighthood next month after a long career of macho roles. But is the day of the rough and tough male lead finally over?
fields.trailText: Sean Connery will collect his knighthood next month after a long career of macho roles. But is the day of the rough and tough male lead finally over?
fields.body:
He's 70 next month, and on 5 July he is to become a Sir, at a ceremony in Edinburgh's Holyrood Palace. So brace yourselves yet again for the Annual Sean Connery Celebrity Experience. You must know the routine by now. Supporter of Scottish independence. Possible new Bond film. Still 'World's Sexiest Man' (says some half-baked magazine poll). News of forthcoming movie starring an aspirant babe from somewhere around the middle of the Hollywood B-List. Stoutly refutes allegations of being a wife-beater...

Yes, there's some grit in the whisky glass this time. In May, Scottish newspapers carried some quotes from Connery's first wife, Diane Cliento, contained in a forthcoming biography of the star by Geoffrey Wansell. In the book, she alleges that Connery badly beat her in a Spanish hotel room in 1965. Connery is considering whether to sue, but no action has been taken so far. Yet there has never been any denial of his public quotes about the legitimacy of hitting women, which Connery has sprinkled through his press record over the last 35 years.

'To slap a woman is not the cruellest thing you can do to her,' he said in a Vanity Fair interview in 1993. Expect opportunist politicians and lazy commentators to raise this issue again, as Sir Sean bends the knee in a fortnight. But by far the most interesting aspect of Connery's biographical darkness is the way it feeds into his own film history - and into the highly charged politics of masculinity in modern movies. When the idea of the 'crisis of men' is one of the biggest cultural themes in the developed West (from Fight Club to American Psycho ), how do we assess a movie icon who stands, like no other, for 'real' manhood - with all the dangers that implies? In short, at the beginning of a hopeful new century, is it time to release ourselves from the sulphurous spell of his Bond-age, and say: Connery no more?

He'll have to be forced, because he doesn't seem to be willing to give up on his own account. With three movies currently in development or being completed (Gus Van Sant's Finding Forrester , a spy thriller called End Game , and a remake of Graham Greene's The Quiet American ), retirement seems to be the last thing on his mind. But we don't need to wait for any more evidence of the desuetude of Connery's art. All we need to do is to look at his successors. With them we can see how things can progress - from a man who thinks 'there are women who take it to the wire', that look for 'the ultimate confrontation', to men who confront their own maleness, as much as their women.

Modern action heroes such as Nicolas Cage or Tom Cruise cruelly show up Connery's limitations. Connery has always does the masterful official well - spies, kings, dragons, wizards, grizzled elder cops. In this he links back to the classic era of Gable and Wayne, Tracey and Bogart. These were straight-up, authoritative guys, efficiently doing some 'tricks' for the camera - same accent, same face, every time. Acting was something done in between improving the golf handicap, and hobnobbing with power élites. But Connery shows few signs of the troubled male self-questioning that makes contemporary stars like Cage or Cruise so compelling, no matter their genre.

When Cage unravels himself in Leaving Las Vegas, or Cruise howls his impotence in Born on the Fourth of July , you see actors fully aware of how complex screen manhood must be these days, to be even remotely credible. Their 'action-and-adventure' movies always bear the trace memory of these experiments - their utter 'inaction', the weakness of their wills. Who can look at Cruise's implacable face in Mission Impossible 2, without recalling his recent psychological extremes: the sleazoid sex instructor in Magnolia, or the doomed doctor in Eyes Wide Shut?

Connery has always moaned about how he 'wanted to kill that Bond', shrug off the bullet-proof tuxedo and show the full range of his talents. But his choice of films belie him. Apart from a few forays into art-moviedom in the Sixties and Seventies (his sex-offending policeman in 1972's The Offence being the most notable success), and his celibate monk in 1986's The Name of the Rose, Connery has always crunched straight down the gravel-path of unambiguous masculinity. And in his later years, rather like his old drinking buddy Michael Caine, the choices have got worse (and his box-office commensurately bigger).

Particularly after Highlander in 1986 - where he waved a sword around with much mystical verve - the older Connery seemed to have lucked into a new iconicity: the Celtic Patriarch. Connery can be an Irish cop in The Untouchables, an Oxford archeologist in Indiana Jones, a Russian submarine captain in The Hunt for Red October, a tweedy academic in The Russia House, a vigilante cop in Rising Sun, a Harvard lawyer in Just Cause - or (wait for it) a crinkly diamond thief in last year's Entrapment.

But the context rarely matters these days: the performance is always the same. Connery makes his cash from peddling a kind of mid-century incorrigibility, a source-code maleness. As an off-the-shelf star property, Sean still seems to solve a lot of problems for a lot of people.

Directors looking for some anchor to their dodgy scripts; movie fans who've surfed their satellite channels and have a taste for some living memories; weary men and women who want a brief respite from the never-ending story of sexual redefinition. And when Sean pulls on that white spiky toupée he's worn for the last few action movies, trims up the beard and straps in the gut, you have to admit that he looks like a citizen with some seniority about him. But the presence of Connery on our screens has now become a bore, an automatic reflex among casting directors that they really should begin to resist. Connery is an unreconstructed male icon, at a time when the new constructions are getting more complex, and more interesting, by the day.

Run through the members of the New Adonii - Jude Law, Leonardo DiCaprio, Ralph Fiennes, Brad Pitt, Matt Damon - and you have probably the most beautiful, sparkling, febrile clutch of male stars in screen history. It's a demand-driven thing. The modern female consumer mostly wants her male icon as a toy, not a rock. In a genderquake, rocks tend to split and crumble, or even explode dangerously. Toys you can stick in your pocket, easily replaced when they get damaged, or begin to dissatisfy.

Even George Clooney - who's positioned somewhat higher up the machismo graph than this bunch - has an essentially non-threatening core to him. You can cake him in Iraqi dust, duet him with Quentin Tarantino, or cast him as Frank Sinatra in the Rat Pack: but he will always be the guy who was great with the terminally ill kids in ER .

Connery's deepest connotations are, like it or not, the cold and steely sexisms of the Bond films. Watch them again, as this new century picks up speed, and you'll want to push the cultural accelerator to the floor (unless, that is, you're still a fully paid-up Loaded lad). Did men really loathe women so much then? Has there even been a more humped-and-dumped, silenced-and-ignored, slapped-and-strangled sequence of screen females than the Bond girls?

It would be wrong to say that the kind of anti-modern masculinity Connery represents has no market any more. There's a lot of anxious dreaming out there, especially among the male info-class - enough for Hollywood to dig down deep into its bag for some of its oldest tricks. For example, Russell Crowe has everything necessary to assume full Conneryhood. The brick-shithouse physical presence. The roughneck post-colonial identity (Scotland or Australia: pick your global backwater). The biographical hints of bad temper and real violence: brawling outside hometown bars, intimidating wussy co-stars on set.

And it's impossible to watch Gladiator without imagining the young, ex-body builder Connery slicing his way through all those corpses. But like those not-quite-real crowds in that not-quite-real coliseum, fighting those not-too-convincing lions and tigers, there's something not-at-all-believable about this vision of masculinity - heroically violent, passionately patriarchal - making any kind of a comeback.

This is gender tourism, for women as well as men: a virtual-reality experience, where it all seems charged and powerful - until you take the Roman helmet off. You could almost call the experience, with a small c, a kind of connery. Take it as a new word - referring to a fake and bogus machismo, a compensatory sexist pleasure, for modern people too wise and weathered to take it seriously. And delivered with a dark, testosteronal growl that, to these faintly regretful ears, just isn't needed any more. Goodbye, Sir Sean (enjoy the gong). But we're shaken and stirred no more.

 Finding Forrester, directed by Gus Van Sant, is out next year

When the idea of the 'crisis of men' is one of the biggest cultural themes in the developed West (from Fight Club to American Psycho ), how do we assess a movie icon who stands, like no other, for 'real' manhood - with all the dangers that implies? In short, at the beginning of a hopeful new century, is it time to release ourselves from the sulphurous spell of his Bond-age, and say: Connery no more? He'll have to be forced, because he doesn't seem to be willing to give up on his own account. With three movies currently in development or being completed (Gus Van Sant's Finding Forrester , a spy thriller called End Game , and a remake of Graham Greene's The Quiet American ), retirement seems to be the last thing on his mind. But we don't need to wait for any more evidence of the desuetude of Connery's art. All we need to do is to look at his successors. With them we can see how things can progress - from a man who thinks 'there are women who take it to the wire', that look for 'the ultimate confrontation', to men who confront their own maleness, as much as their women. Modern action heroes such as Nicolas Cage or Tom Cruise cruelly show up Connery's limitations. Connery has always does the masterful official well - spies, kings, dragons, wizards, grizzled elder cops. In this he links back to the classic era of Gable and Wayne, Tracey and Bogart. These were straight-up, authoritative guys, efficiently doing some 'tricks' for the camera - same accent, same face, every time. Acting was something done in between improving the golf handicap, and hobnobbing with power élites. But Connery shows few signs of the troubled male self-questioning that makes contemporary stars like Cage or Cruise so compelling, no matter their genre. When Cage unravels himself in Leaving Las Vegas, or Cruise howls his impotence in Born on the Fourth of July , you see actors fully aware of how complex screen manhood must be these days, to be even remotely credible. Their 'action-and-adventure' movies always bear the trace memory of these experiments - their utter 'inaction', the weakness of their wills. Who can look at Cruise's implacable face in Mission Impossible 2, without recalling his recent psychological extremes: the sleazoid sex instructor in Magnolia, or the doomed doctor in Eyes Wide Shut? Connery has always moaned about how he 'wanted to kill that Bond', shrug off the bullet-proof tuxedo and show the full range of his talents. But his choice of films belie him. Apart from a few forays into art-moviedom in the Sixties and Seventies (his sex-offending policeman in 1972's The Offence being the most notable success), and his celibate monk in 1986's The Name of the Rose, Connery has always crunched straight down the gravel-path of unambiguous masculinity. And in his later years, rather like his old drinking buddy Michael Caine, the choices have got worse (and his box-office commensurately bigger). Particularly after Highlander in 1986 - where he waved a sword around with much mystical verve - the older Connery seemed to have lucked into a new iconicity: the Celtic Patriarch. Connery can be an Irish cop in The Untouchables, an Oxford archeologist in Indiana Jones, a Russian submarine captain in The Hunt for Red October, a tweedy academic in The Russia House, a vigilante cop in Rising Sun, a Harvard lawyer in Just Cause - or (wait for it) a crinkly diamond thief in last year's Entrapment. But the context rarely matters these days: the performance is always the same. Connery makes his cash from peddling a kind of mid-century incorrigibility, a source-code maleness. As an off-the-shelf star property, Sean still seems to solve a lot of problems for a lot of people. Directors looking for some anchor to their dodgy scripts; movie fans who've surfed their satellite channels and have a taste for some living memories; weary men and women who want a brief respite from the never-ending story of sexual redefinition. And when Sean pulls on that white spiky toupée he's worn for the last few action movies, trims up the beard and straps in the gut, you have to admit that he looks like a citizen with some seniority about him. But the presence of Connery on our screens has now become a bore, an automatic reflex among casting directors that they really should begin to resist. Connery is an unreconstructed male icon, at a time when the new constructions are getting more complex, and more interesting, by the day. Run through the members of the New Adonii - Jude Law, Leonardo DiCaprio, Ralph Fiennes, Brad Pitt, Matt Damon - and you have probably the most beautiful, sparkling, febrile clutch of male stars in screen history. It's a demand-driven thing. The modern female consumer mostly wants her male icon as a toy, not a rock. In a genderquake, rocks tend to split and crumble, or even explode dangerously. Toys you can stick in your pocket, easily replaced when they get damaged, or begin to dissatisfy. Even George Clooney - who's positioned somewhat higher up the machismo graph than this bunch - has an essentially non-threatening core to him. You can cake him in Iraqi dust, duet him with Quentin Tarantino, or cast him as Frank Sinatra in the Rat Pack: but he will always be the guy who was great with the terminally ill kids in ER . Connery's deepest connotations are, like it or not, the cold and steely sexisms of the Bond films. Watch them again, as this new century picks up speed, and you'll want to push the cultural accelerator to the floor (unless, that is, you're still a fully paid-up Loaded lad). Did men really loathe women so much then? Has there even been a more humped-and-dumped, silenced-and-ignored, slapped-and-strangled sequence of screen females than the Bond girls? It would be wrong to say that the kind of anti-modern masculinity Connery represents has no market any more. There's a lot of anxious dreaming out there, especially among the male info-class - enough for Hollywood to dig down deep into its bag for some of its oldest tricks. For example, Russell Crowe has everything necessary to assume full Conneryhood. The brick-shithouse physical presence. The roughneck post-colonial identity (Scotland or Australia: pick your global backwater). The biographical hints of bad temper and real violence: brawling outside hometown bars, intimidating wussy co-stars on set. And it's impossible to watch Gladiator without imagining the young, ex-body builder Connery slicing his way through all those corpses. But like those not-quite-real crowds in that not-quite-real coliseum, fighting those not-too-convincing lions and tigers, there's something not-at-all-believable about this vision of masculinity - heroically violent, passionately patriarchal - making any kind of a comeback. This is gender tourism, for women as well as men: a virtual-reality experience, where it all seems charged and powerful - until you take the Roman helmet off. You could almost call the experience, with a small c, a kind of connery. Take it as a new word - referring to a fake and bogus machismo, a compensatory sexist pleasure, for modern people too wise and weathered to take it seriously. And delivered with a dark, testosteronal growl that, to these faintly regretful ears, just isn't needed any more. Goodbye, Sir Sean (enjoy the gong). But we're shaken and stirred no more.  Finding Forrester, directed by Gus Van Sant, is out next year

webTitle: Can it still be just a  black thing?

fields.headline: Can it still be just a  black thing?
fields.standfirst: The original  Shaft was aimed very specifically at a black American audience. But its new remake is a 'crossover' summer movie - a healthy sign of the times, argues  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: The original Shaft was aimed very specifically at a black American audience. But its new remake is a 'crossover' summer movie - a healthy sign of the times, argues Mark Morris
fields.body:
There's no real mystery to why there's a new film around called Shaft. The chance to use Isaac Hayes's immortal theme tune would be temptation enough.

The whole blaxploitation genre has had a vigorous afterlife: parodied in I'm Gonna Git You Sucka, sampled and referenced in hundreds of hip hop records and videos, and copiously paid tribute to by Quentin Tarantino. And what actor is going to turn down playing a character who we all know is a 'sex machine with all the chicks'?

But the original Shaft was the product of a very particular moment in American history, and had a social significance that far outweighed its importance in strictly cinematic terms. The new film, starring Samuel L. Jackson, has survived a troubled genesis to rise to the top of the US box-office charts. But the 2000 version of Shaft has a different meaning - and possibly a very different type of audience - from the original.

Shaft came out in 1971, a particularly turbulent time in black American history. The civil rights movement had given black Americans equal legal status at last, which in time would lead to mainstream political representation, a growing middle class and a substantial media presence. However, civil rights had failed to end racism, the Black Panthers were in bloody decline, the decay of the traditional manufacturing base - which hit black Americans hardest - had begun, and there was a heroin crisis in the inner cities.

In that context, films like Shaft meant more than their basic crime narratives would suggest. Blaxploitation movies were born of the same rage that fuelled the civil rights movement, born of a wish to shake things up.

Shaft wasn't the first film in this upsurge. According to how you define it, that was either Ossie Davis's Cotton Comes To Harlem or Melvin Van Peebles's Sweet Sweetback's Badasssss Song (both 1970). And it's not the most typical: as blaxploitation films go, it's on the respectable side. John Shaft is a fairly traditional private detective, unlike the pusher and pimp anti-heroes of Superfly or The Mack. And while many of the later films were made by veteran white exploitation hacks, Shaft was directed by the distinguished photographer/writer/musician Gordon Parks (not to be confused with his son, Superfly 's Gordon Parks Jr).

But Shaft was the most successful blaxploitation movie. It had Isaac Hayes's great soundtrack, which won an Oscar for the theme song. It had a whole array of white bad guys, from mobsters to corrupt cops. And it had Richard Roundtree as Shaft, looking impeccably sharp with his Afro and long, leather coat. In his book Hip Hop America , Nelson George ascribes the enduring appeal of blaxploitation films to their depiction of 'aggressive black heroism'. That's all there in the opening sequence to Shaft , as Roundtree strides fearlessly through the Manhattan traffic, raising his middle finger to a cabbie who dares question his right to the roads.

George writes: 'Never in the history of American cinema had there been so many aggressive, I-don't-give-a-damn black folks on screen. That is so crucial. Blaxploitation movies reserved little space for the singing of Negro spirituals, turning the other cheek, or chaste kisses. In fact, characters who possessed these qualities were often the brunt of much-appreciated derision. In blax ploitation, black people shoot back with big guns, strut to bold jams, and have sweaty, bed-rocking sex. Whatever story the often loopy plots hold, they are usually secondary to full-bodied action.'

Before then, blacks had a sketchy presence in mainstream movies, making do with whatever roles were on offer to Harry Belafonte, Sammy Davis Jr and Sidney Poitier. And although Poitier made some fine films and many courageous stands, his appearance in the absurd Guess Who's Coming To Dinner in 1967 made him look like a man out of time, cinema's Uncle Tom. After Malcolm X and Muhammad Ali, the mood was ripe for something different.

The blaxploitation tornado had blown itself out by about 1976. There were two lousy Shaft sequels and a TV series. But blaxploitation has never drifted into the cultural wilderness, not least because, however vari able the films were, the music - by the likes of James Brown, Curtis Mayfield and Bobby Womack - was usually unbeatable.

Director John Singleton grew up in the hip hop era. His first and by far best film - Boyz N The Hood - took its name from an Eazy E track. He's always used rappers in the cast: Busta Rhymes is in Shaft. But his obsession with Shaft predates even that: he claims he first saw it when he was three.

In the mid-Nineties he came up with the idea of doing a film about Shaft's son. He wanted to do it on a low budget, with the energy and sexual brazenness of a hip hop video, and wanted Don Cheadle to star. But MGM, who owned the Shaft franchise, didn't like the idea. So although Singleton directed the new Shaft, it's a long way from his initial vision. Notorious producer Scott Rudin deemed the excellent Cheadle not famous enough: Jackson was brought in. Since the 51-year-old Jackson is only six years younger than Roundtree, he became Shaft's nephew rather than his son.

The whole film became much more expensive. Along the way it lost the pulpiness and sexiness that Singleton had wanted: the result is a competent modern action movie with none of the retro gestures of Pulp Fiction and a lack of bedroom action that left Jackson feeling short-changed. Its cop turned vigilante storyline has its roots less in the first Shaft and more in Dirty Harry.

There are endless stories of trouble on set: Singleton fighting with Jackson, Singleton spending too much time in his trailer with extras and both Singleton and Jackson arguing with Rudin and uniting in contempt for writer Richard Price, a fine novelist who has done plenty of screenwriting ( Sea Of Love, Ransom ). At a press conference Jackson referred to Price as 'that white man'. Even so, Price supplied the obligatory rich white bad guy (Christian Bale) and corrupt white cops, as well as one sympathetic white woman (Toni Collette).

The first Shaft had one intended audience: hip young black men. The new film has at least three potential audiences. The first are people who just want to see an action movie: these are the people Rudin thinks have heard of Jackson but not Cheadle. The second are the sons of the guys who were so inspired by the first Shaft : they should be pleased to see that for once Jackson doesn't have to share the limelight with John Travolta or Geena Davis or Kevin Spacey. And the third, possibly most important, group are the white suburban teenagers who in their millions buy hardcore hip hop records by the likes of Wu Tang Clan and Dr Dre. If there is one thing the music business learnt during the Nineties, it was that you didn't have to tone down hip hop for it to cross over.

But this special kind of crossover only works if the kids don't think the records or clothes are aimed at them. They want the real thing, the thing that's big in the South Bronx or Atlanta. And that's the awkward position that Shaft occupies: it is a big summer movie, but it can't be too much like any big summer movie. Jackson's shaved head gleams from the cover of both Entertainment Weekly and Rap Pages . So far, that tightrope walk seems to have worked. But however much money it takes, Singleton's film won't mean as much as Parks's did. The world has changed.

Also bobbling about the US box-office chart right now is Big Momma's House , a massively unsubtle comedy starring Martin Lawrence. And coming up soon here are the relationship comedy dramas The Best Man and Love And Basketball . What's interesting about those two is that they are middle-class black movies and have no appeal to white kids with ghetto fantasies. Then there are plenty of crude comedies starring rappers, and black crime films like Hype Williams's sporadically brilliant Belly . Which is to say that Roundtree stepped into a near vacuum, offering something never seen before. Whereas the new Shaft exists in a world where the idea of 'black movies' as a genre is - finally - becoming redundant.

Changing times: 30 years of black cinema

1970: The release of Cotton Comes to Harlem and Sweet Sweetback's Badasssss Song herald the start of the blaxploitation genre.

1971: Shaft is first big-budget blaxploitation film. Isaac Hayes wins Oscar for the music. Shaft's Big Score and Shaft in Africa follow.

1972: Two of America's biggest pop stars provide the soundtracks to Trouble Man (Marvin Gaye) and Superfly (Curtis Mayfield).

1973-74: Pam Grier becomes Blaxploitation's First Lady, starring in Coffy and Foxy Brown.

1976: Blaxploitation genre fades. But ensemble comedy Car Wash attracts black moviegoers.

1982: Eddie Murphy explodes on to the scene in 48 Hours and becomes one of the Eighties' biggest stars.

1986: Spike Lee releases his first film, She's Gotta Have It, emerging as figurehead for African-American cinema.

1989: Denzel Washington wins Oscar for his role in Glory. Do the Right Thing sparks debate with its look at New York racial tensions.

1990: Whoopi Goldberg wins Oscar for Ghost.

1991: Boyz N the Hood inspires a host of gritty films depicting the black urban experience.

1992: The release of Malcolm X.

1994: Hoop Dream, about aspiring basketball players, is a critical hit.

1995: Success of Waiting to Exhale shows there is a large audience for middle-class 'female flicks'.

1997: Jackie Brown is a homage to blaxploitation.

2000: Singleton updates Shaft.

 The original Shaft is rereleased 21 July. The new version will be released in November. www.blaxploitation.com

fields.headline: They'll be back
fields.standfirst: Action men like Arnie don't know when to say no
fields.trailText: Action men like Arnie don't know when to say no.
fields.body:
In 1985 Roger Moore strolled through A View to a Kill in his golf casuals and tailored finery. It was his last outing as Bond and, frankly, he looked a bit of a state; too old for the girls and the cross-continental heroics. Worse, his eyebrows had lost their raffish wiggle. Time to hang up the Walther PPK and head off to those lucrative mini-series.

But what is an ageing action man to do once the wrinkles start to match the number of notches on his holster? Just keep going on if you're Arnold Schwarzenegger and Harrison Ford. The Terminator is back and Indiana Jones is coming too.

Schwarzenegger has agreed to reprise his role in Terminator 3 next year, while writer-director M. Night Shyamalan ( The Sixth Sense ) is about to make a deal with the holy trinity of George Lucas, Steven Spielberg and Harrison Ford.

Despite his recently dodgy ticker and advancing years, Schwarzenegger can't resist a return to his defining role. His movies of late have failed to find a large enough audience to justify his rumoured $15 million fee. Although he seemed reluctant to do it again without director James Cameron, that's exactly what is going to happen now his favourite collaborator has demurred.

Similarly, Ford's attempts to be a romantic hero in Six Days, Seven Nights and Random Hearts flopped, so it's back to basics. In the last instalment in 1989 Sean Connery, only a decade older than Ford, played his dad. Now the pair would look more like bridge buddies than father and son.

The big question remains whether the wry cyborg and the whip-cracking archaeologist can be a genuine box-office draw. Can these creaking franchises still pack a punch? The omens look good. The Phantom Menace was a mess, but two decades of anticipation and a few months of rabid hype created a massive audience.

At an age when most stars would rather be out practising their swing, Arnie and Harrison want to swap shooting birdies for bad guys. Let's hope their aim is still true.

webTitle: Amazon drop marks a dotcom watershed

fields.headline: Amazon drop marks a dotcom watershed
fields.standfirst: A slump in the value of the giant online bookseller on feverish Wall Street trading is the latest sign that the internet bubble has burst
fields.trailText: First, lastminute.com saw millions wiped off its share value. Then, boo.com flopped. Now the great e-slump has hit the biggest net name on the planet - Amazon.
fields.body:
First, lastminute.com saw millions wiped off its share value. Then, boo.com flopped. Now the great e-slump has hit the biggest net name on the planet - Amazon.

The crash, late on Friday, sent a chill through the internet chatrooms yesterday. Anxious cyber-investors, who have become rich quick backing the internet bubble, logged on and asked each other one question: how much worse will it get?

Amazon, the online bookseller which started life in a Washington garage in 1994, became the internet's most visible star worth $30 billion (£19bn). After Friday's feverish Wall Street trading it is worth barely half that.

Its crash comes in the wake of a number of high-profile dotcom failures. The sector, which spawned waves of charismatic young entrepreneurs, is now eating its young alive.

On Friday Amazon's share price plunged by 20 per cent as analysts took a closer look at the company's finances. Ravi Suria, a bond analyst with the Wall Street firm Lehman Brothers, issued a damning report which said: 'Amazon must be able to generate the cash-operating profile of a successful retailer. It is essentially this yardstick that we use to analyse the company, and as the rest of this report shows, we find it woefully lacking.'

Suria concluded that the company's weak balance sheet showed the 'financial characteristics that have driven innumerable retailers to disaster throughout history'.

Investors were quick to draw their own conclusions. Wall Street's most powerful analyst, Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, a champion of Amazon's stock last month, forecasted that the company's prospects now held 'little upside' over the coming months. Meeker said that the fourth quarter of this year would determine whether Amazon was a 'survivor' - hardly the description usually attached to a company whose share value was double that of British Airways.

The influential internet investment team at Goldman Sachs has also expressed concern that the company will find the crucial months in the run up to Christmas difficult.

Even Jeff Bezos, who founded the company and owns nearly 40 per cent of it, may have gone a little cold. He recently sold nearly 400,000 Amazon shares to buy a $7.5m (£4.7m) apartment.

Amazon's financial foundations look precarious. The company has raised more than $2.1bn (£1.3bn) in convertible junk bonds through five separate placings. These pay little in the way of interest but, because they allow their holders to convert them into shares, they can prove attractive if the company's prospects look good.

But Amazon, which last year made losses of $700m, has been running a 'burn rate' of more than $100m a month. Analysts now fear Amazon will run out of money.

And, as its share price crashes, Amazon's ability to issue more convertible bonds is undermined, threatening its ability to bankroll its expansion plans.

Amazon argues that much of the money it has raised through bond issues has been spent building the business's distribution network and will thus produce returns in the long run. But a recent investigation by the influential New York Observer newspaper concluded that barely half a billion dollars has been spent on investing in the company's distribution network.

The rest of the cash raised has been spent simply on mopping up the company's cumulative losses - some $1.2bn since Amazon launched. As of March this year Amazon had just $84m in cash, a 30 per cent drop on the amount it had three months earlier. The New York Observer said the company's finances as 'simply appalling'.

Analysts have had their fingers burnt by other recent dotcom disasters on both sides of the Atlantic. They look with horror at online music retailer CDNow.

The US and London-based firm which has a similar business model to Amazon, was worth more than $2bn two years ago. The company is worth less than $100m now and needs a buyer.

Since its launch in 1994 the company has lost more than $200m (£125m). Last Thursday CDNow's founder, Jason Olin, 31, closed the company's large London office.

Similarly eToys, which was worth £8bn two years ago, is now worth just $8bn. Reel.com, the online video retailer, closed down earlier this month with the loss of 200 jobs and Petstore.com had to shut down and sell off its assets to a fellow retailer.

The slump is so bad that investment house Barron's has started to compile a death row of e-commerce firms. Joining CDNow on the critical list are nine other high profile US start ups.

Among Britain's home-grown start-ups the highly public demise of online sportswear retailer boo reinforces the argument that e-tailing is not a quick route to cash. Formed by two Swedes, Ernst Malmsten and ex-Vogue model Kajsa Leander, boo managed to spend $135m in under a year. After it crashed, the technology used to run boo's site was sold off for just £250,000.

This weekend investors must be trying to weigh up whether Amazon - and ultimately all other e-commerce start ups - will go the same way. Certainly Wall Street and the City have turned against them.

As the manager of one US broking firm commented when asked if he would invest in the e-commerce sector . 'We have a word for these companies. We call them radioactive.'

The internet's best (and worst) sellers

BOOKS AND MUSIC
Both sell well on the net. Amazon, for instance has 20 million customers. The problem is, margins are low meaning online retailers have to sell huge volumes if they are to stay in business. And as less than 5 per cent of visitors to Amazon's site buy anything this is a major concern.

CLOTHING
Mounting evidence shows that consumers will always want to touch and try on clothing before buying. Somewhat difficult in cyberspace.

TICKETS
The likes of Easyjet now sell nearly half of their tickets over the internet and offer discounts for those who buy online rather than over the phone.

PROPERTY
Will Smith might have bought his Malibu condo over the net without ever having seen it but this is the exception not the norm. No UK estate agent currently sells homes online, although some are thinking about it.

FINANCIAL PRODUCTS
The huge success of online banks like the Prudential's egg suggest that one day taking out pensions and mortgages and buying stocks and shares will all be done online. Certainly the banks are trying to migrate us online with competitive interest rates and promotional offers such as free WAP phones.

WINE
Nearly a third of people interviewed in a survey for Virgin Wines said they would buy wine over the net.

fields.headline: Pens sharpened for political duel
fields.trailText: It will be an extraordinary publishing war. A series of huge book deals signed by some of Britain's key political players are set to shed light on the murkiest areas of the body politic.
fields.body:
It will be an extraordinary publishing war. A series of huge book deals signed by some of Britain's key political players are set to shed light on the murkiest areas of the body politic.

The six books are all due on the shelves for the key 'politics window', the months of September and October, when politics sparks back into life with the party conference season.

Publishers are jostling for position as they try to make their book the 'must' read of the autumn. But the Government is likely to find itself with the most sweat on its brow. Two books, Andrew Rawnsley's dissection of the New Labour project and Julia Langdon's biography of the former Northern Ireland Secretary, Mo Mowlam, will reopen old wounds.

Rawnsley, an Observer columnist, is expected to reveal the tensions between Tony Blair, Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson. With Brown and Mandelson set to run the next general election campaign, any divisions between them will be pored over with a magnifying glass.

Although the Mowlam biography is unauthorised, her political confidants are thought to have co-operated with the book. As the most popular member of the Cabinet, any sense that she has been shabbily treated will play badly with Labour supporters.

The book will deal with her sacking as Northern Ireland Secretary, her fraught relationship with a number of Ministers and officials and her illness.

Blair will also be uneasy about publication of the diaries of Paddy Ashdown. with whom he often discussed members of the Government he disliked.

Traditional members of the Labour Party will be heartened by the publication of two books extolling the virtues of John Smith, the former Labour leader.

Many friends of Smith, who died of a heart attack in 1994, complain that the New Labour project has airbrushed him out of the party's history. A collection of Smith's speeches with a foreword by the Scottish First Minister, Donald Dewar, will be followed by a biography by the academic Kevin Jeffery.

Baroness Smith, the former Labour leader's widow, is likely to be involved in promoting the first book. She has provided pictures for the book and will discuss with Dewar the tone of his preface. Many believe she is disappointed with the way her husband's record has been ignored by some in the party.

William Hague is also set to have a few sleepless nights. Michael Heseltine's autobiography, Life in the Jungle, will reignite debate over splits in the Conservative Party.

Published by Hodder and co-written with the columnist Anthony Howard, the book is expected to damn Hague with the faintest of praise while holding up Michael Portillo, the man many consider to be the Tory leader in waiting, as a political colossus.

Heseltine will also raise uncomfortable memories of Margaret Thatcher's autocratic style and go into detail about his clashes with Norman Tebbit.

A barrage of bombshell books

Michael Heseltine

Famous for A mane of hair that is not what it was; storming out of Cabinet over Westland.
The book: Life in the Jungle
Publication date: September
Publisher: Hodder
Be seen with it if... You have fond memories of those Conservative days of fighting like ferrets in a sack.
Explosive potential Former lion of the Commons gives his views on Margaret Thatcher (bad), Norman Tebbitt (bad), William Hague (mediocre), Michael Portillo (good). Hezza is an arch media operator, if anyone can make a noise about this, he can. Controversy rating: ***

Andrew Rawnsley

Famous forThe 'psychologically flawed' scoop. Someone high-up in government said it of Gordon Brown. Everyone thinks it was Alastair Campbell. The Observer's Rawnsley has kept his counsel on the issue.
The book: Servants of the People: the Inside Story of New Labour
Publication date: September
Publisher: Hamish Hamilton
Be seen with it if... The 'disagreements, what disagreements?' line never washed with you either.
Explosive potential If you thought the Brown/Mandelson feud was over, think again. And then there's Tony Blair: the book will arrive at conference time and lips are being licked in anticipation.
Controversy rating: ****

John Smith

Famous for Having his political destiny snatched away from him
The book: Guiding Light
Publication date: September
Publisher: Politicos
Be seen with it if... You want to remind New Labour types that there are still those with fond memories of Smith.
Explosive potential Although the words are not new, an introduction by Donald Dewar, who was close to Smith, will work against those who have tried to airbrush Smith out of Labour's history. Controversy rating: **

Mo Mowlam

Famous for Darling of Labour grass roots, conqueror of brain tumour, Northern Ireland Secretary who braved the Maze prison to talk to terrorists.
The book: Mo Mowlam, the biography
Author: Political journalist Julia Langdon.
Publication date: October
Publisher: Little Brown
Be seen with it if... You want to remind Blair just how popular Mowlam is.
Explosive potential How she was forced back to the mainland into a job she didn't want, and frozen out of the inner circle. Langdon has also delved uncovered an early boyfriend who drowned. Mowlam's friends have talked freely
Controversy rating: ***

Paddy Ashdown

Famous for The former Marine who never quite fought his way into Cabinet, architect of the Lib-Lab love-in, cruelly dubbed Paddy Pantsdown by the Sun after affair with secretary.
The book: The Ashdown Diaries
Publication date: November
Publisher: Penguin Press
Be seen with it if... You're an ex-Cabinet Minister who wants to know why you were really dumped.
Explosive potential How Blair offered two Lib Dems seats at the Cabinet in 1997 and was prepared to push out two Labour Ministers to make room, only for the deal to collapse amid threats of a mutiny. Judicious leaks have muffled the explosion.
Controversy rating: **

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: An unorthodox journey along a line of longitude reveals an unexpected side of England plus The Book of Revelation, Home Truths, History in Our Time and On Bullfighting
fields.body:
Two Degrees West
Nicholas Crane
Penguin £6.99, pp365
Buy it at BOL

In the autumn of 1997, Nicholas Crane walked the length of England down the only line of longitude marked on the maps of the Ordnance Survey, a distance of 577.96 kilometres (the decimal precision is characteristic).

Crane sticks to his line as assiduously as a lemming, trespassing on private land and even bivouacking beneath the M62 when necessary. Following such a strict route is deeply counter-intuitive, especially as it constantly seems to pass within a whisker of various interesting but unvisitable sights. But on the whole the idea works: both as a peculiar kind of corrective to the meaningful walks of writers such as Iain Sinclair, and as a revealing guide to an England that is largely absent from more orthodox journeys.

The Book of Revelation
Rupert Thomson
Bloomsbury £6.99 pp264
Buy it at BOL

On a clear spring day in Amsterdam, a dancer goes out to buy his girlfriend a packet of cigarettes. As he walks down the street, some passers-by engage him in seemingly anodyne conversation. Until one of them sticks him in the hand with a hypodermic needle.

When he wakes up, he is chained to the floor in a bare white room, beginning an ordeal of sexual violence at the hands of three masked women that is to last for 18 days.

Thomson's coolly detached prose prevents his story from falling into the obvious trap of high-class pornography. But that same coolness is also responsible for a rather chilly aestheticism that prevents this novel from ever becoming truly engaging.

Home Truths
David Lodge
Penguin £5.99, pp 142
Buy it at BOL

This novella actually started life as a play of the same name. At its heart is an investigation of the cult of the celebrity interview, and the novella's four characters do rather feel as though they were called into existence solely for the purpose of interrogating this theme. David Lodge says in his afterword that the business of converting play to prose fiction is a 'rather unusual literary project'; I'm not sure that here it has quite worked.

Without living actors to breathe the dialogue into life - you can picture an actress having a particularly good time with the venomous Burchillian interviewer - Home Truths tends towards the flat promise of a script rather than the fully realised complexity of a three-dimensional fictional world.

History in Our Time
David Cannadine
Penguin £8.99, pp313
Buy it at BOL

As the intrepid Nicholas Crane shrugs off his sodden rucksack in a bar in Ayrsgarth he discovers from a television that Princess Diana is dead. This same moment triggers the dramatic climax of Lodge's novella. And it's an equally dramatic moment - admittedly most of her moments are - for the Diana-worshipping Bridget Jones. On the evidence of this week's paperback round-up, then, the centrality of the princess to our culture today is little in dispute.

Unsurprising, perhaps, that the jacket of Cannadine's book pictures the sea of floral tributes piled up outside Kensington Palace. He is an excellent guide to the Diana phenomenon in its historical context, and this sharply intelligent collection of essays finds room, happily, for many other twentieth-century figures as well.

 Sophie Harrison

On Bullfighting
AL Kennedy
Yellow Jersey Press £5.99, pp180
Buy it at BOL

This slim volume boasts possibly the most unexpected opening chapter of any sports book: novelist Alison Kennedy's frank account of her aborted suicide attempt.

Though a novice to the subject of bullfighting when commissioned to write this book, Kennedy recognises it as the courting of death dressed up in ritual - death being a subject she had thought about a great deal during the period of depression and writer's block that preceded her decision to throw herself out of a fourth-floor window. Saved by a farcical intervention of fate, she sets off instead to Spain to learn the art and vocabulary of the corrida, more theatre than sport, and to meet with people who face death every day for a living.

Kennedy's familiar dry wit and striking prose make the subject entirely her own, and her observations are fresh because they are partly informed by the personal sorrow she lugs around Spain with her.

 Jane Perry
