For Bukowski, the self is a hole you dig in order to rage against the darkness. Ham on Rye (Bukowski's most painful book) is about digging such a hole.

fields.headline: Murder most torrid
fields.standfirst: The latest from the husband and wife team Nicci French, Beneath the Skin, is a study in claustrophobia
fields.trailText: The latest from the husband and wife team Nicci French, Beneath the Skin, is a study in claustrophobia
fields.body:
Beneath the Skin
Nicci French
Michael Joseph £9.99, pp360
Buy it at BOL

The term 'psychological thriller' has lost much of its meaning in recent years as the serial killer sub-genre with which it is most associated has virtually taken over mystery fiction. Given that any halfway decent writer is going to explore motivation and the psychology of her/his characters, almost any mystery novel can be described in this way. But Beneath The Skin, the fourth collaboration of the husband and wife writing team Nicci Gerrard (of The Observer) and Sean French is very precisely a psychological thriller in that it focuses on the psychological effects on three women - Zoe, Jenny, Nadia - of death threats they receive from someone who is watching their every move.

Their stalker is a man whose pleasure is not so much in the killing but in seeing their fear at the thought of impending death and the way it makes them unravel. The novel is almost a study in claustrophobia. The setting is the suffocating heat of a north London summer and the book is written as three first-person accounts by the women of how their lives narrow down in the face of this disabling threat while the police seem able to do little more than look on.

The novel starts slowly but the tension quickly builds. And builds - even after the authors spring a surprise and reveal who the killer is halfway through. The double twist at the end isn't totally satisfying but this is a novel where the characters are what you remember most.

The first-person narratives, which force the reader closer to the terror the women are feeling, are brilliantly handled. Each women has a distinctive voice. Zoe is a 23-year-old teacher, self-sufficient with a small circle of friends trying to sell her horrible flat on the Holloway Road. Jenny, older, is unhappily married, middle-class, rich and lonely. At first she seems almost a caricature but as her narrative progresses she becomes the most complex of the women. Nadia, a children's entertainer, is a character for whom that overused word 'feisty' should be minted afresh.

It's a curious irony that while over the past decade detective fiction, with its increasing number of strong female protagonists, has empowered women, at the same time serial killer novels have made them victims, usually of truly terrible, graphically described violence. So what's refreshing about Beneath The Skin is that while these are women in peril, at least one of them is going to take her destiny back into her own hands.

webTitle: Blair puts faith in radical priest's ethical politics

fields.headline: Blair puts faith in radical priest's ethical politics
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will hold private talks with one of Europe's most controversial religious figures as part of his effort to put an 'ethical heart' at the centre of politics in Britain.
fields.byline: by Denis Staunton Berlin and Kamal Ahmed
fields.body:
Tony Blair will hold private talks with one of Europe's most controversial religious figures as part of his effort to put an 'ethical heart' at the centre of politics in Britain.

The Prime Minister has agreed to speak on Friday at a conference in Germany organised by Hans Küng, a Swiss theologian, who has radical views on the way communities and religion can work together. He will also have a private meeting with Küng, who has impressed Blair with his call for a new type of ethically based politics.

The meeting will re-ignite the debate on the role of religion in British politics. Küng has called for a new ethical 10 commandments, arguing that people no longer have principles and that society is too fragmented. He says it is difficult to have an absolute ethical position without a religious underpinning.

The news that Blair is to attend and speak at such a high-profile religious event comes a week after William Hague faced criticism for inviting the American right-wing Christian thinker, Professor Marvin Olasky, to meet him to discuss 'compassionate conservatism'. Olasky is one of the Republican Party's closest advisers who has argued for an end to the welfare state, which he says should be replaced by the work of private charities. Although Blair insists he will not talk directly about religion, Downing Street sources said that the Prime Minister's beliefs are well known and that he has agreed to meet Küng to show his support for his work.

'The role of religion is absolutely essential to Tony,' a source said. 'His politics comes from his faith and it is very clear where he is coming from.' Blair will use his address to members of Küng's Global Ethics Foundation to restate his belief in Third Way politics - a mixture of traditional values and modern social programmes which he believes help people out of poverty and into work.

He is also likely to talk about the need for strong communities, the family and the Church, and his belief that rights should be bal anced by responsibilities. He has said in the past that he dislikes politicians who 'wear their religion on their sleeves', and it was made clear by Downing Street officials over the weekend that he would not be making a 'Christian speech'.

Blair first met Küng, author of the books Does God Exist? and Yes to a Global Ethic , last year.

Küng said: 'He knew me first by my books, especially my book On Being a Christian, and I met him in London.' Küng told The Observer : 'I was impressed by his serious commitment in the Northern Ireland peace process, which was only possible because he committed himself personally.

'Tony Blair, despite all the criticism he gets in Britain, takes this job very seriously and he wants to combine a realistic approach to political problems and nevertheless to observe certain ethical standards. He certainly has ethical convictions.'

Küng said that, although you could have an ethical outlook on life without being religious, it was far easier if you did have a faith.

Küng, a Catholic priest, who counts among his friends Helmut Schmidt, is one of the most challenging religious thinkers of his generation. He has clashed repeatedly with the Vatican over his progressive views on abortion and human sexuality.

webTitle: Lives ruined as NHS leaks patients' notes

fields.headline: Lives ruined as NHS leaks patients' notes
fields.trailText: Patients' lives are being ruined because of growing disregard for confidentiality. Medical records, detailing their most intimate and embarrassing secrets, are increasingly being passed around without their consent.
fields.body:
Patients' lives are being ruined because of growing disregard for confidentiality. Medical records, detailing their most intimate and embarrassing secrets, are increasingly being passed around without their consent.

Doctors warn that scandalous abuse of records is now routine in the NHS, with dozens of different people in health authorities, local councils, universities, drug companies and medical schools being given access to confidential data. Doctors fear that patients would stop confiding in their GPs if they knew how many people would see their medical secrets. The Royal College of General Practitioners is so alarmed it is set to issue a warning.

In an internal briefing seen by The Observer, the chair of the ethics committee, Dr Iona Heath, declared: 'From a position of having been the guardians of confidentiality, medicine has now fallen far behind the highest standards, and routine practice now fails to fulfil the basic principles of data protection. There has been no public debate, and the public, as both citizens and patients, are mostly ignorant of the degree to which information is passed around.'

Health authorities now get names and addresses of patients for every treatment GPs give - they have lists, for example, of all patients' contraception. Medical records are sent to researchers to compile disease registers, and widely distributed to groups outside the NHS groups who conduct financial or clinical audits. Lists of women who have had hysterectomies are routinely compiled as part of the checks on cervical cancer screening services.

Medical researchers, including pharmaceutical companies, are regularly given medical records, including names. Medical students often get the name and medical history - and even tissue samples - of living patients, without their consent or knowledge.

Rita Pal, a hospital doctor who set up the pressure group NHS Exposed, said: 'Medical notes are in essence your life - how many affairs you have, if you have an alcohol problem, do drugs, your sexual activity, your psychiatric state. They are all very personal issues. Yet patients have no control over their confidentiality.'

Marion Chester, legal officer at the Association of Community Health Councils, said: 'Identifiable health records are flying around inside and outside the NHS at a rate of knots. It's getting worse, because of the increase in financial and clinical audit, and the increasing use of information technology. The attitude to patient confidentiality is very lax in the NHS.'

An Observer investigation has discovered:

 A 68-year-old man was refused a place in a care home when social services found from his medical records that he was gay.

 An uncle found out that his niece had a secret abortion when the company he worked for was asked to do a financial audit of the local health authority. He told her parents, who are very religious.

 A woman was sacked after her GP sent her records to her employer. The notes revealed that she had a history of mental health problems.

 Patients with medical conditions have been approached by researchers who have had access to their records.

 The medical histories of everyone living in Oxford are used without their knowledge by Oxford University for research. Names are removed, but patient groups claim individuals are identifiable through post codes.

 An MP was sent the medical records of a constituent without her consent. She found out only when the MP passed on the records to her.

There is also alarm that a new NHS-wide computer system to store patient medical records will erode confidentiality further. Chester said: 'Anyone who has access to the computer system and knows someone's NHS number will be able to get medical records.'

fields.headline: Tax row engulfs Labour mogul
fields.standfirst: Records show Blair's millionaire fundraiser pays basic rate only
fields.trailText: Lord Levy, Labour's millionaire chief fundraiser, was last night embroiled in a major row over his tax affairs.
fields.byline: by Gaby Hinsliff and Antony Barnett
fields.body:
Lord Levy, Labour's millionaire chief fundraiser, was last night embroiled in a major row over his tax affairs.

The peer, a close friend of Tony Blair's and his personal envoy to the Middle East, last night angrily denied avoiding tax on his multi-million pound fortune. Despite his vast wealth, his tax returns for the year 1998-99 reveal he is a basic rate taxpayer who paid only £5,000 to the Inland Revenue that year.

Last night a spokesman for the ex-record company mogul admitted the figures 'look extremely odd' but insisted there was a logical explanation. In a statement Lord Levy denied he employed a 'highly sophisticated and effective tax avoidance strategy involving offshore holdings', adding he had only owed £5,000 because he was not earning that year.

'I devoted that period to political and voluntary activities, none of which produced any income for me. I was living off my own savings on which all tax owing had been paid. My tax affairs are and always have been entirely above board.'

Aides said he had sold his house for a smaller one and lived off the capital that year. Nevertheless the row is embarrassing for the Government, which pledged to crack down on tax avoidance only days ago at the Portugal summit. And it turns the spotlight back on the rich men who helped bankroll Labour just as the party is gearing up fundraising efforts for the next election.

Ever since Gordon Brown attacked tax avoidance the Government has been plagued by embarrassing disclosures, including the revelation of former Treasury Minister Geoffrey Robinson's offshore tax haven in the Channel Islands.

Levy has been a controversial figure since he began leading Labour's fundraising drive in 1996. He was the architect of the 'blind trust' method of funding the offices of key players such as Blair and Brown, set up so they could receive donations without knowing who their bene factors were. Levy's team raised more than £10 million in barely five years, a success that put him at the heart of the New Labour project.

Last night a Downing Street spokesman said: 'The Prime Minister has always had a high regard for Michael Levy and nothing that has ever been produced has led him to doubt that judgment.'

Charming, confident and well-connected, Levy would sometimes entertain potential donors to tennis at his expansive home in Totteridge, north London. Blair would drop in for a set or two, and after he had gone the request for a donation would discreetly follow.

Since the election Levy has split his time between fundraising, charity work, and an unpaid post which raised eyebrows in Whitehall, as the Prime Minister's envoy to the Middle East. Levy last night denied owning assets offshore, but admitted owning a house and a bank account in Israel, both of which he said were declared for UK tax purposes.

Born in the East End to a Jewish family of modest means, he made his fortune through setting up Magnet Records, which made the careers of Alvin Stardust and Chris Rea among others. He sold out in 1988, pocketing around £10m, but started a second business, M&G Records.

Suspicions over Levy's finances were first raised when The Observer revealed two years ago that he had links to a tax haven in Guernsey. Last night a spokesman said this was wound up at the end of 1997, without accruing any benefit to Levy.

Late on Friday night the peer sought an injunction against a Sunday newspaper to prevent details of his tax records becoming public, arguing the documents must have been illegally obtained. Judge Roger Toulson threw out the application.

webTitle: Big browser is watching the web

fields.headline: Big browser is watching the web
fields.standfirst: Is the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill a licence for state snooping?
fields.trailText: Is the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill a licence for state snooping?
fields.body:
Yes

Type a few words into a web search-engine and you can find information on any subject in seconds. What happens next depends what one is thinking about and one's reaction to that information. RIP's proponents say the internet is like a public space, and just as the police don't need a judge's warrant merely to keep any eye on someone in the street, they must be allowed to track any person's movements as they click from website to website.

As drafted, RIP gives the police and other government bodies authority to access a person's 'clickstream' - the virtual record of his or her train of thought; no formal investigation need be underway, no warrant is required. Last Monday the Government asked the House of Lords to believe that this was some kind of drafting mistake, but when pressed would not deny that their intention all along was for Big Browser to be Watching You.

RIP can require internet service providers to install 'black boxes' which see every scrap of data traversing their networks, all under the control of a monitoring centre in the MI5 building. There is obviously a problem of oversight here, but the director of the National Criminal Intelligence Service (who will operate it) last week knocked down the straw man that they 'would or could monitor all emails'. The issue is that nobody will know for sure what the boxes are doing, and RIP is drafted so that their operation is lawful without even serving warrants on the ISP.

The real trouble with RIP is that it won't work - and the reason is encryption. On an open system like the internet, the only way to keep data safe is to scramble it, so if a fraudster or industrial spy hacks into your system, the data is unintelligible without the right password or 'key'. Encryption will be ubiquitous - it's already built into the fabric of the next technical standard for the internet, and serious e-commerce applications will never be trusted without it.

RIP proposes to deal with the problem of criminal use of encryption by giving any public authority power to demand any key or password to any data there is some lawful authority to obtain - whether intercepted under warrant, seized in a search, or held by an innocent party. People forget passwords and lose keys all the time, but if you find yourself in this situation you could go to jail for two years. Serious criminals will obviously plead a bad memory, so NCIS wants the sentence to be as long as whatever crime someone is suspected of.

There is also a secrecy condition that can prohibit someone from disclosing that a key has been divulged - on pain of a further five years. But RIP can be evaded by taking elementary countermeasures, and will plainly be impotent against serious criminals.

There is an alternative, but the Government refuses to discuss it. Interception is useless if the data is encrypted, but even the strongest code is useless if the key is stolen. All computers have bugs in the software that allow hackers to break in, and developing a battery of such techniques would allow keys to be stolen covertly (under warrant) when required. The police say this is too difficult and unfortunately for us all, it probably is too difficult for the current management.

The Government's case reduces to a plea without evidence their assurances that the powers are 'necessary' and 'the innocent will not suffer', and Ministers increasingly resort to caricaturing opponents as libertarian absolutists. But RIP won't work, and the danger is that after the 'black boxes' go in and interception has been stymied by encryption, the police will look to compensate through automated mass surveillance of online behaviour. Instead it is time for law enforcement to develop alternatives to interception, and to stop pretending that sweeping executive discretion is a credible way to regulate internet surveillance.

Meanwhile other countries look on in horrified fascination. In any democracy with a written constitution, a law that locked people up for failing to prove they had forgotten something would not get very far. A leading investment bank, fearful that master-keys could be secretly suborned for economic intelligence gathering, has already moved security operations to Zurich, and Britain can expect to be treated as a pariah once company lawyers savour the possibilities. RIP is both a cock-up and a conspiracy - some intelligence agencies understand the internet well, but Ministers and most senior policy officials don't use the internet, don't understand its technology or economics, and don't think that that matters.

Caspar Bowden is director of the Foundation for Information Policy Research
www.fipr.org

No:

The regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill is attacked by some as a 'snooper's charter'. Such epithets may make for snappy headlines. But they do not reflect the reality.

One of the primary drivers behind this Bill is the protection of an individual's privacy. This Government passed the Human Rights Act 1998, which will shortly incorporate the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law. This includes a right to privacy. But this, in any democratic society, is not an absolute right. The ECHR permits interference with an individual's privacy but only where it is in accordance with the law and necessary, for example, to prevent crime. These are precisely the sort of strictures the Bill puts in place. We recognise that some of the powers in the Bill are particularly intrusive. That is precisely why they should, as the Bill proposes, be closely regulated.

Criminals have always been quick to seize on new technologies. We are seeing this now. The internet offers huge legitimate benefits. It is rewriting the rules about how we communicate, how businesses operate and how governments function. But alongside these opportunities come powerful opportunities for criminals to abuse new technologies. So there is a delicate balance to be struck. We need to give due weight to all the interests involved - individual privacy, business expedience and law enforcement. We would be justifiably criticised if we did nothing to prevent the new media becoming tools of drug smugglers, paedophiles or people traffickers.

Contrary to its critics, the Bill does not usher in an era of mass email interception. There is no intention to routinely monitor communications or fit 'black boxes' to all internet service providers. Some may be required to maintain a capability. Interception now and in the future is reserved for use only in the most serious cases - a threat to national security, the nation's economic well-being, or in pursuit of serious crime - and every warrant must be authorised personally by the Secretary of State. There are, we know, crucial cost and technical issues here for industry and we are discussing these now with the relevant players. We have no intention of imposing unreasonable burdens on anyone - we have every intention of ensuring we can fight crime in the twenty-first century.

There have been suggestions that the Bill would allow unfettered access to communications data (eg, itemised billing records). In fact, the Bill introduces comprehensive statutory controls for the first time, strictly governing access to such information. Access must be properly authorised, for specified purposes, and subject to independent oversight. Some have suggested that as many as 28 different public authorities will be authorised to access communications data. Not so. The Bill lists six authorities and police forces. And, as we announced last week, we are looking again at whether we have got the definition of communications data in the Bill quite right.

There is also much hyperbole about the provisions relating to the use of encryption. This technology is vital to the e-commerce revolution, but also a boon to criminals eager to hide their activities. These measures do not give law enforcement agencies any new powers to obtain material - just the ability to understand the contents of material that they can lawfully obtain.

Again, we are looking to see whether changes can be made which provide reassurance while maintaining the balance we seek.

The RIP Bill has been described as 'Orwellian' and 'Kafka-esque'. Instead of reaching for the clichéd literary descriptors, some critics may do better to look at what the Bill actually says, and consider the reality. This is an important Bill - and not just for those who know their symmetric from their asymmetric encryption keys. The powers in the Bill, simply put, are essential to help keep the UK a safe place for everyone to live and work.

Charles Clarke MP is a Minister of State at the Home Office.

RIP can require internet service providers to install 'black boxes' which see every scrap of data traversing their networks, all under the control of a monitoring centre in the MI5 building. There is obviously a problem of oversight here, but the director of the National Criminal Intelligence Service (who will operate it) last week knocked down the straw man that they 'would or could monitor all emails'. The issue is that nobody will know for sure what the boxes are doing, and RIP is drafted so that their operation is lawful without even serving warrants on the ISP. The real trouble with RIP is that it won't work - and the reason is encryption. On an open system like the internet, the only way to keep data safe is to scramble it, so if a fraudster or industrial spy hacks into your system, the data is unintelligible without the right password or 'key'. Encryption will be ubiquitous - it's already built into the fabric of the next technical standard for the internet, and serious e-commerce applications will never be trusted without it. RIP proposes to deal with the problem of criminal use of encryption by giving any public authority power to demand any key or password to any data there is some lawful authority to obtain - whether intercepted under warrant, seized in a search, or held by an innocent party. People forget passwords and lose keys all the time, but if you find yourself in this situation you could go to jail for two years. Serious criminals will obviously plead a bad memory, so NCIS wants the sentence to be as long as whatever crime someone is suspected of. There is also a secrecy condition that can prohibit someone from disclosing that a key has been divulged - on pain of a further five years. But RIP can be evaded by taking elementary countermeasures, and will plainly be impotent against serious criminals. There is an alternative, but the Government refuses to discuss it. Interception is useless if the data is encrypted, but even the strongest code is useless if the key is stolen. All computers have bugs in the software that allow hackers to break in, and developing a battery of such techniques would allow keys to be stolen covertly (under warrant) when required. The police say this is too difficult and unfortunately for us all, it probably is too difficult for the current management. The Government's case reduces to a plea without evidence their assurances that the powers are 'necessary' and 'the innocent will not suffer', and Ministers increasingly resort to caricaturing opponents as libertarian absolutists. But RIP won't work, and the danger is that after the 'black boxes' go in and interception has been stymied by encryption, the police will look to compensate through automated mass surveillance of online behaviour. Instead it is time for law enforcement to develop alternatives to interception, and to stop pretending that sweeping executive discretion is a credible way to regulate internet surveillance. Meanwhile other countries look on in horrified fascination. In any democracy with a written constitution, a law that locked people up for failing to prove they had forgotten something would not get very far. A leading investment bank, fearful that master-keys could be secretly suborned for economic intelligence gathering, has already moved security operations to Zurich, and Britain can expect to be treated as a pariah once company lawyers savour the possibilities. RIP is both a cock-up and a conspiracy - some intelligence agencies understand the internet well, but Ministers and most senior policy officials don't use the internet, don't understand its technology or economics, and don't think that that matters. Caspar Bowden is director of the Foundation for Information Policy Research www.fipr.org No: The regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill is attacked by some as a 'snooper's charter'. Such epithets may make for snappy headlines. But they do not reflect the reality. One of the primary drivers behind this Bill is the protection of an individual's privacy. This Government passed the Human Rights Act 1998, which will shortly incorporate the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law. This includes a right to privacy. But this, in any democratic society, is not an absolute right. The ECHR permits interference with an individual's privacy but only where it is in accordance with the law and necessary, for example, to prevent crime. These are precisely the sort of strictures the Bill puts in place. We recognise that some of the powers in the Bill are particularly intrusive. That is precisely why they should, as the Bill proposes, be closely regulated. Criminals have always been quick to seize on new technologies. We are seeing this now. The internet offers huge legitimate benefits. It is rewriting the rules about how we communicate, how businesses operate and how governments function. But alongside these opportunities come powerful opportunities for criminals to abuse new technologies. So there is a delicate balance to be struck. We need to give due weight to all the interests involved - individual privacy, business expedience and law enforcement. We would be justifiably criticised if we did nothing to prevent the new media becoming tools of drug smugglers, paedophiles or people traffickers. Contrary to its critics, the Bill does not usher in an era of mass email interception. There is no intention to routinely monitor communications or fit 'black boxes' to all internet service providers. Some may be required to maintain a capability. Interception now and in the future is reserved for use only in the most serious cases - a threat to national security, the nation's economic well-being, or in pursuit of serious crime - and every warrant must be authorised personally by the Secretary of State. There are, we know, crucial cost and technical issues here for industry and we are discussing these now with the relevant players. We have no intention of imposing unreasonable burdens on anyone - we have every intention of ensuring we can fight crime in the twenty-first century. There have been suggestions that the Bill would allow unfettered access to communications data (eg, itemised billing records). In fact, the Bill introduces comprehensive statutory controls for the first time, strictly governing access to such information. Access must be properly authorised, for specified purposes, and subject to independent oversight. Some have suggested that as many as 28 different public authorities will be authorised to access communications data. Not so. The Bill lists six authorities and police forces. And, as we announced last week, we are looking again at whether we have got the definition of communications data in the Bill quite right. There is also much hyperbole about the provisions relating to the use of encryption. This technology is vital to the e-commerce revolution, but also a boon to criminals eager to hide their activities. These measures do not give law enforcement agencies any new powers to obtain material - just the ability to understand the contents of material that they can lawfully obtain. Again, we are looking to see whether changes can be made which provide reassurance while maintaining the balance we seek. The RIP Bill has been described as 'Orwellian' and 'Kafka-esque'. Instead of reaching for the clichéd literary descriptors, some critics may do better to look at what the Bill actually says, and consider the reality. This is an important Bill - and not just for those who know their symmetric from their asymmetric encryption keys. The powers in the Bill, simply put, are essential to help keep the UK a safe place for everyone to live and work. Charles Clarke MP is a Minister of State at the Home Office.

fields.headline: Our name is mud
fields.standfirst: Why the world envies Glastonbury
fields.trailText: Glastonbury revellers may this weekend have spotted among their number a less relaxed, wellie-booted delegation from the People's Republic of China observing this most individual of British summer events. They will wander from the Green Field's henge to the dance tent and Pyramid stage, measuring and assessing, puzzling and admiring, with a view to replicating this muddy spectacle for themselves. For, amid all our recent breast-beating (the English  en masse  abroad, the national sport a laughing stock, the international opprobrium), it is worth recalling that there are some events - even involving substantial amounts of all-day drinking - in which we still excel and which, dare we say it, the world regards with jealous admiration.
fields.body:
Glastonbury revellers may this weekend have spotted among their number a less relaxed, wellie-booted delegation from the People's Republic of China observing this most individual of British summer events. They will wander from the Green Field's henge to the dance tent and Pyramid stage, measuring and assessing, puzzling and admiring, with a view to replicating this muddy spectacle for themselves. For, amid all our recent breast-beating (the English en masse abroad, the national sport a laughing stock, the international opprobrium), it is worth recalling that there are some events - even involving substantial amounts of all-day drinking - in which we still excel and which, dare we say it, the world regards with jealous admiration.

The empire may be gone, French chic may be challenging British cool but we can organise a piss-up in a brewery - and, indeed, almost anywhere: Henley, Ascot, Wimbledon, Notting Hill. Glastonbury may be our greatest triumph. We are the nation that can sit through days of torrential rain with toilet facilities that match the worst refugee camps. Overcoming trench foot and sun stroke, occasional bad trips and even more occasional violence, Glastonbury stands as a model of instant community that Amitai Etzioni would envy.

Here's to our muddy goodwill ambassadors.

fields.headline: Republican rebels gain strength
fields.standfirst: The Real IRA's political front has overcome mainstream attempts to crush it after the Omagh bomb, reports Henry McDonald
fields.trailText: Renewed signs of tension in the republican movement and evidence of the growing strength of the Real IRA emerged last week.
fields.body:
Renewed signs of tension in the republican movement and evidence of the growing strength of the Real IRA emerged last week.

The family of IRA hunger-striker Bobby Sands has called on Sinn Fein to return his prison writings to them. Martin Galvin, the former Noraid publicity director, has described the IRA's decision to open up its arms dumps to international inspectors as a surrender. And this weekend the 32 County Sovereignty Committee, the Real IRA's political allies, 'gave two fingers to the Provos' by holding its annual conference on the borders of South Armagh, where it is now thought to have enrolled 40 per cent of active republicans.

Despite being the focus of international odium following the Real IRA's Omagh massacre two years ago, the organisation's political front is demonstrating that it has resisted attempts by mainstream republicans to suppress it. Among the speakers at the conference was Marion Price, the former IRA hunger-striker, and Bernadette Sands-McKevitt, the sister of the IRA leader in the Maze in 1981 who was elected MP for Fermanagh/Tyrone just before he died on hunger strike.

The Sands family is known to have become increasingly disillusioned with the Sinn Fein peace strategy over the past few years. Now, in a thinly veiled attack on the republican leadership, it has called for the trust Sinn Fein set up in the hunger striker's name to be wound up.

In a letter yesterday to the nationalist weekly newspaper, the Andersonstown News , the family reiterated its request for the return of Bobby Sands's writings and for the trust's dissolution. The letter explained: 'We felt that the aims and ideals for which Bobby died and on which the trust was founded have been abandoned.'

Sands's poetry and political thoughts were best-sellers in 1981 before and after he died on hunger-strike during the H-Block struggle for political status. Sands's verse 'The lark and the freedom fighter' became the emblematic poem of republican struggle in the 1980s.

Last year the Sands family refused to turn up at the unveiling of a statue of Bobby Sands on the Twinbrook estate in west Belfast, where he grew up. The Sands family made it clear they opposed Sinn Fein entering a power-sharing coalition with unionists at Stormont.

The family is also bitter over Provisional IRA threats to Bernadette Sands and her husband, Michael McKevitt, following the Omagh bombing in 1998. Senior PIRA figures from Belfast descended on their home in Dundalk following the Omagh atrocity and threatened to kill Michael McKevitt unless the Real IRA, of which is reputedly the leader, called a permanent ceasefire.

Martin Galvin's allegation that the IRA's decision to open its arms dumps to international inspection was 'surrender' was made in a speech before the sovereignty committee's conference.

He said the Provisional IRA's move was decommissioning by other means and claimed Sinn Fein had sold out the republican demand that the RUC be fully disbanded. Galvin, once a close asso ciate of Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, said the Good Friday Agreement was partitionist and would not lead to a united Ireland. It was a 'trap to ensnare republicans into administering British rule'.

The location of the weekend conference was significant in itself - the Carrickdale hotel on the Louth/Armagh border. South Armagh, branded 'bandit country' by British Ministers in the early 1970s, has traditionally been a Provisional IRA stronghold since the Troubles began. However, in recent months the Real IRA and its political allies have been recruiting heavily in the area, according to an independent republican source.

'Two years ago after Omagh the Provos went around slapping a few of the dissidents about. The way things are today they would have to think twice about doing that again.'

The source estimated the Real IRA had around 150 activists, spanning an area from Dundalk in the Republic to Armagh City in Northern Ireland.

The 32 County Sovereignty Committee is planning to form branches in Sinn Fein redoubts such as west Belfast and Derry following its conference. At present the organisation sells 620 copies of its newspaper The Sovereign Nation in nationalist parts of Belfast every month. Last month the organisation exploded a device on London's Hammersmith Bridge, creating traffic chaos. The Real IRA cell responsible for the attack on the bridge is still at large in England.

The terror group, which killed 29 men, women and children in the Omagh atrocity, has developed a new type of mortar. The British Army has classified the weapon as a Mark 19 mortar, which was test-fired in Co Fermanagh earlier this year.

Meanwhile, Sinn Fein's Health Minister, Bairbre de Brun, has publicly distanced herself from the recent upsurge in IRA punishment attacks. De Brun, a member of the Northern Ireland power-sharing executive and assembly member for west Belfast, said: 'I am totally opposed to punishment. I don't think that such attacks contribute to resolving the serious problem of anti-social activity or criminality which exists in some areas.'

The Health Minister went on to blame the policing problem rather than paramilitaries for the continuation of beatings and shootings.

 The Sovereignty Movement said it would picket Home Secretary Jack Straw's house in Blackburn in protest over republican paramilitary prisoners being held in the UK.

webTitle: Straw must not dodge his responsibility

fields.headline: Straw must not dodge his responsibility
fields.standfirst: Lower the refugee barriers and defeat the traffickers
fields.trailText: Sometimes it takes a great tragedy to change things for the better. The squalid deaths last week of 58 people in the back of a lorry at Dover should serve to remind us that ordinary people in desperate circumstances often take desperate risks and to compel us all to examine what we can do to avoid such loss of life happening again.
fields.body:
Sometimes it takes a great tragedy to change things for the better. The squalid deaths last week of 58 people in the back of a lorry at Dover should serve to remind us that ordinary people in desperate circumstances often take desperate risks and to compel us all to examine what we can do to avoid such loss of life happening again.

Certainly, the people responsible for this act of callousness need to be pursued and brought to justice, but that is not going to prevent others, mindful of the vast fortunes to be made, taking their place and risking yet more lives.

What is needed is urgent action to reduce the demand for the traffickers' services. Despite the 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees, this demand exists partly because states have erected more and more barriers to prevent refugees getting to Europe, forcing them into the hands of the brutal international trafficking gangs which grow rich on the profits of helping refugees and other migrants slip into Fortress Europe illegally.

For the last couple of years Ministers have been privately describing the 1951 Convention as 'like Clause 4 of the Labour Party'. I assume this means that not only do they think it is outdated but also that its removal would be a macho symbol of their contempt for woolly liberal values. A few days ago, as he outlined his proposals for change, Jack Straw came out in the open at an EU meeting in Lisbon and called for a debate on the circumstances in which the right to asylum should be exercised.

To do that we need to remember where the Convention came from, and that means confronting some uncomfortable truths. First, why is asylum a human right? At one level, the concept of welcoming and assisting a stranger in trouble is enshrined in all the great religious traditions that inform the moral and ethical framework of us all.

Then there are the searing experiences of the mid-point of the last century which created the insidious myth that 'Britain has a proud tradition of welcoming genuine refugees'. I am afraid we do not. Refugees have always been greeted here with hostility and restrictions.

EU countries receive just over 4 per cent of the world's refugees. It would be a scandal if more of this small number were pushed onto the poorest states to deal with. It would be even worse if these states, following Europe's lead, were to say they too would close their borders to refugees fleeing persecution.

Out of all this come two key principles against which Jack Straw should be judged. First of all, the absolute right of an individual to make a claim for asylum and have it properly considered. Second, that the responsibility for receiving refugees should be fairly shared between the North and South.

He proposes that refugees from countries where gross human rights abuses occur would be able to bypass the traffickers and apply for asylum in the region - for instance, in a neighbouring country - and EU states would all agree to take them on a quota basis.

We would oppose this measure unless it were in addition to existing methods. The heart of the 1951 Convention is an individual right to apply for asylum. If quotas agreed on a basis of political expediency replaced this we would be back in the position of the 1930s.

At the other end of the spectrum there is to be a new 'white list' of countries from which asylum claims would not be considered at all. Jack Straw cites 'EU states, the US, Canada, Australia and many others '. Frankly, no one is going to get very exercised about the states he names, which produce only a tiny handful of asylum-seekers, but the 'many others ' causes us real concern. What others? Turkey - an EU Accession State? The Central European states where Roma people face the worst discrimination in Europe? How will these states be decided - on the basis of an objective assessment of their human rights records or with one eye on not rocking the diplomatic and foreign policy boat?

Jack Straw says it is the middle group of countries where there is a general presumption of safety but where some human rights abuses do occur that should be considered under an accelerated procedure. We disagree. It is asylum-seekers from these states that often present the most complex cases. In these circumstances a fair consideration of the asylum claim is still required.

The right of asylum is fundamental. The challenge to Jack Straw is to interpret the Geneva Convention in a modern context but consistently with those fundamental principles. And the challenge to the rest of us is to make sure he does so.

Nick Hardwick is chief executive of the Refugee Council.

fields.headline: The book of life
fields.standfirst: Gene science spells out our destiny
fields.trailText: Tomorrow, the first rough draft of the human genetic code will be published - one of the epic achievements of contemporary science. We will know the gene sequences that determine our mental and physical behaviour. We will have the tools that in decades ahead will allow us to understand how much of what we do is predetermined and how much is of our own free will, what makes us vulnerable to diseases like cancer and, more importantly, how we might develop treatments.
fields.body:
Tomorrow, the first rough draft of the human genetic code will be published - one of the epic achievements of contemporary science. We will know the gene sequences that determine our mental and physical behaviour. We will have the tools that in decades ahead will allow us to understand how much of what we do is predetermined and how much is of our own free will, what makes us vulnerable to diseases like cancer and, more importantly, how we might develop treatments.

The first consequences are in medicine. A new array of drugs that treat our gene sequences and thus our proclivity both to experiencing certain diseases and responding to new drugs are in prospect. We will become healthier. We will live longer and fuller lives.

Yet the moral and social implications are barely discussed. How much of our intelligence, for example, is acquired and how much is endowed by our gene structure? In the early twentieth century the so-called science of eugenics informed Nazi arguments to justify the holocaust. Once again we are exposed to the risk that deadly value judgments will be linked to the structure of some gene sequences over others. If we can tell at birth that a child will, say, have criminal tendencies, what is the appropriate reaction?

Equally seriously, we will be in a position to predict individual predispositions to certain types of disease. If improved remedies are developed, then the consequences will be less marked - but from the point of view of an insurance company faced with underwriting the risk, the issue remains serious. Private insurance will not just become the preserve of the wealthy, but those with a good gene structure. Science has immense potential for good and cannot nor should ever be halted. But we must begin to debate and prepare for the consequences of science's achievement now.

fields.headline: Men choose for women
fields.trailText: It is not easy to find an issue on which Northern Ireland's male politicians can agree. Last week's debate at Stormont enabled them to express a rare consensus on a motion expressing the Assembly's opposition to 'the extension of the Abortion Act (1967) to Northern Ireland'.
fields.body:
It is not easy to find an issue on which Northern Ireland's male politicians can agree. Last week's debate at Stormont enabled them to express a rare consensus on a motion expressing the Assembly's opposition to 'the extension of the Abortion Act (1967) to Northern Ireland'.

The motion was proposed by the Rev Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party and supported by the SDLP, Sinn Fein, the Ulster Unionist Party and Alliance. Only David Ervine of the Progressive Unionist Party opposed it, on the grounds that women have a right to control their own bodies.

Words such as 'legalised carnage' and 'butchery' were used. Dr Joseph Hendron of the SDLP said 'the most vulnerable person in our society is the unborn child'. On a day when the UFF had threatened to shoot anybody seen attacking a Protestant house and there were reports of more 'punishment beatings' by paramilitaries, many vulnerable people were concerned by more immediate dangers.

Women members of the Assembly challenged the male consensus. Joan Carson of the UUP pointed out the motion would make no difference to the 2,000 women a year who travel to Britain from Northern Ireland to have their pregnancies terminated.

The Women's Coalition proposed the issue should be referred to the Assembly's Health Committee, which should take evidence from doctors, lawyers and other experts. It was defeated by 43 votes to 15.

Peter Mandelson must have breathed a sigh of relief. Devolution means any decision to deal with Northern Ireland's highly ambiguous law on abortion now rests with the Assembly. In recent years there has been a demand that the Government should provide clarification. In 1993, a Westminster parliamentary committee conceded the legal situation is 'so uncertain that it violates international standards of human rights'.

Unlike in the Irish Republic, abortion is permitted in Northern Ireland in cases where there is a substantial threat to the life or wellbeing of the mother, severe foetal abnormality or when the pregnancy is the result of incest or rape. Official figures show 77 medical abortions were carried out in Northern Ireland in l998. But availability varies from hospital to hospital, dependent often on the views of individual consultants.

In a 1992 survey one gynaecologist said he would be prepared to terminate a pregnancy resulting from rape, but not on the grounds of foetal abnormality. Another would grant an abortion for foetal handicap but not for rape.

A more recent inquiry revealed 78 per cent of Northern Ireland's family doctors would like the legal situation clarified. Over 40 per cent said they had referred women facing a crisis pregnancy to a clinic in Britain or would be prepared to do so, while 22 per cent said abortion should remain illegal in Northern Ireland.

As the demand for change has grown, the debate has become more vicious. Family planning clinics offering referral to Britain have been picketed and demonstrators have gathered outside the homes of counsellors. Last summer the Ulster Pregnancy Advisory Association was force to close its clinic in Belfast. Mo Mowlam, Peter Mandelson's predecessor, expressed guarded support for the clinic but was reluctant to get involved, citing the fragility of the peace process as her reason.

The human reality behind this debate is that 2,000 women from Northern Ireland are forced to go to mainland Britain each year to have pregnancies terminated. Pro-Choice groups point out it is more difficult for poorer women to pay for transport and for an abortion in a private clinic.

Such experiences did not receive much attention in the expressions of high morality in the Assembly. Here is one young woman's story. Margaret was 16 when she became pregnant. Her mother was in hospital being treated for breast cancer. Her grandmother accompanied her to London to have an abortion. Margaret wrote: 'It was very frightening. Neither of us had been out of Northern Ireland before. But everybody at the clinic was very nice, and the man who owned the boarding house let me use my nebuliser and did not charge me extra for the electricity.'

fields.headline: On message with a mission
fields.standfirst: After the superwaif summit fiasco, it's likely that she went home to tidy and polish off her red boxes. With a bit more steel, it's said, Tessa Jowell could be cleaning up in the Cabinet
fields.trailText: When Tessa Jowell needs to relax after a long day, what she likes best is, apparently, to tidy up. While lesser women slump exhausted on the sofa, the Employment Minister is still busy picking things up, sorting things out, restoring order to her Camden home. Tessa Jowell is pretty keen on order. There is something about the rather saintly Jowell, who cheerfully admits her life is 'blessed', that is almost too irritatingly good to be true. And she has certainly set hackles rising this week, branded the nation's nanny after her efforts to tackle teenage anorexia backfired.
fields.body:
When Tessa Jowell needs to relax after a long day, what she likes best is, apparently, to tidy up. While lesser women slump exhausted on the sofa, the Employment Minister is still busy picking things up, sorting things out, restoring order to her Camden home. Tessa Jowell is pretty keen on order. There is something about the rather saintly Jowell, who cheerfully admits her life is 'blessed', that is almost too irritatingly good to be true. And she has certainly set hackles rising this week, branded the nation's nanny after her efforts to tackle teenage anorexia backfired.

She ought to be easy to dislike. But Jowell is so unfailingly nice, and so fired with an unexpected passion on behalf of the underdog, that it is really rather difficult not to be charmed. And she is stoical under fire. 'I'm blessed with a large, very close-knit family and I'm blessed with a huge number of friends I absolutely adore,' she says. 'I'm not one of those bonkers politicians who think about nothing but politics. My job enables me to achieve dreams I've held dear since my early twenties, but I have a rich and big life outside politics that helps me keep it all in perspective.'

However, she is still angry that her summit, on whether images of skinny superwaifs fuel anorexia, descended into derision. The press seized on proposals to monitor images of fat and thin women on television. Wasn't she the do-gooder who suggested giving women extra benefits if they breast-fed their babies, and wanted to ban smoking in public places? But Jowell rejects the 'nanny' tag, blaming the media for trivialising her intentions.

'It is ludicrous to suggest that I wanted to set up some sort of ridiculous fat-woman, thin-woman tally last week,' she says. 'It's just another example of the papers going for the cheap shot at the expense of the truth, which was far more sensible, constructive and mundane.

'I loathe nanny politics,' she adds. 'I have never wanted to nanny anyone in my life. That is not what government is for. If some people want to die early, that is their choice: I just want to make sure their decisions are educated ones.'

She's right, but this week Jowell fell foul of the one thing she has always guarded against: letting the political message run out of control. All her life she has tried to do the right thing, and if friends ever criticise, it is to say she should relax a bit.

She was born in 1947, daughter of a doctor and a radiographer, into a family where public service was taken for granted. As a little girl she wanted to be a doctor, but her father said it was men's work. Instead, she did her Master's in social administration at Edinburgh University and started out as a child care officer in Lambeth.

She trained in the unglamorous area of psychiatric social work, spent 12 years with the mental health charity MIND, and still says her most rewarding time was in Birmingham on a social care project: she stayed overnight in old people's homes to see conditions for herself.

As a Camden councillor in the Eighties she was on-message before the message existed, so outraged by the loony-left that she considered defecting to the SDP. Her marriage to social scientist Roger Jowell ended after five years. She met City lawyer David Mills through the council and they married in 1979, after her first unsuccessful attempt at standing for Parliament. She tried again, in Dulwich in 1992, and won.

Telegenic and tireless, Jowell became one of the most familiar faces of the 1997 election campaign, although so anxious not to stray from Labour's Yellow Brick Road that even Millbank raised eyebrows at the number of phonecalls she made before every interview she gave. She landed the job of Public Health Minister after the election, moving to employment at the last reshuffle.

Her only real rocky patch came early. She was the Minister negotiating motor racing's exemption from a ban on tobacco advertising when it emerged that Formula 1 chief Bernie Ecclestone had made a £1 million gift to Labour. Then it transpired her husband was non-executive director of Benetton, which races F1 cars. Jowell had played by the rules, but ended up carrying the can.

She has always been prodigiously disciplined: when her children were young she would work through the night to buy time later in the day for a school play, and still regularly does her red boxes at dawn. Jowell is clearly driven, but her huge network of friends say you would never know it. 'We're always amazed at how she manages to be so nice,' said one. 'We drive away after an evening with her and her husband discussing quite openly where on earth her dark side could be. One presumes there must be one.'

Stories of her kindness abound. One journalist recalls how, when he suffered a brutal redundancy, Jowell asked him to dinner. 'She waited until the next time a three-line whip had been called at the Commons and then took me to a dining room there that is usually strictly out of bounds to journalists,' he says. 'She had booked a table in the centre of the room just so that she could be sure everyone there saw us together. She wanted to make it clear to them all that I was still in circulation. It was quite above and beyond the call of friendship.'

In Government she has retained her knack for a soundbite, but also her principles: her proudest achievement is SureStart, the programme she and David Blunkett set up to advise deprived families on parenting and keeping children off the at-risk register.

When she became Deputy Minister for Women in 1998, alongside Baroness Jay, she manoeuvred the much-ghettoised Women's Unit into the limelight without seeming too strident. Successes have been notable: pushing for the right for new mothers to return to work part-time, bigger maternity grants for the poorest mothers.

But the Women's Unit lacks a significant budget, leaving it often dependent on cheap 'awareness-raising' initiatives rather than concrete action. Enter, fatefully, the anorexia summit. To some degree it is not Jowell's fault: any Minister fighting for large-scale social change under a government nervous of over-regulating is reduced to cajoling for a change of behaviour. And unfair though it unquestionably is, when women cajole and exhort, most people - and almost all men - are reminded of their mothers.

And while Jowell is usually sincere, even close friends admit her manner can sometimes sets hackles rising. 'If people could just hear her when she's just being herself, saying what she really thinks with the passion she really feels, they would view her differently,' said a friend and colleague, 'but the moment she sits down in front of a microphone, she transforms into the worst kind of prissy, irritating nagger.'

Jowell is always tipped for the Cabinet, but has always missed so far: not quite ready, the report card comes back, but definitely next time. Whitehall whispers that she needs more steel to stand up to Downing Street.

And she may be missing out with the public for the same reason that John Prescott, Clare Short or Mo Mowlam luck in: that while she is resolutely on-message, they are often off. She may be word-perfect but her replies are reckoned to be concocted earlier in the New Labour lab. The gaff-prone, gawky response is the one reckoned to be imbued with honesty.

'If Tessa learns the courage of her convictions and steps outside the imprisonment of New Labour's rhetoric, there is no reason why she couldn't be PM in years to come,' said a friend. But unless she does, she could find herself shunted off into some form of political housekeeping. And that fate, for the Minister for Women, would be an irony too far.

Rt Hon Ms Tessa Jowell

DoB: 17 September 1947

Lives: Camden, London

University: Edinburgh (degree in social administration)

Husband: David Mills, City lawyer (one son, one daughter)

Ex-husband: Roger Jowell (marriage dissolved in 1978)

Job: Minister for the New Deal, Department of Education and Employment

Previous job: Public Health Minister

fields.headline: Flashpoint in a fragile peace
fields.standfirst: The area around a 'peaceline' dividing loyalist and nationalist communities became the focal point of new divisions when the Ulster Defence Association threatened to break its ceasefire.
fields.trailText: Less than 12 hours after the first IRA ceasefire, workmen were putting the finishing touches to Belfast's latest peaceline - the permanent wall dividing loyalist and nationalist communities on the Springfield Road.
fields.body:
Less than 12 hours after the first IRA ceasefire, workmen were putting the finishing touches to Belfast's latest peaceline - the permanent wall dividing loyalist and nationalist communities on the Springfield Road.

For anyone foolish enough to believe that 1 September 1994 would herald a new spirit of reconciliation in Northern Ireland, a trip to this latest barrier being built to keep Protestants and Catholics apart would have been a sobering experience.

Six years on from the IRA and loyalist ceasefires, the wall between the swing gates at Lanark Way and the metal barrier blanking off Workman Avenue from nationalist homes across the Springfield Road remains.

Last week the area around the wall became the focal point of fresh divisions, which almost destabilised the fragile, imperfect peace in the province.

On Tuesday the largest loyalist terror group, the Ulster Defence Association, threatened to break its ceasefire unless, it said, attacks on Protestants and their homes along that interface and other parts of north and west Belfast halted. The UFF - the UDA's military wing - in west Belfast warned that it would shoot any nationalist attacking Protestant homes on sight in the area.

It took 48 hours of cross-community negotiations, thinly-veiled threats by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary and protests from the other so-called UDA 'brigades' to get the UFF threat lifted.

Behind the threat lay a mixture of communal paranoia and political cynicism, both of which lie at the very heart of the malaise inside loyalism at a time of historic change. Catholics on the disputed part of the Springfield Road feel as vulnerable as the remaining Protestants living there.

Some Catholic owned homes on the road were built in such a way that the 'fronts' of their houses are actually at the back, away from the Springfield. Just before the loyalist ceasefire Catholic families lived in fear of UFF and UVF murder squads who used Lanark Way as a main route into nationalist west Belfast.

But even moderate unionist politicians in the area claim there has been increasing pressure on Protestants aimed, they believe, at pushing them off the Upper Springfield forever. Hence the use of that emotive, often-abused, phrase from the Balkans, 'ethnic cleansing.'

Chris McGimpsey, an Ulster Unionist councillor and strong supporter of the Good Friday Agreement, faced a jeering mob of loyalist women protesting at the entrance of Lanark Way last Tuesday evening. Some bayed into his face as RUC officers separated them from nationalists on the other side: 'This is all David Trimble's fault.'

McGimpsey accepts residents' claims that there is a concerted effort to drive Protestants out.

'I think the republicans are trying to provoke violence in the hope that they can have both Lanark Way and Workman Avenue shut. Once that happens the remaining Protestants living on the front of Springfield Road will be cut off and isolated from the Greater Shankill/Woodvale area. It will lead to the closure of the last Protestant primary school on the road, it will mean Protestants will be more unlikely to take up jobs in the new University of Ulster site at Springvale. This is orchestrated and I think the Protestant residents are falling into a trap.'

His council colleague and deputy Lord Mayor Frank McCoubrey rattles off a series of recent incidents including a hoax bomb left by republicans at Workman Avenue and a vicious assault on David Sterritt the young Protestant boy who met President Clinton during his historic peace-sealing visit to Belfast in 1995. All this is evidence, he said, of 'ethnic cleansing.'

McCoubrey, who belongs to the UDA-aligned Ulster Democratic Party, said it was community pressure that pushed the UFF to the brink last week.

'We have been doing everything to stop things from sliding back but unfortunately there is a group of people in this community who are saying enough is enough.'

Nationalists on the other side of the line have accused unionist politicians of opportunism and point out that 21 families were re-housed because of sectarian intimidation in north and west Belfast - all of them Catholics.

Sinn Fein's Gerry Kelly and the SDLP's Alex Attwood said they suspected the real motivation behind the UFF warning was a power-struggle within the broader loyalist paramilitary family.

In a sense both sides are right. Protestants living along the Springfield Road interface clearly do feel under siege. Since the start of this year relations between the two main loyalist terror groups, the UDA and the Ulster Volunteer Force, have seriously deteriorated.

The UVF believes the UDA is secretly colluding with another smaller rival, the Loyalist Volunteer Force. Since Christmas the UVF has been locked in a bloody feud with the LVF splinter group. The feud began with a vicious assault on LVF prisoners out on seasonal parole in Portadown. In retaliation the LVF shot dead the UVF's mid-Ulster commander Richard Jameson. Since then the inter-loyalist violence has claimed the lives of two young men from Portadown who were stabbed repeatedly by UVF supporters and north Belfast man Martin Taylor who was killed by the LVF, while building a wall with a prominent UVF member from Ballysillan.

The UVF's suspicions that the UDA were helping the LVF in Belfast - an area where the latter group has little or no base - were confirmed last month. The UVF attempted to kill a man from the Dungannon area which they believed was involved in the Jameson murder. Their intended target narrowly escaped death on the Oldpark Road and was taken by the RUC to Tenant Street police station to make a statement. When the police were finished with him, two senior UFF members picked up the Dungannon loyalist at the station from west Belfast.

UDA leaders including Johnny Adair, the former UFF commander who was recently released from the Maze, have publicly stated that 'everyone will have to look over their shoulder', in the event of a wider feud breaking out between the main paramilitary organisations.

Adair has not been coy in expressing his sympathies for the embattled LVF. Many in the LVF see him as the re-incarnation of another charismatic loyalist leader, the late Billy 'King Rat' Wright, who broke away from the UVF to found their organisation. The LVF's strategy, some say dream-scenario, since their foundation at Drumcree in 1996, is to form an alliance with the UDA, particularly Adair's volatile west and north Belfast brigades.

The main stumbling block in the road to loyalist re-alignment is the Byzantine nature of the UDA. The organisation is run on federal lines with individual areas often taking an independent line from the UDA HQ on the Shankill Road. Senior loyalist sources told The Observer that the UDA's south and east Belfast brigades want nothing to do with the LVF or their ongoing feud with the UVF.

'These areas are happy with the peace process and don't want to slide back to violence. The UFF statement about breaking its ceasefire was purely a west Belfast affair. None of the other brigades were consulted on the Inner Council (the UDA's ruling body). For these areas the threat to end the cessation was the last straw, the west was out of control,' one senior loyalist said.

The latest UFF threat has to be seen therefore in the context of the internal loyalist power struggle. If Protestants feel under threat, then the UFF/UDA can step in to portray themselves as the defenders of their people. While UVF figures - particularly its political wing the Progressive Unionist Party - hold talks with republicans, the UFF can flex its muscles and paint itself as the shield of besieged Protestants in areas like Upper Springfield.

The phenomenon of a Protestant paramilitary group beating its chest and returning to traditional loyalism while another reaches out to the other side is nothing new. In February 1974 the UVF drew up a peace plan and opened up secret dia logue with both the Official and Provisional IRAs. The UVF also called on the UDA to halt sectarian assassinations and demanded that the PIRA stop attacks on policemen and soldiers.

Two days after the UVF announcement, the PIRA said it would end shootings against locally recruited Ulster Defence Regiment soldiers. The UDA leadership sensed the UVF taking a leap forward and was clearly unhappy. The largest loyalist terror group rejected the peace overtures and warned that it would 'continue to carry out the function for which it was created: the defence of the Protestant people and the preservation of the Protestant faith.' It stepped up its attacks on Catholic businesses and civilian targets, carrying out a number of pub bombings.

Twenty-six years later the same tensions exist between the two main loyalist groups on the Shankill Road. This time, however, the dynamics are different. Following a threat by Peter Mandelson that its remaining prisoners would be kept locked up in the Maze if the UFF ceasefire broke, the UDA leadership reigned in the west Belfast brigade. The ceasefire threat was partially lifted on Friday and UDP leaders re-engaged in cross-community dialogue with nationalists.

Among those deputy Lord Mayor Frank McCoubrey held talks with about the Springfield issue was Sinn Fein councillor Tom Hartley. Up until now the UDA and its political wing have been more reticent to hold face-to-face talks with republicans. The irony of the latest crisis is that it has resulted in the UDA sitting down at community level with the PIRA's political allies - unthinkable just a few years ago.

The tensions of the last seven days, however, also illuminate how fragile peace and the month-old power-sharing coalition at Stormont really is.

There are other similar flashpoints like Upper Springfield, the most dangerous of all being Drumcree.

There are further, even more dangerous, tests ahead for David Trimble's and Seamus Mallon's new regime over the next few weeks.
