Last week the area around the wall became the focal point of fresh divisions, which almost destabilised the fragile, imperfect peace in the province. On Tuesday the largest loyalist terror group, the Ulster Defence Association, threatened to break its ceasefire unless, it said, attacks on Protestants and their homes along that interface and other parts of north and west Belfast halted. The UFF - the UDA's military wing - in west Belfast warned that it would shoot any nationalist attacking Protestant homes on sight in the area. It took 48 hours of cross-community negotiations, thinly-veiled threats by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary and protests from the other so-called UDA 'brigades' to get the UFF threat lifted. Behind the threat lay a mixture of communal paranoia and political cynicism, both of which lie at the very heart of the malaise inside loyalism at a time of historic change. Catholics on the disputed part of the Springfield Road feel as vulnerable as the remaining Protestants living there. Some Catholic owned homes on the road were built in such a way that the 'fronts' of their houses are actually at the back, away from the Springfield. Just before the loyalist ceasefire Catholic families lived in fear of UFF and UVF murder squads who used Lanark Way as a main route into nationalist west Belfast. But even moderate unionist politicians in the area claim there has been increasing pressure on Protestants aimed, they believe, at pushing them off the Upper Springfield forever. Hence the use of that emotive, often-abused, phrase from the Balkans, 'ethnic cleansing.' Chris McGimpsey, an Ulster Unionist councillor and strong supporter of the Good Friday Agreement, faced a jeering mob of loyalist women protesting at the entrance of Lanark Way last Tuesday evening. Some bayed into his face as RUC officers separated them from nationalists on the other side: 'This is all David Trimble's fault.' McGimpsey accepts residents' claims that there is a concerted effort to drive Protestants out. 'I think the republicans are trying to provoke violence in the hope that they can have both Lanark Way and Workman Avenue shut. Once that happens the remaining Protestants living on the front of Springfield Road will be cut off and isolated from the Greater Shankill/Woodvale area. It will lead to the closure of the last Protestant primary school on the road, it will mean Protestants will be more unlikely to take up jobs in the new University of Ulster site at Springvale. This is orchestrated and I think the Protestant residents are falling into a trap.' His council colleague and deputy Lord Mayor Frank McCoubrey rattles off a series of recent incidents including a hoax bomb left by republicans at Workman Avenue and a vicious assault on David Sterritt the young Protestant boy who met President Clinton during his historic peace-sealing visit to Belfast in 1995. All this is evidence, he said, of 'ethnic cleansing.' McCoubrey, who belongs to the UDA-aligned Ulster Democratic Party, said it was community pressure that pushed the UFF to the brink last week. 'We have been doing everything to stop things from sliding back but unfortunately there is a group of people in this community who are saying enough is enough.' Nationalists on the other side of the line have accused unionist politicians of opportunism and point out that 21 families were re-housed because of sectarian intimidation in north and west Belfast - all of them Catholics. Sinn Fein's Gerry Kelly and the SDLP's Alex Attwood said they suspected the real motivation behind the UFF warning was a power-struggle within the broader loyalist paramilitary family. In a sense both sides are right. Protestants living along the Springfield Road interface clearly do feel under siege. Since the start of this year relations between the two main loyalist terror groups, the UDA and the Ulster Volunteer Force, have seriously deteriorated. The UVF believes the UDA is secretly colluding with another smaller rival, the Loyalist Volunteer Force. Since Christmas the UVF has been locked in a bloody feud with the LVF splinter group. The feud began with a vicious assault on LVF prisoners out on seasonal parole in Portadown. In retaliation the LVF shot dead the UVF's mid-Ulster commander Richard Jameson. Since then the inter-loyalist violence has claimed the lives of two young men from Portadown who were stabbed repeatedly by UVF supporters and north Belfast man Martin Taylor who was killed by the LVF, while building a wall with a prominent UVF member from Ballysillan. The UVF's suspicions that the UDA were helping the LVF in Belfast - an area where the latter group has little or no base - were confirmed last month. The UVF attempted to kill a man from the Dungannon area which they believed was involved in the Jameson murder. Their intended target narrowly escaped death on the Oldpark Road and was taken by the RUC to Tenant Street police station to make a statement. When the police were finished with him, two senior UFF members picked up the Dungannon loyalist at the station from west Belfast. UDA leaders including Johnny Adair, the former UFF commander who was recently released from the Maze, have publicly stated that 'everyone will have to look over their shoulder', in the event of a wider feud breaking out between the main paramilitary organisations. Adair has not been coy in expressing his sympathies for the embattled LVF. Many in the LVF see him as the re-incarnation of another charismatic loyalist leader, the late Billy 'King Rat' Wright, who broke away from the UVF to found their organisation. The LVF's strategy, some say dream-scenario, since their foundation at Drumcree in 1996, is to form an alliance with the UDA, particularly Adair's volatile west and north Belfast brigades. The main stumbling block in the road to loyalist re-alignment is the Byzantine nature of the UDA. The organisation is run on federal lines with individual areas often taking an independent line from the UDA HQ on the Shankill Road. Senior loyalist sources told The Observer that the UDA's south and east Belfast brigades want nothing to do with the LVF or their ongoing feud with the UVF. 'These areas are happy with the peace process and don't want to slide back to violence. The UFF statement about breaking its ceasefire was purely a west Belfast affair. None of the other brigades were consulted on the Inner Council (the UDA's ruling body). For these areas the threat to end the cessation was the last straw, the west was out of control,' one senior loyalist said. The latest UFF threat has to be seen therefore in the context of the internal loyalist power struggle. If Protestants feel under threat, then the UFF/UDA can step in to portray themselves as the defenders of their people. While UVF figures - particularly its political wing the Progressive Unionist Party - hold talks with republicans, the UFF can flex its muscles and paint itself as the shield of besieged Protestants in areas like Upper Springfield. The phenomenon of a Protestant paramilitary group beating its chest and returning to traditional loyalism while another reaches out to the other side is nothing new. In February 1974 the UVF drew up a peace plan and opened up secret dia logue with both the Official and Provisional IRAs. The UVF also called on the UDA to halt sectarian assassinations and demanded that the PIRA stop attacks on policemen and soldiers. Two days after the UVF announcement, the PIRA said it would end shootings against locally recruited Ulster Defence Regiment soldiers. The UDA leadership sensed the UVF taking a leap forward and was clearly unhappy. The largest loyalist terror group rejected the peace overtures and warned that it would 'continue to carry out the function for which it was created: the defence of the Protestant people and the preservation of the Protestant faith.' It stepped up its attacks on Catholic businesses and civilian targets, carrying out a number of pub bombings. Twenty-six years later the same tensions exist between the two main loyalist groups on the Shankill Road. This time, however, the dynamics are different. Following a threat by Peter Mandelson that its remaining prisoners would be kept locked up in the Maze if the UFF ceasefire broke, the UDA leadership reigned in the west Belfast brigade. The ceasefire threat was partially lifted on Friday and UDP leaders re-engaged in cross-community dialogue with nationalists. Among those deputy Lord Mayor Frank McCoubrey held talks with about the Springfield issue was Sinn Fein councillor Tom Hartley. Up until now the UDA and its political wing have been more reticent to hold face-to-face talks with republicans. The irony of the latest crisis is that it has resulted in the UDA sitting down at community level with the PIRA's political allies - unthinkable just a few years ago. The tensions of the last seven days, however, also illuminate how fragile peace and the month-old power-sharing coalition at Stormont really is. There are other similar flashpoints like Upper Springfield, the most dangerous of all being Drumcree. There are further, even more dangerous, tests ahead for David Trimble's and Seamus Mallon's new regime over the next few weeks.

webTitle: Battered Mugabe hits  back as verdict looms

fields.headline: Battered Mugabe hits  back as verdict looms
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe's beleaguered leader unleashed more violence upon his nation on the first day of the long-delayed elections. A report on the desperation of a man who fears his time is finally up

Voters defy Mugabe thugs
fields.trailText: The morning sun was slowly beginning to warm the air when the first trucks were heard. After a breakfast of porridge and tea cooked over open fires, the villagers were tending crops of corn, tobacco and pepper, when they saw three vehicles in the distance.
fields.byline: Andy Malone in Harare, Andrew Meldrum
fields.body:
The morning sun was slowly beginning to warm the air when the first trucks were heard. After a breakfast of porridge and tea cooked over open fires, the villagers were tending crops of corn, tobacco and pepper, when they saw three vehicles in the distance.

Most of the villagers ran away. But not Julius Zuze, a 21-year-old ambitious man with five 'O' levels. Reared on tales of heroism during the war for black emancipation in the former British colony, he was one of a new generation of Zimbabweans determined to better himself. He was day-dreaming about a job in an office when the first men arrived.

They beat Zuze with four-foot-long wooden poles for two hours until he was unconscious. When he came around, the men were sitting on the grass around him, eating lunch and drinking beer. They beat him until he passed out again. The men then climbed back into their trucks and drove away. So-called democracy in Robert Mugabe's Zimbabwe had just reared its ugly head.

A mile away on this rutted farm road, 200 miles south of Harare, the capital, Mugabe's henchmen had wrecked dozens of homes and left a traumatised population. The sound of The Observer 's car approaching soon after the attack caused panic. Thinking it was the men returning, people locked their doors; others stood taking stock of the damage in the fields, young children darted into the bush, like small animals fleeing pain.

The sun was setting when Mutasa Costa emerged from behind an iron gate and told how his family of four cowered in their house, as more than 200 drunken footsoldiers of the ruling Zanu-PF party ran amok in the garden. 'They threw bricks through the window,' said Costa, surveying the wreckage. 'Then they dragged me out and beat me. I thought I was going to die. Please go now. I am afraid your car will bring them back.'

These were not isolated incidents. As Mugabe faced the biggest threat to his political career, his Stasi-trained secret police went on intimidating the worried Zimbabwean people as they filed into polling stations across the country early yesterday.

Gangs of youths, paid £5 each from state funds, set up barricades on roads in the north, south and east of the country, to prevent known supporters of the main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), from voting.

Peter Trigg, an opposition official, was stopped at a crude barricade of tree trunks and rocks 200 miles north of the capital. Youths armed with clubs and machetes tried to pull him out of the car. He managed to escape, as the gang stoned his vehicle.

There were also reports of widespread abductions of farm workers, seized at gunpoint and driven away in lorries from isolated rural areas in the early hours of the morning by Zanu supporters.

Worried by poll results, Mugabe's state-owned newspapers yesterday published editorials urging people to support the leader of the country's liberation struggle.

Branding the opposition 'agents of the white colonial powers', The Herald newspaper exhorted readers: 'People fought, died and were maimed in search of democratic rights that were denied them by the British and the Rhodesians. Independence brought nationhood and dignity to the African people of Zimbabwe. Vote for what you know. Vote for Zanu-PF.'

Piere Schori, the head of a l20-strong European Union delegation, allowed to monitor the elections, has set up a security office on the third floor of a Harare hotel. Stickers on a wall map show the areas affected by violence: white for calm, pink for high tension and yellow for very high. By yesterday, the map was covered in yellow. 'It is the worst pre-election violence and intimidation I have seen anywhere in the world,' Schori said.

In the run up to the elections, which close tonight, at least 35 people have died in a wave of attacks on MDC supporters. Hundreds more have been injured. Women have been sexually assaulted and raped. At least 10,000 people have been forced to leave there homes, some fleeing into neighbouring countries such as Zambia, South Africa and Mozambique.

In what some observers regard as the actions of a desperate man, Mugabe used the old African tricks of demonstrating pomp and grandeur. Flying round the country in his official helicopter, he attempted to rouse emotions with rhetoric he employed during the victorious four-year guerilla war against white minority rule.

After a four-hour delay at his penultimate rally in Katuma, some 30 miles south of his birthplace, a fleet of Mercedes, flanked by motorcycle outriders, swept into the football station where it was being staged. Wearing a Zanu baseball cap, the 76-year-old did a lap of honour as an official chanted on a megaphone: 'Mugabe! Mugabe!' Bemused schoolchildren bussed in for the event clutched official Zanu flags.

Mugabe waited at a nearby airstrip, refusing to appear until the numbers were greater. Police and officials rounded up people from neighbouring farms and businesses, bribing them with food and money to see the president.

'Most people do not even remember the war,' a journalist said, as the sun beat down on the crowd. 'They just want jobs and food for their families. The economy is the most important thing - money, that is the source of everything. It is time for a big change. Too many old men are in charge of our country.'

As Mugabe ordered the British to 'keep their big mouths shut', a dozen white farmers sat in chairs near the front of the crowd, having received an 'invitation' to the rally from a senior Zanu official. They were given flags covered in Zanu slogans as they entered the stadium, and twirled them awkwardly while Mugabe spoke. Asked why he felt obliged to come one farmer said: 'I think you know the answer to that one.'

The white farmers quietly hope the MDC wins. Their farms were invaded on Mugabe's instructions after he failed to win a referendum in February giving him even greater powers. Although there are only 4,500 farmers out of a population of 11 million blacks and 70,000 whites, Mugabe focussed his wrath on them to win support from the majority blacks. As voting began yesterday, it became evident that Mugabe had misjudged the mood.

The people of Zimbabwe's impoverished townships and rural areas were turning against their first president, sworn in the presence of Prince Charles in 1980. Outside one polling station in Harare yesterday, Trymore Rusike, a 30-year-old security guard, who had taken the day off to vote, was scathing about the president. 'Mugabe and his men are cheats and thieves,' he said. 'I earn only $2,500 Zimbabwe a month (about £50). My children are hungry. I hope I will be excited by next week. I hope this is our new Independence Day - when we are free of Mugabe.'

Asked whether he thought other people would vote for Mugabe because they shared his dislike of whites, Rusike replied: 'No. We are like flowers. All different colours of flower can live in the same garden.'

Albert Phiri, 53, a banker, stood in a queue of more than 500 people at another polling booth in Chitungwiza, a township outside Harare, which has been the scene of mass demonstrations and riots over the country's worsening economy. 'All this stuff about race and land is rubbish. We want change. We want to be modern. Mugabe and his people are dinosaurs. They have no place in a modern world. The old ways must be put in the dustbin for ever.'

Such comments caused a ripple of delight at MDC headquarters yesterday. From rented offices in a city-centre shopping mall, the opposition have spent the last two months campaigning vigorously on behalf of Morgan Tsvangirai, a former leader of the Zimbabwean trade congress, who was imprisoned by Mugabe for six weeks in 1989 on suspicion of being a South African spy.

Aware of international interest in the fate of a country once hailed as an inspiration for all of Africa, the MDC spent much of last week issuing statements about the latest outbreak of violence and organising for camera crews to witness the atrocities.

The strategy outraged Mugabe, who attacked the foreign media for being pro-MDC. He accused local journalists, who had dared to question the government's record, of not being 'sufficiently loyal'.

Buoyed by opinion polls showing the MDC nudging ahead, officials were yesterday already anticipating Mugabe's demise. 'The first thing I am going to do is have the world's largest sale of Mercedes,' said Eddie Cross, who has been promised the post of treasury minister in Tsyangirai's new government. 'I believe we will win a landslide. Mugabe will be forced to resign. We will not put him in jail if he admits to his crimes. We will offer amnesty to all those involved in the violence as long as they tell us what they have done.'

The winner of Zimbabwe's complicated voting system is expected to be declared early this week. As president, Mugabe has powers to appoint 30 seats in the 150-strong parliament. The remaining 120 seats are contested by ballot box. Privately, MDC officials predict they could win as many as 94 seats, a move that would force the president to stand down.

This would prove humiliating for Mugabe and Grace, 36, the president's high-living second wife. Many diplomats chart the decline in Mugabe's fortunes to the day he married his former secretary in 1996, four years after the death from kidney failure of his first wife Sally, a woman revered by the people for her work with the poor.

He had already fathered a child with Grace during his marriage to Sally, who had supported him throughout his years in prison and exile. Following the death of his mother - his father had deserted the family soon after Mugabe's birth - Sally became the most important woman in Mugabe's life, urging him to fight against oppression. They were apart while he oversaw the bush war that defeated Ian Smith's government, leaving the way clear for his election.

His current problems would have been unthinkable then. Under his leadership, Zimbabwe became one of the most prosperous countries on the continent. The sale of precious rocks and food, grown in one of the most fertile climates in the world, earns vast amounts in foreign currency. When the war ended, tourists started flocking into the country to view the abundant game and other attractions such as the Victoria Falls.

Ordinary Zimbabweans were not impressed when they learned that Mugabe's marriage to Grace had cost £1.5m. Nor were they pleased to learn of his trips abroad with his new wife, frequently flying on a jet commandeered from the state airline to fly on shopping trips to London and Cape Town. There was more anger when independent local newspapers published details of the five homes he was building for Grace and her relatives using taxpayers' money, meant to pay for cheap urban homes for impoverished blacks.

'He is utterly obsessed with this woman and cannot make the most simple decision unless she gives the go-ahead,' one former aide was quoted as saying. 'A lot of us date Bob's decline to the death of Sally. Perhaps we blame Grace because she is a woman and we dare not face the fact that we've always followed a madman - a dictator.'

The economy has collapsed this year. Inflation is currently running at 60 per cent, compared with 15 per cent five years ago. Unemployment in some areas is as high as 70 per cent. Mugabe's decision to send 12,000 troops to the Democratic Republic of Congo has not helped. He agreed to the request for help from Laurent Kabila, a former nightclub owner from Dar Es Salam, and now the country's president, who is fighting rebels for control of diamond fields in his country. Some economists estimate the on-going war is costing up to £10m a month.

Yet Mugabe had lost none of his fight last week. Despite international pressure to allow monitors into the country to gauge whether the elections are free and fair, his officials were less than helpful, trying to slow down their movements with bureaucratic hitches.

At the same time, the Central Intelligence Organisation (CI0) - a 2,000 strong secret police force with thousands of paid informants throughout the country - held a series of meetings with Zanu supporters and told them they must ensure MDC supporters are too scared to vote.

Hundreds of people were dragged from farms after co-workers informed on them in return for a £4 bounty. According to intelligence sources and human rights groups, some of those captured were taken to 're-education' camps, where they were beaten and forced to sing pro-Mugabe songs throughout the night.

The testimony was backed up by farm workers interviewed in Hwedza, scene of some of the worst disturbances. Ian Douvenaga, who owns a tobacco farm, told how he watched as a 200-strong gang of Zanu supporters took 30 of his labourers from the property on Friday. 'They were rounded up like cattle,' he said.

Simo Suza, 54, was beaten with a motorcyle chain and made to chant Zanu songs and repeat Mugabe's name. 'They said they would borrow my head if I voted for MDC,' he said. 'I went to the police after I had been treated in hospital. They did not want to know.'

Diplomatic sources believe vote-rigging and intimidation could see the opposition failing to win a majority. 'We will have to assess the level of cheating before we make any official comment,' said a source with the EU delegation. 'We will have to decide whether to declare the elections null and void by next week. But that could create a civil war. It is very difficult.'

Mugabe spent the weekend with Grace awaiting the outcome of the poll, which most observers believe will be excruciatingly close. Not that the prospect of defeat will prove too troublesome for the country's current leader. As the stars came out over Harare last night, Jonathon Moyo, Mugabe's official spokesman, dismissed the prospect of the couple being thrown out of State House, resplendent among the poverty of the capital. 'Remember: there are no rules,' Moyo said. 'The president can make any law he likes. Whatever happens, the government will be formed by Robert Mugabe. You can be sure of that.'

The Mugabe years: from liberty to turmoil in two decades
18 April 1980
Zimbabwe becomes independent. Robert Mugabe is sworn in as Prime Minister after the first multi-racial, majority rule elections in the country. He promises racial reconciliation and embarks on plans to improve health, education and living standards for the country's black population.

June 1983
Mugabe sends the army's Fifth Brigade into the southern Matabeleland provinces to quell a small-scale rebellion by supporters of opposition leader Joshua Nkomo. More than 10,000 Ndebele civilians are killed. The massacres divide Zimbabwe along ethnic lines between the Ndebele (20 per cent of the population) and the Shona (75 per cent).

22 December 1987
Mugabe and Nkomo agree to merge their two nationalist parties. Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party are dominant. Although Nkomo becomes Vice-President and other Ndebeles join the cabinet, the Matabeleland provinces languish and become the country's poorest and least developed.

January 1990
With economic stagnation and growing unemployment, the Mugabe government embarks on an economic programme sponsored by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Rather than cut military spending, he reduces expenditure on health and education.

17 November 1997
Veterans of the war against Rhodesian rule press Mugabe for large 'gratuities' and pensions. Despite an already large budget deficit, Mugabe agrees to pay out Z$5 billion. Already in economic crisis, Zimbabwe's dollar crashes, heralding drastic economic decline.

August 1998
Mugabe deploys 13,000 troops to the Democratic Republic of Congo to prop up threatened President Laurent Kabila. The war is estimated to cost more than US$400 million per year. While some 600 Zimbabweans die and the distant and murky war is highly unpopular, Mugabe, cabinet ministers and army generals benefit from lucrative contracts and diamond mining deals. The war exacerbates Zimbabwe's economic crisis, causing fuel shortages.

15 February 2000
Zimbabwean voters reject Mugabe's proposed constitution, which would have entrenched his presidential powers. Despite public hearings in which citizens called for a reduction of his powers, the draft constitution effectively maintains a one-party state. The defeat of the constitutional referendum shocks Mugabe and his party.

March 2000
Mugabe backs war veterans and other Zanu-PF supporters who invade 1,400 mostly white-owned farms. They say they are eradicating the Rhodesian colonial legacy and reclaiming African land, but the farm invasions are ruled illegal by Zimbabwe's courts and are marked by violence against supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. Mugabe leads a violent campaign for the parliamentary elections in which 32 opposition members are killed.

'I believe we will win a landslide. Mugabe will be forced to resign. We will not put him in jail if he admits to his crimes. We will offer amnesty to all those involved in the violence as long as they tell us what they have done.' The winner of Zimbabwe's complicated voting system is expected to be declared early this week. As president, Mugabe has powers to appoint 30 seats in the 150-strong parliament. The remaining 120 seats are contested by ballot box. Privately, MDC officials predict they could win as many as 94 seats, a move that would force the president to stand down. This would prove humiliating for Mugabe and Grace, 36, the president's high-living second wife. Many diplomats chart the decline in Mugabe's fortunes to the day he married his former secretary in 1996, four years after the death from kidney failure of his first wife Sally, a woman revered by the people for her work with the poor. He had already fathered a child with Grace during his marriage to Sally, who had supported him throughout his years in prison and exile. Following the death of his mother - his father had deserted the family soon after Mugabe's birth - Sally became the most important woman in Mugabe's life, urging him to fight against oppression. They were apart while he oversaw the bush war that defeated Ian Smith's government, leaving the way clear for his election. His current problems would have been unthinkable then. Under his leadership, Zimbabwe became one of the most prosperous countries on the continent. The sale of precious rocks and food, grown in one of the most fertile climates in the world, earns vast amounts in foreign currency. When the war ended, tourists started flocking into the country to view the abundant game and other attractions such as the Victoria Falls. Ordinary Zimbabweans were not impressed when they learned that Mugabe's marriage to Grace had cost £1.5m. Nor were they pleased to learn of his trips abroad with his new wife, frequently flying on a jet commandeered from the state airline to fly on shopping trips to London and Cape Town. There was more anger when independent local newspapers published details of the five homes he was building for Grace and her relatives using taxpayers' money, meant to pay for cheap urban homes for impoverished blacks. 'He is utterly obsessed with this woman and cannot make the most simple decision unless she gives the go-ahead,' one former aide was quoted as saying. 'A lot of us date Bob's decline to the death of Sally. Perhaps we blame Grace because she is a woman and we dare not face the fact that we've always followed a madman - a dictator.' The economy has collapsed this year. Inflation is currently running at 60 per cent, compared with 15 per cent five years ago. Unemployment in some areas is as high as 70 per cent. Mugabe's decision to send 12,000 troops to the Democratic Republic of Congo has not helped. He agreed to the request for help from Laurent Kabila, a former nightclub owner from Dar Es Salam, and now the country's president, who is fighting rebels for control of diamond fields in his country. Some economists estimate the on-going war is costing up to £10m a month. Yet Mugabe had lost none of his fight last week. Despite international pressure to allow monitors into the country to gauge whether the elections are free and fair, his officials were less than helpful, trying to slow down their movements with bureaucratic hitches. At the same time, the Central Intelligence Organisation (CI0) - a 2,000 strong secret police force with thousands of paid informants throughout the country - held a series of meetings with Zanu supporters and told them they must ensure MDC supporters are too scared to vote. Hundreds of people were dragged from farms after co-workers informed on them in return for a £4 bounty. According to intelligence sources and human rights groups, some of those captured were taken to 're-education' camps, where they were beaten and forced to sing pro-Mugabe songs throughout the night. The testimony was backed up by farm workers interviewed in Hwedza, scene of some of the worst disturbances. Ian Douvenaga, who owns a tobacco farm, told how he watched as a 200-strong gang of Zanu supporters took 30 of his labourers from the property on Friday. 'They were rounded up like cattle,' he said. Simo Suza, 54, was beaten with a motorcyle chain and made to chant Zanu songs and repeat Mugabe's name. 'They said they would borrow my head if I voted for MDC,' he said. 'I went to the police after I had been treated in hospital. They did not want to know.' Diplomatic sources believe vote-rigging and intimidation could see the opposition failing to win a majority. 'We will have to assess the level of cheating before we make any official comment,' said a source with the EU delegation. 'We will have to decide whether to declare the elections null and void by next week. But that could create a civil war. It is very difficult.' Mugabe spent the weekend with Grace awaiting the outcome of the poll, which most observers believe will be excruciatingly close. Not that the prospect of defeat will prove too troublesome for the country's current leader. As the stars came out over Harare last night, Jonathon Moyo, Mugabe's official spokesman, dismissed the prospect of the couple being thrown out of State House, resplendent among the poverty of the capital. 'Remember: there are no rules,' Moyo said. 'The president can make any law he likes. Whatever happens, the government will be formed by Robert Mugabe. You can be sure of that.' The Mugabe years: from liberty to turmoil in two decades 18 April 1980 Zimbabwe becomes independent. Robert Mugabe is sworn in as Prime Minister after the first multi-racial, majority rule elections in the country. He promises racial reconciliation and embarks on plans to improve health, education and living standards for the country's black population. June 1983 Mugabe sends the army's Fifth Brigade into the southern Matabeleland provinces to quell a small-scale rebellion by supporters of opposition leader Joshua Nkomo. More than 10,000 Ndebele civilians are killed. The massacres divide Zimbabwe along ethnic lines between the Ndebele (20 per cent of the population) and the Shona (75 per cent). 22 December 1987 Mugabe and Nkomo agree to merge their two nationalist parties. Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party are dominant. Although Nkomo becomes Vice-President and other Ndebeles join the cabinet, the Matabeleland provinces languish and become the country's poorest and least developed. January 1990 With economic stagnation and growing unemployment, the Mugabe government embarks on an economic programme sponsored by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Rather than cut military spending, he reduces expenditure on health and education. 17 November 1997 Veterans of the war against Rhodesian rule press Mugabe for large 'gratuities' and pensions. Despite an already large budget deficit, Mugabe agrees to pay out Z$5 billion. Already in economic crisis, Zimbabwe's dollar crashes, heralding drastic economic decline. August 1998 Mugabe deploys 13,000 troops to the Democratic Republic of Congo to prop up threatened President Laurent Kabila. The war is estimated to cost more than US$400 million per year. While some 600 Zimbabweans die and the distant and murky war is highly unpopular, Mugabe, cabinet ministers and army generals benefit from lucrative contracts and diamond mining deals. The war exacerbates Zimbabwe's economic crisis, causing fuel shortages. 15 February 2000 Zimbabwean voters reject Mugabe's proposed constitution, which would have entrenched his presidential powers. Despite public hearings in which citizens called for a reduction of his powers, the draft constitution effectively maintains a one-party state. The defeat of the constitutional referendum shocks Mugabe and his party. March 2000 Mugabe backs war veterans and other Zanu-PF supporters who invade 1,400 mostly white-owned farms. They say they are eradicating the Rhodesian colonial legacy and reclaiming African land, but the farm invasions are ruled illegal by Zimbabwe's courts and are marked by violence against supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. Mugabe leads a violent campaign for the parliamentary elections in which 32 opposition members are killed.

fields.headline: Heaven help us
fields.standfirst:
William Hague is taking lessons from a US adviser who thinks women politicians defy God's word
Branding Branson is a dangerous game
fields.trailText: William Hague is taking lessons from a US adviser who thinks women politicians defy God's word.
fields.body:
Marvin Olasky, an American of influence accustomed to reverential receptions, found the criticism he received in London last week disturbing and discourteous. The adviser to George W. Bush - who, incredibly, has a good chance of becoming the next leader of the world's only superpower - and confidant of Willie Hague - who, incredibly, has a faint chance of being the leader of its most servile client - was hurt. 'In the context of American history, I am a moderate,' he protested via Conservative Central Office and at a public meeting in Westminster. 'I was surprised that a visitor should be received in such a way by a Government Minister.'

The inhospitable Minister was the Treasury Minister, Stephen Timms, who described the swamp of creationism, class hatred and bigotry from which Marvin emerged as 'repellent'. A Labour Party spokesman went further. Olasky was a 'crank', one said. 'That William Hague has asked him to determine his policies is a cause for serious concern.'

Gleeful newspapers reported that the Tories were now taking advice from a man who would only vote for a woman in desperate circumstances. 'In some situations, I would,' he said in 1998. 'But again, there's a certain shame attached. Why don't you have a man who's able to step forward? God's word says very plainly that an elder is to be a man.'

Reasons to be worried go deeper than standard anti-American contempt. Admittedly, Olasky presents a target which is so easy to hit you'd need formidable self-control not to succumb to the human urge to take a cheap shot. His psychological profile would have fascinated the finest minds in Freud's Vienna. (Olasky began life as a Jew, became a communist atheist and is now a born-again Christian believer in 'Bible-based economics'.) He's taken seriously by Bush and Hague because he learned the wisdom the wannabe statesmen could use as a professor of journalism at Texas University. (Even journalists don't listen to professors of journalism.)

He is the ideologue behind Bush's compassionate conservatism. (Sweet-hearted George, as Governor of Texas, has been the most willing executioner of dubiously and occasionally disgracefully convicted prisoners in recent US history.) He's got a beard. He's called Marvin. What more need be said?

Natural though it is to mock him, there is a danger of falling for the unearned English manner of effortless superiority. Right-wingers can be as patronising as the Left in this regard and see themselves as civilised Greeks to the brutish yank Romans. Everyone can reel off the statistics which show that 90 per cent of Americans believe in the Devil, half go to Church every week and three million believe they were part of a hidden air traffic control crisis when they were abducted by aliens.

The underreported influence of the British religious Right tends to get lost in the sneering and self-congratulation. At the very moment when Westminster pundits are perceiving Hague as a 'credible' candidate, his weird party is going to the fringe and beyond. Hague's meetings with Bush's house philosopher weren't merely a PR blunder.

Last year the Conservative Christian Fellowship moved from its premises in the aptly named Widecombe Court, in the outer London suburb of Finchley, to rooms in Conservative Central Office. The Fellowship was a force in the party before it received the blessing of access to Hague. Ann Widdecombe supported it, of course, as did Peter Lilley, Bill Cash, Olga Maitland and Gary Streeter. What was striking about these Eurosceptic defenders of Britishness was that they embraced an American fundamentalism which had little to do with native religious traditions outside Paisleyite Ulster.

Hague's election as leader was a blow to their hopes. He ran with a gay set of Tory MPs in the early Nineties and showed he was a tolerant fellow when he took charge by supporting homosexual marriage and telling his followers to lay off single mothers. Tim Montgomerie, the Fellowship's director, attacked him for sharing a room with Ffion Jenkins before they were married in the eyes of God. Norman Tebbit raged against finding himself sharing a party 'with those who advocate sodomite marriage'.

Within three years, Hague had come out as the enemy of his former gay friends who wanted the repeal of Clause 28, put the Fellowship geographically and ideologically at the heart of the party and addressed a rally of born-again Christians at the Butlins camp in Minehead with a speech that more than matched the banality of the audience and auditorium.

He has realised he was the prisoner of a dying party and decided to cooperate with his jailers. The average age of Conservative members was 64 in 1997, when the last academic study of the state of British Toryism was completed, and has almost certainly risen since. After the brief cold snap last winter, local Conservative Association newsletters were overloaded with grim but telling obituaries of fallen friends.

The evangelicals, by contrast, were full of vigour. Only by remaining the guardians of our nation's Judaeo-Christian traditions, Montgomerie warned in 1997, could Hague 'attract many Christians and others of traditional belief into the activist-hungry Tory party'. Montgomerie had been inspired by a visit to the US Christian Coalition, who gave him 'high-quality resources'. American fundamentalists 'work in calling that country back to God's laws' was an example to the Conservative leadership.

If Olasky's burblings about women's subordination strike you as bizarre, consider the following passage by Frances Berrill, a regular contributor to the Conservative Christian Fellowships newsletter, in which she describes how she had infiltrated a meeting of the Terrence Higgins Trust on Aids. 'One speaker was a Jewess who had lost her son and the other was a homosexual with Aids.' They spoke with 'a sort of arrogance I found quite intimidating'.

I don't want to be accused of political correctness by dragging up words like anti-Semitism and homophobia. Let's just say that the presence of death couldn't shake her belief that Jewesses were pushy bitches and that gays bullied the silent majority.

The Christian Coalition relies on the support of tele-evangelists. Hague told the God-botherers at Butlins that he would guarantee that 'the next Conservative government will ensure that Christians have the same right to national and digital licences as anyone else'.

Olasky is urging Bush to abolish what little health care there is for the American poor. They will be cared for, if at all, by doctors and nurses popping round to see them in their spare time and getting tax breaks in return. He has already persuaded Bush to hand over welfare to charities. If random compassion fails to provide an adequate safety net, the poor have only themselves to blame because they are 'the victims and perpetrators of illegitimacy and abandonment'.

After meeting Olasky, Hague said he was impressed with the idea that compassionate conservatism meant relying on Lady Bountiful. An aide added that Hague and Olasky didn't want the press to think compassionate conservatism could be confused with softness. 'You shouldn't forget that Texas has more people in prison than any other US state,' he said. As Bush is emptying death rows to get that number down, I don't think it's a mistake many are likely to make.

Branding Branson is a dangerous game

A few years ago I wrote a short piece about the harsh manner in which Virgin Atlantic had treated drivers in its employ. A distraught reader phoned to hear from my lips that the details were accurate. I convinced her that they were and she cried: 'But if you can't trust Richard Branson you can't trust anyone.' I felt like countering, but she was close to tears and I let it go.

Opinion polls show she wasn't an eccentric. They have provided the only convincing argument against abolishing the monarchy by placing Branson as the man most want to see as president of a British republic.

He is the little guy taking on the fuddy-duddies of the Establishment with only a fortune of £2.4 billion and a knighthood from Blair for 'services for entrepreneurship' to help him. The street-fightin' reb image is slightly spoilt, however, by his wielding the Establishment's favourite weapon: the libel courts.

Branson is suing Tom Bower, a brave journalist who took on everything Robert Maxwell's small army of lawyers could throw at him while he prepared a biography of the elephantine crook. His alleged fault is to write in the London Evening Standard about Branson's motives for bidding for the National Lottery. The court debate the detail.

The fate of his bid to produce a 'People's Lottery' free of charge, will be decided this week. Unless you are one of those who believes that Branson is the greatest living Englishman you may be forgiven for asking why he is bothering. Because Branson is a mutton-dressed-as-lamb hipster rather than a sneaker, it is easy to forget that he is just as much a brand as a Nike pump. He has tried branded planes, cola, records, mobile phones wedding dresses, vodka and his terrible trains. Modern business theory holds that producing 'lumpy' goods and services is a trivial task compared to the real endeavour of brand building with every advertising gimmick and brand protecting with corporate lawyers.

If Branson succeeds in getting the lottery he will be the people's friend. His slightly flagging brand will be enhanced and he will be able to attach the his revived logo to whatever lumps he thinks he can sell at a profit.

fields.headline: Why Woy feels let down by his boy
fields.standfirst: It's not Tony Blair's 'second-rate mind' that disappoints Lord Jenkins so much as his failure to give a lead on Europe
fields.trailText: The relationship was beautiful while it lasted. There was the fresh, young prime minister with that knockout parliamentary majority, bursting with vigour but lacking experience. There was the older man, his dwindling interest in British politics rekindled by the excitement of finding this youthful soul-mate, eager to tutor the nubile virgin in the ways of power. They seemed made for each other.
fields.body:
The relationship was beautiful while it lasted. There was the fresh, young prime minister with that knockout parliamentary majority, bursting with vigour but lacking experience. There was the older man, his dwindling interest in British politics rekindled by the excitement of finding this youthful soul-mate, eager to tutor the nubile virgin in the ways of power. They seemed made for each other.

Tony Blair and Roy Jenkins romanced over lunches at Chequers, intimate dinners at Number 10, and cosy tete-à-tetes in the Prime Minister's study. Tony found Labour politicians of Roy's vintage rather avuncularly patronising. Roy was witty, wise and had a flatteringly high estimation of Tony. The older man believed that the younger man would fulfil his unrequited passions. The two had good-natured arguments about which of them invented the phrase 'radical century'. But the desire to heal the breach between Labour and the Liberal Democrats to construct a progressive coalition which would dominate the twenty-first century seemed to be mutual. So, too, did an enthusiasm to place Britain at the heart of Europe

Time passed. Tony continued to whisper soft words, but Roy became frustrated that they never reached consumation. He presented Tony with a most handsome, hand-crafted report recommending a new voting system for Westminster. Tony, who was never less than polite, said it looked nice. Then he stuck it at the back of his sock drawer.

As for Europe, Roy kept nagging and writing to Tony telling him to be more positive. Tony pleaded he would like to be, but Gordon wouldn't let him. Gordon Brown! Always the problem. Gordon was cool towards Europe, and cold about proportional representation. Then, he went on a rampage against élitism and trashed Roy's beloved Oxford University. Roy told Tony he would never get an honorary degree after that. He was Thatchered. So there. He shared some of his pain with the Spectator, telling the magazine's agony aunt, Boris Johnson that Tony is a 'second rate mind'. So it all ends in tears.

Not quite. What I would next expect is the Prime Minister to swiftly kiss and make-up with Lord Jenkins, who says he still regards Tony as a 'very agreeable companion'. Tony will be sending an invitation to dinner even now, if it has not plopped on Roy's doormat already. That was certainly what happened last time Roy had a little outburst of disappointment with the younger man.

We can also have a pretty good guess at what Mr Blair will say to his old friend, because it is what he has been saying for more than three years now to everyone who grows impatient with his failure to give a stronger lead on Europe or make a decision about changing the voting system.

Give me time is the nub of his reassurances. When the stars have moved into a favourable constellation and the moon is pulling the tide in the right direction, then he will announce himself in unequivocal colours for the single currency. As he said last week: 'If I recommend to the British people that we join the euro, I will make the case for it as strongly and powerfully as you could possibly hear.' Dazzled by the sheer force of Mr Blair's persuasive abilities, the current two to one majority against the single currency will be converted into an endorsement of the euro. Just like that.

I am sure the Prime Minister believes this. So why does such a previously ardent admirer as Lord Jenkins now doubt him? Mr Blair will have to jump several fences which he has previously shied from, and one which he has not had to bother about before. The Cabinet has so far been excluded from all the big economic decisions. The Bank of England was given its independence and the suck-it-and-see policy towards the euro adopted, without a debate, never mind a vote, around the top table. John Prescott tells us that it will be different when it comes to the single currency. His assertion that the Cabinet will decide is not just meant as a rebuke to Gordon Brown's claim that the Treasury is the sole judge of the famous five tests, but also as a warning to the Prime Minister.

Still, if Brown and Blair were agreed, I'd expect them to overcome any Cabinet opposition to entering the single currency. But will they agree? The dispute between them boils down to economics versus politics.

For Blair, joining the euro is the golden swipecard that finally opens the door to the throneroom of Europe. Despite the tactical victory over the withholding tax, strategically the prime minister is not fulfilling his self-perceived destiny to be a leader in Europe. He is trying to resist the Franco-German push for a fast-track élite. We can't, protests the prime minister, have a Europe of 'two speeds'. But as his friend - or should this also be former friend? - Gerhard Schröder correctly says, there are already two speeds on the eurobahn: those who are in the single currency, and those who are not. The prime minister cannot look forward to the day when he is still on the hard shoulder while the Greeks have joined the acceleration lane.

The idea of joining the single currency to satisfy the prime minister's political urges is privately regarded with contempt by the Chancellor. Gordon Brown is deadly serious about meeting the economic tests of which he proclaims the Treasury to be 'the guardian'. That's not to say that calculations about power don't also consume Brown and all the time. His quest to become prime minister isn't hurt by his current hero status among the Europhobic press. What could utterly destroy his ambitions for the succession is a referendum on the euro which is lost. It would be a potentially mortal blow, and certainly a savage one, to his credibility as well that of the prime minister.

That brings us to the highest hurdle that Tony Blair will have to get over, which is himself. The prime minister is not going to persuade the country to make the leap until he has the courage to make one himself. Au fond, as Roy Jenkins would say, Blair did not hold a referendum just after the election because even when he was immensely popular he did not think he would win it. It wasn't worth gambling the second term on the single currency. This Prime Minister is capable of taking great gambles for large rewards, as he demonstrated most notably in Northern Ireland and Kosovo. But crab-like caution has been his more abiding characteristic. The only previous time that comes to mind when he made a vault of faith in the face of public and media hostility was the Millennium Dome. That is not an auspicious precedent.

Is Tony Blair likely to feel more or less courageous after the next election when he will have a smaller majority and face a more potent Tory Party?

He will still insist that he was right not to call a referendum on the euro immediately after the last election. What he has been heard to express private sighs of semi-regret about is that he missed the moment to fulfil the other half of The Project by forming a coalition with the Liberal Democrats. I am sure that when he tells Lord Jenkins this, it is not just to string the older man along. The hurdles to be crossed are almost identical to those in the case of the euro: a referendum with an unpredictable outcome; the right-wing press; John Prescott and Gordon Brown; and the Prime Minister's own divided mind.

At least, unlike the euro, there is a Third Way. The Prime Minister is talking warmly, in private, about the Alternative Vote. It would have worked at the last election to smash the Conservatives even more thoroughly. AV is not proportional; it actually tends to exaggerate the swing. There was the older man, his dwindling interest in British politics rekindled by the excitement of finding this youthful soul-mate, eager to tutor the nubile virgin in the ways of power. They seemed made for each other. Tony Blair and Roy Jenkins romanced over lunches at Chequers, intimate dinners at Number 10, and cosy tete-à-tetes in the Prime Minister's study. Tony found Labour politicians of Roy's vintage rather avuncularly patronising. Roy was witty, wise and had a flatteringly high estimation of Tony. The older man believed that the younger man would fulfil his unrequited passions. The two had good-natured arguments about which of them invented the phrase 'radical century'. But the desire to heal the breach between Labour and the Liberal Democrats to construct a progressive coalition which would dominate the twenty-first century seemed to be mutual. So, too, did an enthusiasm to place Britain at the heart of Europe Time passed. Tony continued to whisper soft words, but Roy became frustrated that they never reached consumation. He presented Tony with a most handsome, hand-crafted report recommending a new voting system for Westminster. Tony, who was never less than polite, said it looked nice. Mr Blair will have to jump several fences which he has previously shied from, and one which he has not had to bother about before. Despite the tactical victory over the withholding tax, strategically the prime minister is not fulfilling his self-perceived destiny to be a leader in Europe. He is trying to resist the Franco-German push for a fast-track élite. We can't, protests the prime minister, have a Europe of 'two speeds'. fields.headline: Zimbabwe must vote for freedom
fields.standfirst: Its only hope is if Mugabe goes
fields.trailText: The people of Zimbabwe will complete their business at the country's polling stations today, a process we hope will result in an emphatic rejection of Zanu-PF, the party of President Robert Mugabe. We also hope Mr Mugabe will heed the message and relinquish his hold on a country that he has guided from independence, through an initial flush of economic success to the brink of economic and social disaster which now threatens to infect all of southern Africa. As Zimbabweans vote it is worth reflecting why Mugabe should go, and why Zimbabwe should reject him.
fields.body:
The people of Zimbabwe will complete their business at the country's polling stations today, a process we hope will result in an emphatic rejection of Zanu-PF, the party of President Robert Mugabe. We also hope Mr Mugabe will heed the message and relinquish his hold on a country that he has guided from independence, through an initial flush of economic success to the brink of economic and social disaster which now threatens to infect all of southern Africa. As Zimbabweans vote it is worth reflecting why Mugabe should go, and why Zimbabwe should reject him.

It is not - despite the sound and fury from his critics among Britain's right-wing commentators - because he has championed redistributive land reform that would take from the minority white farmers to give to his country's increasingly impoverished rural blacks. It is not even because of his gratuitous abuse and confrontational stance towards the Tony Blair government, which have brought relations between the former colony and the colonial power to a new low. It is rather the brutal way in which Mugabe and his henchmen have used these issues to distract from economic and political failures and from the creeping despotism of his rule. The strongest case for Mugabe's ejection from power is his conduct throughout the present elections, where the former hero of the struggle for independence has blatantly rejected all democratic norms.

The murders and beatings meted out to members of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change; the intimidation of voters; the harassment and kidnapping of international election monitors all make an incontrovertible case for Mugabe's removal from office. These are all issues untainted by British self-interest.

Zimbabwe has the potential to be one of Africa's genuine success stories and an inspiration to other countries in a deeply troubled continent. For despite the recent depredations of Mugabe's rule, despite Zimbabwe's increasingly shameful and self-interested engagement in the war in the Congo, despite attacks on the free press and the undermining of its political system, it still retains the democratic foundations upon which can be built a successful, functioning modern state. The first step is the courageous rejection by the electorate of the violence, corruption and intimidation that Mugabe and his cronies have represented.

webTitle: Queen Mother was 'ruthless' to royal nanny

fields.headline: Queen Mother was 'ruthless' to royal nanny
fields.standfirst: Love for princesses kept truth hidden
fields.trailText: A portrait of the Queen Mother as ruthless and unforgiving has emerged from the discovery of a 50-year-old box of letters and legal papers.
fields.body:
A portrait of the Queen Mother as ruthless and unforgiving has emerged from the discovery of a 50-year-old box of letters and legal papers.

The documents, which The Observer has discovered are due to be released to the public after the matriarch's death, belonged to the late Marion Crawford, nanny to the royal princesses.

Now held by Crawford's solicitor, the private papers show that the Queen Mother was secretly involved in a government plan to sell anecdotes about her daughters' childhood to an American magazine - a publicity stunt for which the nanny was pilloried for the rest of her life.

The revelations came to light as a result of research carried out for a Channel 4 documentary and have been criticised this weekend by Lord St John of Fawsley, the royal commentator, as a 'strange kind of birthday present' for the Queen Mother, who will be 100 on 4 August.

Crawford, or 'Crawfie' as the princesses Elizabeth and Margaret both knew her, was an intimate companion of the royal family for 17 years, but was ostracised for supposedly selling her story to the press without the permission of her former employers. In fact, the deal was brokered with the Palace by the Foreign Office, who believed the magazine articles would be good for Anglo-American relations.

Childless and separated in later life from the famous sisters she had cared for, Crawfie attempted to commit suicide twice, nearly succeeding in the late Eighties. She eventually succumbed to cancer and died alone in a nursing home - but not before passing on a number of key documents to her solicitor, Bruce Russell, with instructions that they should be released once they could no longer hurt those involved.

Among them is a letter, never seen before, which forms a central part of the programme to be broadcast tomorrow evening. Typewritten, it appears to come from the then Queen and is addressed in informal terms to Crawfie.

'I do feel, most definitely, that you should not write and sign articles about the children, as people in positions of confidence with us must be utterly oyster,' it reads.

'I know you understand this, because you have been so wonderfully discreet all the years you were with us.'

But the letter goes on to refer to a Times journalist, Dermot Morrah, who had been engaged to write pieces based on information supplied to him by Crawfie: 'Mr Morrah, who I saw the other day, seemed to think that you could help him with his articles and get paid from America. This would be quite all right as long as your name did not come into it.'

The royal writer, Anthony Holden, believes the discoveries prove that the popular, 'pearly queen' image of the Queen Mother is far from the steely truth.

'Crawfie was extremely badly treated by the Queen Mother and by all the royals,' he said. 'It is symptomatic of the ruthless and brutal cold-heartedness of that family and of the way they treat the victims they leave in their wake who, including Diana, have generally done them great service.'

For 30 years - during which time she was publicly vilified for her apparent treachery - Crawfie protected her former royal employer by keeping these letters hidden. According to her friends and relatives, she felt her life had been ruined by the Queen Mother's decision to cut all ties.

'She always hoped for a reconciliation, but it never came,' her close friend and confidant Nigel Astell said on Friday. 'Crawfie was intensely loyal and would not use the letters to defend herself, even though they showed she had being acting in good faith.'

Crawford's husband, George Buthlay, signed a contract on her behalf with the American magazine publishers Bruce and Beatrice Gould, of the Ladies' Home Journal. In contradiction to the wishes of the Queen Mother, Crawfie was clearly named as the source. She and her husband were paid $85,000 for the pieces, but for the doting nanny the price was to prove much greater.

The Queen and the King immediately broke all contact with the young teacher from Fife they had chosen for their children back in 1930. A bestselling book called The Little Princesses appeared in 1950 and soon Crawfie had been offered her own, ghosted column in Woman's Own .

'I hope the truth will finally come out,' said Astell. 'That is what Crawfie wanted. She loved Elizabeth and Margaret and could never quite believe what happened to her.'

'Crawfie, The Royal Nanny Who Wouldn't Stay Mum' will be on Channel 4 at 9pm tomorrow.

fields.headline: Whose side is God on?
fields.standfirst: William Hague has been consulting a Christian fundamentalist. Now Tony Blair is making a pilgrimage to a leading Swiss theologian. Why this new concern with religion?
fields.trailText: William Hague has been consulting a Christian fundamentalist. Now Tony Blair is making a pilgrimage to a leading Swiss theologian. Why this new concern with religion?
fields.body:
On a warm autumnal day in September 1997 Tony and Cherie Blair made their way to St Peter's Parish Church in Brighton. The mood was positive on that Sunday, and Millbank, keen to ride the wave of euphoria that had greeted Blair's victory in May, decided that it was time for some good publicity.

Photographers and television camera crews were discreetly invited to the church and asked to be in position before the Blairs arrived. They expected a few shots near the door. But the Labour Party official wanted more. No, come in, he said. Take some pictures of them inside the church. You can stand on the pews if you like, to get better shots.

The following day the pictures appeared across the front pages - the Blairs at worship, he in dark grey suit with white shirt and black and gold check tie, she in smart black suit. In the background the stained glass windows could clearly be seen.

The picture said everything about Blair and religion - the awkwardness at having a media scrum pile into the church after him and the knowledge that Christianity makes up a deeply-held part of his beliefs and should not be hidden.

It also says much about Britain's relationship with religion. Largely unspoken, politicians know that they play the Christianity card at their peril. Play it too hard and voters believe you are trying to exploit God. Blair has suffered from a perception that his politics is of the 'holier-than-thou' variety.

But don't play it at all and you risk falling into the trap of vacuity, with talk of 'community' and 'values' which lacks the essential religious underpinning. 'We know that Blair has sincere beliefs but he doesn't articulate them,' said John Wilkins, editor of the Catholic newspaper, the Tablet. 'That makes it difficult to understand his vision.'

On Friday in the small southern German town of Tübingen, Blair will take a calculated risk at changing that perception. He will speak in front of an overtly religious audience. He will talk about ethics and community values as the guest of one of Europe's most challenging religious figures - Hans Küng, the Swiss radical theologian who is known as the Catholic who dared fall out with the Vatican. Küng is one of Blair's religious mentors and the meeting will cement their relationship.

Some British government officials based in Germany have raised eyebrows at the politics of the meeting. Last week William Hague invited the right-wing American professor, Marvin Olasky, to guide his party's thinking on 'compassionate Conservatism'. His arrival sparked a flurry of comment and analysis on the role of religion in British politics. Could Olasky, who argues that benefits should be given only to those who deserve it, really have anything to add to the British political debate? Blair stayed out of the fray. This week he will enter it and the spotlight will turn from Olasky to Küng.

Blair and Küng first met last year after Blair had expressed an interest in Küng's writings on global ethics. The Prime Minister will deliver the first in a series of lectures organised by the 72-year-old's Global Ethics Foundation, which is committed to linking human rights with clearly defined responsibilities. Küng, who has been in conflict with the Catholic Church for more than 20 years, clearly believes that Blair is just the man to lead the ethical charge.

'He knew me first by my books, especially my book On Being a Christian, and I met him in London,' Küng said last week. 'I was very much impressed by his very serious commitment in the Northern Ireland peace process, which was only possible because he committed himself personally.'

Küng, whose other books include Does God Exist? and Yes to a Global Ethic , acknowledges that believers do not have a monopoly on ethics. But he is convinced that religious faith is an advantage for a political leader.

Acclaimed as one of the most brilliant Catholic thinkers of his generation, Küng was an adviser to the Second Vatican Council in 1962, but his liberal views on birth control and human sexuality brought him into conflict with the authorities. When he questioned the infallibility of the Pope in 1979, the Church withdrew his permission to teach theology but he remained a professor in Tübingen, adored by liberal Catholics, especially in Germany.

'I am still a Catholic priest in good standing. I can say Mass and preach and, being an emeritus now means it doesn't matter whether I have this canonical approval,' he said. He counts Henry Kissinger, Germany's former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, former US President Jimmy Carter and Lord Callaghan among his friends and admirers. His foundation, which has produced films and a television series as well as books and academic papers, is funded by an aristocratic industrialist, Count Karl Konrad von der Gröben.

Küng believes that human rights are directly linked to responsibilities and that, instead of a culture of human rights, the developed world has created 'a perverse culture based on exaggerated claims' where individual rights are played off against one another. Although he maintains that everyone is entitled to certain fundamental rights, he supports tough policies on such issues as unemployment benefits.

'Human dignity consists of both, to have rights and responsibilities. If somebody just does not want to work because he is lazy, then it is not a fundamental human right to be lazy and to be protected in his laziness,' he said. Küng favours Blair's 'working hard for hard-working familes' and 'no rights without responsibilities' mantras. There is no doubt about the warmth of the theologian's approval for Blair.

'He and his wife, one Anglican and one Catholic, they had from the beginning a certain ethical approach to life, rooted in religion, and I think that's already one guarantee,' Küng said. 'When he told me that it is intolerable that in the 21st century we still have fights and battles between Catholics and Protestants in one part of Europe, I think he is passionately committed to this. I think if you compare him with his predecessor, you see the whole difference.'

Blair and the Labour Party's relationship with religion has always been a difficult one. In 1996 Blair wrote an article in the Sunday Telegraph, saying: 'I can't stand politicians who wear God on their sleeves; I do not pretend to be any better or less selfish than anyone else, I do not believe that Christians should only vote Labour.'

But he stirred up a hornets' nest of controversy when he continued: 'My view of Christian values led me to oppose what I perceived to be the narrow view of self-interest that Conservatism - particularly its modern, more right-wing form - represents.'

The right-wing press called for Blair's head, accusing him of trying to play the God card to his own advantage. Simon Heffer, in the Daily Mail, called Blair 'naive' and asserted that his 'grasp of theology is at an elementary level of philosophy'. In his 1995 conference speech Blair spoke about the need for spiritual renewal and the need to bring the soul and morality back into politics.

His Tübingen speech next Friday, it is believed, will draw heavily on his Third Way philosophy of traditional community values in a modern setting. Blair has told friends that he will not use it as a platform to boast about his religion, a good move given Britain's ambivalence to such messages. But the very fact of meeting Küng makes its own point.

Much of Blair's language of spiritual responsibility comes from his long time friend, Peter Thomson, who Blair met when he was at Oxford. It was Thomson, an Australian farmer once described as a 'bit of a hell-raiser', who introduced the Prime Minister to a range of Christian thinkers back in the Seventies. He was also a central influence on Blair becoming an Anglican.

'We had very solid sessions about relating faith to politics,' Thomson once said of his time with Blair discussing religion late into the night at St John's College. Thomson was a mature student whose beliefs fitted well with Blair - personal spiritualism allied with a desire that the Church should reach out into secular society. Blair described Thomson's thoughts on religion and society as 'spellbinding'.

Thomson introduced Blair to another religious thinker who became an important influence on the Prime Minister. The Scottish philosopher, John Macmurray, a one-time Communist who became a Quaker, argued that the Church was seen as condescending, which had led to an increasing secularisation of society. The growth of liberal individualism had starved people of love and a feeling of community, according to Macmurray.

In power, Blair has been more circumspect about his religion, promoting himself as an ecumenical 'big-tenter', willing to learn from all faiths. In an interview with Muslim News in March he said the Islamic faith was 'a deeply reflective, peaceful, very beautiful religious faith'. He has read the Koran and has taken an interest in Hindu teachings. He has a similar outlook to that of Prince Charles, who has discussed being 'defender of faiths' when he becomes King rather than simply 'defender of the faith'. It was Blair who supported controversial moves to give separate Muslim schools state funding on a par with Catholic and Jewish schools.

At his ill-fated Women's Institute speech, he said there needed to be renewed support for the Church's work in the community. Blair's speech in Germany will re-ignite the debate about politics and religion. It is one that he has said he will write himself. The last time he did that, the WI rewarded him with a slow handclap. Küng's Global Foundation will surely be more polite.

Blair's God Squad

Hans Küng

Swiss theologian, fell out with Catholic Church over abortion and sexuality. First met Blair last year, who was impressed with Küng's teachings on global ethics. Blair gives inaugural lecture to Küng's Global Ethics Foundation on Friday, and New Labour's seal of approval.
Words of wisdom:
'The dynamics generated by the rapid expansion of technological progress are unprecedented. To ensure that economic performance is subordinated to human and social goals, globalisation needs political underpinnings and an ethical framework.'

Peter Thomson

One of Blair's closest friends, the Australian farmer was a student alongside him at St John's College, Oxford. Introduced him to the Anglican Church and agreed to come back to Britain in 1996 to be on call in run-up to general election. Prime Minister has dragged his family to Thomson's remote farm for holidays.
Words of wisdom:
'There was no point in saying faith is only about the church - what about the rest of creation? The church still relates to secular society in a patronising, condescending way. But secularisation is in part a liberation.'

Rt Rev Graham Dow

At present Bishop of Willesden, London, Dow is about to become Bishop of Carlisle. A Christian socialist, he was a chaplain at St John's College when Blair was a student. He has followed his former protégé's career closely.
Words of wisdom:
'Thatcher brought the right and wrong back into politics, now Blair is bringing God back. He is tapping into a deep unease in evidence all over the country of people who are anxious about losing the foundations of our Christian heritage, of discarding 1,300 years of faith.'
