Play it too hard and voters believe you are trying to exploit God. Blair has suffered from a perception that his politics is of the 'holier-than-thou' variety. But don't play it at all and you risk falling into the trap of vacuity, with talk of 'community' and 'values' which lacks the essential religious underpinning. 'We know that Blair has sincere beliefs but he doesn't articulate them,' said John Wilkins, editor of the Catholic newspaper, the Tablet. 'That makes it difficult to understand his vision.' On Friday in the small southern German town of Tübingen, Blair will take a calculated risk at changing that perception. He will speak in front of an overtly religious audience. He will talk about ethics and community values as the guest of one of Europe's most challenging religious figures - Hans Küng, the Swiss radical theologian who is known as the Catholic who dared fall out with the Vatican. Küng is one of Blair's religious mentors and the meeting will cement their relationship. Some British government officials based in Germany have raised eyebrows at the politics of the meeting. Last week William Hague invited the right-wing American professor, Marvin Olasky, to guide his party's thinking on 'compassionate Conservatism'. His arrival sparked a flurry of comment and analysis on the role of religion in British politics. Could Olasky, who argues that benefits should be given only to those who deserve it, really have anything to add to the British political debate? Blair stayed out of the fray. This week he will enter it and the spotlight will turn from Olasky to Küng. Blair and Küng first met last year after Blair had expressed an interest in Küng's writings on global ethics. The Prime Minister will deliver the first in a series of lectures organised by the 72-year-old's Global Ethics Foundation, which is committed to linking human rights with clearly defined responsibilities. Küng, who has been in conflict with the Catholic Church for more than 20 years, clearly believes that Blair is just the man to lead the ethical charge. 'He knew me first by my books, especially my book On Being a Christian, and I met him in London,' Küng said last week. 'I was very much impressed by his very serious commitment in the Northern Ireland peace process, which was only possible because he committed himself personally.' Küng, whose other books include Does God Exist? and Yes to a Global Ethic , acknowledges that believers do not have a monopoly on ethics. But he is convinced that religious faith is an advantage for a political leader. Acclaimed as one of the most brilliant Catholic thinkers of his generation, Küng was an adviser to the Second Vatican Council in 1962, but his liberal views on birth control and human sexuality brought him into conflict with the authorities. When he questioned the infallibility of the Pope in 1979, the Church withdrew his permission to teach theology but he remained a professor in Tübingen, adored by liberal Catholics, especially in Germany. 'I am still a Catholic priest in good standing. I can say Mass and preach and, being an emeritus now means it doesn't matter whether I have this canonical approval,' he said. He counts Henry Kissinger, Germany's former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, former US President Jimmy Carter and Lord Callaghan among his friends and admirers. His foundation, which has produced films and a television series as well as books and academic papers, is funded by an aristocratic industrialist, Count Karl Konrad von der Gröben. Küng believes that human rights are directly linked to responsibilities and that, instead of a culture of human rights, the developed world has created 'a perverse culture based on exaggerated claims' where individual rights are played off against one another. Although he maintains that everyone is entitled to certain fundamental rights, he supports tough policies on such issues as unemployment benefits. 'Human dignity consists of both, to have rights and responsibilities. If somebody just does not want to work because he is lazy, then it is not a fundamental human right to be lazy and to be protected in his laziness,' he said. Küng favours Blair's 'working hard for hard-working familes' and 'no rights without responsibilities' mantras. There is no doubt about the warmth of the theologian's approval for Blair. 'He and his wife, one Anglican and one Catholic, they had from the beginning a certain ethical approach to life, rooted in religion, and I think that's already one guarantee,' Küng said. 'When he told me that it is intolerable that in the 21st century we still have fights and battles between Catholics and Protestants in one part of Europe, I think he is passionately committed to this. I think if you compare him with his predecessor, you see the whole difference.' Blair and the Labour Party's relationship with religion has always been a difficult one. In 1996 Blair wrote an article in the Sunday Telegraph, saying: 'I can't stand politicians who wear God on their sleeves; I do not pretend to be any better or less selfish than anyone else, I do not believe that Christians should only vote Labour.' But he stirred up a hornets' nest of controversy when he continued: 'My view of Christian values led me to oppose what I perceived to be the narrow view of self-interest that Conservatism - particularly its modern, more right-wing form - represents.' The right-wing press called for Blair's head, accusing him of trying to play the God card to his own advantage. Simon Heffer, in the Daily Mail, called Blair 'naive' and asserted that his 'grasp of theology is at an elementary level of philosophy'. In his 1995 conference speech Blair spoke about the need for spiritual renewal and the need to bring the soul and morality back into politics. His Tübingen speech next Friday, it is believed, will draw heavily on his Third Way philosophy of traditional community values in a modern setting. Blair has told friends that he will not use it as a platform to boast about his religion, a good move given Britain's ambivalence to such messages. But the very fact of meeting Küng makes its own point. Much of Blair's language of spiritual responsibility comes from his long time friend, Peter Thomson, who Blair met when he was at Oxford. It was Thomson, an Australian farmer once described as a 'bit of a hell-raiser', who introduced the Prime Minister to a range of Christian thinkers back in the Seventies. He was also a central influence on Blair becoming an Anglican. 'We had very solid sessions about relating faith to politics,' Thomson once said of his time with Blair discussing religion late into the night at St John's College. Thomson was a mature student whose beliefs fitted well with Blair - personal spiritualism allied with a desire that the Church should reach out into secular society. Blair described Thomson's thoughts on religion and society as 'spellbinding'. Thomson introduced Blair to another religious thinker who became an important influence on the Prime Minister. The Scottish philosopher, John Macmurray, a one-time Communist who became a Quaker, argued that the Church was seen as condescending, which had led to an increasing secularisation of society. The growth of liberal individualism had starved people of love and a feeling of community, according to Macmurray. In power, Blair has been more circumspect about his religion, promoting himself as an ecumenical 'big-tenter', willing to learn from all faiths. In an interview with Muslim News in March he said the Islamic faith was 'a deeply reflective, peaceful, very beautiful religious faith'. He has read the Koran and has taken an interest in Hindu teachings. He has a similar outlook to that of Prince Charles, who has discussed being 'defender of faiths' when he becomes King rather than simply 'defender of the faith'. It was Blair who supported controversial moves to give separate Muslim schools state funding on a par with Catholic and Jewish schools. At his ill-fated Women's Institute speech, he said there needed to be renewed support for the Church's work in the community. Blair's speech in Germany will re-ignite the debate about politics and religion. It is one that he has said he will write himself. The last time he did that, the WI rewarded him with a slow handclap. Küng's Global Foundation will surely be more polite. Blair's God Squad Hans Küng Swiss theologian, fell out with Catholic Church over abortion and sexuality. First met Blair last year, who was impressed with Küng's teachings on global ethics. Blair gives inaugural lecture to Küng's Global Ethics Foundation on Friday, and New Labour's seal of approval. Words of wisdom: 'The dynamics generated by the rapid expansion of technological progress are unprecedented. To ensure that economic performance is subordinated to human and social goals, globalisation needs political underpinnings and an ethical framework.' Peter Thomson One of Blair's closest friends, the Australian farmer was a student alongside him at St John's College, Oxford. Introduced him to the Anglican Church and agreed to come back to Britain in 1996 to be on call in run-up to general election. Prime Minister has dragged his family to Thomson's remote farm for holidays. Words of wisdom: 'There was no point in saying faith is only about the church - what about the rest of creation? The church still relates to secular society in a patronising, condescending way. But secularisation is in part a liberation.' Rt Rev Graham Dow At present Bishop of Willesden, London, Dow is about to become Bishop of Carlisle. A Christian socialist, he was a chaplain at St John's College when Blair was a student. He has followed his former protégé's career closely. Words of wisdom: 'Thatcher brought the right and wrong back into politics, now Blair is bringing God back. He is tapping into a deep unease in evidence all over the country of people who are anxious about losing the foundations of our Christian heritage, of discarding 1,300 years of faith.'

fields.headline: Virgin in peak-time rail fare 'rip-off'
fields.trailText: Passengers are paying twice as much for almost identical journeys this month on Virgin trains after the company exploited a loophole in rail rules on pricing.
fields.byline: by Sarah Ryle, consumer affairs correspondent
fields.body:
Passengers are paying twice as much for almost identical journeys this month on Virgin trains after the company exploited a loophole in rail rules on pricing.

Virgin says it advertised the changes six months ago - but an Observer investigation into passenger complaints reveals that customers feel ripped off by the manoeuvre.

Rail regulation allows train companies to change their definition of peak time. Virgin has extended its peak period by an hour from 9.30am so saver tickets cannot be used until 10.30. Its inter-city rival on the east coast routes, GNER, still has peak time ending at 9.30am.

Company director Peter Jenkins told The Observer: 'I used to get the train at about 10am to get to Manchester from London for meetings. I turned up the other morning and they told me it would cost £90 unless I went on the 10.53am. I asked why and the man at the counter said: "It's because business travellers were getting away with murder."

'I run a small business and I don't think it's fair. I have to take the earlier train, which is now far emptier than it used to be, so I can't see how it has helped them.' Another passenger, a television director, said she wrote to complain about the new prices. Virgin wrote back telling her that it changed the policy because it thought business travellers were getting too good a deal.

A Virgin spokeswoman denied business travellers are being targeted and said the company is having to put some fares up to replace dwindling government subsidy.

Other train companies have quietly axed services during the last couple of weeks. Another traveller is now forced to use Virgin's service to Warrington because the First North Western train she used to catch from Euston to Newton-le-Willows has been withdrawn. 'I used to pay £23,' she said. 'They just took the service off. There are no notices at the station about it. I was told on Friday that I have to buy a ticket for £45 and that I cannot travel between 4pm and 6.15pm.'

Ernie Preston, of the Rail Passenger Council north-east branch said:'Train companies are commercial and they have an obligation to make as much money for their shareholders as they can, so you cannot blame them. The rail regulator should not have adopted such a bad definition of what constituted a saver ticket.'

According to RPC research, the rise in the average fare between January 1996 and January 2000 was 15 per cent compared with inflation of 11 per cent.

The biggest increases have hit passengers relying on unregulated, 'walk-on' fares - but the new restrictions on saver tickets by Virgin show that even regulated tickets are now affected.

'It is passengers who use services operated by the former InterCity train companies that appear to have suffered the largest average fare rises - Virgin West Coast, Virgin Cross Country and GNER in particular,' the report concluded last month.

webTitle: Why people are dying to come to Britain

fields.headline: Why people are dying to come to Britain
fields.standfirst: The deaths of 58 Chinese at Dover revealed the full extent of a criminal trade in human misery that looks set to force Europe to open up its borders
fields.trailText: The deaths of 58 Chinese at Dover revealed the full extent of a criminal trade in human misery that looks set to force Europe to open up its borders.
fields.body:
Like many villages in the south-eastern provinces of China, Fuquing has seen changes in the past few years. Now there are concrete pavements and a newly landscaped town square. A care and cultural centre for senior citizens has recently opened. Above the traditional squat brick houses rise six-storey mansions topped by huge white satellite dishes and full of crystal and gold.

On a burnished plaque on the wall of a clothes shop an inscription praises a local hero: a 22-year-old who two years ago left his home to seek his fortune in Europe. He was the man who funded the street improvements. A cornerstone in the old people's centre lauds the generosity of another expatriate.

The number of people who have left Fuquing and Changle - the nearby town that was home to most of the 54 men and four women found dead in a container lorry at Dover last Sunday - has led to the coining of a morbid nickname. Fuquing and Changle are, the locals say, 'widows' villages', a term hardly fitting the lively and increasingly wealthy little towns. But this weekend their nickname has never seemed so apposite.

On 19 February a smartly dressed 19-year-old called Chen Lin left his Fuquing home and walked to the railway station. He took a train to Beijing, the Chinese capital, more than 1,000 miles to the north. He had a few possessions, a little money and almost no idea of what his itinerary would be. He was, close relatives told The Observer last week, entirely in the hands of the sh'e tau' - or 'snakeheads' - the local gang leaders who run the human trafficking trade. His family had paid them the equivalent of £14,000 to get Chen Lin to the UK. With his death, it will take them five years to pay off the debt.

Chen Lin's family tracked the young man's progress across Asia. At irregular intervals the 'snakes' - as clandestine emigrants are known in China - would call home. From Beijing the group were taken, by rail, to Moscow.

Then they were moved by car, truck and even horse-drawn cart across the steppes of southern Russia, through the Ukraine and eventually, after a four-day trek over mountains, into the Czech Republic. They were driven through Germany, into Holland and ended up at Zeebrugge where they were loaded into a refrigerated lorry full of tomatoes.

Around four hours later - when customs officials opened the rear doors at Dover - 58 were dead. Gasping under a pile of twisted corpses were two half-comatose survivors. The group had simply run out of oxygen. As they died they freed up air for others. Enough for two.

On Friday a Dutch lorry-driver was charged by a British court with 58 counts of manslaughter and remanded in custody for a week. The Dutch owner of the company which had registered the lorry has been arrested in Holland. Two Chinese appeared in court yesterday charged with conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry to the UK. No one expects swift results, despite the resources that have been allocated to the inquiry from the Kent police team.

But the question of responsibility for the tragedy will not be answered in the courtroom alone. Do we blame the parents who, hoping for a better life for their children, save for years to send their best and brightest to the West? Or the traffickers who, often having made the journey themselves, decide to look for faster ways to get rich than washing dishes in a restaurant? Or the Western governments who have failed to tackle the problem?

Or, sitting in our safe European homes with an eye on the world's less fortunate and a hand on the security hardware catalogue, are we all, to some degree, responsible?

The answer from the British Government has so far been unequivocal. The Dover tragedy was caused by criminals. A crime - nothing more, nothing less.

The police, perhaps unsurprisingly, are at one with the Home Office line. John Abbot, head of the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS) last week spoke of 'a global migration crisis'. 'People have replaced drugs as the most lucrative trade for criminal gangs... we are not talking asylum, we are talking organised crime,' he said.

But the issue is more complex and, many experts say, requires a more sophisticated response to be brought under control. No one is under any illusions about the scale of the problem. It is thought that 400,000 people a year enter the European Union illegally. In the 12 months from March 1999 to March 2000 British officials detected 21,000 people trying to enter the UK clandestinely. In 1996 the figure was 61. And they admit they catch only a fraction.

There are tens of thousands of illegal immigrants working in the UK. Many - particularly eastern Europeans - work on building sites or on farms. South Asians often end up in garment sweatshops. The Chinese fill the kitchens of restaurants.

Criminals may simply be reacting more quickly than national governments to changing patterns of migration and labour demand.

Nicolas Serrière of the UN's International Labour Organisation, based in Geneva, said Western European countries had to rethink their immigration and asylum policy: 'Everyone is having to reconsider their current stand because they desperately need foreign workers. But most countries face intense popular resistance to an increase in immigration. Governments are in a very difficult situation.'

When the German Social Democrat-led government said it would issue 20,000 visas to Information Technology specialists from India the German Right reacted with the slogan ' Kinder statt Inder' - Children before Indians.

Many believe Britain and France face the same problem. Though we have a low-skill surplus we need certain highly skilled migrants badly. 'If you have certain skills you can almost walk into the country without signing anything - we are so keen to have you,' said Philip Trott, a solicitor specialising in immigration law.

'It is becoming increasingly obvious that we have to tailor our immigration policy more closely to our needs. We have to wake up to the realisation that we do need immigrants.'

Foreign Office Ministers have visited India's 'Silicon Plateau' to lure skilled workers to this country, and Education Secretary David Blunkett would like foreign students studying IT in Britain to be allowed to apply directly for jobs here. The plan is opposed by Home Secretary Jack Straw.

Last month Blunkett said he would make it easier for IT workers to obtain work permits. Industry experts say 80,000 could be needed.

The anti-immigration lobby argues that the need for software programmers has little bearing on the fate of three score Chinese crammed into a container. But their carping may be ill-founded.

Margaret Hodge, the Minister with responsibility for equality issues, hosted a breakfast at the Department for Education and Employment recently where the big players in construction, manufacturing and transport explained the difficulties they were having filling posts.

Then the Earl of Limerick, chairman of tyre company Pirelli, mentioned asylum-seekers. It was a scandal, he said, that Britain was suffering a skills crisis, while hundreds of highly qualified refugees were being refused the right to work in this country while their cases were being assessed. 'It's a terrible situation,' he told The Observer. Even the Spectator and the Daily Telegraph have urged a liberalisation of the system. Such a change may be the most effective weapon in stopping a repetition of last week's tragedy.

'The main reason illegal immigration appears to be growing is that restrictive immigration policies have increased, making it difficult for people to arrive in Europe legally,' said Dr Khalid Koser, of London University's Migration Research Centre. 'There is no doubt that these criminal gangs are now marketing themselves, telling people they will be able to get them into Europe and, because it is more difficult to get visas, they can charge higher fees.'

In Fuquing this weekend security officials were making door-to-door inquiries in a bid to identify the victims of the Dover tragedy. Many parents were still unaware their sons or daughters were dead.

Fuquing authorities have now daubed the village's walls with huge slogans calling on residents to 'hit hard at illegal emigration'. Rewards have been offered in exchange for information about the snakeheads.

But their efforts are unlikely to have much impact. Villagers say everyone knows who the gang leaders are: their palatial homes with tiled patios, chandeliers, spiral staircases and security gates are hardly inconspicuous.

And, although there has been the odd angry protest outside the homes of the most notorious snakeheads, for the most part local people are not critical.

The snakeheads' homes are symbols of aspiration and hope, not of a despairing death in a stinking container. The opulence and comfort of the mansions - like Coca Cola, or MTV, or Mercedes cars, or organic starfruit - is just another reminder of the fabulous riches on offer in the West.

fields.headline: Bombed-out bonds may bounce back
fields.trailText: Corporate bonds were the hot investment topic last year. Since the beginning of 1999, no fewer than 17 funds investing in these instruments have been launched, increasing the number available by a third.
fields.body:
Corporate bonds were the hot investment topic last year. Since the beginning of 1999, no fewer than 17 funds investing in these instruments have been launched, increasing the number available by a third. Yet, as so often happens when there is a flurry of launches, performance has been disappointing. The best has produced a return of just 4.2 per cent in the past year. The average is just 0.52 per cent, and 22 of them are actually worth less than they were a year ago.

So should investors sell ? And how would they be affected if the stock market falls?

In fact, this could be a good time to get into corporate bonds: their recent poor performance was largely because interest rates were going up, which made the rates available on some of those already issued look less attractive. Now, rates look set to reach their peak, which will make fixed-interest investments more attractive again.

The corporate bond market is growing rapidly. This should be bad news for investors, but the fall in Government borrowing has led to a severe shortage of gilts. More and more pension funds are now considering buying corporate bonds instead, and this could accelerate: the industry is considering changes to pension rules which should push prices up.

They could also benefit from a jittery stock market, as nervous investors look for greater safety. But choose bonds carefully if you fear a crash. Investment-grade bonds, from blue chips such as Barclays or Marks & Spencer, are likely to rise, while junk bonds, from unknown companies or those with large borrowings, are likely to be marked down.

Most investors buy corporate bonds for income - and because lower-grade funds pay higher rates, they can look attractive. But sorting out the good from the real junk is a job for the experts.

fields.bodyText: Corporate bonds were the hot investment topic last year. Since the beginning of 1999, no fewer than 17 funds investing in these instruments have been launched, increasing the number available by a third. Yet, as so often happens when there is a flurry of launches, performance has been disappointing. The best has produced a return of just 4.2 per cent in the past year. The average is just 0.52 per cent, and 22 of them are actually worth less than they were a year ago. So should investors sell ? And how would they be affected if the stock market falls? In fact, this could be a good time to get into corporate bonds: their recent poor performance was largely because interest rates were going up, which made the rates available on some of those already issued look less attractive. Now, rates look set to reach their peak, which will make fixed-interest investments more attractive again. The corporate bond market is growing rapidly. This should be bad news for investors, but the fall in Government borrowing has led to a severe shortage of gilts. fields.headline: Voters defy Mugabe thugs
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe decides

Battered Mugabe hits back as verdict looms
fields.trailText: Millions of people yesterday mounted a remarkable show of defiance against Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's embattled president, braving attacks by state-employed thugs to vote in elections to determine the future of the former British colony.
fields.byline: by Andy Malone and Andrew Meldrum  Harare
fields.body:
Millions of people yesterday mounted a remarkable show of defiance against Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's embattled president, braving attacks by state-employed thugs to vote in elections to determine the future of the former British colony.

In the biggest turnout since Mugabe was elected in 1980, people queued for hours to cast votes, despite widespread intimidation by supporters of the ruling Zanu-PF party, discredited because of corruption and human rights abuses.

As polls closed last night Zimbabwe's top electoral official, Mariyawanda Nzuwa, said: 'All the reports indicate that the turnout is tremendous with most polling stations registering long queues late into the evening.' Polls open this morning for the final day's voting.

But local Zimbabwean election monitors said some observers were barred from polling stations. International observers also expressed anxiety about the fairness of the polls.

The biggest opposition party last night claimed it would win and that ordinary Zimbabwean people had braved attacks to rid the country at last of a president regarded as a dictator by many commentators.

Sources within the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) claimed they could win as many as 94 seats out of 120 being contested.

But voters in rural areas were targeted by mobs wielding clubs and iron bars. Around Harare, gangs of Mugabe supporters blocked roads, abducted opposition members and torched their cars. A petrol bomb was hurled at one candidate; another was beaten into a coma. Some candidates have fled the country in fear of their lives, while thousands of rural people have escaped into neighbouring countries.

Some analysts saw the size of the turnout as evidence of voters' determination to oust Mugabe, 76, whose rule has been marked by financial scandals and economic collapse. 'It is time for these thieves to go,' said Learnmore Tsuka, waiting in line to vote.

There were reports of ballot boxes being opened by Zanu supporters and prisoners being allowed to vote - providing it was for the government.

'These elections are following standards well below international norms,' a British diplomatic source said.

fields.headline: Paxman victor in Newsnight battle
fields.trailText: Jeremy Paxman, the combative Newsnight presenter and English nationalist, has put one over the auld enemy. His bitter campaign against the 'damn fool' decision to give Scotland a 20-minute 'opt-out' at the end of the flagship BBC2 news programme has forced corporation bosses to scrap the 'Jock slot'.
fields.body:
Jeremy Paxman, the combative Newsnight presenter and English nationalist, has put one over the auld enemy. His bitter campaign against the 'damn fool' decision to give Scotland a 20-minute 'opt-out' at the end of the flagship BBC2 news programme has forced corporation bosses to scrap the 'Jock slot'.

BBC news chiefs will ditch the Newsnight opt-out next year and replace it with a longer Scottish news bulletin at the end of the main evening news on BBC1. They say 10 minutes of news on BBC1 in prime time is worth 20 minutes at 11pm on BBC2.

The plan is designed to buy off Paxman, who has publicly embarrassed the corporation by campaigning against the opt-out, but it will provoke a bitter row between BBC Scotland and Tony Hall, the London-based head of BBC news and current affairs. One senior broadcaster at BBC Scotland told The Observer : 'After devolution we need more Scottish news for Scottish viewers, not less. If London thinks it can scrap our Newsnight , it had better be ready for a long fight.'

Scotland's Newsnight opt-out first went on air last autumn after plans for a Scottish version of the Six O'Clock News were scrapped. Although the BBC said it demonstrated the corporation's commitment to devolution, Paxman, who has ridiculed the Scottish chattering classes as smug, made it clear he loathed it.

He described it as 'a damn fool idea' which disrupted the flow of an in-depth news programme where many items are more than 15 minutes long. One week after it started he said: 'The Scots can have whatever they want, but this dog's breakfast is having a calamitous effect on the whole programme.' On air he lampooned Scots for 'talking among themselves' after 11pm. 'Well, now it's long gone 11 o'clock, children are in bed and Scots are talking about whatever they're talking about.'

Paxman's comments made him a hate figure north of the border. Newspapers accused him of deliberately letting interviews drag on after 11pm so that the Scottish opt-out started up to six minutes late. But he kept up his battle. In an interview to mark Newsnight's 20th anniversary, he said: 'The thing was cooked up as a way of buying off the demand for a Scottish Six O'Clock News , and the sooner it is dead and buried the better.'

Confirming the plan to ditch the opt-out, one BBC figure told The Observer : 'We wanted to give Britain's nations and regions a voice in network programmes but the Scottish Newsnight has been an untidy compromise.

'We reckon that extra minutes at the end of the BBC1 evening news - which attracts a much larger audience than Newsnight - are worth 20 minutes after 11pm on BBC2.'

Friends of Paxman say he is 'sniggering very loudly' over the BBC's decision. 'He has always regarded the opt-out as a millstone around the programme's neck,' one said. 'It's great to know it's going.'

fields.headline: The naked truth
fields.trailText: After the success of The Blue Room, Mendes made it impossible for any famous actress to make any kind of impact on the British theatre scene without the sound of her underwear thudding to the floor.
fields.body:
Wasn't it characteristically sweet and selfless of 34-year-old Sam Mendes to appoint himself as the concerned patriarch of British theatre recently? Coinciding with the news that Jerry Hall was to take over from Kathleen Turner as the briefly nude Mrs Robinson in The Graduate, Mendes made a speech at the Royal Opera House about how British theatre should guard against being 'held hostage by the lure of glamour'.

'We can put shows on the front page of newspapers, but what happens then?' said Mendes. Word is he's feeling guilty about setting the ball rolling. When Mendes got Nicole Kidman to appear naked in The Blue Room, he simultaneously exposed a delicious irony of modern culture. In that the more successful a star gets, the less flesh they're prepared to show in their movies, the more likely they are to get their kit off for the British stage. It doesn't seem to occur to these luvvie wannabes that the likes of Olivier and Gielgud made their names reciting soliloquies, not flashing all they've got at stage hands. That's just the chicks, of course. When Kevin Spacey, the lead in Mendes' Oscar-winning directorial debut, American Beauty, performed in The Iceman Cometh at the Almeida, there didn't seem to be any call for him to take his clothes off every night. Strange that.

Like Turner before her, Hall now has massive amounts of career-rejuvenating publicity to look forward to. Going by the adage that one should weigh one's press cuttings rather than read them, this should amount to about half an ounce on Hall's actual performance, and several tons devoted to 'reviewing' her fortysomething body - how well it's worn, how interesting it is to see what Mick Jagger was being unfaithful to all those years, whether or not she's still a natural blonde, and all those other valuable insights that help us better understand the human condition. After all, this isn't anything sad or tacky - like Cheggers on the telly with his chipolata out - this is art, this is theatre, you fools! Why then do I feel sorry for Jerry Hall already, just as I did for Turner, and even Kidman during her dazzling turn as 'theatrical Viagra'?

People can go on all they like about the 'script demanding it' - everyone knows in their hearts of hearts that it's all just Readers' Wives with dictionary words and an interval. After the success of The Blue Room, Mendes made it impossible for any famous actress to make any kind of impact on the British theatre scene without the sound of her underwear thudding to the floor. The likes of Turner, and now Hall, have to suffer the added indignity of being considered 'past their prime', inciting critics, and members of the public, who've probably been as ugly as sin and shaped like mashed potato all their lives to ponder cod-sympathetically on the wisdom of their late conversion to theatrical naturism. In the end, you think: good luck to them, if they can stand the flak. Kidman didn't have to, but then Kidman is younger, and she has Mendes directing her striptease. Like many a wunderkind director before him, Mendes seems to have a soft spot for young, beautiful naked actresses.

I can't be the only one to have watched American Beauty with a mounting sense of disbelief. Are they awarding Oscars for misogyny these days? Funny and acid American Beauty undoubtedly was - but only as much as a slow episode of Frasier. Elsewhere, we got Spacey as a midlife-crisis crybaby behaving abusively towards his family (tellingly, it was a female-only household that was driving him nuts), and leching after his daughter's friend. In the end, the friend offers up her virginity, but Spacey - wise and merciful being that he is - decides to spare her from his mighty phallus. Middle-aged guys turning down beautiful young girls - that's always happening, isn't it? One could overlook this as blatant male wish-fulfilment (ditto Jack Nicholson's alleged continuing 'gorgeousness') had not Annette Bening's character been so crudely and cruelly drawn, plumbing new depths of woman hatred.

As Spacey's wife, Bening is not a sex object, but more a hate and contempt object. No, worse - the middle-aged woman as boredom object. As the only other actresses in American Beauty are teenage girls, and Mendes has declared himself very satisfied with the movie, then we can only conclude that this is how Britain's brightest theatre and movie hope views the world. As a kind of sexual sweetie shop for guys of all ages, who have control from cradle to grave over whether or not a woman has any use or not. Never mind 'theatrical Viagra' - the next time Sam Mendes gets behind a movie camera, maybe he could try knocking back a cup or two of bromide. The rest of us can simply conclude that young naked actresses have little to fear from the likes of Mendes - it's the older, clothed ones who should watch their backs.

fields.headline: Bronfman gambles  his legacy
fields.standfirst:
The sale of Seagram to Vivendi creates the world's second-largest media group, with a mission to embrace the digital age. Melinda Wittstock assesses the new force's chances of success
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The sale of Seagram to Vivendi creates the world's second-largest media group,    with a mission to embrace the digital age.  Melinda Wittstock assesses the new force's chances of success
fields.body:
There he was, at all Hollywood's best tables: a clever billionaire in the prime of his life, wheeling and dealing Seagram into one of the world's most 'fun' companies - a booze, music and movie empire, his stock heading up as gambles started to pay off.

But in February Edgar Bronfman Junior faced up to the digitally altered music: a movie studio, cable TV networks and even the biggest music business in the world were no longer enough to compete in the new digital media landscape heralded by America Online's $125 billion takeover of traditional media goliath Time Warner.

The Seagram CEO - who has spent the past five years defying those who dismissed him as a dilettante rich kid messing with the family fortune by tripling it - suddenly started casting around for buyers and a deal that would allow the former record producer and songwriter to pursue his musical passion: setting the standards for selling tunes in the digital age.

'World's Largest Wireless Footprint', read one of the headlines of Tuesday's news release announcing Bronfman's $34 bn (£22.5 bn) sale of Seagram to Vivendi, the French utilities-turned-entertainment and telecommunications combine. The deal not only creates the world's second-largest media group behind AOL-Time Warner, it also lets Bronfman keep playing the tune for his Universal Music Group - and what he sees as its digital, subscription-driven future. Why else sell the family heirloom to an entity largely unknown in Hollywood and unquoted on Wall Street?

The lure of the stock-swap sale hinges on Vizzavi, the European internet portal launched last Monday by Vivendi and Vodafone, itself the world's number one wireless telephone provider. Viz zavi will be 'the default home page for 80 million potential mobile and interactive TV customers', insist the corporate newlyweds, a powerful tool for delivering music and, eventually, video to millions of people using handheld wireless devices.

'You'll be able to get connected to your own personal music library,' enthused Bronfman at the Paris news conference. 'I'm a great believer in the future of wireless opportunities.'

So too is Jean-Marie Messier, newly minted chairman of Vivendi Universal, who now possesses money-spinning content to pump down his European digital pipelines - pay TV, the internet and mobile phones all at his disposal. A week before the deal, he could barely contain his enthusiasm for Seagram's assets, labelling music 'the master missing piece' in his drive for interactive supremacy, and adding that 'music was born for the internet'.

But the market was less enthusiastic. Shares in Vivendi lost 8.7 per cent on the Paris bourse; Seagram stock plunged 9 per cent on Wall Street. Messier blamed it all on greedy arbitrageurs, and he had a point, though the digital road ahead will certainly be bumpy.

'There are a lot of scepticism out there, sure,' says Porter Bibb, media pundit and managing partner at Manhattan merchant bank Technology Partners. 'Vivendi Universal is very much a work in progress, but the whole industry is in flux. After the billion-dollar party, the arbitrageurs had driving down AOL-Time Warner - despite its obvious fundamentals - they're not about to miss this opportunity, even though it's a brilliant deal that makes great sense for Vivendi and makes Seagram shareholders a bunch of happy campers.'

Bibb says all the big 'ifs' should come clear in a few months. 'It might be pie in the sky, but if Edgar does have the digital answer to music retailing, if he is creating the secure standard by which record labels and their artists can still make money, not to mention TV and movie studios, it will be worth billions.'

The ink barely dry on the Vivendi deal, Universal Music Group starts selling online this Wednesday, offering its first ever pay-for downloads. Codenamed the 'Blue Matter Project', the secure digital-subscription service will test between 20 and 30 artists.

'We'll know in the next three to four months if this is the new paradigm for music and video retailing,' says Bibb. 'CDs and videocassettes will soon be a thing of the past - and online subscription offers bigger margins.'

Pervading investor cynicism this week revolved around other issues. Wall Street focused on the culture clash and the French company's likely difficulties running a Hollywood studio, given Matsushita's woes with MCA-Universal and Sony's troubles with Columbia.

Bronfman and Messier are pinning their hopes for growth on Vizzavi, but just how fast can its wireless distribution network grow? 'We will be able to distribute wireless music within months,' insists Bronfman. Met with scepticism, he adds: 'I didn't say we'd be able to do it to 80 million people, did I?'

Any expansion into Amer ican wireless internet may also be a long time coming: neither Vivendi nor Seagram has a virtual presence in the US, and the merger won't necessarily help them strike deals with American wireless providers, all building portals of their own or wooing the likes of Yahoo! AOL already brings 23 million US subscribers to Time Warner.

But Messier sees potential in Vodafone's partnership with Bell Atlantic and GTE in the new Verizon wireless carrier. 'As part of our agreement with Vodafone, we have an agreement to be considered as a premier content provider in the US, as we have in Vizzavi,' he says. But Verizon launches in the next couple of weeks without any such link-up - just 'compatibility' with Vodafone's European service.

And then there's the content issue: 'We're not exactly talking about Looney Tunes or Disney,' says Bibb. 'USA Networks, Universal and its association with DreamWorks is a big deal, but it isn't quite in the same league as Time Warner or Disney.'

But Seagram's film business accounts for just 22 per cent of turnover, compared with 40 per cent for music.

Late in the week, all eyes were focused on the intentions of Barry Diller, whose USA Networks is 45 per cent owned by Seagram. Made $300m richer by the Vivendi-Seagram deal, Diller is said to be considering whether to buy himself out. Frustrated in the past by Bronfman's refusal to let him pursue an aggressive growth strategy - he foiled his attempts two years ago to buy the NBC television network - Diller will test Messier to see if Vivendi will be more amenable.

Relinquishing control of the business his father built cannot have been easy for Bronfman. But if he betrayed any anxiousness on the dais in Paris, it was because he couldn't understand a word his new boss was saying: 'He doesn't speak French,' one hack whispered loudly.

Messier blamed it all on greedy arbitrageurs, and he had a point, though the digital road ahead will certainly be bumpy. 'There are a lot of scepticism out there, sure,' says Porter Bibb, media pundit and managing partner at Manhattan merchant bank Technology Partners. 'Vivendi Universal is very much a work in progress, but the whole industry is in flux. After the billion-dollar party, the arbitrageurs had driving down AOL-Time Warner - despite its obvious fundamentals - they're not about to miss this opportunity, even though it's a brilliant deal that makes great sense for Vivendi and makes Seagram shareholders a bunch of happy campers.' Bibb says all the big 'ifs' should come clear in a few months. 'It might be pie in the sky, but if Edgar does have the digital answer to music retailing, if he is creating the secure standard by which record labels and their artists can still make money, not to mention TV and movie studios, it will be worth billions.' The ink barely dry on the Vivendi deal, Universal Music Group starts selling online this Wednesday, offering its first ever pay-for downloads. Codenamed the 'Blue Matter Project', the secure digital-subscription service will test between 20 and 30 artists. 'We'll know in the next three to four months if this is the new paradigm for music and video retailing,' says Bibb. 'CDs and videocassettes will soon be a thing of the past - and online subscription offers bigger margins.' Pervading investor cynicism this week revolved around other issues. Wall Street focused on the culture clash and the French company's likely difficulties running a Hollywood studio, given Matsushita's woes with MCA-Universal and Sony's troubles with Columbia. Bronfman and Messier are pinning their hopes for growth on Vizzavi, but just how fast can its wireless distribution network grow? 'We will be able to distribute wireless music within months,' insists Bronfman. Met with scepticism, he adds: 'I didn't say we'd be able to do it to 80 million people, did I?' Any expansion into Amer ican wireless internet may also be a long time coming: neither Vivendi nor Seagram has a virtual presence in the US, and the merger won't necessarily help them strike deals with American wireless providers, all building portals of their own or wooing the likes of Yahoo! AOL already brings 23 million US subscribers to Time Warner. But Messier sees potential in Vodafone's partnership with Bell Atlantic and GTE in the new Verizon wireless carrier. 'As part of our agreement with Vodafone, we have an agreement to be considered as a premier content provider in the US, as we have in Vizzavi,' he says. But Verizon launches in the next couple of weeks without any such link-up - just 'compatibility' with Vodafone's European service. And then there's the content issue: 'We're not exactly talking about Looney Tunes or Disney,' says Bibb. 'USA Networks, Universal and its association with DreamWorks is a big deal, but it isn't quite in the same league as Time Warner or Disney.' But Seagram's film business accounts for just 22 per cent of turnover, compared with 40 per cent for music. Late in the week, all eyes were focused on the intentions of Barry Diller, whose USA Networks is 45 per cent owned by Seagram. Made $300m richer by the Vivendi-Seagram deal, Diller is said to be considering whether to buy himself out. Frustrated in the past by Bronfman's refusal to let him pursue an aggressive growth strategy - he foiled his attempts two years ago to buy the NBC television network - Diller will test Messier to see if Vivendi will be more amenable. Relinquishing control of the business his father built cannot have been easy for Bronfman. But if he betrayed any anxiousness on the dais in Paris, it was because he couldn't understand a word his new boss was saying: 'He doesn't speak French,' one hack whispered loudly. fields.headline: Of Blackbeard and Bill Gates
fields.standfirst: Rip-off software and CDs, price-rigged pig feed, human rights abusers - a US network is now on to them all
fields.trailText: Rip-off software and CDs, price-rigged pig feed, human rights abusers - a US network is now on to them all
fields.body:
You want to be a billionaire? Answer this one: What do Blackbeard, the Butcher of Croatia and Bill Gates have in common?

While the money clock ticks away, let me tell you about my weekend. I spent it at the Sheraton Hotel in Brussels, watching the guests shuttle between rooms. It looked a little like love, but maybe it meant nothing more to them than a couple nights of fun. There was Steve Ballmer, new CEO of Microsoft, and a thousand of his closest commercial and government friends, meeting under the guise of the 'European Business Summit'.

In the ballroom I modestly averted my gaze as a EU Commissioner told the executives how to form 'strategic alliances' between corporations. The instructor was, of all people, Mario Monti, head of the EC's Competition Directorate, putative protector of the public from cartels and monopolies.

Only three days before, a US judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, ruled that Microsoft had bullied its way to a software monopoly by deceit, coercion and software sabotage. And here was Monti submitting to Microsoft-sponsored indoctrination on 'Promoting Innovation', the company's latest PR cover phrase for its none-too-kosher business practices.

Several hundred riot-ready police ringed the hotel. Their water cannons and scores of black armoured transports, looking like the attack bugs from Star Wars, protected us not from the football crazies massing that evening, but from the threat of pastry. Rumour had it that Noel Godin, who once whacked Gates with a custard pie, would lead a thousand anti-globalisation bakers on a whipped-cream rampage against the summit.

But the night before its start, the Belgians arrested Godin and 68 suspected sous-chefs. Still, a thousand pie-less demonstrators showed up, herded so far away that, from the Sheraton's banqueting room, they looked like a swarm of frustrated ants.

Now the ants have some powerful allies. For nearly a year, in secret meetings in London, a band of lawyers from six continents have planned an unprecedented multi-national assault on corporate monopolies. It's all big guns, including Princess Diana's lawyers, Mishcon De Reya, and the firm of David Boies, who slew Microsoft for the US Justice Department. With a bit of understandable drama, they've named themselves the Global Anti-Cartel Network.

Last year, in an exclusive interview with The Observer , Boies caused a little storm in Microsoft's home town of Seattle by suggesting that every British purchaser of a Windows computer could claim a cash refund in US courts as a victim of Gates's monopoly. This week, the Anti-Cartel Network did just that, filing suits on behalf of those hundred million or so ants toiling on the Windows cyber- plantation outside the US. If the Network wins, expect a cheque for £20 or so. (Boies, however, is sidelined from this action because of his government work.)

Microsoft is merely the Network's first dragon. According to Mike Hausfeld of Washington, the Network's chief lawyer, the 30 law firms are about to make legal history by hitting several price-fixing monopolies with suits demanding compensation under Britain's own anti-monopoly laws.

That's revolutionary because the right of consumers to obtain recovery from cartels is, like so many privileges under English law, constructed in such a way that no one has ever dared assert their rights. In the past 100 years the number of British consumers who have won compensation from price-fixing rings is exactly zero.

It's the same mad story in Europe. For example, the FBI secretly filmed French and US biotech companies fixing the price of pig feed. The companies confessed and paid American customers several hundred million dollars. For Britain's bacon-munching citizens the conspirators offered two fingers and a grin.

Time for change? The Network thinks so. Within weeks it plans to hit the crew you've suspected of rip-offs for years - the big five music companies, whom the Network alleges have conspired to keep the price of CDs above £10 a disc.

Maybe you're thinking an invasion of US lawyers into Blighty is a mixed blessing. You could, of course, leave it to HM Office of Fair Trading to protect you from corporate marauders. But how does the OFT's record look? Last month the US Federal Trade Commission forced Sony, EMI, Warner, BMG and Polygram/Universal to end market manipula tions that hiked CD prices by $2 a disc. Even the Italians fined the companies. Yet, somehow, the sleuths at the OFT found no fix at all in CD sales. One US investigator characterised the OFT's efforts thus: 'It was really so lame . I mean, it was so poorly conceived it was a chuckle . You have to laugh - it was, like, so unscientific.'

The embarrassed OFT has now requested copies of the screaming evidence of price-fixing from US court proceedings. While this could represent an unexpected life-pulse in the old agency, it is more likely to be the eerie post-mortem twitching of a bureaucratic corpse.

Whichever it is, the only way to get justice - and cash back on your CD and Windows purchases - is through the Network's unprecedented two-front strategy: one, to sue in London courts; the other, to sue under UK law for trial in an American courtroom.

That's where the case of the Butcher of Croatia, Andrija Artukovich, comes into play. When Artukovich, a puppet potentate of the Nazi regime, was forced into retirement, he chose, like other cut throats, movie stars and estates agents, to settle in southern California, presumably free from retribution. But in 1980 his surviving victims hit the Butcher with a law suit under America's Alien Claims Torts Act. George Washington signed this law in 1789, declaring America, barely a nation, to have legal jurisdiction to bring to trial and obtain reparations of any ne'er-do-well who violated 'accepted international standards of con duct' - what today we call human rights.

Washington had in mind Bluebeard and other pirates on the high seas, but Hausfeld and his Network sidekick Martin Mendelsohn, who nailed Artukovich with the novel use of the Act, have more recently used it to lighten Siemens, Volkswagen and others of a billion pounds to compensate those enslaved in their factories to work for Hitler's war machine - though neither the guilty companies nor the victims are American.

'We have established that there are certain norms, recognised in the laws of every nation, that raise them to the level of international law,' explained Hausfeld. Among these are universal prohibitions - on the code books, if not in practice - against piracy, slavery, genocide and monopolistic manipulations of the marketplace.

'Cartels and monopolies are the new pirates,' said Hausfeld.

Microsoft's response is a frantic procedural dance to stall both the Network's civil suits and the Justice Department's carving knife just long enough for Gates legally to buy himself a new president.

Republicans promise that, once in the White House, they would change the US judiciary to something a bit more friendly to software barons. And that, by the way, is how you can tell the difference between Bluebeard and Gates. Blackbeard's the one with the eye-patch and a parrot on his shoulder. Gates wears eye glasses and George W. Bush on his shoulder.

webTitle: Sociable, stylish, fun - that's net users for you

fields.headline: Sociable, stylish, fun - that's net users for you
fields.trailText: William Gibson has a lot to answer for. He's the novelist who in 1984 invented the term 'cyberspace' to describe the strange world in which online activities take place - the consensual illusion which exists behind our computer screens, that notional world in which, to quote the famous New Yorker cartoon showing two dogs in front of a computer, 'nobody knows you're a dog'.
fields.body:
William Gibson has a lot to answer for. He's the novelist who in 1984 invented the term 'cyberspace' to describe the strange world in which online activities take place - the consensual illusion which exists behind our computer screens, that notional world in which, to quote the famous New Yorker cartoon showing two dogs in front of a computer, 'nobody knows you're a dog'.

The idea of cyberspace has proved tantalising to a host of ersatz philosophers, fantasists, utopians, dystopians and, er, newspaper columnists. It has spawned acres of speculation about the dichotomy between 'virtual reality' and 'real' reality, between real space and cyberspace. And of course it's true that the two worlds are very different. But maybe we make too much of a meal of this.

My children, for example, seem to move effortlessly between the two, as indeed does their father, who spends more time in the ethereal space than they do, dealing with email, reading and writing web pages and generally being a busy Netizen. The fact that one spends a lot of time online does not necessarily reduce one's engagement with the real world.

But that's only my opinion. Until now, almost everything we know about how real people relate to cyberspace is anecdotal. Now a remarkable new book has raised the discussion to a new level.

The Internet: An Ethnographic Approach ' (Berg) summarises the findings of two anthropologists, Daniel Miller and Don Slater, who have carried out an intensive study of how Trinidadians have incorporated the internet into their lives.

If Miller and Slater are right, most conventional wisdom about the internet as a socially disruptive technology is wrong. Trinidad is not by any standards a high-tech society, yet its citizens have taken to the net like ducks to water, with one household in three boasting a regular internet user. The net has established itself in Trinidadian society as a 'hot' subject.

It has, say Miller and Slater, 'become critical to the desire to be stylish as an individual, but also in attempts to launch Trinidad itself into the vanguard of modernity'. And intense interest in the possibilities of the net extends, they found, even to settlements of squatters.

We in Britain have become wearily accustomed to the prating of bishops and technophobic fanatics about how the internet supposedly threatens family life, creating legions of atomised, isolated individuals locked in their bedrooms pathetically surfing the net.

Well, guess what? 'The Internet has considerably strengthened the nuclear family throughout the Trinidadian diaspora, allowing closer relations between parents and children and between siblings. It has had an equally strong effect on the extended family.'

And what about the charge that the net will create a homogenised, Disneyfied world? Miller and Slater find that: 'Trinidadians' national identity and culture are central to their use of the internet. And their uses of the net are typically, well, Trinidadian. They are heavy users of chat technology, for example, which they employ to 'recreate a very particular mode of interaction and socialisation - full of banter and innuendo - that for many people is the quintessence of being Trinidadian'.

I could go on but you get the point. The internet is changing Trinidad, but not by brutally bulldozing that society's complex social structure. Instead the technology is being adopted by its citizens and used in distinctive ways which resonate with their social structure. In the process, they and their society are changed.

It's a complicated, ongoing process of social change and adaptation. Rather like real life in fact.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: We were all once immigrants
fields.trailText: The terrible fate of the 58 Chinese migrants found dead in a container lorry in Dover ought, among other things, to draw attention to a serious flaw in the economic model that has recently conquered most of the world.
fields.body:
The terrible fate of the 58 Chinese migrants found dead in a container lorry in Dover ought, among other things, to draw attention to a serious flaw in the economic model that has recently conquered most of the world.

In theory 'market economics' rule. In practice it is a specialised version of market economics that has triumphed. What we have is a general acceptance that governments can do nothing about the free movement of capital, except compete with one another in order to attract it; on the other hand, for all the obeisance paid to 'freeing up' product and labour markets, the movement of labour is very tightly controlled.

There has been much controversy about this Government's tough line on asylum seekers, but it is not my purpose this week to enter that particular fray. What is truly remarkable is that it has been so widely accepted that the immigration of 'genuine' asylum seekers is the only immigration that an advanced industrial economy can contemplate.

It is well known that the mighty US economy was founded on immigration and, as my colleague Faisal Islam pointed out recently, the information revolution led by the US economy has been heavily dependent on immigrant skilled workers, while a stream of lower skilled immigrants has helped to keep US inflationary pressures at bay.

The present British labour force is descended, if you look back a couple of thousand years, from a stream of immigrants from Rome, Scandinavia (the Vikings), Saxony, Normandy, France and the low countries (the Huguenots), large areas of Europe (from which came both Jewish and non-Jewish immigrants) and the West Indies. Oh, and I nearly forgot (and with a name like mine!) - Ireland.

Many immigrants were fleeing from persecution; some of those earlier ones were even conquerors; others came to seek a better life. Indeed, western history and literature are abundant in stories which boil down to the migration associated with the search for a chance for people to 'improve their economic circumstances'. This motive was a major factor behind the eventual fall of the Berlin Wall. People were just fleeing from eastern Germany, and found a route out.

One of the key factors behind the generous terms on which the monetary unification of east and west Germany took place was the desire to prevent wholesale migration to the West.

That was a special case. Most people choose not to leave their home surroundings - unless they are desperate or unusually adventurous. The Chinese migrants found dead on arrival in Dover were desperate.

Yes, freedom of choice is supposed to be one of the fundamentals of the modern market economy; but the freedom to choose where you work in the 'globalised' economy is severely constrained.

We seem to have moved from one extreme to another: in the Fifties the UK actively encouraged immigration for economic reasons; now it actively discourages it - with the exception of the NHS, again. Thus market pressures are perforating the shield: in theory the European Union is a kind of 'fortress Europe' in which EU nationals can work anywhere, but which is largely barred to outsiders; in practice the German government has decided it needs tens of thousands of immigrant workers with expertise in information technology.

What would help the immigration debate, apart from a sense of humanity, is a sense of proportion. The 'need' for immigrant workers can be exaggerated: the argument that we need lots of immigrant workers to pay for our pensions does not take enough note of the way the British labour market has been distorted by the fashion for unnecessarily early and often involuntary retirement.

The most libertarian of observers can see that Britain is a relatively overcrowded island, and that there has to be a happy medium between the present Draconian limits and a world of unrestricted immigration. Indeed, a common sense approach to the dangers of overcrowding in particular areas of the country lay behind what we used to call 'regional policy' - a concept that shows welcome signs of revival after years of neglect.

For although capital, in the shape of portfolio or direct investment, can flow almost anywhere under 'globalisation', much of the infrastructure of social capital is by definition fixed. It usually makes more sense to take work to the people of a depressed city or region than to let it erode, and add to overcrowding elsewhere.

In these matters, the 'market' takes an unconscionably long time to work. I have seen it reported that California was considered a 'paradise' in the Fifties, when it had 10 million people, but that the prospect of 50 million is another matter, and there is now a lot of emigration from paradise.

Whatever happens to immigration policy vis à vis applications to enter Europe, the economic rules of the single currency imply that intra-EU migration will increase, if only as an economic adjustment mechanism, just as inter-state migration has always been a strong feature of the US economy.

It is worth noting that a feature of the current Irish boom has been to encourage immigration - an interesting reversal of previous patterns.

We seem to have moved from one extreme to another: in the Fifties the UK actively encouraged immigration for economic reasons; now it actively discourages it - with the exception of the NHS, again. Thus market pressures are perforating the shield: in theory the European Union is a kind of 'fortress Europe' in which EU nationals can work anywhere, but which is largely barred to outsiders; in practice the German government has decided it needs tens of thousands of immigrant workers with expertise in information technology. What would help the immigration debate, apart from a sense of humanity, is a sense of proportion. The 'need' for immigrant workers can be exaggerated: the argument that we need lots of immigrant workers to pay for our pensions does not take enough note of the way the British labour market has been distorted by the fashion for unnecessarily early and often involuntary retirement. The most libertarian of observers can see that Britain is a relatively overcrowded island, and that there has to be a happy medium between the present Draconian limits and a world of unrestricted immigration. Indeed, a common sense approach to the dangers of overcrowding in particular areas of the country lay behind what we used to call 'regional policy' - a concept that shows welcome signs of revival after years of neglect. For although capital, in the shape of portfolio or direct investment, can flow almost anywhere under 'globalisation', much of the infrastructure of social capital is by definition fixed. It usually makes more sense to take work to the people of a depressed city or region than to let it erode, and add to overcrowding elsewhere. In these matters, the 'market' takes an unconscionably long time to work. I have seen it reported that California was considered a 'paradise' in the Fifties, when it had 10 million people, but that the prospect of 50 million is another matter, and there is now a lot of emigration from paradise. Whatever happens to immigration policy vis à vis applications to enter Europe, the economic rules of the single currency imply that intra-EU migration will increase, if only as an economic adjustment mechanism, just as inter-state migration has always been a strong feature of the US economy. It is worth noting that a feature of the current Irish boom has been to encourage immigration - an interesting reversal of previous patterns.

fields.headline: Half-life in the wilderness
fields.standfirst:
Oliver Morgan on the future of Nirex and the UK's nuclear waste policy
Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan on the future of Nirex and the UK's nuclear waste policy
fields.body:
Chris Murray will never forget the moment his company was banished to the wilderness. As managing director of Nuclear Waste Management Company Nirex, he was at company headquarters in Harwell when, at 11.20am on March 17 1997, his boss broke the shocking news to him.

The Conservative Environment Secretary, John Gummer, had turned down plans to build a test site for a deep underground store at Sellafield in Cumbria.

Until then Nirex had been at the very centre of Britain's nuclear industrial strategy.

Murray says: ' It was devastating. It was the first time that the nuclear industry had lost a planning inquiry. And it resulted in a total loss of confidence in Nirex as a company.'

Nirex did not die - it's knowledge base was too valuable for that - but its influence in industry, in policy, in Whitehall and Westminster ended. It became an undead company.

The cautionary tale of Nirex shows what happens when science overtakes government and public opinion, and when political and company objectives become entangled. It is a story which ministers - scarred from the GM foods, BSE and British Nuclear Fuels controversies,- recognise only too well.

Now, three years later, Nirex may return from the twilight zone. The question is, how quickly and in what form?

Environment Minister Michael Meacher is planning a consultation on how to re-open the issue: it was due early this year - but delayed, with rumours it may be pushed back to the autumn.

The Government and Nirex have to first win back public confidence. Next it is vital to convince politicians of the urgent need for new policy. The half-lives of some of the radioactive materials involved are one million years (see sidebar, below right). What is a month here and there, they - and you -may ask?

Charles Curtis, chairman of the Radioactive Waste Management Advisory Committee, established by the government in 1978, believes a decision is vital soon.

'It is in the interest of the public and of public finances to put in place permanent arrangements. There is a great deal of waste which is being dealt with in a temporary and costly manner.'

And, as a House of Lords Science and Technology Committee report pointed out last year: 'The long time-scale might be thought to be a reason for postponing decisions. But the contrary is the case, since existing storage arrangements have a limited life and will require replacement.'

The Lords also pointed out the flaws in the 'fragmentation' of nuclear waste policy: disposal is messy and dangerous, and the categorisation is complicated.

In April 1994 the UK's inventory showed a total of 71,000 cubic metres of waste - in addition to plutonium and uranium stocks, currently not classed as waste.

This is divided into three categories. High-level waste (HLW), which needs active cooling for 50 years before it can be disposed of, makes up 2.3 per cent of the volume but 90 per cent of the total radioactivity. Intermediate- level waste (ILW) makes up 86.6 per cent of the inventory, and contains most of the remaining radioactivity. Low- level waste (LLW) is 11.1 per cent in volume.

These wastes are stored at or near British Nuclear Fuels' Sellafield site and at the UK Atomic Energy Authority's Dounreay site in Scotland.

Fragmentation of waste reflects the haphazard evolution of policy and of the institutions designed to deal with it. The problem was not really addressed until 1976, with a report by the Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution. In 1982 Nuclear Industry Radioactive Waste Management Executive was created. It was renamed Nirex in 1985 and placed on a commercial footing.

Nirex's remit increased the fragmentation - it was given responsibility only for ILW and some LLW.

Nirex faced a series of further problems, regarding disposal sites. Two alternatives were chosen - a near-surface store for shorter-lived LLW and ILW, and a deep site in a disused ICI mine for longer- term ILW. ICI faced local opposition and withdrew its offer.

Nirex was then told in 1984 to explore three sites for a near-surface store, and three for a deep one. In 1987 the Government scrapped plans for a near-surface site. In 1992 Nirex revealed plans for an underground laboratory, called a rock characterisation facility, or RCF, to test geology for a deep repository at Sellafield in Cumbria. There was a storm of protest from residents and environmental campaigners. In 1997 a Government Inspector turned down the application. He stated that the choice of Sellafield for the RCF had not been made objectively, that it was premature, and that more needed to be known about the geology of the site.

In short, a decision which had been taken behind closed doors by scientists blew up in their face.

Nirex has taken the intervening three years to come to terms with this decision.

Key to the problem was Nirex's public awareness. Murray says the only people who thought the issue at hand was a test laboratory were Nirex. The rest of the world saw it as a Trojan horse for a waste dump.

Following the planning refusal, the company cut staff from 230 to 67, slashed its spending from £50 million a year to £11m and became little more than a think-tank on waste disposal issues. It continues to approve packaging processes, carried out by BNFL and UKAEA.

Nirex was hammered from all sides. Its shareholders, BNFL, UKAEA, British Energy and the Government, complained that £500m had been wasted.

The public, media and academics all dug in. Murray says: 'Many were delighted that an institution like Nirex had been turned over. Some thought we deserved it.'

It is tempting to ask Murray and his advisers whether they did anything right.

Nirex admits Nirex was part of the problem, that there was a lack of openness in the decision-making, that it was rushed and, that there was no clear 'road map' outlining key destinations.

One problem which goes to the heart of Nirex's difficulties was 'retrievability'. On the one hand, there was concern that burying waste in a deep store and backfilling it forever meant a decision on where to site a store could never be reversed. So the community there would be living on top of a 'dump'.

But on the other hand, allowing retrievability - at least for the three to four hundred years it would take to settle the current inventory - meant human error or terrorism entered the equation.

This is one of the key issues the government will have to deal with once the consulta tion takes place. Murray, sensitive to public pressure, is now calling for a complete revision of all storage options - including formerly discounted ones such as sea-bed disposal and space disposal.

He is also calling for more public awareness in the decision-making process. The composition of Nirex itself will be a key part of the Government's plans.

Should Nirex be given responsibility for all nuclear waste? Should it be owned by BNFL, UKAEA and British Energy, all of whom produce waste, and have vested interests in its disposal? What form should Nirex take to carry the waste responsibility into the future, and how will it maintain records over that time?

Murray is not prepared to comment prematurely. He, like Meacher, the Environment Minister, cannot afford to get it wrong again.

The 4,500 million-year question
Radioactivity is caused by the instability of nuclei in atoms. The nucleus of an atom contains neutrons and protons which, added together, give an atomic number.

A single element - such as carbon, uranium or plutonium - may have several variants, each with different atomic numbers. These are formed as atoms with unstable nuclei, called radionuclides, created in nuclear reactions.

They attempt to make themselves more stable, changing their atomic make-up by throwing out nuclear matter, and altering the number. This causes radiation. Eventually they become stable, but the timescales vary dramatically.

The benchmark for radioactivity is a radionuclide's 'half-life' - the time it takes for half the atoms in a sample to become stable. Some 95 per cent of radionuclides have half-lives of 100 years or less. For example Nickel-63 has a 96- year half-life. Caesium-137 takes 30 years. But there are some which take much longer.

Plutonium-239 - which contributes about 0.8 per cent of radioactivity in the UK inventory - has a 24,000 year half-life. Chlorine-36 contributes 0.0007 per cent and has 301,000 years, while Iodine-129 gives 0.0001 per cent and has 15.7 million years. Uranium-238 with 0.0022 per cent has a 4,500 million-year half-life.

They will also inevitably leak into the environment. This is because however safe a store is made, water will seep through, carrying traces of the substances through rock and out into the 'biosphere'.

Nirex calculates that this will happen with chlorine-26 and iodine-129 in 100,000 years and with uranium-238 in a million years. Nirex claims the amounts will be very small and not harmful to those living nearby.

Ways of dealing with waste
Geological disposal: Mined tunnels and chambers at least 300 metres deep, with even deeper boreholes to contain waste. Problem: perception as a 'dump'.

Burial nearer surface: Intermediate solution pending technological advances which would render waste harmless or offer a better solution than found so far. Problem: the possibility of human interference.

Ocean bed: Disposal at depths of several kilometres by dumping canisters filled with waste or building a concrete bunker. Problem: unacceptable to many nations.

Ocean bed sediment: Firing torpedoes filled with waste into the ocean floor. Problem: unacceptable to many nations.

Ocean rock: Placing canisters in boreholes in ocean floor. Problem: unacceptable to many nations.

Subduction zones: Canisters placed in areas of ocean floor where earth's crust folds under another section, taking waste towards earth's centre before it re-emerges after hundreds of millions of years. Problem: no guarantee waste would not reappear too soon.

Antarctic ice sheets: Canisters placed in drilled boreholes in ice sheets. Would be moved downwards by melting ice. Problem: potential instability of ice sheets.

Ejection into space: Problem: catastrophe if spacecraft crashed.

Nuclear transmutation: Separation of long-lived radionuclides from wastes and conversion into short lived ones with particle accelerator. Problem: technology still a long way in future.

Synroc: Mix synthetic rock material with waste. Problem: technology not demonstrated.

 House of Lords Science and Technology Committee Third report
