fields.headline: Kennedy and the F word
fields.standfirst: Question time for Liberal Democrat leader
fields.trailText: June 25: The appearance of Charles Kennedy on Question Time last week was on the whole impressive.
fields.body:
The appearance of Charles Kennedy on Question Time last week was on the whole impressive. He started uncertainly, parrying questions on economic migrants and scanning the audience like some night-club owner on the lookout for troublemakers.

Gone is the easy manner of the old Kennedy, broadcaster, bon viveur and wit. Now we have the homme sérieux, husky voiced and earnest.

He dealt skilfully with the planted Tory europhobes who want to pin their party's destiny to the pound, but I was struck by the fact that when he turned to the West Lothian question he managed to advance his party's solution - federalism across the UK - without once mentioning the f-word, which has been used so freely by the Tory press in its demonisation of all things European, even though, as Kennedy pointed out, it means less rather than more centralism.

In the old debates about devolution, those who argued that it would not lead to the break-up of the United Kingdom used to make two assumptions. The first was that Westminster would not punish and isolate Scotland by cutting public expenditure north of the border; the second was that both the Tory and Labour parties would continue to be committed to the United Kingdom as our dominant constitutional entity.

Both propositions still largely hold true but are fraying at the edges. Last week Lord Barnett himself renounced the formula for sharing out public expenditure named after him. In the English regions a head of steam is building up to remove some of Scotland's cash and give it to places like the North East which appear to have fared badly by comparison.

John Prescott skilfully evaded the point when questioned about it on Radio 4's Today, preferring to emphasise the work of the relatively new English regional development agencies. But he did indicate that he thought the correct response to any disparity was to level up rather than down. In any case, the Barnett Formula should over the coming years shave off some of Scotland's relative advantage.

But on the Tory side there seems to be less sagacity and statecraft, on this and other questions. What was not foreseen in the Seventies was how the party would change through the Thatcher era. Its support in Scotland was heavily eroded. The European question, and the eclipse of the party's Europhile wing, has hastened its mutation into an English National Party. Old-fashioned one-nation Conservatives are in a distinct minority. The Scottish Tories are struggling, with some difficulty, to find a place in this new world, wrapping themselves in the Saltire rather than the Union Jack.

But one feature of the new landscape in England is a tone of virulent resentment and dislike of Scotland and its perceived constitutional and fiscal advantages. These voices are still fairly subdued but they are increasingly making themselves heard, not just among Tories from the shires but among policy-makers and intellectuals.

What was certainly not foreseen was that the West Lothian question would first raise its head in the coming Commons debate on fox-hunting. Tam Dalyell is denying himself a vote but few other Scottish MPs are following his example. As Kennedy told his audience, they have no obligation to remain silent on any issue that comes before the UK parliament to which they were elected even though the outcome affects only England.

After all, Scotland lived through a long period under Thatcher when the reverse was true, the period in which poll tax was first tried on the dog and when Scottish committees at Westminster were packed with English Tories. What Kennedy could have added, but circumspectly did not, is that until they embrace federalism - with an elected Senate and even an elected president - the English should really shut up about the West Lothian question. The solution is staring them in the face but they are too stubborn, or too committed to their own totems, to see it.

webTitle: Hunt for loner over hostel fire

fields.headline: Hunt for loner over hostel fire
fields.trailText: Police in Australia yesterday launched a manhunt for a 37-year-old itinerant fruit picker who is thought to have started the blaze which killed 15 backpackers, including seven Britons, in a Queensland hostel last week.
fields.byline: by Jason Burke and Matthew Brace, Childers
fields.body:
Police in Australia yesterday launched a manhunt for a 37-year-old itinerant fruit picker who is thought to have started the blaze which killed 15 backpackers, including seven Britons, in a Queensland hostel last week.

Robert Paul Long was termed 'feral' by one resident of Childers yesterday. He is thought to come from Sydney, but had been living in Childers for three months and had spent several weeks picking fruit on the local mayor's farm.

Several survivors claim Long swore to burn down 'the Palace Backpackers Hostel' after a row with the management over payments last week. Australian survivor Darren Cameron claims a British couple were warned by Long on the eve of the fire to guard against arson.

'They told me they were sitting outside the hostel with [Long] and when they left him to go to bed about midnight the last thing he said was "sleep with the windows open and near the fire exit",' Cameron said. Police have not yet identified a man seen running away after the fire began, but Chief Superintendent Ken Benjamin, leading the investigation, said he 'strongly believed Long could help with inquiries'.

Fifteen backpackers are now known to have died and the toll may rise once the burnt-out shell of the building is made safe for further examination. The hostel register shows 85 residents on the fatal night and the Foreign Office says six are unaccounted for. Police have refused to release the identities of the deceased until formal identifications have taken place and are not confirming whether a list posted on the internet was correct.

The first body was removed yesterday and the rest are due to be recovered today. An inquest has been opened in Brisbane, 200 miles south of Childers. 'I have just walked through the scene of the fire and am heartbroken by what I have seen,' Michael Halliday, the coroner, said.

John Howard, the Australian Prime Minister, and the British High Commissioner will travel to Childers for a memorial service tonight. Emergency officials have been inundated with calls from anxious parents. Police asked all foreign backpackers in Australia to telephone their families.

John Howard, the Australian Prime Minister, and the British High Commissioner will travel to Childers for a memorial service tonight. Emergency officials have been inundated with calls from anxious parents. Police asked all foreign backpackers in Australia to telephone their families.

fields.headline: Suspect boasted of his crimes
fields.trailText: Robert Long, the man police believe started the fatal fire, is an alcoholic, schizophrenic loner with a criminal record,  writes Tracy McVeigh . People who met him were unsettled by his mood swings, strange behaviour and boasts about previous crimes.
fields.body:
Robert Long, the man police believe started the fatal fire, is an alcoholic, schizophrenic loner with a criminal record, writes Tracy McVeigh . People who met him were unsettled by his mood swings, strange behaviour and boasts about previous crimes.

Despite meeting dozens of backpackers in the Palace Hostel and while picking fruit, Long was usually seen alone and only mixed with other hostel residents for an occasional game of cards.

He left a suicide note in a local pub not long before apparently starting the blaze soon after midnight on Friday morning and, bizarrely, had warned several residents to leave their window open so they could escape from the fire.

Survivors yesterday described the 37-year-old suspect as an oddball. Darren Cameron, a 23-year-old from Brisbane, recalled: 'I used to drink with him. I thought he was a really friendly person. After a while you could tell he was mixed up, with different personalities. he was a different person every night.'

Adam Gutteridge, a 26-year-old from Droitwich in Worcestershire, said Long was 'a really strange character, quite short and nasty-looking with a really big beard. He slept on a seat in the television room and just growled at everyone, which people thought was a bit weird.'

Keith O'Brien from Wigan, another who survived the inferno which claimed 15 lives, described Long as 'a real nutter. He'd kip on the couch and nobody would go near it.'

Long regaled some of the young backpackers who he worked alongside with tales of his criminal past as he drank with them. 'He told us he had been convicted of attempted murder, fraud - you name it', recalled Phil Vaughan.

Another who met Long said his ex-wife and two children had been killed in a car crash and that he was 'seriously depressed'.

Yesterday another survivor, Neil Griffith from Fen Ditton, Cambridgeshire, said he had stumbled across Long standing near a burning rubbish bin not long before flames ripped through the century-old wooden hostel.

fields.headline: Counterfeit goods flood high streets
fields.trailText: A quarter of all goods bought by young people in some British high streets are fakes, while a third of branded goods sold over the internet are likely to be counterfeit.
fields.body:
A quarter of all goods bought by young people in some British high streets are fakes, while a third of branded goods sold over the internet are likely to be counterfeit.

New research has revealed that in the course of a single shopping trip in the North-West of England, one in four items seen by 16- to 25-year-old shoppers was fake.

The research, carried out by ArmorGroup, a leading global security risk management group, reveals an explosion in the manufacturing and distribution of fake goods over the past six months.

But not only fashion-conscious youngsters are vulnerable. New techniques to slip fake goods, from computer software to cigarettes, through customs could mean 90 per cent of discounted branded goods bought on the 'grey market' are counterfeit.

Howard Cottrell, executive director of IP Services at ArmorGroup, said: 'Anything with a brand identity is probably being counterfeited somewhere in the world, from tea bags to the most exclusive luxury item you can imagine.'

Statistics about to be published reveal that counterfeiting could be costing the European Union up to £250 billion a year in lost revenue, with more than 100,000 EU jobs lost each year as a result.

Cottrell believes counterfeiting operations have become so sophisticated that fraudsters anticipate consumer trends: 'Prototypes are stolen from international trade fairs and copied, often hitting the street before the original product itself.'

Last year, Reebok's prototype DMX shoe was stolen from a display stand by a Chinese gang. The counterfeit shoes were on sale in Eastern Europe and Russia within weeks.

'Some of the most violent and experienced criminals in the world have realised the profit to be made from counterfeiting,' he said. 'Why risk robbing banks or dealing in drugs when you can copy a £100 Microsoft CD for $2, or produce a £2,250 case of Western cigarettes for $180?'

Al Checkett, director of global security at Unilever Cosmetic International, agrees that some of the world's biggest criminals are using counterfeiting to make enormous profits and to laun der 'dirty money' from robberies and drug deals.

With more than 20 per cent of consumers saying they expect to conduct all their shopping via the internet or phone in five years' time, the problem can only get worse, according to Cottrell.

Of the 50 major IT lawyers, 50 City analysts and 100 top directors questioned by ArmorGroup, 33 per cent had handed over responsibility for brand protection to their legal advisers.

'Many companies, including some big brand owners, don't yet have an anti-counterfeiting strategy in place,' said Cottrell.

De La Rue, a lead provider in brand protection, believes modern technology has made fakes almost impossible to spot.'There's an assumption that if you go into an established chain, you will be buying authentic goods,' said Andy Blundell, managing director of brand protection. ' 'Often the only time people find that they've been sold counterfeit goods is when something goes wrong and they try to return it, only to discover they haven't got the slightest protection.'

webTitle: How Mitterrand sought advice from astrologer

fields.headline: How Mitterrand sought advice from astrologer
fields.trailText: An astrologer who for years advised Francois Mitterrand on affairs of state yesterday released tape recordings of conversations with the late French president, revealing that he asked her advice on issues as varied as the Gulf War and power struggles in the Kremlin.
fields.body:
An astrologer who for years advised Francois Mitterrand on affairs of state yesterday released tape recordings of conversations with the late French president, revealing that he asked her advice on issues as varied as the Gulf War and power struggles in the Kremlin.

Elisabeth Teissier, a best-selling writer and the author of several hugely popular 'you and your stars' columns in the French press, said she had released the tapes, published in the first issue of a new monthly magazine, Le Vrai Papier Journal , to refute suggestions that her relationship with Mitterrand - whose wife used to call him 'the great seducer' - was not solely professional.

Teissier, a former model and actress whom Mitterrand described as 'resembling Ava Gardner', first revealed her contribution to the late president's decision-making processes three years ago, claiming she was Mitterrand's confidante over the course of several years.

She said that between 1989 and 1994, the year before he left office, the president used to call her from the Elysée Palace before taking virtually any important decision. She said Mitterrand gave his approval for the conversations to be recorded from 1991 onwards, knowing that one day they would be made public.

In one conversation, on 9 January 1991, days before a crucial meeting between US secretary of state James Baker and Iraqi foreign minister Tariq Aziz in a last-gasp bid to avert the Gulf War, Teissier called Mitterrand herself to tell 'my dear, my eminent scorpion' that the stars were 'ultra-favourable' for the period around the 10th of the month.

'That's interesting, because at the moment Tariq Aziz is still talking,' Mitterrand replies. 'That's quite a good sign, because it wouldn't usually go on that long... They've been at it for four hours now.'

In another conversation, on 23 January, Teissier tells the president to avoid 'everything to do with the sea'. When Mitterrand asks if he risks 'a shipwreck in the Atlantic', the astrologer reassures him, and informs him that in March he would be likely to have 'a very important role indeed in the negotiations to end the war that will be taking place then'.

On 1 February, Mitterrand - who died of cancer in 1996, less than a year after leaving office - tells his soothsayer that he is soon going to have to make a speech about the progress of the war. 'You once told me there were days when it was better to talk, and days when it was better not to talk. When is the next best day for me to speak? Could you check for me?' he asks her. 'Sunday, Monday or Tuesday,' comes the reply.

Much later, in June, Teissier tells the president 'on no account to drive on the 7th of the month', while on 20 August she informs him bluntly: 'From tomorrow, I'm very much afraid that Yeltsin risks being ousted.' Mitterrand, concerned, replies: 'Oh really? Do keep me abreast of all that...'

Mitterrand's illegitimate daughter, Mazarine Pingeot, who has made a point of speaking out on every possible occasion to defend her father's crumbling reputation, insisted her father always took his decisions independently of Teissier's advice.

webTitle: Eleven shot dead in Bogota bar

fields.headline: Eleven shot dead in Bogota bar
fields.trailText: Eleven people were killed and seven wounded early yesterday morning when a man opened fire with a submachine gun in a crowded Bogota bar after a woman refused to dance.
fields.body:
Eleven people were killed and seven wounded early yesterday morning when a man opened fire with a submachine gun in a crowded Bogota bar after a woman refused to dance.

According to a police spokesman, the shooting followed an argument which broke out in the Reminencias nightclub. When the woman turned down a request for a dance the three men responsible for the killing left the bar briefly, returning a few minutes later with an Uzi sub-machine gun. Eight men and three women died in a hail of automatic fire.

Metropolitan police commander Argemiro Serna said the massacre, which took place in the gritty San Jorge neighbourhood, was a sign of the intolerance and violence which characterise life in this city of 7 million people.

A recent city bylaw outlawed the carrying of firearms at weekends, but despite frequent attempts to control Colombia's culture of violence illegal weapons are easily bought on the black market and arguments are often settled with knives and guns.

Meanwhile, a 36-year civil war, the burgeoning narcotics industry and economic crisis have fuelled spiralling crime rates.

Although fighting between leftist guerrillas, state security forces and right-wing paramilitaries is mainly focused in rural areas, last year there were 2,482 murders in Bogota. Urban guerrillas and paramilitary militias battle to control the sprawling slums in south Bogota, while pros titutes, homosexuals and drug addicts are regularly murdered by 'social cleansing' death squads.

Police said yesterday's shooting was the first mass killing in Bogota since a Colombian veteran of the Vietnam war shot dead 17 people in an Italian restaurant in 1987.

Earlier this month a court reduced the sentence of a man convicted of the 1998 murder of an American drugs enforcement agent in a nightclub brawl in northern Bogota. A judge ruled the gunman acted in self defence.

fields.headline: Alfonso and Jose 'Pepe' Fanjul
fields.trailText: In Review, on 18 April 1999, we published an extract from Christopher Hitchens's book No One Left to Lie To about Bill Clinton. Under the caption 'If you think Bill's bad wait till you meet his friends...' the extract suggested that Pepe and Alfonso Fanjul falsely posed as friends of affirmative action for minorities and affected differing political sympathies.
fields.body:
In Review, on 18 April 1999, we published an extract from Christopher Hitchens's book No One Left to Lie To about Bill Clinton. Under the caption 'If you think Bill's bad wait till you meet his friends...' the extract suggested that Pepe and Alfonso Fanjul falsely posed as friends of affirmative action for minorities and affected differing political sympathies.

We accept that Alfonso and Pepe Fanjul's separate political affiliations and support of affirmative action programs are long-standing and genuine.

We are also happy to make clear that Alfonso and Pepe Fanjul are respected businessmen who have not used their political connections for their own commercial ends. We acknowledge that any suggestion in the extract to the contrary was entirely unfounded.

We apologise unreservedly for any damage and distress caused to Alfonso and Pepe Fanjul by our publication of these statements in the extract and at their request have made a donation to a charity for underprivileged children and their families.

webTitle: Carpet spray cancer scare alert in US

fields.headline: Carpet spray cancer scare alert in US
fields.trailText: America's Environmental Protection Agency has issued a worldwide alert about a potentially toxic chemical used in Britain's biggest selling carpet and upholstery protection spray.
fields.body:
America's Environmental Protection Agency has issued a worldwide alert about a potentially toxic chemical used in Britain's biggest selling carpet and upholstery protection spray.

The main ingredient of Scotchgard, made by 3M, has been found in human tissue, wildlife and the general environment. Tests have raised fears that it could cause cancer and disrupt cell activity. After worldwide research on the spread of the chemical, the only human samples where it was not found was in stored blood of Korean War soldiers - taken before Scotchgard was invented.

After pressure from the US government's Environmental Protection Agency, 3M decided it would phase out production of the chemical, a fluorocarbon called PFOS, by the end of the year. It will cost the company £200 million-worth of sales of Scotchgard products, and destroy 1,500 jobs in three factories.

The EPA has now issued a statement warning: '3M data supplied to EPA indicated that these chemicals are very persistent in the environment, have a strong tendency to accumulate in human and animal tissues, and could potentially pose a risk to human health and the environment over the long term'.

The agency said it would urge companies to stop making the chemical and foreign governments to ban it.

As well as the top-selling Scotchgard carpet and upholstery spray, PFOS is used in fire-fighting foams, paints, adhesives and coatings for fabrics, leather and some paper products. It has been used for 40 years, but its durability, which makes it so useful, means that it has persisted in the environment.

The scare started when 3M monitored the health of workers in its factory in Antwerp, Belgium, which supplies Europe. To check it was just its own workers who were affected, 3M tested blood from a commercial blood bank. It found small amounts of the Scotchgard chemical in the blood of the general population.

In further tests it found 'minute traces' of the chemical in humans and wildlife throughout the world, including Britain.

The company, fearing huge legal suits, passed data to the EPA, and decided to phase out production.

3M insists: 'All existing knowledge indicates that the presence of the perfluorooctanyl compound [PFOS] at the extremely low levels detected does not pose a human health or environmental risk.'

However, fluorocarbons are believed to be carcinogenic. In tests, 3M gave very high dosages to monkeys, who had convulsions, and to rats, whose offspring died.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Air traffic controllers' strike hits BA flights to France
Almost all British Airways flights to and from France tomorrow are expected to be cancelled because of a planned one-day strike by French air traffic controllers.
fields.body:
Air traffic controllers' strike hits BA flights to France
Almost all British Airways flights to and from France tomorrow are expected to be cancelled because of a planned one-day strike by French air traffic controllers.

Teenager feared drowned
Hopes were fading of finding a 19-year-old holidaymaker from Stoke-on-Trent feared swept into the Irish Sea while walking in waves on Blackpool beach early yesterday. A man who tried to save him was rescued after 25 minutes.

Pensioner's trip in the news
George Ridge, 72, travelled down the Thames from Oxford to Henley in a boat modelled on The African Queen from the Humphrey Bogart film but made from old newspapers.

Mexican wave breaks record
Around 3,000 people formed the world's largest official Mexican wave at Storrington, West Sussex. It stretched about two miles across the South Downs and will be entered in the Guinness Book of Records .

Wedding feast
TV chef Jamie Oliver, star of the series, The Naked Chef , married his long-term girlfriend Juliette Norton, a former model, at All Saints Church, Rickling, Essex.

Police mount armed hospital guard on shot man
Armed police were guarding a man aged 39 in hospital after he was shot at his home in Morley, Leeds. His attacker tried to lure him outside, but when that failed fired through the window.

Lost leg's owner sought
Sussex police are trying to retrace the steps of the owner of a false leg after it was found lying in the road in Brighton by a taxi driver.

Fools and Horses may return
The BBC hinted that its comedy series Only Fools and Horses , which starred David Jason and Nicholas Lyndhurst as Del Boy and Rodney, might be revived. It ran for 15 years from 1981 and the final episode, shown at Christmas 1996, was seen by more than 24 million people.

Cage dancers Spice up debut
Posh Spice Victoria Beckham's debut solo single, 'Out of Your Mind', will be launched by a show which will feature 'raunchy dancing' and male dancers 'suspended in G-strings from the ceiling in cages'.

webTitle: Islay faces farcical whisky waste law

fields.headline: Islay faces farcical whisky waste law
fields.trailText: In Compton Mackenzie's Whisky Galore, Hebrideans conspired to defeat the Exciseman. But now the island of Islay faces an even more formidable opponent.
fields.body:
In Compton Mackenzie's Whisky Galore, Hebrideans conspired to defeat the Exciseman. But now the island of Islay faces an even more formidable opponent.

Soon, because of EU law, the island will be criss-crossed by road tankers dumping waste water from the distilleries. But The Observer can reveal that a new study shows the waste water may in fact benefit the environment.

The EU developed the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive because the Mediterranean was turning to sludge. But it applies to the whole community.

Islay's distilleries make more alcohol per capita than anywhere else in the world. Not just any alcohol, but celebrated peaty malts like Lagavulin, Laphroaig, Ardbeg and Bowmore.

'We dry the barley in peat smoke. That's what gives the whisky its distinctive flavour,' says Andy Cant of the island's malting house. When whisky is distilled, it leaves behind a liquid of yeast and cereal known as pot ale. Traditionally this is pumped straight into the sea but the EU Directive insists that any industrial waste water pumped into the sea must meet certain standards.

The pot ale does not meet the EU criteria because the alchemy of whisky production occurs in copper stills and traces of the metal get into the water. The new law says pot ale must either be treated or pumped into fast-flowing currents to prevent concentrations building up.

Laphroaig's outfall pipe is long enough already but Lagavulin distillery along with three others have had to come up with a different solution. The traffic will be constant as two eight-hour shifts a day work to get the pot ale to the new facility. 'The EU law is aimed at the environment, but what about the noise and pollution of all that traffic' says Mr. Palmer.

The distilleries say they considered alternatives but road tankers were the only economically viable solution. 'It's ridiculous we are having to do this in the first place' says Brian Cant, of United Distillers and Vintners.

That sense of farce is set to grow as The Observer has learnt that new scientific evidence shows distillery waste can help the environment.

Ian Lambert, United Distillers environmental officer, says the findings of an independent study to be published this year show that naturally occurring chemicals in the peaty soil neutralise the effects of the copper. 'It even suggests that the discharged water is good for the environment,' he says.

What concerns islanders is that this once tranquil spot will soon be ruined by the noise and pollution of the tankers. They worry that the same peat which gives the whisky its taste does not make a good surface to build roads on. Locals fear that tankers will literally crush them into the bog.

fields.headline: Vive la belle France
fields.standfirst: They're taking over our firms, their football team is rampant, their economy is booming and their health service is better than ours. No wonder French joie de vivre is back. Move over cool Britannia...
fields.trailText: Maybe it began one hot and heady July evening two years ago, when Zinedine Zidane, Manu Petit, Marcel Desailly and friends held up the World Cup trophy they had just won by beating the best football team on earth 3-0.
fields.body:
Maybe it began one hot and heady July evening two years ago, when Zinedine Zidane, Manu Petit, Marcel Desailly and friends held up the World Cup trophy they had just won by beating the best football team on earth 3-0.

Or maybe it was a year earlier, with the surprise election of a Socialist-led government that has since privatised more companies than its four predecessors put together, presided over a 3 per cent fall in unemployment, and seen the French economy grow faster than Germany's, Italy's or Britain's.

Or maybe it emerged last year with the triumphant arrival in France of the dotcom revolution: since then the financing of web start-ups has tripled, the number of internet connections has increased fivefold, and Paris's Nouveau Marché high-tech stocks have soared by an astounding 135 per cent.

However and whenever it began, France today is busy reinventing itself. A country renowned for its heavy-handed bureaucracy, ossified social structure, inefficient and unprofitable state-owned firms, is changing. A once great nation reduced to wallowing in nostalgia and self-doubt has, suddenly, regained its confidence in the future.

'France is finally on the move,' said Jean-Marie Messier, 42, boss of Vivendi, the firm perhaps more than any other at the business end of this dramatic turnaround. 'It's taken a long time, and it may not be moving as fast as some of us would like, but there is nowadays a feeling that all things are possible.'

In 1996, when Messier took up the reins, Vivendi was an unwieldy, heavily loss-making, 150-year-old utility company called Compagnie Générale des Eaux. Messier sold off £10 billion of underperforming assets, radically reorganised the group around two main activities - water and waste treatment, and communications - and boosted sales to £20bn in 1999.

Earlier this year it sealed a joint venture with Europe's biggest mobile phone operator, Vodafone Airtouch, to provide a so-called multi-access portal (MAP) giving internet access to 80 million people in 15 countries through their computer, mobile phone or TV set.

Vivendi pulled off a mega-merger last week with Canada's Seagram's - owners of the Hollywood studios Universal Pictures and the world's biggest music company, Universal Music, whose stars include U2, Sting and Elton John - and the French pay-TV operator Canal Plus, in a deal worth £24bn.

Such aggression in the global corporate merger war is a departure for France. But Vivendi is not alone: the advertising giant Publicis has just bought Saatchi & Saatchi for £1.3bn, France Télécom last month snapped up British mobile phone operator Orange for £33bn, chemicals and pharmaceuticals group Rhne Poulenc last year merged with Hoechst to form Aventis. And to cap it all, France's richest man, François Pinault, recently swallowed Christie's.

'Nobody, but nobody would have predicted, for example, that French companies would now be outperforming German companies in almost every arena that matters,' Messier said. 'For decades Germany has been king of continental European business. Now, indisputably, it is France. That's a huge turnaround.'

Messier is a former high-flying civil servant and graduate of the Ecole Nationale d'Administration, or ENA - the mandarins' finishing school that has produced two of the past three Presidents, six of the past eight Prime Ministers and half the 17 senior Ministers in the present government. Once, ENA was a magnet for the brightest of the twentysomethings, and virtually guaranteed a job for life in the higher echelons of the civil service or a brilliant political career.

In the new France, applications to ENA have tumbled by a third over the past two years. The success of a very different college could explain why: Epita, specialising in advanced computer studies and the internet is open 24 hours a day, seven days a week and has trebled its intake in the same time.

The world wide web, which France was initially reluctant to adopt, is forcing a dramatic sea change in French attitudes to society, work and money. The new generation of dotcom millionaires did not go to the famous grandes écoles , nor do they routinely rub shoulders with the traditional elites. They just had a good idea, and are prepared to put in the hours to make it work. 'France is surfing on the internet information technology wave, and I don't think it's a passing phase,' said Joel Courtois, Epita's director. 'A lot of things are suddenly different: it's OK to work enormously hard, to make lots of money, to prefer to be part of an informal team rather than some hierarchical elite. The youngsters at this school have completely outgrown the old French model.'

The old certainties, that for so long prevented France from embracing what is still known rather disdainfully here as 'Anglo-Saxon liberalism', are fast disappearing. 'Top minds are not turning to the administration any more as their first choice,' said one disillusioned ENA graduate.

'Partly that's to do with a steadily deteriorating public image of the state; partly with the fact that business is now moving so fast - and it doesn't recruit from ENA. Before the internet and the new economy, ENA left all your options open. Now it closes a very big one off.'

France these days is strong in almost every economic area of the future: transport with its high-speed TGV train, aerospace with the Toulouse-based Airbus Industrie consortium and the Ariane space project, entertainment, communications, tourism, agrobusiness, genetics and tourism. But the revival is not purely economic. The exploits of France's multicoloured football team, which this evening plays Spain in the European Championship quarter finals, and of its rugby squad, which walloped the All Blacks to reach the World Cup final, are a source of well-founded national pride.

French literature, in the doldrums as far as the world market was concerned since the likes of Camus and Sagan, has found a new star in Michel Houellebecq, the quasi-existentialist nihilist for the internet age, whose two first novels, Whatever and Elementary Particles , have recently been translated into English.

The prolific French cinema industry, whose chief export for the past 15 years has been Gérard Depardieu, is turning out new talent recognised across the Atlantic. Young French stars Virginie Ledoyen and Guillaume Canet probably did more than anyone since Brigitte Bardot to raise awareness of France in America by starring with Leonardo DiCaprio in The Beach. And if French music was once laughed off the stage in London, ambient post-rock, post-club bands like Air enjoy major success across the Channel. No less an authority than the NME said 'the future sound of easy listening is end-of-the-millennium French techno'.

France still has things to sort out. It maintains one of Europe's biggest, most inflexible public sectors, which employs one in four of the workforce. Its heavy tax burden still forces many small businesses to set up shop in Britain or America. But these days few French people would agree with the kind of statement made by Jean Baudrillard, a sociologist, only four years ago: 'We want to be an alternative, to show that if nobody resists America any more, at least we will - but because we are not sure what model to embody, we tend to offer simply inertia.'

France today is anything but inert. There is a spring in the Gallic step. 'This is a very real, positive rebound, a surge in energy, confidence and passion, a will to change things, to turn traditional values around,' said Bernard Cathelat, a sociologist. 'For the first time since the would-be revolution of 1968, the French want to change the way the way they live their lives.' Cool Britannia? More like groovy Gaul.

La nouvelle élite

fields.headline: Lebanon's real lessons
fields.trailText: Meeting Mahmoud Ossaili is a humbling experience. The walls of his two-storey home on the edge of Rashaf village in south Lebanon are flecked with shell and bullet holes. His wife is blind in one eye after a machine-gun attack on their house. Landmines killed two of the donkeys he used to take him to fields where he eked out a meagre existence. His grandchildren and great nephews and nieces cannot play outside the house because they might suffer the same fate. The daily threat of annihilation took its toll, with Mahmoud suffering several heart attacks during the occupation. Despite all this, Mahmoud, a pious, meek man in his late seventies repeatedly thanked Allah for his survival.
fields.body:
Meeting Mahmoud Ossaili is a humbling experience. The walls of his two-storey home on the edge of Rashaf village in south Lebanon are flecked with shell and bullet holes. His wife is blind in one eye after a machine-gun attack on their house. Landmines killed two of the donkeys he used to take him to fields where he eked out a meagre existence. His grandchildren and great nephews and nieces cannot play outside the house because they might suffer the same fate. The daily threat of annihilation took its toll, with Mahmoud suffering several heart attacks during the occupation. Despite all this, Mahmoud, a pious, meek man in his late seventies repeatedly thanked Allah for his survival.

For more than two decades the Ossailis were prisoners of the Israeli-controlled South Lebanon Army, a rag-tag band of Christian sectarians and mercenary Moslems. Over a round of thick treacly coffee, Mahmoud explained that he knew the men inside the heavily fortified compound which overlooked Rashaf. They came from two Christian villages, Dbil and Ein Nbil, a few kilometres away.

The SLA 'officers' inside the now-abandoned compound were the sons of a man Mahmoud has known for most of his life, Abu George. For more than 20 years Abu George's sons used Israeli-supplied weapons to harass and intimidate the Rashaf populace. Most fled north or to Shia Moslem villages under the protection of the UN, particularly the zone under the Irish battalion's control. A few, like Mahmoud clung on to their homes.

The family only remained thanks to the weekly food and fuel drop from Irish troops. He and a few older residents would mount their donkeys and ride along the dirt road, past the SLA compound with its guns trained on their pitiful caravan and out towards the Irish post. (If you want to help Irishbatt's humanitarian efforts, contact the Defence Forces Press office at DFHQ, Parkgate, Dublin 8.)

Now the SLA men have fled to Israel and an uncertain future. Meanwhile, their families face an equally uncertain future inside a new free, united Lebanon. Those who have stayed in Dbil and Ein Nbil were nervous. Ironically they wanted Irish troops to deploy into their villages, the same villages which provided SLA soldiers that menaced Irishbatt.

When I asked if Mahmoud would like to see Dbil and Ein Nbil suffer the same fate as a shell-shattered, depopulated Rashaf, he threw his hands into the air and shook his head: 'No way, no way. There has been too much blood, too much blood.'

Mahmoud's spirit of forgiveness was one I came across constantly in the Shia Moslem villages close to the Israeli frontier. Even the Islamic Resistance's political leadership, Amal, and the more fundamentalist Hizbollah, were pragmatic about the need for reconciliation. On May 22, when the Israelis pulled out and the SLA collapsed, Irish UN officers had expected bloodletting. Nothing of the sort happened. In fact I saw young bearded men from the Hizbollah armed with AK47s patrolling the border to ensure no further clashes with the Israelis.

Mahmoud's story is germane to our own peace process. Lebanon has just been through a messy and infinitely more brutal civil conflict than we could ever imagine. And yet there is a real sense among all parties there that a line must be finally drawn under the past. The Arabic concept of 'Sulha', roughly translated, as 'revenge', is one that most Lebanese believe has had its day. Sadly, this spirit seems lacking in our own peace process.

The differences between Lebanon and Northern Ireland might outweigh the parallels. But the Lebanese are finally coming to terms with the unsettling truth that coexistence requires real compromises. What a pity our own myopic politicians are still playing to their own constituencies rather than creating a common space for national reconciliation to begin.

webTitle: Stench of sleaze beneath Monaco's perfumed glitz

fields.headline: Stench of sleaze beneath Monaco's perfumed glitz
fields.standfirst: Monaco's wealth is built on dirty money and at the centre of the corruption is the casino
fields.trailText: The cloying stink of dirty money is hard to convey in a newspaper that smells, if anything, of the fading musk of printers' ink, but Monaco's pong requires description.
fields.body:
The cloying stink of dirty money is hard to convey in a newspaper that smells, if anything, of the fading musk of printers' ink, but Monaco's pong requires description.

Imagine, then, the Birmingham Inner Ring Road, a slow-moving, never-ending treacle of traffic belching out fumes, and transport it en bloc to the sclerotic alleys and troglodytic gunnels carved through Monaco's one mile by a quarter of a mile lump of limestone. No ordinary traffic jam, mind: we're talking Bentleys, Ferraris, Porsches, Mercs and stretch-limos better equipped with drugs than the hospital in Sierra Leone, all smogging away at three miles an hour.

Vroom-vroom.

Take these exquisitely-tooled exhausts and intrude them into the windless air of the polluted Monegasque littoral, nailed by Somerset Maugham a lifetime ago as 'a sunny place for shady people'. Paint in shops with gilded marble floors, and shop assistants no less warm-blooded selling handbags for the same price as a home in Sheffield.

Gucci-gucci.

Take the rococo centrepiece of Monte Carlo, the casino, reversing Christ's command - 'into my temple ye brood of vipers'. Inside, it is cathedral-quiet as flunkeys whisper and the High Priests of Big Money make their homage to the roulette wheel. Outside, a gawking throng of plebs worship the arrivals with their respectful murmurs. A couple saunter into the casino: she is young, a raven-haired goddess, with the body of a buttered angel; he is old, and has the skin and hooded eyes of a lizard about to flick out its tongue and gobble her up.

Yum-yum.

Out to sea, as idle as a painted gin palace upon a painted ocean, is a five-masted yacht so ridiculously big it dwarfs the US Navy cruiser here on friendly patrol. In the corner of the harbour, away from the fancier boat-palaces, are the smaller vessels bobbing up and down in a scum of Evian bottles and patisserie paper, the wrappings of croissants, long-consumed, swirling around in an endless eddy.

Welcome to Monaco, where even the scum is rich. And now, three hammer blows that spell trouble for the stinking rich of the microdot nation.

Glug-glug.

First, a French parliamentary commission has produced a report, telling us what we already know: that Monaco's fortune is built on dirty money. Second, the G8's anti-money-laundering unit only left off Monaco's name from its worst offender blacklist after pressure from the French government.

Third, a French judge quoted in the report has raised doubts about the family of His Most Serene Highness Prince Rainier, noting that 'funds of suspect origin' had been in a joint account belonging to Princess Stephanie and her disgraced ex-husband, Daniel Ducruet. Although the princess has always distanced herself from Ducruet's financial dealings, the judge further accuses the authorities of covering up the stink because it got too close to the Royal Family.

The French parliamentary report is plainly rude about the set-up in Monaco, saying that the 'sovereign state of the Principality has chosen fiscal and commercial legislation and a method of judicial working that does not meet European or international norms'. The report's co-author, Arnaud Montebourg, spells it out even less sweetly: 'The Monegasque law is a luxurious shop window behind which shelter less seductive realities. 'The killer section of the report attacked The Rock, as the French call Monaco, at its most revered point, its unholy of unholies, the state-owned casino. This functioned 'without respect for international standards'.

The suggestion is that the casino may be complicit in money-laundering, and it's all the more embarrassing because one of the directors is the ailing His Most Serene Highness himself.

One witness was a former investigating judge who looked into the casino in Monaco, Charles Duchaine.

For the MPs, he detailed the amazing practices of the justice ministry in the state. When he started looking at the casino, he discovered dossiers that had been censored, with pages docked and reports removed, some of them ruled with a diagonal line: 'This passage of no interest for the case.' People running the casino, close to power, had not to be worried, said Judge Duchaine. The inquiry was kicked into touch.

The most damning evidence heard by the inquiry relates to the case of Daniel Ducruet, the former husband of Princess Stephanie.

In 1996, Francisco Chiaro-lanza, an Italian who was suspected of money-laundering, was arrested. They went through his books and found that he had made Ducruet the president of a number of his companies. They found a joint account 'through which ran funds of eminently suspect origin' - bearing the names of Ducruet and Princess Stephanie.

Judge Duchaine took up the case, and took his findings to Monaco's Prosecutor. Duchaine told the French MPs: 'The prosecutor asked me if I would accept to re-do a number of things or to drop them. I have only the memory that these documents put in evidence the participation of Ducruet and some money-laundering activities.'

After Ducruet's evidence was heard, the prosecutor at that time asked for some of it to be 'modified'. For Judge Duchaine, 'these modifications were not contested because otherwise the evidence would have revealed intrigues capable of blackening the name of Ducruet and his ex-wife'.

Evidence like this convinced Montebourg, chairman of the National Assembly's Information Mission on Money Laundering, that all is not well on the Rock. His report accuses the principality of having no proper system of banking ethics, of allowing its celebrated casino to run out of control and of refusing co-operation with international efforts to control suspect flows of capital.

The parliamentary committee suggested France, which provides almost all senior officials in Monaco, including the chief minister, was partly to blame.

The committee called on the French government to scrap all its fiscal and judicial arrangements with the statelet, negotiated in 1963. The committee also criticised Monaco's secretive banking system, with 300,000 accounts for 30,000 people.

The principality's company law allowed a proliferation of offshore businesses, whose activities were beyond legal control, it said. According to one of the magistrates heard by the commission in December, around 50 administrators run hundreds of companies of which the beneficial owners are not known.

Worse, legally the judiciary in Monaco has no right to seek information on the companies' activities.

One commission witness, Monsieur Y, is the head of the anti-money-laundering unit in a big French bank with a branch in Monaco.

He wanted to check the identity of account-holders, who they were, and where they got their money from. He told the MPs: 'I discovered that for a quarter of our clients we didn't have any acceptance paperwork for them... I then asked for a global dossier of all the clients that we had refused. It was a blank page.'

More chilling yet was the testimony of Monsieur Z, who was sentenced to 37 years for cocaine trafficking in the States.

He banked in Monaco: 'You arrive with X million francs and you tell them that it is the commission that you got from the sale of a very nice property. They tell you: "Oh good, that's great". They ask simply to know the origin of the funds, but they don't verify the truth of your claim. If ever, in Monaco, the banks begin to ask questions about the origin of money, Monaco will no longer have a reason to be.'

Poo-poo.

webTitle: Has US lost its death lust?

fields.headline: Has US lost its death lust?
fields.standfirst: As Texas kills another man who may be innocent,  Ed Vulliamy finds capital punishment itself under fire
fields.trailText: Gary Graham was dragged to his execution on Thursday after two decades on death row, fulfilling his promise to 'fight like hell'. He struggled like a trapped animal as - handcuffed, which is highly unusual in these last moments - he was tethered to the gurney to receive the lethal injection. His arms were bruised, his prison vest rumpled.
fields.body:
Gary Graham was dragged to his execution on Thursday after two decades on death row, fulfilling his promise to 'fight like hell'. He struggled like a trapped animal as - handcuffed, which is highly unusual in these last moments - he was tethered to the gurney to receive the lethal injection. His arms were bruised, his prison vest rumpled.

The physical fight lasted 30 seconds. The legal one - an appeal for clemency pending DNA tests and the hearing of further evidence - was already lost.

A divided board of pardons rejected a 120-day stay of execution that morning by 12 votes to five, and a riven high court endorsed its decision by five judicial votes to four. 'They are murdering me tonight,' said Graham, as he looked into the eyes of his appointed witness, Jesse Jackson. 'This is nothing more simple than state-sanctioned murder in America. They know I am innocent. Keep marching, black people...' He died with one eye shut and one eye open, apparently looking at Jackson. 'There was no tears shed,' said Jackson afterwards.

Outside the death chamber in Huntsville, Texas, demonstrators drove a wedge in the police lines that held them back.

A hundred yards away, hooded members of the Ku Klux Klan unfurled Confederate flags and cheered Graham's death. The death penalty itself is now on trial. Graham's execution takes the number of people executed in the killer-state of Texas since the death penalty was reintroduced to 221.

Of those, 135 have taken place since George W. Bush became governor - and Graham's was by far the most controversial and tenuous case. This time, however, the pardons board had spared Bush a difficult political decision; they had not passed him the buck.

The presidential candidate who signed Graham's death warrant once wrote: 'the worst nightmare for a death penalty supporter and of anyone who believes in our criminal justice system is to execute an innocent man'.

But America is now under the pall of the nightmarish spectre that this has happened yet again. For not only does Gary Graham's death leave the marks of a physical struggle in the death chamber, but a trail of unheard evidence, untried tests and uncertainty at the core of his case.

No sooner had Graham's body slumped lifeless than another death penalty controversy was breaking - this time not over the head of Governor Bush, but President Clinton and his appointed dauphin, Bush's presidential election rival, Al Gore.

A condemned migrant agricultural worker, Juan Raul Garza, is due to be executed in Texas on 5 August - not at the order of the Texas state court but of the federal court system. His will be the first federal execution since John Kennedy was President.

And there is a hitch which cuts to the core of another nightmare surrounding the death penalty apart from that of innocence - race.

Garza's lawyers have challenged the President - with the powerful support of the American Bar Association - to call a moratorium on all 21 pending federal executions. And as part of the challenge is an application for the release of a government study into how far race is a factor in applying the death penalty.

The Justice Department has so far turned down the application for Garza's lawyers to analyse the data on which the report is based, with a spokesman saying that the study has not yet been completed.

But Gregory Wierchioch, representing Garza, say he knows that the study has examined at least 12 cases similar to Garza's - involving drug-related murders - in which the federal government did not seek the death penalty.

Wiercioch says that, of the 27 people condemned by the administration of Bush's father for drug-related killings, 23 are black or Hispanic - and he wants to know why.

A former member of a Justice Department review committee, Rory Little, wrote in the Fordham Law Journal recently that between 1994 and 1999 one-third of US attorneys' offices did not file capital punishment requests in similar cases. Garza's lawyers believe that the data reveals the motive to be racial.

The potential Garza crisis for the White House is detonated by the fact that Texas was forced only two weeks ago to suspend nine executions pending investigations into alleged racial bias.

A special review panel had found that, in every case, race had been cited by the prosecution psychiatrist as a reason the defendant constituted a future threat - a pre-requisite for a death sentence in Texas.

The coming federal execution row will turn the spotlight from Bush towards his rival, Gore - whose silence over the Graham execution has been deafening.

Vice-President Gore is an equally ardent supporter of the death penalty, but was last week forced to admit, with respect to the Justice Department study, that 'the question of racial disparity is right now being investigated thoroughly'.

The intervention of the American Bar Association is a crucial and novel ingredient, indicative of swelling public impatience with the death penalty. In a letter to President Clinton last month calling for a federal moratorium, the association's president, William Paul, went expressly beyond the race issue, urging 'a comprehensive examination of the federal death penalty that would not be limited to the question of racial discrimination'.

The challenge is a bold one, to both President Clinton and Vice-President Gore. Successive presidential campaigns have been propelled by the death penalty issue ever since Michael Dukakis let Willie Horton out on parole in 1988, only for him to commit another rape-murder.

But now the wheels of public patience with - let alone support for - the death penalty and the Texas execution machine are turning against the received wisdom of past campaigns, and against the governor of Texas.

All across America - at 9.20 Eastern Time on Thursday, when the guards entered Graham's holding cell - there were demonstrations. 'Moratorium Now Abolition Next' read the placards, from Seattle to Miami, Los Angeles to Maine. Angry crowds faced off with the police in New York's Times Square - 'Turn it off! Turn it off!' - in scenes that have not been seen in America before.

Support for the death penalty is down to 66 per cent - a majority to be sure, but the smallest since the reintroduction of the measure in the 1970s.

Last month New Hampshire became the first state since the reinstatement of the death penalty to abolish it. In Illinois, the hardline Republican governor, George Ryan - a long time proponent of capital punishment - rekindled the latest death penalty debate by imposing a moratorium on all executions.

Ryan has set up a commission to investigate why 13 men were sent to death row only to be subsequently exonerated by new evidence. Establishing the commission, the governor said: 'I don't know if we'll ever go back to the death penalty as we knew it'.

America's position is increasingly open to international criticism. An unpublished UN report obtained by The Observer shows America in fourth place, behind China, Iran and Saudi Arabia, in the ranks of numbers of state executions.

The only other developed country to retain the death penalty is Japan where a tiny number are allowed every year.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Israeli troops fire on Jordanian delegation
fields.body:
Israeli troops fire on Jordanian delegation

Israeli soldiers wounded three Jordanian civilian members of an official delegation when they fired at them across the Lebanese border at Fatma Gate, closed since the Israeli forces withdrew last month. The delegation had been shouting slogans, proclaiming 'Palestine is Arab'.

Vatican criticises China

The Vatican denounced plans by China to ordain new bishops for its state Catholic Church, saying such a move would place new obstacles in the path of closer relations between Rome and Beijing.

Fiji hopes dashed

Hopes for an end to Fiji's hostage crisis were dashed after plans by the military and rebels to sign a deal for the release of Prime Minister Mahendra Chaudhry and 30 other hostages collapsed.

Ferry captain arrested

Chinese authorities have arrested the captain and the owner of an overloaded ferry that capsized in the Yangtze river, leaving more than 100 people feared dead.

Dolphin inseminated

Scientists at Hong Kong Polytechnic University have for the first time artificially inseminated a dolphin, by accurately predicting ovulation using ultrasound.

Cemetery attacked

Five German youths suspected of overturning or damaging 35 gravestones in the Jewish cemetery in the western German town of Worms, once a major Jewish centre, were being questioned by police.

Landslides kill 10

Landslides triggered by torrential monsoon rains Saturday left at least 10 people dead in the port city of Chittagong, Bangladesh.

Motorway blockade

Environmental activists ended their blockade of a key Alpine motorway - the Brenner motorway, which links Austria with Germany and Italy - but threatened further protests against lorry traffic choking the mountains unless their demands were met. Local people have been incensed by a 50 per cent increase in traffic since 1993.

Microlight plight

Colin Bodill, 49, the British pilot trying to make the first solo around-the-world flight in a microlight aircraft. said he hoped China would allow him to continue after forcing him to land when he was blown off his authorised course.

Actress instinctively goes back to basics

Actress Sharon Stone, above, has signed for a reported $15 million to reprise the defining role of her career, in a sequel to the 1992 hit Basic Instinct. But Michael Douglas, who played a policeman who becomes sexually involved with Stone's murder suspect, is not returning.

fields.headline: Put a cork in it
fields.trailText: I would like to correct the impression given by Eduardo Gonçalves' article (Business, last week) concerning Safeway's policy of using plastic stoppers for wine.
fields.body:
I would like to correct the impression given by Eduardo Gonçalves' article (Business, last week) concerning Safeway's policy of using plastic stoppers for wine.

The main threat to the survival of the cork forests of Portugal comes from the supermarket groups such as Safeway. By forcing wine producers to use plastic instead of natural cork stoppers, the supermarkets are removing the main economic benefit that sustains the forests and encourages more trees to be planted.

Far from driving out wild pigs, the cork forests produce acorns on which these animals thrive. This natural habitat is protected by law: years and harvesting of cork bark is only permitted every nine years. To harvest more frequently would not make economic sense: this is the minimum period a tree requires to produce cork suitable for stoppers.
Geoffrey Kelly
Portuguese Cork Association

fields.headline: Liberal tendency
fields.trailText: Brendan Prendiville (Letters, last week) attacks my attempt to explain the liberal élite. He says that the Conservatives were in office for much of the time when that élite was most active.
fields.body:
Brendan Prendiville (Letters, last week) attacks my attempt to explain the liberal élite. He says that the Conservatives were in office for much of the time when that élite was most active.

Many of the key issues were not contested at elections or in Parliament. Those that were did not divide MPs or peers along party lines. The most influential reforms of the Sixties - on obscenity, sexual offences, capital punishment, abortion - were private members' bills. Much of the Tory Party was until recently in the grip of liberal ideas on moral and cultural matters. Most of the rest was uninterested.

This deficiency was not corrected by Thatcherism. Margaret Thatcher failed to defeat conservatism's domestic cultural enemies in the education industry and the BBC, concentrating instead on an obsession with the market.
Peter Hitchens
London SE1

fields.headline: Hunt hypocrisy
fields.trailText: The worst feature of the current anti-hunting campaign is its tokenism. No other factor impedes more thoroughly an overdue re-evaluation of our relations with animals in general.
fields.body:
The worst feature of the current anti-hunting campaign is its tokenism. No other factor impedes more thoroughly an overdue re-evaluation of our relations with animals in general.

There can never be a case for grovelling before 'the settled will' of a predominantly urban puritan majority that has mounted similar campaigns against such undoubted evils as Maypole dancing, Christmas carols, most sex and all alcohol.

Nor is it possible to take seriously your conclusion that 'the liberty to inflict fear, pain, mutilation and death on animals is one that the majority are no longer prepared to grant' (Leader, last week). For every fox hunted to a quick death, a million chickens are force-reared in darkened sheds to be electrocuted and have their throats slit while still alive. Do you consider the latter different because it is performed by urban society's po-faced servants for cash rather than by bucolic amateurs for amusement?
James Leigh
Ripon, N Yorks

fields.headline: RIP could scupper our e-revolution
fields.trailText:
If John Carr really believes the opposition to the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill is Thatcherite, élitist and anti-democratic, perhaps he should get out more. But in any case the Bill will have minimal effect on crime because all but the most stupid criminals will simply switch to a foreign internet service provider for their emails, if necessary via a mobile phone. It already makes sense to host your website in the United States, not only because it's usually cheaper but also because the US constitution provides far greater legal protection than in the UK. If the Bill becomes law in its present form it will end any hope of Britain taking a leading role in ecommerce. In less time than it will take MPs to vote, many online companies will move their entire operation overseas.
Roger Houghton
Bath, Somerset

 Besides the RIP bill being an infringement of liberties, it is illogical on several counts and will not deter the professional criminal from using email.

Any project set-up should include a 'criminal sub-group' whose purpose is to examine the proposed project from the viewpoint of potential criminal activity. This will help to determine the viability of the project.

Taking such a stance in connection with the RIP proposals, by employing an internet service provider based in another country, any UK legislation would be circumvented. The phone bills might be a little higher, but might be worth paying, especially if you desire privacy, for whatever reason, criminal or non-criminal.

On the basis that money will buy anything, the modus operandi of the surveillance systems will soon be ascertained by the criminal fraternity. More elaborate coding techniques for messages will result which will then need more complex detection to be implemented by the ISPs in the UK. This will result in a never-ending spiral which will cost money, which will, necessarily, come from Joe Public. The worst case scenario is that it may be cheaper for all UK internet email users to employ a US ISP with higher phone bills than a UK ISP with more expensive overheads.
Dr Brian Legg
Coventry

 How many criminals will be successfully prosecuted as a result of the Government's intercepting of emails? No serious terrorist or drug dealer is likely to communicate by any means which is easily subject to eavesdropping. So who do the security services really wish to spy on?
Brian Moss
Tamworth, Staffs

fields.headline: Too masculine
fields.trailText: Richard Ingrams (Diary, last week) clearly has some issues with his own masculinity. Not content with his regular homophobic rants, he now suggests that Tony Blair's decision to take time off to bond with his new offspring left him 'looking far from manly'. Since when was a participatory and involved approach   to fatherhood incompatible with 'being a man'?
fields.body:
Richard Ingrams (Diary, last week) clearly has some issues with his own masculinity. Not content with his regular homophobic rants, he now suggests that Tony Blair's decision to take time off to bond with his new offspring left him 'looking far from manly'. Since when was a participatory and involved approach to fatherhood incompatible with 'being a man'?

Given the growing alienation of female voters from the macho posturing which passes for policy under New Labour, reported elsewhere in your paper ('Women Wave Bye-Bye to Tony'), many would welcome more, rather than less, displays of sensitivity and domesticity from our political masters.

If Blair is to be criticised, it is not for his demonstrations of public affection, but for his failure to take the opportunity to establish both maternity and paternity leave as a recognised and valued part of every individual's working life. The persistence of a masculine culture which continues to undervalue the domestic and co-operative in favour of the public and the competitive makes a nonsense of New Labour's claims of social modernisation and Ingrams's absurd panics over the 'feminisation' of society.
Dr Martin Francis
Royal Holloway College
University of London

fields.headline: Violence is the English way
fields.trailText: I agree with you on football violence (Leader, last week), but I will go further. It would be too simple to apportion violent behaviour to disenfranchised youth, living in poverty. As a foreigner living here for 16 years, I feel that the violence has permeated all of society and has become a way for many youngsters, deprived or not, to express their Englishness.
fields.body:

As a foreigner living here for 16 years, I feel that the violence has permeated all of society and has become a way for many youngsters, deprived or not, to express their Englishness.

The xenophobia used by the Conservative Party, especially Margaret Thatcher, to score political points against Europe, the immigrants and so on, has produced a generation of youngsters only able to define their English identity in opposition to their perceived enemies, and not by their common culture.

What is needed is a rethink of the way our children, especially boys, are brought up, condemn and punish bullying in school and workplace, and monitor the press (it does not mean censorship, but maybe a legislation dealing with racist and xenophobic abuse and incitation to violence).

Annie Howard
Radley, Oxon

fields.headline: Adopt new laws
fields.trailText: Mothers such as Julie Goldsmith (News, last week) would not have to be at the mercy of bogus private investigators on the internet if the Government would take action to stop another kind of lottery. Adoption agencies and social services departments can decide whether to act as mediators by helping 'birth' or 'first' parents to send a message to the children they had to part with, enabling the adult adopted child to know that a parent is seeking contact. The birth mother must accept that her child may not want to see her but at least she will not live with uncertainty.

Adoption agencies and social services departments can decide whether to act as mediators by helping 'birth' or 'first' parents to send a message to the children they had to part with, enabling the adult adopted child to know that a parent is seeking contact. In other local authorities (Westminster among others), social services departments think they have a duty to 'protect' adult adopted children from their original parents.

A Department of Health report on this has gone to the Prime Minister and there is hope that Ministers will change the situation - grieving mothers have died without having contacted their lost children, and children have traced birth parents only to find that they have died.

London SE13

fields.headline: 'Staff for favours' row hits Treasury
fields.trailText: Oil companies, financial consultants and building firms who have 'donated' staff free to the Treasury have won lucrative government contracts and profited from crucial policy changes, an  Observer investigation has revealed.
fields.byline: by Antony Barnett, public affairs editor
fields.body:
Oil companies, financial consultants and building firms who have 'donated' staff free to the Treasury have won lucrative government contracts and profited from crucial policy changes, an Observer investigation has revealed.

It drags the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, into a 'staff-for-favours' row, with the Liberal Democrats demanding full details of all projects that private-sector staff inside the Treasury have worked on since the election.

The number of staff big business has seconded to government has mushroomed since Labour came to power, prompting fears that corporations are exploiting information for commercial gain and lobbying through the back door. The Observer has uncovered that:

 Financial consultants Price Waterhouse Coopers, Ernst & Young and Pannell Kerr Forster have all donated staff to Brown since the election. All have won lucrative consultancy contracts from the Treasury, at least one without a competitive tender. These firms have also had success in forcing Brown to backtrack on plans to stop their multinational clients avoiding tax by channelling profits through offshore companies;

 Oil giants BP and Esso have had staff working in the Treasury during a period when Brown has dropped plans to toughen the tax regime on oil companies working in the North Sea. The Treasury has instead eased the tax burden on oil companies, despite their profits being at record levels.

 Until April 1999, building contractor Tarmac, now called Carillion, donated staff to the Treasury. The firm is making millions of pounds in profits from private finance initiative schemes and stands to profit from road-building programmes following a shift in government transport policy.

 Brunswick Public Relations, which works for many large public companies involved in takeover battles, donated a key employee to help work on the controversial Financial Services and Markets Bill. The legislation will regulate activities in the City and any inside information would have been immensely beneficial to Brunswick's clients.

The policy of seconding private-sector employees into the Civil Service was started by the Tories, but since the general election their numbers have grown dramatically. Both multinationals and their advisers have now donated more than 1,000 staff to the Labour Government since May 1997, with many of these firms ending up the right side of policy U-turns and contract awards.

There have been more than 20 private-sector employees working inside the Treasury since the election but, despite repeated requests from The Observer, officials have refused to disclose details of who the employees were and what they have been working on.

Dr Tony Wright, the Labour chairman of the Commons public administration select committee, criticised the Treasury for its secrecy, saying it would fuel fears there was a 'staff-for-favours' system operating. He said: 'I am not against secondments, but we need to know who these people are that are coming in, what projects they are working on and how long they are working on them. If departments do not disclose these details, then there is a danger that people will feel there they are trying to hide something.'

Wright wants to see a public register listing full details of all the employees big business sends into Whitehall.

Lord Neill, the public standards watchdog, has expressed concerns about the potential problems arising from the explosion in the number of private-sector staff working in Whitehall. In January he recommended that all recruits should undergo a training in civil service ethics, and has since expressed support privately for a register.

One secondee from a firm of consultants spoke to The Observer on the promise of anonymity. The secondee said: 'I did work on policy issues and got amazing access... It is now much easier for me to ring up Treasury officials and get information I need.'

In March, The Observer revealed that defence giant British Aerospace, which has won multi-billion-pound military contracts, has eight staff working inside the Ministry of Defence. Other companies which have sent employees to Whitehall include BNFL, Bupa and the tobacco giant BAT. Roadbuilders and construction giants have donated several employees to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

Don Foster, environment spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, said: 'This investigation has demonstrated the excessively cosy relationship between this Government and a range of favoured private-sector companies. While modernising the attitudes of the civil service should be encouraged, I am concerned that there seem to be few safeguards against private companies having an undue influence on government.'

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman said: 'I am confident that interchange with other sectors, backed up by adequate checks and controls, has a key part to play in delivering that more efficient and effective civil service.'

A Treasury spokeswoman said: 'We would be in breach of the Data Protection Act if we were to give out names of staff.'

webTitle: Victims of America's harvest of shame

fields.headline: Victims of America's harvest of shame
fields.standfirst: 800,000 child labourers provide big profits
fields.trailText: Juan will be up before dawn tomorrow to gather grapes in the fields of Kermin, in California's Central Valley. Every morning, he begins his 10-hour day soaked with the dew on the vines.
fields.body:
Juan will be up before dawn tomorrow to gather grapes in the fields of Kermin, in California's Central Valley. Every morning, he begins his 10-hour day soaked with the dew on the vines.

As the rising sun heats the fields, the dew evaporates, to be replaced by clouds of dust. By 7am, his eyes will be weeping and raw from the sulphurous pesticides in the soil. As the sulphur finds its way into his lungs, he will become dizzy and nauseated. Even for an adult, it would be an inhumanly cruel ordeal. But Juan is nine years old. He is one of 800,000 child farm labourers in the United States, more than half of whom are under 15. As California's harvests begin next month, Juan's plight will highlight a nation's shame.

In California, Arizona, Washington state and Texas, children as young as Juan are employed as cheap labour in the billion-dollar agriculture industry. Juan works illegally; he is an 'undocumented' immigrant from Oaxaca in Mexico. But a child of 12 could work legally on a farm. In all industries, bar agriculture, children must be 14 before they can work.

This legal loophole has proven lucrative for the farm giants. A recent study reported that, on average, children start farm work in California at between 13 and 15 years of age. Many work alongside their parents, walking behind them to collect the bunches of grapes cut from the vine, laying them on trays in the sun, then flipping them over to dry them through. Flipping a thousand bunches can earn a worker as little as $30 (£20).

California's child workers cross the border in spring and work their way north from the Coachella Valley in Riverside County to Arvin in Kern County, and then on to Delano and Fresno, arriving in each area at the optimum harvest time. It is an established migrant routine.

Ephraim Camacho, from the support group California Rural Legal Assistance, has worked amongst the community of migrant workers of California for 15 years. He grew up picking cotton in the same fields at the age of eight. In those days the conditions were so bad workers would treat the cuts they got from their knives by urinating on them. He sees the same practice now.

And today there is the added menace of pesticides. 'Twelve women were recently poisoned in a vineyard near Terrabella, California,' he says. 'A helicopter passed overhead spraying them with pesticides and two women were hospitalised. Can you imagine having children out in that?'

Across the nation, the migrant dispossessed face varying hazards. In Washington state, the harvesting of apples, asparagus and cherries runs nearly all year from January to November. Workers arrive by the vanload from Mexico to face organophosphates - a poison rated in the deadly 'category one' by the Environmental Protection Agency - and a variety of injuries.

Fruit trees in the Columbia basin are harvested increasingly by boys aged between 15 and 17, who must stand on ladders to reach the crop.

Since 1995 there have been 15,000 injuries in a working community of 40,000. Workers have attributed skin rashes, dizziness, muscle cramps and miscarriages to the chemicals and physical hardship they endure.

A Human Rights Watch report last week contained testimonies from workers who said they were paid as little as $2-$3 an hour. The minimum wage is $5.15. And it is still legal for a child to be paid $4.25 an hour, provided he does not miss school or work for more than 90 days in a row.

The Farm Bureau, the voice of big agriculture in the United States, says many of the mistreatments workers face are illegal and that they support the enforcement of the law to the full.

Democratic congressman Tom Lantos has lobbied for the minimum working age to be universalised. 'Farms are now agro-businesses, far distant from their 1930s equivalents,' he told The Observer . 'We need greater funding so that the laws will be enforced.'

Lantos also wants new pesticide safety limits for children: the present exposure limits are set for a man of 154lb in weight.

But as Juan returns tonight to the viaduct beneath which he sleeps, the distinction between man and boy has never been so slight.
