webTitle: New Napoleon launches his bid for power in Corsica

fields.headline: New Napoleon launches his bid for power in Corsica
fields.trailText: A once legendary name could be set for a comeback on the French political stage with the announcement by Charles Napoléon, a fifth-generation descendant of Boney's younger brother Jérme, that he intends to stand for the post of mayor in the Corsican capital of Ajaccio.
fields.body:
A once legendary name could be set for a comeback on the French political stage with the announcement by Charles Napoléon, a fifth-generation descendant of Boney's younger brother Jérme, that he intends to stand for the post of mayor in the Corsican capital of Ajaccio.

Napoléon, 49, a political science graduate who runs a Paris property and town planning consultancy, said he had decided to run in the March 2001 local elections because 'people were starting to stop me in the street and asking me why on earth I wasn't'.

He will run on a platform to 'rejuvenate' the port town where his great-great-great-great-great-uncle was born back in 1769. The emperor went on to lay waste to most of Europe's armies before meeting his Waterloo in 1815 and dying on the island of St Helena six years later.

While large parts of the continent can now thank the diminutive military genius for their legal and administrative systems, Charles's ambitions are rather more modest: he wants to build a new library for Ajaccio and create new jobs, crèches and rollerblade tracks.

He is well known in Corsica as president of the Association for the Promotion and Defence of the Corsican Image, dedicated to persuading the rest of France that the picturesque Mediterranean island is more than just a hotbed of separatist bandits and corrupt local politicians.

But Napoléon will still have to wage an effective campaign against at least five serious rivals before being able to mount the town hall steps as mayor. He is relying on the fact that he visits Corsica regularly and has owned a flat there for two years.

He denies he harbours plans to use his hoped-for power base to launch any more nefarious schemes. 'I have no intention of following any further in the family footsteps,' he said.

webTitle: India fights US basmati rice patent

fields.headline: India fights US basmati rice patent
fields.trailText: The battle over who controls the world's food supplies has escalated dramatically with the Indian government launching a legal challenge in the United States against an American company which has been granted a patent on the world-renowned basmati rice.
fields.body:
The battle over who controls the world's food supplies has escalated dramatically with the Indian government launching a legal challenge in the United States against an American company which has been granted a patent on the world-renowned basmati rice.

It is thought to be the first time a government in a developing country has challenged an attempt by a US company to patent - and thus control the production of - staple food and crops in what campaigners dub the 'rush for green gold'.

Basmati rice, sought-after for its fragrant taste, was developed by Indian farmers over hundreds of years, but the Texan company RiceTec obtained a patent for a cross-breed with American long-grain rice.

RiceTec was granted the patent on the basis of aroma, elongation of the grain on cooking and chalkiness. However, the Indian government last week filed 50,000 pages of scientific evidence to the US Patents and Trademarks Office, insisting that most high quality basmati varieties already possess these characteristics. The US Patent and Trademarks office accepted the petition and will re-examine its legitimacy.

The patent - granted only in the US - gives RiceTec control over basmati rice production in North America. Farmers have to pay a fee to grow the rice and are not allowed to plant the seeds to grow the following year's crops.

India fears the patent will severely damage exports from its own farmers to the US. In 1998, they exported almost 600,000 tonnes of basmati rice.

India has also objected to RiceTec calling the rice 'basmati', insisting the name should be used only for rice grown in the Basmati region of India. The Indian government is claiming similar status for basmati rice as that granted to Champagne, Cognac and Scotch whisky.

India's legal challenge is being support by ActionAid, which is launching a campaign to highlight the issue next week.

Ruchi Tripathi said: 'The basmati patent exposes the mounting threat posed by multinationals to crops devel oped and grown by poor farmers for generations.'

There are currently more than 200 patents granted on rice, almost exclusively to US and Japanese companies.

It is currently not possible to patent staple foods and crops in Europe or developing countries but a European directive is about to change that in the EU.

At World Trade Organisation talks which start tomorrow, rich nations are expected to put pressure on developing nations to allow the patenting of crops in their own countries. Tripathi said: 'If rich countries abuse their power to get their way in the World Trade Organisation, developing countries like India will lose the right to challenge patents on crops.'

fields.headline: El Zorro stalks the monster
fields.standfirst: Outfoxed by a people's hero, Mexico's crooked rulers face defeat, reports Ed Vulliamy in Nogales
fields.trailText: Thousands of people walk each day through a turnstile into and out of the Third World, from one side of Nogales to the other. Astride the border between Arizona and Mexico, Nogales - a town of haggling, wheeling and dealing - usually looks to the United States rather than into Mexico, where it belongs. Until El Zorro (The Fox) - aka Vicente Fox Quesada - came to town. He is offering Mexicans the first real election next Sunday since their revolution against Spain.
fields.body:
Thousands of people walk each day through a turnstile into and out of the Third World, from one side of Nogales to the other. Astride the border between Arizona and Mexico, Nogales - a town of haggling, wheeling and dealing - usually looks to the United States rather than into Mexico, where it belongs. Until El Zorro (The Fox) - aka Vicente Fox Quesada - came to town. He is offering Mexicans the first real election next Sunday since their revolution against Spain.

Nogales is now very Mexican indeed, the main street festooned with rival banners, voting registration on every corner, posters and a feeling of change in the air.

For months, Mexico's presidential race - probably the most important ever fought - seemed headed inexorably towards yet another victory, the 14th in a row, for the nominee chosen by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has ruled since its foundation in 1929.

But El Zorro - a former executive with Coca-Cola, 6ft 6in, who wears polished cowboy boots - has blown the contest wide open, challenging the PRI's formidable and corrupt machine and closing the overwhelming lead of Labatista Ochoa, the PRI presidential nominee.

Trailing in third place is Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas, the leftist candidate and a former mayor of Mexico City, who has been urged to quit in order to unite the opposition vote and help Quesada win.

For him to do so would be a twist of ideological irony, but logical in terms of challenging decades of rotten, corrupt government in Mexico.

Quesada, leader of the largest opposition party, National Action, has called the ruling block a 'monster' and bombastically said that what Mexico needs is a 'Lech Walesa or Nelson Mandela', without overtly suggesting himself in the role.

His popular appeal is based on his challenging Mexico's lurching and Byzantine system of corrupt patronage operated by the PRI, and on the enthusiasm of Mexico's budding middle and business classes for a complete clean-out of both politics and the petrified Mexican economy.

At Coke, Quesada was a marketing strategist. That is how he is running his campaign and that is how he wants to run the country. His constituency is largely in the business-minded north and he is admired on both sides of the high border fence that splits the town of Nogales.

His manifesto is one offering to channel loans to small business, to modernise agriculture, to attract foreign investment and to decentralise the moribund bureaucracy.

And the demography of Mexico is changing in Quesada's favour. An emergent middle and technocratic class in prosperous industrial centres across the nation is irrevocably altering the political as well as the economic landscape.

'The most critical vote,' says Roy Campos, who heads a polling organisation, 'is the middle class.'

So far, the election campaign's most marked quality has been its claim to be the fairest as well as the most competitive ever fought, in terms of media debate and the introduction of an independent agency to arbitrate the electoral college system.

But it remains unthinkable that the time-honoured traditions of graft and vote-buying will not mark next Sunday's election. Last week the state governor in Yucatán handed out 1,000 washing machines to poor women as part of his re-election drive.

In 13 states, welfare recipients and corn farmers have been told outright that they will be cut off from all payments and subsidies if they fail to vote for the PRI.

For the United States, the election is also crucial: the affairs of Mexico have become ever more relevant as the border becomes more and more porous - both in terms of immigrants and the endless waves of drugs coming in, and of exports going the other way, along with increasingly strident law enforcement advice for Mexico's supposed war on organised crime.

For the US, Quesada's most attractive quality is not the relative modernity of his economic policies but rather the possibility that a political leader might at last end the pretence of a crackdown against the cocaine cartels that operate under the tutelage of the authorities, and enforce drug laws for real.

The cross-border crisis that entwines the strands of drugs, crime and the political establishment in Mexico reached another climax in April after federal anti-narcotics investigator José Patino Moreno was murdered in the border town of Tijuana.

Moreno had watched raid after raid stymied by corrupt government officials, and was even sacked for his overzealous campaign against the Arellano Félix brothers, one of the most powerful cross-border crime syndicates.

US government and CIA officials attempting to train crime-busting agents see the hand of both the authorities and the syndicate behind Moreno's murder.

At the end of last year, there was another grisly reminder of the severity and scale of the drugs war: a mass grave just across the border from El Paso, Texas, of people who had gone missing in cases where, US officials believe, the authorities as well as the drug syndicates played a role.

The porous border is itself a political crisis for Mexicans and Americans. All along the Arizona fence, armed civilian vigilantes now join the border guards, patrolling the line with two-way radios, and ready to shoot.

'It is not only a question of pushing them back,' says Campos, 'it is a question of giving people a reason for wanting to stay here'.

The idea of a Mexican leader committed to such ideals enthuses people on both sides of the fence that runs through Nogales.

webTitle: Georgians seek buried bones of martyred queen

fields.headline: Georgians seek buried bones of martyred queen
fields.standfirst: She died a horrible death in Persia in 1624, was transported to Portugal, and finally interred in a now ruined church in Goa
fields.trailText: For almost 400 years, the remains of Queen Ketevan, a Georgian martyr and patriot, lay undisturbed somewhere in St Augustine Church. The challenge for archaeologists is to find her.    In an unusual diplomatic move, the Georgians have now said they want their queen back and have asked the Indian government to dig her up. Georgia's Foreign Minister, Irakli Menagarishvili, flew into New Delhi last month to press his case. He asked his opposite number, Jaswant Singh, to try to locate her remains. The Indians agreed to help.
fields.body:
For almost 400 years, the remains of Queen Ketevan, a Georgian martyr and patriot, lay undisturbed somewhere in St Augustine Church. The challenge for archaeologists is to find her. In an unusual diplomatic move, the Georgians have now said they want their queen back and have asked the Indian government to dig her up. Georgia's Foreign Minister, Irakli Menagarishvili, flew into New Delhi last month to press his case. He asked his opposite number, Jaswant Singh, to try to locate her remains. The Indians agreed to help.

Archaeologists must now unravel one of the last great mysteries of the Portuguese colonial era. While there is no doubt that Queen Ketevan is buried in Goa, near the mummified remains of St Francis Xavier - whose toeless corpse is in the Bom Jesus church down the road from St Augustine's - the archives are vague on detail. They say she was interred 'to the right of the altar' in the St Augustine Church.

'The problem is,' said Dr P.P. Shirodkar, who led the last excavation of the church in 1998, 'if you stand facing the altar it becomes the right side. If you stand at the altar, the right side becomes the left side. It is a confusing mystery. There was a practice of burying VIPs in big convents like this, so we are sure she is there somewhere. But so far we have been unable to locate her.'

The church, built in 1602 by Augustinian friars, was originally part of a larger monastic complex. The vault and most of the nave collapsed long ago, leaving only a 46-metre bell tower and façade in the jungle. Excavators in 1988 found 54 grave slabs - but none bore Ketevan's name.

Dr V. Rao of Goa's state-run archaeology unit said attempts to find the queen would begin anew after the monsoon. 'The problem is there were four altars, which makes things difficult,' he said. 'Several Georgians have already come to try and find Ketevan, but have left empty-handed.'

Queen Ketevan was carried off to Shiraz, now in Iran, when the Persians, led by Shah Abbas the Great, pillaged eastern Georgia. According to a contemporary report by Augustinian fathers, the Shah asked her to convert to Islam and become his wife (she was already a widowed grandmother). When she refused, she was stripped to the waist, tortured with hot irons, crushed with a flaming brazier and strangled.

Her body was taken to Lisbon by four Augustinian priests, then to Goa in 1627, as Portugal's Asian empire began to crumble. Although she was Greek Orthodox, Queen Ketevan was subsequently embraced by the Catholic Church as a saint. Her original tomb was said to emit a mysterious light.

Merab Chachua, a Georgian government spokesman, said Georgia, which gained independence in 1992, wanted to give Ketevan a full state funeral. 'Queen Ketevan has been declared a saint by the Georgian Church and she is taught in schools. Many Georgian women are called Ketevan. We would like to have her back,' he said.

webTitle: Don't take a punt on currency refunds

fields.headline: Don't take a punt on currency refunds
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
During a visit to Ireland in February, I bought a watch using my Co-operative Bank Gold Visa card. I found that the watch was faulty and returned it the next day for a refund. When the transactions appeared on my statement, the refund was less than the debit by an amount that was too much to attribute to currency fluctuations.

Initially the bank claimed the discrepancy was due to currency fluctuations, but later admitted that the 2.75 per cent charge had not been refunded. They have now reimbursed the discrepancy but I think this sort of thing should not happen. They are also ignoring my requests for compensation for the time I spent bringing it to their attention.,br> PW, Guildford

 Holidaymakers should be alert to the danger of foreign currency refunds on their credit cards. Banks promise refunds will be the same in sterling as the original cost, but inevitably statements show a different figure, partly because of exchange rate fluctuations but more because banks deduct, and fail to refund automatically, the fee for foreign currency transactions. Some blame Visa or Mastercard; others say they have no way of identifying refunds. Customers do not get their full refunds unless they contact the banks to ask for the money. This is highly unsatisfactory and customer pressure may persuade banks to improve the service.

Co-op says it reimbursed your missing £1.25 immediately you phoned so, even though the bank initially gave you the wrong explanation, I think your case for compensation is weak.

Name on the loan causes concern

I have an unsecured loan with Abbey National and recently wanted to increase it. The adviser agreed that the loan was being repaid by direct debit from my bank account, but said he could not talk to me about the loan because it was not held in my name. Moreover, if I ceased payments, I would be in no way liable for it. Eventually I discovered that the loan was in my ex-husband's name.

He has never banked with Abbey, but does have a mortgage with them. I asked Abbey to dig out the original paperwork but it refused, saying such investigations can be carried out only at the request of the person named on the loan account.

The adviser suggested I sort it out with my ex-husband, but I am not in contact with him. Even so, I cannot bring myself to cease payments and let them chase him for a loan that is not his. What can I do to convince Abbey that I am being honest?
S-LW, Bath

 There is nothing more you could have done. Abbey admits that most customers in these circumstances would simply have stopped making the repayments. The bank would have chased your ex-husband and, when he denied responsibility, presumably finally dug out your application form. But by then you could be marked down as a defaulter.

At Money Writes' request, Abbey did look out the original documentation and discovered that your unsecured loan had been wrongly bundled with your ex-husband's mortgage. This has now been untangled and Abbey confirms that it is happy to lend you the extra money you want. It is also sending you £50 compensation.

Releasing shares without probate

My father, who died recently, owned his bungalow and savings jointly with my mother, the sole beneficiary. No need for probate, we thought. Unfortunately, he had bought electricity shares on privatisation and did not sell them. The registrars for National Grid are happy to release the 56 shares without probate but Computershare, the registrar for Scottish & Southern, in which he had 180 shares, refuses to do so when the total estate exceeds £20,000. My 87-year-old mother now has to go to the expense and effort of obtaining probate, for little net gain, because of this arbitrary limit.

Many people of modest means bought these shares and I am concerned that this could be a problem quite unforseen when privatisation was popular. Am I unreasonable in wishing that Computershare would adjust its procedure?
LC, Lyndhurst

 The Probate Office says there is no set figure for the size of estates on which assets can be released without probate. Institutions can choose their own level, although £5,000 is often accepted and this is the figure that banks and building societies usually take when agreeing to release funds without probate. National Grid releases shares held by estates worth less than £234,000, which is also the starting point for inheritance tax.

Scottish & Southern says it pitches the level at £20,000 because this follows the Association of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators' guidelines. However the company has agreed to treat your father's estate as a special case and is getting in touch to say it will accept a letter of indemnity instead of insisting on probate.

What's the word on Wesleyan?

As the result of a newspaper advert, last year I took out a Guaranteed Growth Bond with the Wesleyan Assurance Society

I was informed by a representative of Wesleyan Assurance Society that the company outperformed most other societies but have never seen it recommended in the newspapers. I have no doubts about my decision, but is it a reliable company?
JM, Brighton

 Getting an independent view of insurance companies is difficult. You can make sure it is properly authorised by phoning the Financial Services Authority (FSA) on 0845 6061234.

The FSA will publish impartial comparative information on pensions, endowments, investments and mortgages in the first half of next year. These will show the main features of each product and how different providers compare for price and flexibility. The FSA says it will not include past performance tables because it does not believe that is a good guide to future performance - but companies and advisers furiously disagree.

An independent financial adviser, if you use one, may give a view, although few keep a close eye on every insurance company.

Read Which? magazine surveys and specialist personal finance magazines, including ones such as Money Management, aimed at financial advisers. Look for past issues and special reports on this subject. Wesleyan is a small and good mutual company.

Interest fixed but not guaranteed

I see that permanent interest-bearing shares quote quite high interest rates. I am a reasonably cautious investor, aged 72, looking for short-term investments lasting one to three years.The rates on these seem attractive, but I have no idea what they are. Could you please enlighten me?
PN, London

 Permanent Interest Bearing Shares, or Pibs, are loans, similar to undated gilts, but issued by building societies instead of governments. They are not shares, nor are they building society savings accounts.

Being permanent means that they carry on indefinitely, and building societies never have to repay the loan unless the society is taken over or wound up. By contrast, dated gilts are repaid on a certain date.

Pibs-holders are repaid only after all other debts have been repaid in full, so there is a chance you may get nothing from a society in deep financial trouble, but it is likely it would have been rescued before then.

If the building society becomes a limited company, its Pibs convert from shares to perpetual subordinated bonds, which can have a higher credit rating and are thus less risky. The changeover makes no difference to investors.

Pibs investors earn interest which is fixed but not guaranteed and there is the small risk that societies may miss an income payment which they do not have to make up later.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies.
fields.bodyText: During a visit to Ireland in February, I bought a watch using my Co-operative Bank Gold Visa card. I found that the watch was faulty and returned it the next day for a refund. When the transactions appeared on my statement, the refund was less than the debit by an amount that was too much to attribute to currency fluctuations. Initially the bank claimed the discrepancy was due to currency fluctuations, but later admitted that the 2.75 per cent charge had not been refunded. They have now reimbursed the discrepancy but I think this sort of thing should not happen. They are also ignoring my requests for compensation for the time I spent bringing it to their attention.,br> PW, Guildford  Holidaymakers should be alert to the danger of foreign currency refunds on their credit cards. Banks promise refunds will be the same in sterling as the original cost, but inevitably statements show a different figure, partly because of exchange rate fluctuations but more because banks deduct, and fail to refund automatically, the fee for foreign currency transactions. Some blame Visa or Mastercard; others say they have no way of identifying refunds. Customers do not get their full refunds unless they contact the banks to ask for the money. This is highly unsatisfactory and customer pressure may persuade banks to improve the service. Co-op says it reimbursed your missing £1.25 immediately you phoned so, even though the bank initially gave you the wrong explanation, I think your case for compensation is weak. Name on the loan causes concern I have an unsecured loan with Abbey National and recently wanted to increase it. The adviser agreed that the loan was being repaid by direct debit from my bank account, but said he could not talk to me about the loan because it was not held in my name. Moreover, if I ceased payments, I would be in no way liable for it. Eventually I discovered that the loan was in my ex-husband's name. He has never banked with Abbey, but does have a mortgage with them. I asked Abbey to dig out the original paperwork but it refused, saying such investigations can be carried out only at the request of the person named on the loan account. The adviser suggested I sort it out with my ex-husband, but I am not in contact with him. Even so, I cannot bring myself to cease payments and let them chase him for a loan that is not his. What can I do to convince Abbey that I am being honest? S-LW, Bath  There is nothing more you could have done. Abbey admits that most customers in these circumstances would simply have stopped making the repayments. The bank would have chased your ex-husband and, when he denied responsibility, presumably finally dug out your application form. But by then you could be marked down as a defaulter. At Money Writes' request, Abbey did look out the original documentation and discovered that your unsecured loan had been wrongly bundled with your ex-husband's mortgage. This has now been untangled and Abbey confirms that it is happy to lend you the extra money you want. It is also sending you £50 compensation. Releasing shares without probate My father, who died recently, owned his bungalow and savings jointly with my mother, the sole beneficiary. No need for probate, we thought. Unfortunately, he had bought electricity shares on privatisation and did not sell them. The registrars for National Grid are happy to release the 56 shares without probate but Computershare, the registrar for Scottish & Southern, in which he had 180 shares, refuses to do so when the total estate exceeds £20,000. My 87-year-old mother now has to go to the expense and effort of obtaining probate, for little net gain, because of this arbitrary limit. Many people of modest means bought these shares and I am concerned that this could be a problem quite unforseen when privatisation was popular. Am I unreasonable in wishing that Computershare would adjust its procedure? Institutions can choose their own level, although £5,000 is often accepted and this is the figure that banks and building societies usually take when agreeing to release funds without probate. National Grid releases shares held by estates worth less than £234,000, which is also the starting point for inheritance tax. Scottish & Southern says it pitches the level at £20,000 because this follows the Association of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators' guidelines. However the company has agreed to treat your father's estate as a special case and is getting in touch to say it will accept a letter of indemnity instead of insisting on probate. What's the word on Wesleyan? As the result of a newspaper advert, last year I took out a Guaranteed Growth Bond with the Wesleyan Assurance Society I was informed by a representative of Wesleyan Assurance Society that the company outperformed most other societies but have never seen it recommended in the newspapers. I have no doubts about my decision, but is it a reliable company? JM, Brighton  Getting an independent view of insurance companies is difficult. You can make sure it is properly authorised by phoning the Financial Services Authority (FSA) on 0845 6061234. The FSA will publish impartial comparative information on pensions, endowments, investments and mortgages in the first half of next year. Wesleyan is a small and good mutual company. Interest fixed but not guaranteed I see that permanent interest-bearing shares quote quite high interest rates. fields.headline: Babies need healthy mothers
fields.trailText: The UK's poor health is emphasised by the finding that babies are up to three times more likely to die in poor areas (News, last week). The parallel finding is that the NHS, based on its founding principles of public funding and free care, is one of the world's best health systems.
fields.body:
The UK's poor health is emphasised by the finding that babies are up to three times more likely to die in poor areas (News, last week). The parallel finding is that the NHS, based on its founding principles of public funding and free care, is one of the world's best health systems.

Curiously, Government 'sources' are 'shocked' at the NHS success. Why? Children are four times as likely to live in poverty in the worst health areas, yet 'only' twice as likely to die there, precisely because the free health and social care services intervene.

Better still to prevent child ill health before birth. Resources should support those experiencing most disadvantage, so that children are born healthy and can benefit from living in communities with good employment, education and environment.

John Nicholson
Chief Executive, UK Public Health Association
Manchester

fields.headline: Revenue@sixes and sevens
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean tried to file her tax return on the internet. Big mistake.
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean tried to file her tax return on the internet. Big mistake.
fields.body:
Filing your tax return through the internet produces the minimal benefit of a £10 refund on your tax bill this year. But there are, in theory at least, other more useful spin-offs.

If you give the Inland Revenue your email address, it will keep you updated on any developments and notify you of approaching deadlines. You can find out your tax liability quite quickly rather than waiting weeks to get a reply. And your tax return should also be easier to complete. You are less likely to lose a computer version than a paper one thrown into the back of a drawer. You can also key in the required information as and when you get those P60s, bank statements and other useful documents.

That's the good news. The reality is that this electronic system is still a gleam in the eye of Somerset House. An understaffed and under-pressure software team produced a filing system that still, this year, does not quite work.

I was one of the first 44,000 taxpayers to register at the Revenue website a couple of weeks ago. But even this was a trial of patience caused by computer glitches. You are told that you need to enter your reference number, your National Insurance number and your postcode. All these details appear on the front page of the paper tax return that was sent out in April. Confusingly, the reference number is marked 'official use' on the tax return - making me for one wonder if I, a mere taxpayer and not an official, should be using it at all. But, yes, you are supposed to use this number.

Even more confusing was the fact that my application was three times rejected by the system even though I entered my details correctly. Making use of a box to send an email query to the Rev enue (limit your queries to a maximum of 250 characters, however), I got two bureaucratic replies, restating the requirements, but not addressing my problem. My third query elicited a very sympathetic reply, asking me to ring the helpline instead. When I rang , I discovered that the fault was theirs - and that I would never have discovered this myself.

It does not bode well that such basic mistakes have occurred and that the Revenue has done so little to signpost the way round them on its registration website.

Faults in the software mean many taxpayers will be precluded from registering if they do everything that is asked of them. A very helpful official on the helpline explained that I would be more likely to get through the registration process if I did not supply my email address or my postcode. In fact, the bare minimum required is to give your reference number and one of either your postcode or your NI number.

When I went back, tried again and gave the minimal amount of information, my registration was accepted immediately. It was then a case of waiting 'seven to 10 days' before the Revenue sent me my 'user ID number' through a very slow snail mail indeed. But it did not particularly matter.

Like the other 44,000 and anyone else who registers now, I am stuck at this point. You cannot complete your return until you have downloaded the Revenue's free self-assessment software - but (you guessed it) due to 'teething troubles' this is sev eral weeks late in arriving. In theory, it will be ready by the end of June. But, if the Revenue has had such a poor start, there could be more errors in the software when it can be downloaded.

The major accountancy firms are not impressed with the Revenue's progress. Mike Warburton of Grant Thornton explains: 'We took part in three trials of electronic filing and then gave up. They could only handle very simple returns. Every circumstance that we came up with, they found a reason as to why it would not work for filing by email. So our firm does not support electronic filing at the moment - although we are keeping our options open. The longer the delay, the more of a shambles it is going to be.'

For me, it's already starting to be a nuisance. With some tax due to pay on 31 July, I would really like to know where I stand now.

Do I abandon my desire to be at the forefront of electronic filing and return to pen and paper? Or do I stay on the trail of the £10 discount, take the Revenue at its word and hope that a marvellous software system is in place by the end of the month? What the hell, I'll hang on. Life is nothing without a bit of adventure.

www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk The helpline can be reached on 0870 241 2092.

webTitle: Is your garden a plot of gold?

fields.headline: Is your garden a plot of gold?
fields.standfirst: As housing land grows ever more scarce, your back lawn could spell profit, says  Anne Caborn
fields.trailText: As housing land grows ever more scarce, your back lawn could spell profit, says Anne Caborn.
fields.body:
Few of us believe in fairies these days, but that fabled pot of gold at the bottom of the garden might still be within your grasp with the help of an enchanted property deal.

Selling off part of a large garden to a property developer - or even teaming up with a builder to co-develop the land - is a growing trend as developable land is used up. 'It's a common device,' said Mike Westcott Rudd at the Land Registry, 'particularly in largish towns which are no longer capable of greenfield development.'

Another option is to build a second home on part of the garden and move into it, selling the original property. 'You can see cases in the Land Registry where this has clearly happened,' said Rudd. This idea can be popular with older homeowners who want to stay in the same area but prefer a modern bungalow to their Victorian pile (with the added bonus that they retain a manageable chunk of their mature garden).

There can be tax implications if you sell land, however. Paul Falvey, tax partner in the Bristol office of Grant Thornton, explains: 'Normally, with your principle private residence, up to half a hectare, including the land on which the house is situated, is exempt from Capital Gains Tax.'

Problems may arise if the land is separated from the main property, or was bought later. On the other hand, integral gardens which are somewhat bigger may be deemed exempt if they are 'for the reasonable enjoyment of the premises'. But this is a subjective judgment, and may vary between tax offices.

If the land sold is subject to CGT, you can still use your annual allowance and can offset your costs - including legal and estate agency fees involved in the sale - as well as what you originally paid for the land.

Tax questions aside, the pile of gold could turn into a brass farthing for those who embark on such a project without care and good advice. The critical factor is whether planning permission will be available, and what objections may be raised. A builder or developer acquiring the land would usually make the deal dependent on planning permission being obtained. Selling the land with outline planning permission already obtained may well increase its value, but there are costs involved.

Boundary disputes can be a costly by-product of a badly executed property split, or they may arise when planning permission is sought.

A great deal of Rudd's time is taken up dealing with these. He advises anyone considering splitting an existing plot to obtain latest Ordnance Survey information. You also need good legal advice. You may want to impose covenants on the land being sold, to restrict what can be built, and to check for covenants on the existing property which would prevent the deal.

Sellers should be exact about anything that could impinge on their home life. This may include the type and height of fences as well as their maintenance, and even which way the property built on the land will face. You may want to prevent anything being built - or an extension being added at a later date - which comes within a certain distance of the boundary. 'You could unwittingly reduce the value of your own property,' said Rudd.

Another example of this might be where mature trees at the bottom of the garden are cleared in order to build the new home, losing you both privacy and a beautiful view. 'An occupant has a right to light but not to a nice view,' said Philip Freedman, who sits on the conveyancing and land law committee of the Law Society.

If you decide to go ahead, One way of selling the land is to put an ad in the local paper. 'Builders watch property sections like hawks,' said chartered surveyor Roy Ilott. You can also approach an estate agent. Ask the agent what they will charge for this, as they will often obtain a fee from the successful developer, so normal house sale commission rates should not apply. You need to compare offers from several. 'Don't accept the first offer,' counsels Ilott.

In some cases the initial approach may come from the developer. 'We have just been involved in purchasing three slices of back garden from three separate owners and assembling them into one plot,' said home builder Peter Dusek, who specialises in architect-designed one-off projects. He paid £25,000 to each home owner and will build a new house on the assembled plot in Ruislip.

Dusek is also keen on the concept of working in partnership with the existing owner in a co-development. 'The advantage for the developer is that there is less cashflow pressure, while the vendor may earn more than if they simply sold the land.'

There may be an agreed set price, or the price could depend on how much of the land the builder can get planning permission for. You may also want to talk to the developer about screening the site while work is in progress, controlling noise, nuisance, even what time they start work. It would be a pity to swap the fairies at the bottom of your garden for a dawn chorus of JCBs.

fields.headline: Sixties joke finds its punchline
fields.standfirst: Graham Norwood reports on a great suburban turnaround as Croydon comes in from the cold
fields.trailText: Graham Norwood reports on a great suburban turnaround as Croydon comes in from the cold.
fields.body:
It may be hard to believe but oft-abused Croydon, best known by outsiders as a blight or a standing Sixties joke, is hitting all the new indicators of prosperity in Tony Blair's Britain. Houses in the most luxurious areas are sold for more than £1m. A tram service with three main lines and a cheap flat-rate fare highlights the outstanding difference in public transport between Croydon and the rest of London, especially the City. The Whitgift Foundation, linked to a family with historic ties to Croydon, funds three private schools, while state schools in the borough perform above the London average.

'There's a real feeling of regeneration in the air,' says estate agent Mark Youll, who has lived and worked in the area for nearly 20 years. 'When I was a young man here there was nothing to do and the office blocks had got the place in their grasp. Now there are bars, restaurants and clubs - it's really alive in the evenings. There are new plans for most areas and as a result there are people wanting to move here from other parts of London,' says Youll.

In reality Croydon has always had popular and distinctive residential homes - they've just been hidden by people's perceptions. The Park Hill estate was developed in the 1930s and includes Swiss-designed town houses built with conventional ground floor rooms on upper storeys. In Shirley Hills, large detached houses are going for up to £1.5m near golf courses.

More modest, but more interesting, are houses that Youll calls 'Victorian gems' in terraced streets in east and west Croydon. Newer developments are being proposed in and around the cen tre and the council is receiving more planning applications than at any time since the boom period of 1988.

A retail application being considered next month is for one of Britain's largest shopping centres at Park Place in Croydon - and not on the outskirts of the area but right in the middle. 'This is aiming at bringing back the abc 1's who haven't looked to Croydon as a serious shopping centre for many years,' according to the council's planning and development director Phillip Goodwin.

New apartments from developers Galliard Homes are already going up nearby, targeting wealthy 20-something residents who want to sample Croydon's version of urban chic and are willing to pay £140,000 to £200,000 for one- and two-bedroom apartments.

'In employment terms we now have serious players talking about relocating from central London,' claims Goodwin. 'There's finally a recognition that Croydon has been undervalued in the past.'

Culturally, too, there's beginning to be a buzz about the place. The council wants to develop a concert and events arena on the large East Croydon gateway site, an ugly empty space which greets you near the mainline station. The proposal is based on a state-of-the-art complex in Helsinki and will hold 12,500 people - much the same size as Wembley Arena and larger than the one built 10 years ago at Docklands. There would be a residential development with 500 luxury properties and a 400-bed hotel, too. The arena would restore Croydon's place on the rock and concert circuit, established when the Fairfield Halls opened in the 1960s.

Since the late 1990s, the middle classes have suddenly found much more to do in Croydon. The Clocktower centre has provided an education and exhibition base and the David Lean cinema has hosted arthouse films. Now the tram service takes locals directly to stops near the Wimbledon tennis championships.

David Beach has moved to Croydon twice after living elsewhere. 'Croydon's attraction has always been the superb communications and facilities although it also has a non-fussy, welcoming, independent air to it. Some London boroughs tend to be mono-cultures but Croydon has variety,' he says.

His partner, Michele Plunkett, moved to Croydon from New York and has been converted: 'Croydon is enjoyable and thrives because of its wide ethnic and economic mix. Parts of Croydon remind me a lot of some New York neighbourhoods.'

Beach is unrepentant about Croydon's image. 'Many mock Croydon's "Sixties slab" architecture - I happen to like it. Some superb buildings went up in Croydon in the Nineties, rivalling anything in the City. Yet they're just two miles from working farms. It's still an undervalued market. Name another London borough with such a variety of quality, affordable housing,' he says.

But what price that housing if Croydon can shake off its image?

Ten reasons to love Croydon

1The Land Registry says house prices rose by about 16 per cent in Croydon in 1990-2000

2 The average price of a detached house is £115,674 - a bargain compared with most of London but already rising above Bexley, Greenwich, Havering and Lewisham

3 Croydon is a London borough in administrative terms but won a battle withthe Post Office to have its address in 'Surrey'

4 The Croydon tram service links the area with Wimbledon, Mitcham and Beckenham, and is the first new London tram service for 50 years

5 There are 11 conservation areas in Croydon - more than in many London districts

6Around 25 per cent of the borough is designated as Green Belt land - much less space is zoned for office use

7Local boy David Bowie said he 'hated Croydon with a real vengeance. It represented everything I didn't want in my life'. He hasn't been back for many years

8About 300 trains link Croydon's overground stations with central London every day

9Takings in the town's Whitgift shopping centre have risen over 20 per cent since the tram service opened in March

10 The author Kingsley Amis had his family house in Croydon, because it was his favourite part of London
fields.bodyText: It may be hard to believe but oft-abused Croydon, best known by outsiders as a blight or a standing Sixties joke, is hitting all the new indicators of prosperity in Tony Blair's Britain. Houses in the most luxurious areas are sold for more than £1m. A tram service with three main lines and a cheap flat-rate fare highlights the outstanding difference in public transport between Croydon and the rest of London, especially the City. The Whitgift Foundation, linked to a family with historic ties to Croydon, funds three private schools, while state schools in the borough perform above the London average. 'There's a real feeling of regeneration in the air,' says estate agent Mark Youll, who has lived and worked in the area for nearly 20 years. 'When I was a young man here there was nothing to do and the office blocks had got the place in their grasp. Now there are bars, restaurants and clubs - it's really alive in the evenings. There are new plans for most areas and as a result there are people wanting to move here from other parts of London,' says Youll. In reality Croydon has always had popular and distinctive residential homes - they've just been hidden by people's perceptions. The Park Hill estate was developed in the 1930s and includes Swiss-designed town houses built with conventional ground floor rooms on upper storeys. In Shirley Hills, large detached houses are going for up to £1.5m near golf courses. More modest, but more interesting, are houses that Youll calls 'Victorian gems' in terraced streets in east and west Croydon. Newer developments are being proposed in and around the cen tre and the council is receiving more planning applications than at any time since the boom period of 1988. A retail application being considered next month is for one of Britain's largest shopping centres at Park Place in Croydon - and not on the outskirts of the area but right in the middle. 'This is aiming at bringing back the abc 1's who haven't looked to Croydon as a serious shopping centre for many years,' according to the council's planning and development director Phillip Goodwin. New apartments from developers Galliard Homes are already going up nearby, targeting wealthy 20-something residents who want to sample Croydon's version of urban chic and are willing to pay £140,000 to £200,000 for one- and two-bedroom apartments. 'In employment terms we now have serious players talking about relocating from central London,' claims Goodwin. 'There's finally a recognition that Croydon has been undervalued in the past.' Culturally, too, there's beginning to be a buzz about the place. The council wants to develop a concert and events arena on the large East Croydon gateway site, an ugly empty space which greets you near the mainline station. The proposal is based on a state-of-the-art complex in Helsinki and will hold 12,500 people - much the same size as Wembley Arena and larger than the one built 10 years ago at Docklands. There would be a residential development with 500 luxury properties and a 400-bed hotel, too. The arena would restore Croydon's place on the rock and concert circuit, established when the Fairfield Halls opened in the 1960s. Since the late 1990s, the middle classes have suddenly found much more to do in Croydon. The Clocktower centre has provided an education and exhibition base and the David Lean cinema has hosted arthouse films. Now the tram service takes locals directly to stops near the Wimbledon tennis championships. David Beach has moved to Croydon twice after living elsewhere. 'Croydon's attraction has always been the superb communications and facilities although it also has a non-fussy, welcoming, independent air to it. Some London boroughs tend to be mono-cultures but Croydon has variety,' he says. His partner, Michele Plunkett, moved to Croydon from New York and has been converted: 'Croydon is enjoyable and thrives because of its wide ethnic and economic mix. Parts of Croydon remind me a lot of some New York neighbourhoods.' Beach is unrepentant about Croydon's image. 'Many mock Croydon's "Sixties slab" architecture - I happen to like it. Some superb buildings went up in Croydon in the Nineties, rivalling anything in the City. Yet they're just two miles from working farms. It's still an undervalued market. Name another London borough with such a variety of quality, affordable housing,' he says. But what price that housing if Croydon can shake off its image? fields.headline: Beware bugs and baby-boomers
fields.trailText: Remember the bad old days of the early 1990s, when 75,000 homes were repossessed in one year and another 500,000 homeowners were in arrears? It was hardly surprising, given that about a million people were being made redundant each year.
fields.body:
Remember the bad old days of the early 1990s, when 75,000 homes were repossessed in one year and another 500,000 homeowners were in arrears? It was hardly surprising, given that about a million people were being made redundant each year.

It may well be true that since those days our economic managers have become adept at running the show more smoothly, but the truth is that disasters are still likely to happen from time to time. Even the cleverest bankers and politicians can get their calculations wrong.

A possible problem area in future is the stakeholder pension due to start next year, says Chris Lynas of accountant Smith & Williamson. Although people will not be forced to save for a pension, Lynas is worried about the recessionary impact of 'compulsion' if it is introduced in a few years: 'It can cause a recession if people stop spending. If the stakeholder pension became compulsory, it could take out something like 10 per cent of people's income. Potentially it would lead to a slowdown in consumer spending.'

A dramatic shift in patterns of supply and demand can also create financial panic and recession. This can happen in situations which look absurd after the event - the tulip craze, for instance, or even the rush to get into some of the flakier dotcom businesses. But it can also happen for the best of reasons. In trying to prevent a repeat of the Maxwell pension scandal, the last Government tightened up the rules governing the solvency requirements of pension funds. These are now being reviewed: this Government regards them as being too stringent. They inhibited many pension schemes from investing as much as they needed to in equities. On its own, this kind of rule would probably not lead to recession - but it could be an important factor. And some commentators are concerned that there could be serious recessionary influences at work from about 2010, when the baby boomers start drawing their pensions and taking huge amounts of equity investment out of the market.

Simple technological failure or malfunctioning is also a major concern. If a computer virus can cause the loss of billions of pounds in a single day, a protracted problem could help engineer a crash. Many people feared, for instance, that the millennium bug might cripple the world's businesses so severely that the world would be plunged into a crash. In the event, the dangers of that bug were exaggerated - but the episode highlighted the vulnerability of economic progress to the technology we have created.

Many recessions take people by surprise. The Wall Street Crash came at the end of a decade of prosperity. That fact in itself makes some commentators nervous now. Are we becoming too complacent with our belief that we are approaching the economic holy grail?

webTitle: Sort our funding, says charity worker

fields.headline: Sort our funding, says charity worker
fields.standfirst: She's in the voluntary sector. He's doing a PhD. Jackie and James need to make every penny work, they tell  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: She's in the voluntary sector. He's doing a PhD. Jackie and James need to make every penny work, they tell Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Vital statistics

Jackie Atkins and James Ramsden

Age: Jackie 30; James 28

Live in: Radford Semele, Warwickshire

Occupation: Charity co-ordinator; hospital doctor

Earns: Jackie £12,000 part-time; James £25,000

Mortgage: £105,000

Debts: James' student loan

Investments: Cash Isa and savings account

Pensions: Jackie has none; James has an NHS pension

Aims: To buy life insurance, a pension for Jackie and to save for their baby's university expenses

Jackie Atkins and James Ramsden own a house but find themselves unable to live in it.

Their house is in Oxford, but they are letting it while they rent in the village of Radford Semele, Warwickshire, chosen because of its location - between Banbury (Jackie's job) and Birmingham (James's studies).

Jackie works for a small charity helping the young homeless. She is nearly two years into a three-year contract, funded by the National Lottery, but is on six months' maternity leave.

Her son, Samuel, was born in March. When she returns to work, she will job-share for two-and-a-half days and her salary will halve. 'On top of that,' she says, 'we will have to pay childcare.'

James is an ear, nose and throat surgeon, but is currently a full-time student. He will complete his PhD on thyroid disease in March 2002. James will then look for a registrar's job. The family will move with him. They will certainly not return to the house in Oxford, whose spiral staircase makes it unsuitable for children.

Jackie would like to continue in the voluntary sector. She should be able to find work wherever they choose to live but her job will always be at risk if funding is withdrawn. She also plans to have more children, so is likely to take more time off.

Their rent is £750 a month. The mortgage on their Oxford home of £744 a month is mostly met by the £600 rent they receive. Their only debt is James's student loan, which costs them £46 a month. He has been repaying it since 1995. They still owe £1,800. Jackie and James have a small amount of money put by (£6,000 in Smile cash Isas and £1,000 in a Smile savings account) and, while Jackie was on full pay, they were able to save £200 a month. But, worryingly, they have no life insurance and Jackie has no pension. She wants to know whether she should wait for the government stakeholder pensions, which will be introduced next April, or whether she should start paying into a pension scheme now. 'I could probably afford £75 a month,' she says.

They want to save their monthly £60 child benefit to pay for Samuel's university expenses. 'We feel that in 18 years' time we will probably have to pay full tuition fees.' She wants to keep the savings in her and James's names and asks: 'What sort of investment is best for this money?'

Adviser 1: Julie Lord
Jackie and James need to insure for enough to clear all their liabilities and provide income for at least five years in case of death or serious illness. Monthly premiums for combined life insurance and critical illness cover are reasonable. There are companies that charge the same for a joint life policy as for two separate ones, say for £100,000 each; separate policies pay for both if both died but a joint policy pays only on the first death.

James should get permanent health insurance. As his NHS salary continues for one year if he is off sick, he can defer receiving payments for 12 months. This reduces the likelihood of claiming, thus reducing the premium.

For Jackie, plenty of good pension providers already offer flexible stakeholder-friendly schemes.

For their son, I suggest they save the £50 a month into unit trust or investment trust savings plan, adding or withdrawing as required. The investment should be in the parents' names but designated for their son - to use his tax allowance.

They could get a second mortgage for their new home and rearrange the loan on their Oxford house as a 'buy to let'. As it pays for itself, a new lender will not worry about their ability to afford a new loan.

Julie Lord works for Cavendish Financial Management in Cardiff.

Adviser 2: Ian Williams
One point needs addressing first: they should ensure that they have life insurance and investments to repay the mortgage if one of them died. They could choose straightforward term assurance and an Isa, or a monthly-paid endowment.

Jackie should buy life insurance. James is a member of the NHS death-in-service scheme, but if Jackie dies, James would probably need outside assistance for child care. I recommend around £50,000 of life insurance, or family income benefit to pay an income of about £8,000, which is cheaper.

I advise waiting until Jackie is back at work before planning pensions or investing for their son, to see how their cashflow pans out. Adjusting to life on a reduced income can take time and it is inappropriate to start plans that may have to be suspended.

I suggest Jackie considers a personal pension that is 'stakeholder-friendly'. Many companies already offer products with low charges that fit stakeholder requirements.

Investing regularly into an Isa in either parent's name could start off a fund for their son's university fees and, if they needed money before university, say for exchange visits, it is immediately available.

Ian Williams works for Bath-based adviser, Chartwell Investments.

· Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: 'We've done quite well - but anything could happen'

fields.headline: 'We've done quite well - but anything could happen'
fields.trailText: 'I know the economy seems to be pottering along pretty nicely - but I feel that a recession could happen,' says Clifford Harrison, a retired modern languages teacher from Birmingham. 'Anything based on equities would suffer as a result.'
fields.body:
'I know the economy seems to be pottering along pretty nicely - but I feel that a recession could happen,' says Clifford Harrison, a retired modern languages teacher from Birmingham. 'Anything based on equities would suffer as a result.'

Clifford - 'approaching the big seven-o' - and his wife Barbara, a retired music teacher, play their financial cards with caution. The only time they have paid to borrow money was when they took out a mortgage. They do have credit cards now, but these are paid off 'on the dot'.

The downside of something going wrong on any risky investments far outweighs the satisfaction they would get from any gains. Both have 'fairly decent pensions', so any extra income they earn on their small portfolio of investments is regarded as a welcome bonus. 'Our chief aim is to get a bit of extra income from our investments - but making sure that the capital is not at risk in any way,' says Clifford.

On the advice of his financial adviser at Chase de Vere, and on the basis of his own reading about financial products, Clifford has kept away from products which are aimed at the cautious but which are poor value. He eschews the 'very low' returns offered on National Savings products, for example. The Harrisons used to put money into Guaranteed Income Bonds, but these are now offering such low rates that they have taken all their money away from them.

They do, in fact, face up to some risk in their investments. They hold corporate bonds through their individual savings account allowances and have seen the capital value slip - the Achilles heel of corporate bonds in times of rising interest rates.

Clifford has also taken out a low-risk investment product from a building society through which he gets a fixed return if the FTSE performs above certain fairly modest benchmarks over the next three years. So long as the FTSE goes up at least 1 per cent in this time, there is no threat to his capital.

The couple have even played the stock market from time to time - but only with small sums. Clifford says: 'You could be envious of people who make a killing on a stock - but we've done pretty well ourselves. We had some BT shares which we sold just after Christmas. Since then they have plummeted. I feel quite proud of that.'

webTitle: Never again? You never can tell

fields.headline: Never again? You never can tell
fields.standfirst: Some believe the days of boom and bust are over. Others fear global factors could hit us all. Either way it's vital to be prepared, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Some believe the days of boom and bust are over. Others fear global factors could hit us all. Either way it's vital to be prepared, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
No one knows when the next recession will be, but some of the most respected thinkers believe it could happen in the next year. Earlier this month the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) warned of the possibility of a hard landing. If the BIS is right we could see the usual hallmarks of recession - job losses, falling house prices, the re-emergence of negative equity, declining share prices and a rise in repossessions and bankruptcies.

In one way or another that would affect most of us - even if it just meant us worrying more about job security, going out less often, spending less money and saving a bit more.

There is no need to panic just yet. The BIS - the committee of central banks - says there is a 'risk' of economic problems ahead, not a likelihood, and certainly not a certainty.

Making the connection between high-level economic debates and the realities of our daily lives is difficult for most people. In the West Midlands though, post Rover, people certainly understand the link between the high value of sterling and job losses for people who work in exporting companies.

But economics is a notoriously difficult area when it comes to predictions. Recessions have a habit of coming when least expected and, even years later, economists will disagree in their analyses of what caused them.

So even if most of the predictions are positive, it is worth assuming that there are difficult times around the corner - and building some caution into your financial plans.

What worries the BIS and other eminent bodies most at the moment is the danger of a recession that starts in the US and spreads to the rest of the world. The finances of different countries are now so interlocked that a crisis in one of the major blocs - particularly the US, Asia and Europe - will quickly spread to the others.

On its own, the UK economy is regarded by most as looking fairly healthy. 'We're looking at more of a softer landing,' says Martin Ellis, chief economist at the Halifax. That means that while some belt-tightening is taking place to stave off inflation - one of the main causes of recession - the measures are likely to be fairly gradual and relatively painless. So, for instance, while the Bank of England has raised base rates by 1 per cent over the past year - equal to an extra £42 a month on a £50,000 mortgage - it did not feel the need to put them up again this month.

There are some who feel we have already suffered most of the pain needed to restrict demand and choke off excessive inflation. The latest house price surveys, from Halifax and Nationwide, both showed a slight decline in values in May. Other economic indicators have suggested a cooling in consumer demand. Standard Life's decision this month to launch a 25-year mortgage, capped at 6.25 per cent, is seen as a pointer towards low long-term inflation and interest rates. Steve Cleal, economist at the newly merged CGNU (the old Commercial and Norwich Unions) speaks for many who are in fairly optimistic mode when he says: 'We expect base rates to peak at about 6.5 per cent in three to six months' time, and then to drift lower next year.'

This optimistic view about the UK was further boosted this month when the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) described our economic state as 'rather enviable'.

So, for the moment, the eyes of most economists are on the US. At the end of this month the Federal Reserve will decide whether to raise interest rates in an attempt to depress consumer demand. But economists fear a recession being triggered if demand weakens too suddenly, or if the dollar plunges in response. Observers are worried that the Federal Reserve will miscalculate its intervention, raise interest rates too high, perhaps, and let the US economy stall.

Signs of jitters in the US stock markets are already clear - notably the 35 per cent fall in the technology-dominated Nasdaq index in March, a mini-crash.

The UK would not be insulated from problems that started in the US. 'If there were a sharp fall in US share prices, that would probably drag down UK share prices,' says Ellis of the Halifax. 'And then you would see other effects here. Confidence would weaken. Unemployment would be likely to rise. Salary increases would be lower.'

It used to be said that economic cycles went in seven-year periods - sweeping gradually or crashing from recession to boom in that timescale. Keeping an economy in permanently positive equilibrium is a very difficult task, given the blunt levers that are available to the bankers and chancellors who set interest rates and fiscal and economic policy. But current successes are making economists feel we are getting closer to this desirable position than we have ever managed before.

A more difficult issue is understanding how fundamental industrial changes will also change our economic climate. How does the technological revolution affect the stability of our lives?

If economists at PricewaterhouseCoopers are right, about 75 per cent of dotcoms are on course to run out of cash in the next two years. If their share prices have been talked up before the companies fail, there could be a lot of volatility in the stock markets.

Looking at stock markets overall, Justin Urquhart-Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers is one of those who expects US-led volatility to give us all 'a bumpy time' in the next few months.

But even he is fairly optimistic. He believes that by the autumn, we could be seeing signs that the US economy is slowing without getting into recession.

'We could then see a lot more money coming back into the market,' he says. 'A lot of institutional money has been kept out of the market since February. So there is an awful lot of pensions and insurance money just waiting to be invested.'

The simple laws of supply and demand suggest that this influx of investment would in itself put an upward pressure on share prices.

What the experts think

Martin Ellis, chief economist at the Halifax: 'There's always the possibility of a hard landing - but we don't think it's particularly likely.'

Justin Urquhart-Stewart, Barclays Stockbrokers: 'We may well have a bumpy time until we do land.'

Charles Levett-Scrivener, Towry Law financial advisers: 'If the US has a hard landing, the UK will have a hard landing. But it won't happen here independently.'

Justin Modray, Chase de Vere financial advisers: 'A hard landing looks a bit unlikely - but we will see some shorter- term volatility.'

Steve Cleal, CGNU: 'The signs are now that the economy is starting to slow down. We don't need a recession to get us out of the problem.'
fields.bodyText: No one knows when the next recession will be, but some of the most respected thinkers believe it could happen in the next year. Earlier this month the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) warned of the possibility of a hard landing. If the BIS is right we could see the usual hallmarks of recession - job losses, falling house prices, the re-emergence of negative equity, declining share prices and a rise in repossessions and bankruptcies. In one way or another that would affect most of us - even if it just meant us worrying more about job security, going out less often, spending less money and saving a bit more. There is no need to panic just yet. The BIS - the committee of central banks - says there is a 'risk' of economic problems ahead, not a likelihood, and certainly not a certainty. Making the connection between high-level economic debates and the realities of our daily lives is difficult for most people. In the West Midlands though, post Rover, people certainly understand the link between the high value of sterling and job losses for people who work in exporting companies. But economics is a notoriously difficult area when it comes to predictions. Recessions have a habit of coming when least expected and, even years later, economists will disagree in their analyses of what caused them. So even if most of the predictions are positive, it is worth assuming that there are difficult times around the corner - and building some caution into your financial plans. What worries the BIS and other eminent bodies most at the moment is the danger of a recession that starts in the US and spreads to the rest of the world. The finances of different countries are now so interlocked that a crisis in one of the major blocs - particularly the US, Asia and Europe - will quickly spread to the others. On its own, the UK economy is regarded by most as looking fairly healthy. 'We're looking at more of a softer landing,' says Martin Ellis, chief economist at the Halifax. That means that while some belt-tightening is taking place to stave off inflation - one of the main causes of recession - the measures are likely to be fairly gradual and relatively painless. So, for instance, while the Bank of England has raised base rates by 1 per cent over the past year - equal to an extra £42 a month on a £50,000 mortgage - it did not feel the need to put them up again this month. There are some who feel we have already suffered most of the pain needed to restrict demand and choke off excessive inflation. The latest house price surveys, from Halifax and Nationwide, both showed a slight decline in values in May. Other economic indicators have suggested a cooling in consumer demand. Standard Life's decision this month to launch a 25-year mortgage, capped at 6.25 per cent, is seen as a pointer towards low long-term inflation and interest rates. Steve Cleal, economist at the newly merged CGNU (the old Commercial and Norwich Unions) speaks for many who are in fairly optimistic mode when he says: 'We expect base rates to peak at about 6.5 per cent in three to six months' time, and then to drift lower next year.' This optimistic view about the UK was further boosted this month when the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) described our economic state as 'rather enviable'. So, for the moment, the eyes of most economists are on the US. At the end of this month the Federal Reserve will decide whether to raise interest rates in an attempt to depress consumer demand. But economists fear a recession being triggered if demand weakens too suddenly, or if the dollar plunges in response. Observers are worried that the Federal Reserve will miscalculate its intervention, raise interest rates too high, perhaps, and let the US economy stall. Signs of jitters in the US stock markets are already clear - notably the 35 per cent fall in the technology-dominated Nasdaq index in March, a mini-crash. The UK would not be insulated from problems that started in the US. 'If there were a sharp fall in US share prices, that would probably drag down UK share prices,' says Ellis of the Halifax. 'And then you would see other effects here. Confidence would weaken. Unemployment would be likely to rise. Salary increases would be lower.' It used to be said that economic cycles went in seven-year periods - sweeping gradually or crashing from recession to boom in that timescale. Keeping an economy in permanently positive equilibrium is a very difficult task, given the blunt levers that are available to the bankers and chancellors who set interest rates and fiscal and economic policy. But current successes are making economists feel we are getting closer to this desirable position than we have ever managed before. A more difficult issue is understanding how fundamental industrial changes will also change our economic climate. How does the technological revolution affect the stability of our lives? If economists at PricewaterhouseCoopers are right, about 75 per cent of dotcoms are on course to run out of cash in the next two years. If their share prices have been talked up before the companies fail, there could be a lot of volatility in the stock markets. Looking at stock markets overall, Justin Urquhart-Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers is one of those who expects US-led volatility to give us all 'a bumpy time' in the next few months. But even he is fairly optimistic. He believes that by the autumn, we could be seeing signs that the US economy is slowing without getting into recession. 'We could then see a lot more money coming back into the market,' he says. 'A lot of institutional money has been kept out of the market since February. So there is an awful lot of pensions and insurance money just waiting to be invested.' The simple laws of supply and demand suggest that this influx of investment would in itself put an upward pressure on share prices. What the experts think Martin Ellis, chief economist at the Halifax: 'There's always the possibility of a hard landing - but we don't think it's particularly likely.' Justin Urquhart-Stewart, Barclays Stockbrokers: 'We may well have a bumpy time until we do land.' Charles Levett-Scrivener, Towry Law financial advisers: 'If the US has a hard landing, the UK will have a hard landing. But it won't happen here independently.' Justin Modray, Chase de Vere financial advisers: 'A hard landing looks a bit unlikely - but we will see some shorter- term volatility.' Steve Cleal, CGNU: 'The signs are now that the economy is starting to slow down. We don't need a recession to get us out of the problem.'

fields.headline: Seven steps to stay ahead
fields.trailText: 1 Build up your savings. Most financial advisers recommend you have enough in an instant access deposit account to keep you going for three months, but you can finesse this situation a bit. If you know you can borrow £2,000 from your father or pay bills on credit cards for two weeks, you can be a bit cleverer - putting your money in a tax-free individual savings account, for example. It will take you longer to get the cash out - but that matters less if you can get funds from elsewhere in the short term. Bear in mind, however, that you start to lose entitlement to Jobseeker's Allowance and other state benefits if you have savings above £3,000.
fields.body:
1 Build up your savings. Most financial advisers recommend you have enough in an instant access deposit account to keep you going for three months, but you can finesse this situation a bit. If you know you can borrow £2,000 from your father or pay bills on credit cards for two weeks, you can be a bit cleverer - putting your money in a tax-free individual savings account, for example. It will take you longer to get the cash out - but that matters less if you can get funds from elsewhere in the short term. Bear in mind, however, that you start to lose entitlement to Jobseeker's Allowance and other state benefits if you have savings above £3,000.

2 Work out what would happen if you lost your job. You may even be reassured by this process. Large companies often pay generous redundancy money, and many have insurance arrangements to pay your salary for six months if you become ill. Start thinking of your contingency plans. How long would it take for you to run out of money? Is there another job you could take on before then? There may be steps you could take now to improve your prospects in the 'worst case scenario' - take that Internet course or speak to the neighbour who's been asking you to help her with car boot sales. You can earn up to £4,250 a year tax-free by letting a room in your house.

3 Pay off your major debts while you can. Tackle any balances outstanding on credit cards. The rates they charge are often excruciating and would be a major burden to you if you lost your job. Work out how you could continue to pay your mortgage for nine months if you were laid off. On mortgages started after October 1995 you do not get help with mortgage payments for this period, even if you are getting Jobseeker's Allowance. For mortgages taken out before then, you have to meet the payments yourself for the first four months. You may consider, therefore, taking out mortgage payment protection insurance - but this is an expensive kind of cover. If you can, you may be better off building up savings instead.

4 Avoid buying on hire purchase. Think hard how you would meet the repayments if you bought that new car on HP and then lost your job. If you are really set on buying it, find out whether you could sell the car back after a few months.

5 Get into the habit of saving each month. Downturns often occur when no one is expecting them. Having a small supply of rainy day money is surprisingly reassuring. You will feel better about yourself if you know you are more than one step away from disaster.

6 Review your investments if you have them. For someone with spare cash of £15,000, Justin Modray of Chase de Vere suggests putting half in deposit accounts and the rest into fixed-interest bond funds and a broadly based managed fund. He predicts some volatility in the market, largely triggered by technology stocks. He warns: 'Even though the IT-based stocks may be the culprit for volatility, they have a knock-on effect on other companies which haven't done anything wrong.' Nevertheless, he says, some of the more traditional manufacturing and services stocks are looking 'pretty good value for money' at the moment.

7 Get ready to negotiate with your creditors if you do get into trouble. Many people end up in court because they do not open their mail. Surprisingly, Sue Edwards, London debt adviser for the Citizens Advice Bureaux, says that the currently tough attitude of mortgage lenders is likely to soften if there is a recession: 'If house prices were to fall, they'd have to get a lot less tough. It wouldn't be economic for them to take some of these properties into possession.'

Some lenders are going for early possession now because they know they can make a profit on reselling the house in a buoyant market.
