fields.headline: Seagull army invades inland towns
fields.standfirst: Keep watching the skies, the birds are coming
fields.trailText: Their high-pitched cries used to echo around craggy clifftops and they appeared on every seaside postcard. But Britain's hungry sea-gulls are deserting their coastal colonies and descending on cities far inland in a desperate search for food.
fields.body:
Their high-pitched cries used to echo around craggy clifftops and they appeared on every seaside postcard. But Britain's hungry sea-gulls are deserting their coastal colonies and descending on cities far inland in a desperate search for food.

Although the overall population is declining rapidly, it is estimated that the urban population of herring gulls and black-backed gulls is rising by as much as 20 per cent a year. In scenes reminiscent of Alfred Hitchcock's terrifying The Birds, attacks on humans are becoming increasingly common.

Ian Mitchell, co-ordinator of the Seagull 2000 monitoring project, said: 'There are even some in Birmingham - and that is as inland as you can get.' Other cities where seagulls are establishing colonies include Nottingham, Westbury in Wiltshire, Yeo-vil, Gloucester, Kidderminster, Whitby and Bridlington. They are also increasingly found on the southern edge of London, and the whole stretch from Edinburgh to Glasgow.

Kirstin Cubitt from Nottingham City Council - 80 miles from the sea - said: 'There are regularly huge numbers of seagulls on a landfill site to the north of the city - sometimes there are whole flocks of them.'

The seagulls are attracted to cities because of the easy pickings from landfill sites and the food littering the streets from ever-spreading fast-food outlets. Julian Hughes, head of species policy at the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, said: 'They are attracted to landfill sites - we're producing more disposed waste than ever before. We're giving them quantities of food that haven't been available since Elizabethan times, when people threw slops in the street.'

The RSPB's headquarters at Sandy in Bedfordshire - 60 miles from the sea - is close to a big colony of seagulls on Graffham Water. Hughes said: 'We have roosts of 700 to 800 birds on a regular basis. We have birds who stay there all year. The development of big inland reservoirs in the Seventies has created a habitat for them.'

However, many seagulls have entirely given up living on or near water and have set up colonies in town centres, on industrial sites, the roofs of supermarkets, and by power stations. More than 10 per cent of all seagulls in Britain are now thought to live on buildings.

David Harry, bird control manager at the pest prevention company Terminix, said: 'They have learnt there is a free and easy source of food in town centres and municipal dumps. They're all born and bred in town centres. Seagull isn't a very good name for them any more.'

At the same time, seagulls are suffering on the coast, with the overall population declining about 40 per cent in the last 25 years.

Mitchell said: 'Some large coastal colonies have declined substantially. We don't know why they are leaving the clifftop habitats - it could be a shortage of food supply.'

Seagulls have always been in coastal towns, but many authorities learnt to control their numbers by making food waste more difficult to get at - for example, by using wheelie-bins. This may have helped drive the birds inland.

Seagulls - who live for up to 20 years and have wingspans of about 4ft - can be very aggressive. There are increasing reports of them attacking people, particularly builders and roof workers. Harry said: 'They get very aggressive when they breed, from late March to early August. They dive-bomb people and actually strike them. They take ice-creams and fish and chips from people's hands.

'They also vomit on you when they are above you - if you imagine anchovies out in the sun for a month, it's pretty revolting.'

Recently a builder rendering a wall in Cardiff was attacked and ended up with stitches. People have also been attacked in Wiltshire, and one person fell off a roof trying to fight off seagulls.

Local authorities and companies are also keen to deter the birds because of the mess they make. Harry said: 'You get a hundred birds in a colony and they descend on a town. They produce a lot of guano in one day.

'The long-term roosts are like bone-yards - it's thick with ham bones, chicken drumsticks and lamb bones. The mind boggles when you see it.'

fields.headline: UK firms splurge £700m on guests
fields.trailText: Millions of canapés and gallons of champagne will be served up in the next few weeks in what is already set to be a record summer for corporate hospitality.
fields.body:
Millions of canapés and gallons of champagne will be served up in the next few weeks in what is already set to be a record summer for corporate hospitality.

While traditional fixtures such as Ascot and Wimbledon will see the costs soar to a record £700 million, the 'explosion' of entertaining at top cultural events like the opening of Tate Modern is fuelling this year's growth spurt.

Businesses are spending an estimated £210m between them to take clients to the exhibitions and shows attended by the likes of Sting, Madonna and Stella McCartney. About £140m of that goes to the arts, compared with a mere £500,000 in 1980. The remaining £70m is spent on lavish catering and facilities.

Colin Tweedy, chief executive of Arts & Business, a firm aiming to bring hard cash to good causes, says more women bosses and busier diaries have played a major part in shifting interest from days at the races to arts events.

'A lot of people have got exhausted with the mega-sports activities. Male-oriented sports events where people spend hours and hours drinking are not acceptable any longer. Arts are more inclusive for male and female guests and you can time them to suit everybody.'

For the same reason, corporate breakfasts have become increasingly popular, offering brevity and value for money from the point of view of the company. For the first year, the Creative Britons awards ceremony this week will be a breakfast instead of a black-tie meal. Sponsors Prudential say they have attracted more (the implication is 'better') corporate guests for a 7.45am event than they would do in the evening. The show will be over at 9am and the guests, fed and f ted, will be at their desks ready for work. And it costs much less to supply smoked salmon, eggs and bagels than it does to lay on a five-course dinner with accompanying wines.

'Companies like Ernst & Young have become quite brutal,' added Tweedy. 'They ask why they spend all that money on opera or theatre to have people sitting in rows in the dark unable to talk to each other. Many companies still buy these tickets, but they are looking for alternatives.'

Defenders of corporate involvement say that without private money, and the strings attached, Tate Modern would not have been built and the revitalised Serpentine Gallery would not be free to the public. They argue that the 15 or so top firms who give most of the millions are to British art today what the Medicis were to Renaissance Italy.

The hunger for association with Tate Modern, for example, has meant the gallery can charge more than £250,000 for corporate membership and use of its facilities for entertaining. The Serpentine Gallery event last week, attended by the Duchess of York, Sting and Madonna, raised £400,000. Tickets for the forthcoming White Knights Ball, featuring the Kirov Ballet and Plácido Domingo, are selling for £1,000 per head. But none of this helps the galleries outside London and the South-East. They must rely on the age-old support of public funding.

But of the £700m total corporate hospitality market, sports events still take the lion's share. Vodafone will spend £9m on sponsoring the England cricket team and Manchester United.

According to marketing director Wayne Moss, though the big events are still Wimbledon, Grand Prix, Ascot and the Five (Six) Nations Rugby, 'spectator events are probably fairly static, so companies are being offered a more and more imaginative range of activities - participation hospitality. Everything from tank driving to learning to fly light aircraft.

'Corporate hospitality is not bribery and corruption, it's a cost-effective and productive form of advertising and marketing.'

webTitle: Now bigger is the ideal figure

fields.headline: Now bigger is the ideal figure
fields.standfirst: With women's vital statistics growing, M&S gives a boost to size 14s
fields.trailText: Are you a size 14 woman with a 36in C cup bust, a 28in waist and 38in hips? Do you stand around 5ft 6 ins tall on size six feet? If the answer is yes, grab your credit card and head for your favourite designer clothes store. You are the model of female beauty.
fields.body:
Are you a size 14 woman with a 36in C cup bust, a 28in waist and 38in hips? Do you stand around 5ft 6 ins tall on size six feet? If the answer is yes, grab your credit card and head for your favourite designer clothes store. You are the model of female beauty.

The biggest-ever study of the female figure has revealed that British women have grown up to 20 per cent curvier and taller. Marks & Spencer, which conducted the survey, is responding by becoming the first retailer to abandon size 12 fashion models in favour of size 14.

Britain's biggest women's clothing retailer has spent a year measuring thousands of women and comparing the results with its archives which date back to the 1920s. The results show that the average British woman's bust has grown by four inches and gone from a B to a C cup.

Her waist is eight inches bigger. Six inches have been added to her hips. She is one inch taller and her feet are up to two sizes larger. Overall, the average 32B-20-32 figure of the 1920s has been replaced by 36C-28-38 today.

Although most women like to think they can squeeze into a size 12, size 14 to 16 is now the norm. Sophie Dahl, Kate Winslet and Lisa Tarbuck - not superwaif models such as Kate Moss - are the new figures of beauty.

When this autumn season's clothes begin arriving in stores, Marks & Spencer will use 14 as its 'base' size. Size 14 models will be used in advertisements, mail order catalogues and on the catwalk. Tailor's dummies have been redesigned. Five years ago many women would have considered 14 to be fat.

David Rowlinson, who coordinated the size survey, said: 'We have always used size 12 models to try on our clothes and appear in advertisements and on the catwalk, but modern women are taller, with bigger frames, larger hips and breasts. From now on we will use 14.'

The retailer's move will be welcomed by health officials and Ministers, who last week hosted a body image summit at Downing Street to persuade editors, advertisers and fashion designers to use fuller figure models in an effort to tackle the growing problem of teenage eating disorders.

Marks & Spencer used body scanning technology to measure thousands of women in Glasgow, Chester, Nottingham, Cardiff, and Surrey. Every aspect of the body from finger diameter to cup size was recorded and compared with the company's archives.

The study shows that every 10 years the average British female adds half an inch to her bust, one inch to her waist and three-quarters of an inch to her hips. Although one woman in two claims she is a size 12 or under, more than 60 per cent are a size 14 or above.

The retailer dismisses suggestions that its decision to abandon size 12 models risks making women who buy its clothes feel fat. 'We certainly do not want to make women feel large,' Rowlinson said. 'Every size is important to us but what we are saying is do not worry about being a 14. Size 14 is good. We want to dress real women, not models, and real women are size 14.'

When Marks & Spencer asked traditional modelling agencies for size 14 models to show off their autumn collection, they said they did not have any on their books. So the company appointed a firm to work in-house. Mike Bunting, of Mase Management, spent six months choosing size 14 women - including amateurs - to model the new look.

'We had to recruit and measure hundreds of women to find the right ones,' he said. 'Everyone in the building feels it is the right way to go. Size 14 is not fat or overweight.'

webTitle: Fake goods flood into shops - and worse is to come

fields.headline: Fake goods flood into shops - and worse is to come
fields.trailText: A quarter of all goods bought by young people in some British high streets are fakes, while a third of branded goods sold over the internet are likely to be counterfeit.
fields.body:
A quarter of all goods bought by young people in some British high streets are fakes, while a third of branded goods sold over the internet are likely to be counterfeit.

New research has revealed that in the course of a single shopping trip in the North-West of England, one in four items seen by 16- to 25-year-old shoppers was fake.

The research, carried out by ArmorGroup, a leading global security risk management group, reveals a massive explosion in the manufacturing and distribution of counterfeited goods over the past six months.

But not only fashion-conscious youngsters are vulnerable. New techniques to slip fake goods, from computer software to cigarettes and trainers, through customs could mean up to 90 per cent of discounted branded goods bought on the 'grey market' are counterfeit.

Howard Cottrell, executive director of IP Services at ArmorGroup, said: 'Anything with a brand identity is probably being counterfeited somewhere in the world, from tea bags to the most exclusive luxury item you can imagine.'

Statistics about to be published reveal that counterfeiting could be costing the European Union up to £250 billion a year in lost revenue, with more than 100,000 EU jobs lost each year as a result of fraudulent trade.

Cottrell believes counterfeiting operations have become so sophisticated that fraudsters anticipate consumer trends: 'Prototypes are stolen from international trade fairs and copied, often hitting the street before the original product itself.'

Last year, Reebok's prototype DMX shoe was stolen from a display stand by a Chinese gang. The counterfeit shoes were on sale in Russia, Eastern Europe and the Far East within weeks.

'Some of the most violent and experienced criminals in the world have realised the profit to be made from counterfeiting,' he said. 'Why risk robbing banks or dealing in drugs when you can copy a £100 Microsoft CD for $2, or produce a £2,250 case of Western cigarettes for around $180, especially as there's no likelihood of imprisonment if you're caught, only the lightest of fines?'

Al Checkett, director of global security at Unilever Cosmetic International, agrees that some of the world's biggest criminals are using counterfeiting to make enormous profits and to launder 'dirty money' from robberies and drug deals.

With more than 20 per cent of consumers saying they expect to conduct all their shopping from home via the internet, phone or post in five years' time, the problem can only get worse, according to Cottrell.

Of the 50 major IT lawyers, 50 City analysts and 100 top directors questioned by ArmorGroup, 33 per cent had handed over responsibility for brand protection to their legal advisers.

'Many companies, including some big brand owners, don't yet have an anti-counterfeiting strategy in place,' said Cottrell. 'This is particularly the case with fast growth companies in sectors like telecoms and IT, as well as the dotcoms.'

De La Rue, a lead provider in brand protection, believes modern technology has made fakes almost impossible to spot. 'There's an assumption that if you go into an established chain, you will be buying authentic goods,' said Andy Blundell, managing director of brand protection. 'Often the only time people find that they've been sold counterfeit goods is when something goes wrong and they try to return it, only to discover they haven't got the slightest protection.'

Retailers in the North-West are particularly liable to face counterfeit goods because of the preponderance of illegal manufacturing outlets that have sprung up in traditional textile centres.

John Anderson, secretary of the Anti-Counterfeit Group, representing brand owners such as Nike and Gucci, said: 'This is no longer the domain of lovable Del Boy-type rogues; these people are big-time criminals.'

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: The writer Luke Jennings and chef Marco Pierre White have been wild about fishing since they were boys. They  love the escapism, the chase and the same old jokes. Only catch is, Marco doesn't eat fish
fields.trailText: The writer Luke Jennings and chef Marco Pierre White have been wild about fishing since they were boys. They love the escapism, the chase and the same old jokes. Only catch is, Marco doesn't eat fish.
fields.body:
Luke Jennings About five years ago I rang Marco because I was writing a piece about fishing and I knew that he was a pike fisherman. He was working at the Hyde Park Hotel at the time. What I thought was going to be a two-minute conversation was 45 minutes, with all this mania around him, pans clattering and Frenchmen swearing. We went off the next day to the River Kennet and had a fantastic time - I caught the biggest, which is rare.

We got into the habit of setting off at 4.30am, when the roads are empty, and driving out to the countryside. It's fantastic starting on a winter's day when there's still mist over the water. You feel the need to fish welling up inside you, the need to go to some watery place. For me, it does something that nothing else does. One of the things about fishing with Marco is that he feels exactly the same. You get there, tear through breakfast and just get straight in.

Marco is a very aggressive fisherman - he won't take no for an answer, he'll keep changing techniques until he gets a result. I'm more of a watcher and a waiter. Marco gets impatient with failure and will go on trying different things until he gets it right.

A few years ago, when we were convinced there was a monster pike in the Serpentine, we had a campaign of fishing there. It was very cold, in the middle of winter, and we were both feeling cheesed off. So Marco said, 'Well, look, at least let's have some breakfast' and picked up his mobile phone, and 10 minutes later, across Hyde Park came this line of waiters in black suits carrying a silver service, a table and two chairs. And they set it all up beside the lake, so we had a highly civilised breakfast.

You're philosophical when you don't catch anything. We have a good time anyway. It's all good fun: the chatting and the mucking about. We have a small stock of jokes which we retell, and we might talk about our lives and our careers. I've fished all my life, as has Marco - and we talk about the fishing we did as children. I fished in Sussex, where I was born, then later in Wales. I'd ride about on my bicycle looking for places to fish, such as farmers' ponds.

For both of us, it's always been something we've escaped to, from everyday life to this more ritualised, predatory few hours. We very rarely kill a fish. Besides, cooking a pike is such a performance - it take hours. A fish like a pike is a wild, savage creature. The thrill isn't to kill it, but to have a connection. There's a mystical element to fishing. People say it's enough just to go to a beautiful place, not enough for me - or Marco - we want to catch, to outsmart the fish. Marco fishes more than I do; he's a better fisherman. I'm Watson to his Sherlock Holmes.

Marco Pierre White The secret of fishing is going with people you find rather interesting. When the fish aren't biting, all you have is conversation. Luke is intelligent, and we have a fantastic time together. He's the perfect companion - generally he never catches as many as I do.

Salmon fishing is a working game: I'll fish that pool, you fish that one. You don't see each other as much. When you are fishing for pike, it's a waiting game. You put your bait out and you'll sit and be patient.

I think one of the special things about fishing is the sharing side of it. You share a cigarette, you share a sandwich, you share a cup of coffee, and when one of you catches a fish, you are sharing it with the other because he's landing it for you. You don't go there with a script - it just happens.

Last Sunday, we went salmon fishing on the River Test near Southampton, the best salmon pool on the south coast of England. Some of the greatest days of my life have been at Test Wood. I'm not a great believer in flogging the water if the conditions aren't right, so we didn't fish much - there was too much water. Luke was spinning with an artificial lure, and caught a sea trout very quickly. With a spinner you cast it up stream, count it down, wind it back, so you don't need an understanding of the current. I was working a Devon minnow, which you push out alongside the current, slowly letting it swing around, so it's all about feeling the contour of the bottom. It's a slower method; you have to be more skillful. I fish there every Saturday morning, and I know where the stones are.

Fishing is escapism. It takes us away and allows us to reflect on our lives. You see how aggressive London really is; it's very competitive. We don't go to kill: it's catch and release. Sometimes I have to kill pike if I find them in a certain water because they are predators, they'll eat the young trout or salmon. I don't enjoy eating fish, myself.

Luke and I share other pastimes, like shooting and being in the countryside, but the way we make our living is different. I have 1,000 people in my company, so I'm always mixing with staff, surrounded by people, communicating. When Luke is writing a book, it's solitary. I think I'm less sociable than he is, which is ironic.

We both have two boys of similar ages and a daughter each. We had lunch this week with them and our wives, and often take our children fishing. But it's not the same for them as it was for me as a child. I used to live in the country and climb up a tree and spend hours watching fish. You'd see these big fish and you'd start to dream and fantasise about catching them. But the abundance just isn't there any more.

fields.headline: Back to basics
fields.standfirst: Despite years spent on the school run, Phil Hogan finds he's still got a few things to learn about Advance Driving
fields.trailText: Despite years spent on the school run, Phil Hogan finds he's still got a few things to learn about Advance Driving
fields.body:
Like most people, I don't consider myself a perfect driver - just a million miles further up the evolutionary trunk road than the blimpheads who spend their lives looming and parping in my rear-view mirror or gunning towards me on the wrong side of every country lane in leafy Hertfordshire. Still, we can all improve, and with the help of my recently acquired Pass Your Advanced Driving Test (Ray View Books, £7.99), I aim to sharpen up my act.

The manual, produced for the Institute of Advanced Motorists, is a spanking, well-written book full of clear photographs of drivers doing the right thing, as well as loads of aspirational tips and techniques. Just feel these chapter headings: 'Steering for smoothness'; 'Avoiding clutch abuse'; 'The pleasures of cornering'. Fantastic! It even uses a sophisticated blonde in a red MG coupé to demonstrate handling characteristics and precision overtaking and to show that wholesome motoring habits are not just of interest to RAC men with hair sprouting out of their ears.

The first thing to remember is not to read it while you are actually driving, as it can hamper concentration. By the time my instructor Richard arrives to give me a real-time session, I have gone as far as I can with the book - remembering to 'feed' the steering wheel from hand to hand instead of tying my arms in a knot, being more tolerant of the idiot in front, trying to reverse into a tight spot without nudging other people's cars out of the way. I have even made an inane attempt at 'live' commentary as I tool along, which is intended to put an edge on my long-range observation, but looks to the outside world like someone talking to themselves. 'Er... brow of a hill coming up, um, parked motorbike, horse neighing, lamp post...'

But the importance of spotting hazards before they become hazards can't be overstated, says Richard, who is an old-school, ex-Met police officer with a record of experience in advanced tuition and traffic behaviour and distressing accidents as long as your small intestine. If safety is the faith, Richard is its first apostle and arch proselytiser. He's spent too many years standing in too many people's living rooms delivering bad news not to be. And it's not rocket science, he says. It's basically a question of seeing what's coming up, and 'engineering' the time and space to respond. 'Everything else slots into place.'

We sit through a video showing a windscreen view of a busy high street - buses pulling out, delivery vans with hazard-warning lights flashing, elderly shoppers at the kerb looking every way except the right one. He stops the film from time to time to ask questions. 'What's happening here?' 'What would you do next?'

'Slow down' is always a good answer. 'Hope for the best' isn't even on the sheet. It's all about risk reduction. But you can't force it on people, he says. You have to make believers out of them. In some of Richard's sessions with corporate fleet drivers - hardened Mondeo men to whom the merest suggestion that they might try travelling at less than the speed of light would be to call their very rephood into question - the job of persuasion is harder than it ought to be. He switches the video back on and runs an animated reconstruction of a pile-up in 1991 in which 58 vehicles were involved and 10 people died. 'I always show people this before we go out on the road,' he says.

The film is simply made - little computer-generated shapes jerking their way down the motorway - and yet to see such wanton stupidity unfolding in front of your eyes is unexpectedly affecting. This is the truck that lost itself in the fog. Here is the car immediately following. Here are the two further back, doing 60, and then all the others, bumper to bumper - this is the explosion, the fire, car after car ploughing blindly into the cumulative wreckage. 'Most of the dead were in this area,' Richard says, pointing to what is now an indistinguishable mass of black. And it all happened in minutes.

At last, we're in the car, me behind the wheel ostentatiously adjusting my mirror and seat and trying to get my handbrake-clutch-ignition-gear configuration in the right order. I have cleared the car of debris for the occasion, but you can never be sure that a plastic Darth Vader figurine won't come rolling out from nowhere and jam itself under the brake pedal just as I'm approaching the level crossing with the nonstop 12.03 to Liverpool Street thundering through. And then we're off, moving up a country lane, checking my mirror with pathological regularity. I ask Richard about the new orthodoxy of not bothering to change down when there's a roundabout or traffic lights coming up. Like many of the techniques in the manual, it's not written in stone, he explains. It's a way of unfettering your mind, so that if one of those deer on the warning signs does happen to leap over a hedge, you're not still busy wondering what gear you should be in. But we shouldn't burden ourselves with too much detail, he says. 'I've never dealt with a crash that has come about as a result of someone changing gears too often.'

He shows me how to corner for pleasure, which means getting round a bend using the accelerator rather than the brakes; he offers his own rapid-fire commentary on peripheral hazards - mud on the road, woman pruning hedge, skid marks_ We hit the motorways, the M11, the M25, Richard offering suggestions for improvement, praising generously when I do something right: 'Yes - I liked the way you checked the sliproad'; 'Yes - I liked the way you signalled to change lane after the car passed you.' And, yes, he likes the way I'm engineering my space.

But later I discover that the real test is keeping your head under the pressure of needing to get somewhere fast - such as, er... home in time to pick the kids up from school. Richard notes that I'm losing concentration. Which I think is his way of saying that, strictly speaking, I shouldn't really be able to see my face in the mirror of the car in front.

 For details about advanced tuition or the driving test, call the Institute of Advanced Motorists on 020 8994 4403

At last, we're in the car, me behind the wheel ostentatiously adjusting my mirror and seat and trying to get my handbrake-clutch-ignition-gear configuration in the right order. I have cleared the car of debris for the occasion, but you can never be sure that a plastic Darth Vader figurine won't come rolling out from nowhere and jam itself under the brake pedal just as I'm approaching the level crossing with the nonstop 12.03 to Liverpool Street thundering through. And then we're off, moving up a country lane, checking my mirror with pathological regularity. I ask Richard about the new orthodoxy of not bothering to change down when there's a roundabout or traffic lights coming up. Like many of the techniques in the manual, it's not written in stone, he explains. It's a way of unfettering your mind, so that if one of those deer on the warning signs does happen to leap over a hedge, you're not still busy wondering what gear you should be in. But we shouldn't burden ourselves with too much detail, he says. 'I've never dealt with a crash that has come about as a result of someone changing gears too often.' He shows me how to corner for pleasure, which means getting round a bend using the accelerator rather than the brakes; he offers his own rapid-fire commentary on peripheral hazards - mud on the road, woman pruning hedge, skid marks_ We hit the motorways, the M11, the M25, Richard offering suggestions for improvement, praising generously when I do something right: 'Yes - I liked the way you checked the sliproad'; 'Yes - I liked the way you signalled to change lane after the car passed you.' And, yes, he likes the way I'm engineering my space. But later I discover that the real test is keeping your head under the pressure of needing to get somewhere fast - such as, er... home in time to pick the kids up from school. Richard notes that I'm losing concentration. Which I think is his way of saying that, strictly speaking, I shouldn't really be able to see my face in the mirror of the car in front.  For details about advanced tuition or the driving test, call the Institute of Advanced Motorists on 020 8994 4403

fields.headline: Beating breast cancer
fields.standfirst: Every year more than 200 males are diagnosed with a disease they thought they could never get. By Jim Pollard
fields.trailText: Every year more than 200 males are diagnosed with a disease they thought they could never get. By Jim Pollard.
fields.body:
Richard Francis's novel Taking Apart the Poco Poco begins inside the obsessive mind of a character called Raymond, who sleeps in his kitchen, spends his first few moments after waking savouring the smells in the kitchen and howls when he finds a chicken on the washing machine. It's a page or three before the reader realises that Raymond is actually a dog. It's neatly done.

However, the surprise of discovering that you're seeing the world from the point of one of nature's dumber mutts is nothing compared to the stunt the author pulls 150 pages later. Margaret, the novel's central adult female character, is in hospital to have a lump in her breast examined. She strikes up a conversation with someone she takes to be a waiting husband and is amazed - as we are - to find she's talking to a fellow patient.

A bloke with breast cancer? Most of us find it easier to get our heads around the idea of a talking dog. Male breast cancer is like open government, British manufacturing or the Tottenham Hotspur defence, a contradiction in terms, an oxymoron, even. I mean, you can't call those things breasts, can you? Well, you can, and they do. Doctors diagnose over 200 men with breast cancer every year. That's a tiny number compared to the thousands of women, but for the men concerned, the rarity of their condition comes as no consolation, quite the opposite. Each has to deal with a disease he thought he had no chance of getting.

Stuart Gilder was one. And the former policeman is honest enough to admit: 'I burst into tears the moment the door was closed. So did my wife. I had had a feeling that it was cancer but when they tell you it's still a terrible shock. You wonder fleetingly "How long have I got?" We didn't say much on the way home - we both thought a lot. I kept thinking how each journey begins with a single step and I had no intention of giving up. I decided cancer would be a word I'd speak not whisper.'

Stuart was 51. Two years later, after a mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy, he's applying to become a Breast Cancer Care volunteer to help other men in the same unexpected predicament.

Men make up less than 1 per cent of breast cancer cases. In 1993, the last year for which figures for new cases are available, there were 248 men diagnosed in England and Wales compared to 30,495 women. More recent figures are available for deaths from the disease, with 76 male and 11,759 female mortalities in 1998.

Dr Eadie Heyderman's Coping With Breast Cancer is one of the few books on the subject to discuss the condition in males. She says women and men have different, almost opposite, attitudes to their breasts. 'Women think every breast lump must be cancer while men think a lump in the chest can't be cancer and ignore it,' she says. 'The outcome for men and women is actually pretty similar for the same type and stage of the disease, but men are more likely to wait before seeking treatment until the lump has broken through the skin to form an ulcer or become attached to the chest wall.'

The risk of breast cancer increases with age. Although it's younger women who are most worried about the disease, it's older women who get it. Eighty per cent of cases occur in women over 50. The highest risk group is women in their sixties. Men are more likely to get it in their seventies.

Cancer is caused by carcinogens in the environment, but exactly why one person should succumb to them and another not depends on genetic and other individual factors. Professor Ian Fentiman, the professor of surgical oncology at London's Guy's Hospital, who has treated several men with breast cancer says, 'Cancer-causing carcinogens enter the body from food, water or the air and damage the body's DNA. Usually this is repaired, but as the repair mechanism becomes less effective with age, the risk increases.'

In female breast cancer, hormones, particularly oestrogen, play a major role. They don't cause it, but do encourage its growth. Kate Law of the Cancer Research Campaign says, 'Each time a woman ovulates she releases a surge of oestrogen; the more often this happens in a lifetime the greater the risk of breast cancer.'

Men have far lower levels of oestrogen which probably explains breast cancer's later age of onset and far lower incidence among them, but hormones are still involved. Hormone-blocking drugs, such as Tamoxifan, are used in the treatment of both sexes while men who have Klinefelter's syndrome, in which they are born with an extra female chromosome, have a 20 times greater risk of breast cancer than the average male. But Fentiman, who also advises the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, stresses that 'male breast cancer is not a sign that you're less of a man. It's just bad luck.'

When it comes to breast cancer, size matters. Women have far more breast tissue for lumps to develop in. However, men with larger breasts are also at marginally greater risk. Indeed, the Imperial Cancer Research Fund believes men who are grossly overweight by the time they are 30 may double their risk of breast cancer. Interestingly, this theoretical risk is not reflected - yet - in the figures: obesity is increasing, male cancer rates are not. They've stayed pretty static since 1971, in which time the number of female cases has increased by nearly a third.

Liver disease can also increase male oestrogen levels. Egypt has one of the highest rates of male breast cancer - 5 per cent of cases compared to 1 per cent in the UK - because of the prevalence of the infectious liver disease bilharzia. 'In equatorial Africa, male breast cancer can rise to 20 per cent of cases,' says Fentiman, 'again an infection is probably the cause. But working in very high temperatures can also be a factor, as it stops the testes working so well and upsets the testosterone-oestrogen balance. It used to affect steelworkers, for example.'

Diet is also a hot topic with regard to breast cancer. Dairy products are currently in the dock, but it's unlikely to be as simple as that. 'Japanese women have a low incidence of breast cancer in Japan,' says Kate Law, 'but when they move to the west, their incidence goes up to western levels. It may be because they start eating fatty foods which increases their oestrogen levels or it could be something in the Japanese diet, soya, perhaps, which protects against cancer.'

Genealogy is certainly involved, particularly for men. About 5 to 10 per cent of women who develop the disease come from families with a history of female breast cancer. Among men this proportion rises to one in five. Mutations in two genes have been identified as the guilty parties and a test is now available for them.

Stephen Wilshere was 69 when he was diagnosed with breast cancer, having already lost his mother and a daughter to the disease. He had the test and the varying reactions of his family are a case study in the issues surrounding genetic testing. 'When I was told I had a breast cancer gene, my eldest daughter, who has her own children, decided to have the test, too,' he says. 'She was told she hasn't got it. But my son, who has no children, and my youngest daughter both decided not to be tested. Although my youngest is concerned about breast cancer and gets herself checked regularly, she says she's comfortable at present and doesn't want to find out something she might not be able to handle.'

Because the numbers involved are so small, even men in a high-risk family are not themselves considered by the medical profession to be at high risk. Given the probabilities this makes sense, but problems arise when doctors fail even to acknowledge the possibility. In a survey of male patients at one New York cancer centre, three-quarters had had to seek a second opinion before their breast cancer was recognised. Esquire magazine in the US recently carried an article about an Oregon man whose diagnosis took over 10 years despite repeated consultations with half a dozen doctors. The reason? He was a young man, just 36.

This may be an extreme case, but the general delay in diagnosing men is real. In the US, diagnosis takes 18 months longer for a man than a woman. Fentiman says, 'Some men wait until they have had the lump for 16 months before consulting a doctor. The average delay is eight months. In women it's less than one. This means we often see men at a later stage when the possible outcome is less good.' In the UK, 72 per cent of men are still alive five years after diagnosis. Early diagnosis improves survival chances. Perhaps, it's no coincidence that all the male breast cancer survivors quoted here went to see their GPs within a month of finding the lump.

Of course it can be embarrassing. The nameless male breast cancer patient in Taking Apart the Poco Poco is desperately worried about being a man with a woman's disease. 'I keep imagining what it would look like if they put it in the local rag,' he says. '"Stockport Man Dies Of Breast Cancer." What a way to go. Sometimes I think that's the worst part.' He should worry. Apparently, until relatively recently, the treatment for advanced male breast cancer in America was an orchidectomy, popularly known as castration. Gulp. These days it's a far less sensitive part of the anatomy that's removed. 'Losing a breast is a shock, of course,' says Ron House, 74. 'But it's nowhere near as traumatic as for a woman for whom it's the loss of a part of her personality as well as part of her body. Men just wind up with a scar instead of a nipple and you soon get used to that.' After all, as every teenager wonders: why do men have nipples anyway? *

Self-testing: what to look for

It's easy for men to examine their breasts. A simple grope will suffice. 'Nine out of 10 lumps in women aren't malignant,' says Kate Law of the Cancer Research Campaign, 'but in men a lump is more likely to be cancerous. Because they have less tissue, men can more easily tell the difference between a cyst and a growth. Cysts are moveable whereas a malignant growth clings and doesn't budge. Men, especially older ones, should check themselves regularly and see a doctor if concerned.' Other symptoms include discharge from the nipple, the nipple retracting, ulceration or swelling either in the breast or under the arms in the lymph nodes.

fields.headline: Second opinion
fields.standfirst: Are amalgam (mercury) fillings bad for our health?
fields.trailText: Are amalgam (mercury) fillings bad for our health?
fields.body:
YES Dr Jack Levenson, author of Menace in the Mouth

In 20 years of practice, I have never seen such a profound medical effect as that which you get when you remove the mercury fillings from someone who is sensitive to this metal. Unexplained symptoms like general tiredness or headaches are alleviated within weeks.

Mercury is a cumulative poison in the body. If you're exposed to it, it collects in the tissues and organs. Someone with mercury fillings is exposed 24 hours a day. Even the British Dental Association admits that every time we chew the filling breaks down slightly and mercury is released into the system. And I believe this exposure can be incredibly harmful.

Evidence has linked mercury to a whole array of illnesses including ME and Alzheimer's. New evidence has even indicated that it could be a contributory factor in heart disease. There's also a link between mercury and high levels of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in someone's body - and it's shown that these levels fall if fillings are removed. It's no surprise, therefore, that other countries including Japan and Germany have banned, or at least restricted, the use of amalgam fillings.

NO Dr Jacinta Yeo, spokesperson for the British Dental Association

Mercury has been used in fillings for the last 150 years and according to all Department of Health toxicity reports no harm is done by this. Yes, there are a few people who are allergic to mercury, but this shows up as ulceration in the mouth not as whole-body symptoms. If you don't have this allergy, mercury is not a health risk. The science backs us up on this. A recent German study looked at people attributing symptoms, such as headaches, to their mercury fillings. They compared the levels of mercury in their bloodstream to that of people with the same number of fillings yet no symptoms and found levels were the same. What differed was the two group's mental attitude. The group complaining of symptoms were found to be generally more obsessive about their health than the other group. UK adults absorb about nine millionths of a gram of mercury a day, and only about a sixth of this amount comes from amalgam fillings. The rest comes from pollutants or our diet. I'd say, if you're worried about amalgam, fine, care for your teeth so you don't have to have the fillings in the first place. It'll benefit your health far more than having the ones you do have removed.

fields.headline: Alternatives
fields.trailText: Your body
fields.body:
Your body

History will be made on Tuesday when, for the first time, a hospital will be opened outside India for the practice of Ayurvedic medicine. Gopi Warrier, chairman of the Board of Trustees, says that he wants the hospital to follow the spiritual principles of Ayurvedic medicine, which is reputed to be over 5,000 years old. Ayurveda is derived from two Sanskrit words and means literally 'the art of living'. It is a preventative, holistic system of medicine, which aims to promote harmony and balance in the body, using, among other methods, herbal remedies, diet, relaxation exercises, massage with oils and a type of sauna to sweat out toxins. The hospital will be free, but in most cases will only admit patients with a letter of reference from their GP. The hospital will initially be located on the third floor of the Old Royal Masonic Hospital in Chiswick and will move to its new premises in west London later this year. There will be three Ayurvedic doctors, two Western doctors, three therapists and five nurses, and the focus will be on chronic rather than acute conditions, such as asthma, rheumatoid arthritis, colitis, depression and prostatitis. Warrier, whose database contains 100,000 clinical trials of Ayurvedic, Chinese and European herbal medicine, says that the hospital 'is meant for everybody who has illnesses which are not being cured by Western medicine'.

Your mind

One therapy which is already well established in the US and is becoming increasingly popular in Europe is flotation. Plans are now under way for the first major European flotation conference to be held next year in Bad Salzer, Germany. The procedure is, on the face of it, absurdly simple: you lie for an hour on your back in body-temperature water buoyed up by Epsom salts. It is claimed that during this time you experience total weightlessness, which relieves the central nervous system of 90 per cent of its work load, thereby liberating vast amounts of energy and transporting you to a completely different state of mind. The effect of this is a deep state of relaxation brought about by the release of endorphins (mood elevators) and the repression of stress-related chemicals such as adrenaline. Sally Hill, a complementary therapist and researcher from Somerset, has studied the effect of floating on a small group of sufferers from osteo-arthritis with an average age of 70. Two found they could knit and sew again, one walked along the beach for the first time in years, and several slept without being disturbed by pain.

Your questions

I've been diagnosed as having an aortic aneurysm. Can I opt for an alternative medicine treatment?

Ryan Cullens, London

An aortic aneurysm is a dilation of the aorta, which is the main trunk from which the arterial system proceeds, rising from the left ventricle of the heart and passing down through the thorax. It needs careful monitoring by your doctor, but homeopathy, herbalism and acupuncture can help. High blood pressure, associated with it, can be improved by reducing your intake of salt and increasing your potassium levels with bananas, dried fruits and molasses. For heart conditions, some herbalists recommend digitalis, but it should be taken under careful medical supervision.

 Enquiries to Richard Lawrence c/o Life Magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

fields.headline: Fishing lines
fields.standfirst: Jim Ainsworth, editor of The Good Food Guide, trawls Britain for the country's best purveyors of fish, fresh and smoked, from the shell, and battered with chips
fields.trailText: Jim Ainsworth, editor of The Good Food Guide, trawls Britain for the country's best purveyors of fish, fresh and smoked, from the shell, and battered with chips.
fields.body:
Wet fish

Some fishing boats spend two or three weeks at sea, so the fish caught early on is not as fresh as it might be when landed. Day boats fish overnight and return with a fresh catch the morning after - this is what top fishmongers particularly prize.

Steve Hatt 88 Essex Road, London N1 (020 7226 3963) Steve Hatt is the fourth generation of his family to run the shop (opened in 1898) and, quite apart from being one of London's top merchants, he is one of the most passionate of all fish retailers about the health of the home fishing industry. This has, he says, been destroyed from within over the past two decades, as successive governments have bargained away rights and quotas in exchange for things they consider more important. Hence most of our fish is imported, even cod and haddock. We gave up valuable fishing grounds to Iceland, the Faroes and Norway, and now import as much as 95 per cent of our haddock. Because continentals value their fish more highly than we do, they fight harder for their rights, and also control prices. Spaniards and Italians are prepared to pay far more for prime quality fish so they get the pick, while too many British customers are satisfied with second best, usually available in supermarkets. The message is clear: unless we support independent fishmongers, demand the best, and are prepared to pay for it, the situation will get steadily worse.

Coakley-Greene Stall 41c, The Market, Oxford Street, Swansea (01792 653 416)

A family business since 1856, supplying anything from tiny whitebait via marlin and tuna to a whole 400lb shark. Sources include the Seychelles (for parrot fish, groupers and snappers). Plus local day boats; bass is in season.

Pembrokeshire Sea Fayre The J Shed, Milford Docks, Milford Haven (01646 697 999) Supplies live shellfish, including crab and lobster from local boats, packed in seaweed; also rod-caught sea bass and exotics including swordfish and marlin from the Middle East.

Fish Cuisine 4 Frogmore Street, Abergavenny (01873 856 989) Now separate from the hotel and catering supplier, run by Richard Gafney, who has spent 20 years in the fish trade. The shop sells all sorts of interesting items, but fish accounts for 75 per cent of business, and it is launching a seafood bar for oysters, cockles, lobster salad, etc. Also does mail order (carriage free over £25).

Australian Seafood Company 95 Ballards Lane, London N3 (020 8371 8369) Supplier of live Down Under shellfish, such as marrons and yabbies (£13.10 per kg, about a dozen), as well as Balmain and fresh, uncooked Moreton Bay bugs (£14.95 per kg, about four) which need just seven minutes in boiling water. Direct, controlled supply also enables it to sell fresh reef fish such as barramundi, coral trout, red emperor and snapper, processed in Perth, Western Australia, and flown refrigerated to London within 72 hours. Call to ask about delivery in central London.

JH Mann, 7 Hillsborough Road Sheffield (0114 234 3538) Sourcing fish from ports around the country, Peter Mann (third generation in the family business) finds that he is selling more varieties than 10 years ago, partly thanks to a demand fuelled by television cookery programmes. Cod is still his predominant line, but stocks are declining, and the big tasty ones are being replaced by ever smaller ones - a clear indication that the fishing industry is in crisis. As cod has become more expensive, it has worked its way up the ladder to become 'a classy fish', featuring in smart restaurants - another sign of the times.

E Ashton Central Market, St Mary's Street, Cardiff (01222 229 201) While Jonathan Adams buys from day boats and sells live lobsters (£19.90 per kg) and crabs (£5.50 per kg), he also turns up a few farmed fish. Sea bass are reared in France and Greece, turbot in Scotland and Spain; warmer waters generally produce bigger fish more quickly, and he maintains that the quality is excellent, supplies are regular, stocks of wild fish stand a better chance of recovering, and the result is less expensive. Another string to his bow is a range of marlin, swordfish, green-lipped mussels, yabbies, red snapper and parrot fish, sourced from Australia, the Seychelles and Saudi Arabia, generally delivered within 48 hours of being caught.

Other recommended fishmongers

Wellgate Fisheries 5 Wellgate, Clitheroe, Lancashire (01200 423 511)

Direct Fish High Street Market, Arndale Centre, High Street, Manchester (0161 832 8908)

Charles Brickland 5 Pepper Row, Chester (01244 327 867)

Keracher Units 5/8, Whitefriars Street, Perth (01738 638 454)

Cross of York 90 Clifton, York (01904 624 838); also at 3 & 4 Newgate Market, York

Smoked fish

Severn & Wye Smokery Chaxhill Westbury-on-Severn, Gloucestershire (01452 760 190) Richard Cook smokes salmon, trout, eel and sea bass caught in the estuaries of these two rivers. Wild salmon (in season now) is supplemented by farmed salmon at other times, and at 16 to 18 hours, the smoke is quite heavy: prices vary from pre-sliced smoked farmed salmon at £18 per kg to an unsliced side of whole salmon at £31.50 per kg. Orders over £65 are carriage free.

Inverawe Smokehouses Taynuilt, Argyll (01866 822 446; www.smokedsalmon.co.uk)

Farmed salmon is used because it is regularly available, but diet makes a difference (too much fat from force feeding to get the weight up produces an oily fish) so Inverawe is careful to select mature, fitter and properly fed fish. A lengthy 48-hour smoke over oak chips gives this salmon a strong flavour. Sold in several formats, with prices including carriage - eg, 4oz packs (£5.95) to whole trimmed sides (£25.55) - plus 50 more lines including smoked trout, eel, halibut, cod's roe, gravlax, etc.

Cley Smokehouse High Street, Cley-next-the-Sea, Norfolk (01263 740 282) Kippers don't come much juicier than this. Large Norwegian herring are part of the secret, caught in the autumn when they have a high fat content, and frozen for use throughout the year. At the shop-cum-smokery in this small village, they are briefly brined, then cold smoked over smouldering oak sawdust overnight, or up to 48 hours, depending on conditions. Pay £3.96 per kg (about four kippers). There is no mail order, but the shop is open seven days a week.

Bridfish Unit 1 Old Laundry Industrial Estate, Sea Road North, Bridport, Dorset (01308 456 306) Patrick Gibb's award-winning kippers are also produced from frozen Norwegian

A Pert of Arbroath 244 High Street, Arbroath, Angus (01241 873 522); also at 3 High Street, Kirriemuir (01575 574 483) Producer of whole hot-smoked haddock, better known as Arbroath Smokies. The small fish, bought daily from Aberdeen market 50 miles away, are split open and cleaned but not filleted, before being salted for about two hours. After the salt is washed off, the fish are tied together in pairs and hung up to dry, then smoked and cooked in a concrete-lined pit over whole pieces of oak or beech. It takes only 30 to 40 minutes, each fish being removed when it is ready. Supplies at the moment are 'desperate', as the fish are just recovering from spawning - prices therefore are liable to fluctuation.

Specialists

Cornish Fish Direct The Pilchard Works, Tolcarne, Newlyn, Penzance, Cornwall (01736 332 112; www.cornishfish.com) If you think pilchards and sardines only come in tins, take the kids along to The Pilchard Works, a working museum open every day from Easter to October. A pilchard is an adult sardine, and Nick Howell sells them fresh - line caught from day boats and filleted - at around £2 to £2.20 per kg. Fish landed Thursday morning are sent out the same day, to be with you by Friday morning (orders over £40 carriage free). He also salts larger fillets for three months, and puts them in oil (£2.80 for a 200g jar): try them as a meatier and more satisfying alternative to anchovy.

James Baxter & Son Thornton Road, Morecambe, Lancashire (01524 410 910) Potted brown shrimps are a great delight, not least because all the hard work is done for you, and the butter is a bonus. Boiled in sea water, shelled and potted, they are made to the same recipe that has been in the Baxter family (now in its sixth generation in the business) since the 19th century. Sold in 2oz (57g) and 7oz (200g) cartons, plus a new 3.5oz (100g) version. Price depends on size of order (eg, 20 x 2oz cartons cost £62 including carriage).

RE Campbell 72 Maltings Road, Bagley's Lane, London SW6 (020 7371 5566) Father Bob Campbell and son Robin trade in impeccably sourced Iranian caviar from the Caspian Sea. Thanks to Russian mafiosi and contraband Iranian dealers, there is a lot of suspect caviar about, but theirs comes with a CITES certificate from a licensed trading corporation in Iran, with every tin sealed and numbered at source. Beluga (pale grey to black) 'really does taste best' and costs £275 for 250g (£55 for 50g); Oscietre (smaller, pale brown eggs) is £175 (£40 for 50g); Sevruga (smaller still, dark grey) is £135 (£27 for 50g). Store between 0 and -2 C for up to 14 days, eat within 24 hours of opening, and use a non-metallic spoon (plastic, horn, wood or mother of pearl).

Caviar House 161 Piccadilly, London W1 (020 7409 7171) A combination of restaurant, seafood bar and take-away, this Copenhagen-based family company, founded in 1950, also has airport shops at Heathrow and Gatwick. Eggs from Beluga, the largest and rarest sturgeon, cost £740 for 250g (£160 for 50g); Oscietre is £285 (£60 for 50g); and Sevruga, which accounts for 70 per cent of the total catch, is £246 (£53 for 50g). They also sell Royal Black (from 40-year-old Oscietre sturgeon) and Imperial (from 80-year-old Oscietre).

Pembrokeshire Meat & Fish 21 St Govans Centre, Pembroke Dock, Pembrokeshire (01646 685 747) As stocks of wild sea trout decline, so the incentive to farm them becomes more attractive, if only to relieve pressure on the wild. They are a delicacy - a brown trout that runs away to sea and ends up halfway to being a salmon - known in Wales as sewin. Stephen Thomson of Haven Harvest oversees their progression from 100g freshwater tiddlers to adults weighing anything from 1.5 to 4 or 5lb, transferring them to seawater after about a year. Milford Haven had a rough time a few years ago when the Sea Empress ran aground, but this is now a Special Area of Conservation, with low-density stocking, no chemical treatments, and a strong current to put some muscle on the fish. He supplies several outlets, but Pembrokeshire Meat & Fish can get hold of them quickly (telephone first), and sells them at £4 per lb.

Fish and chips

When it comes to fish and chips, forget day boats that potter round the coast. This is big business, and the white fish is typically 'frozen at sea' in factory ships within a few hours of being hauled into the boat. Although they are a national institution, fish and chip shops vary considerably in quality, depending on the skill and care of the owner.

Olley's Fish Experience 67 Norwood Road, London SE24 (020 8671 8259) As the name suggests, this is no ordinary chippie. Order from curved, gold-rimmed blackboards, and be prepared for some of the best fish and chips in London, if not the country: cod, haddock, hake, salmon, monk, halibut and skate are all battered and deep-fried to order. Harry Niazi is fanatical, keeping his freshly prepared batter at 1 to 3 C, so it forms a proper seal when it hits the 180 C groundnut oil. Chips are blanched first (it makes a big difference) and cooked at 170 C until crisp. Mushy peas are home-made; 'no curry sauce'. Take away or eat in.

Park Chippy Station Road, Suffield Park, Cromer, Norfolk (01263 513 050) Dave Audley is happy with 'frozen at sea' fish because it is filleted, cleaned, processed and frozen within three hours of being caught; his range includes huss, plaice, skate wing, haddock and cod in five sizes, from children's to a 14oz whopper. He uses beef dripping for fying ('It gives a better flavour'), and never lets a piece of fish anywhere near the fat until it has been ordered and paid for: nothing is worse than fried fish that has to hang around waiting for a customer to stroll in. Chips are soaked in a solution that allows them to dry quickly, thus producing a better chip, which also stops them absorbing too much fat. Only take away, but there are queues at peak times.

Bizzie Lizzie's 36 Swadford Street, Skipton, North Yorkshire (01756 793 189) Last year's winner of the Best Fish & Chip Shop in the Country, Jean Ritson is another devotee of 'frozen at sea' white fish, because it is 'the best you can get'. The defrosted cod and haddock are portioned, and pin bones removed, before being dunked in batter that is made fresh three or four times a day. Chunky chips are blanched in cooler dripping first and allowed to rest before being crisped off in baskets when needed; that way there is always a good supply ready when coach parties turn up, but nothing spoiling if things are quiet. Cod, chips and peas to take away cost £2.80, and there is a restaurant as well.

Other recommended fish and chip shops

Henry Higgins 47 Station Road, Woburn Sands, Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire (01908 583 144)

Belfield's 72 Parliament Street, Burnley, Lancashire (01282 428 042)

Fish'n' Chick'n 9 The Mall, Bar Hill, Cambridge (01954 781 627)

Hanbury's Licensed Fish Restaurant Princes Street, Torquay, Devon (01803 329 928)

P & M Fionda 231 Low Waters Road, Hamilton, Strathclyde (01698 281 877)

Croesy Fish Bar 7 Edlogan Square, Croes-y-Ceiliog, Cwmbran, Gwent (01633 860 033)

Brady's 513 Old York Road, London SW18 (020 8877 9599)

Two Brothers Fish Restaurant 297 Regent's Park Road, London N3 (020 8346 0469)

Upper Street Fish Shop 324 Upper Street, London N1 (020 7359 1401)

Shellfish

Live shellfish are available for those who enjoy preparing them personally, and ready cooked for those who prefer the easy route. The chances of finding a bad oyster these days are slim in view of the rigorous purification process they have to undergo. Mussels are available now, but autumn and winter are the best seasons.

Menai Oysters Tal-y-Bont Bach, Dwyran, Anglesey (01248 430 878) Sean Krijnen trained as a marine biologist, specialising in shellfish for his MSc, and took over this business on the south-west corner of Anglesey eight years ago. He grows Pacific oysters from seed (natives don't like the conditions here) and it takes about three years for them to reach maturity and a saleable size of 90g to 120g. Mail-order deliveries are despatched at 4.30pm the day before to arrive Tuesday to Friday: £14 for one dozen; £18 for two; £22 for three, etc, or £40 for 100 oysters (prices include carriage).

Fish on the Quay Cadwgan Place, Aberaeron (01545 571 294) Peter Bottoms reckons to 'shift more shellfish than anyone else in west Wales', specialising in crab, lobsters and prawns from the Bay (buy them live, or still warm from the pot), plus anything from local day boats. He is also part of the Cardigan Bay Fishermen's Association that takes conservation seriously, returning egg-laden hen lobsters to the sea, with the help of a small EU grant, to ensure the viability of future generations of both lobsters and fishermen. Alternatively, eat seafood salads, chowder and fresh mackerel across the courtyard at Hive on the Quay (01545 570 445, open daytime only, seven days a week, until September) which Peter Bottoms supplies. Note also the Cardigan Bay Fish Festival in Aberaeron Harbour on 9 July, with everything from sea shanties to chef demonstrations.

Mail order

Far from being second best, mail order is often the preferred way to buy spankingly fresh fish, cutting out the middleman. Typically landed from day boats, it can be on its way to you within a few hours. The cost of transport (which can be shared with friends) is easily compensated for by the high quality. While some of the previous entries offer mail-order delivery, the following are specialists.

Quayside Fish The Harbourside, Porthleven, Cornwall (01326 562 008) John Strike's fish comes from day boats, sold direct at the harbourside and by mail order at £8.50 per delivery: refrigerated orders leave by 4pm, and arrive before noon next day. It will supply whatever is in season - take the advice about best buys (currently plaice and turbot) with confidence - and will send it as whole fish, fillets, or whatever you require. Live lobsters are £15.90 per kg, and crabmeat is second to none: white (usually from big-clawed cock crabs) is £23.95 per kg, but brown (typically from a hen crab) is £9.70 per kg and is an underrated joy - make it into soup or spread it on sandwiches. It also smokes its own fish, from large haddock via smoked salmon to popular hot roast-smoked salmon.

Club Chef Direct Lakeside, Bridgewater Road, Barrow Gurney, Bristol (01793 433 733; www.clubchefdirect.co.uk) Top restaurants always seem to get magnificent supplies - enormous scallops in the shell, razor clams, live lobster, skate wings, wild sea bass and sea trout - that are far better than anything you ever see in a shop. Together with Steve Downey of Heritage Fine Foods, a few of them (Rick Stein, Shaun Hill, Pierre Koffmann, Franco Taruschio, Philip Howard, Richard Corrigan and others) have formed a group to supply ordinary retail customers with exactly the prime-quality produce they use themselves. Subscription to the club costs £100 pa (other supplies include meat, poultry, offal, mushrooms, game and more), and while Steve Downey organises supplies - guaranteed next-day delivery for members, typically at prices below high-street retailers - the chefs will contribute recipes to a monthly magazine (for June, Sally Clarke on crab and Michel Roux Jr on red mullet). Non members can contact Heritage Fine Foods (01275 474 707) for similar supplies without the bells and whistles.

Loch Fyne Oysters Clachan, Cairndow, Argyll (01499 600 264; www.loch-fyne.com) Pacific oysters are grown from seed in the loch, packed in wooden panniers, and cost £9 per dozen by overnight delivery (£5 carriage for orders under £60). Smoked salmon is among the very best, sourced from Loch Duart, with sustainability a central aim: 'We do not smoke wild salmon, which is now effectively an endangered species.' An unsliced side (the best way to buy it) weighing around 1kg costs £21, while the luxurious Kinglas fillet is £18.50 for approximately 500g. There are lots of other lines, from gravlax to langoustines and smoked cod's roe, and personal callers can eat in the adjoining oyster bar. Branches in Nottingham, Cambridge, Elton (near Peterborough), Twickenham and Barnet.

River Exe Shellfish Farms Lyson, Kenton, Exeter, Devon (01626 890 133; David@resf.freeserve.co.uk) Pacific oysters are grown in the estuary of the River Exe, and sold at the farm gate, oyster bars in county shows, events such as Henley, and by mail order. Nigel Smith reckons that conditions in the Exe produce a creamier oyster than those from the east coast at Colchester or Whitstable, an effect enhanced by draining off the first water after opening and resting them for 10 minutes. Small to medium-sized oysters are delivered packed in seaweed Tuesday to Friday, within 24 hours of the order: £16 for a dozen, up to £52 for 10 dozen (prices include delivery). They can also be eaten with Marston's bottle-conditioned oyster stout at sister company Abbotsbury Oysters Ferrybridge, Weymouth, Dorset (01305 788 867).

Marchents PO Box 100, Fareham, PO14 2SX; (0870 900 2900; www.marchents.com) This company brings together small and medium-sized producers of meat, vegetables, cheese, cakes, preserves and more, and sells via the internet. Fish comes from Matthew Stevens of St Ives, and includes ready-to-cook fillets of brill, John Dory, monk and plaice, all sourced locally, plus whole lemon and Dover soles. Also sells smoked fish, shellfish and caviar.

Wing of St Mawes 4 Warren Road, Indian Queens, St Columb, Cornwall (01726 861 666; www.cornish-seafood.co.uk). For good fresh fish and shellfish, as well as its own-smoked fish. *

Fish and chips When it comes to fish and chips, forget day boats that potter round the coast. This is big business, and the white fish is typically 'frozen at sea' in factory ships within a few hours of being hauled into the boat. Although they are a national institution, fish and chip shops vary considerably in quality, depending on the skill and care of the owner. Olley's Fish Experience 67 Norwood Road, London SE24 (020 8671 8259) As the name suggests, this is no ordinary chippie. Order from curved, gold-rimmed blackboards, and be prepared for some of the best fish and chips in London, if not the country: cod, haddock, hake, salmon, monk, halibut and skate are all battered and deep-fried to order. Harry Niazi is fanatical, keeping his freshly prepared batter at 1 to 3 C, so it forms a proper seal when it hits the 180 C groundnut oil. Chips are blanched first (it makes a big difference) and cooked at 170 C until crisp. Mushy peas are home-made; 'no curry sauce'. Take away or eat in. Park Chippy Station Road, Suffield Park, Cromer, Norfolk (01263 513 050) Dave Audley is happy with 'frozen at sea' fish because it is filleted, cleaned, processed and frozen within three hours of being caught; his range includes huss, plaice, skate wing, haddock and cod in five sizes, from children's to a 14oz whopper. He uses beef dripping for fying ('It gives a better flavour'), and never lets a piece of fish anywhere near the fat until it has been ordered and paid for: nothing is worse than fried fish that has to hang around waiting for a customer to stroll in. Chips are soaked in a solution that allows them to dry quickly, thus producing a better chip, which also stops them absorbing too much fat. Only take away, but there are queues at peak times. Bizzie Lizzie's 36 Swadford Street, Skipton, North Yorkshire (01756 793 189) Last year's winner of the Best Fish & Chip Shop in the Country, Jean Ritson is another devotee of 'frozen at sea' white fish, because it is 'the best you can get'. The defrosted cod and haddock are portioned, and pin bones removed, before being dunked in batter that is made fresh three or four times a day. Chunky chips are blanched in cooler dripping first and allowed to rest before being crisped off in baskets when needed; that way there is always a good supply ready when coach parties turn up, but nothing spoiling if things are quiet. Cod, chips and peas to take away cost £2.80, and there is a restaurant as well. Other recommended fish and chip shops Henry Higgins 47 Station Road, Woburn Sands, Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire (01908 583 144) Belfield's 72 Parliament Street, Burnley, Lancashire (01282 428 042) Fish'n' Chick'n 9 The Mall, Bar Hill, Cambridge (01954 781 627) Hanbury's Licensed Fish Restaurant Princes Street, Torquay, Devon (01803 329 928) P & M Fionda 231 Low Waters Road, Hamilton, Strathclyde (01698 281 877) Croesy Fish Bar 7 Edlogan Square, Croes-y-Ceiliog, Cwmbran, Gwent (01633 860 033) Brady's 513 Old York Road, London SW18 (020 8877 9599) Two Brothers Fish Restaurant 297 Regent's Park Road, London N3 (020 8346 0469) Upper Street Fish Shop 324 Upper Street, London N1 (020 7359 1401) Shellfish Live shellfish are available for those who enjoy preparing them personally, and ready cooked for those who prefer the easy route. The chances of finding a bad oyster these days are slim in view of the rigorous purification process they have to undergo. Mussels are available now, but autumn and winter are the best seasons. Menai Oysters Tal-y-Bont Bach, Dwyran, Anglesey (01248 430 878) Sean Krijnen trained as a marine biologist, specialising in shellfish for his MSc, and took over this business on the south-west corner of Anglesey eight years ago. He grows Pacific oysters from seed (natives don't like the conditions here) and it takes about three years for them to reach maturity and a saleable size of 90g to 120g. Mail-order deliveries are despatched at 4.30pm the day before to arrive Tuesday to Friday: £14 for one dozen; £18 for two; £22 for three, etc, or £40 for 100 oysters (prices include carriage). Fish on the Quay Cadwgan Place, Aberaeron (01545 571 294) Peter Bottoms reckons to 'shift more shellfish than anyone else in west Wales', specialising in crab, lobsters and prawns from the Bay (buy them live, or still warm from the pot), plus anything from local day boats. He is also part of the Cardigan Bay Fishermen's Association that takes conservation seriously, returning egg-laden hen lobsters to the sea, with the help of a small EU grant, to ensure the viability of future generations of both lobsters and fishermen. Alternatively, eat seafood salads, chowder and fresh mackerel across the courtyard at Hive on the Quay (01545 570 445, open daytime only, seven days a week, until September) which Peter Bottoms supplies. Note also the Cardigan Bay Fish Festival in Aberaeron Harbour on 9 July, with everything from sea shanties to chef demonstrations. Mail order Far from being second best, mail order is often the preferred way to buy spankingly fresh fish, cutting out the middleman. Typically landed from day boats, it can be on its way to you within a few hours. The cost of transport (which can be shared with friends) is easily compensated for by the high quality. While some of the previous entries offer mail-order delivery, the following are specialists. Quayside Fish The Harbourside, Porthleven, Cornwall (01326 562 008) John Strike's fish comes from day boats, sold direct at the harbourside and by mail order at £8.50 per delivery: refrigerated orders leave by 4pm, and arrive before noon next day. It will supply whatever is in season - take the advice about best buys (currently plaice and turbot) with confidence - and will send it as whole fish, fillets, or whatever you require. Live lobsters are £15.90 per kg, and crabmeat is second to none: white (usually from big-clawed cock crabs) is £23.95 per kg, but brown (typically from a hen crab) is £9.70 per kg and is an underrated joy - make it into soup or spread it on sandwiches. It also smokes its own fish, from large haddock via smoked salmon to popular hot roast-smoked salmon. Club Chef Direct Lakeside, Bridgewater Road, Barrow Gurney, Bristol (01793 433 733; www.clubchefdirect.co.uk) Top restaurants always seem to get magnificent supplies - enormous scallops in the shell, razor clams, live lobster, skate wings, wild sea bass and sea trout - that are far better than anything you ever see in a shop. Together with Steve Downey of Heritage Fine Foods, a few of them (Rick Stein, Shaun Hill, Pierre Koffmann, Franco Taruschio, Philip Howard, Richard Corrigan and others) have formed a group to supply ordinary retail customers with exactly the prime-quality produce they use themselves. Subscription to the club costs £100 pa (other supplies include meat, poultry, offal, mushrooms, game and more), and while Steve Downey organises supplies - guaranteed next-day delivery for members, typically at prices below high-street retailers - the chefs will contribute recipes to a monthly magazine (for June, Sally Clarke on crab and Michel Roux Jr on red mullet). Non members can contact Heritage Fine Foods (01275 474 707) for similar supplies without the bells and whistles. Loch Fyne Oysters Clachan, Cairndow, Argyll (01499 600 264; www.loch-fyne.com) Pacific oysters are grown from seed in the loch, packed in wooden panniers, and cost £9 per dozen by overnight delivery (£5 carriage for orders under £60). Smoked salmon is among the very best, sourced from Loch Duart, with sustainability a central aim: 'We do not smoke wild salmon, which is now effectively an endangered species.' An unsliced side (the best way to buy it) weighing around 1kg costs £21, while the luxurious Kinglas fillet is £18.50 for approximately 500g. There are lots of other lines, from gravlax to langoustines and smoked cod's roe, and personal callers can eat in the adjoining oyster bar. Branches in Nottingham, Cambridge, Elton (near Peterborough), Twickenham and Barnet. River Exe Shellfish Farms Lyson, Kenton, Exeter, Devon (01626 890 133; David@resf.freeserve.co.uk) Pacific oysters are grown in the estuary of the River Exe, and sold at the farm gate, oyster bars in county shows, events such as Henley, and by mail order. Nigel Smith reckons that conditions in the Exe produce a creamier oyster than those from the east coast at Colchester or Whitstable, an effect enhanced by draining off the first water after opening and resting them for 10 minutes. Small to medium-sized oysters are delivered packed in seaweed Tuesday to Friday, within 24 hours of the order: £16 for a dozen, up to £52 for 10 dozen (prices include delivery). They can also be eaten with Marston's bottle-conditioned oyster stout at sister company Abbotsbury Oysters Ferrybridge, Weymouth, Dorset (01305 788 867). Marchents PO Box 100, Fareham, PO14 2SX; (0870 900 2900; www.marchents.com) This company brings together small and medium-sized producers of meat, vegetables, cheese, cakes, preserves and more, and sells via the internet. Fish comes from Matthew Stevens of St Ives, and includes ready-to-cook fillets of brill, John Dory, monk and plaice, all sourced locally, plus whole lemon and Dover soles. Also sells smoked fish, shellfish and caviar. Wing of St Mawes 4 Warren Road, Indian Queens, St Columb, Cornwall (01726 861 666; www.cornish-seafood.co.uk). For good fresh fish and shellfish, as well as its own-smoked fish. *

fields.headline: World wine web
fields.trailText: What's the bottle? 1999 Norton Semillon/Chardonnay.
fields.body:
What's the bottle? 1999 Norton Semillon/Chardonnay.

Price and stockist? £4.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, selected branches of Thresher and Victoria Wine.

What's interesting about the wine? Argentina's climate is generally better-suited to red wines than whites. The fragrant, Muscat-like Torrontés seems to do well but, with the exception of a couple of high-end Chardonnays, that's about it. This well-priced blend of Semillon and Chardonnay from one of Argentina's best producers is an exception to the rather dull rule. The grapes were picked early to retain natural acidity and to prevent the wine from tasting flabby and over-alcoholic. It was fermented in stainless steel at cool temperatures to emphasise fruit flavours. The result is a really good glass of wine at £4.99.

What does the wine smell and taste like? On the nose, it has aromas of boiled sweets (which you often get with cool fermentation) and peaches, giving the impression of ripeness and fruit intensity. On the palate, the wine is on the full-bodied side (Mendoza is not the coolest climate in the world), but it's got enough natural acidity for balance. The wine is unoaked, allowing the flavours of these two well-suited grapes to express themselves fully: herbal notes from the Semillon and rounder, more tropical fruit characters from the Chardonnay.

What does it go with? A very adaptable white, suited to almost anything but red meat. Try it with chicken, pork or fish dishes.

Serving temperature? Nice and cool, say between 8 C and 10 C.

Will it keep? Not really. Drink it now.

What are we tasting next? 1998 Enate Cabernet/Merlot, Somontano (£5.99, Sainsbury's).

Send your views to tim.atkin@observer.co.uk
