fields.headline: Super fry
fields.standfirst: If you thought a fish-and-chip supper was not a healthy option, think again...
fields.trailText: If you thought a fish-and-chip supper was not a healthy option, think again...
fields.body:
Fish and chips present the most cogent argument there is against the myth of food combining: protein and carbohydrate together, as they were meant to be until recent faddish revelation. By this, I don't just mean that I like, we like, eating them together - though that could scarcely be beside the point - but that these pairings, bread and cheese and steak frites, no less than fish and chips, have an integrity that defies any passing gobbledygook.

But who am I kidding? My interest in these matters is not as an alternative health critic but as a voluptuary. I'm after pleasure, not nutritional confirmation. But should you be concerned about such matters as fat intake, you should know that deep-frying is a relatively innocent occupation. The extreme heat in which you deep-fry immediately seals whatever is being fried, so the foodstuff's actual fat uptake is curtailed. And it is this sudden, succulence-ensuring sealing that makes deep-frying the culinary miracle it is. No doubt you find it, as a method, slightly déclassé, but bite into a piece of fish that's been dipped in pale batter and then into bubbling oil and you will taste a textural contrast - crisp carapace, tender flesh that's been steamed to milky softness within - that the great names of the old nouvelle cuisine could only dream of.

Do I sound embarrassingly enthusiastic? Well, I am a convert. I don't mean that I've only just eaten fish and chips for the first time (that not by a long chalk), but I have only just cooked fish and chips for the first time. I thought it was the sort of food no one in their right mind cooked at home, and I don't say that only because I live next door but one to a chippy. But now I know I was wrong. How I was wrong.

The novice fryer, though, cannot do it all alone. I thought I'd do it the traditional, unpretentious way: a big old pan, filled with oil spluttering dangerously, excitingly, and a basket for dipping and retrieving. But since I know that the temperature of the oil is crucial and since I also know that I am not someone who should be anywhere near a food thermometer, let alone dipping it in boiling oil, I decided to keep the stabilisers on. I borrowed a Magimix deep-fat fryer (much more inviting, and more aesthetically appealing, than those fearful ones with plastic coated instant-seal lids), bought embarrassing amounts of oil, amounts I haven't used in my whole life thus far, and got frying. The joy! It's my favourite new toy.

In many ways, making fish and chips is more ritual than cooking: think of it as an Anglo version of the Japanese tea ceremony. Actually, a propos of that, the Anglo-element is itself debatable. Fish and chips, as we all know, is traditional British feed; along with the roast beef Olde England, it's what John Bull tucks into. But how British is British? Fried fish in batter found its way into the culinary canon by dint of the street stalls of the Portuguese Marrano Jews who'd come here in the 16th century. When chips were first paired with this fried fish (which would have been eaten cold by the Jewish population) is not clear, but Claudia Roden cites Malin's, a fish and chip shop in Bow (established 1860), which in 1968 was awarded a commemorative plaque to mark the place as the oldest enterprise selling fish and chips together in Britain. She explains the conjunction as a loose union, if only culinary, between Eastern European and Irish immigrants, in the main, along with some longer-established Sephardic families.

The proper accompaniment to fish and chips is meant to be mushy peas (and you all will probably have heard that apocryphal story, attributed, no doubt unfairly, to Peter Mandelson, which has him in a chippy up north exclaiming enthusiastically, 'Lovely - and I'll have some of that guacamole to go with'). I, being a southerner, choose otherwise. Chips, when eaten alone, need only salt and vinegar, though sometimes brown sauce is desirable; fish and chips proper need pickled eggs and gherkins, real crocodile-skinned, juicy-crisp, pickled cucumbers.

The fish

I think it's a choice between cod or skate. The problem with skate is definitely the bones, though it is a fish that fries beautifully. But cod is really the fish people mean when they talk about fish and chips. You want fillets with the skin on (this helps keep the fish firmly in one piece), and I should reckon on a 150g-200g piece per person; obviously less for children. The batter is important, though, for the frying temperature of the oil is the most crucial factor. And since the fish needs to be fried at the same temperature as the second-dunking of the chips, I suggest you give the chips their first immersion (see below) then turn up the heat to fry the fish before giving the chips their final searing. If you're worried that the fish taste will permeate the chips (it shouldn't: just don't keep reusing the same old oil for too long), do the chips fully before the fish.

I like beer batter, though you could just as easily use water (as I do when making fish and chips for the children's tea; I've had the deep-fryer for a scant week and already I've been wholly, addictively familiarised), and it is ridiculously easy to make: you simply stir the liquid into the flour to blend. I find one of those little things often called a Magiwhisk (think of a contraption rather like a tinny handle with, instead of a spoon at the end, the outline of a spoon wearing a wire beard) the best way to get rid of lumps. The batter should be thinner than a cake batter but thicker than pancake batter. You need to feel confident it's not just going to drip off. So pour the liquid into the flour slowly - and if you sprinkle the fish with a little flour before dunking it into the batter, it will adhere better.

The amount of batter makes enough to coat two decent-sized pieces of fish. I would think beer batter is meant to be made with bitter, or was traditionally, but I use whatever lager I've got in the fridge.

400g cod fillets, skin on

tsp salt

100g self-raising flour, plus more for

dusting and dredging

150ml lager (about half a small bottle) or water

Heat the oil to 190 C and have the basket in the fryer, waiting. If using water, dissolve the salt into it. Pour the beer (or salted water) into the flour in a bowl, whisking as you do so till you've got a creamily thick and smooth batter. If it's a beer batter, add salt now.

Dust some flour over the fish fillets, or just dredge them on a plate you've already sprinkled with flour. Dip them into the batter, making sure they're well covered (but don't get too neurotic about it dripping off: that can't be totally avoided) and then, piece by piece, drop them into the hot oil. Now, when I say drop, I don't mean splosh them in, but hold them above the oil and then gently lower them in. Give the batter time to harden a little in the oil before letting go of the fish altogether; this helps prevents its sticking to the basket.

Once the fish is in and has had 30 seconds or so, get a chopstick or two (that's what I like to use) and turn it. Carry on with the rest of the fish, or as many as you can at one go, and fry till the batter is golden and puffy and crisp. When it looks right, the fish will be à point . Remove to a plate lined with a piece or two of kitchen towel, if this assuages some of your fat guilt.

The chips

Now this is a story. If you've never read Jeffrey Steingarten's essay on finding the perfect chip in The Man Who Ate Everything (Vintage Books, £14), then you must. His extensive research leads to the one superior fat in which the perfect frite should be fried: horse fat. I admit in this respect I've failed, for I haven't tried it. But anyway, these electric deep-fat fryers warn against the use of solid fats - a pity, as I remember some wonderful chips fried in lard in Dublin (where Stephen Bloom also ate his). The two rules for chips are simply: use good potatoes (preferably Maris Piper), and cook them twice. You cook them first at a lower temperature in order to make sure they're cooked within; the second immersion at a higher temperature is to crisp them up. Apparently you can give them the first go and then leave them on kitchen towels for hours , just heating them and crisping them up as you want to eat them. I haven't tried. One decent-sized potato (about 200g, it wouldn't matter if it were more) per person should be about right.

Heat the oil to 170 C. Peel the potatoes, slice them thickly, then cut the slices into thick chips (or whatever size you want them). Put a tea towel out, plonk the chips in the middle, and then wrap over the two ends, like a package, and give a gentle rub. Now your chips are ready for frying.

Put the chips into the basket and lower this into the hot fat and wait for it to rise, yellow and bubbling, up above the pale strips of potato. Unless the basket is really packed, five minutes is all you should need for this stage. Lift up the basket, give it a second or two to settle and for oil to drip off, and then turn the chips out on to kitchen towels.

Turn the gauge up to 190 C and when it's reached that temperature, either fry the fish (see above) or just finish off the chips. Two or three minutes should be plenty, but just do this by eye and ear: the chips should look golden and golden-brown in places (good to have some variety) and they should rustle when shaken in the basket and clatter when turned out on to a plate.

Two or three minutes should be plenty, but just do this by eye and ear: the chips should look golden and golden-brown in places (good to have some variety) and they should rustle when shaken in the basket and clatter when turned out on to a plate.

fields.headline: Fish pubs
fields.trailText: There's far more to fish dishes in pubs than that old staple fish and chips. Many publicans have abandoned the batter to concentrate on fresh fish carefully prepared, cooked and served.
fields.body:
There's far more to fish dishes in pubs than that old staple fish and chips. Many publicans have abandoned the batter to concentrate on fresh fish carefully prepared, cooked and served.

The Red Lion in Axford, Wiltshire (01672 520 271), off the A4, is an excellent example, with fish delivered daily. You may find grilled monkfish, sea bass and skate, along with Dorset mussels, crab fishcakes, lobster and whitebait. The brick-and-flint pub dates from the 17th century and has beams, open fires, ancient settles and a pleasant garden. Handpumped beers include Hook Norton Best and Wadworth 6X, and there are six wines by the glass. The Red Lion offers accommodation and is a good base for touring the Kennet Valley, Savernake Forest and the Kennet and Avon canal.

You can't ignore a pub in a Devon village called Beer and The Anchor Inn (01297 20386), Fore Street, off the A3052, gets plaudits from both Camra's Good Pub Food and the Which? Guide to Country Pubs for the quality of its fish. It's run by the Old English Pub Company, which specialises in quality, tradition and comfort. Close to Seaton and Sidmouth, supplies of fresh fish are not a problem and you may find the likes of haddock, salmon and mackerel smoked on the premises; steamed sea bass with horseradish and smoked salmon sauce; roast loin of monkfish in smoked bacon with a mushroom sauce and fresh salmon with prawns and lemon butter. The local Otter craft brewery supplies delectable beers and there's a good wine list. As well as its three bars, the Anchor also has a no-smoking restaurant.

There are more fishy pleasures at The Fox (01962 771 363) in Bramdean, Hampshire, off the A272, which, as well as fox memorabilia, has a carving of the Prince of Wales's feathers to mark a visit by George IV when he was heir to the throne. The inn was also involved in the battle of Cheriton in 1644. The menu offers avocado and prawns; plaice stuffed with prawns and crab; halibut, red snapper or locally smoked trout; and fillet of fresh salmon with tarragon sauce. The beers include Greene King Triumph and Marston's Pedigree, with three dozen bins of wine and four by the glass. The Fox has a garden, patio and no-smoking area. Booking for meals is advisable.

The Russell Arms (01296 622 618), at Butlers Cross, Chalkshire, off the A413 and A4010, has a netful of fish and seafood dishes, in the shape of mussels, swordfish steak, oysters, calamares, and lobster bisque, with the likes of cod, haddock, and plaice delivered from Grimsby and London. Other dishes may include halibut au gratin and grilled lemon sole. The whitewashed pub in the centre of the village offers Brakspear's cask beers and has an extensive French and Spanish wine list.

The Black Bull (01325 377 289) in Moulton, North Yorkshire, a mile from Scotch Corner, has beams, settles and open fires, plus a restaurant based in a 1932 Brighton Belle Pullman carriage. You can also eat in the bar. The vast range of fish and seafood may include cured fish platter; oysters; smoked salmon; seafood pancake thermidor; mussels and queen scallops with garlic, Cheddar and breadcrumbs; seafood in wine with pancetta and curried sauce. There's a good wine list and Theakston Best on pump.

 Contact Roger Protz on roger.protz@which.net

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: Indian, Japanese, Irish, Italian and English cuisine... Five of the country's greatest chefs all with one aim: to create a signature dish with fish
fields.trailText: Indian, Japanese, Irish, Italian and English cuisine... Five of the country's greatest chefs all with one aim: to create a signature dish with fish.
fields.body:
Some years ago, when I was writing recipes for a magazine, my editor advised me that its readers preferred to cook salmon, prawns and chicken. It seemed a bit limited. Had life become so sterile that it was considered dangerous to cook a glistening whole mackerel, with its saline scent and provocative bones?

I need not have worried - it seems that our piscine timidity is fast disappearing. Where once my local fishmonger displayed plaice and trout, he now arranges fantastical farmed sturgeon and monstrous-headed monkfish. Chefs are slowly but surely persuading us to cook everything from spiced sea bass to scallop sashimi.

Adrian Rudolf, owner of Fish & Fowl in Parliament Hill, north London (020 7284 4184) explains: 'If someone like Rick Stein or Jamie Oliver has been on telly and used fillets of dorade, you will be inundated with requests for them the next day.'

Vanessa Strike, joint owner of The Quayside Fish Centre in Porthleven, Cornwall (see Directory, page 53), agrees. She used to mainly sell cod, haddock and plaice; now, after countless chef programmes, her customers want sea bass, John Dory, red mullet and brill.

She believes that such programmes, combined with more travelling and eating out, have opened people's eyes to the pleasures of fish. 'It's not unusual these days for someone to ask us for pomfret or red snapper,' she says. 'We've even had requests for zebra fish. Apparently, it is very nice.' Shrinking home stocks, however, have also led to unfamiliar fish appearing in the markets. 'If the weather is bad and the fish is scarce,' explains Vanessa, 'you can't afford to have a bare fish counter, so you have to buy in exotics like swordfish or marlin.'

As a supplier to both the restaurant trade and the public, Adrian Rudolf has also experienced the rising popularity of fish first-hand. 'In a few years,' he says, 'chefs have doubled the number of fish dishes on their menus, and where they once used one fishmonger, they now buy from three or four.' Consequently, many suppliers have had to specialise in one or two fish, such as tuna or wild salmon. Most are now expected to fillet and portion the fish before delivery, and you should never be afraid to ask your fishmonger to do this for you.

Curiously, the chefs themselves modestly attribute their customers' increased appetite for fish to a growing awareness of healthy eating. Some, such as Richard Corrigan, suspect that anxiety over farming practices has led to this trend. In reality, many chefs are proactive in shaping their customers' tastes. Germain Schwab, chef/proprietor of Winteringham Fields in North Lincolnshire, is a classic example. 'When we first opened in 1989,' he recalls, 'nobody ate much fish here. I decided to give them a tiny fish appetiser to try and tempt them.' Then they started to order them when he transferred them on to the menu.

It is never easy to predict where such fashions will lead. Perhaps a glance at restaurant menus reveals the future. It seems to lie with simply cooked, filleted fish, such as pan-fried char with samphire, or sea bream with tapenade and balsamic vinaigrette. A far cry from processed prawns and flabby farmed salmon.

Vineet Bhatia of Zaika

No fish is safe from Vineet Bhatia, head chef of Zaika, in west London. Every ingredient that enters his kitchen is analysed for its role in creating a subtly spiced, modern Indian dish. If he is presented with a Black Scabbard and finds that its gelatinous, pearly white flesh makes wonderful sweet dumplings, then he will serve them wrapped in gold leaf and floating in a creamy cardamom sauce.

Vineet Bhatia specialised in Indian cooking at the prestigious Oberoi Hotel School of Management in New Delhi. His fascination has led him to develop a lighter style of cooking which combines traditional Indian spices with non-Indian flavourings, such as lime leaves, lemon grass and honey. He then combines regional techniques to create a new style of cooking. Thus his recipe for spicy sea bass with Indian couscous fries the fish Bengali style and serves it with a typical Punjabi sauce and an unusually spiced south Indian semolina base.

These days, he thinks nothing of making a firm-fleshed halibut biryani or of gently poaching scallops in a delicious chilli and lemon-grass coconut sauce. All of which might sound a little dubious to those who like their poppadoms plain, but one bite of his scallops with their accompanying whipped masala mashed potato and you may find that your local take-away has lost its charm.

Zaika, 257-259 Fulham Road, London SW3 (020 7351 7823)

Spicy sea bass with Indian couscous

Some supermarkets sell gram flour, green mangoes and coarse semolina, but you can find them, along with fresh curry leaves, in Asian shops. Serves 4.

Tikhi machli - marinated fish

6 dried, long red chillies

3 cloves garlic, finely chopped

60ml sunflower oil

lemon, juiced

a pinch of salt

4 x 800g sea bass, scaled, cleaned and filleted

120g natural yogurt

20g gram flour

tsp turmeric powder

20ml sunflower oil

1 tsp cumin seeds

1cm fresh ginger, finely diced

1 fresh green chilli, cut into fine strips

1 dried, long red chilli

1 sprig of fresh curry leaves

a pinch of asafoetida (optional)

1 tablespoons roughly chopped coriander leaves

Upma - Indian couscous

15ml sunflower oil

15g butter

1 tsp dark brown (Indian) mustard seeds

1 tsp finely chopped fresh ginger

1 tsp finely chopped, seeded green chilli

a sprig of fresh curry leaves

75g coarse semolina

80ml canned coconut milk

1 tsp lemon juice

1 tsp caster sugar

2 tbsps chopped coriander leaves

for the garnish

unpeeled green mango, finely sliced into fine

matchsticks, optional

Begin by marinating the fish. Soak 6 dried chillies in warm water for 30 minutes until soft. Drain and purée, then mix in the garlic, oil, lemon juice and salt.

Remove the fine pin bones running down each fillet with a pair of tweezers. Trim and halve the fillets across, cutting a few gashes into their skin to help the marinade. Don a pair of rubber gloves and rub the marinade into the filleted fish. Refrigerate for 30 minutes.

Next, make the sauce by mixing together the yogurt, gram flour, turmeric, salt and 300ml water. Heat the oil in a saucepan, add the cumin seeds, ginger, green chilli, the whole red chilli, curry leaves and asafoetida in quick succession. As it splutters, add the yogurt mixture, bring to the boil, then simmer gently for 8 minutes, stirring continuously to prevent lumps forming. Strain the sauce, add more water if necessary to ensure that it has a creamy consistency, and check the seasoning. Set aside while you prepare the upma.

Place 15ml oil in a deep saucepan with the butter. Set over a medium heat and stir in the mustard seeds. As they crackle, add the ginger, green chilli and curry leaves. Then lower the heat and add the semolina. Dry roast for 5-6 minutes until it releases a nutty aroma. Stir in 240ml warm water and the coconut milk. Increase the heat and add the lemon juice, a pinch of salt and sugar. Cook for a further 3 minutes.

Finally, cook the fish over a medium-high heat, skin-side down in a non-stick frying pan. Once it is half cooked, with crisp skin, turn it over and cook for a further minute. Then rest for a few minutes while you reheat the sauce. Once it's hot, mix 1 tbsps chopped coriander leaves into the sauce and 2 tbsps chopped coriander to the upma.

Spoon the upma into the centre of 4 soup-bowl plates. Pour the sauce around it and place the pan-fried sea bass on top of the upma. Garnish with raw mango matchsticks, if you wish.

Mark Edwards of Nobu

Unlike many well-known chefs, Mark Edwards, head chef at London's übercool, Michelin-starred Nobu in Mayfair, admits that he didn't begin his career with a burning desire to cook. Instead he wanted to travel. Unwittingly, this enabled him to discover his true vocation: cooking Asian-inspired food. In 1987, he was working at The Rainbow Room in New York. 'England was still in the grip of cream and butter,' he recalls, 'and I was suddenly being given chillies, lemon grass and ginger. I loved it, and decided that I had to learn more.' He arranged to work in Singapore, followed by Hong Kong, before slowly travelling home via south-east Asia. He arrived in London in 1994 in time for what he calls the 'Asian revolution' and a job at Vong, where French meets Thai in Knightsbridge.

Nobuyuki Matsuhisa (aka Nobu) head-hunted him to open his eponymous restaurant. It had a menu that sensitively reinterpreted Japanese recipes by adding an element of Western cooking. Thus a dish of new-style sashimi might have its subtle taste developed by a dash of searing hot olive and sesame oils, or a scattering of fresh green chilli and coriander.

Fish dominates the menu, from Nobu's signature dish of Miso Black Cod to Mark Edwards' latest creation of sake-steamed John Dory. 'Working here has totally changed my approach to fish,' he explains. Every ripple of a fish's body is felt and understood before a chef reaches for a knife, its texture assessed before anything is created. One bite, and you understand why this is superlative food.

Nobu, 19 Old Park Lane, London W1 (020 7447 4747)

Seared scallop and sweet shrimp sashimi

Squeamish cooks might prefer to ask their fishmonger to open and clean their scallops - in which case, make sure you get them to save the skirts. Never use frozen scallops for this recipe - they should always be fresh. If you're buying fresh out of the shell, always check that they are very fresh indeed. You can, however, use frozen raw shrimp, as does Mark Edwards.

You will have more soy sauce mixed with lemon juice, and olive oil mixed with sesame oil, than you will need, but Mark Edwards says that it only mixes properly in this quantity. An excuse to make some more. Serves 4 as an pre-appetiser; serves 2 as an appetiser.

8 raw sweet shrimp ( pandauls borealis , also

known as Greenland prawns or ama ebi)

4 large scallops (live, if possible)

1 garlic clove, crushed into purée

30g fresh ginger, peeled and finely sliced into

matchsticks

1 bunch chives, finely sliced

freshly ground black pepper

5 dessertspoons Japanese soy (Kikkoman) mixed

with 1 dessertspoon fresh lemon juice

2 teaspoons 10 year old balsamic vinegar

10g white sesame seeds, lightly toasted

4 dessertspoons light olive oil mixed

with 1 dessertspoon sesame oil

Remove the prawns' heads and peel away their shells. If a black line runs down their backs (their digestive cord), gently pull away and clean.

Open the scallops with a table knife and remove them from their shells, taking care to keep them whole. Gently remove the skirt - which looks like a piece of elastic - from the white muscle before discarding the white muscle. (If you have bought shelled scallops, they will not have the skirt, but you will still need to discard the white muscle.)

Soak the skirts in salted water and scrub to remove any sand. Rub the large end of a chopstick along the length of the skirt on a flat surface to remove any sand from inside the skirt.

Wash and pat dry the scallops, then, using a very sharp knife, slice them into as many thin, whole, round slices as possible. It is important to cut each slice in one movement - slicing towards yourself. If you use a sawing movement the scallop will break up.

Arrange the shrimp, scallop slices and skirt flat on a serving dish. Rub with the garlic purée.

Sprinkle the shredded ginger and sliced chives evenly over the top of the dish, before seasoning to taste with the black pepper, soy sauce and lemon mixture, balsamic vinegar and the toasted sesame seeds.

Heat the olive oil and sesame oil mixture until it is smoking, and drizzle a little over the top of the dish to sear the shellfish and activate all the flavours. Serve immediately.

Richard Corrigan of Lindsay House

A dainty dish of wild salmon is not quite what one associates with Richard Corrigan, the bluff Irish chef of Lindsay House, in Soho. Hearty plates of pigs' trotters and black pudding, yes - but red mullet, sea bream and lobster, no. Such stereotyping clearly upset Corrigan, as he explains: 'I always serve fish in the summer,' he says. 'I only have two meat dishes on at the moment, just as in winter I usually only offer two fish dishes. This is a commercial restaurant - I serve people what they want to eat.'

Having grown up on a farm in County Meath, one of seven children, he developed a taste for freshwater fish when young. His father was an expert poacher and extended the family diet by netting wild salmon for breakfast and keeping eels in the river in a big washtub punctured with holes. 'To see a 12lb wild salmon being shared out by the men to feed several families is a beautiful thing,' says Corrigan. 'When it is really fresh, it smells of fresh grass.' As a child he would catch young pike with a lump of meat. 'My mother would bake it with bay leaves, butter and seasoning and serve it for supper with a pool of salty butter and a salad.'

His cooking may have become more sophisticated, but clearly his taste has been shaped by his past. His wild salmon is still liberally seasoned and served with a butter sauce, albeit flavoured with fennel and brown shrimp.

Lindsay House, 21 Romilly Street, London W1 (020 7439 0450)

Wild salmon, salsify and brown shrimp with fennel emulsion

The following recipe can be adapted by replacing the salsify with asparagus, in which case allow 4 tips per person and cook in boiling water until tender. Salsify can sometimes be found in specialist greengrocers and organic shops. Lardo is the fat from Parma ham; you can also use the fatty part of Parma ham slices. Serves 4.

4 wild salmon steaks (about 150g each) cut from

the centre, about 2cm thick, central bone and

skin removed

4 strips lardo (see above)

sunflower oil

for the salsify

juice of lemon

8 sticks salsify

1-2 garlic cloves, peeled

fresh bouquet garni of thyme and bay leaf

30g unsalted butter

80g peeled brown shrimp (to be added right at

the end)

for the fennel emulsion

unsalted butter

bulb fennel, chopped, reserve the feathery

part or use 2 tbsps finely chopped fennel

herb leaves

1 garlic clove, chopped

1 shallot, chopped

150ml vegetable stock

6 tbsps double cream

salt and freshly ground black pepper

Be sure all the bones have been removed from the salmon steaks. Wrap a strip of lardo around the outside of each steak, just as you would wrap a tournedos in fat, and tie it on with string. Set aside in the fridge.

To prepare the salsify, half fill a deep saucepan with water and add the lemon juice. Trim and peel the salsify, then cut in half, dropping each stick into the acidulated water as it is prepared (to prevent discolouration). When all the salsify is in the pan, add the garlic and bouquet garni and bring to the boil. Simmer for 5-6 minutes, or until the salsify is just tender, but still quite firm. Remove from the heat and leave to cool in the liquid. When cool enough to handle, drain and cut into matchsticks 13-15cm long. Set aside. If using asparagus, keep the tips whole.

Preheat the oven to 230 C/gas mark 8. To make the fennel emulsion, melt a knob of butter in a saucepan, add the fennel (but not the feathery bits), garlic and shallot, and sweat gently until very soft. Pour in the stock and bring to the boil. Add the cream and stir, then simmer for 3 minutes. Remove from the heat. Purée the mixture in a blender or food processor, then press it though a sieve into a clean pan. Add the chopped feathery part of the fennel (or chopped herb fennel) and season with salt and pepper. Set aside.

To cook the salmon, put a film of sunflower oil in a cast-iron frying pan that has an ovenproof handle and set over a medium heat. Season the salmon steaks. When the oil is hot, put the salmon steaks in the pan and sear for about 30 seconds on each side. Transfer the pan to the oven and cook for about 5 minutes (the salmon will be medium rare).

To finish the salsify or asparagus, melt the butter in a frying pan and toss with the shrimp to reheat. Season to taste. Reheat the fennel emulsion, if necessary.

To serve, pile the salsify in the centre of each warmed plate and set a salmon steak on top. Spoon the fennel emulsion around. Serve immediately.

Georgio Locatelli of Zafferano

Georgio Locatelli wanted to give his recipe for breadcrumbed eel for this article. 'It's delicious,' he urged. 'You just have to throw it on to the embers of a dying barbecue, and in 20 minutes you can eat it. You bite through the crisp crust and it melts in your mouth.' 'But Georgio,' I protested, 'how do you prepare the eel?'

'Ah well,' he replied. 'You do have to kill it, then hang it over a sink and skin it.' He paused, then added, 'It's not very nice, even when you have a special implement to dispatch it quickly.' Tasty though his dish sounded, we agreed that perhaps it would be better to settle for his gilt-headed sea bream (orata) instead, something you can buy ready-filleted from the fishmonger.

In true Italian manner, Locatelli is generous and enthusiastic about all his cooking. Born in a Michelin-starred restaurant in Corgenno, near the lakes in northern Italy, he found his place in the kitchen at the age of five. 'Freshwater fish is really underrated here in Britain,' he remarks. 'Perch, pike and eel are completely overshadowed by farmed salmon.'

Nevertheless, he clearly manages to console himself by serving other delicacies such as small, breadcrumbed red mullet, pancetta-wrapped monkfish with samphire, char-grilled calamari with tomato and, of course, orata with spinach, balsamic vinaigrette and a piquant sesame radish garnish. His food is labelled as modern Italian. Simply prepared, with good ingredients and bold flavours, it has won him a Michelin star for his Knightsbridge restaurant.

Zafferano, 15 Lowndes Street, London SW1 (020 7235 5800)

Pan-fried fillets of sea bream with tapenade and balsamic vinaigrette

A cleaned sea bream weighing 600g should yield two fillets, each about 200g. Serves 6.

12 tbsps balsamic vinaigrette (see below)

6 tsps black olive tapenade (see below)

3 handfuls blanched spinach (about 600g raw

baby-leaf spinach)

a medium-sized bunch of chives

6 red radishes

light-flavoured extra-virgin olive oil for pan-frying

6 fillets of sea bream, each weighing about 200g

a small knob of butter mixed with a little olive oil

1 tbsps sesame oil

Before you begin, make the balsamic vinaigrette and black olive tapenade (see below). Blanch the spinach by dropping in batches into a pan of boiling water. As soon as it wilts remove and cool under cold water, wring dry and set aside.

Just before cooking, slice the chives into 3cm lengths. Then wash, trim and cut the radishes into fine sticks, the same length. Mix together.

Heat the light olive oil in a non-stick frying pan over a medium-high heat. Season the fish fillets and then cook them skin-side down for about 3-4 minutes.

Meanwhile, toss the blanched spinach with some melted butter and a little olive oil in a pan set over a low heat. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

By now, the fish should be cooked. Turn it over, flesh side down for a few seconds to seal it. Then remove from the hot pan and place on kitchen paper to remove any excess fat.

Place the spinach in the centre of 6 large, deep, warm plates. Using a spatula, quickly spread 1 tsp of tapenade over the flesh of each fillet and place on top of the spinach. Season the radish and chive salad with salt, freshly ground black pepper and the sesame oil. Then sprinkle over each portion of fish. Finally, pour 2 tbsps balsamic dressing around the spinach on each plate. Serve immediately.

Zafferano's balsamic vinaigrette

This makes far more than you need, but the rest can be kept for salads.

125ml balsamic vinegar (such as Agazotti Gold Top)

1 tbsp balsamic vinegar (Agazotti aged 40 years -

or use the best you can get for both types)

1 generous tbsp lemon juice

tsp Worcestershire sauce

tbsp millefiori (thousand-flower) honey or a

good flower honey

tsp caster sugar

375ml good extra-virgin olive oil

salt

Place the two vinegars, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce, honey and sugar in a bowl. Warm it slightly to melt the honey and infuse the flavours.

Using a plastic spoon or spatula gradually add the olive oil - pouring slowly - as the vinegar and oil should not emulsify together. Finish with a pinch of salt to taste.

The vinegar and oil should separate - so give them a slight stir just before serving.

Black olive tapenade

Serves 6

220g Tagiasche olives (stoned) or small black olives

40g anchovy fillets

2 tbsps of Tonatore or light-flavoured extra-virgin

olive oil

Place the olives, anchovy fillets and garlic in a small blender and slowly add the oil. Use as directed above.

Germain Schwab of Winteringham Fields

Germain Schwab, chef/owner of his restaurant, is a man entranced by nature. Living in the depths of rural North Lincolnshire, he utilises everything around him to create exquisite seasonal food. The first whiff of lime blossom on the summer air and it is picked and transformed into a piquant sauce for brill. As soon as the first summer morels begin to appear nearby, he will gather them up as an accompaniment to turbot, stuffed with a tiny spoonful of turbot mousse.

Schwab's philosophy is simple. 'I try to be inventive with local produce,' he says, forgetting to add that as a result he has been awarded two Michelin stars and a '9' in The Good Food Guide . Nearly half of his menu uses fish, much of it from British rivers and lakes - perhaps as a result of his having been born in the landlocked Jura. 'My fishmonger in Grimsby buys me freshwater char (omble-chevalier) from Wiltshire,' he states. 'It doesn't get the recognition here it deserves, but I have always loved it.' He frequently partners it with succulent English samphire, which has just come into season on the salt marshes.

Everything Schwab buys has to be gleaming fresh. 'With fish, you need to look for sparkling eyes, bright red gills and a lovely colour. Char or wild salmon should literally look vivid,' he says. Then it is a question of creating a harmonious dish with home-grown ingredients like lovage, English mace ( Achillea decoloras ) and basil. Summer on a plate, you might say.

Winteringham Fields, Winteringham, North Lincolnshire (01724 733 096). Rooms are available if you wish to stay overnight

Pan-fried fillet of char, marsh samphire and gazpacho coulis

If you wish to buy char, ask your fishmonger to order it from CJ Newnes & Partners, Shop 10, Billingsgate Market, Trafalgar Way, London E14 (020 7515 0793). Alternatively, you can order it direct from them - provided you collect it from Billingsgate between 5am and 8am.

Serves 6 as a starter.

3 char, 225g each, filleted

180g marsh samphire, washed

1 small carrot

medium celeriac

2 tomatoes

1 red pepper

cucumber

6 basil leaves

18 sprigs English mace or tarragon

for the coulis

1 chopped shallot

1 tsp chopped garlic

5-10g butter

200ml fresh fish stock (not a cube)

25ml white-wine vinegar

fresh red or green chilli

for the seasoning

Tabasco, soy sauce, sugar and Worcestershire

sauce

You need to keep nearly all your vegetable trimmings, including your tomato seeds. All of the following have to be cut into 1cm dice or squares. So peel the carrot and celeriac, then cut into 1cm dice. Blanch in boiling salted water and refresh in cold water. Blanch the tomatoes in boiling salted water for 10 seconds, then peel, seed and cut into 1cm squares. Set the trimmings to one side.

Quarter and seed the red pepper (discard the seeds) and cut into 1cm squares. Peel and seed the cucumber (discard the peel and seeds), then dice the flesh into 1cm cubes. Cut the basil leaves into 1cm squares. Mix together the diced carrot, celeriac, tomatoes, cucumber, pepper and basil in a large bowl.

Sweat the shallot and garlic with the butter in a saucepan, making sure it does not colour. Add the vegetable trimmings with the fish stock, vinegar and chilli. Simmer for 5 minutes, then blend in a food processor and pass through a fine sieve.

Season to taste with salt, pepper, Tabasco, soy sauce, sugar and Worcestershire sauce.

When you are ready to serve, bring the coulis just to the boil, add the diced vegetables and basil. Meanwhile, pan-fry the char on one side with the lid on until cooked for about 3 minutes. Drop the samphire in a pan of boiling water (no salt) for about a minute, until it is hot but not overcooked. Drain and season with a little butter and pepper.

Place the samphire on the left-hand side of each plate and the char just on top of the samphire. Pour the warm coulis and diced vegetables around the plate. Sprinkle each plate with the English mace or tarragon sprigs and serve immediately.
fields.bodyText: Some years ago, when I was writing recipes for a magazine, my editor advised me that its readers preferred to cook salmon, prawns and chicken. It seemed a bit limited. Had life become so sterile that it was considered dangerous to cook a glistening whole mackerel, with its saline scent and provocative bones? I need not have worried - it seems that our piscine timidity is fast disappearing. Where once my local fishmonger displayed plaice and trout, he now arranges fantastical farmed sturgeon and monstrous-headed monkfish. Chefs are slowly but surely persuading us to cook everything from spiced sea bass to scallop sashimi. Adrian Rudolf, owner of Fish & Fowl in Parliament Hill, north London (020 7284 4184) explains: 'If someone like Rick Stein or Jamie Oliver has been on telly and used fillets of dorade, you will be inundated with requests for them the next day.' Vanessa Strike, joint owner of The Quayside Fish Centre in Porthleven, Cornwall (see Directory, page 53), agrees. She used to mainly sell cod, haddock and plaice; now, after countless chef programmes, her customers want sea bass, John Dory, red mullet and brill. She believes that such programmes, combined with more travelling and eating out, have opened people's eyes to the pleasures of fish. 'It's not unusual these days for someone to ask us for pomfret or red snapper,' she says. 'We've even had requests for zebra fish. Apparently, it is very nice.' Shrinking home stocks, however, have also led to unfamiliar fish appearing in the markets. 'If the weather is bad and the fish is scarce,' explains Vanessa, 'you can't afford to have a bare fish counter, so you have to buy in exotics like swordfish or marlin.' As a supplier to both the restaurant trade and the public, Adrian Rudolf has also experienced the rising popularity of fish first-hand. 'In a few years,' he says, 'chefs have doubled the number of fish dishes on their menus, and where they once used one fishmonger, they now buy from three or four.' Consequently, many suppliers have had to specialise in one or two fish, such as tuna or wild salmon. Most are now expected to fillet and portion the fish before delivery, and you should never be afraid to ask your fishmonger to do this for you. Curiously, the chefs themselves modestly attribute their customers' increased appetite for fish to a growing awareness of healthy eating. Some, such as Richard Corrigan, suspect that anxiety over farming practices has led to this trend. In reality, many chefs are proactive in shaping their customers' tastes. Germain Schwab, chef/proprietor of Winteringham Fields in North Lincolnshire, is a classic example. 'When we first opened in 1989,' he recalls, 'nobody ate much fish here. I decided to give them a tiny fish appetiser to try and tempt them.' Then they started to order them when he transferred them on to the menu. It is never easy to predict where such fashions will lead. Perhaps a glance at restaurant menus reveals the future. It seems to lie with simply cooked, filleted fish, such as pan-fried char with samphire, or sea bream with tapenade and balsamic vinaigrette. A far cry from processed prawns and flabby farmed salmon. Vineet Bhatia of Zaika No fish is safe from Vineet Bhatia, head chef of Zaika, in west London. Every ingredient that enters his kitchen is analysed for its role in creating a subtly spiced, modern Indian dish. If he is presented with a Black Scabbard and finds that its gelatinous, pearly white flesh makes wonderful sweet dumplings, then he will serve them wrapped in gold leaf and floating in a creamy cardamom sauce. Vineet Bhatia specialised in Indian cooking at the prestigious Oberoi Hotel School of Management in New Delhi. His fascination has led him to develop a lighter style of cooking which combines traditional Indian spices with non-Indian flavourings, such as lime leaves, lemon grass and honey. He then combines regional techniques to create a new style of cooking. Thus his recipe for spicy sea bass with Indian couscous fries the fish Bengali style and serves it with a typical Punjabi sauce and an unusually spiced south Indian semolina base. These days, he thinks nothing of making a firm-fleshed halibut biryani or of gently poaching scallops in a delicious chilli and lemon-grass coconut sauce. All of which might sound a little dubious to those who like their poppadoms plain, but one bite of his scallops with their accompanying whipped masala mashed potato and you may find that your local take-away has lost its charm. Zaika, 257-259 Fulham Road, London SW3 (020 7351 7823) Spicy sea bass with Indian couscous Some supermarkets sell gram flour, green mangoes and coarse semolina, but you can find them, along with fresh curry leaves, in Asian shops. Serves 4. Tikhi machli - marinated fish 6 dried, long red chillies 3 cloves garlic, finely chopped 60ml sunflower oil lemon, juiced a pinch of salt 4 x 800g sea bass, scaled, cleaned and filleted 120g natural yogurt 20g gram flour tsp turmeric powder 20ml sunflower oil 1 tsp cumin seeds 1cm fresh ginger, finely diced 1 fresh green chilli, cut into fine strips 1 dried, long red chilli 1 sprig of fresh curry leaves a pinch of asafoetida (optional) 1 tablespoons roughly chopped coriander leaves Upma - Indian couscous 15ml sunflower oil 15g butter 1 tsp dark brown (Indian) mustard seeds 1 tsp finely chopped fresh ginger 1 tsp finely chopped, seeded green chilli a sprig of fresh curry leaves 75g coarse semolina 80ml canned coconut milk 1 tsp lemon juice 1 tsp caster sugar 2 tbsps chopped coriander leaves for the garnish unpeeled green mango, finely sliced into fine matchsticks, optional Begin by marinating the fish. Soak 6 dried chillies in warm water for 30 minutes until soft. Drain and purée, then mix in the garlic, oil, lemon juice and salt. Remove the fine pin bones running down each fillet with a pair of tweezers. Trim and halve the fillets across, cutting a few gashes into their skin to help the marinade. Don a pair of rubber gloves and rub the marinade into the filleted fish. Refrigerate for 30 minutes. Next, make the sauce by mixing together the yogurt, gram flour, turmeric, salt and 300ml water. Heat the oil in a saucepan, add the cumin seeds, ginger, green chilli, the whole red chilli, curry leaves and asafoetida in quick succession. As it splutters, add the yogurt mixture, bring to the boil, then simmer gently for 8 minutes, stirring continuously to prevent lumps forming. Strain the sauce, add more water if necessary to ensure that it has a creamy consistency, and check the seasoning. Set aside while you prepare the upma. Place 15ml oil in a deep saucepan with the butter. Set over a medium heat and stir in the mustard seeds. As they crackle, add the ginger, green chilli and curry leaves. Then lower the heat and add the semolina. Dry roast for 5-6 minutes until it releases a nutty aroma. Stir in 240ml warm water and the coconut milk. Increase the heat and add the lemon juice, a pinch of salt and sugar. Cook for a further 3 minutes. Finally, cook the fish over a medium-high heat, skin-side down in a non-stick frying pan. Once it is half cooked, with crisp skin, turn it over and cook for a further minute. Then rest for a few minutes while you reheat the sauce. Once it's hot, mix 1 tbsps chopped coriander leaves into the sauce and 2 tbsps chopped coriander to the upma. Spoon the upma into the centre of 4 soup-bowl plates. Pour the sauce around it and place the pan-fried sea bass on top of the upma. Garnish with raw mango matchsticks, if you wish. Mark Edwards of Nobu Unlike many well-known chefs, Mark Edwards, head chef at London's übercool, Michelin-starred Nobu in Mayfair, admits that he didn't begin his career with a burning desire to cook. Instead he wanted to travel. Unwittingly, this enabled him to discover his true vocation: cooking Asian-inspired food. In 1987, he was working at The Rainbow Room in New York. 'England was still in the grip of cream and butter,' he recalls, 'and I was suddenly being given chillies, lemon grass and ginger. I loved it, and decided that I had to learn more.' He arranged to work in Singapore, followed by Hong Kong, before slowly travelling home via south-east Asia. He arrived in London in 1994 in time for what he calls the 'Asian revolution' and a job at Vong, where French meets Thai in Knightsbridge. Nobuyuki Matsuhisa (aka Nobu) head-hunted him to open his eponymous restaurant. It had a menu that sensitively reinterpreted Japanese recipes by adding an element of Western cooking. Thus a dish of new-style sashimi might have its subtle taste developed by a dash of searing hot olive and sesame oils, or a scattering of fresh green chilli and coriander. Fish dominates the menu, from Nobu's signature dish of Miso Black Cod to Mark Edwards' latest creation of sake-steamed John Dory. 'Working here has totally changed my approach to fish,' he explains. Every ripple of a fish's body is felt and understood before a chef reaches for a knife, its texture assessed before anything is created. One bite, and you understand why this is superlative food. Nobu, 19 Old Park Lane, London W1 (020 7447 4747) Seared scallop and sweet shrimp sashimi Squeamish cooks might prefer to ask their fishmonger to open and clean their scallops - in which case, make sure you get them to save the skirts. Never use frozen scallops for this recipe - they should always be fresh. If you're buying fresh out of the shell, always check that they are very fresh indeed. You can, however, use frozen raw shrimp, as does Mark Edwards. You will have more soy sauce mixed with lemon juice, and olive oil mixed with sesame oil, than you will need, but Mark Edwards says that it only mixes properly in this quantity. An excuse to make some more. Serves 4 as an pre-appetiser; serves 2 as an appetiser. 8 raw sweet shrimp ( pandauls borealis , also known as Greenland prawns or ama ebi) 4 large scallops (live, if possible) 1 garlic clove, crushed into purée 30g fresh ginger, peeled and finely sliced into matchsticks 1 bunch chives, finely sliced freshly ground black pepper 5 dessertspoons Japanese soy (Kikkoman) mixed with 1 dessertspoon fresh lemon juice 2 teaspoons 10 year old balsamic vinegar 10g white sesame seeds, lightly toasted 4 dessertspoons light olive oil mixed with 1 dessertspoon sesame oil Remove the prawns' heads and peel away their shells. If a black line runs down their backs (their digestive cord), gently pull away and clean. Open the scallops with a table knife and remove them from their shells, taking care to keep them whole. Gently remove the skirt - which looks like a piece of elastic - from the white muscle before discarding the white muscle. (If you have bought shelled scallops, they will not have the skirt, but you will still need to discard the white muscle.) Soak the skirts in salted water and scrub to remove any sand. Rub the large end of a chopstick along the length of the skirt on a flat surface to remove any sand from inside the skirt. Wash and pat dry the scallops, then, using a very sharp knife, slice them into as many thin, whole, round slices as possible. It is important to cut each slice in one movement - slicing towards yourself. If you use a sawing movement the scallop will break up. Arrange the shrimp, scallop slices and skirt flat on a serving dish. Rub with the garlic purée. Sprinkle the shredded ginger and sliced chives evenly over the top of the dish, before seasoning to taste with the black pepper, soy sauce and lemon mixture, balsamic vinegar and the toasted sesame seeds. Heat the olive oil and sesame oil mixture until it is smoking, and drizzle a little over the top of the dish to sear the shellfish and activate all the flavours. Serve immediately. Richard Corrigan of Lindsay House A dainty dish of wild salmon is not quite what one associates with Richard Corrigan, the bluff Irish chef of Lindsay House, in Soho. Hearty plates of pigs' trotters and black pudding, yes - but red mullet, sea bream and lobster, no. Such stereotyping clearly upset Corrigan, as he explains: 'I always serve fish in the summer,' he says. 'I only have two meat dishes on at the moment, just as in winter I usually only offer two fish dishes. This is a commercial restaurant - I serve people what they want to eat.' Having grown up on a farm in County Meath, one of seven children, he developed a taste for freshwater fish when young. His father was an expert poacher and extended the family diet by netting wild salmon for breakfast and keeping eels in the river in a big washtub punctured with holes. 'To see a 12lb wild salmon being shared out by the men to feed several families is a beautiful thing,' says Corrigan. 'When it is really fresh, it smells of fresh grass.' As a child he would catch young pike with a lump of meat. 'My mother would bake it with bay leaves, butter and seasoning and serve it for supper with a pool of salty butter and a salad.' His cooking may have become more sophisticated, but clearly his taste has been shaped by his past. His wild salmon is still liberally seasoned and served with a butter sauce, albeit flavoured with fennel and brown shrimp. Lindsay House, 21 Romilly Street, London W1 (020 7439 0450) Wild salmon, salsify and brown shrimp with fennel emulsion The following recipe can be adapted by replacing the salsify with asparagus, in which case allow 4 tips per person and cook in boiling water until tender. Salsify can sometimes be found in specialist greengrocers and organic shops. Lardo is the fat from Parma ham; you can also use the fatty part of Parma ham slices. Serves 4. 4 wild salmon steaks (about 150g each) cut from the centre, about 2cm thick, central bone and skin removed 4 strips lardo (see above) sunflower oil for the salsify juice of lemon 8 sticks salsify 1-2 garlic cloves, peeled fresh bouquet garni of thyme and bay leaf 30g unsalted butter 80g peeled brown shrimp (to be added right at the end) for the fennel emulsion unsalted butter bulb fennel, chopped, reserve the feathery part or use 2 tbsps finely chopped fennel herb leaves 1 garlic clove, chopped 1 shallot, chopped 150ml vegetable stock 6 tbsps double cream salt and freshly ground black pepper Be sure all the bones have been removed from the salmon steaks. Wrap a strip of lardo around the outside of each steak, just as you would wrap a tournedos in fat, and tie it on with string. Set aside in the fridge. To prepare the salsify, half fill a deep saucepan with water and add the lemon juice. Trim and peel the salsify, then cut in half, dropping each stick into the acidulated water as it is prepared (to prevent discolouration). When all the salsify is in the pan, add the garlic and bouquet garni and bring to the boil. Simmer for 5-6 minutes, or until the salsify is just tender, but still quite firm. Remove from the heat and leave to cool in the liquid. When cool enough to handle, drain and cut into matchsticks 13-15cm long. Set aside. If using asparagus, keep the tips whole. Preheat the oven to 230 C/gas mark 8. To make the fennel emulsion, melt a knob of butter in a saucepan, add the fennel (but not the feathery bits), garlic and shallot, and sweat gently until very soft. Pour in the stock and bring to the boil. Add the cream and stir, then simmer for 3 minutes. Remove from the heat. Purée the mixture in a blender or food processor, then press it though a sieve into a clean pan. Add the chopped feathery part of the fennel (or chopped herb fennel) and season with salt and pepper. Set aside. To cook the salmon, put a film of sunflower oil in a cast-iron frying pan that has an ovenproof handle and set over a medium heat. Season the salmon steaks. When the oil is hot, put the salmon steaks in the pan and sear for about 30 seconds on each side. Transfer the pan to the oven and cook for about 5 minutes (the salmon will be medium rare). To finish the salsify or asparagus, melt the butter in a frying pan and toss with the shrimp to reheat. Season to taste. Reheat the fennel emulsion, if necessary. To serve, pile the salsify in the centre of each warmed plate and set a salmon steak on top. Spoon the fennel emulsion around. Serve immediately. Georgio Locatelli of Zafferano Georgio Locatelli wanted to give his recipe for breadcrumbed eel for this article. 'It's delicious,' he urged. 'You just have to throw it on to the embers of a dying barbecue, and in 20 minutes you can eat it. You bite through the crisp crust and it melts in your mouth.' 'But Georgio,' I protested, 'how do you prepare the eel?' 'Ah well,' he replied. 'You do have to kill it, then hang it over a sink and skin it.' He paused, then added, 'It's not very nice, even when you have a special implement to dispatch it quickly.' Tasty though his dish sounded, we agreed that perhaps it would be better to settle for his gilt-headed sea bream (orata) instead, something you can buy ready-filleted from the fishmonger. In true Italian manner, Locatelli is generous and enthusiastic about all his cooking. Born in a Michelin-starred restaurant in Corgenno, near the lakes in northern Italy, he found his place in the kitchen at the age of five. 'Freshwater fish is really underrated here in Britain,' he remarks. 'Perch, pike and eel are completely overshadowed by farmed salmon.' Nevertheless, he clearly manages to console himself by serving other delicacies such as small, breadcrumbed red mullet, pancetta-wrapped monkfish with samphire, char-grilled calamari with tomato and, of course, orata with spinach, balsamic vinaigrette and a piquant sesame radish garnish. His food is labelled as modern Italian. Simply prepared, with good ingredients and bold flavours, it has won him a Michelin star for his Knightsbridge restaurant. Zafferano, 15 Lowndes Street, London SW1 (020 7235 5800) Pan-fried fillets of sea bream with tapenade and balsamic vinaigrette A cleaned sea bream weighing 600g should yield two fillets, each about 200g. Serves 6. 12 tbsps balsamic vinaigrette (see below) 6 tsps black olive tapenade (see below) 3 handfuls blanched spinach (about 600g raw baby-leaf spinach) a medium-sized bunch of chives 6 red radishes light-flavoured extra-virgin olive oil for pan-frying 6 fillets of sea bream, each weighing about 200g a small knob of butter mixed with a little olive oil 1 tbsps sesame oil Before you begin, make the balsamic vinaigrette and black olive tapenade (see below). Blanch the spinach by dropping in batches into a pan of boiling water. As soon as it wilts remove and cool under cold water, wring dry and set aside. Just before cooking, slice the chives into 3cm lengths. Then wash, trim and cut the radishes into fine sticks, the same length. Mix together. Heat the light olive oil in a non-stick frying pan over a medium-high heat. Season the fish fillets and then cook them skin-side down for about 3-4 minutes. Meanwhile, toss the blanched spinach with some melted butter and a little olive oil in a pan set over a low heat. Season to taste with salt and pepper. By now, the fish should be cooked. Turn it over, flesh side down for a few seconds to seal it. Then remove from the hot pan and place on kitchen paper to remove any excess fat. Place the spinach in the centre of 6 large, deep, warm plates. Using a spatula, quickly spread 1 tsp of tapenade over the flesh of each fillet and place on top of the spinach. Season the radish and chive salad with salt, freshly ground black pepper and the sesame oil. Then sprinkle over each portion of fish. Finally, pour 2 tbsps balsamic dressing around the spinach on each plate. Serve immediately. Zafferano's balsamic vinaigrette This makes far more than you need, but the rest can be kept for salads. 125ml balsamic vinegar (such as Agazotti Gold Top) 1 tbsp balsamic vinegar (Agazotti aged 40 years - or use the best you can get for both types) 1 generous tbsp lemon juice tsp Worcestershire sauce tbsp millefiori (thousand-flower) honey or a good flower honey tsp caster sugar 375ml good extra-virgin olive oil salt Place the two vinegars, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce, honey and sugar in a bowl. Warm it slightly to melt the honey and infuse the flavours. Using a plastic spoon or spatula gradually add the olive oil - pouring slowly - as the vinegar and oil should not emulsify together. Finish with a pinch of salt to taste. The vinegar and oil should separate - so give them a slight stir just before serving. Black olive tapenade Serves 6 220g Tagiasche olives (stoned) or small black olives 40g anchovy fillets 2 tbsps of Tonatore or light-flavoured extra-virgin olive oil Place the olives, anchovy fillets and garlic in a small blender and slowly add the oil. Use as directed above. Germain Schwab of Winteringham Fields Germain Schwab, chef/owner of his restaurant, is a man entranced by nature. Living in the depths of rural North Lincolnshire, he utilises everything around him to create exquisite seasonal food. The first whiff of lime blossom on the summer air and it is picked and transformed into a piquant sauce for brill. As soon as the first summer morels begin to appear nearby, he will gather them up as an accompaniment to turbot, stuffed with a tiny spoonful of turbot mousse. Schwab's philosophy is simple. 'I try to be inventive with local produce,' he says, forgetting to add that as a result he has been awarded two Michelin stars and a '9' in The Good Food Guide . Nearly half of his menu uses fish, much of it from British rivers and lakes - perhaps as a result of his having been born in the landlocked Jura. 'My fishmonger in Grimsby buys me freshwater char (omble-chevalier) from Wiltshire,' he states. 'It doesn't get the recognition here it deserves, but I have always loved it.' He frequently partners it with succulent English samphire, which has just come into season on the salt marshes. Everything Schwab buys has to be gleaming fresh. 'With fish, you need to look for sparkling eyes, bright red gills and a lovely colour. Char or wild salmon should literally look vivid,' he says. Then it is a question of creating a harmonious dish with home-grown ingredients like lovage, English mace ( Achillea decoloras ) and basil. Summer on a plate, you might say. Winteringham Fields, Winteringham, North Lincolnshire (01724 733 096). Rooms are available if you wish to stay overnight Pan-fried fillet of char, marsh samphire and gazpacho coulis If you wish to buy char, ask your fishmonger to order it from CJ Newnes & Partners, Shop 10, Billingsgate Market, Trafalgar Way, London E14 (020 7515 0793). Alternatively, you can order it direct from them - provided you collect it from Billingsgate between 5am and 8am. Serves 6 as a starter. 3 char, 225g each, filleted 180g marsh samphire, washed 1 small carrot medium celeriac 2 tomatoes 1 red pepper cucumber 6 basil leaves 18 sprigs English mace or tarragon for the coulis 1 chopped shallot 1 tsp chopped garlic 5-10g butter 200ml fresh fish stock (not a cube) 25ml white-wine vinegar fresh red or green chilli for the seasoning Tabasco, soy sauce, sugar and Worcestershire sauce You need to keep nearly all your vegetable trimmings, including your tomato seeds. All of the following have to be cut into 1cm dice or squares. So peel the carrot and celeriac, then cut into 1cm dice. Blanch in boiling salted water and refresh in cold water. Blanch the tomatoes in boiling salted water for 10 seconds, then peel, seed and cut into 1cm squares. Set the trimmings to one side. Quarter and seed the red pepper (discard the seeds) and cut into 1cm squares. Peel and seed the cucumber (discard the peel and seeds), then dice the flesh into 1cm cubes. Cut the basil leaves into 1cm squares. Mix together the diced carrot, celeriac, tomatoes, cucumber, pepper and basil in a large bowl. Sweat the shallot and garlic with the butter in a saucepan, making sure it does not colour. Add the vegetable trimmings with the fish stock, vinegar and chilli. Simmer for 5 minutes, then blend in a food processor and pass through a fine sieve. Season to taste with salt, pepper, Tabasco, soy sauce, sugar and Worcestershire sauce. When you are ready to serve, bring the coulis just to the boil, add the diced vegetables and basil. Meanwhile, pan-fry the char on one side with the lid on until cooked for about 3 minutes. Drop the samphire in a pan of boiling water (no salt) for about a minute, until it is hot but not overcooked. Drain and season with a little butter and pepper. Place the samphire on the left-hand side of each plate and the char just on top of the samphire. Pour the warm coulis and diced vegetables around the plate. Sprinkle each plate with the English mace or tarragon sprigs and serve immediately.

fields.headline: Beside the seaside
fields.standfirst: On a shingle promontory in the English Channel, in the shadow of a nuclear power station, lies Dungeness, a ghost town of scrap metal and rusting vans. Generations of fishing families have made this bleak outpost their home and, as Kate Mikhail discovers, their cottages stand as a testament to their trade and resilience
fields.trailText: On a shingle promontory in the English Channel, in the shadow of a nuclear power station, lies Dungeness, a ghost town of scrap metal and rusting vans. Generations of fishing families have made this bleak outpost their home and, as Kate Mikhail discovers, their cottages stand as a testament to their trade and resilience.
fields.body:
If you weren't a Nesser, you didn't belong. Well, that's what it used to be like in Dungeness when this tiny Kent fishing community was literally cut off from the outside world and visited just once a week by a horse and cart carrying supplies. There were the Oillers, the Tarts, the Thomases and the Richardsons, fishing families one and all, and, not surprisingly, all related.

'I was an Oiller and married a Tart, and my mother was a Tart and married an Oiller,' says Doris Tart, who still lives in the house she was born in 78 years ago.

Dungeness sticks its nose out into the English Channel from the south-eastern tip of the Romney and Walland marshes. One of the world's largest shingle promontories, it's a windy, desolate, but dramatic landscape wrested from the sea by the Romans, where wild flowers and shimmering grasses cling to the pebble surface and migratory birds stop off for a breather after their long-haul flights. Where the shingle ends, there is an abrupt drop down to the sand flats and the water. In fog or early morning mist, when the sea is completely shrouded, you feel as if you could plummet off the end of the world.

Doris's pink and green cottage, Ocean View, is the first of half a dozen fishermen's cottages strung out in a line along the eastern side of the Ness. The small, simple clapboard houses all face out to sea, the road in front of them leading to the lighthouse which blinks lazily in the distance, while behind lurks the local leviathan: a massive nuclear power station that lets out a constant hum and a trickle of smoke. During the day, the dull grey mass of the power station takes on the presence of a faded backdrop, while at night it lights up like Vegas. Either way, it towers over Dungeness, accentuating the smallness of the community, exposed as it is on a vast, flat expanse of land and buffeted from both east and west by strong, salty winds.

In the past, before the road was built, each fisherman kept his boat in front of his house, from where tracks ran down to the coast to bring the fish back over the shingle. Each had his own storage hut as well, a large shed thrown together from driftwood. Some of the tracks remain, and many of the old huts are still standing - leaning this way and that, their doors and windows either gaping holes or completely boarded up.

Inside, old rusty tools, matted nets, furniture, and in one, a black jacket and red- and-white scarf hanging on a hook, have all been abandoned, left to be slowly battered into oblivion by the abrasive elements. All around, marooned boats and debris litter the shingle: ancient metal chains half sub merged under pebbles; an old lorry engine left high and dry; tyres; anchors; timber and rusted iron and a worktable sporting a no-nonsense clamp - Dungeness's recent history is all here.

One old shack, a patchwork of old doors, driftwood and corrugated iron, houses a massive, old lorry engine used for winching boats ashore. Hefty workmen's gloves lie discarded on the floor, their owner long gone, while the wind whistles through, eating away at wood and metal alike. The air is filled with a delicious honey-sweet smell from the clumps of sea kale which cover the shingle, and tar used to protect the boats and buildings.

Shingle is, by nature, always on the move, and over the years, the expanse between the cottages and the coastline has stretched and stretched, forcing the fishermen to build new generations of sheds nearer to the sea. Everything changed when the road was built. That was during the Second World War, when Dungeness was full of troops and the locals had to have a special passport just to get into the village.

'We were on alert all the time,' recalls Doris, pushing aside a crab she is in the middle of preparing. 'If Hitler had invaded, it was going to be along this coast.' The Ness, as a result, was heavily mined, with just the narrowest of strips left clear for the fishermen to launch their boats.

Today everything has shunted further down the beach towards the lighthouse, where the water is deeper and able to take the larger boats that are now used. New fishing huts have sprung up all around - but times have changed, and the romantic old shacks have been replaced with second- hand lorry containers, which are cheaper, more secure and able to put up more of a fight against the voracious wind.

Jumbo, a retired fisherman, still keeps his old black container, which he visits when he can. He also looks after another which belonged to his neighbour, Gordon, who died a few years ago. Gordon's hut is more like a little home - a large wooden construction with an arched roof, filled with a table and chairs and all his fishing gear, just as he left it.

About 40 fishermen work in Dungeness today, in crews of two to five. On the boat by 4am or 5am, and hopefully back by midday with a catch which includes cod, plaice, Dover sole, crabs and turbot, it's a gruelling life. Most of the time, the area around the boats is completely deserted, the odd car evidence that its owner is out at sea. There's the occasional burst of activity as boats come in and hauls are unloaded, but otherwise it is still a ghost town piled high with nets, crates of equipment and tangled junk: the rectan gular box of an old red Royal Mail van here, and a bashed-around black van there, its wheels knocked from under it and its cabin removed.

Kenny Thomas has been a fisherman all his life, and his father and grandfather before him. His son Joe is also following in their footsteps. Kenny's great-grandfather was a deep-sea diver brought in to dive on the wrecks. 'He married one of the Tart girls,' says Kenny. 'It's all Tarts and Oillers round here.' Kenny happily admits that 'everyone is related to everyone else somewhere along the line', the reason being that 'there was no road, so they all married each other'.

The fact that everything, once finished with, is left to crumble where it stands and go back to the soil - metal, plastic and even nylon nets all eventually succumbing to the erosive weather - makes Dungeness a beachcomber's paradise.

The late film director Derek Jarman, who bought Gran and Granddad Char's Prospect Cottage in 1986, made full use of the treasure to be found on his doorstep. Rocks, pebbles, wood, shells, iron and glass have all been used to sculpt his garden. The result: a beautiful collection of totem-like pieces of driftwood, orange California poppies, herbs and all manner of plants bordered by sun-bleached sticks, rusted old chains and large, upright stones, which he likened to dolmens.

No fences interrupt the line of vision. The buildings stand in stark relief against the surrounding space and shingle, low to the ground, like the plants, all the better to withstand the relentless wind.

Winter in Dungeness is harsh and cold, and the winds are fierce. This is also the time when the shingle shifts eastwards, away from the power station and round to the cottages. Whoever had the bright idea of building a nuclear power station on such precarious ground clearly wasn't looking to the future. Inhospitable as it is, Dungeness gets under the skin. And although it is no longer cut off from the outside world, Dungeness is still primarily a working fishing village. It is also a preservation area, protected from development by the Dungeness Trust, which suits Doris just fine. 'I don't mind,' she says. 'As long as it stays as it is while I'm on deck.'

Well, that's what it used to be like in Dungeness when this tiny Kent fishing community was literally cut off from the outside world and visited just once a week by a horse and cart carrying supplies. There were the Oillers, the Tarts, the Thomases and the Richardsons, fishing families one and all, and, not surprisingly, all related. Dungeness sticks its nose out into the English Channel from the south-eastern tip of the Romney and Walland marshes. One of the world's largest shingle promontories, it's a windy, desolate, but dramatic landscape wrested from the sea by the Romans, where wild flowers and shimmering grasses cling to the pebble surface and migratory birds stop off for a breather after their long-haul flights. Where the shingle ends, there is an abrupt drop down to the sand flats and the water. In fog or early morning mist, when the sea is completely shrouded, you feel as if you could plummet off the end of the world. Doris's pink and green cottage, Ocean View, is the first of half a dozen fishermen's cottages strung out in a line along the eastern side of the Ness.
