fields.headline: Another country
fields.standfirst: It was bad enough for the old guard at the Grand Ol' Opry when  kd lang dressed in drag and announced she was gay. But now she's done the unforgiveable... she's made a rock album with Madonna's producer
fields.trailText: It was bad enough for the old guard at the Grand Ol' Opry when kd lang dressed in drag and announced she was gay. But now she's done the unforgiveable... she's made a rock album with Madonna's producer.
fields.body:
It's a hot early summer afternoon in LA, and we're driving through Beverly Hills, slowly making our way out of town, up the Pacific Coastal Highway. On the left, the Pacific Ocean blinks invitingly at the traffic. Travelling no faster than 10mph, locked into a tailback, the minutes cease to hold any resonance.

From the slow procession of cars - LA city workers travelling back to their hill-side mansions in Malibu - blares a cacophony of differing sounds. No one is impatient; loose, sun-tanned arms hang out of every window, fingers happily drumming on the side of the car. Peering from window to window, catching a glimpse at individual universes, I see people smiling. Almost all are singing: 'God only knows/What I'd be without you'; 'Round, round, get-a-round/I get around'; 'Welcome to the Hotel California. Such a lovely place/Such a lovely face'.

John Steinbeck periodically hitchhiked up and down this stretch in the 40s, finally settling down in Salinas, 100 miles further up the coast. The truck stops give way to Mexican diners, before leading to the doorways of bankrupt farmers; the road is Steinbeck's agrarian America personified. A 700-mile stretch of the cruel and the kind.

We are on our way to interview kd lang, who is filming her latest video somewhere south of Malibu. We are already half an hour behind schedule, but neither my companion nor I seem worried. As we gaze at the cliff-top houses on our right, precariously balanced on rocky ridges above the highway, we locate a procession of trucks by the roadside. kd lang's video shoot, inside the grounds of a smallish and dilapidated bungalow, has brought the traffic to a standstill.

Walking up the ridged driveway that leads up to the house, the singer can be seen hovering around the back garden. She is midway through a take, wearing a Pacific blue work shirt hanging over grey tracksuit bottoms. Her sweat in the daylight gives her the warm glow of someone who has just been jogging. She looks bigger, healthier than I remember; perhaps her frame is too bulky for that honeysuckle voice. Her boyish hair snakes around her face as she sings to the backing tape. At one point, after the director shouts 'Cut!', she makes exaggerated boy-band poses; hula-hooping her hips while her fists punch the air, seesaw-style.

'Hiya,' she grins, when we are introduced. It's impossible not to grin back. Stepping forward, I shake her hand. Hers is a friendly, warm, palmy handshake. 'We'll chat in a minute,' she promises. 'We can talk between takes in my trailer. I have lots of time off this afternoon. Hey! In the meantime, help yourself to something to eat.'

I hover around the driveway, stopping off for a coffee. Between cigarettes, I wander back to the garden, looking at kd lang sitting by a window, still singing at the camera. She looks shyly at the director, then at the crew. The song is the first single from her new album Invincible Summer, produced by Damian le Gassick, occasional collaborator with Madonna and William Orbit.

Sitting idly on a log bench at the back of the garden, listening to kd lang sing the warm, heartfelt words, I momentarily doze off. She walks over after the music stops. 'C'mon, then. We'll go down to my trailer.'

kd lang shuffles behind me in her white rubber flip-flops as we walk up the highway to her trailer. She turns away from the traffic anxiously as it passes her side up the road. For two days, the video shoot has slowed down the three-lane road to a near standstill. 'Man, these people must hate me,' laughs kd lang. 'I'm stopping them from getting were they want to go.'

We clamber into her trailer - slow, careful steps so we don't fall off - and kd lang immediately ushers me to the kitchen table by the rear window. As I unpack my tape recorder, she clasps and unclasps her hands in front of her face, viewing the Dictaphone suspiciously. Her quiet voice occasionally breaks into a riotous guffaw. 'You're not going to ask me any awkward questions, are you?' she joshes. She picks at her fingernails; they've all been chewed methodically down to the quick. I think of other caramel-voiced, lesbian country-and-western singers to strike a comparison against, and strike nothing.

Kathryn Dawn Lang was born on 2 November 1961 in Edmonton, Canada. Inspired at an early age by country-and-western diva Patsy Cline, kd lang formed The Reclines, a garage-influenced country group, who released a string of critically acclaimed albums in the mid-80s: Truly Western Experience, Angel With a Lariat, Shadowland and Absolute Torch & Twang.

Alongside musicians such as Lyle Lovett and Steve Earle, kd lang came to epitomise 'new country' - and soon came into conflict with the Nashville old guard. Earle, in particular, carburettor-voiced with his dramatic tales of Harley-Davidsons and small-town miscreants on Death Row, quickly found himself without a deal. Sitting in her trailer, kd lang recalls, 'He really went out of his way to kick up a fuss at everything he saw wrong. I was more careful, took my time in making my own judgments about Nashville and what I was doing there. As a woman, especially in country, you have to be very careful. Country music is still one of the last bastions of old, white men. There are some incredible attitudes there that you don't see in other parts of the recording industry. Look at all these new country girls at the moment. Incredibly clean-cut, sexy, but not trampy. Country music - as run by Nashville - has always wanted to protect womankind. Can you imagine just how stifling that can be after a while?'

Continuing to write and record, kd lang built up a sizeable alternative audience outside the US, where the new country was more readily received. It wasn't until the success of 1992's Ingénue, however, that she was finally accepted as a mainstream performer. The record was an immediate success; its lovelorn ballads drawing from resolutely anti-Nashville influences, such as Love, The Mamas and the Papas and The Beach Boys. 'The country music press was very hostile,' smiles kd lang. 'But by that time, I'd been picked up by pop radio.'

The same year, kd lang removed herself further from her country-and-western audience by publicly declaring her lesbianism. Her career had, until then, been plagued by rumours of her sexuality. In an interview with the American rock bible Rolling Stone, she alluded to her alternative lifestyle. A subsequent cover for Vanity Fair, showing her in male drag being shaved by Cindy Crawford, caused further outrage.

It was a hugely cathartic moment. 'I got all these letters from people who had never met me,' she mumbles. 'All horrible things, people screaming like I'd let them down.'

She looks nervous. 'I don't like being interviewed,' she admits. 'It's a bit of a nerve-wracking experience.' Why? 'I guess I'm quite shy. I'd rather make the records and tour.'

Her life in Los Angeles is surprisingly low-key these days. Gone are the times when she reinvented herself as an oversexed conquistador and was linked to Madonna around the time of the Sex project. 'I bought a house a couple of years ago,' she says, sipping weak coffee from her mug. 'And I hang out there with my friends. Don't get back to Canada as often as I used to, either.'

Her new album, Invincible Summer, has been almost two years in the recording. 'I wanted a warm sound for this,' she says. 'Even though I'm making pop music now, I still have all those country-and-western leanings. So I look at each individual album as a collection that says something different from last time. It's the way Patsy Cline recorded, and how I was in Nashville. I want a body of work not just albums. There has to be a theme, some kind of evolution.'

The singer gets called back to the set, so I trudge back down the PCH to the house. I can hear her singing somewhere in a room above. Half an hour later, back in the trailer, she grasps another mug of coffee. Her coming-out in 1992, I venture: was it orches trated? 'Absolutely not,' she says, blushing. 'God, if it was then that must have been the most clumsy thing ever! The rumours had plagued me for years, everyone talked about it. Critics would often ask me questions about my personal life. Was there a boyfriend? I'd smile, and turn the conversation around. Sure, there is someone, I'd say. Or, I'm not that interested in a relationship at the moment.

'It was incredibly difficult to conduct interviews for a while, so we went to Rolling Stone and told them,' she continues. 'But I certainly didn't expect the kind of reaction that it got. My fans were horrified. And I didn't get it. I'd always thought country music was about tough choice and heartbreak. But you come up against some really old-fashioned bigotry. Well, look at us now. Steve Earle makes all kinds of music, Lyle Lovett has become an underground hero. And I make pop music. After a while, I just couldn't take the endless criticism any more.'

She sighs as she receives another call from the director. I follow her back to the set; it's fast approaching six in the evening. The crew hunkers down for a final take, and with the video declared finished, starts to pack the lighting equipment into vans adjacent to the highway. Driving back down the PCH, later that night, I run through LA's radio stations searching for an appropriate tune. I settle on 'Constant Craving', arriving back in LA soothed by kd lang's soaring vocals.

It's too hot the next morning when I climb up Sunset Boulevard towards the Chateau Marmont where kd lang has a room. Reaching the hotel early, I backtrack to the Virgin record store a couple of blocks away and start skimming through her back catalogue. On her early album sleeves, she looks heavily posed, visibly uncomfortable in the pictures. Yesterday, she'd revealed why she's moved to Los Angeles. 'It's quiet here,' she'd said. 'No one knows me. Everyone's out look ing for the hot new face. Besides, I've never bothered to cultivate a scene around me.'

I walk back to her hotel, sweating in the stifling mid-morning heat. Sitting in the garden out back, kd lang is still dressed in her work shirt from the day before. 'Hey, how was your night?' she asks. 'Did you go out?' I tell her I went out for dinner with friends. She asks for the name of the restaurant. 'I'll make a point of going there,' she notes.

I watch her chewing her nails as I unpack my Dictaphone. It's a habit that draws people to her, this quiet, shy, recording artist who became the bane of the Nashville trustees.

'They just didn't know what to make of me,' says kd lang, giggling. 'Women are not expected to behave that way . We're supposed to be demure and silent until we are spoken to. Not that I was some radical feminist, I just didn't want to sing the rubbish that was coming out at that time.'

Still, she admits she would like to return to her country roots one day. 'Yeah, it might be good fun. I think it would be good to go back and maybe do an album of standards, or something.' She laughs: 'We could get together, all the new country musicians, and record an album asking for forgiveness.'

She still looks nervous, anticipating every question. Some of the old country idioms have yet to iron themselves out of her character, I reason. Most country performers are always embarrassingly insecure in their hospitality. Like Berry Gordy's finishing school at Motown, Nashville drums into its performers a sense of decorum and taste. Then, as in the case of kd lang, it flinches with rage when the stars try their hand at individuality.

kd lang is painfully polite, occasionally stopping to ask if I need anything. 'Are you sure you wouldn't like some more coffee?' she asks. 'What about something to eat? Did you get breakfast all right?'

We start to talk about her voice in the early years - how she would occasionally break down in tears during the middle of a performance. 'It was incredibly moving to hear this voice coming from inside me,' she says. 'And especially up there, when I'm on stage. You get to see just how it feeds off all the emotions in the room. Sometimes it's just overwhelming.

'I get all kinds of letters. Fans tell me that my voice is like some kind of gift from God. And I've never been ambivalent about it. When 'Constant Craving' came out, it was a huge hit. One of these songs that seemed to change people's lives, touch something inside them. Then especially, I knew what it was like to feel gifted.' She gives me a scolding look: 'So keep that cigarette away!'

She fidgets with her lapel. Seated at the next table, friends from her record company idly chatter about the weather. As always, kd lang looks slightly self-conscious, dislocated from the scene at the Chateau Marmont. Earlier, she had described herself as a 'small town girl' who came to find refuge in the big city. It's a consistent theme in her work; her women are almost always slowly strangled by their own emotions.

As the time comes to end the interview, kd lang smiles convincingly and gives me another palmy, full-fingered handshake. And then she retreats. As I leave the garden, she looks up momentarily and grins again. 'Have a great stay here,' she says. 'Have a great time.'

Later that evening, I return to the record store and buy some more of her records. That night, with her voice still nagging comfortably through my hotel room, I'll dream again of the Pacific Coastal Highway.

 Invincible Summer is released on 3 July

'I bought a house a couple of years ago,' she says, sipping weak coffee from her mug. 'And I hang out there with my friends. Don't get back to Canada as often as I used to, either.' Her new album, Invincible Summer, has been almost two years in the recording. 'I wanted a warm sound for this,' she says. 'Even though I'm making pop music now, I still have all those country-and-western leanings. So I look at each individual album as a collection that says something different from last time. It's the way Patsy Cline recorded, and how I was in Nashville. I want a body of work not just albums. There has to be a theme, some kind of evolution.' The singer gets called back to the set, so I trudge back down the PCH to the house. I can hear her singing somewhere in a room above. Half an hour later, back in the trailer, she grasps another mug of coffee. Her coming-out in 1992, I venture: was it orches trated? 'Absolutely not,' she says, blushing. 'God, if it was then that must have been the most clumsy thing ever! The rumours had plagued me for years, everyone talked about it. Critics would often ask me questions about my personal life. Was there a boyfriend? I'd smile, and turn the conversation around. Sure, there is someone, I'd say. Or, I'm not that interested in a relationship at the moment. 'It was incredibly difficult to conduct interviews for a while, so we went to Rolling Stone and told them,' she continues. 'But I certainly didn't expect the kind of reaction that it got. My fans were horrified. And I didn't get it. I'd always thought country music was about tough choice and heartbreak. But you come up against some really old-fashioned bigotry. Well, look at us now. Steve Earle makes all kinds of music, Lyle Lovett has become an underground hero. And I make pop music. After a while, I just couldn't take the endless criticism any more.' She sighs as she receives another call from the director. I follow her back to the set; it's fast approaching six in the evening. The crew hunkers down for a final take, and with the video declared finished, starts to pack the lighting equipment into vans adjacent to the highway. Driving back down the PCH, later that night, I run through LA's radio stations searching for an appropriate tune. I settle on 'Constant Craving', arriving back in LA soothed by kd lang's soaring vocals. It's too hot the next morning when I climb up Sunset Boulevard towards the Chateau Marmont where kd lang has a room. Reaching the hotel early, I backtrack to the Virgin record store a couple of blocks away and start skimming through her back catalogue. On her early album sleeves, she looks heavily posed, visibly uncomfortable in the pictures. Yesterday, she'd revealed why she's moved to Los Angeles. 'It's quiet here,' she'd said. 'No one knows me. Everyone's out look ing for the hot new face. Besides, I've never bothered to cultivate a scene around me.' I walk back to her hotel, sweating in the stifling mid-morning heat. Sitting in the garden out back, kd lang is still dressed in her work shirt from the day before. 'Hey, how was your night?' she asks. 'Did you go out?' I tell her I went out for dinner with friends. She asks for the name of the restaurant. 'I'll make a point of going there,' she notes. I watch her chewing her nails as I unpack my Dictaphone. It's a habit that draws people to her, this quiet, shy, recording artist who became the bane of the Nashville trustees. 'They just didn't know what to make of me,' says kd lang, giggling. 'Women are not expected to behave that way . We're supposed to be demure and silent until we are spoken to. Not that I was some radical feminist, I just didn't want to sing the rubbish that was coming out at that time.' Still, she admits she would like to return to her country roots one day. 'Yeah, it might be good fun. I think it would be good to go back and maybe do an album of standards, or something.' She laughs: 'We could get together, all the new country musicians, and record an album asking for forgiveness.' She still looks nervous, anticipating every question. Some of the old country idioms have yet to iron themselves out of her character, I reason. Most country performers are always embarrassingly insecure in their hospitality. Like Berry Gordy's finishing school at Motown, Nashville drums into its performers a sense of decorum and taste. Then, as in the case of kd lang, it flinches with rage when the stars try their hand at individuality. kd lang is painfully polite, occasionally stopping to ask if I need anything. 'Are you sure you wouldn't like some more coffee?' she asks. 'What about something to eat? Did you get breakfast all right?' We start to talk about her voice in the early years - how she would occasionally break down in tears during the middle of a performance. 'It was incredibly moving to hear this voice coming from inside me,' she says. 'And especially up there, when I'm on stage. You get to see just how it feeds off all the emotions in the room. Sometimes it's just overwhelming. 'I get all kinds of letters. Fans tell me that my voice is like some kind of gift from God. And I've never been ambivalent about it. When 'Constant Craving' came out, it was a huge hit. One of these songs that seemed to change people's lives, touch something inside them. Then especially, I knew what it was like to feel gifted.' She gives me a scolding look: 'So keep that cigarette away!' She fidgets with her lapel. Seated at the next table, friends from her record company idly chatter about the weather. As always, kd lang looks slightly self-conscious, dislocated from the scene at the Chateau Marmont. Earlier, she had described herself as a 'small town girl' who came to find refuge in the big city. It's a consistent theme in her work; her women are almost always slowly strangled by their own emotions. As the time comes to end the interview, kd lang smiles convincingly and gives me another palmy, full-fingered handshake. And then she retreats. As I leave the garden, she looks up momentarily and grins again. 'Have a great stay here,' she says. 'Have a great time.' Later that evening, I return to the record store and buy some more of her records. That night, with her voice still nagging comfortably through my hotel room, I'll dream again of the Pacific Coastal Highway.  Invincible Summer is released on 3 July

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ...The Norman Foster Studio
fields.trailText: ...The Norman Foster Studio
fields.body:
A retrospective of architect Norman Foster's work begins on Tuesday. The Observer 's Deyan Sudjic describes curating the show.

The most intriguing part of this retrospective was working my way through the Norman Foster studio's archive. Strung out across east London, in a series of climate-conditioned fine art stores, Foster has salted away literally hundreds of models of all scales and sizes that provide a fascinating record of his work, going back to his earliest days as an independent architect more than 30 years ago. In a bleak Hackney shed, among a clutch of Barry Flanagan hares and a Damien Hirst just back from Brooklyn, I unearthed a giant representation of the dome of the Reichstag, big enough to stand up in, just like one of the great models of St Paul's made for Christopher Wren.

Foster's unbuilt scheme to relocate the BBC to the site of the Langham Hotel lingers on as a giant model broken up in sections and stacked up to the ceiling in flight cases. There are scores of studies for high-rises in Japan, Germany, Beirut, Australia and America; beautifully detailed designs for remodelling London's South Kensington, for building an airport in Shanghai and universities in Malaysia; and an original structural model for the Sainsbury Centre at the University of East Anglia, later discarded in favour of the even more beautiful version that was actually built.

There is even the model of the house that Foster designed with Buckminster Fuller, the maverick genius who invented the geodesic dome. There are rough-and-ready foam models made in the studio, as well as immaculately finished models intended to impress clients. There is one beautiful study of the Prado in Madrid.

The challenge was to use this remarkable wealth of raw material to create an exhibition which has as its theme not just a retrospective look at the practice's past, but also addresses current concerns. Foster is now interested in wider urban issues and there is a unique spread of work, from the exploding cities of the Pacific rim, to attempts to regenerate the hollowing out doughnuts of Europe's post-industrial cities. No one has more experience of working with the reality of the contemporary city.

 The Norman Foster Studio - Exploring the City, from 27 June, Sainsbury Centre for Visual Arts, University of East Anglia, Norwich (01603 456060)

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ...Euro 2000 football team
fields.trailText: ...Euro 2000 football team
fields.body:
(3-5-2)

Manager Dino Zoff (Italy)

Goal Barthez: well worth the money Manchester United have paid for him.

Back three Blanc: he's got pace, can read the game and the Radio Five Live female presenters say he's got nice legs. Also he missed out on playing in the the World Cup final because he'd been unfairly booked. Djukic: an intimidating presence, a bit mean. Cannavaro: the Italian team are totally solid on defence, so you just have to have an Italian in there.

Midfield Thuram: he's fast and one of the few French players in the squad who doesn't play in England. Maldini: getting on a bit, but experience is often more important than youth at this level. Beckham: without him, the English side wouldn't score any goals. The fans are quite warming to him; chanting now includes 'There's only one David Beckham.' Zidane: he may have played pretty poorly in Italy, but when it comes to the big tournaments he does the business. Zahovic: a gifted midfielder; Slovenia against Yugoslavia was one of the most exciting games of Euro 2000.

Upfront Although everyone would expect me to choose Henry (France), I'm going for Hakan Sukur: he scored two goals against Belgium, tore the defence apart and will surely leave Galatasaray for mega money and an Italian club soon. Shearer: I'll bung him in because he never fails to deliver when you need it. Corny but true. Anyway, Garth Crooks told me he couldn't have scored that goal against Germany.

webTitle: Fast forward: the loafer's guide to popular culture

fields.headline: Fast forward: the loafer's guide to popular culture
fields.standfirst: This week: Absolut Mandrin
fields.trailText: This week: Absolut Mandrin
fields.body:
A new Chinese dictator? Nope. It's the latest flavour from the Swedish vodka importers, now on sale in the UK alongside their pure, pepper, lemon and blackcurrant versions. Its delicate orange flavour should make it a staple in hip freezers over the summer, if the temperature continues to rise.

Does it make good cocktails? In every cool bar in town, dahling. This one's by Jason at Zeta Bar (35 Hertford Street, London W1; 020 7208 4067): shake together 50ml Absolut Mandrin, 100ml carrot juice, 10ml Monin Ginger Syrup. Pour into cocktail glass, top with ginger ale, garnish with carrot wedge.

How did Absolut become the leading vodka brand? Absolut Rent Bränvin (Absolut Pure Vodka) was first sold in Sweden by one Lars Olsson Smith in 1879. A century later, the product was repackaged in a clear bottle modelled on Swedish medicine bottles and imported to the US as a premium brand. Lars still appears on the bottle's medallion, emphasising the history, but the marketing is unmistakably modern: almost every ad features the shape of the bottle and a short slogan starting with the word 'Absolut'. In 1985, Andy Warhol was commissioned to paint a bottle for an ad that was so successful that more than 400 collaborations with artists have followed: everyone from Haring to Hirst.

How about its profile in Britain? One of Absolut's strengths as a global brand has been its ability to adapt to local trends. In this country, selling has centred on the designer bar boom, with the right establishments offered beautiful display cases for their own flavours of Absolut vodka. At its height, this trend saw bars selling frozen shots flavoured with fruit, chocolate bars (white Toblerone was the Loafer's favourite), even pear drops.

A success story to rival Abba, then? Absolutely.

fields.headline: Holding back the years
fields.standfirst: The way we live now: Miffy mania
fields.trailText: The way we live now: Miffy mania.
fields.body:
When I was young, it was simple. Little girls wore little skirts and tops. We had brightly coloured clips in our hair and carried sweet little bags in which might rest a Mr Man book and/or a plastic beaker full of squash. We knew, however, that when we grew up, we would put away such childish things. Confine them to the dressing-up box. In return, we all eagerly anticipated an adulthood of flesh-coloured tights, wedge-cut hair and handbags.

Then, about five years ago, these simple rules changed. After the traditional teenage flirtation with push-up bras, spots and clunky shoes, twenty- and thirtysomething women found themselves reclaiming the kindergarten. Bye-bye shoulderpads and trouser suits. Suddenly, accessories and clothes for five-year-olds were in vogue.

It started with 'actress/ model' Sadie Frost and her intensely irritating sparkly hairclips. Wearing them as an adornment on dead-straight hair, and in partnership with an oddly serious facial expression, Frost emanated a perfect double whammy of youth + intelligence. Forget Liz Hurley, described in That Dress by the Evening Standard as 'over-ripe'. Hurley, and others who dressed to suit their age, looked positively matronly compared to La Frost, who dressed to suit her shoe size.

Which brings us to Paula Yates. Faced with the Frost Hairclips, the nation's favourite scapegoat went one better by sporting a girlie-sized Little Miss Naughty top on national television. This really started something. Suddenly, women everywhere - mothers, even! - were throwing on Little Miss tops and grabbing Hello Kitty bags. It was as if we had all developed age amnesia. Everyone was grooving, hairclips a go-go, to Teletubby music with toddler T-shirts as dancewear.

The latest children's icon to receive this adult-cult treatment is that little white rabbit called Miffy. Miffy, for the uninitiated, is the charming offspring of the Dutch illustrator Dick Bruna, who invented her 45 years ago this month. Shortly to star in her 100th book, she is dearly loved by children across the globe. The first 40-odd years of Miffy's life passed in a way that might be expected - parents bought the books, children loved them, scribbled all over them and then forgot about them, as children do. But now these children have grown up and rediscovered Miffy. And not for their own offspring, but for themselves. Miffy is particularly huge in Japan, where this year vast beds of tulips have been grown in her form and fans are prepared to cross the world on pilgrimage to stand outside Bruna's front door in Utrecht.

Here in Britain, the Frost/Yates brigade is equally Miffy mad. Miffy clothes are doing a brisk trade at Top Shop, where spaghetti-strap tops in lime and lilac and hooded jackets in navy and orange are sweeping out of stores, tucked under the business-like elbows of 30-year-olds; in Soho there's nothing quite so stylish as wearing a Miffy T-shirt. You might even go to a board meeting brandishing a mobile phone in a new Miffy carrying case.

Not surprisingly, Bruna, now 72, is said to be delighted by this worldwide craze. He has established boundaries, though. He doesn't want his other characters, Snuffy, Boris Bear and Poppy Pig, to be used for mass-merchandising purposes - the books they appear in are apparently for children alone. There are also rules about the ways the Miffy image can be used. There is no chance of Miffy underwear, for example. Unlike the creations of authors such as AA Milne, whose Pooh books are stuffed with grown-up jokes and witty asides, Miffy's world is strictly a child's world.

Marketing expert Alison Vellacott admits that she is mystified by it all. 'It is unusual for something to take off in this way without there being a television product alongside it,' she says. 'I think people just remember Miffy from childhood. Women love the minimalist style and groovy colours. Or perhaps they are buying into the simple, innocent image of childhood.'

Tim Spratt, manager of London lifestyle shop Brats, is accustomed to women coming in and asking for red-and-blue plastic Miffy bucket bags. 'This sort of children's gear is now chic for adults,' he explains. And sales of more traditional baggage by, say, Louis Vuitton or Mulberry are apparently suffering. According to Spratt, that sort of stuff is very last century. 'When I started out 10 years ago, we sold Mulberry all the time,' he says. 'Nowadays it goes more slowly. People just don't want to spend £78 on a purse. Not when you can spend £15 on something fun and lively. Something which says you're still young at heart.'

But, one has to ask, as with the Tweenie clock, when will it stop? Spratt is unsure. 'I bought some Miffy shampoo for a friend the other day. He is 68 years old. He adored it; I knew he would. He just loves the drawings.'

Yet this is a craze that goes beyond irony, or even art appreciation (despite the fact that Miffy limited-edition prints are doing a brisk trade this season in Harrods). Although the Miffy gear comes built for adults, Vellacott admits that you have to be pretty flat-chested to get away with one of the tops. Dress like a child, become a child. Or perhaps the Miffy option is just cheaper than plastic surgery. Why get all those wrinkles smoothed out with collagen? It's far easier to simply go on a bit of a diet, don a Miffy top, add a couple of hairclips, and watch the years drop away. Rosie Millard

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ...making a movie
fields.trailText: ...making a movie.
fields.body:
It is a modern myth that we all have a creative spark inside us, but if you have a burning desire to be the next Scorsese, you have picked an expensive medium. Let's say that your goal is a cinema release, on the tightest realistic budget. It is considered impossible to make a feature for less than half a million. Budget for about £1m and don't be misled by marketing hype - yes, Robert Rodriguez made El Mariachi for $7,000 but Columbia spent a further $1m on it.

A script is a good starting point, but the producer is your project's lynchpin, arranging contracts, equipment and locations. Everything is negotiable, including your crew's wages. One option is to defer most of their pay until the film has made a profit. They might go for this if they are desperate, but bear in mind that you won't see much of the box-office profits anyway: about 50 per cent goes to the exhibitor and 30 per cent of the remainder to the distributor. The producer gets the rest, but pays off investors before staff. Or pay your crew according to union rates. Expect to spend £516 per 50-hour week for a scaffolder; £682 for a make-up artist; £728 for a casting director; £784 for an art director, lighting director or sound recordist.

Equipment is usually hired. The most basic set-up might include a camera (£2,250 per week), zoom lens (£900), prime lenses (£800), video playback and colour video assist (£1,500), a head and legs for the camera (£450), not to mention dollies, tracks, lights, insurance and, naturally, actors. They will cost from £360 per week, while stuntmen earn £378 per day.

35mm film stock is another expense. Directors of low-budget films typically shoot 10 times more film than is finally used (blockbusters work on a ratio of 20:1). Film is measured in feet and a 90-minute feature is 8,800ft long, so buy 88,000ft of film (£160 per 400ft roll). To put this in perspective, Michael Cimino shot 1.5 million feet of Heaven's Gate .

Processing the film is another £40,000, and then there are the costs of marketing it to distributors at film festivals. Editing costs are variable, but very expensive if you use a digital camera since cinemas have not made similar advances. In fact, have you thought about writing poetry instead? Robin Barton

Actors £360 each per week

Stunt performers £1,512 each per week

Equipment £30,000 per week

Film stock £32,500

Processing £40,000

Total more than your budget

Expect to spend £516 per 50-hour week for a scaffolder; £682 for a make-up artist; £728 for a casting director; £784 for an art director, lighting director or sound recordist. Equipment is usually hired. The most basic set-up might include a camera (£2,250 per week), zoom lens (£900), prime lenses (£800), video playback and colour video assist (£1,500), a head and legs for the camera (£450), not to mention dollies, tracks, lights, insurance and, naturally, actors. They will cost from £360 per week, while stuntmen earn £378 per day. 35mm film stock is another expense. Directors of low-budget films typically shoot 10 times more film than is finally used (blockbusters work on a ratio of 20:1). Film is measured in feet and a 90-minute feature is 8,800ft long, so buy 88,000ft of film (£160 per 400ft roll). To put this in perspective, Michael Cimino shot 1.5 million feet of Heaven's Gate . Processing the film is another £40,000, and then there are the costs of marketing it to distributors at film festivals. Editing costs are variable, but very expensive if you use a digital camera since cinemas have not made similar advances. In fact, have you thought about writing poetry instead? Robin Barton Crew £50,000 per week Actors £360 each per week Stunt performers £1,512 each per week Equipment £30,000 per week Film stock £32,500 Processing £40,000 Total more than your budget

fields.headline: On the right track
fields.trailText: Can you believe it? One minute I'm at the local clinic having our six-year-old tested for glue ear and selective hearing, the next minute I've accumulated enough childcare points to go off with our old neighbour Tim for an exciting Saturday night out at the dog track.
fields.body:
Can you believe it? One minute I'm at the local clinic having our six-year-old tested for glue ear and selective hearing (place child in front of TV and enquire at eight different volumes whether he knows how long past his bedtime it is), the next minute I've accumulated enough childcare points to go off with our old neighbour Tim for an exciting Saturday night out at the dog track, which is not to be sniffed at, though no doubt some of the competitors would disagree if their unaccountable habitual interest in treating their noses to an informal tour of each other's rectal environments is anything to go by.

The stadium has a beautifully striking neon-lit Art Deco frontage, so in a way it's quite nice that we get to pass it three times while we try to find a car park where they don't insist on us having brought our own dog ('Are you an owner, sir?' 'Am I an owner of what?'), and soon we are shuffling through the turnstiles with all the other nicotine-tanned punters with sovereign rings, cauliflower ears and stunted growth who have missed the first race because they were late back from having their scrotums pierced. Still, plenty of time to ask the poker-faced woman who looks as if she'd rather be eating her own toenails if we can put a pound on numbers three and five before they set off again. Neither of us knows the first thing about losing money by guesswork, so we get quite exhilarated when Tim's dog falls over its own feet the minute he leaves his cage but then brilliantly has the presence of mind to catch up with his chums by taking a short cut across the middle to the halfway point, where the rest of them are already gleefully tearing the clockwork rabbit to pieces. But hang on a minute - aren't they supposed to let the rabbit win?

Apparently so. Tim gets his money back for reasons of irregularity and we start again. OK, look, I say, there are only six runners, so how hard can it be to have a grand evening out and make ourselves millionaires in the process? Of course we don't know the difference between betting on whatever the so-called Tote is or putting our shirts on those blokes in trilbys who stand in front of blackboards flapping their arms at each other like deaf people having an argument, but it's to do with starting prices and odds and is therefore no more fathomable to the normal human mind than the giant electronic board which, in its attempts to explain why one dog is more likely to make us rich than the next, has all the scrutability of a Chinese bus timetable.

We place another bet and someone driving a tractor comes to smooth the sand down, followed by a person wearing a bowler hat he has found in a skip on the way to work and whose job it is to parade the dogs with a view to letting us see how confidently they can take a crap in public. Even at this stage, I notice that mine is facing in a different direction to all the others. Tim, meanwhile, is squinting critically across the arena trying to work out the length of the track using a complicated series of estimates based on the square of the angle of the hypotenuse multiplied by how long he thinks his car probably is.

It's all very educative. The races are over in the time it takes to grimace, because greyhounds are pretty fast, though they do seem to get bored at the final stretch, possibly suddenly realising that the rabbit is wearing a fluorescent orange railwayman's jacket. What they need is a little jockey to keep them whipped into that frenzy of pointless, unquestioning pursuit that makes great racehorses look as if they know what they're doing. My dog comes fifth, just ahead of the one with three legs.

We decide to lose our money from the grandstand, the better to take in the atmosphere and drink Guinness. This place is full of interest. I don't think I've ever seen someone carry two pints in one hand before and it's good to see they have a playground at the far side in case you have to bring the children at the last minute. Tim volunteers to go for the grub while I do the betting, but four races go by while he's still in the queue, which is so long you could lose a week's pocket money just waiting for it to dawn on whoever runs the kitchen how popular chips are.

My dog comes in fifth for the third time running. I wonder if you can get odds on that?

fields.headline: Hearts and bones
fields.standfirst: They help guard against heart disease, ease painful joints and improve your skin, no wonder fish oils are essential
fields.trailText: They help guard against heart disease, ease painful joints and improve your skin, no wonder fish oils are essential.
fields.body:
I realise I'm in danger of coming across as evangelical about oily fish, such as mackerel, salmon, tuna, sardines, pilchards, trout and herrings, but they have so many positive nutritional qualities that it's hard to know where to start. Their benefits to health are primarily due to their fish-oil content, specifically omega 3 and 6 fatty acids, which encourages the liver to produce high-density lipoprotein (HDL), or 'good' cholesterol, which works to remove low-density lipoprotein (LDL), 'bad' cholesterol, from the body by transporting it to the intestine, from which it is excreted. Because LDL is deposited in the blood vessels and can cause heart attacks, angina or strokes by obstructing them, boosting your intake of HDL can reduce the risk of developing heart disease.

Another benefit of oily fish is that it can dramatically reduce the inflammation and pain associated with rheumatoid arthritis, although many of my patients who have osteo- and psoriatic arthritis report that they feel a lot better once they start eating plenty of oily fish. Although some people believe that taking cod-liver oil helps to reduce the symptoms of arthritis, the body absorbs omega 3 and 6 fatty acids more efficiently from oily fish.

A similar symptomatic relief can be seen in individuals who are plagued by psoriasis, a common, chronic skin disorder. Psoriasis usually manifests itself first in dry, red patches on the elbows, scalp, legs and knees that then become covered with white scales. Although there isn't a cure for this condition, dietary adjustments - and especially boosting intakes of omega fatty acids - can calm the skin down. This is because these acids alter the body's biochemistry, particularly the inflammatory reaction that is thought to bring on psoriasis. People with other skin complaints, such as eczema or acne, may also find that eating plenty of oily fish improves their complexions.

Omega fatty acids may furthermore bring relief to women who suffer from severe womb, period or pre-menstrual breast pain. It appears that the oils enable the body to produce natural painkilling substances, as well as anti-inflammatory agents. I have observed that women who have painful periods tend to experience the greatest relief if they eat oily fish every other day during the week leading up to menstruation and some every day during their periods.

Omega 3 fatty acids are vital for the healthy development of the brain and central nervous system in foetuses, while the mother-to-be's consumption of oily fish during pregnancy has been found to have a slightly beneficial effect on both length of gestation and birth weight. Other interesting research carried out by the Institute of Respiratory Medicine at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney, Australia, suggests that there is a correlation between the consumption of oily fish and the reduction of children's risk of developing asthma. New studies are also beginning to make a connection between a deficiency in omega 3 fatty acid and depression and mental illness.

If all of this wasn't enough, oily fish is also rich in vitamin A (also known as retinol), which is essential for growth, healthy skin and hair, good vision and strong tooth enamel, adding further compelling evidence to the argument that pregnant women should include plenty of oily fish in their diets. (Women who have been taking a fish-oil supplement like cod-liver oil should stop when they become pregnant, however, as its vitamin A concentration is too high; the level in oily fish is much lower and hence safer.)

In addition, oily fish gives the body a good dose of vitamin D, which works in conjunction with calcium to build healthy bones and teeth. We normally synthesise the majority of the vitamin D in our bodies by exposing our skins to the sun, but because Britain doesn't see much sun from October to March we should instead rely on dietary sources of vitamin D - including oily fish - to replenish our reserves of this nutrient during the winter. People who spend a lot of time indoors, as well as older or sick people and smokers, have an increased requirement for vitamin D and should therefore ensure that they include sources of this nutrient in their diet. Remember, too, that oily fish (especially such small-boned fish as pilchards and sardines) can provide a valuable source of calcium and iron.

However, omega oils can only work effectively if they are able to bridge the gap between the bloodstream and the brain. Because saturated fatty acids (which are contained in animal fats, such as butter, cream and cheese) compete with the unsaturated omegas for access to the brain, you should keep your intake of saturated animal fats low. By using olive oil rather than butter when cooking, not combining cheese with fish dishes and spreading only a little butter on your toast or bread when preparing a tuna sandwich, you'll be assisting the fish oils to carry out their healing processes.

Although concerns have been raised about the levels of dioxin that they contain, it appears that the benefits of eating oily fish far outweigh the potentially slight risk to health of consuming small amounts of this pollutant. One of the most useful aspects of the oily fish scenario is that tinned fish can be just as beneficial as the fresh varieties, which can sometimes be hard to buy or unappetising to cook. Whatever source you prefer, aim to eat two to three servings of oily fish a week.

All in all, oily fish is both impressively versatile and provides a plethora of health benefits. Not only should you eat it, but I advise that you introduce your children to it as soon as you can, giving them small amounts at a time and perhaps disguising its taste in mayonnaise or a pasta sauce. If you do so, you'll be building up their bodies to lead a healthy life.

fields.headline: Art
fields.trailText: Barbican | Sculpture at Goodwood | Barbara Hepworth Sculpture Garden | Henry Moore | The Millennium Dome
fields.body:
Barbican Just time to catch Andy Goldsworthy's Snowballs in Summer - 14 giant snowballs gradually melting from Midsummer's Day, leaving behind the materials Goldsworthy has packed into the snow - chalk, Highland cow hair, pebbles, berries, metal, wheat and wire. Snowballs dotted around Barbican and Moorgate tube stations. Or watch the snowballs melt via live webcams on www.eyestorm.com

Sculpture at Goodwood Gracious park next to the racecourse, featuring work by Bill Woodrow, Cathy de Monchaux and William Furlong. Hat Hill Copse, near Chichester, West Sussex. Details (01243) 538449

Barbara Hepworth Sculpture Garden at St Ives - fountains, greenery, the sea air of Cornwall, the Tate and a colony of late abstract sculptures. Details (01736) 796226

Henry Moore at Bretton Country Park, near Wakefield, West Yorkshire. Twelve monumental bronze figures stare out across the moors, sheep grazing at their feet. Details (01924) 830579, and next door_ Yorkshire Sculpture Park Two hundred acres of eighteenth-century landscape, with works from Rodin to contemporary neon sculptures. Details (01924) 830579; www.ysp.co.uk

The Millennium Dome Leave the big tent and find the art outdoors: Anthony Gormley's Millennium Man, Anish Kapoor's parabolic whirlpool, Ton Cragg's gyrating chessmen, Richard Wilson's slice of a ship moored on the Thames.

fields.headline: Classical
fields.trailText: Cheltenham Festival | Ilford Opera | Glyndebourne Festival Opera | Henley Festival | Warwick and Leamington Festival | York Early Music Festival | Fishguard International Music Festival
fields.body:
Cheltenham Festival 30 June to 16 July

Dally over coffee in and around the Pitville Pump Room and park for a morning concert, or bring a picnic for the fireworks on 1 July. Venues further afield include Tewkesbury Abbey (Tallis Scholars, 4 July). World première of Drawn from the Water ( puppet theatre and gamelan piece) at Sandford Parks Lido (6 July). Bring cushions and blankets.
Details (01242) 227979

Ilford Opera 28 June to 29 July

Acis and Galatea, Tosca and La Cenerentola performed in the seated, covered cloister of Ilford Manor, five miles south of Bath, which has famously beautiful gardens designed a century ago by Harold Peto. Take a picnic and eat al fresco or in the tea room. Sartorial code: 'Dress for warmth'.
Details (01225) 868124

Glyndebourne Festival Opera to 27 August

For gardens and Sussex Downs landscape, it's still hard to beat the most famous of all country house operas - not to mention Michael Hopkins's still new theatre and the incomparable musical standards. It may be sold out, but there are always last-minute returns and standing-room tickets sold on the day.
Details (01273) 812321; box office (01273) 813813; www.glyndebourne.com

Henley Festival Oxfordshire, 5 to 9 July

Lesley Garrett, José Carreras and Jacques Loussier appear on a floating stage for this riverside festival.
Box office (01491) 843404; www.henley-festival.co.uk

Warwick and Leamington Festival 1-11 July

Massed choirs sing from the walls of Warwick Castle (8 July) with a world première by Howard Skempton and works by Handel, Brahms and Parry. Excellent chamber concerts on offer in the Royal Pump Rooms.
Box office (01926) 496277

York Early Music Festival

7 to 16 July Held in a various churches around the city (and the Minster) rather than outdoors, but unmissable for early music enthusiasts, especially with the opening of the National Centre for Early Music in the converted St Margaret's Church, Walmgate. This year's themes are Bach's chamber music and music for the York Millennium Mystery Plays.
Details (01904) 658338; box office (01904) 632220

Fishguard International Music Festival

Pembrokeshire, 21 to 29 July Delightful, first-rate international music festival in this Welsh fishing village, with concerts, recitals and jazz by artists including the Tallis Scholars, Skampa Quartet and BBC National Orchestra of Wales. Details (01348) 873612

Plus, six of the best of Musical Firework shows around the country (01625) 560000: Close Encounters of the Classical Kind Blenheim Palace, Woodstock (25 August); Last Night of the Proms Burghley House, Stamford, Lincolnshire (29 July); Fireworks and Laser Spectacular Castle Howard, York (23 July); Music from the Movies Shugborough Hall, Staffs (22 July); Fireworks and Laser Spectacular Eastnor Castle, Ledbury (16 July); Voyage 2000: A Classical Journey (various dates). For details of events at English Heritage properties, call (020) 7420 0220.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText:
What a performance
Summer is hot and the PDII is soaring - this being, of course, the famous Paul Dacre Indignation Index, whereby the editor of the Daily Mail becomes more and more exercised about the country's collective moral turpitude to a point where he is in danger of exploding. Bearing the full brunt of his crusade for moral conservatism have been the demons of depravity at Channel 5 - or Channel Filth as Mr Dacre would have it. However, there is a shaming secret in the closet of this squeaky clean Mary Whitehouse-in-a-wool suit. That is Associated Newspapers' own shameful televisual product The Performance Channel.

The 'performance' part of its name, you might imagine, relates directly to Nic Roeg and Donald Cammell's Seventies cult film starring Mick Jagger in a depraved sex and drugs masterpiece. Furthermore, for those of you unacquainted with the output of this so-called 'arts' channel, it peddles a regular diet of sexual infidelity, extreme violence and near-nudity masquerading as respectable 'opera' which frankly makes Channel 5's nude Keith Chegwin outrage look like a peccadillo of the mildest form. Fortunately, The Performance Channel's output is restricted to a 'specialist' audience of cable subscribers, so Mr Dacre's middle England readership is largely spared its smutty output.

Hey, I thought of that first
Twelve years ago Charlie Parsons, that visitor from Planet 24, had an idea... what about a programme that maroons members of the public on a desert island to eke out an existence? And how about a competitive element - each week they could vote out the person they liked the least?

If it sounds a bit tired now, that's because Parsons has had to watch while Endemol succeeded in Europe with Big Brother , and Castaway and its rival Shipwrecked both won endless industry attention over here.

Parsons and his team offered the show to all the big names. Michael Jackson, Alan Yentob, Tim Gardam, Peter Salmon and Kevin Lygo but, alas for Parsons, Survivor perished as a UK scheduling idea. After only two weeks on air, the show has even beaten the US version of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? Survivor averaged 18.1 million viewers a week ago while that other British idea, Millionaire, won 15.5 million. Says Parsons: 'I am not so bothered about being turned down in Britain - after all, we all make mistakes, and pass on the occasional hit - but to see so many similar formats appearing afterwards was galling.

fields.headline: Pop
fields.trailText: T in the Park | Essential Festival | Womad | Cambridge Folk Festival | The Big Chill: Enchanted Garden 2000 | Reading & Leeds
fields.body:
T in the Park Balado Airfield, near Kinross, 8 & 9 July Scotland's answer to Glastonbury, with strong alcohol revered in place of heathen spirits. Unusual big-name line-up (All Saints, Moby, Iggy Pop, Macy Gray) slightly marred by blandness of the headliners, Ocean Colour Scene and Travis. Tickets £58 (weekend); £34 (one day). Call: (0141) 339 8383; www.tinthepark.co.uk

Essential Festival Stanmer Park, near Brighton, 15/16 July. Two distinct days, both funky. Saturday is an electronic dance festival headlined inevitably by local DJ deity Fatboy Slim. Sunday is more intriguing, featuring the multifarious talents of Talvin Singh, Flavor Flav, Beenie Man, Angie Stone and the legendary James Brown. Close to the seaside too. Tickets £50 (weekend); £30 (one day). Call (0990) 344 4444; www.essentialfestival.co.uk

Womad Rivermead, Reading, 20 to 23 July. Said by aficionados to be the friendliest and most fun of all the festivals, the World of Music and Dance festival is steadily shedding its reputation as an earnest, middle-class bongo session, and is now the most eclectic of all. Khaled, Youssou N'Dour and Suzanne Vega headline, and there's a creche too. Tickets £69 (weekend); £18 (Fri); £32 (Sat or Sun); two under-13s free with each adult Call (0118) 939 0930; www. womad.org

Cambridge Folk Festival Cherry Hinton Hall, 27-30 July Bring your tankard along for one of the best line-ups in years, featuring Joan Baez, Billy Bragg, Eliza Carthy, Dick Gaughan, Ani DiFranco, Kate Rusby, Dr John, Kathryn Williams, De Danaan and Juan De Marcos's Afro-Cuban All Stars. Tickets £50 (weekend); £39 (conc); £18 (Fri); £28 (Sat); £28 (Sun); children under five free; ages 5-13 £10. Box office (01223) 357851; www.cam-folkfest.co.uk

The Big Chill: Enchanted Garden 2000 Larmer Tree Victorian Pleasure Gardens, Salisbury, Wiltshire, 4-6 August. Trancey, vibey kinda festival for people who've had enough of dehydrating on dodgy white powder in pricey, overpopulated clubs and prefer to roll a spliff and listen to the likes of Nitin Sawhney, DJ Lovegrove and Biosphere in a rural idyll. Civilised, man. Tickets £60 (adults); £18 (children) www.bigchill.co.uk

Reading & Leeds Rivermead, Reading, 25-27 August; Temple Newsam Park, Leeds, 26-28 August Sponsored by a brewery and soullessly awful in almost every respect (Stereophonics and Oasis are among the headliners) but worth going on Saturday for those in the South, or Sunday for those in the North: this is the day that Pulp and Beck are co-headliners - just imagine the postmodern nylon goofball sparks flying as Jarvis and Beck dance together! Tickets £80 (weekend); £33 (one day) Call (08701) 500 044; www.readingfestival.com www.leedsfestival.com

webTitle: P&O's cruise demerger sails into choppy waters

fields.headline: P&O's cruise demerger sails into choppy waters
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
When P&O announced its long-awaited plan to demerge its cruising business in February, it pointed to the superior valuation of Carnival, its US cruising rival, to justify the move.

Last week, Carnival warned that it is having to offer discounts in order to fill ships, which means its earnings for 2000 will be only 'slightly higher' than last year's. Surprise, surprise, P&O is now stressing the differences between its cruise operation and Carnival's, rather than claiming they should be similarly valued.

There is some justification for this. Its ships are newer than Carnival's, so it can justify higher rates. It is less exposed to the fiercely competitive Caribbean market than the US operator. And forward bookings are good, albeit lower than the millennium-boosted levels seen at the end of 1999.

But Carnival's profits warning is also a sign of how fast the market can change. As recently as April, it was predicting earnings growth for this year as high as 10 per cent. The City fears that P&O's optimism will also soon prove misplaced.

Carnival's warning vindicates those who predicted that cruising profits would be undermined by the number of new ships being launched almost monthly. P&O's insistence that it is just meeting growing demand is supported by past results, where a 50 per cent increase in capacity of its flagship Princess fleet has produced a 64 per cent increase in operating profits.

But the City is worried that supply and demand could now tip the wrong way. The cruising market does look healthy; the number of people going on cruises has been rising at 7.9 per cent a year in the US and even faster in the rest of the world. Given an ageing - and increasingly wealthy - population, and the fact that cruising still represents less than 2 per cent of the holiday market, predictions that it will continue to grow at that rate look reasonable.

But, sooner or later, the sharp rise in the number of ships will catch up with the growth in demand for a holiday on the sea. The City fears that time is fast-approaching - which, given that the industry will add another 35 per cent to capacity by 2003, is not comforting news. The City is already factoring a deceleration in growth into P&O's forecasts. Deutsche Bank, for example, predicts flat operating profits for the cruise division, despite a 23 per cent rise in capacity.

Whether that is too pessimistic will not be clear for another six months or so. What is certain is that, unless Carnival stages a sharp turnaround, the valuation of P&O Princess - as the cruising business will be known - when it floats in October will be far less now than it would have been three months ago. P&O may be in better shape than Carnival, and may command a premium rating, but that is likely to put P&O on perhaps 20 times earnings, not the 50 times Carnival once commanded.

The 10 per cent fall in its shares last week, which has left them at little over half their value at the beginning of the year, discounts too much bad news. The unkindly named 'P&O rump', including ferries and transport, will be attractive in its own right, albeit without the glamour of the cruising side. A valuation of 670p a share for the combined business is not unreasonable. Throg Street has long been a fan of the shares and, at their current level, they look cheap. But buyers should expect them to remain volatile at least until demerger.

Under offer
What should managers do when someone makes an offer for their company? The obvious answer is to inform shareholders and let them decide whether or not to accept. Shareholders are, after all, the owners of the business and they should get the chance to decide whether to accept the offer - particularly if it is at a 50 per cent premium to the share price.

But what if you think the offer, premium or no, undervalues the business? And what if the prospective bidder is an existing shareholder, and you suspect it is simply trying to flush out another buyer so that it can sell its stake for a tidy profit?

Christian Salvesen, the transport business, found itself in just that position when Swedish investment group Custos approached it with a 180p-a-share offer. It decided shareholders did not need to know about the bid and turned it down flat. Not surprisingly, Custos did not want to leave it there and duly announced its interest to the market. Salvesen's view that the offer was too low was vindicated by the shares, which leapt to 185p, and by analysts' predictions that the company could be worth as much as 250p a share.

But if Custos, which has been a shareholder only since August and whose purchase price was probably about 100p a share, wants to flush out a buyer, what about the other shareholders - many of whom will have been around a lot longer, and who could have paid up to 40 per cent more than Custos for their shares. And while Salvesen's management may think 180p is too low, the City appears not to agree. Shares have not touched that level for at least five years - indeed, they were less than half that a year ago.

In fact, Custos insists it is not simply courting a bid. It thinks that the logistics business is ripe for consolidation into a small number of pan-European companies. It believes Salvesen is well placed to take advantage of that. Or it would be if it had the financial firepower. Custos has backing from venture capitalist Doughty Hanson, which means it has up to £1 billion to spend. And it wants Salvesen's existing management to help it do so.

The interesting question for Salvesen's other shareholders is where do we go from here? The company has been top of everyone's list of bid targets since the one from British rival Hays failed three years ago, but predators have been thin on the ground. Perhaps they have been deterred by the 35 per cent shareholding still in the hands of the founding family - whose implacable opposition caused the failure of the Hays bid. Or perhaps they think that, if they wait long enough, they would win Salvesen's customers by default. Salvesen may claim that it has a £150 million war chest, but that would not be enough to take it decisively into Europe.

Recent escapes by Wickes and Blue Circle show that the City may not think old-economy companies worth much, but that does not mean it will sell to anyone cheap. If Custos is serious about acquiring, it will have to pay a bit more. But it will still leave Salvesen vulnerable to a trade buyer. Shareholders should sit tight and enjoy the ride.

fields.headline: Travellers in an online land
fields.standfirst: This is one sector that can make the most of e-commerce, writes  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: This is one sector that can make the most of e-commerce, writes Faisal Islam
fields.body:
Shoppers have already 'booed' off online clothes retailing, and the amazonian selling of books hardly represents a new age for business. After the hype, the reality of e-commerce has left consumers underwhelmed.

But the travel industry is one sector the internet fits snugly with. Buying travel products requires no wearing, holding, touching, tasting or feeling. It is weightless - based entirely on information and availability. And it is one sector that is forging ahead. Battle lines are being drawn for the anticipated 'shakeout' of smaller firms.

EasyJet, the budget airline, sold 72.1 per cent of its flights over the internet in the week to last Monday. In both the US and Europe, rival airlines have joined forces to launch consumer sites later this year. Meanwhile e-tailers such as Ebookers, Expedia and Lastminute compete with a multitude of smaller sites and the airlines' own websites.

Even after the recent market jitters about business-to-consumer (b2c) sites, e-travel remains a favoured area. Merrill Lynch predicts a $32 billion European market by 2004, and analysts at the Gartner Group predict a sixfold increase in revenues by the end of next year, to $30bn.

Online travel agencies are still receiving funding, which has dried up in other b2c sectors since April's market correction. The collapse of Lastminute.com's share price signalled the market's worries at that point. Now the structure of the sector is set for a consolidation. Ebookers, the London-based, Europewide company, is running out of cash, but conditions for raising fresh funds are far from rosy.

The market for e-travel is clearly strong, but investors are uncertain which horses to back. The key question is whether net-savvy consumers value the independent guidance of one-stop portals such as Expedia and lastminute. com, or whether are they going straight to the airline.

The answers may lie in a glut of research on consumer behaviour in the market over the Atlantic. The Travel Industry of America's report, Travelers' use of the Internet , makes for interesting reading. The number of people using the internet to book airline tickets or hotel accommodation jumped by 146 per cent to 16.5 million. About 35 million used the internet to research travel plans before using other methods to purchase tickets; some 52.2 million used the internet at some point for making plans.There are opportunities both in the sale of travel products and in the provision of information.

But here is the rub; just over half of buyers purchase directly from airline or accommodation sites. Independent portals account for 39 per cent.

By the end of the year, Orbitz - the US collaboration between airlines American, Delta, United, Northwest and Continental - and the unnamed European effort now being constructed by McKinsey, will be trading. The stock market panned Lastminute and Ebookers after these announcements. But the travel market is somewhat more complex than the brutal calculus of internet analysts will allow.

The airline collaborations will sell only 'published fares'. These are airline-branded tickets that are rarely sold at discount, but whose availability is published on central reservation systems. You can get on the same flight more cheaply by purchasing a 'negotiated' fare. Such bargains are branded not by the airline, but by a travel agent such as Ebookers. The agent can mix and match outward and return portions.

Airlines can thus discount their seats without affecting their valuable brands. Travel agents need to be 'bonded' in each country in which they wish to sell negotiated fares, and need to develop direct relationships with airlines.

The introduction of Orbitz and its European airline-owned equivalent should only affect sales of published fares. The rationale for having negotiated fares does not diminish. Most importantly, competition authorities will watch very carefully to see whether the airline-owned venture is treated any differently. The US Department of Justice is already investigating Orbitz.So unless there is a change in the regulatory environment, the airline-owned portals will not affect travel agent discounters.

Moreover, the entire sector will have to compete on factors other than price. The process of booking a flight or holiday over the internet can be fiddly and frustrating. Strong content will complement ease of use. United Airlines has signed a deal with On2.com, a leader in broadband content. The strategic alliance will co-develop what they claim will be 'the first travel website featuring television-quality travel videos'. Something for the future, perhaps, but it illustrates long-term plans that recognise the need for consumer content.

Leading guidebook brands such as Fodor's, Rough Guide and Time Out are owners of key content and could help draw customers to sites.

The industry lends itself well to mobile commerce. Ebookers, Lastminute and Thomas Cook have signed a number of deals with European mobile phone operators to provide Wap-based services. A website will be able to locate an individual mobile phone and give tailored information on trains, perhaps with a seat-booking facility.

Such visions will require more funding, alternative sources of revenue, strategic partnerships and mergers. Thanks to the savage marketing costs required by b2c, sites are burning the piles of cash gleaned from investors. Ebookers, Europe's biggest e-travel agent, is said to have just two calendar quarters of cash left. Other sites have seen their plans to fund expansion dashed by the market correction.

Ebookers says its business plan envisaged a need to raise further funds at the end of 2000. The question for investors is exactly what the original money was spent on. In this instance, it has funded a unique network of strongholds - call centres and access to negotiated fares - in 11 European countries. It is a localised presence that should increase the quality of information, and therefore content, for the website. Analysts say the firm, listed on Nasdaq and Germany's Neuer Markt, will need to show that its disparate European purchases have been integrated into the company.

Not all e-travel agents have similarly objectified their spending, and they may suffer, particularly if investors foresee that company being among those 'shaken out'.

In the US, consolidation has begun. Travelocity, 70 per cent owned by Sabre, recently bought Preview Travel. The number two site, Expedia, 80 per cent owned by Microsoft, acquired discount hotel sites travelscape.com and VacationSpot.com to expand its selection of hotel rooms.

Last month, lastminute. com signed a deal with Expedia.co.uk making Lastminute the exclusive provider of late booking offers. Expedia offers booking for travel deals no later than 72 hours in advance, so the two companies complement each other .

In the new deal, Lastminute will provide the company's first-range deals, including flights, holidays, restaurant and theatre bookings. It is the natural development of an 18-month-long partnership, but it bodes ill for players without Lastminute's high profile or the backing of a giant such as Microsoft. Smaller players are likely to be squeezed out if they do not find a niche.

The launch of another b2c site, ifyoutravel.com, may not seem the best ideas. The question is not so much if you travel, but who you use.

By the end of the year, Orbitz - the US collaboration between airlines American, Delta, United, Northwest and Continental - and the unnamed European effort now being constructed by McKinsey, will be trading. The stock market panned Lastminute and Ebookers after these announcements. But the travel market is somewhat more complex than the brutal calculus of internet analysts will allow. The airline collaborations will sell only 'published fares'. These are airline-branded tickets that are rarely sold at discount, but whose availability is published on central reservation systems. You can get on the same flight more cheaply by purchasing a 'negotiated' fare. Such bargains are branded not by the airline, but by a travel agent such as Ebookers. The agent can mix and match outward and return portions. Airlines can thus discount their seats without affecting their valuable brands. Travel agents need to be 'bonded' in each country in which they wish to sell negotiated fares, and need to develop direct relationships with airlines. The introduction of Orbitz and its European airline-owned equivalent should only affect sales of published fares. The rationale for having negotiated fares does not diminish. Most importantly, competition authorities will watch very carefully to see whether the airline-owned venture is treated any differently. The US Department of Justice is already investigating Orbitz.So unless there is a change in the regulatory environment, the airline-owned portals will not affect travel agent discounters. Moreover, the entire sector will have to compete on factors other than price. The process of booking a flight or holiday over the internet can be fiddly and frustrating. Strong content will complement ease of use. United Airlines has signed a deal with On2.com, a leader in broadband content. The strategic alliance will co-develop what they claim will be 'the first travel website featuring television-quality travel videos'. Something for the future, perhaps, but it illustrates long-term plans that recognise the need for consumer content. Leading guidebook brands such as Fodor's, Rough Guide and Time Out are owners of key content and could help draw customers to sites. The industry lends itself well to mobile commerce. Ebookers, Lastminute and Thomas Cook have signed a number of deals with European mobile phone operators to provide Wap-based services. A website will be able to locate an individual mobile phone and give tailored information on trains, perhaps with a seat-booking facility. Such visions will require more funding, alternative sources of revenue, strategic partnerships and mergers. Thanks to the savage marketing costs required by b2c, sites are burning the piles of cash gleaned from investors. Ebookers, Europe's biggest e-travel agent, is said to have just two calendar quarters of cash left. Other sites have seen their plans to fund expansion dashed by the market correction. Ebookers says its business plan envisaged a need to raise further funds at the end of 2000. The question for investors is exactly what the original money was spent on. In this instance, it has funded a unique network of strongholds - call centres and access to negotiated fares - in 11 European countries. It is a localised presence that should increase the quality of information, and therefore content, for the website. Analysts say the firm, listed on Nasdaq and Germany's Neuer Markt, will need to show that its disparate European purchases have been integrated into the company. Not all e-travel agents have similarly objectified their spending, and they may suffer, particularly if investors foresee that company being among those 'shaken out'. In the US, consolidation has begun. Travelocity, 70 per cent owned by Sabre, recently bought Preview Travel. The number two site, Expedia, 80 per cent owned by Microsoft, acquired discount hotel sites travelscape.com and VacationSpot.com to expand its selection of hotel rooms. Last month, lastminute. com signed a deal with Expedia.co.uk making Lastminute the exclusive provider of late booking offers. Expedia offers booking for travel deals no later than 72 hours in advance, so the two companies complement each other . In the new deal, Lastminute will provide the company's first-range deals, including flights, holidays, restaurant and theatre bookings. It is the natural development of an 18-month-long partnership, but it bodes ill for players without Lastminute's high profile or the backing of a giant such as Microsoft. Smaller players are likely to be squeezed out if they do not find a niche. The launch of another b2c site, ifyoutravel.com, may not seem the best ideas. The question is not so much if you travel, but who you use.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Egg on Lloyds' face | Affinity | Freeserve frenzy
fields.body:
Egg on Lloyds' face
The £1.5 BILLION value the market is putting on Egg must be very galling for Lloyds TSB. With a fair wind, it may break even in 2002. Lloyds, by contrast, will probably be making £5.4 billion by then, 50 per cent more than last year. Yet the market values it at less than 11 times forecasts and a yield of 5.6 times earnings.

The only comfort for Lloyds is that it is not alone. The 35 per cent fall in its shares over the past year is not far out of line with its banking colleagues. These are genuine concerns, but the fall in Lloyds shares is now discounting too much. Sure, the internet is exposing the pockets of fat the banks had always denied were there. But the market has been expecting margins to fall for years. And Lloyds, like all the other banks, now has its own internet offering.

Those choosing to bank online are likely to opt for names they know, which give the added convenience of branches and cash machines. That should mean lower costs for Lloyds, even though it will never be as efficient as an internet-only bank.

But neither will it eat cash the way Egg and its e-rivals do. Indeed, Lloyds is such a formidable generator of cash that the European acquisition which has been the subject of so much speculation would be easily affordable, despite the recent purchase of Scottish Widows and its own heavy internet spend.

The bank has an excellent management team and a history of good results. Times are getting harder, but the price is too low. Buy.

Affinity marketing
Last February, Affinity Internet shares hit £82. Now they're lagging at £15, following the hi-tech shake-out. But is Affinity undervalued?

The company provides entertainment content, en-cryption products, integrated telephone services and convergent billing. It also hosts online games and online shopping and internet access.

Its partners include Vodafone AirTouch Unisys and PowerGen. There are now more than 1.5 million registered Affinity users and, in its results last April, revenues rose almost 2,000 per cent to £3.4 million. Analysts say Affinity users will be worth £400 each at the end of the year, against Freeserve's £2,000.

This is disappointing, but some 23 per cent of Affinity revenues came from advertising and e-commerce in the first quarter. This proves that it has successfully diversified since it started up as internet service provider to companies eager to get on the web.

Its target for profitability by 2001 sounds ambitious - especially after its pre-tax loss of £9.17m over the last calendar year. But investors looking to climb aboard the hi-tech bandwagon could do a lot worse than back Affinity. Buy.

Freeserve frenzy
The heat around the sale of Freeserve has come and gone like an English summer. One uncomfortable fact seems to be creeping up on investors, and on Dixons: that this is the company no one wants to buy. Investors will be hoping for more news this week on just who is lining up to buy the internet service provider in a frenzied auction.

The T-Online putative bid could be the only money on the table, and silly value estimates aside (650p a share) it looks unlikely that there'll be much of a premium on the shares if - and it is still a big if - there is a solid buyer.

What the first full-year results are likely to disclose is losses of around £20m, with improving but not wildly impressive revenues. The ISP market was always going to be a difficult one for Freeserve to keep to itself. As Dixons is now able and, from what it says, willing to sell some of its 40 per cent stake, shareholders must hold on to the possibility of a German takeover, but anyone eyeing the lowly shares at 433p and thinking of a bid-premium profit looks set to be disappointed.
