fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: e-therapy for violent fans | Dream on, chaps
fields.body:
e-therapy for violent fans
Phil Neville had a pretty awful Euro 2000, but spare a thought for the folks at auction sites QXL and eBay.

They had their work cut out deleting sales of football tickets from their sites, as such business is tantamount to touting.

A more enterprising QXL could have taken advantage of the information in our very own Trading Floor a fortnight ago and promoted the art of non-confrontational football support. Dutch authorities say there was very little violence around England's match against Eindhoven partly because of the abundance of something sold on QXL as lot 5544851. The lot now has a red star next to it, which means that the supplier is a 'star seller'.

Of course if the calming influences of that product fail, it is reassuring to note the sale of an M60 machine gun on the site - deactivated of course.

Dream on, chaps
On the topic of football, we hear that Sega has shelled out more of its new economy millions to plaster 'Dreamcast' on the shirts of Deportivo La Coruna, the Spanish champions.

After engaging in an impressive guerilla marketing campaign against official Euro 2000 sponsor PlayStation, it is are perhaps keen to keep its brand name around in the Champions' League, also sponsored by its bitter rival.

The chaps at Sega clearly know their footie and worked out it was their only chance of seeing Dreamcast on a shirt after the group stages finish.

Give a bit more
So what's this we hear about PR guru and internet whizz Matthew Freud immersing himself in the sexy paper clip sector?

Turns out Matthew has been advising e-procurement start-up savings-team.com. The company is initially offering its free service to businesses based in and around London.

We could be wrong but is impending fatherhood bringing out a generous side in Mr Murdoch-to-be?

webTitle: Up and down the high street

fields.headline: Up and down the high street
fields.standfirst: Reports of its death are exaggerated, but the town centre must change in order to survive, writes  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Reports of its death are exaggerated, but the town centre must change in order to survive, writes Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Are we witnessing the death of the high street, with hundreds of empty shops blighting our towns and cities?

It looks that way. After all, wafer-thin margins and rising shop rents have seen the quoted retail sector lose over 30 per cent of its value over the past two years.

The demise of the mid-range clothing market, squeezed out by designer label shops at one end and aggressive discounters at the other, this month forced C&A to pull out of Britain, with the loss of 5,000 jobs. Arcadia last April announced it was shutting down its loss-making Principles for Men chain.

The Queen Mother of retailing, Marks & Spencer, which last week stunned its competitors when it became the first major retailer to launch its summer sale, last year issued profit warnings, while Storehouse's former jewel, BHS, was last month sold to retailing axe man Philip Green for £200 million - peanuts compared with what the chain was worth in its heyday.

Speculation as to who the next major casualty will be is rife. Arcadia, owner of Warehouse, Miss Selfridge, Dorothy Perkins and Burton among many others, is under most pressure. Analysts believe the success of women's clothing shops such as Zara and Mango from Spain plus New Look puts Arcadia in a tough position.

The malaise is compounded by slow consumer spending while prices on essential items fall. The British Retail Consortium's most recent price index, three weeks ago, recorded year-on-year price deflation of 1.1 per cent - the 13th successive monthly decrease.

'While deflation in the high street is great news for customers, retailers are seeing margins squeezed at the same time as pressure is applied to their operating costs,' said BRC's Mark Bradshaw.

It all paints a gloomy picture for retailers. But anyone who thinks we are watching the high street's demise is wide of the mark.

Instead, what's happening is polarisation in every facet of this industry. These days, top multiples are interested in only about 300 high streets and shopping malls. Strong provincial city centres such as Manchester, Bristol and Birmingham and sprawling out-of-town centres such as Bluewater and Meadowhall are where they want to be.

To display wider product ranges, major chains are demanding large units, which they cannot get in the smaller high streets.

Next, for instance, now sells sofas, bedlinen and other homeware items as well as its staple line of clothes for thirtysomethings. It has 300 stores nationwide and has spent the past decade upping its floorspace.

'We need to increase the amount of products on the shelves,' said a Next spokesman. 'We're aiming for additional space as opposed to additional stores.'

Suburban towns could provide larger units were it not for fragmented ownership of high street shop units. Only when high streets are owned by a single entity can shops be 'knocked through' to create these larger units.

Greg Nicholson, head of investment at property consultant CB Hillier Parker, recently bought a parade of shops in Oxford city centre for Boots. The pharmacy wanted a large - 30,000 sq ft - unit. It took two years to achieve its aim.

Likewise Nicholson's firm has overseen the makeover of London's Regent Street. He says it was possible to create large units only because the Crown owns the whole street. 'Shopping centres can manage their space easily. They can buy out leases because they are owned or managed by a single party. Regent Street shops were historically treated separately, but we've applied a shopping-centre- style management. It's worked. We now have 17 major international retailers in there.'

Recent surveys have revealed that 80 per cent of this country's retail spend is concentrated in 20 per cent of all available space. So if there is a dash for malls and major city and town centres, where does that leave the 1,200 high streets in this country which don't figure in the multiples' 'grand scheme'?

According to top retail consultant Clive Vaughan of Retail Intelligence, the excluded must either become centres of convenience or encourage leisure uses with restaurants, cafes and gyms. 'The ones that are left clearly need to find a role. Some places will just feature convenience shops, a food store, a chemist, a newsagent and little else,' he said

Dorking in Surrey is one town that has thrived in its role as a secondary centre. True, it is has a relatively wealthy commuter population and is surrounded by attractive countryside. But the town has for the past few years seen an exodus of major chains. Facing town centre oblivion, Dorking has reinvented itself as a focus for independent traders combined with top- notch restaurants.

'Dorking realised three or four years ago that retail polarisation was happening,' says its town manager, Simon Matthews. 'What we did was to flip the whole thing round. We have a traditional linear high street, with 300 small units. Most majors wanted big units. We decided to go for the independents, and now 80 per cent of our shops are run by them. We've got wine merchants and thriving restaurants here.'

Matthews concedes that his job would be tougher if he had to manage a less prosperous town, but maintains it is not impossible to revive town centre high streets. 'You have to create a brand and play up all your advantages,' he said.

Easy in Dorking. Much harder in depressed parts of the country. But with people prepared to travel further to shop and spend the whole day in retail therapy, Britain's secondary towns have very little choice.

Shops till he drops: The British Land gamble
John Ritblat, the colourful 64-year-old chairman of British Land, is viewed as the supreme real estate deal-maker of his generation.

But the next 10 days will decide whether history will view the pugnacious Ritblat - owner of the Broadgate office complex next to Liverpool Street station - as Britain's biggest shopping-centre landlord or as a nearly man who failed to give his shareholders a decent return on their investment.

Ritblat is in the midst of an intense war for 29.9 per cent of Liberty International shares. Liberty, a listed property company, is controlled by 70-year-old South African billionaire Donald Gordon, who built up his worldwide property empire from nothing. Liberty's main investment is a 75 per cent stake in Capital Shopping Centres - the UK's most powerful shopping-centre landlord. CSC's eight regional shopping centres include the Metro Centre in Gateshead and Lakeside in Essex.

Ritblat owns the Meadowhall shopping centre in Sheffield. He bought it last year for £1.2 billion from Eddie Healey and Paul Sykes. Ritblat's intention is to create the biggest shopping-centre group in the country. An eventual demerger from British Land is predicted by analysts.

It seems strange that at a time when the retail sector is going through the mill, Ritblat wants to go long on retail property. But analysts agree that Ritblat's strategy is cute.

'Shopping centres were one of the fastest growing sectors in property until two years ago,' said one. 'But growth has slowed recently because rents have reached a plateau. But there is no doubt that, in the long term, the massive centres will become more valuable because government planning laws limit the building of new centres and the demand for space in them is such that eventually rents will have to reflect this.'

But Liberty's Gordon is desperate to protect his company. He has offered to trump Ritblat's bid for the shares - a mix of cash and paper valuing the 29.9 per cent stake at 520p a share - by offering an all-cash bid at 575p.

But the bank that sold Ritblat the 29.9 per cent stake, South Africa's Standard Bank, has entered into a legally binding agreement with Ritblat. Breaking that agreement would cost Standard £15 million.

This brings the differential between the two bids down. Standard's decision to sell still requires shareholder approval. The likelihood is Standard shareholders will vote to reject Ritblat's offer, knowing a bigger bid lies in the wings. The only thing Ritblat can do is up his bid and convert it into cash.

Ritblat is poised to do this at a time when his company is being slated by shareholders for failing to deliver - its share price has lost 25 per cent in the past 12 months. In addition, it has gearing at 122 per cent.

If Ritblat misses out on Liberty and CSC, it will be a sign that the wily old fox of British property has run out of puff. The man who has spent his career chasing deals could turn into the quarry.

Forget food and footwear - it's all fast cars and feng shui

The declining role of the state, increasing inequality, and the emergence of new technology are keys to shifting patterns of consumer spending, writes Faisal Islam.

As the state slowly rolls back from provision of social services, individuals are diverting spending towards private healthcare, pensions and sometimes education.

Financial services have gained over the past 10 years. Indeed seven of the nine sectors that have seen the largest percentage point increase in household expenditure are related to either finance or leisure.

A report from consumer analyst Mintel says the total spent on financial services and pensions in 1999 was £101billion, up from £54bn in 1989, representing an increase in the share of household spending from 12.8 per cent to 15.1 per cent.

Education fees and charity saw the fourth-largest growth in share of spending. Medical services are also in the top 10 sectors over the past decade. There has been a 30 per cent increase in self-pay operations over the past three years.

A shift towards buying services rather than goods will see greater tendency for price increases, because wages are more inflationary than goods.

The shift in consumption patterns also reflects increasing inequality of incomes since the Seventies. Some of that is due to the emergence of a split between two-earner and no-earner households.

As incomes increase, consumers will spend little more on inferior goods such as food and clothing. They will spend their wealth on luxuries - second cars, third holidays and feng shui consultants.

In the clothing sector the past decade has seen a boom in sales of designer clothing. At the other end discount stores such as Matalan have also been successful. 'It is the mainstream middle ground - C&A, BHS and Marks & Spencer - that is suffering,' says Neil Mason of Mintel.

Shifts in social attitudes to activities such as gardening and home decorating are a recent phenomenon. 'DIY and electricals are taking a bigger share of the retail cake; clothing is losing that share,' says Richard Hyman of Verdict Research.

Consumers are also spending their money on a raft of expensive new technologies that were not around a decade ago, such as mobile phones and the internet. Households now subscribe to television channels and also pay-per-view. The large-scale entry of women to the labour market over the past three decades and consequent lifestyle changes have also affected spending. Women are not having as many children or starting their families as early as they did in the past. The average woman has her first child at 29. Such trends have left an increasing concentration of wealth in the hands of childless, but wealthy couples. 'The money that may have been spent on essentials, such as food and clothing for children,' says Sarah Smith of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, 'might now be spent on fast cars and adventure holidays.'

He has offered to trump Ritblat's bid for the shares - a mix of cash and paper valuing the 29.9 per cent stake at 520p a share - by offering an all-cash bid at 575p. But the bank that sold Ritblat the 29.9 per cent stake, South Africa's Standard Bank, has entered into a legally binding agreement with Ritblat. Breaking that agreement would cost Standard £15 million. This brings the differential between the two bids down. Standard's decision to sell still requires shareholder approval. The likelihood is Standard shareholders will vote to reject Ritblat's offer, knowing a bigger bid lies in the wings. The only thing Ritblat can do is up his bid and convert it into cash. Ritblat is poised to do this at a time when his company is being slated by shareholders for failing to deliver - its share price has lost 25 per cent in the past 12 months. In addition, it has gearing at 122 per cent. If Ritblat misses out on Liberty and CSC, it will be a sign that the wily old fox of British property has run out of puff. The man who has spent his career chasing deals could turn into the quarry. Forget food and footwear - it's all fast cars and feng shui The declining role of the state, increasing inequality, and the emergence of new technology are keys to shifting patterns of consumer spending, writes Faisal Islam. As the state slowly rolls back from provision of social services, individuals are diverting spending towards private healthcare, pensions and sometimes education. Financial services have gained over the past 10 years. Indeed seven of the nine sectors that have seen the largest percentage point increase in household expenditure are related to either finance or leisure. A report from consumer analyst Mintel says the total spent on financial services and pensions in 1999 was £101billion, up from £54bn in 1989, representing an increase in the share of household spending from 12.8 per cent to 15.1 per cent. Education fees and charity saw the fourth-largest growth in share of spending. Medical services are also in the top 10 sectors over the past decade. There has been a 30 per cent increase in self-pay operations over the past three years. A shift towards buying services rather than goods will see greater tendency for price increases, because wages are more inflationary than goods. The shift in consumption patterns also reflects increasing inequality of incomes since the Seventies. Some of that is due to the emergence of a split between two-earner and no-earner households. As incomes increase, consumers will spend little more on inferior goods such as food and clothing. They will spend their wealth on luxuries - second cars, third holidays and feng shui consultants. In the clothing sector the past decade has seen a boom in sales of designer clothing. At the other end discount stores such as Matalan have also been successful. 'It is the mainstream middle ground - C&A, BHS and Marks & Spencer - that is suffering,' says Neil Mason of Mintel. Shifts in social attitudes to activities such as gardening and home decorating are a recent phenomenon. 'DIY and electricals are taking a bigger share of the retail cake; clothing is losing that share,' says Richard Hyman of Verdict Research. Consumers are also spending their money on a raft of expensive new technologies that were not around a decade ago, such as mobile phones and the internet. Households now subscribe to television channels and also pay-per-view. The large-scale entry of women to the labour market over the past three decades and consequent lifestyle changes have also affected spending. Women are not having as many children or starting their families as early as they did in the past. The average woman has her first child at 29. Such trends have left an increasing concentration of wealth in the hands of childless, but wealthy couples. 'The money that may have been spent on essentials, such as food and clothing for children,' says Sarah Smith of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, 'might now be spent on fast cars and adventure holidays.'

webTitle: Strike threat signals summer of rail chaos

fields.headline: Strike threat signals summer of rail chaos
fields.trailText: Railtrack's 5,000 signalmen are tomorrow expected to vote for industrial action in support of higher pay, presaging a summer of rail strikes and travel disruption.
fields.body:
Railtrack's 5,000 signalmen are tomorrow expected to vote for industrial action in support of higher pay, presaging a summer of rail strikes and travel disruption.

The ballot of RMT members follows the rejection of a pay deal the very amount of which is the subject of hot dispute. Railtrack claims the package of a 5 per cent rise in basic salary coupled with increased night rates, roster changes and a one-off payment of £350 is worth 9 per cent, but the union claims it is being offered just 5 per cent.

The union wants signalmen to get parity with drivers, whose average salary is £27,000. Signalmen earn about £22,000 - although this ranges from £15,000 to £33,000, depending on the size of box operated.

A ballot on whether to accept the pay deal was rejected by 1,851 votes to 897, and both sides believe that means there will be a vote for industrial action. Railtrack has insisted it will not improve on its offer. That could mean a repeat of the rail strikes and road chaos last seen in 1994, when the signalmen took industrial action. Then, managers manned some of the boxes but the one-day strikes still caused massive disruption.

Dominic Johnson, head of employee relations at the Confederation of British Industry, condemned the strike ballot threats. 'We are disappointed: this style of brinkmanship fits so uneasily with the widespread rhetoric of partnership in union and management.'

This year the industrial disputes could spread to the roads. The bus industry is bracing itself for a summer of discontent as staff shortages and concern about pay rates among employees clash with management's determination to keep slicing costs. Already, there are pockets of industrial unrest in areas such as East Lancashire, the west of Scotland and Manchester, as unions press for more pay.

This month Stagecoach, one of the biggest bus operators, warned: 'There is limited scope for further cost reductions against a difficult industrial relations climate.'

Other companies are also finding their staff unwilling to settle pay claims easily. Travel West Midlands, part of National Express, is currently in negotiation with its 4,000-strong staff.

The bus companies' problems are compounded by the fact that finding bus drivers is difficult. Stagecoach has had to transport some from Glasgow to Oxford, where high house prices are adding to staff difficulties. Costs are rising while bus travel is static or falling. Upward oil prices are squeezing profits further. Stagecoach's profits from its UK bus operations are down from £81.9m to £80.8m in the year to March.

fields.headline: Weapons of mass commercialisation
fields.standfirst: MoD procurement chief Sir Robert Walmsley talks to  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: MoD procurement chief Sir Robert Walmsley talks to Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is not the world's most commercial organisation. Instead of 'flat' management it has military-style hierarchy; instead of consumer-speak it goes for jargon and acronym.

For example, the man who has agreed to an interview with The Observer is not known by his name, but by the initials that make up his title, chief of defence procurement, or CDP.

So when, with military precision, his secretary phones to confirm the meeting a month in advance, the voicemail message reads: 'This is APS to CDP confirming interview at MoD.' QED.

CDP's office is situated on the top floor of the MoD's main building in Whitehall. He has all the qualifications you would expect for so senior a figure in the military. His CV reads like a pilgrim's progress through the establishment - educated at the Edinburgh public school Fettes College, like the Prime Minister, he joined the Royal Navy, studied engineering at Cambridge and spent his active military service on submarines before moving into procurement.

But far from being stiff and starched, the man behind the title, Sir Robert Walmsley, is waiting in civvies and has an air of determined relaxedness.

Buying weapons and military equipment is not the armed forces' strong suit. The MoD faces annual embarrassment at the hands of the National Audit Office, which publishes its 'Major Projects Report' each summer. Its latest, covering 1998, found that the top 25 MoD equipment projects would cost some £2.8 billion, more than originally planned, and would on average enter service more than three-and-a-half years later than intended. By far the worst cost overrun is the Eurofighter - £1.5bn over bud get - followed by the Merlin MkII anti-submarine helicopter (£815 million) and the Tornado's mid-life upgrade package (£354m).

The situation was made worse last winter when it emerged that radios and guns issued to soldiers in Kosovo did not work properly. The NAO also reported in February that 60 per cent of equipment does not meet operational requirements.

Walmsley's task is to turn this around. He made his intentions plain shortly after being appointed in 1996. Any procurement activity that could be contracted to the private sector should be, he declared. Now his main focus is the MoD's 'smart procurement' initiative. Key to this is establishing a 'partnership' between the MoD and the defence industry.

The MoD process has been streamlined, with a 'central customer' - the Defence Procurement Agency, headed by Walmsley - defining what equipment is wanted. Projects will be assigned to small Integrated Project Teams, of which there will be 145, overseeing some 1,200 projects.

Walmsley is acutely aware of the need for radical improvement in performance. But he is also shrewd enough not to raise expectations. He knows that the MoD is a conservative institution.

He has, he says, five targets in mind: cost, time, performance, customer satisfaction, and the DPA's operating costs. One target is for no increase in total year-on-year procurement costs. That will be met, he says. In addition, the DPA's admin costs have fallen dramatically.

He has taken controversial decisions on commercial grounds. Recently, for example, he chose British Nuclear Fuels - heavily criticised for management failure at its Sellafield reprocessing plant - to be part of a consortium to take over from engineering group Hunting in managing the Atomic Weapons Establishment at Aldermaston, home of the Trident missile.

The justification is commercial. Hunting was not doing a good enough job, and the contract had to be contestable. BNFL's management failings at Sellafield will not necessarily be replicated elsewhere in the company, he says, and a severe penalty regime has been devised to ensure that the contract is managed safely.

But defence and the commercial world are not the most natural of partners. Walmsley has to take distinctly uncommercial positions on certain issues.

Take ships. Ministers are sure to want to award a £1bn contract to build six 'roll-on, roll-off' ferries for the MoD to a UK yard. Under European Commission rules the contract must be open to all European yards, but in the case of warships, Ministers can award contracts to the UK with impunity. Walmsley says simply: 'Warships should always be built in British yards.'

Why, when we buy helicopters and other equipment from overseas companies?

'The reasons are security, and managing control of integrating the weapons on to the ship,' he says. But there is another reason: 'There would be a complete lack of reciprocity of opportunity if we didn't do this,' he says. European ships would still be built by European yards.

Foreign attempts to take over UK defence companies are similarly complex. For example, French company Thomson CSF is buying UK defence company Racal, and observers believe the deal will be completed, albeit with conditions. But rumours that the same company wants to take over Southampton-based shipbuilder Vosper Thorneycroft would, if true, receive a chilly response.

The MoD has a regulatory role, he says, and would need persuading that there were any benefits in having a company 'as important to us as Vosper' in foreign hands. 'We would need to know how security would be maintained. We would need to know that our technological competence would not be bled dry as a result of synergies in a merger.'

Walmsley doubts whether he could be persuaded. Like his views on warships, his views on takeovers indicate an unwillingness to be thoroughly commercial. As for his willingness to refashion the MoD from within so that it can equip UK forces better, we can but wait and see.

webTitle: Now for the news you can choose

fields.headline: Now for the news you can choose
fields.standfirst: Melinda Wittstock on the anchors' collusion in the move from TV to email
fields.trailText: Melinda Wittstock on the anchors' collusion in the move from TV to email
fields.body:
Late every weekday afternoon Peter Jennings, ABC News's $7 million-a-year evening anchorman, sits down at his desk and does something that would have been heresy only a few years ago: he writes an email to thousands of news junkies around the US giving them the full rundown of what they'll see on World News Tonight at 6:30pm - that is, if they bother to tune in.

All three American networks' flagship evening newscasts have been losing viewers for a decade, but never has that erosion, in both ratings and credibility, been so precipitous, a far-reaching survey into US news habits confirmed last week. With the internet winning over more and more Americans who want the news to revolve around their own interests, it's no wonder Jennings and his rivals at NBC and CBS are looking for ways to capitalise on the clamour for 'personalised' and 'interactive' news.

'Peter feels he has a more personal relationship with the viewers this way: there's an intimacy, a connectedness,' says Mark Lukasiewicz, the ABC senior news producer who works with Jennings on the email. 'But what distinguishes his efforts is that it's not really about promoting the broadcast; it's to help people understand what we do, and how we make the decisions we make. It demystifies the newsgathering process.'

Some 40,000 subscribers are now privy to the famous anchorman's innermost thoughts about life, the media goldfish bowl and the news behind the night's headlines. Many of them interact with him every day with queries, suggestions and sometimes complaints about his news judgment.

Compelling proof of ABC News's new-found interactivity came when a man in Minneapolis dared suggest by email that Jennings was just a frontman for someone else's words. 'So I picked up the phone and called him direct to tell him how terribly indignant I was that he would suggest such a thing and that I indeed did write the email,' recalled Jennings. 'The gentleman was quite surprised that I called and really, I think, appreciative to know that the emails were actually written by me.'

Jennings's e-offering contains none of the breathless teasers or cross promotions you would expect from MSNBC.com's detailed 'look-ahead' to NBC's Nightly News with Tom Brokaw or the daily cyber circular from CBS Evening News anchorman Dan Rather.

Rather's pre-air email leads off with an inspirational message. On Wednesday, it was Mark Twain: 'Always do right; this will gratify some people and astonish the rest.'

No doubt the battle for circulation in the news anchor email wars will soon be as fierce as their on-air ratings rivalry. But this is a very different sort of competition, and not one that has much to do with good journalism.

Where television news 'running orders' were once a fiercely guarded secret, they are now freely available to all, an hour or two before airtime, which gives any competitor a long time to catch up. But with the growth of three 24-hour cable news networks (CNN, MSNBC and Fox News Network), and to a lesser extent the growing reliance on dotcom news sites, the news is now available to all.

'They're all saying the same things, so it doesn't really matter,' says Mark Crispin Miller, media pundit and New York University professor. 'In an odd way they are not competing journalistically any more.'

Not true, Lukasiewicz protests: 'We're just as competitive as we've always been, and we're not foolish: if there are exclusives and other stories we need to protect - sources or embargoes - we won't mention it in the email. Peter concentrates on the thinking behind the bulletin: sometimes he'll write about why we didn't cover a story, or on a slow news day he'll write about the difficulty of choosing the lead. '

But behind the scenes last week, television news executives were pondering more disturbing reading: a poll by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press showed that the number of Americans deserting broadcast news for cyber news had doubled in the past two years. Thirty per cent now turn to web news outlets at least once a week, and 15 per cent point and click for their news every day.

'What was happening slowly, is now happening at an alarming rate,' says Andrew Kohut, director of Pew, a respected media research organisation. 'It's astonishing, but more college graduates under 50 now log on every day for online news than watch the once-revered nightly news. '

The Pew survey also revealed an intriguing credibility gap. Some 54 per cent give CNN.com a 'believability' rating, compared with just 40 per cent for the cable network. Over at ABC, it's the same story: 44 per cent trust ABCNews.com compared with 29 per cent who feel they can rely on ABC newscasts.

'I think what we're seeing more and more is a news consumer wanting the news on his or her schedule,' says Barbara Cochran, president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association. 'Now people want to be in the editorial driving seat, and the internet is making that possible. '

Now that 'news you can choose' is a reality, AOL Time Warner, Disney/ABC, and the NBC-allied Microsoft, which linked up a fortnight ago with satellite and broadband powerhouse DirecTV to create 'Ultimate TV', are squaring off for a big battle - and not just with each other.

Interactive TV newcomer Zatso.com is already making huge strides in the 'news personalisation' market. Now streaming 150 different TV news stories a day from 24 local and nine national TV news partners - including Reuters and the Weather Channel - Zatso says it's Personal Newscast Service gives viewers 'the power to screen out unwanted stories and dig deeper into the ones they care about'. In April, a joint national survey by Zatso and the Radio-Television News Directors' Association, found that 82 per cent of Americans want to skip stories, while 79 want to choose the mix and order of stories in a newscast. Some 73 per cent wanted 'news on demand', while 65 per cent hankered for more 'personalised news'.

And, damning for the TV news professionals, 58 per cent insist they'd make better editorial decisions than the news editors. 'It doesn't spook us; it excites us,' says ABC's Lukasiewiez. 'Anything that broadens people's interest in news can only be good for us.'

But more choice does not necessarily mean more knowledge. Just as the biggest news is always unexpected, people often learn the most when they least expect it.

'In cyberspace it is now getting perilously easy for each of us to construct airtight, overly comfy cocoons for ourselves,' says Professor Miller. 'We can now pre-select the kinds of stories we want to see, hear or read - and tune out anything we don't want to face. It's not going to make for well-informed citizens.'

But why not respect the editorial preferences of the viewers? Now that it's becoming possible for news media to narrowcast to the extent that they can tell people only what they want to hear and when they want to hear it, how long might it be before they're tempted to stop broadcasting what everyone should hear?

It's a question only the American 'news consumer' will answer in time. What seems a cyber certainty is that they'll get the news they demand - and the news they deserve.

It's a question only the American 'news consumer' will answer in time. What seems a cyber certainty is that they'll get the news they demand - and the news they deserve.

fields.headline: London gripped by towering ambition
fields.trailText: Lord Rogers, head of the architectural practice behind the Dome, will next month unveil plans for the country's second-tallest building.
fields.body:
Lord Rogers, head of the architectural practice behind the Dome, will next month unveil plans for the country's second-tallest building.

Rogers, who with fellow peer Lord Foster dominates the British architectural scene, is designing a tower thought to be 45 storeys high and to contain 1.25 million sq ft of retail, office and residential space. The tower will be the centrepiece of a revamped Paddington basin in west London. The derelict site is owned by property tycoon Elliott Bernard, who will soon begin work on a huge office and retail complex opposite Paddington station.

The tower has no planning permission yet but a source close to Bernard said: 'We're extremely confident this will go through unscathed.'

London is in the midst of a skyscraper frenzy. In the City of London, Foster is waiting to see whether Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott will allow his 'erotic gherkin' - a 42-storey steel and glass tower for insurance giant, Swiss Re - to go ahead.

Meanwhile, Gerald Ronson, the man jailed for his part in the Guinness insider-dealing scandal 10 years ago, has submitted plans for a 40-storey tower in the City.

The UK's tallest building is Paul Reichmann's Canary Wharf tower, with 50 storeys.

fields.headline: Morris slams euro-philes
fields.trailText: Pro-Euro union leaders are jeopardising the chances of winning a referendum on the single currency, according to Bill Morris, head of the Transport and General Workers Union. They are thereby and playing into the Conservative Party's hands, he says.
fields.body:
Pro-Euro union leaders are jeopardising the chances of winning a referendum on the single currency, according to Bill Morris, head of the Transport and General Workers Union. They are thereby and playing into the Conservative Party's hands, he says.

In an interview with The Observer, Morris lashed out at union bosses, such as Sir Ken Jackson of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union and John Edmonds of the GMB, who speak out in favour of speedy entry to the single currency.

On Friday, Jackson shared a platform with former Conservative Chancellor Kenneth Clarke, saying some 3 million jobs depended on the UK being in Europe.

However, an earlier suggestion from Morris - that the decision on whether the British economy meets the official membership tests for the single currency should be delegated to the Bank of England - has been dismissed by senior Whitehall sources.

Morris's proposal, made a week ago, has been taken seriously in Westminster and the City because Morris is an ally of Gordon Brown and a member of the Court of the Bank of England. A Labour member of the Treasury Select Committee said: 'This is just the way Brown works. If he is capable of handing monetary policy over to the Bank he is quite likely to hive off this decision too.'

But a senior Treasury source told The Observer: " The suggestion is absurd. The Chancellor has made it clear that he is the guardian of the euro policy, especially the convergence tests.

'Apart from anything else, the Bank would have a vested interest in opposing a decision that the UK was ready to join. Turkeys don't vote for Christmas.'

If Britain were to join the single currency, the Bank of England would have to hand over control of interest rates to the European Central Bank in Frankfurt and the Monetary Policy Committee, the BoE's highest-profile adjunct, would lose its role.

Morris was uncompromising in his attack on union colleagues over the single currency. 'There is a lot of scare mongering coming from trade unions about the suggestion that 3 million jobs will be lost if we don't go into the euro. Unless the trade unions moderate their approach, they could well lose the Government the referendum, and play into the Tories' hands by making it a difficult issue at the next election.'

Morris said his concerns were not about the principle of joining, which he supported, but about the timing. But he conceded that UK and European economies may be converging, as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development indicated in a recent report.

 Leaders of manufacturing unions and the TUC are to meet Tony Blair tomorrow to demand action over the plight of manufacturing industry. Roger Lyons, head of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union, said: 'It is vital that the Prime Minister takes personal charge of the manufacturing crisis and makes it clear the Government will do something.'

webTitle: Whitehall keeps OFT on its leash

fields.headline: Whitehall keeps OFT on its leash
fields.trailText: The Government is set to abandon plans that would have given a major boost to the powers of the Office of Fair Trading in dealing with company acquisitions and mergers.
fields.body:
The Government is set to abandon plans that would have given a major boost to the powers of the Office of Fair Trading in dealing with company acquisitions and mergers.

A green paper on competition policy, due to be published in the next month, is expected to rule out allowing the OFT to take over the role of the Competition Commission and become the single authority judging merger decisions.

The move is a significant step back from the radical restructuring of merger authorities outlined by the Government as part of its competition policy review.

Whitehall sources have told The Observer that Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers will instead reveal that the current system - where the OFT carries out an initial examination of mergers and refers them to the Commission if they merit deeper investigation - is to be maintained.

The decision not to create a 'super OFT' will be seen as a blow to the organisation, whose outgoing director-general, John Bridgeman, has clashed with the Government over issues such as its 'rip-off Britain' campaign. Bridgeman is to be replaced by a board of appointees.

However, it is understood that both the OFT and the Competition Commission accept that the current system has advantages.

A Whitehall source said: 'The balance of the argument has come down in favour of the present split. There may be efficiencies in having a single body, but there are serious reservations among competi tion authorities about the power it would have.

'The Mergers Task Force in Brussels carries out both stage one and stage two investigations - and people think it is too powerful. After all, if it goes to stage two, it is effectively re-examining its own examination.'

The OFT has already gained greater powers to police anti-competitive behaviour - it can fine companies and raid their offices - under the Competition Act which came into force this year.

It will also gain control of deciding when mergers should be investigated, under a competition test.

Under the current system, Byers himself decides which mergers should be referred to the OFT. In addition, he can modify Competition Commission decisions by, for example, blocking mergers which are cleared with conditions attached.

Byers will confirm that Ministers will now be involved only in exceptional cases, such as defence mergers where British security is an issue.

The new policy will require primary legislation. The DTI is pressing for this to be included in the first Queen's Speech after the election - should Labour win. The green paper has yet to be finalised.

webTitle: A date with destiny and Mrs Trellis

fields.headline: A date with destiny and Mrs Trellis
fields.trailText: I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue | The 99p Challenge | The Romantic Road
fields.body:
I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue R4

The 99p Challenge R4

The Romantic Road R3

How much longer, I wonder at the start of every new series, can that best of all Radio 4 comedy shows, I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue, keep going? It started in 1972 and is now halfway through its thirty-fifth series, but if you listened last week when the panel were asked to read King Lear in the manner of racing commentators, you'll know that it's as sharp as it ever was - maybe even sharper.

The crunch will come when chairman Humphrey Lyttelton, who hasn't missed a single broadcast in 28 years, elopes with Samantha or Mrs Trellis or, more likely, drops dead in harness. He's 79, still plays the trumpet and clearly has a lot of puff left, but when the inevitable happens - as Humph would put it, when the bogus asylum-seeker of destiny meets the Widdecombe of eternity - what will replace it?

Nothing, I thought gloomily, and then last week came a glimmer of hope. The 99p Challenge has the same indefinable quirkiness, the same spontaneity reliant on the wit of the panellists. As soon as I heard Armando Iannucci was among them I relaxed.

In the themes-for-themed-restaurants game, he gave us Dobsons, where all the food is called either Frank Dobson or something else and all the waiters are dressed like Tony Blair and when you ask for a pizza, the waiter/Blair says no, you've got to have Frank Dobson. Other suggestions included RSI Fridays, where all the staff have repetitive strain injury. OK, it's probably the way I tell them, but believe me, 99p is worth every penny.

The panel, incidentally, are all men, who - at the risk of sticking my neck out - I find far funnier than women on quiz shows. When Jo Brand gets heckled she says: 'Shut up or I'll come and sit on your face.' So there goes my neck anyway.

I've never heard of Heinrich von Kleist, let alone read him, so was I glued to Radio 3's The Romantic Road because the presenter, Julian Evens, and German literati were so enthusiastic about his work. He was the antithesis of pedagogic Goethe who staged von Kleist's comedy The Broken Jug so hamfistedly it was a flop. As Mark Twain said, a German joke is no laughing matter.

fields.headline: Absolutely Fabergé
fields.trailText: Kirov Ballet
fields.body:
Kirov Ballet Royal Opera House London WC2

The Kirov have been showing us their crown jewels in two weeks of glorious dancing. The ballet gives way to the opera company on Wednesday, after fitting in an extra Monday matinée of Balanchine's Jewels. Then they return for three weeks in August, in programmes worth seeing as often as you can.

This is a revitalised company. The dancers look alert and interested, even as bystanders in ballets they know backwards. They are helped by rehearsing in the airy studios of the new Opera House, instead of the cramped, overheated backstage conditions they endured in previous seasons at the Coliseum. Watching them do class in the De Valois studio, I saw them being kept up to speed by Yuri Fateyev, the coach responsible for maintaining the Balanchine repertoire.

Mr B required dancers to move faster, be more daring in his choreography. He was intent on extending the dance vocabulary he had inherited from his Maryinsky training before he left Russia for the West. The Kirov have gradually been taking on the ballets in which he re-examined the Petipa technique they know so well. Jewels (made for New York City Ballet in 1967) is their latest acquisition - an American Van Cleef and Arpels concoction transformed into a Fabergé egg.

Jewels is a suite of three one-act ballets named after gemstones. Each ballet refers to other, older ballets: Swan Lake, The Sleeping Beauty, Les Sylphides - so see Jewels and you have a précis of the repertoire the company has brought to London.

'Emeralds', to Fauré incidental music, is a homage to romantic love. Chaste ballerinas are pursued by besotted cavaliers, as strands of dryads wind around them in a green glade. It is the most elusive of the three ballets to bring off, for so much of it is based on simple walking. While the women drift weightlessly on point, the men, as one of the original American cast explained to me, should move as deftly as Fred Astaire: totally wrapped up in their partners and the music, responding naturally. The Kirov's young pretenders are still stepping out like princes.

The leading man in 'Rubies' is street-wise Gene Kelly rather than elegant Astaire. Viacheslav Samodurov interprets him as a jester, teasing the girl (Diana Vishneva) he is never likely to get. Vishneva relishes the game, flashing a smile as brilliant as her virtuoso beats and battements. She is cut out to be a bold Balanchine dancer, raring to go, while Maya Dumchenko in the other Ruby role is a darker gem, retaining her mystery.

'Diamonds' displays the polished facets of Uliana Lopatkina, who has matured into a ballerina of expressive depth. With Igor Zelensky as a jewel of a partner, she brings all Petipa's vision scenes, including Swan Lake Act II, in her train as the queen of diamonds. The corps, in ice-white tutus, follow her lead, transforming what can seem a paste finale into the real thing.

Lopatkina seems to have a direct line to another world. She has insights into Nikiya's kingdom of the shades and Odette's sinister lake beyond the reach of the Kirov's up and coming dancers. Veronika Part was a gorgeous Swan Queen without a story to tell. Svetlana Zakharova on Thursday revealed more of Odette's secrets: hyper-supple, she makes the same extravagant swan shapes as Sylvie Guillem but lacks Guillem's core of control.

Meanwhile, in the Linbury Studio basement, the Royal Ballet is performing modern works at bargain prices. Unsatisfied ticket holders were slipping into the last act of Swan Lake to catch the Kirov corps. You can't keep a good balletomane down.

webTitle: Nomura adds BAe to its hit list

fields.headline: Nomura adds BAe to its hit list
fields.trailText: Japanese investment bank Nomura has set its sights on a bid for defence giant BAe Systems - a deal that would rank among the most controversial in recent City history.
fields.body:
Japanese investment bank Nomura has set its sights on a bid for defence giant BAe Systems - a deal that would rank among the most controversial in recent City history.

Guy Hands, chief financier behind Nomura's Principal Finance Group, confirmed that BAe, the world's second- largest defence contractor, is on his shopping list.

'We look at a lot of things, but it would definitely be something we would consider,' he told The Observer . Hands said an imminent offer was unlikely because he was involved in bidding for the Millennium Dome and Welsh utility Hyder. 'But it's maybe something we will look at in the future,' he added.

Hands' remarkable statement came at the end of a week in which City rumours had circulated that Nomura was considering a major takeover play. It also caps an eventful seven days for BAe which saw the conversion of civil aircraft manufacturer Airbus from a consortium into a standalone quoted company, with BAe holding 20 per cent.

A bid for BAe Systems would spark huge controversy in both in the City and Whitehall. Ministers are keen to extricate themselves from takeovers, but will make an exception for defence companies changing hands if such a deal could compromise national security.

Since its merger with GEC Marconi, creating a £12 billion company, BAe has become the most important commercial defence organi sation in Britain. The prospect of a Japanese company seizing control would raise difficulties.

But despite the political complications, a merger would make sense for a shrewd financial player like Hands.

Analysts have pointed out that BAe's shares are significantly undervalued at 430p; they suggest 550p would more fairly reflect its earnings potential and strong cashflow position, supported in particular by payments of £1.5bn from Saudi Arabia in this year alone.

Hands is known for his innovative methods of extracting value from underperforming companies - he favours operations with strong cashflows.

BAe's market capitalisation is £12.24bn, but if Hands were to pull off his audacious plan, he would have to bid more than £15bn.

BAe is also known to be considering a 'super alliance' with American aerospace giant Boeing.

Hands made his name by spotting the potential of securitising company cashflows, and this has seen him do deals on everything from trains to pubs. He is Britain's second-largest landlord.

Last week he submitted his bid for the Greenwich Dome site, which he is favourite to win. Observers say he will outbid Robert Bourne, the Labour-supporting leader of rival consortium Legacy.

He is also in the middle of a bid battle for the Welsh multi-utility Hyder. Hands bid £402 million but has been trumped by a counter-offer from American-based WPD.

fields.headline: Northern cross
fields.standfirst: In York's new Mystery Plays, God is a golfer, Herod practises law in Harrogate
fields.trailText: York Millennium Mystery Plays | Singin' in the Rain | A Busy Day
fields.body:
York Millennium Mystery Plays York Minster

Singin' in the Rain Olivier, RNT London SE1

A Busy Day Lyric, London WC2

For the first time ever, the Mystery Plays - the medieval pageants which enact the biblical view of world history - are being staged in York Minster. To rousing effect. Gregory Doran has directed a cast of over a hundred actors, only one of whom - the impressive Ray Stevenson who plays Jesus - is employed professionally. The finely snarling Herod (Tim Holman) practises law in Harrogate; God - the clarion-voiced John M. Hall - is a teacher and a golfer.

A specially built stage rises in tiers, with the Minster's pale gothic arches receding above. When Noah sees his rainbow, the chancel vaulting is flushed with stripes of candy-coloured lights. Before the Passion, lighting transforms the pallor of the Minster's stone and the matching oatmeal-coloured garments of the crowd: everything turns the colour of terracotta, as if someone had administered a blood transfusion. It's hard to imagine a more potent combination of setting and play.

The evening is only intermittently holy, and rarely an advertisement for Christian kindness. At the beginning of the evening, when a growling chord rang through the building, half the audience rose to its feet, believing it to be the National Anthem, played in honour of the Duke of York who was present. When they realised it was merely announcing the voice of God, they sat down again quick. In the manner of the Mysteries - and of cathedrals - this is an occasion made up of harshness, worldliness and domestic life, as well as elevation.

The devotion of the Nativity is beautifully spelt out: the stable's arch is a homely version of the Minster's magnificent gold-knotted gothic; a bemused Joseph - spotting that Mary has given birth - inquires: 'What is that sweet thing on thy knee?' But there can be few episodes less compassionate than this terrifyingly staged Last Judgment. In the darkness, everyone gathers, holding a light aloft, waiting to know their fate. When an intransigent Christ casts his vote, the damned let out a desolate gasp; as the elect go upwards with burning candles, the lights of the discarded are snuffed out in the basement.

Doran and his designer Robert Jones do not like leaving well alone. The Creation scene - which brings the colours of the Minster's stained glass on to the stage - is too busy. And there's no excuse for the Angels having such ugly wings - heavy sapphire horseshoes which are feathered at the front and tackily flat at the back.

But the achievement is tremendous. A huge, beautiful space has been populated. Twenty-first century technology has helped: a microphone concealed in a staff has become known as 'the thirteenth apostle', but the most penetrating moments would have been recognised in the fourteenth century. The Flood is conjured up by rippling huge blue sheets across the steps, while little faces peep anxiously from the windows of Noah's Ark. At the Creation, the great throng on the stage heaves a concerted sigh - as if it is they who are breathing life into the world.

The interchange between film and theatre is getting more complicated. It's no longer only stars who are skipping from screen to stage: scripts are doing it too. The Graduate is soon to get its second Mrs Robinson; Lucy Bailey's version of Baby Doll - first seen at Birmingham Rep, and later at the National - reached the West End this week. And now Jude Kelly's production of Singin' in the Rain - premiered last year at West Yorkshire Playhouse - has arrived at the Olivier, fresh and bubbling and a hit.

In directing a theatrical homage to a film which is itself a homage to the screen, Kelly does what the theatre can and film can't do: she includes scenes from both screen and stage. Big video screens project a variety of images around the actors as they caper and sing. Excerpts from black-and-white movies are seen, first as grainy, mouthing dumb shows, and later cracklingly supplied with soundtracks in which the turning of a page explodes like a forest fire. Huge crayoned drawings of lips and eyes float behind one scene; another is accompanied by a twinkling forest of stockinged legs.

There's too much of this - it begins to look nervous - but its use gives the production an occasion. Singin' in the Rain can be glossed as a musical about the movies' discovery of sound; this revival can be read as the theatre's acknowledgment of the new technology. And it can give the evening wings: in a lovely final version of the title song, dozens of figures with white umbrellas, sou'westers and transparent macs cavort like jolly ghosts in a misty drizzle, while around them on three video screens a crowd of little white wellies are seen wagging away.

No one is going to match the loping athleticism of Gene Kelly, but Paul Robinson gives the part his own rangey charm; as the girl, Zoe Hart has a bell-like sweetness. Rebecca Thornhill - the beauty with no voice - is a gorgeous gargoyle. And Mark Channon, a lithe, insouciant comic, is outstanding. The songs are irresistible. So is the rain. As dancers splash in the puddles, the front rows in the stalls duck for cover. You wouldn't get that in the movies.

It wouldn't have been a bad idea to make A Busy Day into a musical. As it is, it has an historical interest and some sprightly effects - but it isn't buoyant. The eighteenth-century novelist Fanny Burney is mainly famous for her always-in-the right-spot diaries, for being chased around the park by a demented George III, and for having a mastectomy without anaesthetic. It has taken 200 years for her comedy to be produced - in a tailored version by Alan Coveney - first by the Bristol-based Show of Strength company, and now at the Lyric Shaftesbury Avenue.

This tale of match-making, intrigue and true love has polysyllabic patter worthy of Arthur Sullivan, and nicely spiky asides. It also contains a striking exchange about racism. But it's an inconsequential, fops-and-flounces affair. Ben Moor - known chiefly for his performances of his own fantastical biographies - is an extravagant fop with a runner-bean body, stork-like legs and goggling face. Stephanie Beacham blares efficiently as a hoity-toity harridan. Sara Crowe does her gurgles. La!

webTitle: Of gay dads, mystery molls and bonkbuster queens

fields.headline: Of gay dads, mystery molls and bonkbuster queens
fields.standfirst: Schlesinger and Frankenheimer fail to live up to their glorious careers, though Julie Andrews makes a brave attempt
fields.trailText: The Next Best Thing | Deception | Chill Factor | Isn't She Great | Jaya Ganga | Big Momma's House | Relative Values | Brothers
fields.body:
The Next Best Thing (12, 109 mins) Directed by John Schlesinger; starring Madonna, Rupert Everett

Deception (15, 104mins) Directed by John Frankenheimer; starring Ben Affleck, Charlize Theron

Chill Factor (15, 102mins) Directed by Hugh Johnson; starring Cuba Gooding Jr, Skeet Ulrich, Peter Firth

Isn't She Great (15, 100mins) Directed by Andrew Bergman; starring Bette Midler, Nathan Lane

Jaya Ganga (85mins) Directed by Vijay Singh; starring Asil Rais, Smriti Mishra

Big Momma's House (12, 108mins) Directed by Raja Gosnell; starring Martin Lawrence, Nia Long

Relative Values (PG, 90mins) Directed by Eric Styles; starring Julie Andrews, William Baldwin

Brothers (15, 90 mins) Directed by Martin Dunkerton; starring Justin Brett, Daren Jacobs

What, if you're finally fed up with football, is the next best thing? Alas, it can't be The Next Best Thing, Madonna's umpteenth shot at building a steady acting career. She's a thirtysomething yoga teacher with a ticking biological clock. A transplanted English gardener, Rupert Everett, is her super gay chum. One drink-sodden night, they sleep together and along comes baby Sammy. Can Rupert be a true father? Five happy years would seem to indicate so, but then Madonna falls for a hunky investment banker (Benjamin Bratt) who wants to move her and the young 'un to New York, and Rupert demands his parental rights. What seemed to begin as frothy comedy turns bewilderingly to heavy-duty court melodrama.

John Schlesinger's directing days of wine and Oscars are long gone. The sour precision of Darling and the freshness of America observed in Midnight Cowboy have left him. He can bring nothing but a surface competence to this very odd party. Though Everett has moments, he is essentially required to do his Julia Roberts's ex-best friend turn with tragedy added. And does Hollywood tackle the gay rights issue? On the contrary, Hollywood squishes round to happyish ending that anxiously smothers any rights in pink ribbon. The best thing by far is Madonna, here cast as an identifiable human being possessed of warmth and some feelings. This mellow makeover, from the eternal mistress of the makeover, suits her well. Pop star images always need changing but movie star images have to work a narrower patch. Who knows, she may even be playing herself at last.

From the slumping of Schlesinger to the fading of Frankenheimer. The Manchurian Candidate was the sharp-edged stuff of political history; Deception - 38 years later - is the detritus of directing history. Ben Affleck, looking like a bemused honours graduate who's strayed off campus, is an ex-con who gets mistaken for another ex-con by a gang bent on casino robbery. Charlize Theron, a baby doll in miniskirts to freeze your legs off during this Michigan winter, is a mystery moll. Gary Sinise does his manic villain act from memory. The film-makers (apart from changing the title from Reindeer Games at the last minute - always a dodgy sign) enter a ritual plea not to give the plot away. Master, I obey. Nobody could give away a plot like this because nobody would want to. All concerned twist in the freezing wind.

By contrast, Chill Factor seems almost tolerable. If you've seen Speed or Speed 2, then you've seen this. Disaffected US army officers turned terrorists steal bomb that explodes at 50C: ice-cream lorry driver and soda jerk foil their evil plot. They have saved on star salaries: Cuba Gooding Jr and Skeet Ulrich are our pretty downmarket heroes. They've saved on the script as well, which is little more than 'Aw! shit!' endlessly repeated. But director Hugh Johnson has enough cash in the bank for some decent special effects and he whips up an undemanding storm of action. Don't strain to catch it now, though: it has Channel 5 written all over it.

So to two pleasant surprises. Isn't She Great isn't great, but this standard bio of Jacqueline Susann, first queen of the bonkbusters, rattles crisply along, full of fun and delivered with consistent style. Bette Midler is Jackie, the failed actress who wanted to be famous, and Nathan Lane is Irving, the stolidly unassuming agent/ hubbie who set her roaming Valley of the Dolls.

Once upon a distant time, I interviewed Susann and she didn't remotely resemble Midler, who appears to have confused her with Ethel Merman. The original doll was brittle and nervy and plastered in pancake make-up, droning portentously away while Irv stayed safely in the Dorchester bedroom. And, indeed, when you turn to the Michael Korda memoir which sparked this enterprise, the lack of similarity is total. The real Jackie said: 'My readers are like Stella Dallas. They want to press their noses against the windows of other people's houses and get a look at the parties they'll never be invited to, the dresses they'll never get to wear, the lives they'll never live, the guys they'll never fuck.' She and Irv weren't a cuddly twosome, more Mr and Mrs Rapter.

But who cares? Andrew Bergman may have finished off Demi Moore with Striptease , but he knows how to set Midler free to do her strident, ebullient thing. Stockard Channing makes a pleasantly malicious best mate; John Cleese picks up an easy payday as Susann's grotesque publisher. It bears about as much relationship to reality as Tony Curtis's Houdini or Mario Lanza's Caruso - and you wouldn't guess that Jackie's trade was seamy side up when it came to deflowering virgins. Good news, though: her girls always wanted to get married in the end. They're period pieces - and we can laugh with what passes for an easy conscience.

The other pleasant surprise, Jaya Ganga, is a curiosity, a first film by the Paris-based Indian novelist Vijay Singh, about a Paris-based Indian novelist (Asil Rais) who goes home in search of an ephemeral lost love called Jaya. It's a road movie - or more precisely, a river movie as Rais journeys the Ganges from mountain to plain - which arrives in Britain after four years by way of Montreal, Mar del Plata, Oslo and 49 weeks in one of France's smaller art houses; survival and dogged progress by word of mouth - and you can see why. Singh is a stilted, neophyte director, advancing in snapshots and set pieces, but he has wonderful scenery to work with - including some of India's more unfamiliar backwaters - and the tale itself is never less than fascinating. Rais meets Zehra (Smriti Mishra), an upmarket prostitute-cum-poetess and buys her freedom from the brothel madame. She gives herself to him in tremulous belief until, out on a boat on the wide river, Jaya returns. Fresh, complex and quite charming. Mishra (one debut among many here) has a shimmering, affecting beauty. If you like it, tell a friend.

Gross... grosser... Big Momma's House. Martin Lawrence is a Second Division Eddy Murphy, primed with all the derivative Nutty Professor tricks in latex with computer assists. He's an FBI agent on the trail of a bank robber who (for reasons too arid to chronicle) has to dis guise himself as a two-ton Tootsie. The humour is lavatorial end-of-the-pier, tipping constantly into crude farce. Competent players, like Nia Long from love jones - are reduced to cyphers. Few jokes rise above groin level. Yet, to be fair, there's an energy which has clearly battered American audiences into submission. Big Momma is a box-office winner, which (probably) shows that the US is a deeply foreign country of which we comprehend much too little.

The infinite variety of British cinema (1): I say, old man... wizard idea. Why not film Noël Coward's Relative Values 46 years late in the Isle of Man, so we get all our tax breaks and stuff? Then we could afford a couple of lesser Hollywood luminaries (say, Jeanne Tripplehorn and the stunningly non-charismatic William Baldwin) to pretend to be the brightest lights of their day. And Stephen Fry to do his sub-Jeeves butler bit. And... and Julie Andrews as the Countess of Marshwood. Bound to be a smash, what?

Well no, because this wizened saga of the British class system is too long ago and far away from any modern experience; because Coward's control of plot and characters is hopelessly diffused among the mugging and smirking; and because Eric Styles, on this showing, can't direct actors for toffee. Colin Firth is camply impaled as Peter, fount of sardonic witticisms. Sophie Thompson's Moxie, the upwardly mobile maid, twitters desperately. It's all jolly embarrassing, especially for an increasingly formidable Dame Julie, the only human reference point around. I kept hoping she'd burst into song.

The infinite variety of British comedy (2): Brothers, a marginally dramatic clone of late-night Sky TV's randy holidays exposed, follows five yobs to Greece and stews them there in a pot of vomit, semen, faeces and ouzo. You come out feeling soiled and thinking that the Daily Mail may be right after all. But ritual disgust is beside the point. Martin Dunkerton (of modest Channel 4 fame) thinks that there's box-office gold at the end of this unwiped orifice. If he's right, we can probably forget Euro 2004 as well.

fields.headline: The appliance of science
fields.standfirst: A new home for inventions that changed the world - and yes, some of it IS rocket science
fields.trailText: The Wellcome Wing, Science Museum
fields.body:
The Wellcome Wing, Science Museum London SW7

This week, the Science Museum unveils a transformation that is as radical in its own way as the Tate's decision to cut itself in two. Its new building, the Wellcome Wing, is South Kensington's answer to the Tate Modern, an attempt to do something that the Science Museum hasn't done before. Boasting an Imax cinema and a series of highly theatrical installations, it is the closest the museum feels it can safely get to the new generation of science centres that try to seduce the allergic with dollops of sweetening interactive syrup. It's a reflection of the nagging fear that unless we do something drastic, we face raising a generation of technological illiterates clinging to the wreckage of a once-great scientific culture like the devotees of a cargo cult.

Designed by Richard MacCormac, the Wellcome Wing is discreet and elegant on the outside, like a Japanese paper lantern. Inside it is dominated by a cavernous, luridly lit interior that irresistibly suggests the set for the finale of a Bond film. Sceptics might see a risk here of producing something closer to the Dome than Bankside, in which content takes second place to form.

But the Science Museum's outgoing director, Sir Neil Cossons, is too smart to be caught in this elephant trap. While building its new wing, the museum has been hard at work on a comprehensive restructuring of its main floor that has resulted in an impressive new display, Making the Modern World . It's a selection of the most historically significant objects in the museum's collections, ranging from Arkwright's spinning machine to the Babbage Difference Engine. The first, it could be said, is the machine that built Manchester; the second, the first proto-computer, eventually led to Silicon Valley. The display is an attempt to show how we got to where we are now, and acts as an integral prologue to the Wellcome Wing.

It's an essential part of Cossons's shrewd twin-track strategy to demonstrate that being popular and being serious are not mutually exclusive. The Science Museum is simply drowning in objects. It has been collecting everything from railway engines to rockets for longer and in greater depth than anybody else. It has warehouses all over Britain stuffed with racks and racks of clothes brushes and musical instruments, Gatling guns and model ships, fuse boxes and sewer-pipe samples. It is the nation's attic, and in it somewhere is the Rosetta stone for our contemporary, technologically based culture. What the museum has been looking for is a means of cracking the code.

Curated by Andrew Nahum, designed by architects Wilkinson Eyre, with graphics by Farrow Design, Making the Modern World is a brave attempt to explain and in the process make science an essential part of the wider world of culture. The exhibits are given meaning by what they were before they ever got into the museum. It's a past life that gives them a power and resonance far beyond that of the sculpture that so many of them resemble. They aren't just interpreting what happened, they are what happened. They are witnesses to history and actors in it.

The V2 rocket, for example, seized by the British Army from the firing range at Cuxhaven in the last days of the Second World War, is an artefact that can be understood on many levels. In engineering terms it is brilliantly original. As an object in its black and white painted quarterings that allowed it to be tracked photographically on the proving ground, it looks as beautiful as a Brancusi. But its manufacture in caves led to the death of 20,000 slave labourers. The 1,000 or so rockets fired in anger at Britain in 1944 and 1945 were terrifyingly destructive, as is the threat that its technological successors, nuclear-tipped ICBMs, still represent. It is only when you take all these meanings together that you really understand what the V2 is.

Or take the Leica M2 camera manufactured in 1965 on show in a case not far from the V2. It's an elegant, functional design. But this particular camera belonged to Nick Ut, a war photographer who used it to take the horrifying picture of Kim Phuc, running in flames down a palm-lined country road in 1972 after her Vietnamese village was napalm-bombed. Showing the camera next to the transmitter used by Ut to wire the photo to Associated Press for distribution around the world, as well as the contact sheets from which he made his selection, in no way diminishes the power of the most haunting image of the horror of war since Goya. If anything it gives it an even more terrifying immediacy.

Elsewhere is Stephenson's Rocket of 1829, in some ways an object so familiar from school books as to have been stripped of all meaning. Yet look at it again in this context and you think about what its construction actually meant for the way we all now live.

The context in which these objects were made is suggested in subtle ways. Nahum records the heroic days of the engineer in the nineteenth century with a beautiful model of the Forth Bridge and a job lot of busts of great engineers grouped together against one wall to show their social status. The climate of the 1950s, with its still-innocent belief in the powers of technology, is hinted at by original Dan Dare strip cartoons.

The display is conceived as a layered composition. There are huge objects, cars pinned to the wall, jet fighters protruding from columns, beside scores of tiny models, silhouetted against filtered natural light. You are allowed to explore the various layers of meaning within this room for your self. The interpretations are there, in the witty captions and juxtapositions. But the display allows you to make your own conclusions.

Science, after all, gave us not just the V2 but also the dialysis machine, the body scanner and the cinema.
fields.bodyText: The Wellcome Wing, Science Museum London SW7 This week, the Science Museum unveils a transformation that is as radical in its own way as the Tate's decision to cut itself in two. Its new building, the Wellcome Wing, is South Kensington's answer to the Tate Modern, an attempt to do something that the Science Museum hasn't done before. Boasting an Imax cinema and a series of highly theatrical installations, it is the closest the museum feels it can safely get to the new generation of science centres that try to seduce the allergic with dollops of sweetening interactive syrup. It's a reflection of the nagging fear that unless we do something drastic, we face raising a generation of technological illiterates clinging to the wreckage of a once-great scientific culture like the devotees of a cargo cult. webTitle: Rubble, ashes and tears... and that's just the half of it

fields.headline: Rubble, ashes and tears... and that's just the half of it
fields.trailText: Aldeburgh Festival |  Andrew Ball Fiftieth Birthday Concert
fields.body:
Aldeburgh Festival Snape, Suffolk/ Radio 3

Andrew Ball Fiftieth Birthday Concert Wigmore Hall, London W1

Asbestos had closed the Jubilee Hall, and Param Vir's opera Ion, still unfinished by the first night, proved a muted opening fanfare in its incomplete, unstaged state. Yet after a limping start, Aldeburgh has recovered its usual bright form. On the second weekend, the sun shone and the Hepworth sculptures which stand between the Maltings and the marshes were handed over to the nation in one of those arcane British ceremonies in which great and good, some associated with Aldeburgh since Britten's day, gathered in the early evening haze to chink glasses and celebrate a state of almost no change (the sculptures stay where they are but are now in the care of the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge).

The events in this, the fifty-third festival, place a rewarding emphasis on music - never a foregone conclusion in any festival - with well-constructed programmes rather than flimsy edifices on which to prop big international stars, of which there are blessed few in sight. The force behind this seriousness is Thomas Adès, the artistic director, who is quietly in evidence as pianist, conductor and composer while not dominating proceedings. The featured composer instead was Gerald Barry. This Irish iconoclast was the focus of an intriguing Composers' Ensemble portrait concert, though the deafening acoustic of the Pear-Britten School Recital Room (in place of the Jubilee Hall) railed against enjoyment. A highlight was 'Water Parted', a poignant microcosm of Barry's opera The Intelligence Park , sung by the mezzo-soprano Buddug Verona James, smoky-voiced and striking. Later, Birmingham Contemporary Music Group conducted by Adès gave the world premiere of Barry's hard-driven, punchy and exuberant Wiener Blut.

Only two of Adès's own compositions are being played, including the UK premiere of his 1999 piece America (A Prophecy), performed by the London Philharmonic, the Tallis Chamber Choir and the Britten-Pears Chamber Choir. Adès wrote America as a millennium piece for the New York Philharmonic and has since reworked it, in search of greater clarity. Scored for soprano, chorus and orchestra, it examines the shattering of natural civilisations by conquering colonists. A prophetess (Janice Watson) soars out of the tumult to issue a warning of the rubble, ashes and tears to come (her words taken from a Mayan text). The cogent, caustic textures and syncopations, which build to a thundering climax and subside into an astringent lament, made a fierce impact in the live Radio 3 broadcast.

The Borodin Quartet, now newly established with a different leader and viola player, will give seven concerts at Aldeburgh to launch a two-year project to perform the complete quartet cycles of Beethoven and Shostakovich throughout Europe. In Saturday morning's recital, they were more convincing in the two Shostakovich works, the Quartet No 7 in F sharp minor and the Second Piano Trio (in which they were joined by the formidable Russian pianist Ludmila Berlinskaia). Whereas Beethoven's Op 18 No 6 had sounded urbane and noncommittal, this playing style suited the desiccated melancholy of Shostakovich's 1960 quartet, a spiky, spidery exploration of grief and the shortest of his 15 in the form.

At the Wigmore Hall, Andrew Ball, a pianist who deserves medals for his unstinting pursuit of the new, allowed himself the treat of travelling backwards for his fiftieth-birthday recital. Works by Busoni, Schumann and the Russian romantic, Liapunov, revealed an expansive, showy side to Ball usually kept hidden. Nevertheless, by opening with Busoni's innovative 'Sonatina seconda', he tacitly reminded us where his musical loyalties lie. This mysterious work was written in 1912 when Busoni was steeped in the occult and newly startled by the Italian Futurists. While other composers were teetering on the safe harmonic shore, Busoni cast off to the uncharted waters of structural anarchy (the publisher's engraver was so alarmed by the composer's manuscript that he sought reassurance before going ahead with the plates).

The modest eight-minute work, without system or key signature and often without barlines, is a first signpost featuring a question mark to announce music's most hazardous path for the next eight decades. Ferruccio Busoni's pivotal position in music of the twentieth century in part explains his cult following among composers. Ball also performed three short, assured works by the young British composer Morgan Hayes (b 1973) and Four Inventions by Philip Cashian (b 1963), expressive, virtuosic essays by a rewardingly individual composer.

To return, for a moment, to Aldeburgh: Andrew Porter, my predecessor on this column, gave the Hesse Lecture this week on the ticklish subject of music criticism. He lamented the occasion on which he reviewed Peter Maxwell Davies's Sixth Symphony. The heading was made to read: 'Six power! What a score: Every time Max comes to a climax he starts to swell again.' One can see the cause of his dismay, though the sub-editors had somehow got it right. Maxwell Davies's latest symphony, the Haydn-inspired Seventh, broadcast live from the Orkney Festival, showed that the systole and diastole of his music is still working, and well. One of the headaches of music criticism is to describe such serial tumescence in anything but sexual terms. I shall, I hope, have enough time before I hear this characteristically well-fleshed piece in concert to clean up my metaphors.

 Maxwell Davies's Seventh symphony is at the Proms on 21 July
