fields.headline: Chinese bairns
fields.standfirst: It's not easy being a village schoolteacher. Especially if you're only 13
fields.trailText: Not One Less
fields.body:
Not One Less (U, 106 mins) Directed by Zhang Yimou; starring Wei Minzhi, Huike Zhang

The wonder of cinema is that, just occasionally, it can take you somewhere you could never go to and sit you down as equals - concerned, involved observers - among people you could never otherwise meet. Say a primary school class deep in rural China, where poverty is making a box of chalk last a month.

There's one stooped schoolmaster called Gao and he needs a month off with his dying mum. Can the 'mayor' - grand title for a gap-toothed farmer who never pays his bills - find a supply teacher to fill in? Only a 13-year-old from a neighbouring village. But she doesn't stand a chance of getting paid unless she keeps the dwindling class intact. Lose one more and she has nothing. That's the 'not one less' of the title.

Zhang Yimou, from Red Sorghum and Raise the Red Lantern , is a great director. When he lived and worked with the amazing Gong-Li, their films found a world audience and an emotional power that rattled China's rulers in their office cages. But he and Gong-Li have parted now, the end of a prolifically creative affair, and Zhang has changed course utterly. Not One Less has an almost documentary simplicity. No professional actors and the children all use their real names, the mayor is a real mayor, Teacher Gao chalks real blackboards for a living. The decrepit shack of a school in the flyblown scatter of a village is rural depopulation waiting to happen. Zhang doesn't need art to make you believe: immediate authenticity.

Wei Minzhi, the 13-year-old in the firing line, is a thin, gawky girl with a stubborn face. At first she sits outside, stunned, as her rabble class run wild, but gradually she gets the hang of things, until the cheeky chappie of indiscipline, 10-year-old Zhang Huike, is suddenly dispatched to the city to scrape a living and send what cash he can back to his sickly mum. Not one less? Teacher Wei has somehow to bring him back. The second half of the film is the odyssey of her search for him among the neon lights and bewildering harshness of urban civilisation.

This is not, it should be said clearly, a movie with any global ambitions. Its core audience must be basically inside China. It grows didactic towards the close and the sunny ending, featuring Beijing's answer to Esther Rantzen, seems perfunctorily contrived. But that's not really the point. A film that tells China (and us) that a million children a year have to drop out of school every year in desperate impoverishment and shows us what that means has a fine cinematic heritage, from Bicycle Thieves to Los Olvidados. Better still, if you can identify with the people involved, you can feel for them, too.

There's nothing far away about Wei Minzhi's dogged determination or about her class's giggling boredom. One blackboard jungle is much like another, from Yanqing County to Yeovil. Nor is the awful lure of the city, the draining of resource and hope from the countryside, a phenomenon that ends at the Great Wall. The aim may not be universal and the rattling of bureaucratic cages may be more modestly cautious than heretofore: but its targets arise naturally wherever you are.

Zhang Yimou has not gone quiet without his muse. He has merely tried another path, and if you come to remember the moment in triumph when Wei Minzhi's sullen face splits into a smile, you'll remember the final eagerness to learn and the strength of leadership discovered along that human trek.

 Philip French is on holiday

fields.headline: The changing of the avant-garde
fields.standfirst: After 18 months in the studio, Radiohead unveil their brave new direction - songs without choruses
fields.trailText: Radiohead
fields.body:
Radiohead Piazza Santa Croce, Florence

It's the longest day of the year, and three years exactly since the last time I saw Radiohead. Then, it was Dublin in a thunderstorm; tonight it is Florence in a warm, cloudless dusk. Then, the band was celebrating the ecstatic reaction to its third album, OK Computer ; now it is testing out tracks from the long-awaited fourth album (as yet untitled, due in October). In 1997, the mood was of complicated euphoria (nothing's ever simple with Radiohead); in 2000, it is nervous expectancy.

The creation of the new album has been a tortuous process. Read through guitarist Ed O'Brien's internet diary for the last 18 months, and you get the impression of a band uncomfortably questioning everything they do, a band seemingly terrified of the 'slick' or the 'obvious'. Songs have been reworked, remixed and scrapped relentlessly, in a desperate attempt not to release anything too catchy. The good news is: they've succeeded. On the evidence of the 10 new songs previewed here, the new album is not contaminated by even the tiniest hint of catchiness.

Not that the crowd seem too concerned by the prospect. Mostly tanned and beautiful, singing football chants, smoking, flirting and laughing, they don't look like stereotypical Radiohead fans at all. Up on the roof terraces overlooking this glorious piazza, people clink glasses and wait happily for the band's arrival. Their loping English frames are greeted with huge cheers.

The first thing you notice about Radiohead 2000 is that Thom Yorke seems to have been working out. He has the same severely cropped blond hair, the same pallid skin, but his biceps bulge and he looks less wraithlike. Fitter, happier...

The first song is even called 'Optimistic'. With its sinuous acoustic shuffle, it even sounds optimistic, at least until the dark string samples and the screaming start. They then play two songs from The Bends ('Bones' and 'Planet Telex'), and, as the sky darkens and a cloud of hashish hovers over us like smog, a magisterial rendition of 'Karma Police'. All this combines to create a false sense of security among the fans.

Then 'Morning Bell', the second of the new songs, is played. Yorke picks out some jazzy chords on electric piano, a syncopated drumbeat kicks in, Jonny Greenwood makes his guitar sound like an accordion. The vibe is strangely mellow. Gradually, tempo and intensity are turned up, and Yorke glides from high-pitched moaning to a sort of muttered rap. It ends. The sound of 3,000 people saying 'Hmmm...' fills the air.

They follow it with another new song. 'How to Disappear Completely...' is oceanic and eerie, all strummed acoustic, drifting bass and string samples. 'I'm not here...' Yorke sings, then starts to wail wordlessly. 'Hmmm...' says the crowd, again. After a rabidly received version of 'Street Spirit' and an upbeat old B-side called 'Talk Show Host', they play two more new songs. They are stylistically very different - 'Everyone, The National Anthem' is a Chemical Brothers-style blast of fuzz bass and pounding breakbeat, with Yorke screaming something about 'The fear!', while 'Kid A' is a neo-funk workout with clavinet, wah-wah guitar and prowling bass.

However, a definite pattern has begun to emerge by now: these songs are not, strictly speaking, songs at all. They are jams, montages, sonic experiments, unrelieved by vocal melodies or hooklines. Yorke's voice seems to have become another instrument rather than the focus of the music - which is interesting , of course, but something of a disappointment to the Italian crowd, who demonstrate the kind of Radiohead song they prefer by waving their lighters to 'Lucky' and moshing excitedly to 'Just'.

Of the five other new tracks aired by the band, the weirdest is 'You and Whose Army', which begins with Yorke crooning tunelessly through a distorting microphone while playing chords on the piano seemingly at random. Someone in the audience laughs, and the singer gets cross: 'Shut up!' he shouts, unsmiling, before the track swells into a sort of gospel-inflected rock opera. The most radio-friendly track is probably 'Knives Out', which starts off sounding like an upbeat Smiths single, all jangly guitar and nice chord patterns, but studiously refuses to develop a chorus of any kind. The best of the new tracks, though, is 'Egyptian Song', which, with its slow, intoxicating piano rhythm and Yorke's haunting falsetto, sounds like an elegy for Jeff Buckley.

So where does this leave us? My initial reaction to Radiohead's new direction was, I admit, puzzlement and frustration. Why would a band with such a rare gift for combining sonic invention with memorable, emotive songs, give up half of its winning formula? For all of OK Computer 's futuristic production, you could still play most of its songs on acoustic guitar in a subway station if you were so minded. That is clearly not the case with the new songs.

Having said that, there are four songs on OK Computer - 'Airbag', 'Subterranean Homesick Alien', 'Exit Music', 'Climbing Up the Walls' - that, in retrospect, pointed the way towards Radiohead 2000. Linear, atmospheric and inspired by the high-pressure rhythms of Miles Davis's Bitches Brew , they now sound like prototypes for the new songs.

In fact, looking back over Radiohead's evolutionary progress over four albums reminds me of two other bands who started off by adding a slight twist to pop/rock conventions - Talking Heads and Talk Talk - and went on to make fourth albums which pushed the envelope of popular music: Remain in Light and Spirit of Eden . My guess is that the fourth Radiohead album will have a similarly ground-breaking feel.

Still, if atmospheric prog-jazz-rock is not really your thing, don't despair. Radiohead have not lost their mantle as one of the world's most powerful live bands. The concert in Florence ended triumphantly, after two hours, with a stormy ride through 'Paranoid Android', the 'Bohemian Rhapsody' of its generation, and a magnificent 'Exit Music'. 'The panic, the vomit!/ The panic, the vomit!' the crowd roared in Latin-accented unison. 'We hope that you choke,' Yorke sang sweetly back to them. Many people undoubtedly will when they hear the new album.

 Radiohead play the Meltdown festival, Royal Festival Hall, on 1 July. Autumn UK tour: Tredegar House, Newport, 1/2 Sept; Victoria Park, Tower Hamlets, London, 23-25 Sept; Glasgow Green, 28/29 Sept; Victoria Park, Warrington, 1-3 Oct

In 1997, the mood was of complicated euphoria (nothing's ever simple with Radiohead); in 2000, it is nervous expectancy. The creation of the new album has been a tortuous process. Read through guitarist Ed O'Brien's internet diary for the last 18 months, and you get the impression of a band uncomfortably questioning everything they do, a band seemingly terrified of the 'slick' or the 'obvious'. Songs have been reworked, remixed and scrapped relentlessly, in a desperate attempt not to release anything too catchy. The good news is: they've succeeded. On the evidence of the 10 new songs previewed here, the new album is not contaminated by even the tiniest hint of catchiness. Not that the crowd seem too concerned by the prospect. Mostly tanned and beautiful, singing football chants, smoking, flirting and laughing, they don't look like stereotypical Radiohead fans at all. Up on the roof terraces overlooking this glorious piazza, people clink glasses and wait happily for the band's arrival. Their loping English frames are greeted with huge cheers. The first thing you notice about Radiohead 2000 is that Thom Yorke seems to have been working out. He has the same severely cropped blond hair, the same pallid skin, but his biceps bulge and he looks less wraithlike. Fitter, happier... The first song is even called 'Optimistic'. With its sinuous acoustic shuffle, it even sounds optimistic, at least until the dark string samples and the screaming start. They then play two songs from The Bends ('Bones' and 'Planet Telex'), and, as the sky darkens and a cloud of hashish hovers over us like smog, a magisterial rendition of 'Karma Police'. All this combines to create a false sense of security among the fans. Then 'Morning Bell', the second of the new songs, is played. Yorke picks out some jazzy chords on electric piano, a syncopated drumbeat kicks in, Jonny Greenwood makes his guitar sound like an accordion. The vibe is strangely mellow. Gradually, tempo and intensity are turned up, and Yorke glides from high-pitched moaning to a sort of muttered rap. It ends. The sound of 3,000 people saying 'Hmmm...' fills the air. They follow it with another new song. 'How to Disappear Completely...' is oceanic and eerie, all strummed acoustic, drifting bass and string samples. 'I'm not here...' Yorke sings, then starts to wail wordlessly. 'Hmmm...' says the crowd, again. After a rabidly received version of 'Street Spirit' and an upbeat old B-side called 'Talk Show Host', they play two more new songs. They are stylistically very different - 'Everyone, The National Anthem' is a Chemical Brothers-style blast of fuzz bass and pounding breakbeat, with Yorke screaming something about 'The fear!', while 'Kid A' is a neo-funk workout with clavinet, wah-wah guitar and prowling bass. However, a definite pattern has begun to emerge by now: these songs are not, strictly speaking, songs at all. They are jams, montages, sonic experiments, unrelieved by vocal melodies or hooklines. Yorke's voice seems to have become another instrument rather than the focus of the music - which is interesting , of course, but something of a disappointment to the Italian crowd, who demonstrate the kind of Radiohead song they prefer by waving their lighters to 'Lucky' and moshing excitedly to 'Just'. Of the five other new tracks aired by the band, the weirdest is 'You and Whose Army', which begins with Yorke crooning tunelessly through a distorting microphone while playing chords on the piano seemingly at random. Someone in the audience laughs, and the singer gets cross: 'Shut up!' he shouts, unsmiling, before the track swells into a sort of gospel-inflected rock opera. The most radio-friendly track is probably 'Knives Out', which starts off sounding like an upbeat Smiths single, all jangly guitar and nice chord patterns, but studiously refuses to develop a chorus of any kind. The best of the new tracks, though, is 'Egyptian Song', which, with its slow, intoxicating piano rhythm and Yorke's haunting falsetto, sounds like an elegy for Jeff Buckley. So where does this leave us? My initial reaction to Radiohead's new direction was, I admit, puzzlement and frustration. Why would a band with such a rare gift for combining sonic invention with memorable, emotive songs, give up half of its winning formula? For all of OK Computer 's futuristic production, you could still play most of its songs on acoustic guitar in a subway station if you were so minded. That is clearly not the case with the new songs. Having said that, there are four songs on OK Computer - 'Airbag', 'Subterranean Homesick Alien', 'Exit Music', 'Climbing Up the Walls' - that, in retrospect, pointed the way towards Radiohead 2000. Linear, atmospheric and inspired by the high-pressure rhythms of Miles Davis's Bitches Brew , they now sound like prototypes for the new songs. In fact, looking back over Radiohead's evolutionary progress over four albums reminds me of two other bands who started off by adding a slight twist to pop/rock conventions - Talking Heads and Talk Talk - and went on to make fourth albums which pushed the envelope of popular music: Remain in Light and Spirit of Eden . My guess is that the fourth Radiohead album will have a similarly ground-breaking feel. Still, if atmospheric prog-jazz-rock is not really your thing, don't despair. Radiohead have not lost their mantle as one of the world's most powerful live bands. The concert in Florence ended triumphantly, after two hours, with a stormy ride through 'Paranoid Android', the 'Bohemian Rhapsody' of its generation, and a magnificent 'Exit Music'. 'The panic, the vomit!/ The panic, the vomit!' the crowd roared in Latin-accented unison. 'We hope that you choke,' Yorke sang sweetly back to them. Many people undoubtedly will when they hear the new album.  Radiohead play the Meltdown festival, Royal Festival Hall, on 1 July. Autumn UK tour: Tredegar House, Newport, 1/2 Sept; Victoria Park, Tower Hamlets, London, 23-25 Sept; Glasgow Green, 28/29 Sept; Victoria Park, Warrington, 1-3 Oct

webTitle: The shock of the nude (especially if you can't draw very well)

fields.headline: The shock of the nude (especially if you can't draw very well)
fields.standfirst: Eric Fischl has a starry reputation for his scenes of suburban sexuality - but there's something missing
fields.trailText: Eric Fischl | Karen Kilimnik
fields.body:
Eric Fischl Gagosian Gallery, London W1 to 28 July

Karen Kilimnik South London Gallery, London SE5 to 23 July

Of all the visitors who fetch up at Tate Modern daily to discover that 20,000 others had the same idea, none is possibly quite as surprised as the art critic of the New York Times.

Michael Kimmelman recently published an elegantly disdainful report on the mania for art in London - the queues, the headlines, the epidemic of new galleries, 'the huge engine of national self-congratulation' installed at Bankside. 'The masses', he declared, were 'weirdly fascinated' by art; the British had lost their minds. Why else would they act as though London was now art capital of the world when 'much of the work you see was shown in New York first'?

This rebuke from the cultural imperium sounded strangely antique, as if written in the days before art became a global business. Kimmelman even went on to remind his readers how long it took the British to appreciate Abstract Expressionism back in the Fifties. But his article perfectly encapsulated the transatlantic delay that still besets the special relationship: each country fondly believing that the other lags far behind it. Take the new Gagosian Gallery, which opened last month in London's West End. Larry Gagosian is the most successful art dealer in the US, with galleries in Los Angeles and Manhattan. Kimmelman regards his advance into London as a form of colonisation and a sign of change. Here, the Gallery is seen as retrograde, a belated attempt to capitalise on the London art boom of the Nineties. In fact, Gagosian is simply cross-pollinating the market - selling Damien Hirst in New York and Eric Fischl in London. You can't immediately recall Fischl? Why, he's a star turn across the Atlantic.

Fischl became famous in the Eighties for his scenes from suburban life on Long Island. In 'Sleepwalker', a sullen adolescent masturbates into the children's paddling pool. In 'Bad Boy', his cousin sneaks a glimpse of a woman's naked pudenda while groping for money in her open bag. She might be his mother, his sister, his neighbour - this was John Updike with an incestuous twist. Fischl also probed deep into Thirties realism, discovering spurts of sexual anxiety among the angled shadows. His paintings looked a little like Edward Hopper degraded and Gagosian sold them hard to his Hollywood clients.

Twenty years and much celebrity later, Fischl is showing a series of oils and some giant watercolours in the glass-and-granite cool of the Gagosian Gallery. The oil paintings form a freeze-frame sequence, enacted in a single bedroom and featuring the same nude woman. Scene 1: a naked man stares intently at you, though his appetite is clearly pricked for the stripping woman whose silhouette appears on the wall. Scene 2: she becomes your private dancer, nose as pert as Barbie and nipples to match, while another man lies detumescent on the bed. Scene 3: a clothed man fingers his collar apprehensively, while the woman slumps on the floor; and so on until the final image which zeroes exclusively on her pudenda.

There are continuity faults - nightstands vanish, telephones appear - to establish a specious air of uncertainty. Some sort of narrative is trailed in the shifting male cast, which apparently includes a likeness of the film director Mike Nichols. At one point, the woman even seemed to be replaced by a mysterious sister, though this turned out to be no more than defective brushwork. Everything strains for portentous effect: an effect scuppered by Fischl's lack of skill as an artist.

These pictures are full of holes - where Fischl can't bring off an arm or a leg, or can't resolve some cinematic pull of focus. He likes the idea of momentary transition, but tries to achieve it by slithering incoherently all over the canvas. He uses paint like greasy lubricant. For a figure painter, his anatomy is amazingly inept. Worse, by his own humble admission, Fischl has never mastered even the rudiments of draughtsmanship.

Which doesn't leave much but content and a starry reputation in the US. The former seems weak and depleted in Fischl's latest paintings, which have none of the unnerving backstory implicit in his work through the Eighties. The latter may count for a lot to Gagosian's international clients, but it doesn't amount to much outside the market in London. It's possible that we have yet to catch up with the achievements of Fischl; on the strength of this show, I doubt it.

Karen Kilimnik, also arriving from America in a cloud of fame, has turned the South London Gallery into the visual equivalent of a little girl's diary. Kilimnik loves ballet: there are amateur snapshots of The Nut cracker and a model of Giselle's grave, complete with balsawood headstone and a garland of plastic lilies. She loves film stars: there are lots of wispy pin-ups, awkwardly painted from magazine photographs. She adores ponies, flowers, fashion and fairylights and, believing that she might have some Russian blood, she has included an effortful sketch of Nureyev and an imaginary map of Russia in pretty gold paint.

Kilimnik is 45 and an inveterate fantasist. In New York, she was pegged as a pioneer of 'scatter' art, though that seems a heavy burden for such narrow shoulders. If there was any vision in her media-based images you might call them naïve; more talent and you'd call them kitsch. As it is, her arrested development seems painfully real; her art forever trapped in the pre-teen bedroom.

fields.headline: Theatre
fields.trailText: Coventry Mystery Plays | The Globe | Ludlow Castle | The National Theatre | Knee-High Theatre
fields.body:
Coventry Mystery Plays The ruins of the old cathedral will be torchlit for a new version of the plays from 18 July to 5 August, when the city's Belgrade Theatre and the Polish company Teatr Biuro Podrozy join forces to marshal a 100-strong cast and a menagerie of inflatables, including a giant ostrich and a 10ft tortoise.
Box office (024) 7655 3055

The Globe, where you can shelter under the thatch or go pack-a-macked as a groundling, runs until September, with Vanessa Redgrave playing Prospero as a gruff sea-dog and Mark Rylance as a delicate and witty Hamlet. In July, Grupo Galpao brings Brazilian street theatre from the mining state of Minas Gerais to Shakespeare's magic circle, with a brisk Portuguese version of Romeo and Juliet.
Box office (020) 7401 9919

Ludlow Castle Each year, the Ludlow Festival has open-air Shakespeare staged in the inner bailey of the castle. It's Pericles this year, until 9 July, with Rula Lenska and Stephen Beckett (PC Jarvis of The Bill ).
Box office (01584) 872150

The National Theatre takes to the South Bank terraces from July to September. Events, all free of charge, include the Antipodean aerialists Strange Fruit and a screening on the Lyttelton flytower of Buster Keaton's Sherlock Junior accompanied by the five-piece band Blue Grassy Knoll. Details (020) 7452 3327

The Open Air Theatre in Regent's Park Relandscaping has recaptured the idea of a secret garden, and you can now eat without looking at the car park. Apart from A Midsummer Night's Dream , Much Ado about Nothing and The Pirates of Penzance, in August there's to be a witching-hour evocation of succubi and hobgoblins - and a sing-along-a Sound of Music.
Box office (020) 7486 2431

Knee-High Theatre are touring The Red Shoes until the first week in August. It will be produced in the Lost Gardens of Heligan - overgrown and discovered only a decade ago - and in Porthcurno at the Minack, a stone amphitheatre on a cliff near Land's End. At the end of August, the company will produce Nick Darke's Hell's Mouth - involving Samurai stunt bikes and burning cars - in a water-filled disused clay pit near St Austell.
Details (01872) 223159

fields.headline: Summer enchanted evenings...
fields.standfirst: And the days, of course.  Here's our round-up of what's on. But we can't guarantee the weather
fields.trailText: And the days, of course.  Here's our round-up of what's on. But we can't guarantee the weather.
fields.body:
Soft summer evenings; baked warmth, long shadows, bare limbs and the smell of honeysuckle: what better than outdoor entertainments? Nothing so English, nothing so uncertain. Think of smoked salmon and strawberries and cold white wine; graceful cotton dresses and music floating on the air; lying back on your blanket and staring at the mackerel clouds while sounds wash through you. Or think of squashed sandwiches, warm beer, gusts of rain, water in your sandals, grass stains on your too-thin clothes which embody the triumph of hope over experience.

My first outdoor show was, I think, a robust production of Hamlet at Ludlow Castle in Shropshire. Wimbledon was going on; Nastase was in the finals, I remember. It was a glorious late afternoon - the kind that nowadays I would regard with alarm, rushing around with hats and sun block for my children. The sky was electric blue, the sun a blowtorch, the grass beige and prickly. But it was meant to be night watch in Denmark; owls hooting in the winter frost. On clanked the actors in their armour; we were close enough to see the sweat running down their faces. At the line, "Tis bitter cold', the audience hooted with laughter. A woman passed out with sunstroke halfway through, and her panicked companion poured half a bottle of warm lemonade over her face in order to revive her.

Many years later, on a similarly hot summer evening, I went to hear Aida performed on Hampstead Heath. We did the whole thing properly for once - those dinky M&S eats, cold chicken and dips, cherries and nectarines. Also, a flask filled with dry martini and a chilled bottle of Chardonnay. Lying back on the grass, we drank the lot. Aida sounded sublime but increasingly vague. At the end, I was unable to get to my feet. I lay among the debris of our picnic smiling, dim-witted, wondering how I would ever get home.

I've been to plays, concerts, films; I love the democracy of these shows. You get the bikers in leather, with their beer cans; the groups who look as if they've decamped from the Opera House, with their long dresses and elegant suits, their folding tables, portable fridges, long-stemmed goblets, silver cutlery and linen napkins; the families with their hurriedly concocted picnics wrapped in foil; the lovers, legs entangled on the grass; men and women who come on their own, empty-handed, and sit on the grass looking happy. Cultures don't clash. Crowds are comradely, children welcome.

If you want the greatest art, better go somewhere else. The event may be what draws people, but it is only partially the point and often just an excuse. Here, at its best, the outer and inner life can meet - noise and quiet, conviviality and peace, gluttony and spirituality. Time slows down; we're all off the hook - outside, and outside of the pressures and constraints of our compartmentalised lives. People light lanterns at dusk, and walk home slowly, shining their paths through the night. There's nothing so magical.

But magic gets doused by rain. Mud's a real turn-off. Soggy sandwiches are unromantic, squashed strawberries sad.

fields.headline: Moral muse
fields.standfirst: I'm adopted. Should I look for my biological parents?
fields.trailText: I'm adopted. Should I look for my biological parents?
fields.body:
I was adopted as a baby and couldn't have wished for better parents. But since giving birth I keep wondering about my biological parents in a way that I never did before.

My partner is of the opinion that I should leave well alone as I am bound to hurt my parents and myself in the process. What do you advise?

K.T. of London

The stock answer is that it's natural to want to know about your roots, therefore it's right. Something that's instinctively normal may be too powerful to resist even though it can be painful at the same time. Your partner is partly right in having reservations - the facts you unearth might not be gratifying.

Even that realisation won't block your curiosity, so examine your motives for wanting to know, considering the worst possible outcomes. What if you discovered your parents were serial murderers, child molesters, or drug pushers/criminals - could you live with that? The reasons which cause parents - or more often just mothers - to give away their children are generally those of social dislocation of one sort or another. Imagine such a person, who has, with difficulty, rehabilitated herself, being horror-struck as she sees her daughter emerging from the mists of yesteryear, to dredge up a part of her life she thought she'd buried. Imagine your mother a socially successful lady, and how she might react to all her legitimate family coming face to face with the evidence of her 'murky past'.

The mystery of our ancestry can be very romantic while it is unknown. I have an elderly relative who believes her great-grandmother was the daughter of a laird who ran away with the coachman and was disowned by her aristocratic family. She spends her quiet moments examining the lineaments of high society, trying to identify a family likeness.

Most of us like to be proud of our roots. I don't think your adoptive parents will be the least perturbed by your curiosity and researches, if you undertake them. The people who are going to be the most affected by the digging up of old secrets are yourself and your real parents. I don't try to dissuade you, but it could be a very emotional and traumatic experience, though it may equally be a wonderful and enriching one. Go ahead if you feel brave enough, but be as prepared for shock and disappointment as you are for love.

Readers' replies

I gave my baby daughter away under pressure in 1960. We were reunited in 1989 and have had a good relationship since. It was one of the happiest experiences of both our lives.

Your partner's advice sounds sensible, but you probably already know yourself that you will not rest until you have begun the process of tracing your parents.

You do not know what you will find, but all the evidence points to the need to know, even if pain ensues. Most mothers who gave their babies away for adoption did so under atrocious pressure: they suffer immense grief for the rest of their lives. I suggest you contact the National Organisation for the Counselling of Adoptees and Parents (Norcap), telephone: 01865 875000. H.T. of London

 Your partner's concern is well-intentioned. I am a 29-year-old only-child. Last month, my mother admitted that before meeting my father she had a child which was immediately adopted. Fearing mine and her peers' reactions she had kept this a secret, but has always wanted to get in touch. Having now discussed this as a family, we came to the same conclusion as your partner - not least because the child's father committed suicide shortly after the birth. We would love to meet this person, but fear causing pain, upheaval and possibly rejection. Only if you are prepared for every emotional permutation, should you get in touch. C.E. of London

Next week's dilemma is from T. G. of Hove

My wife died 13 months ago in a car accident, aged 29. I'm 31. We'd had four happy years together and were about to start trying for a baby. I was devastated.

To my surprise I started to feel attracted to someone I met just seven months after her death. This other woman is like my wife in many respects - I know that is part of the attraction - and is helping me come to terms with my loss. Something that's instinctively normal may be too powerful to resist even though it can be painful at the same time. Your partner is partly right in having reservations - the facts you unearth might not be gratifying. fields.headline: An everyday story of... cancer
fields.standfirst: As Ruth in The Archers awaits her mastectomy, Radio 4 is being flooded with letters of protest. Are there story lines that soaps shouldn't touch?
fields.trailText: As Ruth in The Archers awaits her mastectomy, Radio 4 is being flooded with letters of protest. Are there story lines that soaps shouldn't touch?
fields.body:
If you listen to The Archers, and millions do, you will be crossing three sets of fingers this week. One for the Grundys (has poor old Joe lost the plot?), two for Mike Tucker's strawberries, and three for Ruth Archer, devoted wife and mother of two young children, who has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer and is now fearfully awaiting a mastectomy. 'Seventy percent of women who undergo the operation continue to lead a normal life,' a sympathetic woman doctor advised Ruth and her husband, David, in a poignant episode last week. 'That's reassuring, isn't it, Ruth,' said David. 'I just want to go home, please David, take me home,' said Ruth.

When The Archers first came on air, 50 years ago, its brief was to educate the postwar public about new farming methods, which it continues to do: Pat's stumpy carrots dealt recently with the organic issue, young Tommy got clobbered for damaging GM crops and if John Archer's premature demise (his tractor tipped over and crushed him) hasn't yet produced an EU Health & Safety ruling regarding the correct use of agricultural machinery, you can be sure it's in the pipeline.

The farming brief has broadened over the years to include general social issues and The Archers ' scriptwriters have never been afraid of tackling difficult, complex subjects. There was Elizabeth's abortion and Susan Carter's three-month prison sentence, and as soon as Ruth comes round from the anaesthetic - always assuming of course that she does come round - she'll be straight back into the Great Brookfield Inheritance struggle.

The breast cancer story line, however, is a particularly strong one, because, of all the serious health problems that women can face in their lives - infertility, menopause, hysterectomy - mastectomy, with its overtones of disfigurement and mutilation, is the most taboo.

How helpful is it to women actually suffering from breast cancer, especially young women (Ruth Archer is 34), to have such a delicate personal problem aired in such a public way? When Ruth was first diagnosed, Radio 4 invited listeners to ring a special confidential helpline for further advice, but says it's too early to gauge the response. However, Friday's Feedback reported a pretty negative response to the way the subject had been tackled. Listeners felt it should have been treated more opti mistically. Conversely, when Peggy, the barmaid played by Barbara Windsor in EastEnders , had a mastectomy last year, hundreds of viewers, men and women, wrote to the BBC, thanking the producer for tackling a difficult subject so sensitively. 'It's the first time, as far as we know, that anyone in a soap has had a mastectomy,' said Sharon from the EastEnders production office.

Not everyone was impressed, however. Felicity Smart, who had a mastectomy five years ago and a further operation on her left breast last Christmas, wrote to the BBC shortly after Peggy's ordeal on behalf of the Breast Carer Support Group at St Thomas's Hospital in London. Emotionally it hit the spot, they agreed, but medically it was hopelessly inaccurate. No one pulls pints and wisecracks with customers three days after having a mastectomy.

When Felicity Finch, who plays Ruth in The Archers, learned about her gruelling new story line, she contacted Breakthrough, the national charity committed to fighting breast cancer through research and awareness for more information. 'Breakthrough sent me a lot of very helpful leaflets,' says Felicity. 'So that at least when I got round to talking to people who had had breast cancer I knew something about it. As an actor you always have to research your part but somehow this was different. It snowballed. Everyone I talked to seemed to have a relative or a friend who'd been through it. That was the other thing - everyone reacts to the problem differently so there's no textbook way of playing Ruth in her present situation. In fact, the way I'm playing her now might surprise some people because in the past she's been such a strong character and here she is collapsed and weeping and thinking the worst. Occasionally you may suggest to the script editor that you don't think your character will react a certain way, but with Ruth I have absolute trust in the scriptwriter's characterisation.

'What did surprise me, though, when I was doing my research, was just how many young women there are who get breast cancer straight after pregnancy these days. But when they go to see their GPs about lumps in their breast they are told there's nothing wrong - it's just something connected with their pregnancy. I do believe that by tackling a story line like this, The Archers is doing a great service for women's health.'

Miranda Vicenti was 23 when she was told she had breast cancer. That was nine years ago. At the time she had two children - Daniella, 20 months, and Serge, three months. Two years after her first mastectomy, she went back to hospital for a second. 'Anything that raises public awareness of the problem and makes other people sympathetic to women who have it must surely be a good thing,' says Miranda who recently gave up her job as an air hostess. She underwent seven months of extremely painful reconstruction surgery, which involved removing some of her back muscles and countless skin grafts. Miranda's Chest, a Channel 4 documentary chronicling the entire operation, was broadcast in October 1998. 'People said I was mad or an exhibitionist or both to publicise it so blatantly but I was thinking about the whole awareness thing. Most women are terrified of reconstruction surgery but I thought if they saw me going through it and coming out OK they'd feel less scared.'

In the case of The Archers, it is not the subject matter but the way it has been put across that has offended some listeners. Anna Jay from Harpenden, a lifelong Archers fan who had breast cancer surgery three years ago, said: 'If I'd heard Ruth carrying on the way she is when I was first diagnosed I'd probably have topped myself. Women, especially women with small children, don't go on like that. They can't afford to break down. They're tough. Personally, I'm more interested in what happens to Clarrie in that dreadful council house.'

Is there any story line that Archers executive producer Vanessa Whitburn would turn down on taste grounds? 'That's the key word - taste. If it's done tastefully, nothing is out of bounds,' says Whitburn. So might we yet see Higgs driving Jack Woolley off to Borchester General in the Bentley for an operation on his prostate, another medical taboo area which most doctors agree could use a little raised awareness.

'Why not?' says Whitburn.

fields.headline: True Confessions
fields.standfirst: My husband met a new love on the internet... So did I
fields.trailText: My husband met a new love on the internet... So did I.
fields.body:
As I drove home from work I was dreading the weekend. My husband and I were to discuss how to tell our three children that our marriage was over. Soon, also, I would have to tell my parents, which I was dreading, as I would have to admit to them that although I had been the one to ask him to leave, the reason his departure was imminent was that he had found a new partner on the internet.

I did not understand how he could be so certain about someone he had yet to meet. Little did I know that I was about to find out for myself. During the weekend, we were managing a friendly enough evening, me listening to music, he surfing the internet, when he suggested I have a go. 'It's fun, you'll at least meet a new pen pal and most people just do it for a laugh.'

'It' was writing a brief description of yourself and the kind of person and relationship you were looking for and submitting it to a virtual lonely hearts column. I wrote something very tongue in cheek about myself. Now all I had to do was choose some men to send it to. I looked through the list of hopefuls from across the world who were seemingly prepared to travel hundreds of miles for a quickie or just friendship. I decided they were all weird, dangerous, or just plain ugly but thought I would grace them with my 'presence'. It never occurred to me that they were just like me.

I sent my description to about a dozen and over the next few hours received replies from around the globe. Around midnight, a reply came through from someone I had included on my list solely because he was an architect, something I had always wanted to do. By the end of the week we knew a lot about each other and like any new couple were buoyed up by how much we had in common. We even lived less than 100 miles apart. I still did not know his real name, though, nor he mine. But I did know by then that I wanted to meet him. Meanwhile the computer that was my link with him also ensured my safety: part of me was afraid that my Mr Wonderful could actually be a lunatic.

Then our means of communication let us down. When we finally resumed contact we realised we could have lost touch by accident - an unbearable prospect. He sent his phone number. I couldn't at first match the human voice with the person in type. We talked for several hours until on impulse I said I was driving to see him. He wasn't a weirdo, he was wonderful and still is. So, what did I tell my parents? That we met through friends.

webTitle: Conversion and the road to victory

fields.headline: Conversion and the road to victory
fields.trailText: Tuesday is crunch day for Standard Life, when policyholders decide whether to turn the insurer over to the vicissitudes of the stock market in return for windfalls that will, in some cases, be substantial.
fields.body:
Tuesday is crunch day for Standard Life, when policyholders decide whether to turn the insurer over to the vicissitudes of the stock market in return for windfalls that will, in some cases, be substantial.

Fred Woollard, the policyholder who mounted the Standard Life conversion campaign, needs to win the support of 75 per cent of those who vote to force the insurer to consider demutualisation. If he wins more than 50 per cent but less than 75 per cent, the management will be in a difficult position; anything less than 75 per cent will indicate a lack of confidence, even though management is within its rights to take the result as a victory.

The board is sticking to the line that 75 per cent is the important figure and anything less is irrelevant. Woollard may campaign for a place on the board, and a vote that is less than decisive will be a distraction for the board, no matter how much it pretends otherwise.

The management would be entitled to stand firm, even in the face of a less-than-overwhelming vote of confidence. Given the vigorous stand it has made in favour of maintaining its present status it has no other choice - but it cannot afford to ignore such a message from policyholders.

If Woollard falls at the 75 per cent hurdle, but lands somewhere in the 50 to 75 per cent zone, we can expect some soul-searching from management and promises to do more to promote the benefits of mutuality.

Standard Life does not want to 'bribe' customers with special bonuses and the like, but if it wins on Tuesday its management must do more than mouth platitudes, especially if the victory is narrow.

webTitle: Business and banking - this time it's personal

fields.headline: Business and banking - this time it's personal
fields.standfirst: If you can't get away with a 'free' account, seek out the best deal for the self-employed, says  Virginia Wallis
fields.trailText: If you can't get away with a 'free' account, seek out the best deal for the self-employed, says Virginia Wallis.
fields.body:
I am ashamed to admit I have been indoctrinated by a bank. Not in a big way, I hasten to add, but it has been costing me around £50 a year in bank charges, even though I've never had an overdraft.

When I went freelance, my bank training (coupled with a vague desire to impress my tax office) led me to believe that as a self-employed person I would need to open a separate business account. So I did. But was it really necessary?

No, said the Inland Revenue. Although it is 'helpful to maintain a separate bank account' it doesn't matter what kind it is so long as you meet the legal requirement to keep adequate records of all business transactions.

Yes, said the banks. All those questioned took a dim view of people who use the free services of a personal current account for business purposes. 'The reason why banks differentiate between personal and business accounts is that business customers create more work, so their accounts cost more to run,' says Brian Capon of the British Bankers' Association (BBA).

Surely my modest and cashless enterprise's yearly total of 18 cheques in and two out isn't that expensive to deal with - especially as I save the bank money by using its phone banking service to pay my expenses?

'These days there is a wavy line between personal and business accounts,' says Capon. 'Transaction level is the key factor. If you're only paying in a couple of cheques per month and you don't expect your bank to handle large amounts of cash, it may be willing to run a business account free of charge if you negotiate.'

So I'd better add 'talk way out of bank charges' to my 'to do' list. Alternatively, I could make a note to change my account altogether.

The Business Investor account from Nationwide looks interesting. You can pay in up to 10 cheques a day and make a maximum of six withdrawals a month without charge, and the account pays interest of 2.05 per cent on balances over £2,000. But although the account comes with a cheque book, it lacks the convenience of telephone banking.

It could make sense to take up the offer of at least a year's free banking from Barclays, HSBC and Lloyds TSB, as I did when I opened my NatWest account (a year's free banking is still available for new customers). But once the free-banking period is over, these banks' charges, as well as those of Girobank, would be little different from what I am paying NatWest. With an average cost of 60p to write or pay in a cheque and around 40p for automated transactions, you can see why the Treasury's Banking Review team, headed by Don Cruickshank, thinks the average bank customer pays £400 a year in bank charges.

Most personal customers may pay nothing, but a small business which makes 15 deposits a week could easily pay that much - and that's before taking account of the monthly service charge.

It would be harder to hit the £400 mark with an account from the Co-operative Bank, but only if you maintain a balance of at least £2,000; otherwise it would cost slightly more than most of the other high-street offerings. Keeping a balance of at least £5,000 on the Bank of Scotland's Direct Business Cheque Account secures zero charges and a reasonably healthy 3.75 per cent in credit interest (a lower rate is paid on balances below £5,000). But, in common with Royal Bank of Scotland's charge-free Business Banking Direct Account, you have to be happy to pay in your hard-earned cheques by post. Unless you pay extra to use a secure postal service - such as Royal Mail Special Delivery or Post Cash - you'll have the hassle of going back to whoever paid you to get a replacement if a cheque goes missing in the post.

The advantage of being able to pay in a cheque over the counter is that if it gets lost in the banking system, it's the bank's responsibility. This is also true of a cheque paid in via a cash machine, which is the alternative to postal depositing offered by Abbey National's Business Bank Account. Aimed at business customers who keep their accounts in credit, it carries no charges if you pay in fewer than 25 cheques a month and/or make fewer than 25 withdrawals (the limits are 50 in the first year). And unlike the other banks, Abbey National offers both telephone and Internet banking.

 Abbey National 0845 300 3040, Bank of Scotland 0500 828 111, Co-op 0345 215 215, Girobank 0800 214 807 Royal Bank of Scotland 0800 521 607. All others, local branch

Keeping a balance of at least £5,000 on the Bank of Scotland's Direct Business Cheque Account secures zero charges and a reasonably healthy 3.75 per cent in credit interest (a lower rate is paid on balances below £5,000). But, in common with Royal Bank of Scotland's charge-free Business Banking Direct Account, you have to be happy to pay in your hard-earned cheques by post. Unless you pay extra to use a secure postal service - such as Royal Mail Special Delivery or Post Cash - you'll have the hassle of going back to whoever paid you to get a replacement if a cheque goes missing in the post. The advantage of being able to pay in a cheque over the counter is that if it gets lost in the banking system, it's the bank's responsibility. This is also true of a cheque paid in via a cash machine, which is the alternative to postal depositing offered by Abbey National's Business Bank Account. Aimed at business customers who keep their accounts in credit, it carries no charges if you pay in fewer than 25 cheques a month and/or make fewer than 25 withdrawals (the limits are 50 in the first year). And unlike the other banks, Abbey National offers both telephone and Internet banking.  Abbey National 0845 300 3040, Bank of Scotland 0500 828 111, Co-op 0345 215 215, Girobank 0800 214 807 Royal Bank of Scotland 0800 521 607. fields.headline: Credit wherever credit is due...
fields.standfirst: People like to know why they are refused loans - but it's not as simple as that, says  Colin Frier
fields.trailText: People like to know why they are refused loans - but it's not as simple as that, says Colin Frier.
fields.body:
Living on credit may have become a way of life for many. But it can never be taken for granted. Miss a couple of mortgage payments, forget to pay off that loan on the car, and you could find your next application for credit unexpectedly refused. But finding out precisely why you have been turned down has never been easy.

Now, under pressure from the Office of Fair Trading and the Data Protection Registrar, there are guidelines, endorsed by all the major organisations in the credit industry. The Guide to Credit Scoring 2000, produced at the end of March, is slowly making itself felt, offering the prospect of a better deal for people turned down for credit.

Anthony Sharp, chairman of the Money Advice Liaison Group, admits that those refused credit are not always treated as helpfully as they might be. 'The credit industry has been pretty poor in dealing with cases where applications have been turned down.'

However, he says, there are important differences between the new guidelines and the previous ones. 'Whereas the 1993 guidelines suggested that credit grantors should give reasons when turning down an applicant for credit, the new guide says that they will give one or a number of reasons,' he says.

According to David Smith of the Finance and Leasing Association, the guide places specific responsibilities on those in the credit industry to be more open in explaining adverse decisions. He says that not only will customers be told they have been refused credit because they have not reached the credit score target, or because of something adverse on their credit reference agency file, but, where it is relevant, they will also be given a specific reason for their rejection. For example, he says: 'Where a customer is refused credit because a large mortgage means they are already fully financially committed, they will be told that that is the reason.'

However, Sharp admits that although greater transparency is generally a good thing, it can also have its dangers. He says the move to greater openness risks more fraud. And for that reason 'the industry shouldn't and mustn't go into tremendous depth when explaining decisions'. Although the guidelines are not law, he says the commitments made by the industry in dealing with applicants refused credit 'come as close to a right as you can get'.

But Jane Guy of the Money Advice Association is dubious about the need for greater openness. 'Some decisions will be bad decisions,' she says, 'but the majority are fair and reasonable.' For example: 'Changes in circumstances, such as separation, divorce and bereavement, are often probably sound reasons for declining loans.'

She suggests people consider seeking advice before applying for credit. 'They can then see why it is likely they would be rejected.' For example, an 18-year-old who asks for a loan of £500 is likely to be accepted, but anyone over 25 who has never had credit before is likely to be refused.

Guy says: 'Because they are not often challenged, it is rare for credit grantors to overturn decisions.' But occasionally this happens. Guy recalls the case of a single mother with two children who was in full-time work. She had been refused a personal loan because the lender felt that, as someone without childcare support, she would not be a reliable worker. 'The Money Advice Association took evidence of her work and sickness record to the lender, and they overturned the decision,' she says.

Carol Hufton, senior compliance manager at the Office of the Data Protection Registrar, says she has never known a case of a person being given a detailed explanation of why their application was turned down.

'Decisions are often made on an amalgamation of factors,' she says. And although she admits that not having the right to detailed reasons can be a source of great frustration for people, and though she often sympathises with the predicaments of individuals, she says she can usually understand why the decision was made. 'Without trying to defend decisions made by credit grantors, credit isn't a right, and there is no legal right to know why you have been refused.'

Lloyds TSB says that although the bank has signed up to the new guidelines, and committed to its policies, it is wary of providing customers with too much detailed information: 'There is a fine line between providing more information on decisions and playing into the hands of fraudsters.'

The bank produces its own guide to credit scoring, and encourages customers who are experiencing difficulties to come in to talk. The spokesperson says that where credit is refused because of something adverse on a credit rating agency, the bank will advise the customer on how to obtain that information. And where someone has failed to meet the target credit score, 'although they won't be given detailed reasons, they may be given hints - such as the fact that they have had 10 cheques returned unpaid in recent months'.

The spokesperson adds that Lloyds TSB will also inform customers if a person is turned down because of the bank's lending policies. For example, if it were the bank's policy not to lend to people over the age of 70, or not to offer a personal loan of less than £500, individuals not meeting these criteria would be told. But whether such sentiments really represent the prospect of greater openness for those refused credit is still unclear. 'We will just have to see how it goes,' says Sharp.

webTitle: Banks in partial climbdown over charges for using holes in the wall

fields.headline: Banks in partial climbdown over charges for using holes in the wall
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Banks are caving in to public outrage over their plans for swingeing charges on cash machines. Abbey National will not charge customers of other banks for using its machines. At the end of the year it will also scrap the £1.50 disloyalty fee to its own customers if they use a 'foreign' machine.
fields.body:
Banks are caving in to public outrage over their plans for swingeing charges on cash machines. Abbey National will not charge customers of other banks for using its machines. At the end of the year it will also scrap the £1.50 disloyalty fee to its own customers if they use a 'foreign' machine.

The move is a victory for the consumer lobby and for Cash, which last year exposed the exorbitant charges banks were planning to introduce. The row started when Barclays announced a £1 surcharge for non-customers. Barclays' plan, announced without consulting other members of the Link cash machine network, would have led to double charging for some customers. Abbey customers using a Barclays machine would have paid £2.50.

Nationwide threatened legal action and the bank postponed its move. Other banks supported Barclays. The banks were attacked by Don Cruickshank, now head of the Stock Exchange, in a Government commissioned report.

Halifax, Nationwide, Bank of Scotland and the Co-operative Bank plan no charge for use of their machines - neither surcharges nor disloyalty fees.

Lloyds TSB plans to charge customers of other banks 50p from next year. Its own customers will pay nothing for using other machines. Barclays is planning a surcharge but has not said what. HSBC will not charge its own customers but has made no decision about others using its machines. NatWest is continuing to charge its customers £1 to use 'foreign' machines but has not said if it will charge customers of other banks.

New cash machine operators are coming into the market with plans to charge fees. Their machines will increasingly appear in shops and other locations where there are none at present.

fields.headline: Co-op must be protected - TUC
fields.trailText: New laws should be passed to protect the Co-op from hostile takeover bids such as the raid launched by entrepreneur Andrew Regan three years ago, according to the Trades Union Congress.
fields.body:
New laws should be passed to protect the Co-op from hostile takeover bids such as the raid launched by entrepreneur Andrew Regan three years ago, according to the Trades Union Congress.

The TUC also argues that a two-tier board should be set up and that the Co-op should move into into the housing market, care provision and financial services.

The calls come in the TUC's submission to the Co-op Commission, launched by Tony Blair in February to review the performance and assess the future of the movement, founded 150 years ago by the Rochdale pioneers.

Although it does not have the profile of the Labour party or trade unions, the Co-op is a vital part of Labour politics. For example, Co-ops are able to vote on party matters and played an important part in the nomination process for London mayor.

The TUC's proposals - one of about 50 submissions received by the Commission so far - are likely to be highly influential because they reflect the views of its general secretary, John Monks, who was appointed by Blair to head the Commission.

The TUC paper was handed in on Wednesday. It says the Co-op - which comprises 47 different mutually owned societies - is failing to attract new customers and members. It adds that it is not being efficient in the areas in which it operates - from food retailing through 1,100 shops owned by the Co-operative Retail and Co-operative Wholesale Societies, to funeral and banking services.

It argues that the Co-op should become more involved in housing because people on average earnings are being priced out of many areas and private and public housing markets do not cater for them. The Co-op should get into 'caring professions', particularly childcare services and even old people's homes.

It also says the Co-op should expand its role in financial services through credit unions, and take advantage of the internet. The document also states: 'The TUC believes the protection of mutuals depends ... on strong legislation.'

A spokesman said: 'Many of the submissions have said there should be a law banning takeovers. We perhaps would not go that far - if a society was struggling it should not be protected. But we certainly want stronger protection in a Co-op Act.'

The TUC views have been backed up at a series of public meetings held to gauge the views of the public and of Co-op members on its future. At a meeting in in Oxford on 17 June, speakers said they felt the organisation was vulnerable to carpetbaggers; measures should be taken to protect it, they said.

fields.headline: Standard Life pledges shake-up
fields.trailText: Standard Life will promise policyholders a shake-up in the way it runs its business if it wins its historic vote on demutualisation on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Standard Life will promise policyholders a shake-up in the way it runs its business if it wins its historic vote on demutualisation on Tuesday.

Management will set out plans to promote the benefits policyholders have received by investing with the mutual. However, the insurer - which has a reputation for arrogance and aloofness in the financial services industry - is resisting special bonuses for policyholders on the basis that this would be interpreted as a bribe.

Friday was the deadline for postal votes in the poll to decide the future of Standard Life, one of the world's largest mutual organisations and a household name in Britain. The final vote will be taken at a special general meeting in Edinburgh on Tuesday.

This weekend, Fred Woollard, the Australian leading the demutualisation push, seemed to have conceded defeat in his bid to turn the mutual into a public company.

Woollard said he did not expect to get the 75% majority in favour of conversion needed to force the board to consider changing status. He forecast windfalls of £5,000 to £6,000 for policyholders; Standard Life management disputed this figure.

Financial Spreads, a City spread-betting firm, was predicting late on Fridya that Woollard would win up to 60% of votes. Earlier it had been predicting a majority of between 58% and 63%. The firm said it believed that more than a million of Standard Life's 2.3 million policyholders had voted.

Woollard said if he did not reach the 75% threshold, he expected to win more than half the vote, forcing Standard Life to review itself: 'Whatever the result on 27 June, I believe Standard Life will not return to its relatively sleepy existence.'

Woollard has said he may stand for the board of the insurer next year but said he and his supporters would wait on their next move. 'We are not going away, and whatever we do next will probably not happen quickly.'

Stewart Stevenson, the retired Bank of Scotland director who has led a campaign to keep Standard Life mutual, predicted victory for management but said it should do more to develop mutual ownership. He said management should ask policyholders about this.

Standard Life refused to comment on the vote, but a source said: 'I you have been trhough something like this, only a fool would not have picked up some lessons.'

fields.headline: Phone rangers fight for rights
fields.standfirst: Call centres had a reputation as 'telephone sweatshops', but that may be changing, says  Jim Pollard
fields.trailText: Call centres had a reputation as 'telephone sweatshops', but that may be changing, says Jim Pollard
fields.body:
They are first-jobbers. They earn just £4.69 an hour. They get no shift allowance. They get little training. And, at 3 o'clock in the morning, they could be answering your 999 call.

'The building was unfit. The heating and ventilation were poor and it was infested with fleas.' This is Dougie Rafferty, who worked as a 999 operator and spoke out about conditions in his Glasgow call centre. Six months later there is still no code of practice for emergency calls and the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) is investigating call centres generally.

These are defined by the HSE as work environments in which the main business is conducted over the phone by a handler also using display screen equipment. They usually operate on a contract basis, handling calls for clients across several industries. Rafferty, for example, worked for Excell Multimedia, handling emergency calls on behalf of Cable and Wireless Communications (CWC).

Telebusiness is growing at 40 per cent a year - 40 per cent more piped music and 'putting you on hold'. Occasionally, it can be more than merely irritating. Oftel, which regulates telephone services, was forced to investigate CWC's 999 call handling procedures after emergency services were provided with incorrect addresses (see box below).

Oftel still has no formal code of practice with carriers handling emergency calls. Even if a code is introduced, it will not cover competence or training. 'We can't influence a company's relationship with employees,' Oftel's spokes person admitted. 'We monitor quality, not terms of employment.'

But concern is increasingly focused on terms of employment. The Government reckons that by 2002 there will be more people working in call centres in the UK than there will be teachers and farmers put together.

When Rafferty went public this year, things were not looking good. 'There was no sick pay, so you'd get people coming in with streaming colds and passing them on. One guy had an epileptic fit and had his pay docked for time spent in the ambulance and hospital. Staff turnover was at least 125 per cent.'

Call centres have even created their own industrial injury. Solicitor Adrian Fawden, who acts for the Communications Workers Union, has dealt with dozens of cases of acoustic shock. 'A sudden loud noise down the headset can cause long-term tinnitus - ringing in the ear - and over-sensitivity to noise,' he says. 'It's the shock as much as the volume.'

Despite this, a joint TUC/Royal National Institute for Deaf People survey found that nine out of 10 call centre staff had had no training in the risks of noise. Fawden warns: 'Technology is running ahead of safety with software constantly being upgraded to handle more calls.'

The HSE began its examination following the RNID/TUC report and hopes to publish its preliminary findings this summer, but it admits this is a new area. 'Many call centres get away with being pretty awful places to be because of the local labour market,' says the Communications Workers Union regional organiser Donald McDonald. 'Usually they're sited in areas of high unemployment. That's why you get university graduates prepared to work for £9,500 a year.'

However, there is evidence that things are changing. Rafferty's former employer, Excell Multimedia, has lost its £140 million contract to Vertex. 'Typically the worst team or individual was identified and named and shamed in public,' says McDonald. 'It was common practice in the industry, but Vertex has stopped it and staff report a much better atmosphere.'

The new employer, which has 12 centres and 5,000 staff who answer 100 million calls a year, also offered a 4.8 per cent pay rise. 'When we arrived we asked staff what they wanted and they gave us 257 suggestions which we're now looking at with employee rep resentatives,' says Vertex's Janie Hazelwood. 'Our style is not about command and control; it's about our clients' reputations.'

But with sick pay still not provided and no increase in the 15 days' holiday a year, Rafferty, who now works for the Communications Workers Union, is reserving judgment. 'I want to see significant changes in these places.'

So, apparently, does the Call Centre Association (CCA), which represents 430 companies operating 4,500 centres. This month, it is piloting service standards in 24 centres which it hopes will be up and running throughout the industry by next year. 'They'll be about customer service and staff, rather like the Investors In People initiative,' says the CCA's head of quality and standards, Colin Mackay.

Stuart MacMillan Pratt is managing director of The Ops Room, which provides marketing services to companies including Aiwa, Land Rover and Mars. Its 60-station call centre is staffed by a mixture of permanent and temporary staff. 'People are realising that large call factories are impersonal and that smaller units are better,' he says. 'I know all my staff personally. I trust them to organise their breaks within their team. I trust them to handle a call and to know how long it needs to last.' MacMillan Pratt argues that the proof of the pudding is that 80 per cent of his permanent staff started as temps.

Customer contact should be based on training, not on scripts, he says. 'We offer training in basic skills and also in the specific products. Our staff don't just know about Land Rovers, they've actually been off-road driving one.'

At the end of this year the CCA will change its name to the Call and Contact Centre Association to reflect the growth of e-commerce. Mackay believes this development is good for call centre staff. 'Call centres won't be killed off by the growth of the internet,' he says, 'but they will change. They'll have to become involved in a wider range of activities, which will increase opportunities for staff and should make the work more interesting.'

Just how much more interesting is open to debate. Vertex's Hazelwood admits: 'At the end of the day, the job is answering telephones.'

Emergency service or service emergency?

Deregulation of telecoms has made the chain of responsibility for 999 calls more complex. Three companies - BT, Cable and Wireless Communications, and Kingston Communications - handle them in call centres.

It is Oftel's responsibility to ensure that 999 calls are correctly routed and take priority over others. After that, they are the Home Office's responsibility.

Dougie Rafferty, a former 999 operator for CWC, says that as 999 calls aren't profit-making they are not top priority. 'No extra staff were put on for events like Firework Night, and record-keeping was disastrously inadequate.'

In 1998 it was revealed that CWC had dozens of incorrect addresses. The company admitted to eight incidents of inadequate information being passed to the emergency services. Oftel subsequently said it was 'now satisfied' with CWC's address records.

Still only BT routinely provides Oftel with data on matters such as misdirected calls. The other two supply it on request. Oftel wants this formalised, but six months since Rafferty first spoke out, no code has yet been agreed.

'A sudden loud noise down the headset can cause long-term tinnitus - ringing in the ear - and over-sensitivity to noise,' he says. 'It's the shock as much as the volume.' Despite this, a joint TUC/Royal National Institute for Deaf People survey found that nine out of 10 call centre staff had had no training in the risks of noise. Fawden warns: 'Technology is running ahead of safety with software constantly being upgraded to handle more calls.' The HSE began its examination following the RNID/TUC report and hopes to publish its preliminary findings this summer, but it admits this is a new area. 'Many call centres get away with being pretty awful places to be because of the local labour market,' says the Communications Workers Union regional organiser Donald McDonald. 'Usually they're sited in areas of high unemployment. That's why you get university graduates prepared to work for £9,500 a year.' However, there is evidence that things are changing. Rafferty's former employer, Excell Multimedia, has lost its £140 million contract to Vertex. 'Typically the worst team or individual was identified and named and shamed in public,' says McDonald. 'It was common practice in the industry, but Vertex has stopped it and staff report a much better atmosphere.' The new employer, which has 12 centres and 5,000 staff who answer 100 million calls a year, also offered a 4.8 per cent pay rise. 'When we arrived we asked staff what they wanted and they gave us 257 suggestions which we're now looking at with employee rep resentatives,' says Vertex's Janie Hazelwood. 'Our style is not about command and control; it's about our clients' reputations.' But with sick pay still not provided and no increase in the 15 days' holiday a year, Rafferty, who now works for the Communications Workers Union, is reserving judgment. 'I want to see significant changes in these places.' So, apparently, does the Call Centre Association (CCA), which represents 430 companies operating 4,500 centres. This month, it is piloting service standards in 24 centres which it hopes will be up and running throughout the industry by next year. 'They'll be about customer service and staff, rather like the Investors In People initiative,' says the CCA's head of quality and standards, Colin Mackay. Stuart MacMillan Pratt is managing director of The Ops Room, which provides marketing services to companies including Aiwa, Land Rover and Mars. Its 60-station call centre is staffed by a mixture of permanent and temporary staff. 'People are realising that large call factories are impersonal and that smaller units are better,' he says. 'I know all my staff personally. I trust them to organise their breaks within their team. I trust them to handle a call and to know how long it needs to last.' MacMillan Pratt argues that the proof of the pudding is that 80 per cent of his permanent staff started as temps. Customer contact should be based on training, not on scripts, he says. 'We offer training in basic skills and also in the specific products. Our staff don't just know about Land Rovers, they've actually been off-road driving one.' At the end of this year the CCA will change its name to the Call and Contact Centre Association to reflect the growth of e-commerce. Mackay believes this development is good for call centre staff. 'Call centres won't be killed off by the growth of the internet,' he says, 'but they will change. They'll have to become involved in a wider range of activities, which will increase opportunities for staff and should make the work more interesting.' Just how much more interesting is open to debate. Vertex's Hazelwood admits: 'At the end of the day, the job is answering telephones.' Emergency service or service emergency? Deregulation of telecoms has made the chain of responsibility for 999 calls more complex. Three companies - BT, Cable and Wireless Communications, and Kingston Communications - handle them in call centres. It is Oftel's responsibility to ensure that 999 calls are correctly routed and take priority over others. After that, they are the Home Office's responsibility. Dougie Rafferty, a former 999 operator for CWC, says that as 999 calls aren't profit-making they are not top priority. 'No extra staff were put on for events like Firework Night, and record-keeping was disastrously inadequate.' In 1998 it was revealed that CWC had dozens of incorrect addresses. The company admitted to eight incidents of inadequate information being passed to the emergency services. Oftel subsequently said it was 'now satisfied' with CWC's address records. Still only BT routinely provides Oftel with data on matters such as misdirected calls. The other two supply it on request. Oftel wants this formalised, but six months since Rafferty first spoke out, no code has yet been agreed.

webTitle: A warmer winter for all over-60s

fields.headline: A warmer winter for all over-60s
fields.standfirst: I am a 62-year old man in full-time employment. Can you tell me if I am entitled to the Winter Fuel Payment of £150 each year? I understand that men over 60 recently became entitled to it - but I don't know if there is a restriction limiting it just to men who claim benefits.
fields.trailText: I am a 62-year old man in full-time employment. Can you tell me if I am entitled to the Winter Fuel Payment of £150 each year? I understand that men over 60 recently became entitled to it - but I don't know if there is a restriction limiting it just to men who claim benefits.
fields.body:
Yes, you are eligible. The Government relaxed the rules on 16 November last year. Since then everyone over the age of 60 qualifies for the payment 'regardless of whether they are claiming a pension or one or another qualifying benefit,' according to the Department of Social Security.

But before this date, only people of pensionable age - 60 for women, 65 for men - were eligible, and they also had to be receiving the basic state pension - or some other benefit.

There are some restrictions, though. Only one Winter Fuel Payment is made per household. The timing of a potential claimant's birthday is important too. Although the payment is made in December, the qualifying date is the September before - this year in the week starting 18 September.

In your case, it is possible that you could qualify for a rebate for last year. The DSS will backdate payments to 1997 if you met the age requirement for all or some of that period.

 For more information on how to claim, ring the DSS helpline on 08459 151515.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.
