fields.headline: Italy 2 - 0 Romania
fields.trailText: Italy: Francesco Toldo, Paolo Maldini (captain), Fabion Cannavaro, Alessandro Nesta, Mark Iuliano; Antonio Conte, Gianluca Zambrotta, Demetrio Albertini, Stefano Fiore; Filippo Inzaghi, Francesco Totti.
fields.body:
Italy: Francesco Toldo, Paolo Maldini (captain), Fabion Cannavaro, Alessandro Nesta, Mark Iuliano; Antonio Conte, Gianluca Zambrotta, Demetrio Albertini, Stefano Fiore; Filippo Inzaghi, Francesco Totti.

Romania: Bogdan Stelea, Cristian Chivu, Liviu Ciobotariu, Iulian Filipescu, Miodrag Belodedici; Dorinel Munteanu, Florentin Petre, Constantin Galca, Gheorghe Hagi (captain); Viorel Moldovan, Adrian Mutu.

Referee: Vitor Manuel Melo Pereira (Portugal)

1 min Here we go. Romania kick off and we can expect everything to go through the shaven-headed Hagi.

2 A free kick from the right for Italy, taken by Cannavaro, easily claimed by Stelea in the Romanian goal.

5 An early ball over the top by Totti seeks out Inzaghi, who (surprise, surprise) has wandered oh... 20 yards offside. Learn the rules, boy!

8 Mister Sitter. Fiore, played in by Totti on the left, squares to the offside specialist, Inzaghi, who contrives to miss the target from 10 yards. Italians everywhere will be shaking their heads in amazement.

11 Hagi stands over a free kick 30 yards out centre-left. His rising drive clears the four-man wall by 10 feet and 21 players stare at the ball sail into the crowd, whilst Hagi stares at the ground.

13 Stelea almost handles outside his area, but some sleight-of-hand ensures that the Romanian keeper gets away with it.

14 A cross delivered by Hagi on the left, aimed at Mutu. Two Italian defenders double-team to clear, but for the first time since their opening game against Turkey, the Italian defence looks suspect.

17 The Romanians are giving away a lot of possession in their half of the pitch, which is ominous considering that they're playing Italy, not England. Romania already seem content to try and score on the break, letting the Azzuri come at them. A dangerous tactic, if ever there was one.

18 A corner to Romania from the left, rolled out to Galca to have a crack. He does, and it's almost a carbon-copy of Hagi's earlier effort. A cow's arse and a banjo spring to mind...

22 Conte released through the middle by Totti, who is playing a deeper, playmaking role. Stelea gets there just in time, and manages to find touch with his clearance.

24 For a delicious second, Moldovan sees daylight between him and the Italian goal. Iuliano, the Juventus defender, ghosts in to dispossess the Romanian forward and the door is promptly slammed shut. The Azzuri looking more solid at the back.

27 The game is slowing up and it needs an incident, a booking or something, to raise passions. The ball has been pinging around the midfield for a few minutes now.

29 Totti picks out Inzaghi wide right and miraculously onside. His first-time cross is a good one and Fiore, with more time that he thought he had, slashes at the half-volley with comical results. Last time I looked the ball was still rising...

29m 30s It's started coming down now.

32 Totti again the provider, a long, high ball for Inzaghi to chase. Belodedici, beaten for pace, betters the Italian with brawn. If the Italians try that five, six times, eventually it'll work. But Inzaghi'll probably miss anyway.

33 GOAL! Italy 1 - 0 Romania So clinical. A cross is cleared by Belodedici as far as Fiore centre-left, who chips it back in to Totti on the left of the Romanian area. A chest, an elegant sweep with the right leg and the ball disappears under Stelea as Totti disappears under a pile of blue shirts.

35 Almost the perfect retort by Hagi, played in by Mutu down the right. Confronted by an advancing Toldo, the maestro lobs the ball over the keeper only to be denied by the far upright.

36 Back down the other end now as Totti goes close to doubling Italy's lead, his right-foot flick shot just drifting wide of Stelea's left-hand post.

38 Albertini booked for an agricultural hack on Hagi.

40 Hagi latches on to a cleared cross, but he's still feeling the Albertini challenge and elects to pass the ball out to Galca. His piledriver from 25 yards just bends the wrong side of the left post with Toldo well beaten.

43 GOAL!! Italy 2 - 0 Romania Albertini's drilled pass ricochets off Mutu and becomes a perfect through-ball for Inzaghi, clear on the right. Four paces brings him face-to-face with Stelea, and his finish is a smooth as you'd expect. From Baggio. A nice way to end a year-long goal drought.

44 Hagi again, trying to reply in kind, drives a shot from 25 yards straight into Toldo's arms.

46 Half time: Italy 2 - 0 Romania.

Second half

45 Italy restart the contest. Maldini has been substituted, with Pessotto on in his place.

48 Romania, understandably, have started with more urgency. Hagi tries a speculative effort from 40 yards (to no avail). The clearance appears to send Inzaghi clean through, but the offside flag thwarts the Italian again This time the decision looked a little harsh.

51 Nesta lucky to escape with a verbal ticking-off after halting Munteanu's surging run down the right channel. The free kick is wasted and possession is lost. The Italian back three looks very, very solid.

55 A brutal challenge by Hagi on Conte, which earns the veteran a booking. Meanwhile subsitute Ganea comes on for Moldovan.

56 Hagi's challenge has ended Conte's participation. As the stricken midfielder is stretchered off, substitute Di Biaggio takes his place.

57 It's all happening as Ganea has a half-chance, but the space is extinguished by Nesta. Iuliano has been poleaxed and is recovering off the pitch.

59 Iuliano is back on, and the Italians need all hands on deck as Romania come sweeping forward.

60 Red card ...for two bookable offences, Hagi is sent from the pitch for 'diving' in the Italian area, played through by Ganea. Zambrotta appeared to be tugging his shirt. A very harsh decision that probably ends this brilliant midfielder's international career. Can't see a way back for Romania.

63 Free kick to Romania on the right, near the corner flag. The ball falls to Ciobotariu at the far post, and the strike is goalbound but cannons off and Italian leg. The follow-up shot is deflected for a corner. The set-piece is wasted, and Romanian heads start to sag.

68 Mutu in a one-on-one with Toldo at the near (left) post. Toldo gathers at the Romanian's feet, and Mutu takes the full force of the keeper's boot in the ribs.

69 Albertini spots Inzaghi in space and (miracle of miracles) onside. The ball is flicked over and the striker pulls it down with the right foot and drills a powerful volley from 20 yards. Stelea, at full stretch, makes an amazing save to push the ball onto the right upright. Romania lucky not to be three down.

70 Substitute Lupescu replaces Galca for Romania.

74 Ganea wins a free kick centre-right, 25 yards out. Munteanu's effort clears the wall and the running track. Poor.

75 It's the one the fans wanted to see. Totti is substituted and Del Piero saunters on to an ovation.

78 Albertini is pulling the strings in midfield and a great reverse ball lets in Inzaghi on the left. The profligate striker puts it wide of the near post when scoring seemed easier.

81 Romania are becoming more and more frustrated as Italy choke the life out of the game.

83 Inzaghi pulled down 30 yards out centre-right. Del Piero will fancy this one. The Italian is leaning back as he strikes it, and if they doubled the dimensions of the goal it would still have sailed over. A disappointment.

86 A corner to Italy on the right. Del Piero takes, but the flat trajectory is food and drink to this Romanian defence. Italy are just playing out time, and Romania look like they wish it was all over.

89 Ganea up-ended in the Italian area and the referee motions play on. No protests from the team in yellow - they look like they know that the fates are not on their side tonight.

90 Three extra minutes. A free kick on the right touchline to Romania. Mutu, who has stood out since the dismissal of Hagi, gets his head to the ball but the direction is lacking.

93 Full time: Italy 2 - 0 Romania.

fields.headline: Hague embraces Lords reform
fields.trailText: William Hague is poised to outflank Labour on democratic reform by embracing a largely elected             second chamber and sweeping changes designed to make the executive - and specifically the prime             minister - fully accountable to parliament.
fields.body:
William Hague is poised to outflank Labour on democratic reform by embracing a largely elected second chamber and sweeping changes designed to make the executive - and specifically the prime minister - fully accountable to parliament.

The Tory leader is preparing in the next fortnight to publish a 25,000-word report prepared for him by a commission headed by the distinguished political scientist Lord Norton.

The report, "Strengthening Parliament", is intended to make the Commons - currently often deserted - the focal point of British political life again.

The Norton commission will recommend:

 stronger select committees free of the control of party whips

 new powers for the Lords to block the fast-growing use of subsidiary legislation

 a requirement that the prime minister regularly open set-piece debates

 television cameras to be given more freedom to film inside parliament and interview MPs inside the Palace of Westminster

 the prime minister to be required to appear in front of select committees

 prime minister's questions, which were made weekly by Tony Blair, to revert to a twice-weekly event

 MPs to be given powers to scrutinise and even block items of departmental spending.

The commission may also propose reform of the finance bill, which implements the Budget, so that scrutiny of technical and political issues is divided.

More draft government bills would be subject to full scrutiny by experts cross-examined by MPs.

The commission is also expected to recommend that select committees be given more resources so they are more closely modelled on US congressional committees.

Committee reports would also be regularly debated in the Commons, forcing the government to give a full response to criticisms expressed by all-party bodies.

Party whips would be banned from controlling membership of committees, giving MPs an alternative to seeking a career as a minister.

Rules to ensure that ministers only made substantial announcements to the Commons, rather than on television or radio, would also be tightened.

In a separate move, the Conservatives are now expected to support a second chamber in which half the members are elected.

Sir George Young, shadow leader of the Commons, said this week that the Tories would support a higher percentage of elected members than the 30% maximum proposed by the Wakeham commission. Conservative MPs expect Mr Hague to increase the figure to 50%.

Labour, fearing undue conflict between the Commons and a democratic upper house, appears to favour only 100 elected members.

Although there will be some cynicism about Mr Hague 's plans in view of Lady Thatcher and John Major's treatment of parliament, the Tory leader believes the Commons' scrutiny role can be improved.

Labour sources said it was easy for political parties to promise in opposition to make life difficult for themselves if elected, but then not to act on their promises. The current decline in parliament's importance is partly a function of the government's large majority.

Lord Norton himself said: "The idea is to have a full programme of reform ready which could be implemented right at the start of the parliament. History shows that reform has to be implemented at the start of parliament, or else the impetus falters."

Mr Hague has promised to implement the broad reform package within weeks if he were elected.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Centre court | Theatre of dreams | Reel thing
fields.body:
Centre court
The opening of Van Kampen Gardens at Hampton Court, Herefordshire, is marked by a midsummer festival weekend of non-stop music, theatre and children's workshops.

 Open Sat 11am-11pm, Sun 11am-5pm. Wed-Sun 1pm-5pm. Admission £5/under 6 free/6-13 £3/family £12. Hope-under-Dinmore, Leominster (01568 797777).

Theatre of dreams
Visit the home dressing room on an hour's tour of Manchester United, then linger in the museum.

 Open 9.30am-5pm daily. Tours 9.40am-4.30pm, book in advance or on day, 0161-868 8631. Museum only: £5/£3.50/family £14; with tour £8/ £5.50/family £22. Sir Matt Busby Way, Old Trafford, Manchester.

Reel thing
Scotland's Royal Highland Show highlights the agricultural calendar, with pedigree livestock, flowers, showjumping and crafts.

 Open Sat 7am-8pm, Sun 8am-7pm. Admission: Sat £15/£7.50, Sun £12.50/£7. Between A8 and Edinburgh Airport (0900 8030 444).

Brunel's kingdom
Steam, the museum of the Great Western Railway, tells the story of the GWR through famous locomotives, live actors and posters.

 Open daily 10am-6pm, 8pm on Thurs. Admission £4.80/£3/family £13. Kemble Drive, Swindon, Wilts (01793 466646).

Wild West
Find Sumatran tigers in Forest zone, the cheetah in Savannah zone and the Ape Centre discreetly camouflaged at Paignton Zoo Environmental Park.

 Open daily 10am-6pm. Admission £6/£4.90/family £21.80. Totnes Road, Paignton, Devon (01803 527936).

Country living
The two-day annual Middlesex County Show brings out the best of British farming, with arts, crafts, showjumping, morris dancing, falconry and veteran cars to boot.

 Open Sat/Sun 9.30am-6pm. Admission Sat £6/£2.50; Sun £7/£3. The Showground, Park Road, Uxbridge (020-8866 1367).

Hip hop

fields.headline: Combe House, Exeter
fields.trailText:
Address: Combe House, Gittisham, Nr Honiton, Exeter, Devon EX14 3AD
Tel: 01404 540400.
Web address: www.thishotel.co.uk
fields.body:
Address: Combe House, Gittisham, Nr Honiton, Exeter, Devon EX14 3AD
Tel: 01404 540400.
Web address: www.thishotel.co.uk

First impressions: Grade I listed Elizabethan manor with dark wood panelling, antique furniture and 400 years of family portraits. But surprisingly unstuffy, friendly and informal.

What are the rooms like? Stone mullioned windows with spectacular views. Japanese lilies. Locally-made patchwork quilts. No chintz.

The bed test: Deeply comfortable, soft without sag, enormous.

The bathroom test: Candles, gilt mirrors. Suitably luxurious.

The restaurant: State-of-the-art modern cooking. Nouvelle cuisine with proper portions. Lunch £10-£16, dinner from £28.50. And worth it.

What is there to see within walking distance? Rolling hills, woodland walks. Gittisham is the kind of village usually found on chocolate boxes and jigsaw puzzles.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? That's just long enough to get lost in the winding Devon lanes.

How much a night? Suites/ master bedrooms from £225 a night. Singles £80.

Would you go back? Whenever my bank manager permits, which sadly won't be often. It would be just the place for a stop-over on the way to Cornwall.

fields.headline: Cash without frontiers
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor finds the sites that will help you ensure a healthy cash flow abroad
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor finds the sites that will help you ensure a healthy cash flow abroad
fields.body:
Universal Currency Converter
There are plenty of currency converters on the web, but not all of them offer 180 currencies. The UCC enables conversions from the Ecuadorean sucre to the Kazakhstani tenge (as well as the euro) and rates are updated every minute.

Travel on Demand
Many countries impose restrictions on the amount of foreign or local currency that visitors can import and export. (In the case of Russia, you cannot order roubles in advance of the trip, nor take them home with you.) This site details all such restrictions.

American Express International ATM Locator
Those who have ensured their Amex card is affiliated to the Express Cash programme can use this site to find out which cashpoints will accept it. Rather than displaying a list, customers need to look for, say, the Bank of Guam logo on an ATM. Some of the logos are displayed, and printing them out for your purse or wallet might prove useful.

International ATM Locator
Another site that promises much but fails to deliver, the Barclays ATM finder lists each country, but clicking on them elicited no response. It is, however, possible to compare the cost of using a Barclays Connect card in Greece, France, Italy, Spain and the US.

Chequepoint
An initially flashy site that proves cumbersome to use. To arrange a money transfer, for example, visitors fill in an online form. Chequepoint then sends a quotation and Bank Transfer Form by e-mail, which you fill in, print out, sign and deliver or fax to your bank. Delivery only takes place once your bank has approved the transaction. It's difficult to estimate just how long all this might take, but it's unlikely to be much use if you're stranded penniless in the Far East. This is online ordering for its own sake, and not worth the hassle involved.

Thomas Cook Currency
A hefty handling fee of £5 (but no commission) and fairly competitive exchange rates make this an efficient way of ordering currency and traveller's cheques, which are then delivered by post.

webTitle: Michael Eavis: I lost my heart in... Hanoi

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Hanoi
fields.standfirst: Michael Eavis
fields.trailText: Michael Eavis
fields.body:
Why: In 1996, I went to Hanoi with my late wife Jane and we took a day off from our Oxfam duties, got on a bus without knowing where we were going and travelled for miles and miles down bumpy roads. The journey was uncomfortable and, at first, we didn't know if we had made the right decision. But we arrived in this place full of lakes and mountains, got a flat boat with Vietnamese ladies punting and set off down this incredibly shallow water through the mountains. We had to lie flat on our backs in some places because there was only about 18 inches clearance - it was like going through a tunnel, but at the end were sunlit lakes full of ducks and flying geese and surrounded by willows.

When we got back to Hanoi, we asked other people about this place, but no one had any idea where it could be. All I know is that is was about 50 miles from Hanoi going east, and that it was the most beautiful and unique place I have ever seen.

What's the best thing? The beauty of not knowing the name of this place and the fact that we did not know where we were going when we set off. One day, I will go back and find this mysterious place again. I also loved the Vietnamese. They don't harbour any malice towards westerners and are actually proud of driving the US out.

My advice? Find this bus going to this place and come back and tell me the name of it. Failing that, simply get on any bus from Hanoi and go out into the countryside, see the mountains and enjoy the spirit of the Vietnamese. Despite the fact that people don't have the things we have, they don't complain, but get on with life.

How do I get there? Kuoni Travel (01306 747000) has 15 nights including all accommodation and transfers from £1,179.20, flights via Bangkok.

 Michael Eavis hosts the Glastonbury festival this weekend.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Advice from fellow readers
fields.body:
Linnea Glynne-Rule wanted to know if she could get a cargo boat to New York.

My daughter travelled on a container ship from Thamesport to Montreal and back with Canada Maritime, booked through Strand Voyages. She had a wonderful time. There are passages to New York from Thamesport available through Strand Voyages and also The Cruise People. Good sailing

Sandra West.

 Strand Voyages (020-7836 6363) is the booking agent for various companies that run cargo boats. Ships to New York and Norfolk, Virginia, are full for the next few months. Montreal costs £995pp one way, for a 10-day journey via Antwerp and Le Havre. The Cruise People (020-7723 2450) has spaces to Staten Island from Thamesport costing approximately £1,125pp in a double cabin. The boat can be picked up in Le Havre.

This week's question

We are considering travelling to Thailand in the first two weeks of October for our honeymoon. Will the weather be okay? Our plans are to fly into Bangkok and then travel onto Chang-Mai and Ko Samui. Any info?
GC

fields.headline: Portugal 2 - 0 Turkey
fields.trailText: Portugal: Baia, Costa, Couto, Dimas, Figo, Rui Costa, Conceicao, Costinha, Bento, Pinto, Gomes. Subs: Espinha, Quim, Jorge, Vidigal, Sousa, Sa Pinto, Xavier, Beto, Pauleta, Secretario.
fields.body:
Portugal: Baia, Costa, Couto, Dimas, Figo, Rui Costa, Conceicao, Costinha, Bento, Pinto, Gomes. Subs: Espinha, Quim, Jorge, Vidigal, Sousa, Sa Pinto, Xavier, Beto, Pauleta, Secretario.

Turkey Recber, Akyel, Penbe, Temizkanoglu, Ozalan, Unsal, Korkut, Buruk, Havutcu, Erdem, Sukur. Subs: Catkic, Tuncay, Yalcin, Ozkoylu, Kaya, Izzet, Derelioglu, Akman, Ercan.

Referee: D Jol (Holland)

1 minute Kick off! After carefully playing the ball around, the Turkish defence then carelessly lose it. Immediately Dimas swirls in a fantastic cross to the far post which is headed behind. But from the resulting corner Coult climbs all over his marker. Free kick to Turkey!

3 Turkey have their first effort on goal. But Okan's limp header goes well wide.

7 Rui Costa plays a one-two off Pinto and looks ready to let one go from 20 yards out - but then he's tackled from behind. It's a foul, surely? No, says the referee and Turkey break. So far the game has been fast-paced and attacking - there's no sign that either team are playing for a draw

10 Figo makes his first contribution, out on the left. But after his cross is blocked he falls awkwardly while challenging for the bouncing ball. Fortunately for Portugal he seems OK.

13 Portugal are doing all the pressing - with Rui Costa and Figo making magic every time they get the ball. Figo again drifts out onto the left but his cross drifts just past the back stick.

15 So far there's been plenty of good football but not many chances. Rui Costa wins a corner. The ball in looks dangerous, but Recber comes out and makes the best take of the tournament.

17 Turkey aren't playing badly, but Portugal are having all the possession. Rui Costa - the man's everywhere at the moment! - fires in a shot with dangerous intent but it is blocked by Okan.

20 A corner comes in and the ball drops to Costinha six yards out. Time seems to stand still. He must score. No!!!! It's brilliantly saved by the Galatasaray reserve keeper Recber, who has to receive treatment for an injury he's sustained around the rib-cage.

24 Figo dribbles it past two Turkish defenders - with skill rarely since Stanley Matthews retired - and then leashes a 25 yard shot which goes just wide. It's all Portugal at the moment. Surely a goal can't be far away?

27 At last Turkey get a respite and win a free kick about 40 yards out. The ball's launched in and Victor Baia hesistates. It's coming straight to Hakan Sukur, 15 yards out. Can he get it on target? Oh no his header's gone over.

28 Yellow card! Joao Pinto is the culprit. But the Turkish fellow dived and then rolled about five times, and the decision was definitely harsh.

30 RED CARD!!! Alpay is sent off for aiming a punch a Cuoto. No contact is made whatsoever, but Cuoto clutches his nose like he's been pole-axed by Mike Tyson.

32 Yellow card! Okan is booked for a foul. The Turks look unhappy. And who can blame them - they've weathered the Portuguese storm and now they're down to 10 men.

34 Turkey have definitely changed their formation following the sending-off. They've now playing a 4-3-2 rather than their usual 3-5-2.

36 All credit to Turkey - they are tackling like demons and still coming forward. Arif exchanges a delicious one-two with Hakan Sukur, but he's just offside. If anything Turkey have had their best spell since they were reduced to ten men.

38 Yellow card! Cuoto is booked for Portugal. Anyone who has bought the number of bookings and sending offs in this game would have made a fortune by now!

39 Yellow card!. Rui Costa for dissent to linesman.

40 Another yellow card!! This time it's Costinha. Did anyone mention a house in Barbados?

42 Portugal get a corner. Recber goes on one of his first game walkabouts but Costinha fluffs his header - from six yards - just wide. He could have scored two by now!

43 GOAL! Portugal take the lead!!!! A perfect cross is flighted in from Figo and Gomes cushions in a terrific header in from eight yards.

45 And it's very nearly two. Figo plays it to Rui Costa who coasts past a defender and gets to the touchline. But Joao Pinto misses from eight yards.

First half injury time There's supposed to be four added minutes, but a clash of heads means that it will go on several minutes longer. Suddenly Couto challenges Arif and it's a penalty to Turkey!!! Did Cuoto get a touch on the ball? Quite possibly, but it was very risky sliding in from behind. So it will be Arif to step up. Can he level the scores?

NO!!!!! Victor Baia has saved it!!! Arif smashes it straight down the middle and Baia blocks it brilliantly. The ball drops to Sukur, but under a challenge from Cuoto he can't control it and Baia cleans up.

Half-time Portugal 1 Turkey 0. Five yellow cards, a sending-off and a missed penalty! All-in-all not a bad half.

46 Substitution: Paolo Sosa is on for Costinha

49 Figo lays it off to Rui Costa - but his shot is heroically blocked. The resulting corner is cleared, but immediately Portugal get it straight back, and Figo scampers down the left and drills in a lovely low cross which Gomes is only inches away from.

51 Turkey get a corner which Baia flaps at hopelessly. The ball drops to Akyel about six yards out, but from a difficult position his shot goes over.

54 Another Portugal corner. It's cleared to Arif who takes it past three players before he is tackled.

55 GOAL!!!! 2-0 Portugal. Figo pops on the right, plays it beautifully past Unsal and then takes it into the box. He has time to look up before rolling a ball across the six-yard box to Gomes who makes no mistake.

57 Turkey's heads are going down - and they have only got 10 men. Surely it's all over now.

59 And it's nearly 3-0. Pinto fires just wide from 20 yards.

60 Yellow card! Paulo Sosa gets one for a nothing challenge. Is the referee trying to beat some kind of record? Call Norris MacWhirter now, because he might be needed.

62 Turkey make two substitutes: Arif for Suat and Oktay for Okan.

64 It's becoming too easy for Portugal now. Rui Costa and Figo are irresistible - well certainly for the Turkish defence at any rate - and fine player from the former sets up Gomez 20 yards out. Will he score a hat-trick? Not with a shot like that he won't....

67 What a miss!!! Portugal get a corner and the ball is flicked on to Paulo Sosa, three yards out. There's no Turk near him, and he must score....but instead he fluffs the ball across the goal and Gomes is unable to pick up the pieces.

70 Again Gomes misses a chance of a hat-trick. Figo is producing Beckham-like crosses for fun at the moment. But Gomes knocks it wide from six yards.

72 Portugal have got the extra man and they're stretching Turkey all over the place. It's all too easy. Enterprising play sets up Rui Costa for a volley from 20 yards out, but it's well saved.

74 Portugal substitute: Sa Pinto comes on for Gomes.

76 And he immediately runs 50 yards without a challenge. But his shot from 20 yards is easily saved. Luis Figo, who ran half the length of the pitch to support him does not look at all happy.

78 Turkey ,make a rare excursion into the Portuguese half - but the cross goes over Sukur's head.

79 Turkey win a free kick on the corner of the penalty box. It's curled in towards goal, but it hits Dimas and Baia clears up. Turkey are definitely coming into the game a little bit more as Portugal drop back - but surely it's too late.

82 Yellow card! Ogan gets one for confronting the assistant referee.

83 Baia fluffs his clearance straight to Hakan Unsal about 40 yards out. Will he try a Beckham? Oh yes he does, but it just floats over the bar. Baia just about had it covered though...

84 Turkey substitute: Sergen comes on for Ogun.

88 It's like an exhibition match now. Every time Portugal attack it's three against three. All credit to Turkey though, they are still coming forward and Baia has to react smartly to smother a cross. Can't see it being another Spain v Yugoslavia though...

90 Figo free kick 25 yards centre-left, hits the wall and the maestro drills the ricochet swerving and dipping just over the bar.

92 Full time: Portugal 2 - 0 Turkey. On the balance of play, the better team won. Portugal will have to play better in the semi-finals.

It's brilliantly saved by the Galatasaray reserve keeper Recber, who has to receive treatment for an injury he's sustained around the rib-cage. 24 Figo dribbles it past two Turkish defenders - with skill rarely since Stanley Matthews retired - and then leashes a 25 yard shot which goes just wide. It's all Portugal at the moment. Surely a goal can't be far away? 27 At last Turkey get a respite and win a free kick about 40 yards out. The ball's launched in and Victor Baia hesistates. It's coming straight to Hakan Sukur, 15 yards out. Can he get it on target? Oh no his header's gone over. 28 Yellow card! Joao Pinto is the culprit. But the Turkish fellow dived and then rolled about five times, and the decision was definitely harsh. 30 RED CARD!!! Alpay is sent off for aiming a punch a Cuoto. No contact is made whatsoever, but Cuoto clutches his nose like he's been pole-axed by Mike Tyson. 32 Yellow card! Okan is booked for a foul. The Turks look unhappy. And who can blame them - they've weathered the Portuguese storm and now they're down to 10 men. 34 Turkey have definitely changed their formation following the sending-off. They've now playing a 4-3-2 rather than their usual 3-5-2. 36 All credit to Turkey - they are tackling like demons and still coming forward. Arif exchanges a delicious one-two with Hakan Sukur, but he's just offside. If anything Turkey have had their best spell since they were reduced to ten men. 38 Yellow card! Cuoto is booked for Portugal. Anyone who has bought the number of bookings and sending offs in this game would have made a fortune by now! 39 Yellow card!. Rui Costa for dissent to linesman. 40 Another yellow card!! This time it's Costinha. Did anyone mention a house in Barbados? 42 Portugal get a corner. Recber goes on one of his first game walkabouts but Costinha fluffs his header - from six yards - just wide. He could have scored two by now! 43 GOAL! Portugal take the lead!!!! A perfect cross is flighted in from Figo and Gomes cushions in a terrific header in from eight yards. 45 And it's very nearly two. Figo plays it to Rui Costa who coasts past a defender and gets to the touchline. But Joao Pinto misses from eight yards. First half injury time There's supposed to be four added minutes, but a clash of heads means that it will go on several minutes longer. Suddenly Couto challenges Arif and it's a penalty to Turkey!!! Did Cuoto get a touch on the ball? Quite possibly, but it was very risky sliding in from behind. So it will be Arif to step up. Can he level the scores? NO!!!!! Victor Baia has saved it!!! Arif smashes it straight down the middle and Baia blocks it brilliantly. The ball drops to Sukur, but under a challenge from Cuoto he can't control it and Baia cleans up. Half-time Portugal 1 Turkey 0. Five yellow cards, a sending-off and a missed penalty! All-in-all not a bad half. 46 Substitution: Paolo Sosa is on for Costinha 49 Figo lays it off to Rui Costa - but his shot is heroically blocked. The resulting corner is cleared, but immediately Portugal get it straight back, and Figo scampers down the left and drills in a lovely low cross which Gomes is only inches away from. 51 Turkey get a corner which Baia flaps at hopelessly. The ball drops to Akyel about six yards out, but from a difficult position his shot goes over. 54 Another Portugal corner. It's cleared to Arif who takes it past three players before he is tackled. 55 GOAL!!!! 2-0 Portugal. Figo pops on the right, plays it beautifully past Unsal and then takes it into the box. He has time to look up before rolling a ball across the six-yard box to Gomes who makes no mistake. 57 Turkey's heads are going down - and they have only got 10 men. Surely it's all over now. 59 And it's nearly 3-0. Pinto fires just wide from 20 yards. 60 Yellow card! Paulo Sosa gets one for a nothing challenge. Is the referee trying to beat some kind of record? Call Norris MacWhirter now, because he might be needed. 62 Turkey make two substitutes: Arif for Suat and Oktay for Okan. 64 It's becoming too easy for Portugal now. Rui Costa and Figo are irresistible - well certainly for the Turkish defence at any rate - and fine player from the former sets up Gomez 20 yards out. Will he score a hat-trick? Not with a shot like that he won't.... 67 What a miss!!! Portugal get a corner and the ball is flicked on to Paulo Sosa, three yards out. There's no Turk near him, and he must score....but instead he fluffs the ball across the goal and Gomes is unable to pick up the pieces. 70 Again Gomes misses a chance of a hat-trick. Figo is producing Beckham-like crosses for fun at the moment. But Gomes knocks it wide from six yards. 72 Portugal have got the extra man and they're stretching Turkey all over the place. It's all too easy. Enterprising play sets up Rui Costa for a volley from 20 yards out, but it's well saved. 74 Portugal substitute: Sa Pinto comes on for Gomes. 76 And he immediately runs 50 yards without a challenge. But his shot from 20 yards is easily saved. Luis Figo, who ran half the length of the pitch to support him does not look at all happy. 78 Turkey ,make a rare excursion into the Portuguese half - but the cross goes over Sukur's head. 79 Turkey win a free kick on the corner of the penalty box. It's curled in towards goal, but it hits Dimas and Baia clears up. Turkey are definitely coming into the game a little bit more as Portugal drop back - but surely it's too late. 82 Yellow card! Ogan gets one for confronting the assistant referee. 83 Baia fluffs his clearance straight to Hakan Unsal about 40 yards out. Will he try a Beckham? Oh yes he does, but it just floats over the bar. Baia just about had it covered though... 84 Turkey substitute: Sergen comes on for Ogun. 88 It's like an exhibition match now. Every time Portugal attack it's three against three. All credit to Turkey though, they are still coming forward and Baia has to react smartly to smother a cross. Can't see it being another Spain v Yugoslavia though... 90 Figo free kick 25 yards centre-left, hits the wall and the maestro drills the ricochet swerving and dipping just over the bar. 92 Full time: Portugal 2 - 0 Turkey. On the balance of play, the better team won. Portugal will have to play better in the semi-finals.

fields.headline: GPS
fields.trailText: Global positioning system.
fields.body:
GPS? Global positioning system.

What does it do? Tells you where you are - within 100 yards.

Do I care? Not if you're walking down the high street. But you might, if you were lost in the mountains or sinking in the Channel.

What does it give you? A grid reference, usually, or latitude and longitude. Also distance travelled, speed and time to destination.

Not a substitute for map-reading, then? No. It helps you plot your own way out of trouble or give a precise location to the rescue services.

How does it work? By picking up radio signals from US military satellites.

A bit like those nifty Cruise missiles? Sort of. They've degraded the signal for you and me, though. The military version is really pinpoint.

What's the physics? They locate microwaves from four different satellites and plot them against each other.

Sounds expensive. You can get a good one for £150. Some are less than £100. The price has dropped tenfold in 10 years.

Who makes them? Garmin and Magellan are the market leaders.

Where do I buy them? Electronics and specialist outdoor shops: or see "dealer locator" on www.garmin.com or www.magellangps.com

Points to watch: Avoid models with only one or two receivers: multi-channel systems are more reliable and quicker.

Do they work everywhere? Efficiency is reduced among high buildings and in deep canyons, rain forests and heavy snowfalls.

What's the alternative? Carry a sextant; get lost.

webTitle: Essential Spanish for Kids, Essential French for Kids

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: Essential Spanish for Kids, Essential French for Kids (AA Publishing, £3.99)
fields.trailText: Essential Spanish for Kids, Essential French for Kids
fields.body:
Whoever thought the Automobile Association was a subversive organisation? Yet here it is, in black and white. "Warning!" says the back cover. "Don't let your teachers catch you with this book."

Nothing new, of course, about inducing children to do the right thing by telling them that it's a bit naughty. But who cares, so long as it works?

"There are no grammar exercises and no vocabulary tests," say the publishers of these guides. "Just the words and phrases you want to know."

We grown-ups have a name for such things, of course. We call them phrasebooks. But where grown-up phrasebooks have chapters called "Arriving", "Ordering dinner" and "At the bureau de change", these versions, aimed at nine- to 12-year-olds, have "Hanging out", "Looking good" and "Wanna play?"

There are sections on beach talk ("Is this your bucket?"), spending pocket money ("This is rubbish") and electronic games - how many adult phrasebooks contain the words "Am I dead?"?

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Simple tastes | Green issue | Tank tops
fields.body:
Simple tastes
Simply Travel is organising Taste for Travel evenings with food-writer Josceline Dimbleby at the Grissini restaurant at the Hyatt Carlton Hotel in Knightsbridge, London, on June 28 and July 5. Tickets are £35 including champagne reception and dinner. Details on: 020-8541 2223.

Green issue
If you are thinking of following in the divots of the stars this summer and going golfing in Scotland, where the Open is being played at St Andrews from July 20-23, the Scottish Tourist Board has produced a map showing more than 300 courses in the country. It includes all the details you need about playing the courses. The map is free. Tel: 08705 511511.

Tank tops
A combination of the sterling exchange rate against euro- participating countries and high taxation has left the UK at the bottom of an American Express Foreign Exchange survey to establish the best value for motoring in Europe.

1 Austria 53p per litre, travel costs £88.36 per 1,000 miles
2 Spain 54p, £90
3 Ireland 61p, £101.68
4 Switzerland and Belgium 64p, £106.68
6 Germany 66p, £110.02
7 Italy 74p, £123.40
8 France 77p, £128.38
9 Holland 78p, £129.23
10 UK 83p, £138.36

Holiday connections
The increased popularity of mobile phones and the new trend for constant communication means that mobile phones now feature in the UK's top holiday must-haves, according to Visa. The other most important must-haves are credit and debit cards and first-aid kits.

Departure time
Across the UK, workers receive on average 23 days annual holiday a year, recruitment agency Select Appointments found when it contacted 400 businesses employing 241,000 staff. For those in publishing and printing, the average was 26 days, whereas in the entertainment and leisure sectors the average was 20 days.

Park and ride
A UK Theme Park Survival Guide, published by Kids Out magazine, details top tips to keeping ahead of the crowd this summer. These include booking in advance to take advantage of discounts, using the virtual queuing schemes where available, and taking your valuables in a hip-bag rather than a handbag. The guide is free if you send a self-addressed envelope to Kids Out Book Offer, 87 Notting Hill Gate, London W11 3JZ. Alternatively, you will be sent one when booking tickets on-line for Chessington or Thorpe Park.

fields.headline: Seduction in Shanghai
fields.standfirst: An edited extract from And I'd Do It Again, by Aimée Crocker, which appears in Erogenous Zones.
fields.trailText: An edited extract from And I'd Do It Again, by Aimée Crocker, which appears in Erogenous Zones.
fields.body:
There is, or was, a famous tea-house in Shanghai which is perhaps better known than any other in the world because it is the model of the Willow Pattern China that every one knows so well. I met two Englishwomen there whom I knew slightly. Now, Englishwomen often give the impression that they are very proper and very reserved. But my experience with these two, and a great many after them, has led me to believe that the calm exterior of the British woman conceals something really more adventurous than one ever suspects.

The story begins when I got into conversation with Miss B and Lady D. Miss B was telling the story of the Willow Tearoom plate and it was very sweet and just what I would have suspected from the trim, boyish-looking young woman...

Our conversation covered many things, and it came out somehow that I was interested in adventures. Suddenly Lady D looked steadily through her lorgnette at her friend and said: "You know, we have just time to take her to the most wonderful of all adventures. Do you think she would care to come?"

Miss B thought I would and I protested that I would try anything once. The upshot was that we all hired a chair and away we went to an address that I did not hear. I speak of the fact that we hired a chair, because it was evident that the English ladies did not want their own bearers to know where they were going.

However I was not nervous. After threading through the amazing streets of the old city, we came to a courtyard which was hidden away as if to keep the world from knowing about it, but where there was a very decent looking house, clean and seemingly newer than the century-old buildings about it.

My guides got out and went to the door and, after pressing on a panel, engaged themselves in conversation with old woman.

We went in . . .

I had courage enough to ask my friends what kind of experience was in store for us. I learned little. "Even if we could tell you," said Lady B, "it would be useless. But you may believe that it is an experience which you will never forget and which, in your turn, you will never be able to describe."

She was right...

I insisted that Miss B go first, and I remember almost better than any other moment in my life the next 20 minutes or so while I sat alone in that strange place wondering.

I heard almost nothing through the thick curtains that concealed the door through which she had passed, but there was a strange whining sound, like music. It reminded me of a violin, playing far away. Sometimes, when the sound was more distinct, I would feel a slight perspiration and a shiver. It is hard to explain.

After a while, there was dead silence.

Finally I heard the shuffling of slippers, and the curtain was drawn back. It was Miss B returning.

She was staring straight ahead of her. She did not see me. Her eyes were dilated, her face was flushed. She seemed in a trance. It was as though she had taken a powerful drug. What was it? I almost decided to run away, but the old woman was motioning to me, and I felt obliged to follow her through the door into darkness.

I say darkness. That is not exact. There was the soft glow of a lamp... a single flame burning like a soul. It made shadows on the carved ivory panels of the walls. The shadows flickered over a large Chinese bed in the room's centre. There was a grass mat on the floor, and absolutely nothing else in the place. The one window back of the bed was covered by an impenetrable curtain. There was not a sound.

The old woman's hands were held out for my robe. Frightened to refuse, I gave it to her, but I was terrified to give it. It seemed as thought my last defence... against a mysterious, imagined something... were being taken away.

She softly pushed me to the bed and motioned me to lie down. I did, as if I were hypnotised. Naked I lay out straight on my back, across the bed, I could see nothing but the flickering shadows of the lamp, and the old woman departing.

Then suddenly there was some one in the room. I had not seen him come in. It was an old man, a very old man, with a thin, wax-like face.

Almost without a sound, he shuffled in silken slippers over towards me, stopped about two yards from the bed, and peered at me in silence. His hands were folded under his large sleeves. His eyes glowed and picked up the light of the lamp from in back of me.

Then, still looking fixedly at me, he unfolded his arms and brought out from somewhere a small stringed instrument with an abnormally long neck. He sat down cross-legged on the floor, turned his back on me, and began to play.

That first note... it was as though it were drawn from my heartstrings. It was as though something in me were being played with a bow. It drew from the vitals of my life and being and plunged me into a voluptuousness that cannot be described.

It was as though invisible hands were touching me and pouring a rich current of electricity through me and into me. My eyes closed, my body relaxed. Like a million hands pressing my body, torturing me with a delicious torture, that sound... or was it music?... enwrapped me and carried me out of myself into an orgy of physical hysteria.

No, I cannot explain it. I cannot make myself clear. It was not alone sexual, not alone sensual. It transcended every and all physical pleasure I have ever known... Faster and faster and more rich the sound came from the little man's hands, rhythm after rhythm consumed me and lighted fires of passion and madness in me that are unspeakable, unfathomable.

Then it stopped...

I hardly regained complete understanding of actual life again until I was being led downstairs by Miss B, whose arm was tightly around me, guiding me and bracing me for fear that I fall. I tried to speak, to ask questions, but I found no voice. I felt myself being led out to the waiting chair and carried off by our coolies.

webTitle: Can you have a safe holiday in a war zone?

fields.headline: Can you have a safe holiday in a war zone?
fields.standfirst: Do your homework and you can make substantial savings staying in so-called hotspots, while being nowhere near the line of fire.  John Aglionby  reports
fields.trailText: Do your homework and you can make substantial savings staying in so-called hotspots, while being nowhere near the line of fire. John Aglionby reports
fields.body:
Matamanoa, Gili Trawangan, Alor and Pamalican are some of the most exotic holiday destinations in the world, home to glorious white-sand beaches, sparking crystal-clear seas and a stunning array of coral and sea life.

Many people would jump at the chance to sample the delights they have to offer. A good proportion of them would think twice, however, when they discover they are in Fiji, Indonesia, Timor and the Philippines respectively.

All of these countries are in the headlines for the wrong reasons - coups, sectarian violence, civil unrest, separatist uprisings, kidnapping of tourists, terrorism. From the comfort of an armchair in England, they all seem very good arguments for finding an alternative place to spend one's hard-earned money.

And perhaps neighbouring countries should also be included on the exclusion list. Remember, the 21 people being held hostage by Muslim separatist guerrillas in the southern Philippines were actually in Malaysia, on the resort island of Sipaden, when they were seized.

On closer inspection, though, dismissing out of hand countries in conflict means you could be missing out on a perfectly safe holiday at greatly-reduced rates. Unrest, quite naturally, breeds panic among holidaymakers who tend to flee at the first sign of trouble. But more often than not it is only a very small area that is engulfed by the upheaval.

"We were totally unaffected by the coup and, as we do not have TVs or radios in guest rooms, most people had no idea what was going on," says Reginald Raffles, who owns a resort on the remote Mamanuca islands in Fiji, in reference to the coup in the capital Suva on May 19. "Our guests stayed on. But we were hit hard by cancellations from people due to come in."

Mark McWhinnie, the manager of the Sheraton Fiji on Denarau island, who had the same problem, believes most tourists act far too hastily. "For example, Bali emptied out when there were riots and civil disorder in Jakarta [in May 1998]" he says. "In people's perception, it's dangerous because they lump it all together as one country and don't study the issues more carefully."

The occupancy rates at both resorts are currently a third of what they should be and so, with a bit of patience and determined negotiating, I was able to get discounts of up to 50%. Paradoxically, though, it is often the case that the more expensive the hotel, the smaller the discount in percentage terms. Upmarket resorts want to protect their brand name and maintain standards.

When Lombok, the island immediately to the east of Bali in Indonesia, descended into a maelstrom of sectarian violence for three days at the end of January, the tourist market was ruined. Five months on and even the best hotels are struggling to reach 60% occupancy. "However, I do not believe in slashing rates because I am offering a quality product that I know people are willing to pay for," explains Joe Polito, the manager of the Oberoi resort in Lombok. "People will come back before too long."

Polito recommends that people looking for a good deal - and there are still plenty to be had in Lombok despite there having been no unrest since the initial disorder - should head to non-chain hotels that rely solely on the destination and not also on the reputation of their product. "It's these hotels that are finding it most difficult and are glad of any customers they can get," he said.

While all three agree the danger to tourists is often exaggerated, they all stress that it is crucial to do one's homework before venturing to a potentially risky destination. "I'm not going to suggest that people should take a risk, but if you're sitting on the fence then the best thing to do is to ring up where you're going and speak to people on the ground," McWhinnie says.

Albert, an Austrian tourist I bumped into in January in the eastern Indonesian city of Ambon when covering an outbreak of sectarian fighting, had not done enough homework. He assumed a two-day lull meant it was all over and that, despite the city being partitioned and prone to random shooting, he would still be able to get a week's unimpeded diving. Twenty-four hours later, he was dodging the bullets on his way back to the airport.

Embassy travel advisories are always worth checking but not always worth obeying, as Mandy and Andrew Nicklin found out. They got married on May 27 and had planned to spend part of their honeymoon in Fiji. Even though the Foreign Office advised against "all but the most essential" travel to Fiji, and suggested that all Britons there leave, they decided to go ahead with their trip.

"We thought we were going to have to change our itinerary," Mandy says. "But we contacted the travel company which was saying that travelling round the [outer] islands as we were and not going anywhere near the capital Suva, where all the trouble was, should be okay."

There are no hard-and-fast rules and no two conflicts are ever the same. But, particularly in countries as large and spread out as Indonesia and the Philippines, violence in one place does not automatically mean the whole country is on the verge of erupting into major unrest.

Then again, you can always be unlucky and end up with a much longer "vacation" than you expected, as the Sipaden holidaymakers are in the unenviable position of discovering.

Troubleshooter's guide to staying safe

1 Check how serious the unrest is.

2 Find out how safe your hotel is if the trouble has not stopped.

3 Check your travel insurance covers you. Insurers are usually the most cautious of people.

4 Don't take too much local currency and ensure you have plenty of hard currency. In times of disorder, local currencies can fluctuate rapidly and massively. Many people rely on credit cards, but in many remote areas that have experienced unrest they are not accepted.

5 Make sure you have a safe exit route just in case the trouble escalates.

6 The better deals are likely to be found at the smaller, less well-known hotels and tour operators.

7 Keep abreast of the FO's updated travel advisory. Available from the local embassy or high commission. UK tel: 020-7238 4503.

8 Don't switch off from the outside world. Buy a newspaper regularly and listen to the radio and TV news.

9 Keep in touch with family and friends back home. Remember they can't see what you're up to and so are likely to be far more worried than you.

10 Don't expect sympathy if you get shot, particularly if you ignore advice.

fields.headline: Unwinding to the sea
fields.standfirst: Geneticist  Steve Jones rediscovers his roots tracing the Afon Ystwyth from its source
fields.trailText: Geneticist Steve Jones rediscovers his roots tracing the Afon Ystwyth from its source
fields.body:
After half a lifetime of hill walking and scientific field trips, Steve Jones decided 10 years ago that it was time to stop confronting the forces of nature and start working with them. "I mean, what's the point of fighting gravity?" he says.

"So rather than climbing up mountains, I decided to come down rivers and, as somebody who was born in Wales and spent years there, I conceived the notion of walking down all the rivers of Wales. I haven't done it yet, but I've done quite a few of them.

"And it's a real pleasure, because you start off in the harsh and difficult neck of the woods, when you're feeling fresh, and you end up at the sea, where there's always a nice pub, rather than at the top of a mountain where you have to walk the whole bloody way down again."

His favourite so far is the Afon Ystwyth, which starts in the Plynlimon massif of mid-Wales, also the source of the Wye and Severn. The area is close to his heart as Professor of Genetics at University College, London, because he has some Y-chromosome genes which show that the Welsh have a common male ances try with people in the Basque country of northern Spain.

The river emerges from a peat bog and works its way down through a little-known area heavily used for lead and silver mining from Roman times until the 19th century.

As a geneticist, Jones takes a special interest in the way local plants have adapted to pollution by heavy metals. "It's nice to think when you're walking through these places with just a bit of scrappy grass on them, that it's all evolved by a process of natural selection. Plants from those mines have been taken and bred together to make a super-strain, which has been used to re-seed mines around the world."

Next comes the social history: this part of Wales was always poor, but many valleys have large and imposing houses where the mine-owners lived. Half-way down the Ystwyth valley is Trawsgoed (Crosswood in English), an elegant Georgian structure that was home to the wealthy Vaughan family before being taken over by the University of Wales.

From there, the river continues through the beautiful, if rainy, Welsh landscape and reaches the sea at Aberystwyth by an Iron Age hill fort called Pen Dinas. Jones was born within a few hundred yards of it and ending the day there has "another kind of resonance".

"The walk starts off gloomy and atmospheric and ends up fairly idyllic. The great strength of many of these Welsh river walks is simply that nobody ever does them. There are honeypots, but people never go more than a few hundred yards from the car, so you can be a whole day without seeing anyone.

"It's not the Lakes or Snowdonia, where there are fantastic features you can point to. It's just the general atmosphere of being relatively unspoilt.

"Rivers are always moving, and their mouths are always moving. As a biologist and a geneticist and an evolutionist, you're aware of this balance between what seems static but is in fact always changing, and a river is the constant image of that. Herodotus said: 'No man can stand in the same river twice'.

"And that's the kind of truth I like to get about walking down rivers. I'm not one of those people who has this false and romantic image of the landscape being unchanging. It's always changing, and it always will."

Hard times in the hills

The Vaughans of Trawsgoed were the greatest landowners of the county of Cardiganshire from the 14th to the 20th century. They owned the local lead and silver mines and used the proceeds to build a mansion surrounded by woods and parkland.

But they were originally from England, and their exploitation of the land and treatment of the local people was rarely enlightened. They declined to learn Welsh or invest in the welfare of their workers and tenants, and Prof Jones calls them "classic grinders of the faces of the poor".

"There are all kinds of legends about them and it was claimed that if they wanted to get rid of an awkward tenant, they would drop a sheep on a rope down his chimney at night, then suddenly attack the house and find the sheep.

"Then the tenant would be found guilty of sheep stealing and hanged. There were various riots as a result, none of which made much impact on history, but which are interesting to me because one side of my own family were small farmers in that area."

The house was taken over in the 20th century by the University of Wales for its Grassland Research Station, which made a major contribution to developing strains of grass for the rehabilitation of mining sites.

The following appology was printed in the Guardian's Corrections and Clarifications column, Tuesday June 27, 2000

In this article, we recommended a book, A Welsh House and its Family: The Vaughans of Trawsgoed, by Gerald Morgan. Mr Morgan has pointed out that the accompanying article included a number of mistakes from which a reading of his book should have saved us.

Among these were our statement that the Vaughans were the largest landowners in Cardiganshire from the 14th to the 20th centuries (that should have been the 17th to 20th centuries); that the Vaughans never learned Welsh (they were a Welsh-speaking family until the 18th century); that their former home was taken over by the University of Wales (it never was); that it became a Grassland Research Station (it did not: it was bought by the government in 1947 and became the Welsh headquarters of the Agricultural Development and Advisory Service).

Part of the farmland originally belonging to Trawsgoed (but not the mansion itself) is now run by IGER (Institute for Grassland and Environmental Research). Apologies for all that.

fields.headline: Cheap and cheerful
fields.standfirst: People turn their noses up at the Costa Blanca, but go at the right time, says  Jim White, and you'll get affordable family fun in the sun without the marauding hordes
fields.trailText: People turn their noses up at the Costa Blanca, but go at the right time, says Jim White, and you'll get affordable family fun in the sun without the marauding hordes
fields.body:
When I told my mate exactly whereabouts in Spain I was taking the family on holiday, he visibly aged.

"Calpe, eh?" he said. "I've been there."

Then he paused, the kind of pause that rarely prefaces a glowing endorsement, before adding: "Worst holiday of my life."

He tried for several seconds to be tactful, but out it all came: the catalogue of woes suffered there. The stifling concrete tower block, for instance, in which festered the shoe-box sized mosquito farm that served as his accommodation. Then there was the beach so covered in blistering flesh he had returned to England unaware if it was sandy or rocky. Oh, and on his one trip to a nightclub, there was a mass brawl involving a gang from Derby who had taken offence at the swanky, metropolitan behaviour of a group of lads from Leicester.

"Calpe," he concluded. "Khazi more like."

But my mother had booked a villa there, up in the hills overlooking the town and had invited us all along. She had been before and, unless she was keeping something from us, had yet to be embroiled in a territorial spat at the Club Paradiso or Bar Britannia. So there was no turning back.

Twenty minutes' drive north of Benidorm, its more celebrated Costa Blanca neighbour, the guidebooks tell you that Calpe occupies a stunning scenic spot: a wide sandy bay, perfectly dissected by a huge limestone rock. Frankly, the scenery is not the first thing you notice. Back in the early 60s, it is said that all the first British package tourists to the place could see bobbing about at the base of the rock were the brightly- coloured fishing boats of the local fleet.

Now, we discovered the moment we looked down on the town from the grand sweep of our villa's terrace, the town's main purpose appears to be to provide a laboratory for every architect of the brutalist school to put into practice theories discredited by social disasters elsewhere. Dozens and dozens of ugly concrete towers scar the bay. Whereas in Las Vegas, say, every hotel is themed to make a theatrical statement, here they seem to be designed solely to demonstrate the texture of the breeze block.

And they are still building them, 20-storey holiday apartment complexes that look as though they must have taken all of minutes to plan. There are more cranes in Calpe than in the city of London, thrusting up the new engines of the local economy. Meanwhile, every inch of the surrounding hillsides has been covered in an ever- growing rash of white-washed holiday villas, quickly smothering all before it in suburbia. Day and night the air is filled with a constant cicada hum of drilling and hammering.

Oddly, though, after the initial shock had worn away, as the days merged into a rioja and barbecue haze, the architecture grew increasingly less threatening. At night, as we stood on our balcony, the blocks provided a glittering light show, twinkling away beneath us almost benevolently.

And we quickly discovered that the best view of the town was from the terrace of the Guitar Bar on the front itself. Not just because it offered a clean sweep along the shoreline to the mini Gibraltar of the rock. But mainly because the bar was located on the ground floor of the ugliest building around, so it was the only place in town where you couldn't see what you were sitting in.

Besides we were having too much fun to be worried about aesthetics. Whatever the architecture, a resort takes on a completely different complexion depending on the time of year you visit. Blackpool is another proposition altogether in January compared with July. Mainly because it is empty. And more by fluke than forward planning, we had hit the jackpot. The brilliant thing, it turned out, about going to a popular Spanish holiday resort during the summer half-term is that everything is in operation, but the season has not yet cranked up to its full level of madness. Thus there are plenty of cheap flights, all the attractions are open, but nobody is there yet.

And even Calpe has its virtues when empty. Take the beach. With only a few pensioners savouring the muscular buying power of their grey pounds scattered across it, this turned out to be a mile-long glittering stretch of clean sand. Every night it is vacuumed by municipal trucks to a condition so pristine, your chances of discovering a dog end are marginally lower than winning the lottery.

Or there's the bars and restaurants, yet to be colonised by the fighting men of the East Midlands, which battle instead for your custom, sending out hit squads to accost your evening stroll, armed with jugs of sangria and comedy English. "Yes, you, looky looky, free drink, lovely jubbly."

Up in the mountains, the limestone harshness is softened by bursts of bougainvillaea, morning glory and lemons hanging in their thousands from the trees. The winding roads have yet to become impassable for the drifts of tourist coaches. And the weather is almost absurd in its perfection. Whereas in August the sun is so hot a short hop across the sand char-grills the feet, every morning in early June dawns a blissful combination of clear skies, a thermometer hovering around 80F and a cool breeze fanning in from the sea.

But, best of all, there is Agualandia. Or, as the hoardings advertising its pleasures put it: "The largest water park." There is no qualification as to whether it is the largest water park in the world, in Spain, or merely on the road between Calpe and Benidorm, but nonetheless it is some operation.

In August, Agualandia is no place for a misanthrope. So heaving with humanity is it, my nephew once spent an afternoon there and managed to go on three slides. The rest of the time he spent queuing. Lining up at a theme park can be a depressing experience at the best of times. But when you are shuffling along for an hour behind an 18-stone, middle-aged man dressed only in a posing pouch, with Newcastle United's crest tattooed on each buttock, you can lose the will to live.

In June, there are no queues. Though the occasional 18-stone, middle-aged man with Newcastle United insignia indelibly adhered to his lower regions is still in evidence.

Agualandia is a paradise of waterslides and pools perched on a hillside overlooking the vista that is Benidorm, a place that makes Calpe look picturesque. From the top of one slide, you can gaze down into the town and wonder if that is the Queen Vic British pub serving all-day full English breakfast for 90 pence you can see down there. Or is it McAfferty's Irish bar with karaoke den and widescreen TV offering a full range of Sky Sports channels?

When we went, though, there was little time to ponder such profound issues. With no queues, we shot down so many rides in such rapid succession that, by the end of the day, the seats of our swimming trunks were so smooth you could see your face in them. Or at least you could see your cheeks.

Each ride has its own name. My favourite was Rapidos, a meandering white-water number negotiated in an industrial-sized rubber ring ("you won't need a tyre dad, you've got a spare one already, hahaha"). Hugo and Ellie preferred the Black Hole, a terrifying enclosed chute apparently designed to cull claustrophobics. Barney could not get enough of the Kamikaze, a vertiginous beast that thrusts you through the water at such speed it combines a white-knuckle ride with a course of colonic irrigation. What my wife liked best of all was the turnstile marked exit.

She had her revenge though. She went shopping. The Costa Blanca is a paradise of ceramic-making. Every village in the hills is crammed with pottery shops, selling vast terracotta tubs for the sort of price your local B&Q charges for a flower pot. In Calpe, there is a ceramics supermarket, churning out the stuff to accommodate every taste from those engaged by a couple of subtle sweeps of azure on an earthenware pot to those who prefer 7ft-tall ceramic cartoon ducks. With no other shoppers around to fur up the check-outs, she and my mother bought enough to fill a small stately home. As they grazed for pottery, the children kitted themselves out in straw sombreros the width of satellite dishes in lively shades of puce and lime.

At the end of the week, as I stood in Alicante airport, thigh deep in breakables that could not be stored under any circumstances in the hold, watching my children swish round on luggage trollies wearing sombreros, I tried to wear an expression to suggest these were irony purchases, a knowing wink at Costa Blanca naffery. Judging by the way they wore them, though, the children thought they were the height of style, swish souvenirs of the perfect family break.

In August, Agualandia is no place for a misanthrope. So heaving with humanity is it, my nephew once spent an afternoon there and managed to go on three slides. The rest of the time he spent queuing. Lining up at a theme park can be a depressing experience at the best of times. But when you are shuffling along for an hour behind an 18-stone, middle-aged man dressed only in a posing pouch, with Newcastle United's crest tattooed on each buttock, you can lose the will to live. In June, there are no queues. Though the occasional 18-stone, middle-aged man with Newcastle United insignia indelibly adhered to his lower regions is still in evidence. Agualandia is a paradise of waterslides and pools perched on a hillside overlooking the vista that is Benidorm, a place that makes Calpe look picturesque. From the top of one slide, you can gaze down into the town and wonder if that is the Queen Vic British pub serving all-day full English breakfast for 90 pence you can see down there. Or is it McAfferty's Irish bar with karaoke den and widescreen TV offering a full range of Sky Sports channels? When we went, though, there was little time to ponder such profound issues. With no queues, we shot down so many rides in such rapid succession that, by the end of the day, the seats of our swimming trunks were so smooth you could see your face in them. Or at least you could see your cheeks. Each ride has its own name. My favourite was Rapidos, a meandering white-water number negotiated in an industrial-sized rubber ring ("you won't need a tyre dad, you've got a spare one already, hahaha"). Hugo and Ellie preferred the Black Hole, a terrifying enclosed chute apparently designed to cull claustrophobics. Barney could not get enough of the Kamikaze, a vertiginous beast that thrusts you through the water at such speed it combines a white-knuckle ride with a course of colonic irrigation. What my wife liked best of all was the turnstile marked exit. She had her revenge though. She went shopping. The Costa Blanca is a paradise of ceramic-making. Every village in the hills is crammed with pottery shops, selling vast terracotta tubs for the sort of price your local B&Q charges for a flower pot. In Calpe, there is a ceramics supermarket, churning out the stuff to accommodate every taste from those engaged by a couple of subtle sweeps of azure on an earthenware pot to those who prefer 7ft-tall ceramic cartoon ducks. With no other shoppers around to fur up the check-outs, she and my mother bought enough to fill a small stately home. As they grazed for pottery, the children kitted themselves out in straw sombreros the width of satellite dishes in lively shades of puce and lime. At the end of the week, as I stood in Alicante airport, thigh deep in breakables that could not be stored under any circumstances in the hold, watching my children swish round on luggage trollies wearing sombreros, I tried to wear an expression to suggest these were irony purchases, a knowing wink at Costa Blanca naffery. Judging by the way they wore them, though, the children thought they were the height of style, swish souvenirs of the perfect family break.

fields.headline: Searching questions
fields.standfirst: www.leisurehunt.com
fields.trailText: www.leisurehunt.com
fields.body:
Anything to do with the Countryside Alliance?
Not at all. It's a hotel search and booking service.

Another one? That sounds familiar.
Unlike last week's site, laterooms.com, Leisure Hunt lists hotels from all over the world. The blurb on the front claims to recognise "towns and villages worldwide". This is something of an exaggeration, although it does hold true for the US and Britain: the UK has 33,000 listings. As an indication, Leisure Hunt lists five hotels in Warsaw, all of them sizeable and one of them not built from concrete. All the entries are illustrated and have star ratings.

On the other hand...
Only a very small selection of hotels are discounted, and on the days I visited the special offers were confined to British chains. Nor were they particularly cheap - a 15% discount on a three-night stay in Oasis Village Lakeland in Penrith, for example, reduced the price to £277.

Can I book?
That depends on the hotel. Some of them are linked to the SpeedBook network; others have to be contacted individually.

I'm not very excited.
The art of building a successful travel site lies in building up a database and manipulating it successfully. Leisure Hunt has managed the former, but they haven't put much effort into the latter. The result is a flat, lifeless endeavour which, while it functions perfectly adequately, is unlikely to inspire visitors. For purposeful travellers only.
