fields.headline: Wherever turns you on
fields.standfirst: What makes us lose our inhibitions and get embroiled in steamy holiday affairs?  Lucretia Stewart, editor of a new anthology on the subject, knows better than most...
fields.trailText: What makes us lose our inhibitions and get embroiled in steamy holiday affairs? Lucretia Stewart, editor of a new anthology on the subject, knows better than most...
fields.body:
I am writing this on Büyükada, one of the Princes Islands in the Sea of Marmara. The American writer friend who introduced me to the island claimed once to have had sex with six Kurds here. They were workmen, apparently, who were restoring one of the beautiful old wooden houses (yalis) with which the island is covered. He was passing, he caught their eye, or they caught his, and the rest is history.

Gays have a secret language to which heterosexuals appear not to be privy. We were walking down the hill to dinner when we passed the yali in question. He pointed it out, first drawing my attention to the elaborate fretwork carving of the balcony, then he told me about the Kurds with their beautiful blue eyes. I said, "Six? What, all at once?" "No, of course not, silly. One after the other."

I have never had sex on Büyükada. I've never even come near it, unless the charming hotel manager coming to meet me off the late boat from Bostanci because he thought I shouldn't walk the 200 yards to the hotel alone counts as anything more than gallantry. Yet Büyükada is one of the most romantic places in the world.

There are no cars here (except for a garbage truck and one, or maybe two, police vans). You go everywhere by horse-drawn carriage - a surrey with a fringe on top, like the one immortalised by the song in Oklahoma - drawn by pairs of matched bays or greys. The only sounds you hear are the clip of the horses' hooves; the clinking of the reins; the querulous-teething-baby cries of the seagulls; the strangulated screams of the fighting or mating cats (these two are often indistinguishable); and the fog-horn call of boats arriving and departing all day long from dawn until midnight. All you smell is sea and jasmine and grilling meat and fish.

If you look across the Sea of Marmara, on a clear day, you can see the angular silhouettes of Bostanci, Maltepe and Kartal, those densely-populated, intensively built-up outer suburbs of Istanbul; they look like a larger, less elegant Manhat tan, and seem alarmingly near. I prefer it when it's hazy, like today, and the Asian shore looks far away. There's a point at dusk, before the million lights on the far coast are turned on, when the sea and sky merge to become one, and there's just a wall of grey-blue.

But enough of Büyükada - whose erotic potential I am clearly not destined to experience (at least, not on this trip). That's the whole point. You can't plan your erotic travel. If you do, you're just a sexual tourist and that's not the same thing at all. Travellers are looking for adventure, and some are prepared to be more adventurous than others. "Relief", or titillation for his jaded palate, is the aim of the sexual tourist.

What is it exactly about sex and travel? The one enhances the other. Both involve exploration and experimentation; linking the two is almost irresistible. A romantic and unusual, preferably exotic, setting compounds the thrill. The more exotic the setting, the greater the kick. It doesn't need to be about danger, though some travellers clearly find an element of risk a turn-on.

In 1980, the Anglophile American scholar Paul Fussell published a book called Abroad. The book contained a chapter entitled L'Amour du Voyage, in which Fussell claimed that "Making love in a novel environment, free from the censorship and inhibitions of the familiar, is one of the headiest experiences travel promises."

The operative word here is "promises". The traveller, like the sexual adventurer (of whom some homosexuals seem to be the most daring - although some might think "reckless" a better word), embarks on his quest in the hope of encountering the unknown. Erotic travellers are, as the old song would have it, "Strangers in the night exchanging glances/Wondering in the night what were the chances/We'd be sharing love before the night was through." For these lovers at first sight, love (and sexual adventure) is simultaneously just a glance away and many miles from home. The promise of a foreign affair, that enticing combination of the erotic and the exotic, can prove unbearably alluring.

The trailer that advertises the video of the film version of Han Suyin's novel Love is a Many-Splendoured Thing promises that "Passion loses control in exotic Hong Kong". Implicit is the suggestion that uncontrollable passion and sexual adventure (even, with luck, depravity) beyond wildest imaginings, are possible only in such places as "exotic Hong Kong". But, in EM Forster's story The Obelisk, written in 1939, the travel undertaken by a schoolmaster and his wife is merely to an out-of-season seaside resort. Nonetheless, it leads to a chance encounter with two sailors, which in turn leads to sex, which leads to unprecedented perception, none of which would have been possible if the couple had not "travelled".

I've enjoyed my share of love-making in exotic spots and understand all too well the relationship between the place, the moment, the situation and the person, which all combine mysteriously to create an atmosphere ripe for adventure.

There's something magical about tropical countries: the strangeness, the dreamy warmth, the scent, the fact that no one in the real world knows where you are or what you are doing. In the right circumstances, that most depressing of encounters, the one-night stand, can seem positively thrilling. As the old poem has it, "Wouldn't you like to sin/On a tiger skin/With Elinor Glyn?" The tiger skin is the real attraction.

I have always found the east - I suppose I might as well go all the way and call it the Orient - particularly evocative. I first understood its erotic potential in Canton, in a Ferris wheel that revolved slowly high above the city. Later that evening, back at a hotel on the banks of the Pearl River (the name alone evokes a kind of magic) with the sounds of the boatmen in their sampans on the water, all scruples were forgotten, all cares banished; London, other obligations, other people, everything ceased to exist. Only the moment remained. You can recognise such moments, not just afterwards when they linger in your memory with a crystalline clarity, but at the time, almost as if you have taken a drug that intensifies your senses - of smell, of sight, of hearing.

My experience in China was followed by others - to the extent that I came to associate the Far East with a particular kind of erotic experience - and, when I was back in England with its monochrome colours and its gloomy climate, I would take out and examine my store of such memories rather as a miser might gloat over a secret hoard. The second time was on the Star Ferry pier in Hong Kong; the third in Raffles Hotel in Singapore. Raffles, in its last, great, seedy days before it was refurbished and lost all its character, was a real turn-on.

I had just arrived from London. When I got to my hotel, a gleaming, modern skyscraper, I found a message telling me that an old boyfriend happened also to be in Singapore and was staying at Raffles. I caught a cab and went over. We had one drink, then another, and then dinner. Just as I was almost fainting with exhaustion, saying, "I really must get some sleep," he said, "Come and have a look at the Tiffin Room."

The Tiffin Room, as far as I can remember, was a monument to colonial glory, festooned with stuffed tigers' heads and glass showcases containing reports of sporting triumphs. So, when he kissed me and said, "Come upstairs for a bit," I thought: "Well, why not? How often does opportunity knock in Raffles?"

S ome years later, I found myself in Siem Reap, in the Grand Hotel d'Angkor when it was still shabby and atmospheric before the Raffles group (which now controls almost all the great hotels in the east) got their hands on it and renovated the life out of it. I went to bed with a handsome mine-clearer who was risking his life on a daily basis helping clear the mines scattered like handfuls of rice by the Khmer Rouge.

We had stayed up late, drinking whisky and listening to the time-warp sounds of the Doors with a group of UN soldiers and whatever women their sergeant had been able to round up. When the party showed signs of getting out of hand, he asked if he could come upstairs to collect the copy of Conrad's Victory I had promised to let him have. I did give him the book, but that wasn't what he had meant. I had breakfast with him the next morning but, after that, I never saw him again. It didn't matter a bit. The evening and the night that had followed had been, in their own way, quite perfect.

In the early 90s, when my travels ceased to take me east, I discovered that it was possible to enjoy myself in Martinique, Guadeloupe, St Vincent, Grenada, New York, Paris, Venice, Seville, on the night train to St Petersburg...

 Erogenous Zones: An Anthology of Sex Abroad, edited and with an introduction by Lucretia Stewart, is published by Random House/ Modern Library at £14.99.

webTitle: Travelling to New York by sea

fields.headline: Travelling to New York by sea
fields.standfirst:
I want to travel to New York by ship towards the end of September, returning in October. I am not looking for an expensive cruise and ideally would like to go on a cargo boat which takes a few passengers at a price not exceeding twice a reasonable airfare. Any suggestions?
Linnea Glynne-RuleIf
fields.trailText: I want to travel to New York by ship towards the end of September, returning in October. I am not looking for an expensive cruise and ideally would like to go on a cargo boat which takes a few passengers at a price not exceeding twice a reasonable airfare. Any suggestions?
fields.body:
 My daughter travelled on a container ship from Thamesport to Montreal and back with Canada Maritime, booked through Strand Voyages. She had a wonderful time. There are passages to New York from Thamesport available through Strand Voyages and also The Cruise People. Good sailing
Sandra West.

 Strand Voyages (020-7836 6363) is the booking agent for various companies that run cargo boats. Ships to New York and Norfolk, Virginia, are full for the next few months. Montreal costs £995pp one way, for a 10-day journey via Antwerp and Le Havre. The Cruise People (020-7723 2450) has spaces to Staten Island from Thamesport costing approximately £1,125pp in a double cabin. The boat can be picked up in Le Havre

webTitle: A yomp in the Brecons and carry on losing

fields.headline: A yomp in the Brecons and carry on losing
fields.trailText: Sorry for stepping into Lacey territory for a second but let me get this right: England's footballers lost to Romania largely because of an inability to pass the ball to one another? Twenty grand a week and, although they can find their way to the Ferrari dealer or the latest Wilmslow wine bar, team-mate is incapable of kicking a ball directly to team-mate without an opponent getting in the way?
fields.body:
Sorry for stepping into Lacey territory for a second but let me get this right: England's footballers lost to Romania largely because of an inability to pass the ball to one another? Twenty grand a week and, although they can find their way to the Ferrari dealer or the latest Wilmslow wine bar, team-mate is incapable of kicking a ball directly to team-mate without an opponent getting in the way?

This, it seems to me, is like Carol Vorderman getting everything right on Countdown except the adding up. My kids could hoof the ball to the opposition for that money and they are only three. Anyway, now Alan Shearer and co know what it is like to be derided as useless, to talk a grand game and then get stage-fright when the curtain goes up. Anyone who has been around the England cricket team over the past decade understands what I am talking about.

Just substitute Kevin Keegan, with his off-the-scale enthusiasm, for Bumble with his and you get the picture. Passion, dedication, spirit, self-belief, work ethic, Churchill's speeches and all the other flimflam that coaches chunter on about play their part. But at the end of the day, Brian, there is no substitute for skill and particularly not for the fundamentals like passing a ball or bowling length and line. The footballers may be wondering what else could have been done in prepara tion. Probably very little. So how could it all go wrong?

Well, yet again our cricketers have been there, done that and got the Vodafone leisure top. They, too, are given every chance to succeed. So each winter, it seems, an England team goes abroad boasting that it is the fittest, best prepared of all, only to return home chastened, realising that there is a bit more to it.

On Tuesday, or even Monday, the squad for the second test at Lord's, to be announced tomorrow, will meet, practise, socialise, play golf and talk about Thursday's match. If required, they will have the undivided attention of coaches, dieticians, trainers, psychologists and nursemaids. The introduction of central contracts means that, had he deemed it appropriate, the England coach Duncan Fletcher could have convened a training camp and taken the whole lot away to yomp in the Brecons or catch the sun in Lanzarote - whatever it takes. Yet still they lose, except now - as with the footballers - there are no excuses other than their own shortcomings as players.

The England cricket set-up has not always been such a well-oiled machine. My own introduction to test cricket involved a late call-up and a card asking me whether I would be prepared to accept a match fee and a drive to Old Trafford in time for the solitary practice session on the afternoon before the match.

There was no national coach and players used their peers in the side to help sort out technical hitches. Bowlers were dogsbodies. Do as much as you think you need were my instructions, which meant run in for as long as the batters wanted a net.

Before a later test I was asked, nonsensical as it may seem, to bowl flat out from 15 yards at Dennis Amiss to replicate the pace of Michael Holding, which made me feel that big and played havoc with my length. My nought for plenty was offset by Amiss' double hundred, so at least some good came of it.

Anyway, despite opposition ("who's going to bowl at you, then?"), I was given 10 minutes' batting before fielding practice, which consisted of some slip catches for the elite and a bit of ground work, a few throws and some steepling catches for the spear-chuckers.

Any tactics - which, in those days, most cricketers thought were small breath-fresheners - were discussed over dinner with the new boy, me, sitting next to the chairman Alec Bedser, as tradition demanded, to be ear-bashed about bowling a thousand overs in May. (Some years later, another rookie innocently asked Bedser whether he had considered himself a strike bowler. "I didn't run in like a twat and pitch it halfway down," he snorted, "so I couldn't have been.")

Next morning, not long before the start of play, Alan Knott, arguably the greatest keeper of all, approached me as I warmed up and wondered if I'd bowl a few to him, so he would know how fast I was and where to stand. Fred Karno would have done a better job of preparing an international team and, on a truly awful pitch that made Edgbaston seem like a shirtfront, we lost to West Indies by 425 runs. Plus ça change . But at least it hobbled into the fifth day.

On Tuesday, or even Monday, the squad for the second test at Lord's, to be announced tomorrow, will meet, practise, socialise, play golf and talk about Thursday's match. If required, they will have the undivided attention of coaches, dieticians, trainers, psychologists and nursemaids. The introduction of central contracts means that, had he deemed it appropriate, the England coach Duncan Fletcher could have convened a training camp and taken the whole lot away to yomp in the Brecons or catch the sun in Lanzarote - whatever it takes. Yet still they lose, except now - as with the footballers - there are no excuses other than their own shortcomings as players. The England cricket set-up has not always been such a well-oiled machine. My own introduction to test cricket involved a late call-up and a card asking me whether I would be prepared to accept a match fee and a drive to Old Trafford in time for the solitary practice session on the afternoon before the match. There was no national coach and players used their peers in the side to help sort out technical hitches. Bowlers were dogsbodies. Do as much as you think you need were my instructions, which meant run in for as long as the batters wanted a net. Before a later test I was asked, nonsensical as it may seem, to bowl flat out from 15 yards at Dennis Amiss to replicate the pace of Michael Holding, which made me feel that big and played havoc with my length. My nought for plenty was offset by Amiss' double hundred, so at least some good came of it. Anyway, despite opposition ("who's going to bowl at you, then?"), I was given 10 minutes' batting before fielding practice, which consisted of some slip catches for the elite and a bit of ground work, a few throws and some steepling catches for the spear-chuckers. Any tactics - which, in those days, most cricketers thought were small breath-fresheners - were discussed over dinner with the new boy, me, sitting next to the chairman Alec Bedser, as tradition demanded, to be ear-bashed about bowling a thousand overs in May. (Some years later, another rookie innocently asked Bedser whether he had considered himself a strike bowler. "I didn't run in like a twat and pitch it halfway down," he snorted, "so I couldn't have been.") Next morning, not long before the start of play, Alan Knott, arguably the greatest keeper of all, approached me as I warmed up and wondered if I'd bowl a few to him, so he would know how fast I was and where to stand. Fred Karno would have done a better job of preparing an international team and, on a truly awful pitch that made Edgbaston seem like a shirtfront, we lost to West Indies by 425 runs. Plus ça change . But at least it hobbled into the fifth day.

webTitle: Wasim lets his bat do the talking

fields.headline: Wasim lets his bat do the talking
fields.trailText: While Hansie Cronje was getting misty-eyed, Wasim Akram was reducing Sri Lanka's bowlers to tears. In only 89 balls he blitzed eight fours and six sixes before falling for an exact 100, catapulting Pakistan into complete command of the second test in Galle.
fields.body:
While Hansie Cronje was getting misty-eyed, Wasim Akram was reducing Sri Lanka's bowlers to tears. In only 89 balls he blitzed eight fours and six sixes before falling for an exact 100, catapulting Pakistan into complete command of the second test in Galle.

A month ago he had seemingly lost his lethal edge. The big hauls had dried up and, though he was making starts, substantial innings were few and far between.

But since Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum concluded that Wasim was "not above board", the former Pakistan captain has captured 18 wickets at 14.44 and belted 248 runs at 62. All in 2 tests and at the ripe old age of 34.

Wasim's third test century overshadowed the 22-year-old prodigy Younis Khan's more sedate second hundred - one of four in Pakistan's 600 for eight declared. By stumps Sri Lanka, trailing by 419 on the first innings, were 45 for one.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: The question of who will partner the West Indies opener Sherwin Campbell in next week's second test at Lord's is wide open after Adrian Griffith, left out of the first at Edgbaston, stroked New Zealand A 's rookie attack for a century at Chelmsford yesterday.
fields.body:
The question of who will partner the West Indies opener Sherwin Campbell in next week's second test at Lord's is wide open after Adrian Griffith, left out of the first at Edgbaston, stroked New Zealand A 's rookie attack for a century at Chelmsford yesterday.

Another fringe player Ramnaresh Sarwan, who turned 20 yesterday and whose blazing style has already been likened to Clive Lloyd's, also pressed his claims with 53.

The chances of a test recall for Griffith, who batted five hours for 130, were confused, though, when Chris Gayle, who made a duck in the first test, showed timely form yesterday with 65. Wavell Hinds hit 74 off 87 balls - including 10 fours and two sixes - but Brian Lara managed only 16, caught behind after top-edging an attempted pull off the medium-pacer Daryl Tuffey.

All in all it was an impressive warm-up for the tourists, who enter the final day on 381 for seven - an overall lead of 420.

Nick Knight did his chances of retaining his test spot no harm, top-scoring for Warwickshire with 82 out of 162 for seven in last night's National League match against Surrey at Edgbaston. It was his highest score of the season in limited-overs matches, with Dominic Ostler the next highest scorer on 25.

Sourav Ganguly was the destroyer at Old Trafford with three for 22 as Northamptonshire , batting first under lights, fell for 178 against Lancashire . Matthew Hayden offered the strongest resistance with 48.

webTitle: Wells finds his firing range to rev up the Spitfires

fields.headline: Wells finds his firing range to rev up the Spitfires
fields.standfirst: Kent Spitfires 215-7 v Sussex Sharks
fields.trailText: Bolstered by a powerful innings from Alan Wells, who was returning to haunt his former club, Kent set Sussex a challenging target under the floodlights at the County Ground last night.
fields.body:
Bolstered by a powerful innings from Alan Wells, who was returning to haunt his former club, Kent set Sussex a challenging target under the floodlights at the County Ground last night.

Yet the visitors' display was hardly typical of current form. Kent's one-day batting has been rather introverted this season and until yesterday evening their best score was 204, made in the Benson & Hedges Cup against Middlesex. Indeed, in seven National League matches not a single batsman had reached an aggregate of 100 runs.

But before a vibrant brass band, they looked a little more like their old selves in this National League First Division encounter. Wells, a former Sussex captain, scored a fine 90 before his old supporters; Kent's best effort in limited-overs cricket this season.

After four successive defeats Kent at least looked competitive, though the chronic problems at the top of their batting order persist.

David Fulton, Robert Key and Ed Smith have been in such miserable form that not one has scored a first-class 50 this season and here they tried opening with their former wicketkeeper Steve Marsh.

Marsh first played this role in Wednesday's NatWest win over Cumberland. He scored 23 in 30 overs, so it was hardly deemed a success. Yesterday he scored just one before he was caught behind off James Kirtley.

By then Fulton had already departed for a duck, chopping on to the second ball of the match. But, after Wells survived a caught-and-bowled half-chance to Bill Taylor when he had scored only 11, things began to look better for Kent.

The miscue did not appear to inhibit him. In partnership with Rahul Dravid and Matthew Walker, who each made 37, the former England batsman's runs came off only 117 balls and there were nine fours as well as two sixes, hit over mid-on into the practice nets and over square-leg off successive Michael Bevan deliveries just before he was dismissed.

A late flurry from the captain Matthew Fleming (22), who bats before Mark Ealham these days, saw Kent to a total of 215 for seven.

Sussex Sharks, who like the Spitfires went into this fixture with a solitary win in the National League, were without their all-rounder Robin Martin-Jenkins, who was suffering from a side strain.

In his place they played the all-rounder Michael Yardy, who was making his first competitive appearance for the first team.

fields.headline: Cronje departs in tears
fields.standfirst: Neil Manthorp reports on the final indignity of a fallen idol
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje left the witness box a broken man yesterday, sobbing uncontrollably after delivering more than 10 hours of testimony to the King Commission.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje left the witness box a broken man yesterday, sobbing uncontrollably after delivering more than 10 hours of testimony to the King Commission.

South Africa's former captain had to to be helped from the chamber by an aide, who grabbed his shoulder to stop him from falling.

On a dramatic final day Cronje admitted that the sum of between $10,000 and $15,000 (£6,600-£9,900) paid to him by a bookmaker, Sanjay Chawla, was a "deposit" for a one-day match, at the end of last winter's triangular series with England and Zimbabwe, which he had promised to throw if South Africa were assured of a place in the final. Chawla would pay $100,000 for the result.

A professional gambler, Marlon Aronstam, who persuaded Cronje to set up England's run-chase in the fifth test at Centurion Park this year and gave him £5,000 and a leather jacket, testified that Cronje had said soon after their first meeting that he could throw a match in the triangular series if it was meaningless.

"He told me that the best way to make money from cricket was to lose a game and he said that he had Pieter Strydom, Herschelle Gibbs and Nicky Boje on his side," said Aronstam. "I couldn't believe it, I was shocked. We hadn't even known each other for an hour."

Boje and Strydom have denied ever being involved in match-fixing.

"It hurts me more than anything else to have to sit here . . . and say things that harm Hansie," said Aronstam, his voice breaking with emotion.

He said the money he paid had been a drop in the ocean for a professional gambler, who could make 10 times that amount from betting on one match.

His credibility as a witness was vigorously tested under cross-examination. When it was suggested to him that £5,000 was a lot of money to pay Cronje, he shook his head at the phalanx of lawyers and said: "No, what you guys get paid for sitting here all day is a lot of money."

Cronje's personal ethics were again laid bare when he was forced to admit creaming $10,000 off the agreed price for corrupting the performances of Gibbs and Henry Williams against India in Nagpur in March and keeping it for himself. He confessed that $25,000 was the arranged fee but he offered only $15,000 to the players.

"Maybe I was trying to cut something off for myself," he finally conceded.

"May I suggest," interjected Judge Edwin King, "that that is exactly what you were trying to do." Cronje could only bow his head. "It was the worst thing that happened," he said of the offer to the two players, who in the end did not take it up.

Cronje again expressed remorse for his actions and said: "I hope I can put the money to good use to try to redress the wrongs I have done to my game and my country."

The commission's lead advocate, Shamila Batohi, added the final word before Cronje left the stand when she said that investigations would continue and Cronje might have to be recalled should fresh evidence emerge.

But it is unlikely that that is what caused his breakdown. More likely it was the fear of losing the support of his family. In Afrikaner culture the status of the family is crucial to a person's well-being. But on Thursday a close friend of the family had revealed that the support of Cronje's mother and wife was conditional on him not lying to the commission. His marriage has been deeply affected by the affair.

Cronje was asked: "Are you sure there isn't any more money hiding at home?" "If my wife finds a single dollar in our house I think she would cut the other testicle off," he replied.

fields.headline: Why Woy Was Wrong
fields.standfirst: Oxford's chancellor failed his first duty
fields.trailText: For a man who is paid to protect the interests of Oxford University, Roy Jenkins's interview in this week's Spectator is singularly inept.
fields.body:
For a man who is paid to protect the interests of Oxford University, Roy Jenkins's interview in this week's Spectator is singularly inept. The Great Pooh-Bah, as he was rightly labelled by Paddy Ashdown, fell into each trap carefully laid for him by his interviewer: insulting the prime minister by unilaterally declaring Mr Blair could no longer expect, following Gordon Brown's attack on the university, to receive the honorary degree that is normally handed out to Oxford graduates who become prime minister, and adding further injury with the gratuitous suggestion that the prime minister had a "second class mind". The Oxford University chancellor is supposed to be the prime minister's mentor. With friends like this, who needs enemies?

There is a long and dishonourable list of reasons for honorary degrees: the pursuit of influence, cash, PR and marketing to name just four. They're almost as old as the universities, with Oxford having traced its first "dishonourable" degree back to 1479 and Cambridge to 1493. Both ancient and modern institutions continue to bestow them with zeal. The more modern universities have blatantly sought the publicity which comes with celebrity names - from Bob Geldof and Joanna Lumley (Kent) to Prunella Scales (Bradford). Broadcasters are particularly popular - John Cole, Kate Adie, Sandy Gall, Sue Lawley and Jenni Murray have all collected honorary awards. Sir David Attenborough has 19 of them and Sir Peter Medawar, the Nobel prize winner in the field of immunology, collected 23. The doctorate by which Samuel Johnson is still known was purely honorary.

Where Oxford has a right to feel aggrieved with its chancellor is the arrogance, snobbism and undiluted elitism which he displayed in his interview. But then it should never have expected him to fight for its corner. As one former Labour colleague once noted: "The only thing Woy ever fought for was a table for two at the Mirabelle."

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Paris | Namibia | New York
fields.body:
Europe

Trek : The Definitive Cultural Tour of Central Asia, visiting Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. The 18-day adventure departs on August 22. Price is £2,950pp. Himalayan Kingdoms (0117 9237163).

Paris : See the Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe as part of three-night trip travelling out on Eurostar on September 29 with a choice of hotels. Prices, including entrance to Longchamps, start from £179pp depending on the hotel. Eurotours (0870 3330889).

Finland : A week's walking holiday from August 5-12, run by guide Pete Hawkins, exploring the Koli National Park. Cost is £795, full board. Peakland Walking Holidays (01298 872801).

Malta : One-week painting courses by artist Jeni Caruana, including half-board, transport to sketching locations and use of some art materials. Courses run from October onwards and cost £380pp, excluding flights. Malta Art (01939 233311).

Africa

Namibia : A photographer's dream - a 17-day tour in November led by Peter Jones, the lecturer and wildlife photographer. The trip includes a tour of Sossusvlei, Etosha, Skeleton Coast, Damaraland and Kaokoland with the opportunity to see "desert elephants", black rhino, seal and bird colonies and big cats. Inclusive price is £2,720pp. Tana Travel (01789 414200).

North America

New York : Three-night Christmas shopping trips in November and December from £452pp, based on four sharing. Thomas Cook Holidays (01733 418100).

Vermont : Seven-night holiday over Christmas at the Rabbit Hill Inn, Lower Waterford. Price, based on two adults sharing, is £1,072pp. New England Vacations (01727 837100).

South America

Ecuador : Explore Andean villages and markets, go on a challenging four-day trek on foot and on horseback in Northern Ecuador and stay in a rainforest lodge on the Rio Napo on a 14-day holiday, starting October 22. Price is £1,205 excluding flights, which are approx £500. Tribes (01728 685971) .

Australia

Queensland : Explore the state by road. Travelling from Brisbane to Cairns, Austravel has a 16-night package from £1,158 (based on two people sharing), including international flights, three nights in Brisbane, nine days' car hire, eight nights' accommodation between Brisbane and Cairns and five nights in Cairns. Valid for departures from August 15. Flights into Brisbane and out of Cairns. Book and pay by August 8. Details: 0870 055 0206.

fields.headline: A weekend in Provence
fields.standfirst: A new air route makes one of France's most popular regions more accessible from London.  Matt Wells  finds out what's on offer
fields.trailText: A new air route makes one of France's most popular regions more accessible from London. Matt Wells finds out what's on offer.
fields.body:
While for some, nothing less than a year in Provence would do, a few days pottering around a few sleepy towns and villages drinking cheap wine and soaking up the stunning weather is no less good for the soul.

The area may be one of the most visited in France, but there is no sense of being exploited for the sake of a fast buck. Given that most of these places date back to times of distant antiquity, no one is in any hurry to get anywhere soon.

Nîmes

Nîmes, with a direct flight to London, is as good a starting place as any. But while it has the world's best-preserved amphitheatre and a town hall dating from 5th-century BC, there is no escape from the ubiquitous king of the flat roof, Sir Norman Foster, even among some of the most enduring architectural triumphs of the Roman Empire.

Opposite the Maison Carée in the old town square, Foster has created an art gallery that takes its cue from the angular geometry both of the Roman forum and the terminal building at Stansted, which for many travellers to this part of Provence will have been their last glimpse of England.

Recovery from this disconcerting realisation can be facilitated by a swift visit to the airy museum café that, handily, provides a central base from which to strike out into the baffling maze of narrow streets and lanes fanning out from the centre of the town.

Nîmes is one of those places where nothing much really happens. There are three festivals (ferias) every year (the latest one last month was a washout, much to the simultaneous distress and delight of locals whose fun was comprehensively spoiled but who now have something to moan about for the rest of the year). Apart from that, Nîmes is an austere, straightforward provincial town - quite an architecturally stunning one, it should be noted, but straightforward nonetheless.

Given a fairly accidental kind of history, which means that there is no one characteristic that defines the place, Nîmes is somewhat less than the sum of its parts. Yet to miss out on some of these parts would be to neglect an insight into Roman history, which only a visit to the seat of the empire itself would otherwise provide.

The amphitheatre, which is dated to the 1st century, may not be the largest in the Roman world, but locals boast that it is the best-preserved. Its 34 elliptical tiers once provided seating for 23,000, and the arena is still used for concerts, theatrical performances and the occasional bullfight. Those whose secret desire to witness such a cruel ritual is tempered by the thought of the suffering endured by our fellow beasts, may enter such an event at Nîmes with a clearer conscience: the local custom is that the bull is not fought to the death.

For a slightly quieter life, the grand Jardins de la Fontaine - around which the old town of Nmes grew up - provide welcome shade from the afternoon sun, among the elaborate fountains created by the Romans to contrast with the arid nature of the surrounding area.

Nîmes is undoubtedly the tourist trap of the region, and visitors should be prepared for the usual hordes of French schoolchildren or German families, depending on the time of year. Yet even on the busiest days, the crowds are dwarfed by the presence of this spectacular set of remains, to which admission is free.

Hotels

Hotel Central (+334 66 67 27 75), doubles from about £20.

Hotel La Baume (+33 4 66 67 28 42), luxurious rooms available from around £45 a night.

Restaurants

Cte Bleue, rue Littre/rue du Grand Couvent.

Lakayna,18 rue de l'Etoile

Nîmes Tourist Office: +33 4 66 67 29 11.

Arles

Vincent van Gogh decided it was the best place to come for inspiration, and the artist's legacy is exploited even to the extent of painting yellow the exterior of the café he famously used as a subject.

Fans can visit the institution where he received treatment for his personality problems - now a cultural centre, its gardens restored to appear how they looked when Van Gogh painted them.

But the town's best features emerge several feet below the Café van Gogh (they have no shame). Arles is home to the largest set of Roman remains outside Italy and deep in the "cryptoportiques", the shape of Roman Arles emerges. In the cool, dank underground arches, which formed the original town square, an image emerges of a bustling market square not so far removed from the present-day town centre.

Above ground, the cool shade of the 12th- and 14th- century Cloitre Saint Trophime is open to visitors who want to retrace the steps of the monks who passed through from their dormitories to the cathedral nearby. Across town, in the rue Vauban, the chapels of St Jean de Moustier and St Blaise are what remain of the St Cesaire convent, the first monastic order in the western world open to women.

Guided tours of the main monuments in the city, including the remains of the remarkable Cirque Romain, built in 150AD for chariot races, can be arranged through the tourist office.

Arles is the largest municipality (or "commune") in France, and its civic tentacles stretch into the Camargue, the vast marshlands of the Rhne delta which fans out towards the Mediterranean. Jeep excursions, arranged through the tourist office, take visitors deep into the swamplands, which are home to hundreds of bulls (reared for fighting), semi-wild white horses and flocks of flamingoes.

A 20-minute drive away on the other side of Arles is the 15th-century settlement of Les Baux de Provence, perched on a rocky outcrop and towering over the region. Avignon

They only stayed for 100 years or so, but the legacy of the Avignon popes, who for a time rivalled Rome as the centre of the Catholic world, dominates the town. Construction of the papal seat began in 1335 under Pope Benoit XII, and continued with his successors - and today the Palais des Papes (the Popes' Palace) defines the city and dominates the Rhne delta over which it towers.

The curse of the millennium appears to have evaded this part of France, and the main projects to commemorate the turn of the century here benefit greatly from the lakes of imagination that have long since dried up on the other side of the Channel. The Pont du Gard is to be illuminated in dramatic fashion, while here in Avignon, the Palais des Papes plays host to an exhibition of modern art which is breathtaking in both ambition and experience.

Every hall and corridor of the palace provides a backdrop to an installation, artwork or concept designed by a variety of internationally-acclaimed stars and national French names. Nowhere else, Tate Modern included, will you get the chance to see such a stunning variety of modern talent exposed in such an accessible and impressive manner. From the great bronze egg-shaped mirror of Anish Kapoor to the deliciously sacrilegious altar icons of Pierre et Gilles, this is an exhibition of world-class proportions. It is all the more impressive that this has been mounted in the French equivalent of Cardiff.

But residents of Avignon are more exercised by the giant pink hands, fashioned by Christian Lacroix - a native of the nearby town of Arles - which adorn random public buildings. Les gants Mapa (Marigolds), they have been dubbed by unkind local politicians. The great pink washing-up gloves notwithstanding, La Beauté en Fabula truly lives up to its name

After such an impressionistic event, the rest of Avignon seems to pale into insignificance, but there is much else to see. Just outside the town is the Saint André Fort, a gothic fortress that protected Villeneuve and sheltered an 11th-century abbey, and which provides stunning views across the Rhne valley and the sprawling city of Avignon.

The towns and villages of the Vaucluse are within easy striking distance. Hire a car, or take the train - Aix en Provence is the next major town, and tours are organised from the tourist office.

For those who can't really be bothered, the countless bars and high-quality restaurants in Avignon provide ample opportunity to waste plenty of time doing nothing very much.

Hotel du Palais des Papes

Hotel Medieval (+334 90 86 11 06), doubles from £20.

+33 4 90 62 65 36.
fields.bodyText: While for some, nothing less than a year in Provence would do, a few days pottering around a few sleepy towns and villages drinking cheap wine and soaking up the stunning weather is no less good for the soul. The area may be one of the most visited in France, but there is no sense of being exploited for the sake of a fast buck. Given that most of these places date back to times of distant antiquity, no one is in any hurry to get anywhere soon. Nîmes Nîmes, with a direct flight to London, is as good a starting place as any. But while it has the world's best-preserved amphitheatre and a town hall dating from 5th-century BC, there is no escape from the ubiquitous king of the flat roof, Sir Norman Foster, even among some of the most enduring architectural triumphs of the Roman Empire. Opposite the Maison Carée in the old town square, Foster has created an art gallery that takes its cue from the angular geometry both of the Roman forum and the terminal building at Stansted, which for many travellers to this part of Provence will have been their last glimpse of England. Recovery from this disconcerting realisation can be facilitated by a swift visit to the airy museum café that, handily, provides a central base from which to strike out into the baffling maze of narrow streets and lanes fanning out from the centre of the town. Nîmes is one of those places where nothing much really happens. There are three festivals (ferias) every year (the latest one last month was a washout, much to the simultaneous distress and delight of locals whose fun was comprehensively spoiled but who now have something to moan about for the rest of the year). Apart from that, Nîmes is an austere, straightforward provincial town - quite an architecturally stunning one, it should be noted, but straightforward nonetheless. Given a fairly accidental kind of history, which means that there is no one characteristic that defines the place, Nîmes is somewhat less than the sum of its parts. Yet to miss out on some of these parts would be to neglect an insight into Roman history, which only a visit to the seat of the empire itself would otherwise provide. webTitle: Banging the drum as the violins play on

fields.headline: Banging the drum as the violins play on
fields.trailText: Another England flop and again the mixed feelings: part sorrow, part relief.
fields.body:
Another England flop and again the mixed feelings: part sorrow, part relief. Not for the first time the national team will watch the real business of a major tournament back home on television, having been bundled out in the first round.

After the defeat by Romania in Charleroi on Tuesday it would have taken the hardest of hearts to resist a twinge of sympathy for Kevin Keegan, his coaching staff, his players and the thousands of decent England fans who had provided such fervent support.

Yet once more there was that small voice, deep down, which, as the team bus pulled away for the last time, uttered a subdued "whoopee!" For although there had been no pleasure in seeing England eliminated after being given another lesson in the basics of passing and movement, the knowledge that this would make it possible to watch better football elsewhere was no small consolation.

It is only natural that, when England qualify for a European Championship or World Cup, they should be the focus of the English media's attention. This is why there are daily press conferences at the squad's training camp to check on any injuries while listening to players announce they are quietly confident, are not underestimating the opposition and are ready to give their all, if selected.

The England coach, meanwhile, insists that team spirit has never been stronger, the preparations have never been better and he counts himself fortunate among men to have been put in charge of such an outstanding assembly of footballing talent. Anyone tempted to query this perfect state of affairs risks being cast in the role of a mongrel barking at Crufts.

Once a tournament has begun, and allowing for the few occasions when England have made serious progress, this is like having to listen to endless variations of Chopsticks while being aware that recitals of Chopin are on offer elsewhere.

In between discussing the state of Steve McManaman's knee, Alan Shearer's bruised buttock or which piece of Tony Adams last went missing, glimpses of French glories, the Italian renaissance, Turkey's awakening and Slovenia's sheer pleasure at being in Euro 2000 have been frustratingly brief.

No doubt the best of the rest of the tournament will be held up as an example of what England should be trying to achieve. Then the new Premiership season will kick-off and this will quickly be forgotten as football's equivalent of the Royal Mint resumes the task of making money.

Thirty years ago Alf Ramsey arrived back from England's abortive attempt to retain the World Cup declaring that the Brazil of Pele, Tostao, Jairzinho and Gerson "have nothing to teach us". What Ramsey meant was that England already knew what needed to be learned but he was accused of insularity all the same.

Not a lot has changed. English football is still searching for a system of youth development which will make the most of its natural talent while giving the national team the proper amount of time it needs to train together and play together. But, unless the clubs co-operate, England will continue to muddle along in the hope that the next Paul Gascoigne is a teetotaller.

Of all the instant panaceas suggested, restricting the number of foreign players in the domestic game is the most facile. Presumably Margaret Hodge, the employment minister who controls work permits for overseas footballers, is not related to Steve Hodge, a member of Bobby Robson's squad in the 1986 World Cup. Otherwise she might have known enough about the game to remember that for only two of the years between 1970 and 1980, when England did not qualify for anything, were imports allowed into the Football League.

Apparently the bookmakers are already accepting bets on who the next England coach will be. Some of the names being bandied about merely emphasise how thin the list of credible candidates has become.

Bryan Robson? Man, as John McEnroe used to scream, you cannot be serious. What about John Gregory, a true Anglophile of Aston Villa, even if he has been trying to sign a piece of French frivolity called David Ginola. He is a good club manager, Gregory, but it would still be the equivalent of asking a Birmingham bus driver to be successful in formula one.

The Football Association missed a trick when Ron Greenwood retired from the England job after the 1982 World Cup, having set up a dynasty of successors which included Bobby Robson, Terry Venables, Dave Sexton, Don Howe and Brian Clough. True, Robson and Venables eventually managed England but the FA has never abandoned its ad hoc nature of appointments and dismissals.

Robson, whose contract was not renewed, Venables, who did not get a new contract when he wanted one, and Glenn Hoddle, who was contracted out, each left for reasons which had more to do with bad headlines than bad football.

So a process which began with Ramsey, who produced successful teams but did not believe in press conferences, has turned full circle. England now have a coach who is a PR man's dream but whose team walks in its sleep.

It is as well that the Kevin Keegan funfair went home early. We could not have stood much more hoopla.

fields.headline: White's week
fields.standfirst: Fighting and fire-fighting:  A bid doomed to crash before it took off
fields.trailText: ...on fighting and fire-fighting: A bid doomed to crash before it took off.
fields.body:
A pparently the committee organising England's bid to host the World Cup in 2006 operate much like the England back four. They appear not to talk to one another. The regime installed at the FA last season promised that the organisation would speak with one voice. This week, after the undignified withdrawal from Europe of their representatives both on and off the pitch, there has been a cacophony of conflicting noises seeping out of Lancaster Gate.

"Our bid was accepted by Fifa as the best, but it is now looking very bleak indeed because of the damage done by the images flashed round the world," said Tony Banks on Wednesday, as footage of flop-bellied Englishmen re-arranging the furniture in Charleroi's main square became a hit on South African television. On Thursday, however, Alec McGivan, the bid committee chairman, told Radio 4 listeners that the bid was not drowning at all, but waving cheerfully. Meanwhile public relations advisers were recommending withdrawing the bid now before further humiliation was heaped on the English game.

Like the Labour Party during the election for London mayor, however, those in pursuit of an enterprise doomed from the start have gone too far to turn back. Instead, next week they will put their faith in Adam Crozier, the new chief executive of the FA, to undertake a giddy round of last-minute lobbying.

Crozier is a renowned firefighter. In his previous incarnation as an advertising man he was made head of Saatchi and Saatchi the day the founding brothers walked out taking half the client list with them. Saatchi staff, their morale lower at the time than Phil Neville's, speak in awe of the way Crozier handled the crisis: calm, relaxed, authoritative. Within two years the company was back as the second largest in London.

One to one he is a brilliant performer, capable of convincing the most seasoned sceptic that the FA is set on dynamic governance of English football. But, as David Beckham proved in Euro 2000, it is too much to expect one man to transform a hopeless case in less than two weeks. And the fact of the matter is that the hooligans didn't finish England 2006, it was dead from the start, fatally flawed the moment the English FA broke ranks and bid against Germany, the region's agreed candidate. Since its most plausible allies had undertaken to stand behind the Germans, England had little chance of gleaning enough support to make it to the second phase of voting. Long before Oat Head and pals were filmed relieving themselves on continental cobblestones, Crozier admitted to me that the real worry in the FA camp was about clearing that first hurdle.

Of course, the ugly collection bespoiling Belgium did not help. But it was the way the trouble was received which said everything about the political reality of England's bid. During France 98, the morning after a nasty riot in Marseille, Fifa's Sepp Blatter told everyone that the FA could not be blamed, it was society's problem. After Charleroi - in the annals of England shame no more than a minor skirmish - the FA was immediately held responsible by the Germany-bid-sympathising Uefa with the threat to expel the national team. Why, came the Uefa spin, had the FA and the British government done so little to prevent predictable mayhem when the Germans had done so much? It was not just the trouble which Uefa wanted broadcast, it was the English incompetence leading up to it, which contrasted so abjectly with German efficiency. Crozier got a hint of what Uefa thought when he sought clarification on the putative removal of the England team and was given access to officials only on the phone. He must have realised it was all over.

One thing Messrs Banks, McGivan and Crozier say about their bid is true: we have the stadiums, the infrastructure and the police experience which suggest we could stage a magnificent competition. If only we had had the political nous to wait until it was our turn to bid, you never know, we might even have been given the chance to prove it.

fields.headline: Blood on the mat
fields.standfirst: You thought wrestling was just panto? Jonathan Bernstein reports on a film about the agony behind the theatrics
fields.trailText: You thought wrestling was just panto? Jonathan Bernstein reports on a film about the agony behind the theatrics
fields.body:
There was a scene in Woody Allen's Hannah And Her Sisters where Max Von Sydow's acrid old misanthrope, driven wiggy by the base nature of public taste, seethes "Can you imagine the level of a mind that watches wrestling?" That same scene reappears in a new documentary about wrestling which asks the same question, albeit coated with less open revulsion.

As a screenwriter, Barry W Blaustein attained a reasonably comfortable level of prosperity (he co-penned most of Eddie Murphy's movies, including the upcoming Nutty Professor sequel), but in 1996, he put his formatting software to sleep and embarked on a labour of love. A lifelong fan of professional wrestling, Blaustein set off to analyse his enduring appetite for the bloody pantomime he terms "theatre at its most basic". Bare-bones camera crew in tow, Blaustein spent the next three years criss-crossing America, capturing rookie wrestlers bleeding and fracturing their dues in smokey halls, TV regulars at the top of their game and battered veterans at the end of the line. His conclusion: "Wrestlers are just like you and me. Except they're really different."

Inane as that sounds, it's a fairly accurate precis of the apparently irresistible urge that drives men long past their prime to participate willingly in their own evisceration. Take the enduring and all-too-destructible Terry Funk. This squashed-face 50-plus veteran has served time in Vince McMahon's World Wrestling Federation, the rival World Championship Wrestling and innumerable tinpot independent promotions. Doctors diagnose the nerves in his knees and elbows as damaged beyond any hope of repair. Beyond The Mat catches him preparing for the latest in a long line of farewell testimonials by taking part in the debut pay-per-view of the then-underdog company Extreme Championship Wrestling, which made its reputation by encouraging its workers to hurl each other through flaming tables and rake each other's skin with barbed wire.

At the end of the pay-per-view, Funk lies bloodied and gasping under two halves of a table. He seems exhilarated. The subsequent farewell match was filmed 18 months ago. Just last week, Funk was slugging it out in a cage match on WCW's Nitro, along with the steroid-and-saline-maintained likes of Hulk Hogan, Ric Flair and Roddy Piper. These are guys who are reaping the benefits of turning themselves into cartoons. Now they get paid for showing up, spouting their catchphrases and displaying their merchandise.

The dark heart of Beyond The Mat is in the segments devoted to a middle-aged wrestler who didn't get to enjoy the benefits of a brand name. Jake "The Snake" Roberts was a WWF champion in the early 90s. His two gimmicks - his evangelical delivery and the snake he carried into the ring in a sack and then hurled on the prone bodies of vanquished opponents - built his reputation as the most creative of heels (wrestling parlance for bad guys). The Roberts Blaustein tracks down and attempts to keep tabs on is a bloated crack addict, numbed by years of excess, spilling blood in front of a 65-strong crowd in a hall somewhere in Illinois. Tormented by regiments of personal demons, Roberts recounts grim tales of his mother, who married when she was 13, his numerous slain relatives and the father who treated him like a stranger. The movie then cuts to Roberts visiting his disapproving dad. Roberts' relationship with his own daughter is scarcely healthier. She berates him for his weakness and neglect. He flees after five minutes. Roberts is the wrestler who stayed on the road because he has no home to go back to.

The nearest thing to a happy ending Beyond The Mat has to offer is in the case of Mick Foley. In his teenage years, Foley won the attention of wrestling schools through the 8mm movies his friends shot of him hurling himself off the roof of his house onto mattresses. His subsequent career as Cactus Jack saw him attain legendary status, less for his agility and innovative moves as his astonishing ability to absorb pain. In his New York Times No 1 bestselling autobiography, he recounts in not-for-the-squeamish detail how he lost most of his left ear, how he shattered every bone in his body and how the highlight of his career was when uber-heel The Undertaker threw him off the top of a 5m (16ft) cage resulting in a fall so chaotic, no one in the arena believed he had survived. For the climax of Foley's segment, Blaustein pulled a manoeuvre almost McMahonesque in its exploitative qualities. After showing Foley and family backstage conversing cheerfully with that night's opponent The Rock (then in his heel phase), Blaustein then cuts to the two men in the stage beating each other to a pulp. Rather, he shows The Rock slamming Foley repeatedly over the head with a steel chair. He then cuts to the reaction of Foley's wife and pre-teen son and daughter. He stays focused on their tears and screaming as Foley's wife escorts them from the arena while assuring them: "Daddy's going to be all right." The Foleys are then shown several weeks later in their lovely Florida home watching the footage. "I'm a bad dad," mutters a shaken Mick Foley.

Though Foley later claimed that Blaustein had pulled something of a fast one, as his kids had been to plenty of his matches in the past, he was still supportive enough of the movie to help promote it. In this he was the lone WWF superstar (as the federation's wrestlers are all referred to). When Barry Blaustein began filming, the WWF was yet to become the all-encompassing media monstrosity it has subsequently become. Thus, Vince McMahon, desirous of any publicity for his company, which was then being drubbed in the ratings by the WCW "Nitro" show, permitted him all-access. In 1999, when the movie was amassing a pre-release buzz so favourable that Academy Award consideration seemed a possibility, the WWF was a very different proposition. "Disney is the model," Vince McMahon has said, and often, of his gargantuan family business. He had no interest in promoting a piece of product that displayed the workers as all too human, as far from impervious to pain - and if Beyond The Mat is laudable for anything, it's because it puts paid to the myth that no one gets hurt - and over which he had no control. After first attempting to buy the film from Blaustein, McMahon refused to allow any names or images owned by the WWF to appear on any promotional material, which pretty much capsized its box-office prospects beyond the so-called "smarts" (fans who know it's all fake but somehow can't stop themselves getting worked up into a frenzy).

As compelling a portrait as Beyond The Mat is of this peculiar ritual, there's also the sense that it documents an era about to end. As Vince McMahon relentlessly expands his empire, diversifying into a theme restaurant, a record label, a football league and parlaying The Rock's inextinguishable charisma into a movie career, he has said that one of his goals is to remove the word "wrestling" from the WWF name so that everyone understands he's in the business of sports entertainment. Over at the floundering but still fighting WCW, Vince Russo, the storyliner who bolted from the WWF, has even more telling ambitions. He wants to start recruiting actors and teaching them to wrestle.

 Beyond The Mat is out on Friday

webTitle: Turkey on the road to somewhere

fields.headline: Turkey on the road to somewhere
fields.standfirst: Denizli recalls the Wembley rout that proved a turning point
fields.trailText: When Neil Webb completed England's 8-0 win over Turkey at Wembley in October 1987, Mustafa Denizli hardly felt like breaking into a series of cartwheels down the touchline. Today, the Turkey coach may look back on that humiliation and smile.
fields.body:
When Neil Webb completed England's 8-0 win over Turkey at Wembley in October 1987, Mustafa Denizli hardly felt like breaking into a series of cartwheels down the touchline. But as the coach leads out his team against Portugal this afternoon he will look back on that humiliation and smile.

It is not that England are sinking beers on the sofa while his side play a quarter-final which fills him with glee. For Denizli the thrashing during his first spell in charge was pivotal to Turkey's progress. That it was a qualifier for the 1988 European Championship emphasises how far they have come.

"The fact that we lost 8-0 is very important in terms of creating today's success," he said yesterday. "It motivated us very much. Turkey needed a change of philosophy and in England we lost the match but we gained a philosophy. Because of this I remember that match not as an 8-0 defeat but as the beginning of new horizons for Turkish football."

An attacking mentality was established, the need for greater organisation and discipline taken in. Before departing two months later Denizli also attempted to make people believe. He pointed to the target of quali fying. Unless Turkey try to go somewhere they will always go nowhere, he said.

Now, without question, they have arrived. Their display in Euro 96 was disappointing, their first tournament since the 1954 World Cup ending without a point or a goal. But here they have recovered from their initial stumbles, survived domestic pressure so intense that Denizli said "you could lose your mind", and given a fanatical country something to shout about. After Galatasaray's Uefa Cup triumph most Turks must be hoarse by now.

That club success, coupled with their Euro 2000 showing, has confirmed Turkey as a growing force. The virulent criticism after the opening defeat by Italy has been all but forgotten. Then Denizli was told the football was "incredibly dreadful". One of yesterday's papers announced: "You cannot stop Turkey." Another declared: "Portugal are finished." There is rarely a middle ground.

The players, on about £85,000 each to reach the semi-finals, know millions will be watching and hoping. Turkey will grind to a halt and expectations are huge, but in certain respects the pressure is off. Having become the first Turkish side to reach a quarter-final they are unlikely to arrive back to a welter of rotten kebabs.

Those who have followed the team closely say the players have been noticeably more relaxed since securing their place in the last eight. Yesterday morning they were seen signing autographs at their Amsterdam hotel. Some have been shopping. And Denizli, who had been tense, shared his thoughts on Thursday over coffee and cigarettes.

Some wonder whether the team are too calm, feeling their job is done. But losing touch with the mood back home ought to be tough with Turkish television being beamed into the team's hotels. "It's been amazing seeing the scenes in Turkey," said Leicester's Muzzy Izzet. "It made you realise how much it meant."

The fervour has apparently not reached the heights that greeted Galatasaray's European success. Club ties remain stronger than the national bond and after the win over Arsenal perhaps the bar has been raised. But at least one person was wounded in the celebratory gunfire that greeted victory over Belgium as Turkey took to the streets. And the expat community here, which runs into hundreds of thousands, is buzzing with excitement.

Haydar Soylu, who runs the Omur hotel-restaurant in Rotterdam, epitomises the mood. Behind the bar hangs a picture of Hakan Sukur and upstairs today his coffee shop will be packed with people craning to watch the game live.

"If Turkey score," he says, "I am frightened everyone will come crashing through the ceiling."

Turkey's achievement here has been important not only in football terms but in integrating the country into Europe in a way politicians cannot achieve. And the European influence has been important in Turkey's sporting emergence. The arrival in the mid-1980s of the German coaches Jupp Derwall, who worked at Galatasaray, and Sepp Piontek, who was with the national team, is seen as crucial. So too the introduction of international stars such as Gheorghe Hagi and Gica Popescu. New methods and disciplines have complemented the Turkish technique and with each adventure the experience has grown.

Today it is the wonderful technique of the Portuguese which has to be counteracted. Denizli has described them as "the best team in the tournament" but the Turks have the passion, the counter-attacking flair and the goals of Hakan Sukur to make this far from a foregone conclusion. Certainly Denizli will not be smiling if he is beaten 8-0 tonight.

Turkey (3-5-2): Rustu; Fatih, Ogun, Alpay; Tayfun, Okan, Suat, Tayfur, Abdullah; Hakan Sukur, Arif.

Suspensions: None.

Portugal (4-1-4-1): Vitor Baia; Abel Xavier, Couto, Jorge Costa, Dimas; Vidigal; Conceicao, Rui Costa, Paulo Bento, Figo; Nuno Gomes.

Suspensions: None.

Referee Dick Jol

fields.headline: Ron's in the dugout!
fields.standfirst: The Fast Show's Ron Manager gives his...er... thoughts on Euro 2000
fields.trailText: The Fast Show's Ron Manager gives his...er... thoughts on Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Euro 2000... isn't it?... hmm?... wasn't it?... where did it all go wrong?... a lack of concentration... a moment's madness... and Boof! Another on-the-spot fine for public urination as Big Ron and I drowned our sorrows at "Heidi's Hole-in-the-Wall" on Tuesday night.

But Euro 2000... hmm? A bit of a Mickey Mouse tournament, wasn't it? Let's face it, the real competition starts in October! When England face the might of Germany! A titanic clash between two of the favourites for the only cup that matters! . . . and this time Kev's lads can go all the way.

Once-mighty Germany... humbled in Charleroi! Once-mighty Brazil humbled at Wembley!... silky skills pitted against dogged determination!... bit like my honeymoon, actually... er... hmm... er... marvellous.

And I've got a letter!... from Mr Reg Wedlake of South London, who writes: "Why do people always refer to Hooliganism as 'The English Disease'? Most of the chaps returning from the fleshpots of Europe seemed to think they picked up things locally."

Well, Reg, this makes my blood run wild!... and I think many of them had picked things up locally... and I don't mean plastic chairs! But it seems everything's the English disease nowadays!... German measles!... I don't think you can call that an English disease, hmm? What about Asian Flu?... Nile Fever?... Dhobi itch!... isn't it?... My haemorrhoids are killing me!

Er... let's not be too harsh on the long-suffering fans. After the roller-coaster ride of England's last group match, many of those lads didn't know if they were coming or going... one minute sampling the delights of continental Europe... the next they're on the ferry home. And... spare a thought for the returning English squad. As the fans trooped wearily through customs for far-flung destinations - Gateshead, London King's Cross - Beckham was probably just getting into Victoria himself!

But don't despair! Japan and South Korea 2002, isn't it?... hmm?... and don't let slip the dogs of war down there! ... Relish the Sushi!... Relish the Tussle!... There's plenty there to build on!... Young talent!... The Boy Owen!... makes Ronaldo seem long in the tooth!... Paul Scholes!... Paul?... Why the ever-furrowed brow?... Scholesy!... always dangerous!... reminiscent of that other ginger talisman of '66, wasn't it?... hmm? Alan Ball in his pomp!

Ballsy?... Ballsy... hmm? Squeaky voice?... was he a dangerous player?... certainly wouldn't want him as your manager!

And as my colleague Big Ron Atkinson says, England showed they're a better team when driving at the game!... hmm? Not many of them allowed to drive from Old Trafford after the game... Yes!... but when on the back-foot, we started back- pedalling and shot ourselves in the foot and... er... lost our shape at the back... and er... I've put my foot in my mouth, haven't I? I can actually do that, you know! There's a picture of me somewhere.

But Euro 2000... hmm?... a bit of a Mickey-Mouse tournament, wasn't it? Sometimes you wonder what those Euro-burghers are thinking... hmm? Tinkers!... er... Tinkerers!... aren't they? The hokey-cokey of the club competitions!... Champions League... Uefa Cup... You're in!... You're out! Second leg... In!... The Intertoto Cup!?... What?... Sounds like a little dog, doesn't it? Oo-err, I don't think we're in Kansas anymore... Auntie Em... Auntie Em!

There's no sense of tradition... of history!... Take any English institution... The Worthington Cup!... Milk Cup!... Littlewoods Cup!... Rumbelows Cup!... er, Coca-Cola, wasn't it?... hmm? But... Mickey Mouse? ... don't make me laugh! ... Always did make me laugh, actually... always up to something, wasn't he?... ho ho... those big feet! No matter what way he turned, those big ears that always seemed to be facing you... hmm?

Gary Lineker, wasn't it?... Francis Jeffers, the jug-eared talisman... hasn't he assumed Gary's mantle at Everton with aplomb!... wonder how he gets it over his head...

But Mickey Mouse or not, there's still some action going on here - check my Top Tip for some of the jiggery-pokery you might see, illustrated by my good friend Mr John Watson!

As for the team in form for the quarter-finals... ? Well, your guess is as good as mine, having missed a few games midweek as myself and my fellow columnist, Big Ron Atkinson, consoled ourselves on Wednesday by taking a car down to Eurodisney! Arrived back in Brussels' main square late Friday evening for a couple of liveners at "Heidi's Hidey-Hole"... Big Ron's Donald Duck impersonations had me in stitches... could hardly contain myself!... and blow me, another on-the-spot fine! Still, Big Ron assures me I can put it on expenses to the Guardian... reckons he always does.

And finally! We were royally entertained round at Edgar Davids' the other night... Don't worry you Dutch supporters! Just a quiet night in round the goggle-box! Does he see everything in 3D, do you think?... And here's his one to watch!... Jaap Stam!... hewn out of wood!... nickname... "The Dutch Elm"... and you can't tell me that's an English disease, Mr Blatter!

©Paul Whitehouse and Jim Reilly 2000

As the fans trooped wearily through customs for far-flung destinations - Gateshead, London King's Cross - Beckham was probably just getting into Victoria himself! But don't despair! Japan and South Korea 2002, isn't it?... hmm?... and don't let slip the dogs of war down there! ... Relish the Sushi!... Relish the Tussle!... There's plenty there to build on!... Young talent!... The Boy Owen!... makes Ronaldo seem long in the tooth!... Paul Scholes!... Paul?... Why the ever-furrowed brow?... Scholesy!... always dangerous!... reminiscent of that other ginger talisman of '66, wasn't it?... hmm? Alan Ball in his pomp! Ballsy?... Ballsy... hmm? Squeaky voice?... was he a dangerous player?... certainly wouldn't want him as your manager! And as my colleague Big Ron Atkinson says, England showed they're a better team when driving at the game!... hmm? Not many of them allowed to drive from Old Trafford after the game... Yes!... but when on the back-foot, we started back- pedalling and shot ourselves in the foot and... er... lost our shape at the back... and er... I've put my foot in my mouth, haven't I? I can actually do that, you know! There's a picture of me somewhere. But Euro 2000... hmm?... a bit of a Mickey-Mouse tournament, wasn't it? Sometimes you wonder what those Euro-burghers are thinking... hmm? Tinkers!... er... Tinkerers!... aren't they? The hokey-cokey of the club competitions!... Champions League... Uefa Cup... You're in!... You're out! Second leg... In!... The Intertoto Cup!?... What?... Sounds like a little dog, doesn't it? Oo-err, I don't think we're in Kansas anymore... Auntie Em... Auntie Em! There's no sense of tradition... of history!... Take any English institution... The Worthington Cup!... Milk Cup!... Littlewoods Cup!... Rumbelows Cup!... er, Coca-Cola, wasn't it?... hmm? But... Mickey Mouse? ... don't make me laugh! ... Always did make me laugh, actually... always up to something, wasn't he?... ho ho... those big feet! No matter what way he turned, those big ears that always seemed to be facing you... hmm? Gary Lineker, wasn't it?... Francis Jeffers, the jug-eared talisman... hasn't he assumed Gary's mantle at Everton with aplomb!... wonder how he gets it over his head... But Mickey Mouse or not, there's still some action going on here - check my Top Tip for some of the jiggery-pokery you might see, illustrated by my good friend Mr John Watson! As for the team in form for the quarter-finals... ? Well, your guess is as good as mine, having missed a few games midweek as myself and my fellow columnist, Big Ron Atkinson, consoled ourselves on Wednesday by taking a car down to Eurodisney! Arrived back in Brussels' main square late Friday evening for a couple of liveners at "Heidi's Hidey-Hole"... Big Ron's Donald Duck impersonations had me in stitches... could hardly contain myself!... and blow me, another on-the-spot fine! Still, Big Ron assures me I can put it on expenses to the Guardian... reckons he always does. And finally! We were royally entertained round at Edgar Davids' the other night... Don't worry you Dutch supporters! Just a quiet night in round the goggle-box! Does he see everything in 3D, do you think?... And here's his one to watch!... Jaap Stam!... hewn out of wood!... nickname... "The Dutch Elm"... and you can't tell me that's an English disease, Mr Blatter! ©Paul Whitehouse and Jim Reilly 2000 Ron's top tip No2: the bicycle kick

webTitle: Rid us of this turbulent shoot-out

fields.headline: Rid us of this turbulent shoot-out
fields.trailText: The beauty of sport is its narrative. The players are the dramatis personae; the stadium is the theatre. The action unfolds, the story is told, it takes as long as it takes for a conclusion to be reached. Except, of course, that it no longer does.
fields.body:
The beauty of sport is its narrative. It is what attracts good writers. The players are the dramatis personae ; the stadium is the theatre; the play is the play. The action unfolds, the story is told, it takes as long as it takes for a conclusion to be reached.

Except, of course, that it no longer does. Hamlet has been deemed to be too long, those useful Danish midfielders Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead, the thing has to be finished by Act Three. This weekend's quarter-finals signal the start of the "penalty shoot-out phase", loved by television, loathed by anyone who truly believes in sport.

Penalty shoot-outs are like bad sex: they offer instant gratification and a quick conclusion. They do not bring the narrative to a satisfying conclusion; they distort and ultimately destroy it. Poor teams will play for penalties and may win a fraudulent victory. Sport can accommodate luck; it cannot accommodate larceny.

The European Championship is where this travesty began: in the 1976 final, when Czechoslovakia beat West Germany on penalties (the World Cup followed suit six years later). Euro 96 was disfigured by shoot-outs, determining the results of two quarter-finals and both semis.

The introduction of the extra-time golden goal in that competition achieved nothing: it merely terrified teams into becoming even more negative. Indeed, all the evidence is that, when it comes to golden goals, the world's best players are leaden-footed. Why not scrap the match and just have the shoot-out? Better still, draw lots in the dressing room and give everyone another two hours in the garden.

Television - and tournament organisers - cannot abide a draw but a draw can sometimes be the perfect result. England v Germany (Euro 96) and England v Argentina (1998 World Cup) were magnificent drawn games, wrecked by the artificiality of penalty shoot-outs. England are the world's worst penalty takers; perhaps they are secret purists. They should lead the fight for the restoration of real results.

There has to be a better way. Ideally the game should be replayed and replayed until there is a winner. To hell with the TV schedules. If the final has to be postponed, postpone it. If that is deemed unacceptable - and with TV pulling the strings, no doubt it would be - write a computer programme that allows the play during the game to be assessed objectively to produce a winner on points.

Football needs its own Duckworth-Lewis method, a way of measuring the precise state of a game. This could be shown on a minute-by-minute basis. Say the total play represents 100%; team A might be leading team B (on the basis of territory, corners, shots on goal, posts hit) by 60%-40%. That would force team B to attack, as all that could save them is a conventional win or a monumental turnaround in the game.

That way, of course, the poorer team could never hold out for a draw and the artificial sanctuary of the shoot-out.
