webTitle: Hélène Rouart in Her Father's Study, Edgar Degas (1886)

fields.headline: Hélène Rouart in Her Father's Study, Edgar Degas (1886)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Hilaire Germain Edgar Degas (1834-1917), an avant-garde artist obsessed with academic traditions; an intensely erotic painter and sculptor of women's bodies who was celibate; a modern man who was an extreme French nationalist and anti-Semite; and the most fascinating Impressionist after Manet.

Subject: Hélène Rouart, only daughter of Degas's friend, the rich painter and collector (and fellow rightwinger) Henri Rouart.

Distinguishing features: This is a strange portrait. It is supposed to be of Hélène Rouart, but she is utterly overwhelmed by signs of her father. She stands in his study surrounded by his art collection, posing behind his chair, which is colossal compared with her, as if behind a restraining fence. She is diminished by the imagined presence of her father, who might be just outside the room - though actually he was travelling in Venice when this was painted.

Hélène has a pasty complexion, her hair is flattened, her dress encases her. She lists like a passenger on a swaying deck. This is the ailing, unhappy daughter of a 19th-century patriarch, so subjugated to the fetishised, massive presence of her father - images of his taste, his wealth - that she seems half-dead. To her left is a landscape of Naples by Corot, and lower down a drawing by Millet, and she is juxtaposed with them as another of her father's treasures. To her right is the glass case containing her father's collection of Egyptian funerary artefacts. She too is mummified and entombed in this room. Degas makes Hélène show the ringless fingers of her left hand. The only man in her life, this painting says in a brutal way, is her father.

Degas and women is a subject that's hard to get to the bottom of. There's a violence to this painting, but perhaps also an empathy. Degas expressed misogynist sentiments, yet was friends with the painter Berthe Morisot. This painting is from the period when Degas was turning away from the city crowd, towards a private erotic theatre staged in the studio and bourgeois interior. Hélène in this painting is a terrible contrast with the women stars of Parisian nightlife whom Degas painted in the 1870s as heroines of urban freedom. His 1879 painting Miss La La at the Cirque Fernando, also in the National Gallery, has a woman flying in the air, alone and free in the open space above the crowd, hanging by her teeth from the trapeze.

What a fall to earth is in this painting. Hélène Rouart, the well-behaved daughter of the bourgeoisie, is repressed, dulled in a way that Degas's proletarian performers are not. She's painted to make her as lifeless as possible: her hands drape weakly over the chair back, her face is passionless. This is middle-class depression, the crisis of the 19th-century individual that Freud would later diagnose. But it would not be true to say there's no desire in this painting. It is unbelievably luxurious: Degas kept repainting and retouching it over many years, making the reds ever richer, the texture more opulent. The sexuality that is absent from Hélène's demeanour becomes the glint of silver on the mummies' vitrine, the luxury of a Chinese silk hanging. The painting is suspenseful: possibilities, unacknowledged desires, circulate in its tense space, between the painter, the young woman and her father.

Hélène Rouart married and left home soon after posing for Degas. As for Degas, he died 30 years later with this canvas still in his studio.

Where is it? Room 44, National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885)

fields.headline: Opportunity knocks for Dugarry
fields.standfirst: Spain v France
fields.trailText: The turbulent life of Nicolas Anelka may take another downturn tomorrow if France's coach Roger Lemerre follows his gambling instincts and replaces him with Christophe Dugarry for the quarter-final tie with Spain.
fields.body:
The turbulent life of Nicolas Anelka may take another downturn tomorrow if France's coach Roger Lemerre follows his gambling instincts and replaces him with Christophe Dugarry for the quarter-final tie with Spain.

Dugarry, one of the many French striking failures in the last World Cup, impressed Lemerre with his performance against Holland on Wednesday, and not just because he headed the opening goal. Lemerre said: "I thought he was one of the best players on the pitch," fulsome praise considering that the Dutch, unlike the French, played their strongest team.

Lemerre also revealed that he brought off Dugarry only to prevent him being sent off after he reacted petulantly to receiving a yellow card. "He will be useful to us in future matches," said Lemerre, who obviously expects France to go all the way to the final.

His praise does not guarantee that Dugarry will start tomorrow, though there must be a good chance. He was also impressive when replacing Anelka in the second game against the Czech Republic, with his aggressive style helping to turn the match France's way. Even if he starts on the bench again, Anelka, who has yet to score in the tournament, will be under intense pressure to perform.

Perhaps traumatised by his inability to locate a barn door, let alone hit one, during France 98, Dugarry prefers to play in midfield these days, taking up Emmanuel Petit's position on the left side against Holland. But he showed against the Czechs that he can still play up front and, against the Dutch, that he can still score goals.

The only other minor quandary for Lemerre is how best to balance his midfield, which may lead him to bring in Youri Djorkaeff for either Petit or Patrick Vieira.

Lemerre has no regrets about playing what amounted to reserve team against Holland, although he was disappointed with France's first defeat since last September. He is aware that at major tournaments a winning rhythm is important, which he sacrificed by resting key players for their general benefit.

The Spanish, on the other hand, must still be mentally and physically exhausted after their efforts against Yugoslavia, in which they scored twice in injury time for the dramatic win that clinched Group C.

The problem with the Spanish players is that they rarely sing from the same hymn sheet at major tournaments, perennially failing to live up to expectations. Having lost to Norway in the opening game, they staggered past Slovenia before staging that amazing comeback against the Yugoslavs, though it has convinced them that destiny may be intervening on their behalf.

Echoing a line from a Beach Boys' song, the winger Joseba Etxeberria said: "I'm beginning to get good vibrations. Coming back from being eliminated to winning the group in a couple of minutes gives you a tremendous psychological boost. Now we have to be faithful to our style and go out and attack France from the first minute. We will not be inhibited because we are facing the world champions."

Spain will also be looking to banish memories of their 2-0 final defeat to France in the 1984 championship.

Spain's coach Jose Antonio Camacho says that the French style is more suited to their game than Holland's, adding: "It could be an even better match than the one against Yugoslavia." Though it could scarcely have such a melodramatic finish.

France (probable, 4-3-1-2): Barthez; Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Candela or Lizarazu; Vieira, Deschamps, Petit or Djorkaeff; Zidane; Henry, Anelka or Dugarry.

Spain (probable, 4-4-2): Canizares; Salgado, Abelardo, Paco or Hierro, Sergi; Mendieta, Guardiola, Helguera, Fran or Munitis; Alfonso, Raul.

Venue Jan Breydet Stadium,

Bruges

Kick-off 7.45pm BST

Referee Pierluigi Collina

(Italy)

Head-to-head Spain 10 wins, France 9; draws 6

Television

Live on BBC 1 from 7.15pm
Highlights on BBC 1 at 12.30am
Highlights on ITV 1.40am.

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 7.30pm

fields.headline: Kevin Keegan ha ha ha
fields.standfirst: The unofficial story of England's ill-fated Euro 2000 challenge
fields.trailText: The unofficial story of England's ill-fated Euro 2000 challenge, by Martin Thorpe.
fields.body:
June 8

England leave home shores and head for Spa, apparently in no need of the Belgian town's famous health-giving properties. "The players are ready, I'm ready, the country is ready and we're looking forward to it," says the national coach Kevin Keegan of Euro 2000.

"We want to get going. I'm excited at the prospect of what we are going to do, what success we can bring, and when and where it will end."

David Beckham agrees. "There's a great atmosphere among the lads and we're looking forward to doing the business on the field," he says, before making the rash prediction that: "It's going to be interesting over there when we get there."

When he gets there, Beckham can be excused a double take at the team bus, which is painted with the faces of laughing fans alongside the legend "Football without frontiers". One of the fans looks uncannily like Scary Spice.

Meanwhile the other England coach is also getting scary. "If we can get the very best out of the players at our disposal then we can win it, I really believe that," Keegan says at England's training ground.

June 9

The first panic: whether to cheer or fear a knee injury to Alan Shearer, playing his last tournament before retiring from international football. The second panic: which player gets to be Chris Tarrant in the board-game version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? - the millionaire players' off-duty pastime of choice. Things have gone downhill since the last World Cup, when Scrabble was favourite.

June 10

Third panic: there's no Racing Post in the camp to provide a form guide to today's Derby. Cue urgent SOS back home for a copy. Oh, and the tournament begins in Brussels.

June 12

Keegan sticks by a fit-again Shearer and an ill-looking 4-4-2 system for the opening game against Portugal. England scare themselves by going 2-0 up, then watch helplessly as the first holes appear in their midfield and Keegan's optimism.

England lose 3-2 with Michael Owen taken off at half-time for failing to hold the ball up. Presumably Keegan was out of the room when Owen said just before the finals: "I can't play as a target man. I am about getting in behind defenders and using my pace. It's the only way I can play. If you take some parts of my game away I'm not going to be the same player."

June 13

So low are England's expectations these days that Les Reed, one of the less well known team coaches, offers the novel excuse that going 2-0 up after 20 minutes was not planned for and had confused the players. "We didn't expect to go in the lead quite convincingly as early as we did. It was part of the game plan we probably expected to invoke later in the game, and psychologically that may have thrown us."

Keegan and the Football Association add more confusion by trying to justify Beckham's one-finger salute to some England fans by saying he was subjected to terrible abuse as he departed down the tunnel. Beckham had in fact made the gesture minutes earlier in the middle of the pitch.

June 16

Rioting in Charleroi prompts questions as to why England could not stop these yobs travelling abroad. The FA is left questioning the wisdom of sticking "football without frontiers" on the team bus.

June 17

England kick off nervously against Germany, requiring a win against their bogy side to stay in the tournament. One English flag in the ground carries the advice: "Don't Panic". ITV's Clive Tyldesley begins his commentary: "Are you sitting comfortably? Neither am I."

But, glory be, England finally find a team worse than them and, after 34 years of frustration, win 1-0. Despite a total lack of creativity, at least England avoid going out on penalties (for the time being).

June 18

After the Germany game, Uefa informs England that if there is one more disgraceful display like that the team will be sent home. Unfortunately it is referring to the drunken English yobs who rioted again. The FA sees that its 2006 World Cup bid is stopped in its tracks - just like the England kit van, which breaks down on the way back to Spa after the game.

June 19

Having seen off Germany, Keegan is intoxicated and, like many in that state, loses touch with reality. "The best way for Alan Shearer to finish would be to pick up the Euro 2000 trophy," he insists. "It is our job to make that dream a reality."

June 20

England step on to the Charleroi pitch with one foot in the quarter-finals, as it were. Unfortunately, it is not Phil Neville's left one, which concedes the decisive penalty in the dying minutes as Romania win 3-2 and England are out.

"It's difficult when you play like we did tonight," Keegan says. "I can't tell you why this player couldn't pass the ball or that player couldn't muster enough energy to make a run when we needed to. We can't go on as we did tonight. Now we need to get something going that the players can trust in."

The honest truth at last? In fact, these are Keegan's words after England lost 1-0 to Scotland at Wembley in October. Despite all his PR about winning Euro 2000, he must have known all along his players were not up to it. Now all he has to do is rescue the situation in time for England's opening World Cup qualifier in October. At least it's against Germany.

"We didn't expect to go in the lead quite convincingly as early as we did. It was part of the game plan we probably expected to invoke later in the game, and psychologically that may have thrown us." Keegan and the Football Association add more confusion by trying to justify Beckham's one-finger salute to some England fans by saying he was subjected to terrible abuse as he departed down the tunnel. Beckham had in fact made the gesture minutes earlier in the middle of the pitch. June 16 Rioting in Charleroi prompts questions as to why England could not stop these yobs travelling abroad. The FA is left questioning the wisdom of sticking "football without frontiers" on the team bus. June 17 England kick off nervously against Germany, requiring a win against their bogy side to stay in the tournament. One English flag in the ground carries the advice: "Don't Panic". ITV's Clive Tyldesley begins his commentary: "Are you sitting comfortably? Neither am I." But, glory be, England finally find a team worse than them and, after 34 years of frustration, win 1-0. Despite a total lack of creativity, at least England avoid going out on penalties (for the time being). June 18 After the Germany game, Uefa informs England that if there is one more disgraceful display like that the team will be sent home. Unfortunately it is referring to the drunken English yobs who rioted again. The FA sees that its 2006 World Cup bid is stopped in its tracks - just like the England kit van, which breaks down on the way back to Spa after the game. June 19 Having seen off Germany, Keegan is intoxicated and, like many in that state, loses touch with reality. "The best way for Alan Shearer to finish would be to pick up the Euro 2000 trophy," he insists. "It is our job to make that dream a reality." June 20 England step on to the Charleroi pitch with one foot in the quarter-finals, as it were. Unfortunately, it is not Phil Neville's left one, which concedes the decisive penalty in the dying minutes as Romania win 3-2 and England are out. "It's difficult when you play like we did tonight," Keegan says. "I can't tell you why this player couldn't pass the ball or that player couldn't muster enough energy to make a run when we needed to. We can't go on as we did tonight. Now we need to get something going that the players can trust in." The honest truth at last? In fact, these are Keegan's words after England lost 1-0 to Scotland at Wembley in October. Despite all his PR about winning Euro 2000, he must have known all along his players were not up to it. Now all he has to do is rescue the situation in time for England's opening World Cup qualifier in October. At least it's against Germany.

webTitle: Hagi back to refresh depleted Romania

fields.headline: Hagi back to refresh depleted Romania
fields.standfirst: Italy v Romania
fields.trailText: Romania may be the underdogs but they are intent on snapping at a few more heels yet. While the inquest continues for Kevin Keegan, England's conquerors are scenting a bigger scalp, Italy, tonight .
fields.body:
Romania may be the underdogs but they are intent on snapping at a few more heels yet. While the inquest continues for Kevin Keegan, England's conquerors are scenting a bigger scalp, Italy, tonight .

But, if Romania are to reach the semi-finals, they will have to do it the hard way. They have three players suspended tonight - Dan Petrescu, Adrian Ilie and Cosmin Contra - while Gica Popescu is out of the tournament with a ruptured calf muscle.

Even so, there is no doubt whom the Italians would rather have faced. "We won't underestimate Romania because they will present a much greater threat to us," their coach Dino Zoff said yesterday.

"They were a lot better than England, not only tactically but also from an athletic viewpoint. England were one-dimensional."

As always, Romania's best hope lies with their veteran talisman Gheorghe Hagi. Suspended against England, the midfielder has had time to recharge his batteries, not to mention shave off his hair. The Romanian coach Emerich Ienei said: "We have beaten the English without him, now we can beat the Italians. With Hagi around, anything and everything is possible."

An Italian practice match yesterday offered a few clues - or, perhaps, red herrings - as to Zoff's team. In full view of Romanian television crews his first XI included Alessandro del Piero and Luigi di Biagio, with Francesco Totti and Antonio Conte in the reserves . The Italian media were sceptical, to say the least.

While Hagi returns for Romania, Florentin Petre is expected to replace Petrescu and Ioan Ganea, scorer of the penalty that knocked out England, should come in for Ilie.

webTitle: Dutch find their friction as critics stick the boot in

fields.headline: Dutch find their friction as critics stick the boot in
fields.standfirst: Holland v Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The Dutch would not feel at home unless there was a row in the camp. And one has conveniently blown up on the eve of their quarter-final against Yugoslavia. But, while the problem used to be disagreements between black and white, now the argument is between old and new.
fields.body:
The Dutch would not feel at home unless there was a row in the camp. And one has conveniently blown up on the eve of their quarter-final against Yugoslavia. But, while the problem used to be disagreements between black and white, now the argument is between old and new.

After Wednesday's 3-2 defeat of France, Johan Cruyff heavily criticised Frank Rijkaard's "star" players and Edgar Davids in particular for his persistent haranguing of the referee. "He showed he was good in the second half with his chasing but why can't he keep his mouth shut?" Cruyff said.

The bespectacled midfielder saw red instead of his normal orange. "He's not there," he retorted. "He doesn't know what the manager tells us to do and what we talk about prior to a game."

Cruyff is one of a number of media critics who continue to find fault with the Dutch side although they have won all their games, are joint top scorers in the tournament with seven goals and topped their group in order to stay in Holland for this crucial game.

However, it is the manner of the Dutch performances which have left the sceptics unconvinced. After victory over an unlucky Czech Republic side was secured by a last-minute penalty, even Rijkaard stuck the boot into his team.

But the orange still failed to blossom against Denmark and Holland were flattered by a 3-0 scoreline. Wednesday's narrow win over a France Second XI said more about French strength in depth than about Holland's chances of winning the tournament.

In this regard it may sound strange to counsel the Dutch against complacency as they prepare to meet Yugoslavia, whom they beat in the last World Cup, but already some Dutch players have predicted a trouncing for the Yugoslavs, which has been met with an equally predictable response. "Their arrogance is a motive for us," said the midfielder Ljubinko Drulovic.

It is easy to see the Dutch point. Yugoslavia's defence is a wonder to behold. They let in three goals against tiny Slovenia in the opening tie, kept a clean sheet against Norway before engaging in a see-saw classic against Spain which saw them throw away the lead three times and then lose the match to an injury-time goal.

But from this pantomime sequence their four-goal striker Savo Milosevic has extracted an intriguing logic. "If the Dutch think they know our game, they are wrong," he said, "because I never know how Yugoslavia will play."

A sounder source of optimism for the Dutch is that the Yugoslavs have the worst disciplinary record of the tournament. They have had a player sent off in all three games, and also picked up 13 yellow cards.

As a result of bookings, the midfielder Slavisa Jokanovic and the young forward Mateja Kezman are both ruled out of today's game. The defender Goran Djorovic is injured and the key midfielder Vladimir Jugovic is doubtful with back trouble.

Holland's injury doubts concern the goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar and the midfielder Ronald de Boer.

Holland (possible, 4-4-2): Van der Sar; Reiziger, Stam, F de Boer, Numan; Overmars, Davids, Cocu, Zenden; Bergkamp, Kluivert.

Suspensions : None.

Yugoslavia (4-4-2): Kralj; Komljenovic, S Mihajlovic, Djukic, Saveljic; Stojkovic, Stankovic, Jugovic, Drulovic; P Mijatovic, Milosevic.

Suspensions : Jokanovic, Kezman.

Venue De Kuip stadium,

Rotterdam

Kick-off 5.0pm BST

Referee Jose Maria Garcia Aranda

(Spain)

Head-to-head Holland 4 wins, Yugoslavia 3 wins, 1 draw

Television

Live on ITV from 4.45pm

Highlights on BBC1 at 12.30am

Highlights on ITV at 1.40am

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 12.30pm

fields.headline: Del Piero fuels passionate debate
fields.standfirst: Luxury player or indispensable?  We meet the man who has Italy split down the middle
fields.trailText: Luxury player or indispensable? Paddy Agnew meets the man who has Italy split down the middle.
fields.body:
Towards the end of Italy's training session in Geel on Thursday morning a frisson ran through the massed ranks of the Italian football media. As the players were preparing for the ritual mini-game that wraps up many sessions, all eyes were on the line-ups.

Surprise, surprise: Alessandro del Piero was in the "first XI" and his erstwhile rival Francesco Totti was relegated to the reserves. It was too much for the man from Ansa, Italy's national press agency, to resist. By the time training finished Ansa had sent out a quick flash: "Surprise in training, Del Piero not Totti".

As Italy prepare for their Euro 2000 quarter-final clash with Romania at the King Baudouin stadium in Brussels tonight, the nation's thoughts are focused on the Totti or Del Piero issue. It seems that for Italians a major football tournament is not worth the candle unless it engenders a furious, nationwide debate as to which of two contemporary stars should figure in the side.

The tradition dates from the Mexico World Cup in 1970 when Internazionale's Sandro Mazzola and golden boy Gianni Rivera of Milan were judged incompatible by the coach Ferruccio Valcareggi. And in the 1998 World Cup in France, Del Piero was in a two-way battle for a place with the only contemporary Italian who could reasonably be considered even more famous (and wealthy) than himself, the "Little Prince" Roberto Baggio.

As in 1970 and 1998, Italy's 56m-strong armchair army of potential national coaches want both their stars to play. Please, why not Mazzola with Rivera, Del Piero with Baggio, and now Totti with Del Piero?

The enthusiasm for Del Piero is understandable. Likewise, one can only admire the cavalier tactical approach urged by an editorial in yesterday's Gazzetta Dello Sport, calling on the team coach Dino Zoff to start with a four-man attack led by Del Piero and Filippo Inzaghi, supported by Totti and Stefano Fiore. Admirable, but hardly realistic. Only in the most extreme of losing circumstances, and maybe not even then, would Zoff consider such an attacking quartet.

No, for Del Piero fans the bad news is that Totti is almost certain to start tonight, once more relegating one of the world's highest-paid footballer to the substitutes' bench. If Del Piero plays, it will most likely be only as a second-half substitute, just as in Italy's opening Euro 2000 wins against Turkey and Belgium when he came on instead of Fiore and Totti respectively.

It was the third of Italy's first-round games, their 2-1 victory over Sweden in Eindhoven on Monday, which poured fuel on the Totti or Del Piero debate. Zoff opted to field a side containing eight reserves, including Del Piero. He seized his chance in the best possible manner, scoring an 88th-minute left-foot winner straight out of the Roy of the Rovers school of prowess.

"It's true that after scoring that goal I felt an almost violent sensation," the Juventus player says, "and that was because the goal meant a lot. The game against Sweden was a difficult one in that we were already into the quarter-finals, and therefore those of us who had played less than the others had to be sure to lay on a good show."

The "good show" was delivered and the nationwide debate exploded. It is one ripe with the possibility for endless local polemics of the north v south, Juventus v Roma (Totti is Roma's captain) variety. Not for nothing, the front page of the Rome sports daily Corriere Dello Sport yesterday carried the headline, "This is Totti's Italy". Doubtless the Turin daily Tuttosport will respond this morning with calls for Del Piero to start.

To the credit of both players, neither has indulged in polemics or tried to make life difficult for Zoff. Both want to play, obviously, yet both have spent most of Euro 2000 so far explaining what a good player the other is. "I'm taking this whole thing calmly and serenely," Del Piero says. "There is no war of nerves between me and Francesco."

Non-Italian observers, confused by the sight of Del Piero on the bench, possibly underestimate two considerations. Totti, 23, is a supremely talented player, and Del Piero has spent much of this season on the comeback trail after a 10-month lay- off caused by cruciate ligament damage to his left knee in November 1998.

Whereas Totti has played at close to his best throughout the season, Del Piero has made a slow journey back to full strength and sharpness. Intriguingly, however, Del Piero appears close to journey's end as Euro 2000 moves into the quarter-finals. His ability to glide past defenders, his free-kick skills and terrific natural touch are all back. One suspects that if he played for any other country he would line up not as a striker but as midfield playmaker. Significantly, in one Serie A game last season when Zinedine Zidane was unavailable for Juventus, Del Piero dropped back to appear in the Frenchman's playmaker role, doing so with total ease and to great effect.

Zoff, however, does not want that type of playmaker. His choice is the talented Fiore, who tends to be more combative and mobile. Which leaves Del Piero and Totti to battle for a place up front and, in that context, Zoff probably believes Totti's greater physical strength gives him the edge.

Cynics might argue that, if Del Piero is dropped again, he can console himself with his huge pay packet. He has estimated annual earnings, after tax, of $11m (£7.3m), half in salary from Juventus and half from deals with such as Coca-Cola, Adidas and Walt Disney.

Del Piero, too, is still only 25 and clearly there are other European Championships, not to say World Cups, ahead. However, the sight of him on the substitutes' bench brings to mind the day almost a year ago when he and Juventus concluded months of contract negotiations. Asked how he felt about being then the world's best-paid footballer, he replied: "Money is important because it helps you to live better, but there are lots of things in life you simply can't buy."

Starting with a guaranteed first-choice place in Dino Zoff's Italy team.

webTitle: Crozier denies power shift to Wilkinson

fields.headline: Crozier denies power shift to Wilkinson
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan was told yesterday there will be no pressure put on him by the Football Association or its technical director Howard Wilkinson to make changes to his backroom staff or be forced to accept a more hands-on role by Wilkinson over tactics.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan was told yesterday there will be no pressure put on him by the Football Association or its technical director Howard Wilkinson to make changes to his backroom staff or be forced to accept a more hands-on role by Wilkinson over tactics.

Wilkinson will continue to offer any technical help the England coach needs, although he made it clear that he will not be playing any greater role with Keegan's squad.

On a day of confused signals from the FA the chief executive Adam Crozier responded to reports of a rift between Keegan and Wilkinson and that the technical director was increasing his power base. Such conclusions "could not be more wrong", said Crozier.

The reports were based on suggestions by the FA chairman Geoff Thompson that Wilkinson should take a more active role with the senior team.

Following widespread and strong criticism of Keegan's tactics after England's failure in Euro 2000, Thompson said: "Kevin may need a little bit of help in that department and he would accept that himself."

While he did not explicitly advocate Wilkinson playing a more hands-on role or a tactical adviser being specifically appointed No2 to Keegan, Thompson added: "We have got a very good technical director, a lot of good coaches and have got to encourage the integration of that into the full international set-up".

But Crozier declared: "Any changes to Kevin Keegan's back-up team are ultimately his responsibility and his alone. Of course, the lessons of the European Championships can and must be learned. But the relationship between Kevin Keegan and Howard Wilkinson will not change.

"Crucially Kevin has had, and will continue to have, full responsibility for selecting the England team, its tactics and its performance on the pitch.

"We are all 100% behind Kevin because he is the best person for the job. His ability, charisma and inspiration command the support of us all."

Wilkinson, who has overall responsibility for technical development from youth teams upwards, running the Under-21 side and providing assistance to Keegan, made his own position clear, claiming Thompson's comments were taken out of context. "Reports of my increased involvement are totally alien to what was said and to what the real situation is," said Wilkinson.

After England's defeat by Romania and elimination from Euro 2000, Keegan insisted he would not be seeking tactical help from an acknowledged strategist and was entirely satisfied with the back-up staff he had chosen.

Wilkinson, who took emergency charge of the England team for the 2-0 home friendly defeat by France in February 1999, is compiling a report on Euro 2000 which he will surely be encouraged to discuss with Keegan.

 Kevin Keegan's team may have retreated from the Low Countries but English football may still enjoy success in Rotterdam, venue for the Euro 2000 final. The national Pub Cup champions, the Earl Soham Victoria, will attempt this weekend to add the European Carlsberg Pub Cup by overcoming Swedish, Danish and Irish opponents. The final precedes Holland's quarter- final tomorrow.

"We are all 100% behind Kevin because he is the best person for the job. His ability, charisma and inspiration command the support of us all." "Reports of my increased involvement are totally alien to what was said and to what the real situation is," said Wilkinson. The national Pub Cup champions, the Earl Soham Victoria, will attempt this weekend to add the European Carlsberg Pub Cup by overcoming Swedish, Danish and Irish opponents. webTitle: The forgotten awards that can boost a grant

fields.headline: The forgotten awards that can boost a grant
fields.standfirst: Student scholarships and bursaries worth millions go begging every year for lack of takers. Jill Papworth tells you where to look
fields.trailText: Student scholarships and bursaries worth millions go begging every year for lack of takers. Jill Papworth tells you where to look.
fields.body:
Millions of pounds available through student scholarships and bursaries go unclaimed each year because of a lack of awareness of their existence and how to apply, according to a new internet-based service to help students find sources of funding.

"Greater awareness would go a long way to alleviate the growing concern over the funding of students at university," says Iain Aitken, managing director of freefund.com, who reckons there are more than 200,000 scholarships and bursaries available in the UK worth up to £150m a year.

Research from www.freefund.com, which so far has 20,000 funding sources worth around £16m on its database, reveals that only one in three students and 15% of their parents have considered applying for a scholarship or bursary. When asked for their reasons for not applying 23% of students said they didn't know how to and 14% said they were not aware of their existence, with similar reasons given by their parents.

Scholarships, usually awarded for excellence in an academic field, and bursaries, normally offered to students in financial difficulty, are on offer from academic institutions, commercial organisations and charitable trusts.

The traditional way to find out about those available is to trawl through hefty tomes in local reference libraries or careers advice offices. But the internet has opened up a valuable new search medium for identifying sources of funding.

Using web search engines to check out scholarships and awards available from individual academic institutions can be frustrating. It seems that very few universities have yet collated information on the awards available from their various departments into one document. Notable exceptions include the University of Newcastle upon Tyne (www.shadowdreams.co.uk), The University of York (www.york.ac.uk), and Loughborough University (www.lboro.ac.uk

York uses government funds to provide several bursaries worth a maximum of £2,000 per year, awarded on the basis of need, for mature full-time undergraduates over 25. Details and application forms are available from the undergraduate office.

It also has two Golf Bursaries, awarded annually by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, to the value of £1,250 to those who meet the university entry qualifications and have a handicap of 4 or better. Those interested are invited to contact the director of physical recreation at the university's Sports Centre.

Loughborough's website offers a handy summary chart of its available awards, each of which can be clicked on for further information. It includes two music scholarships of £500 awarded each year along with 150 music tuition bursaries worth £150 and some 70 sports scholarships with a cash value of £1,000, available to exceptional sports people in any sport studying any subject.

Scholarship Search UK (www.scholarship-search.org.uk) is a website that was set up in 1999 as a direct result of the withdrawal of the LEA maintenance award and the introduction of tuition fees. The site covers scholarships above the value of £100 a year and, though the database is not yet complete - you can't yet access the sections on commercial and government organisations or charitable trusts - it offers a useful free search facility of awards from academic institutions.

To conduct a search, you simply select the awarding institution (or "all"), and the subject area. You can also indicate your sex and place of residence if you wish to narrow things down. I found it worked best not to be too restrictive on the search parameters, so I only specified the subject area.

Entering "business", for example, threw up a selection of 12 awards including one-year mathematics and economics bursaries worth £1,000 each from the University of Hull awarded on the basis of performance at A level or equivalent. They can also be awarded for significant potential shown in references or at interview.

Two three-year general business or finance Lord Benson Awards, worth £2,000 per year, are available from the London School of Economics supported by Pricewaterhouse Coopers to assist undergraduates from central London boroughs who otherwise might be deterred by financial hardship.

Live links are provided to the home pages of institutions that come up on your search results so you can click for application details.

The new freefund.com site requires you to fill in a much more detailed personal profile, answering 50 or so questions on your subject area and lifestyle. "The idea is to avoid time wasting by matching up your profile with scholarships you could not only apply for but stand a good chance of getting," says Mr Aitken. Search results then explain the application process for each scholarship with relevant contact details.

Personal details which might seem irrelevant can prompt details of very specific awards you'd be unlikely to know of. Young vegetarians or vegans who are sick or in need, for example, would find themselves eligible for educational grants worth from £100 to £1,000 from the Vegetarian Society.

Where you live can also be important, as some universities and colleges offer scholarships to people who live in particular parts of the country. The University of Wales, for example, has awards for candidates who are natives of Wales and who have been educated at secondary schools there.

Anyone considering applying for a scholarship or bursary on being accepted for their course is advised to contact the faculty department at the university or college to find out what, if any, awards are on offer. For those particularly gifted at music or sport, at least 39 universities offer music related awards and some 21 make sports-related scholarships available.

Having an idea of the career you want to pursue after finishing your studies can also lead to funding, as many companies and organisations offer scholarships to students before they start higher education.

The army (www.army.mod.uk) offers cadetships to honours degree undergraduates. As a holder you are commissioned as an army officer on probation and paid a salary. In return you are committed to serve as a Regular Army officer for five years after completing Sandhurst. You must be over 17 and a half on 1 September in the year of application. Priority is given to those reading engineering and technology related degrees.

 Useful published directories include Guide to University Scholarships and Awards by Brian Heap, published by Trotman; The Grants Register, published by Macmillan; The Educational Grants Directory, published by the Directory of Social Change and The Directory of Grant-Making Trusts, published by the Charities Aid Foundation.

fields.headline: Can anyone stop France?
fields.standfirst: World champions strut their stuff as Euro 2000 enters the finishing straight
fields.trailText: Already the European Championship is looking like one of the better tournaments, even if the ticketing arrangements have been as reliable as the distribution of gas bills in the Ottoman empire. Footballwise there is a freshness and vigour about Euro 2000 appropriate to the game's first big occasion of the new century.
fields.body:
Already the European Championship is looking like one of the better tournaments, even if the ticketing arrangements have been as reliable as the distribution of gas bills in the Ottoman empire. Footballwise there is a freshness and vigour about Euro 2000 appropriate to the game's first big occasion of the new century.

The approach of most teams has been uninhibited and positive. From the moment Sweden and Belgium went for each other's jugular in the opening match it was clear that, if this was to be a cat-and-mouse tournament, it would be played in the spirit of Tom and Jerry. Sensible refereeing has helped, given the odd aberration with offsides and penalties. So far, from Pierluigi Collina downwards, yellow cards have been controlled and none of the few dismissals has warranted serious argument.

The prospects for the knockout stages, then, are encouraging. It is never wise to pronounce judgment until the quarter- finals have been completed, but unless this weekend's matches become crabbed with a caution which none of those taking part has yet shown, there should be an improvement on Euro 96, when two of the four ties went to penalties after goalless stalemates, both semi-finals were settled in like fashion and the final was won by Oliver Bierhoff's golden goal.

Such contrived conclusions can have a distorting effect on the plot, which would be a particular pity now since the intriguing set of group matches which have brought Turkey, Romania, Yugoslavia and Spain face to face with Portugal, Italy, Holland and France deserve a better outcome.

Quite clearly France are the team to stop. Ever since the World Cup holders strode past Denmark, Roger Lemerre's team have been in little doubt about their destiny. Even the French reserves, while losing 3-2 to Holland in Amsterdam on Wednesday, managed to leave the Dutch wondering how they were going to compete with such an awesome depth of Gallic strength.

Most of this weekend's quarter-finalists would find little difficulty in making a place for Johan Micoud in their midfields. Yet the 26-year-old from Bordeaux will only play a prominent part if Zinedine Zidane is injured or suspended.

Maybe France's route to the final lies in a peninsula campaign. Victory over Spain tomorrow could see them meeting Portugal in Brussels in Wednesday's semi-final. The omnipotent look worn by the French in this European Championship offers a sharp contrast to the more diffident, more defensive initial approach of Aimé Jacquet's side to the 1998 World Cup. Then, much the same set of players crouched behind sandbags looking to Laurent Blanc or Lilian Thuram to go on a recce when the coast was clear.

What a difference it makes, being on top of the world. No team on earth, not even Brazil, knows how to strut its funky stuff like the French. Two years ago, even as the centre of Paris was thronged with celebrating fans, the sports daily L'Equipe still wished that Jacquet had triumphed with a greater sense of style. It is a reservation unlikely to be repeated should France win their second European title.

All right, so Lemerre's team does not have a vein of gold at its heart to compare with the 1984 midfield of Platini-Tigana-Giresse. Yet to the foundations of 1998, built squarely on the goalkeeping of Fabien Barthez, the central defensive partnership of Blanc and Marcel Desailly, and the wit and skill of Zidane, has been added the attacking speed and scoring power of Thierry Henry.

Upset the odds

So can anyone upset the odds and send France packing? Holland would be the choice of most people but the Dutch and French cannot meet until the final, and in any case Frank Rijkaard's co-hosts first have to see off Yugoslavia in Rotterdam tomorrow and Italy or Romania in Amsterdam on Thursday.

Clearly, now is the time for Holland to shake off the fits of torpor which have been known to overtake them for odd periods. Certainly Yugoslavia, an ageing team maybe but worldly wise and ever alert to any opportunity, would look to punish any Dutch lapses of concentration.

Savo Milosevic, the ambling Serb whom Aston Villa never really made out, is the leading striker of Euro 2000 with four goals. In his present form he is well capable of embarrassing Sander Westerveld, should Edwin van der Sar be unfit and should Liverpool's Dutch goalkeeper repeat Wednesday's error which gave France their opening goal.

France would appear to have the easier route to the final. Spain's chances of stopping them in the quarter-finals will depend to some extent on how much beating Yugoslavia 4-3 in Wednesday's thrilling conclusion to Group C, while the French regulars were resting up, has taken out of Jose Camacho's players. Otherwise Gaizka Mendieta, the hub of their midfield, represents Spain's best chance of disturbing the realm of Zidane.

The quarter-finals of this European Championship have a dangerously predictable look about them. A shock is overdue and it may yet be achieved by Turkey, who have already raised an eyebrow or two by knocking out Belgium, though the weaker of the co-hosts.

While it is hard to believe that the combinations of Portuguese movement which tore England apart in Eindhoven will not find ways through Mustafa Denizli's defence today, there will surely be space for the Turks to exploit on the counterattack, and this is where Hakan Sukur, with his speed and power, can be most dangerous.

Italy against Romania this evening is not easy to call either, and would appear to be the quarter-final most likely to go to penalties. If Demetrio Albertini and Antonio Conte can be got at in Italy's midfield then Dorinel Munteanu is surely the player to do it. Alternatively it may be a case of which defence cracks first, if any.

A forecast for the semi-finals? Portugal against France and - sorry, Italy - Romania against Holland.

fields.headline: Firth goes forth
fields.standfirst: With a non-romantic role in Noel Coward's Relative Values, followed by Bridget Jones' Diary, Colin Firth is playing against his "dashing" screen persona
fields.trailText: With a non-romantic role in Noel Coward's Relative Values, followed by Bridget Jones' Diary, Colin Firth is playing against his "dashing" screen persona
fields.body:
He's still best known as TV heart-throb Mr Darcy in the BBC's 1995 dramatisation of Pride And Prejudice, but Colin Firth's cinema work has been equally impressive. From his debut with Rupert Everett in Another Country, he's developed into a reliable character actor in features such as The English Patient and Shakespeare In Love (he also plays Shakespeare himself in the Millennium Dome's Blackadder film), mixing in more contemporary films such as Nick Hornby's Fever Pitch. In the current Noel Coward adaptation, Relative Values, he plays the foppish cousin of lady of the manor Julie Andrews.

Was the prospect of working with Julie Andrews daunting?

There's no question she has legendary status. But she was a wonderful team leader in an old-fashioned sort of way. You know, rallying the troops and keeping spirits high, reminding us to keep our backs straight.

The film addresses Anglo-American tensions and differences. Were there any on set?

It's funny, I do find that American actors tend to be irrationally in awe of English actors and the whole English tradition. And we envy American actors for their ease in front of the camera. I think, certainly in the press, there's a sort of self-loathing for our own cinema at the moment, but that's not how it's perceived abroad. The Americans all perceive us to be highly trained and to have this theatrical discipline, some sort of substance which they lack, which I don't think is really true to be honest. So generally there's no tension. If anything, there's a tremendous mutual respect, probably slightly baseless.

You're in the middle of Bridget Jones' Diary. Is it refreshing not to be doing a costume drama?

Everything's a costume drama really. It's all an artificial world you're creating, and in some ways it feels far more artificial trying to re-create the present day. It's very odd, you get bogged down in far more difficult detail when you do modern stuff than when you're doing period. If you're playing Mr Darcy [in Pride And Prejudice] you just say he'd wear one of those sorts of frocks and it would probably be blue, whereas with the modern stuff you really get caught up in some tricky decisions - what kind of trainers would he wear, etc. The audience knows what the reference points are.

You, Colin Firth, actually feature as Bridget Jones' fantasy in the book. Does that make things complicated?

No, thankfully they've dispensed with all references to me in the film.

You did actually meet Helen Fielding, though, didn't you?

Yes, the interview she does in the second book, I was part of the contrivance. It was a sort of performed conversation we had, which was very funny. I don't know how conscious she was, but she sort of went into "Bridget" mode, which was rather different from her.

Does that mean you had to go into Colin mode?

Well I did a bit. I tried to be a bit more serious, and less patient.

There are also rumours that you're going to play Tony Blair.

This often happens: I read what I'm going to do in the papers, but no one's told me about it.

Did you entertain the prospect for a while?

Well, it depends, it's very hard for those things to work when they are so contemporary. It's better to wait 10 years or so to get a perspective on it, but by that time I'll be old enough to do the Enoch Powell story or something.

webTitle: Microsoft in TV talks with Murdoch

fields.headline: Microsoft in TV talks with Murdoch
fields.standfirst:
Ballmer ignores legal battle to seek News Corp deal for global interactive service

E-finance: special report
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft said yesterday that it was talking with News Corporation, the media group controlled by Rupert Murdoch, about a possible partnership offering interactive television services in the UK and around the world.
fields.body:
Microsoft said yesterday that it was talking with News Corporation, the media group controlled by Rupert Murdoch, about a possible partnership offering interactive television services in the UK and around the world.

Speaking after the launch of Microsoft's new web-based software Steve Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, said: "We would love to have News as a partner for .net TV."

News Corp, which owns 40% of BSkyB as well as the Times and the Sun newspapers in the UK, competes against the cable TV companies such as NTL in the UK which are partly owned by Microsoft.

Mr Ballmer's comments come as News Corp is planning to spin off its satellite TV assets into a separate company. Microsoft is one of a handful of companies understood to have approached the media group about a possible stake in the new company.

Mr Ballmer said there was "nothing in the offing" regarding an alliance but added that he had talked with Peter Chernin, the News Corp president, "a number of times recently, and we will continue to have good discussions".

Analysts believe that News Corp may be less keen on Microsoft as a partner because of its rivalry in the TV market.

In an interview with the Guardian yesterday Mr Ballmer spelled out the Seattle-based group's vision for the new platform, which was launched on Thursday.

He vigorously defended the company's decision to press ahead with "dot net" in spite of the fact that it appears to fly in the face of a legal ruling which accused the company of abusing its monopoly to dominate the world's computers.

"I am not going to say that we are going to restrict ourselves in trying very hard to build a platform for everybody," he said yesterday. fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: Lake District | South Africa | Grenada
fields.body:
Europe

Lake District
Luxury in the Lakes guided cycling weekend based at the Lindeth Howe hotel, near Bowness-on- Windermere for two nights for weekend of June 30. Cost is £195pp. Country Lanes (01425 655022).

Rome
Midweek break staying at the four-star Hotel Genova costs £391pp. Price includes bed and breakfast and return flights from London Heathrow and transfers. Travelscene (0870 7774445).

Sweden
White-water rafting under the midnight sun in Jukkasjärvi until July 14. It costs approximately £70pp (half price for children under 16). Accommodation in two-bedroom cabins in Jukkasjärvi is available for around £52 per cabin per night. Fly to Kiruna with SAS from £271pp (call 0845 60727727). Swedish Travel & Tourism Council (0207-870 5600).

The Alps
Fifteen-day Alpine Trails trip includes seven days of trekking in the High Alps of France, Italy and Switzerland. Your luggage is transported between campsites, leaving you free to concentrate on the scenic beauty to be found on the Mont Blanc circuit, the Matterhorn and the Bernese Oberland. You will travel between these three sections by local transport: cable cars, mountain trains and buses. The trip costs £688pp through July and August. Explore Worldwide (01252 760100).

Africa

South Africa
From now until August 31, African Odyssey is offering a special summer safari package, including a complimentary game drive. Cost is £995pp (based on two sharing) and includes flights, three nights' B&B hotel on Cape Town's waterfront, transfers to the Pilanesberg National Park, three nights' half-board in one of two luxury lodges. African Odyssey (01242 224482).

North America

San Francisco
Short break July 5-19 staying three nights at the Handlery Union Square hotel for £589pp with two sharing. Flights from Gatwick. Bon Voyage (0800 9807090).

Caribbean

Grenada
Seven nights at the Calabash Hotel at Prickley Bay. Price, before July 12, departing Gatwick either Wednesday or Friday, is £799pp. Free sports include windsurfing, kayaking, snorkelling, tennis and golf. Tropical Places (0800 0185256)

Asia

China
Seven nights' twin accommodation at the Grandview Garden hotel in Peking for £499pp, with two sharing. The package is available from July, departing on Tuesdays and Thursdays until end of August. For more details, contact China Holidays (020-7287 6727)

webTitle: Should entry grades for university be lowered for less privileged students?

fields.headline: Should entry grades for university be lowered for less privileged students?
fields.standfirst: For many years it seems not many university students have come from lower socio-economic groups. Should schools and government ensure that more people from disadvantaged backgrounds gain the qualifications necessary for entry, or does higher education work better because it builds on what has been achieved and doesn't rely on arbitrary adjustments? Have your say here
fields.trailText: For many years it seems not many university students have come from                           lower socio-economic groups. Should schools and government ensure                           that more people from disadvantaged backgrounds gain the                           qualifications necessary for entry, or does higher education work better                           because it builds on what has been achieved and doesn't rely on                           arbitrary adjustments?
fields.body:
Dear Alan,
For many years, far too few university students have come from lower socio-economic groups. In the longer term, it is the task of schools and government to ensure that more people from disadvantaged backgrounds gain the qualifications necessary for entry. Furthermore, the debts accumulated by university students under existing arrangements undoubtedly introduce a disincentive to people from poorer families.

But in the shorter term, the task must fall to the universities themselves. Many have done this for years informally; Clare College, Cambridge, has adopted a formal system to take account of the applicant's school and its experience of the admissions process.

The Newcastle University scheme reported this week, which uses postcodes to identify less privileged students, takes this a stage further. The scheme is by no means perfect, but its attempt to level the playing field is to be applauded.

Increasingly, universities rely on A-level grades as indicators of potential. Yet there is a poor correlation between grades and success at universities. This increases the need for other criteria, such as the Scholastic Aptitude Test widely used in the US. The admissions process needs a thorough overhaul. Finding the best way of properly representing applicants from less privileged backgrounds should be an important part of such a review.

All good wishes,
John Dunford
General Secretary,
Secondary Heads Association

Dear John,
As the son of a Billingsgate fish porter, I care passionately about equality of opportunity. But I do not believe that lowering entry grades for particular social groups "levels the playing field".

Higher education is higher because it builds on what has been achieved. Students must have the capacity to benefit. A levels are an independent national assessment of ability; it is not fair to make arbitrary adjustments. The most appropriate place to intervene is in early education, which currently exaggerates the circumstances of birth.

Pressuring universities to fill social quotas is wrong. Some students are patronised, others done out of their rightful places, and universities are deflected from seeking out excellence. Everyone loses.

I admired what you achieved as a head teacher. I cannot believe you would want to tell pupils who had done well that their places were going to those who had done less well, because of where they lived.

With best wishes,
Alan Smithers
Professor of Education,
Liverpool University

Dear Alan,
I agree that universities should not lower entry grades for existing places. The time to introduce a scheme to encourage lower social groups is when the size of the university population is expanding.

Universities must not lose the opportunity granted by the current expansion to broaden the range of their intake. Newcastle University has created an extra 70 places for students under its programme with local schools. Although you are against the Newcastle scheme, you do not appear to oppose its aim. Perhaps the more difficult question is how, rather than whether, the playing field should be levelled.

For some courses, lowering the grades for certain groups may be appropriate. For most, it would be better to supplement the grades required with criteria that are better determinants of potential.

The government should encourage universities, if necessary using financial levers, to improve their social mix. I agree that early education is a high priority, but children already in the system cannot wait for an improvement there.

All good wishes,
John

Dear John,
Your distinction between existing and new places bothers me. If Newcastle is able to expand, it should do so on merit. Otherwise, it will create a two-tier system.

I am all for a fair admissions system. In that respect A levels, even now, are as good as it gets. Trials of a US-style aptitude test in the late 60s found it was less informative than A levels, and it was dropped.

The present system is not perfect. It would be better if it operated on actual rather than predicted grades. There also needs to be some flexibility. In a study of mature students at Manchester University admitted through an access scheme, we found that they did at least as well as the A-level entrants, but that was a reflection of the rigour of the entry exam and selection process.

When you look at the figures in detail there is no gross underrepresentation of social groups in higher education in relation to their applications and performance. In a recent study we found that 10% of applicants from social classes 4 and 5 were admitted, even though they constituted only 8% of applicants and their A-level scores were lower.

It is good that universities are encouraging more applications through summer schools, and that schools are raising the achievements and aspirations of their pupils. I agree we should keep the admissions process under review. But we should not let the wider access issue run away with us.

With best wishes,
Alan

Dear Alan,
I agree that universities should admit students on the basis of grades achieved rather than grades predicted. More open admissions criteria would be helpful, too.

I was interested to hear about the success of the mature students at Manchester. I am certain they did not form a separate group of students, and I do not believe the Newcastle scheme will create a two-tier system there, either.

Universities which admit a low proportion of state pupils must examine their procedures. Summer schools will help, but admissions tutors need more training if the situation is to be improved. Closer links between universities and local schools will increase the proportion of applicants from the state sector and from social classes 4 and 5. Let's work for a brighter future in both our sectors.

All good wishes,
John

Dear John,
My point about the mature students was that they did well because they were admitted on tough academic criteria. If widening access means identifying more of the more talented this way, then I am a fan.

But you seem to want to take into account the social mix. We no longer hear about the gender gap in higher education because women have become the majority on the basis of superior school performance. The spotlight is now on sociological factors, but did you know there are discrepancies by month of birth? How long before admissions tutors are asked to take astrological deficits into account?

Data compiled by the Sutton Trust show that the higher the admissions requirements, the more likely entrants are to come from independent schools and higher socio-economic groups. Since the trust rules out bias on the part of the universities, this means that those students are more often putting themselves forward and meeting the required standards.

One of the messages I take from this is that independent schools achieve more because of the extra money they receive. Whatever our differences, more money for state schools is, I think, something on which we can agree.

With best wishes,
Alan

Useful links

Education Unlimited's higher education section
Liverpool University's department of education
Secondary Heads Association

webTitle: Endowment life raft may not stay afloat

fields.headline: Endowment life raft may not stay afloat
fields.standfirst:
Investment watchdogs are looking at a scheme which purports to make up mortgage shortfalls cheaply. Rupert Jones reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Investment watchdogs are looking at a scheme which purports to make up mortgage shortfalls cheaply. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
A new scheme which claims to offer a lifeline to people worried about endowment mortgage shortfalls was this week being probed by investment watchdogs.

Midlands-based company Mortgage Paid For Sure (MPFS plc) hired a London hotel on Monday to unveil its "pioneering and unique" solution to the endowment crisis. It offers homeowners worried their policy may not be on track to pay off the mortgage a guarantee that it will make up any shortfall in return for a fee of £175.

But the scheme has prompted concern at the Financial Services Authority, the main City watchdog, which believes that in its present form it may breach the rules covering insurance business. As a result, the company has suspended its activities while an investigation is carried out.

The MPFS scheme would, for a one-off flat fee of £175 irrespective of the size of the policy or how long it had to run, guarantee to make up any shortfall. But if there was a surplus when the policy matures, the firm would take 25% of this. And if the policy is surrendered before maturity, MPFS would take 10% of the surrender value.

However, it is understood the Financial Services Authority believes the firm may not have the necessary backing from an authorised insurance company as required under the Insurance Companies Act. If a firm carries out this sort of business without authorisation it risks committing a criminal offence and any contracts it issued would be invalid.

MPFS managing director John Webb says he was unable to find a Lloyd's syndicate or insurance company to underwrite the deal. Instead, he says, the plan was it would operate its own "reserve fund" from which any payouts would be made.

He also disclosed that the Staffordshire-based company is not regulated by a watchdog such as the Financial Services Authority. Mr Webb said it did not need to be regulated because it is not giving financial advice.

So one obvious question was: what happens if the firm goes bust in a few years' time, before my policy has matured - do I lose my money? Mr Webb's reply was that if it was to shut down, "the worst case scenario is that the most anyone could lose would be that [£175] fee".

In other words, the answer to the question was quite possibly yes. On Wednesday night, Mr Webb said he had suspended the company's activities while the Financial Services Authority looks into the matter.

The controversy comes as letters from insurance companies have been going out to millions of people, many of whom are being told their policies may not be on target to repay the mortgage. The Financial Services Authority has estimated that as many as 3m of the 10m policies may be in shortfall.

What now look like over-optimistic assumptions about investment growth are at the heart of the problem. During the late 80s and early 90s, some insurers sold the policies using projections of future growth of up to 12% a year.

But industry watchdogs now say these projections were too high. Last year investment watchdog the Personal Investment Authority set a new projection rate of 6% future growth per year.

Many people are being told that their policies are probably on target if the old projection rate is used, but may fall short if the 6% growth figure is used.

However, some commentators - particularly independent financial advisers - insist that a projection rate of 6% future growth per year is way too low.

They point to a survey in Money Management magazine in April which revealed that for 25-year endowment policies maturing in February this year, the average gross annual yield was 13.1%. The magazine studied 34 different companies and found that even the worst performer in terms of yield, Equitable Life, achieved 11.9%.

Some independent financial advisers say this shows that the 6% figure is very conservative indeed. But other experts argue that good performance in the past does not mean good performance in the future.

People concerned that they may have been given poor advice regarding an endowment will be watching closely the case of a couple from London, who may be set to receive a payout from insurer Legal & General on the grounds that they were wrongly sold an endowment.

The case is currently with the Personal Investment Authority ombudsman, who has just issued a preliminary decision on the dispute in the couple's favour, and is understood to call on Legal & General to repay all their endowment payments plus interest on the grounds that the salesperson did not properly explain the risks involved with investing in a stock market-linked product.

Legal & General can now either agree to pay up or can reject the decision - if it takes the latter route, the case will go to the ombudsman for a final decision. A Legal & General spokesman says that as the matter has not yet been resolved, it does not wish to comment.

If the couple win the case, it could open the floodgates to a spate of similar claims from people who say they were victims of mis-selling.

What you can do

If you are worried that your endowment policy may not pay off the mortgage, there are a number of things you can do.

The number one piece of advice from the Financial Services Authority, the chief investment watchdog, is: "Don't make any hasty decisions." It says you should never cash in your policy, or stop making payments, without taking advice. This is because endowments often involve high charges in the early years, and if the policy is only a few years old you will probably end up getting back less than you've spent.

After taking advice, you may consider one or more of the following options:

 Do nothing. While the predictions are for lower investment returns in the future, nobody can really be sure what will happen. You may be happy to cross your fingers in the hope that the policy makes the grade, particularly if your policy only just fails to hit the target using a projection rate of 6%, or if the potential shortfall is fairly small.

 Increase your monthly payments into the policy. While this will probably delight your insurer, you may feel this amounts to throwing good money after bad. Also, with some companies it may involve you having to pay extra charges.

 Contact your lender and arrange to change part of your mortgage to a repayment loan. This could be a much better option. For example, if your mortgage is £60,000 and the potential endowment shortfall is £10,000, you could rejig the mortgage so that £50,000 continues on an interest-only basis and £10,000 is converted to a repayment loan.

 Set up a separate investment that can be used if necessary to meet a shortfall. One good way of building up a lump sum might be to go for an individual savings account. However, check carefully to see what the charges are. With many stocks and shares Isa providers, the minimum monthly investment is £50 but in a few cases is as low as £25.

 If you have a spare lump sum, and your lender allows it, you could make extra capital repayments to your lender to reduce the amount you owe on the mortgage loan. Check for early redemption penalties.

 Arrange for the policy term to be extended. "This is not likely to be a good idea if the policy will continue after you have retired, unless you are sure you will still be able to afford the payments," says the FSA (www.fsa.gov.uk).

People concerned that they may have been given poor advice regarding an endowment will be watching closely the case of a couple from London, who may be set to receive a payout from insurer Legal & General on the grounds that they were wrongly sold an endowment. The case is currently with the Personal Investment Authority ombudsman, who has just issued a preliminary decision on the dispute in the couple's favour, and is understood to call on Legal & General to repay all their endowment payments plus interest on the grounds that the salesperson did not properly explain the risks involved with investing in a stock market-linked product. Legal & General can now either agree to pay up or can reject the decision - if it takes the latter route, the case will go to the ombudsman for a final decision. A Legal & General spokesman says that as the matter has not yet been resolved, it does not wish to comment. If the couple win the case, it could open the floodgates to a spate of similar claims from people who say they were victims of mis-selling. What you can do If you are worried that your endowment policy may not pay off the mortgage, there are a number of things you can do. The number one piece of advice from the Financial Services Authority, the chief investment watchdog, is: "Don't make any hasty decisions." It says you should never cash in your policy, or stop making payments, without taking advice. This is because endowments often involve high charges in the early years, and if the policy is only a few years old you will probably end up getting back less than you've spent. After taking advice, you may consider one or more of the following options:  Do nothing. While the predictions are for lower investment returns in the future, nobody can really be sure what will happen. You may be happy to cross your fingers in the hope that the policy makes the grade, particularly if your policy only just fails to hit the target using a projection rate of 6%, or if the potential shortfall is fairly small.  Increase your monthly payments into the policy. While this will probably delight your insurer, you may feel this amounts to throwing good money after bad. Also, with some companies it may involve you having to pay extra charges.  Contact your lender and arrange to change part of your mortgage to a repayment loan. This could be a much better option. For example, if your mortgage is £60,000 and the potential endowment shortfall is £10,000, you could rejig the mortgage so that £50,000 continues on an interest-only basis and £10,000 is converted to a repayment loan.  Set up a separate investment that can be used if necessary to meet a shortfall. One good way of building up a lump sum might be to go for an individual savings account. However, check carefully to see what the charges are. With many stocks and shares Isa providers, the minimum monthly investment is £50 but in a few cases is as low as £25.  If you have a spare lump sum, and your lender allows it, you could make extra capital repayments to your lender to reduce the amount you owe on the mortgage loan. Check for early redemption penalties.  Arrange for the policy term to be extended. "This is not likely to be a good idea if the policy will continue after you have retired, unless you are sure you will still be able to afford the payments," says the FSA (www.fsa.gov.uk).

webTitle: Double standards in the Cronje affair

fields.headline: Double standards in the Cronje affair
fields.trailText: One fact comes across clearly in the media coverage (your own site included) of the Cronje affair in this country. The relevant cricket boards are intent on tainting foreign players, in retaliation for the allegations pressed upon their own apparently respectable teams.
fields.body:
One fact comes across clearly in the media coverage (your own site included) of the Cronje affair in this country. The relevant cricket boards are intent on tainting foreign players, in retaliation for the allegations pressed upon their own apparently respectable teams.

With the start of the King Inquiry in Cape Town, the media began to make comments based on the expectation that the betting scandal would be cleared sooner rather than later. But Ali Bacher's accusations have only brought forth counter-accusations from the umpire in question, Javed Akhtar. It seems that some of those involved have been unable to lie effectively. Even when big names have actively denied any involvement, their refutals have come across as shallow and self-promoting. When the public has been able to see through the facade, why is ICC giving the false image of having been in the dark?

Being based in England, one gets the impression - rightly or wrongly - that ICC is keen to convey the message that, whatever happens, the English team has never been involved in match-fixing. The Chris Lewis inquiry has been swept under the carpet, and ICC has not pressurised the ECB to investigate further. Ditto with the Australian inquiry. Why then have the PCB and the UCBSA been forced to make public their investigations? While I agree that for cricket to come clean, a lot of light needs to be shed on this matter, the rule must be applied to everyone.

Even the British media is quick to point out the failures of foreign players, and as past evidence is quick to prove, these accusations are always hurled at those players who are deemed most dangerous. I give but two examples. When the whispers about Cronje first appeared in the international press, some sections of the media immediately latched onto the fact that Lance Klusener was involved somehow. The same was done more recently to Shoaib Akhtar. Those players who are not easily defeated on the field seem to receive the most flak.

The entire affair has become something of a joke. Cricket fans all over the world sometimes get up at odd hours due to the different time zones involved. Little did they realise that the outcome of the matches had already been decided. ICC itself keeps reacting with caution every time another match is revealed to have been fixed. The top organisers are trying to keep a lid on things, while other events are unravelling by themselves. No wonder then that the players were so unafraid of completing the deals in the first place. Even with bank accounts being checked, I sincerely doubt that all will be found out.

All I can add is that cricket should no longer be regarded as a gentleman's game. That outdated notion must be thrown out along with the idea that everyone but the players are as clean as they claim to be.

Ms Razia Malik lives in Botswana. To read the previous Punter's Point, on the trials of being a cricket-lover in a student flat, click here
