fields.headline: Guilt-free safaris
fields.standfirst: Sue Wheat  chooses five holidays where your enjoyment won't compromise the wildlife, environment or the local community
fields.trailText: Sue Wheat chooses five holidays where your enjoyment won't compromise the wildlife, environment or the local community.
fields.body:
Getting close to wildlife is such a spectacular experience, it's not surprising that safaris, wildlife and nature holidays are so popular. But in many tourist destinations, the delicate ecosystems have been trampled under foot. And throughout Africa, Asia and South America, local people have become resentful because the land they once had free access to has been "protected".

The earth has lost 30% of its natural habitat in the past 30 years. Tourism often makes life worse for wildlife and natural landscapes, but some tour operators are finding an eco-friendly alternative. Here are five wildlife holidays that fit the bill.

Kenya
Eselenkei

The Eselenkei Conservation Area is on Maasai tribal land in the shadow of snow-topped Kilimanjaro, a few miles north of Amboseli National Park. Unlike many safari areas in Kenya, the animals here are still very wild as the area is relatively unvisited. Tourist numbers are limited to eight a day to minimise the impact on the environment.

Animals sighted within the Conservation Area include elephant, lion, leopard, cheetah and other cats, Thomson's and Grant's gazelles, gerenuk, impala, oryx, lesser kudu, zebra, wildebeest, giraffe, striped hyena, bat-eared fox, and ostrich. Birds of prey are also prolific.

The range of animals is all the more amazing considering that the Maasai and wildlife have been at loggerheads in recent years. In 1984, the Maasai were evicted from their traditional lands in Amboseli to make way for conservation and safari tourism. The Maasai began killing animals thinking that it would stop the tourists coming and they would get their land back.

A Kenyan organisation, Porini Ecotourism (in association with British tour operator Tropical Places), started working with the Maasai to find a solution. The Maasai tribal lands have been set aside as a private reserve for wildlife and the Maasai are now receiving a rent for the lease of the land from the tour operator plus an entry fee for each tourist visitor. They also benefit from employment as game scouts, road builders and workers at the luxury safari lodges. Profits are used for maintenance of boreholes, animal husbandry and education for the Maasai. Tourism is starting to work for, not against, them.

• Tropical Places (0800 0185256) and www.porini.com. Three nights, £299 plus flights. The Eselenkei Safari can also be combined with a stay at a Mombasa beach hotel.

Galapagos
Backstage wildlife cruise

Discovery Initiatives has a new approach to nature travel. Every trip is arranged by liaising closely with a conservation group, research station or community project, which they pay to organise a specialist wildlife visit instead of using a local travel agent or ground handler. The visitor gets an "backstage" insight into the local wildlife and environment, and the environmental agency or community gets the money to further their conservation efforts or to invest in community welfare projects.

In the Galapagos, you travel for 10 days on one of a variety of small, luxury yachts around the islands away from the ordinary tourist route. There's plenty of opportunity to see Darwin's finches, blue-footed boobies, the flightless cormorant, some of the 11 species of giant tortoise that can live to more than 200 years old, plus fur seals and migratory whales.

By teaming up with the Galapagos Conservation Trust and the Charles Darwin Research Centre, you get an insight into the islands' environmental legacy - and each cruise of 10 people raises US$5,000 for the organisations. For half a day, you are hosted by the Charles Darwin Research Centre where the giant-tortoise breeding programme takes place, and you get to meet the researchers in one of the world's greatest areas of natural importance.

• Discovery Initiatives (01285 810621, email: enquiry@discoveryinitiatives.com). Price: £2,975, departures Sept 23-Oct 6 and March, July 2001.

Offshore
Out of the blue

Whale and dolphin-watching has become big business in recent years, but, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, some tour operators are doing more harm than good, continually chasing after the whales and dolphins and disturbing their feeding patterns and social interaction.

As a result, the WDCS has launched its own travel wing, Out of the Blue. Groups are kept small (eight-12) and each is accompanied by a WDCS expert who has a good working knowledge of the area and of the cetaceans being studied.

The areas visited include the Peninsula Valdes in Argentina - a calving and mating ground for the endangered southern right whale - and the Johnstone Strait off Vancouver Island in Canada, which is probably the best place in the world to watch orcas (killer whales), with a 300-strong resident population in summer.

Each trip includes whale and dolphin-watching from motor launch, yacht or raft, talks by local naturalists and WDCS researchers, and a visit to a WDCS field station to learn about conservation work. You can relax and watch the experts at work or get involved yourself - on the Azores trip, those who want to dive can help collect naturally-shed skin samples from the sea for DNA analysis.

• WDCS (01225 334511, email: info@wdcs.org) and Bluetravel. Forthcoming trips include Scotland (Aug 19-26, for £500 and Sept 1-4, £260); the Azores (Aug 26-Sept 5, £1,150), Argentina (Nov 18-Dec 1, £1,320), and Canada (July 21- Aug 4 2001, £1,434). Prices do not include flights or travel.

UK
Lundy Island

Lundy Island stands 10 miles off the coast of north Devon, where the Atlantic meets the Bristol Channel. Only half a mile wide and three and a half miles long, it is an island that understands the need for good management. Visitors come here particularly for birdwatching and diving.

The puffin inspired the island's name ( Lundey is norse for Puffin island) and puffins can still be seen, although now in small numbers. In the summer, the island is famous for auks (razorbills and guillemots), which breed on the cliffs. The eerie call of the manx shearwater can be heard late in the day, and sightings of rare migrant birds are common in spring and autumn.

Lundy is also famous for Sika deer, Soay sheep (the UK's original wild sheep), Lundy ponies (now a recognised breed), grey seals, basking sharks and dolphins. Lundy was the first designated underwater marine reserve in the UK and, as the water here is very clear, diving is excellent, although the temperature is only for the sturdy. All dive groups must get permission from the warden, and warden- led snorkelling sessions can be arranged.

Owned by the National Trust, but managed by the charity Landmark Trust, its properties have been preserved and renovated and are now let out to tourists. These self-catering properties accommodate 102 people and there is also camping space for 40. Day trippers can also access the island on its supply ship, MS Olenburg, which runs from Bideford or Ilfracombe most days, weather permitting, but as it takes a maximum of 260, the island is never overcrowded.

• Accommodation in various properties, ranging from Castle Cottage (two people), £195-£487 a week depending on season; Old Light Trinity (four people), £288-£728 a week; Government House (five people), £344-£935 a week. Last-minute short breaks and B&B sometimes possible to the end of July. Details on 01237 470422 (www.lundyisland.co.uk or email: bookings@landmarktrust.co.uk).

South-east Asia
Symbiosis

Symbiosis Expeditions arranges tailor-made trips in south-east Asia. Its wildlife specialist, Mike Ball, organises wildlife tours for all types of clients - from those with a basic interest in nature to specialists in their field.

"If someone wanted an add-on to a holiday in Thailand, for instance, I might send them to Khao Yai National Park about 100 miles from Bangkok, which has elephant, gibbons, tigers and impressive birdlife," he says. "But if people have particular areas of interest, we will check out exactly where is best for them and who to link them up with. For instance, last year we arranged a trip to Borneo for an entomologist who wanted to find a tarantula that hadn't been seen since the 1920s. We set up his trip with a specialist wildlife ground-handler in Malaysia and the entomologist found the spider in two weeks."

Symbiosis is particularly focused on organising wildlife holidays with close community involvement and using local wildlife specialists. Tiger tracking in a national park in Sumatra is possible, for instance, with a "Parang Hariman" or tiger caller on a two-to- three-day forest hike. Symbiosis also has close links with research projects and local conservation organisations. For example, the Crater Mountain Project, a research station in the highlands of Papua New Guinea, monitors rainforest flora, fauna and birdlife, including the New Guinea harpy eagle. One of the rarest eagles in the world, it lives in the rainforest canopy, feeds on large forest animals, and is currently endangered because of habitat loss.

• Symbiosis Expeditions. (020-7924 5906, email: wildlife@symbiosis-travel.co.uk). Price of tours vary depending on trip and destination, but work out at roughly £100 a day including flight.

fields.headline: Eastern promise for Rangers
fields.trailText: Rangers face an early trip to eastern Europe in their campaign to qualify for the Champions League. Yesterday's draw for the second qualifying round paired them with either Zalgiris Kaunas of Lithuania or Brotnjo of Bosnia. Rangers will be at home in the first leg on July 26, with the return on August 2.
fields.body:
Rangers face an early trip to eastern Europe in their campaign to qualify for the Champions League. Yesterday's draw for the second qualifying round paired them with either Zalgiris Kaunas of Lithuania or Brotnjo of Bosnia. Rangers will be at home in the first leg on July 26, with the return on August 2.

Scottish sides will be quietly pleased with the draw for the qualifying round of the Uefa Cup. Celtic and Hearts are both away in the first leg on August 10, against Luxembourg's Jeunesse Esch and Iceland's Vestmannaeyjar respectively. Aberdeen will play the Irish side Bohemian, with the first leg at home. The returns are two weeks later.

Ipswich Town have completed the signing of Martijn Reuser from Vitesse Arnhem. The 25-year-old former Dutch international, who was on loan to them for the final three months of last season, has agreed a three-year contract. He will cost an initial £1m and £250,000 more if they avoid relegation next season.

The Manchester City striker Shaun Goater has been given the freedom of his home town of Hamilton, Bermuda. Five thousand Bermudans lined the streets this week as he was honoured, and henceforth June 21 will be "Leonardo Shaun Goater Day".

Liverpool's right-back Vegard Heggem is unlikely to play again this year after injuring his hamstring in Norway's Euro 2000 match against Yugoslavia. Liverpool have two other right-backs, the German international Markus Babbel, recently signed from Bayern Munich, and Rigobert Song, the captain of Cameroon.

Shakthar Donetsk (Ukr) v TNS Llansantffraid

Rangers v Zalgiris Kaunas or Brotnjo

Jeunesse Esch (Lux) v Celtic

Aberdeen v Bohemian

webTitle: Future of German Green party threatened by nuclear fall-out

fields.headline: Future of German Green party threatened by nuclear fall-out
fields.trailText: Joschka Fischer, Germany's foreign minister and the Greens' best-known figure, warned his party colleagues yesterday that the government's deal to scrap nuclear energy would leave them facing an identity crisis.
fields.body:
Joschka Fischer, Germany's foreign minister and the Greens' best-known figure, warned his party colleagues yesterday that the government's deal to scrap nuclear energy would leave them facing an identity crisis.

Delegates to the Greens' party conference are expected to approve the deal to close down all Germany's nuclear reactors by around 2020. Though widely seen as an outstanding victory for Green politics, the agreement will take away a large part of the movement's rationale. The Greens were founded in the late 1970s specifically to halt nuclear power.

The environment minister Jürgen Trittin, himself a member of the Greens, said the timetable for closure was the best the government could get. But it is much longer than the Greens had demanded, and their joint leader, Antje Radcke, rejected the pact as an unacceptable compromise.

She and other hardliners were trying at the conference yesterday to rally support for a grass roots revolt. But only about 100 of the 750 delegates put their signatures to a motion rejecting the agreement.

Last week's agreement between the electricity industry and Gerhard Schröder's "Red-Green" coalition was the result of 18 months of tense negotiations. It commits the power companies to shut down reactors after an averaging running time of 32 years. Germany currently depends on atomic power for almost a third of its electricity.

In an interview with the mass circulation Bild Zeitung yesterday, Mr Fischer, who backs the agreement, accepted none the less that its endorse ment would put the movement in a quandary.

"The Greens must not only find themselves, but also renew themselves by finding new issues," he said. "On this process depends the future of the party."

The need for new causes had already been underlined by Mr Radcke's fellow party leader, Günda Röstel. "What we need now is the one big peg," she said in an interview this week. "We are on the hunt for specifically Green themes."

She suggested opposition to genetically modified foods as a possible solution.

Because of the idiosyncratic way in which the Greens are organised, holders of public office, like Mr Fischer, cannot simultaneously hold leadership posts in the party structure. But the foreign minister has for some time been manoeuvring to strengthen his position.

He is to take the process a step further today by standing for a new 16-member council to coordinate strategy. The vote will test his popularity among rank-and-file Greens, many of whom regard him as someone who has "sold out" on core Green values, especially pacifism.

The conference is also due to elect a new duo to the leadership and one of the expected victors, Fritz Kuhn, is a known ally of Mr Fischer. It is hoped that he and the other likely winner, Renate Künast, can inject greater professionalism into the organisation of a party which has been losing support at the polls since entering government two years ago.

But Mr Fischer remains optimistic: "The Greens won't die. If the party congress comes to sensible decisions - and that applies to nuclear withdrawal and the new leadership vote - then we have a great opportunity to turn the wheel round," he told Bild Zeitung.

webTitle: Help:  Why is there always a 'but'?

fields.headline: Help:  Why is there always a 'but'?
fields.standfirst: Whenever my manager says I've done a good job there's always a but. I'm left feeling I can never get it quite right.  Rick P, civil engineer, Bath
fields.trailText: Whenever my manager says I've done a good job there's always a but. I'm left feeling I can never get it quite right. Rick P, civil engineer, Bath
fields.body:
Research into feedback at work shows managers think they praise people more than they actually do, whereas employees report receiving five times more criticism than praise. This gap between perception and reality is partly due to it being easy to forget to praise good work, whereas bawling someone out has an urgency to it.

The other reason is what you're experiencing, the prevalence of qualified approval. To say 'that was excellent but ...' is a waste of praise: what's heard and remembered is the actual or implied criticism.

Knowing you can never please is disheartening and rarely provides the motivation to try harder. If you know your work is good don't let anyone undermine your confidence. Don't simply accept criticism, question it. Ask how he would have done things and why that would have been better. For every 'but' request help such as training or resources to enable you to improve future performance. Your picky boss will be less likely to criticise if he has to help you find solutions.

He may have reasons for keeping you edgy and uncertain. Nothing maintains the status quo like underlings feeling they're not capable of doing as good a job as those who direct their efforts. Despite slow moves to kinder management there are still many who foster insecurity among staff in the mistaken belief that it keeps them on their toes.

webTitle: Making the right moves after the show

fields.headline: Making the right moves after the show
fields.standfirst: Follow up on leads and claim check-mate
fields.trailText: Follow up on leads and claim check-mate
fields.body:
When you leave the fair, having battled with 13,999 other graduates for the attention of your favoured employers, you may well have had enough of careers thoughts for a while. However, taking a few moments to reflect on the day can really help you to make best use of what you have found out and plan for your next move.

1. Be ready to go

If you come away with a clear idea of the type of work you want, don't stop there. Follow up on the day in order to land that all-important job offer. With actual job vacancies, check the basics such as deadlines and how to apply (application form, CV or other method). Then arm yourself with plenty of background info about the employer. Check how you match the job requirements. If in any doubt, get back in touch with the people you met at the fair for more information.

2. Follow up leads

You may not be ready to apply yet. In this case, any contacts you made today could be invaluable. Keep in touch with them, and keep building up your information. For some areas, graduates have to charm their way into an entry-level position. For this, you need to be organised and persistent. Woo your contacts professionally, and they may offer you helpful advice - maybe even a job.

3. Keep records

Take the time to jot down who you met today, and what was said. What new information did you get today? What do you want to find out next? Who can help you with this? The catalogue can be very useful for keeping track of this.

4. Take time to consolidate

Not everyone leaves the fair on a high. If you lack a clear career aim afterwards, don't despair. Anything you have found out can be helpful, if you use it to inform your search for the right career. You may be reconsidering career ideas which you had before the fair. This can be a blow to morale, but you can use it to clarify what you are after. What changed your mind? Are the requirements too steep? There may be another way in through a different entry point or getting some voluntary work experience. Or maybe your new insight into a business leaves you less keen to work there. If so, use the new information to get a clearer idea of what you want.

5. Look for someone special

The exhibitors at the fair tend to be larger organisations, who find it worth committing several staff to two days answering jobseekers' questions. This means that not every type of employer is represented. Find other ways to contact the employers which interest you. See the box for information on starting points.

6. Seek a sign

It is tempting to turn up at the fair hoping for inspiration. With all these jobs available, surely you'll find one which is right for you? Without some ideas to check out, however, you may come away no clearer than before. Go back to basics.

Think about what you want from work and what you can offer. Concentrate on finding a starting point which will use your skills. If you can make it to a higher education careers service, try the Prospects Planner software to help you find ideas.

7. Find help

Getting professional advice will probably be necessary at some point. See the box for sources of help, most of which are available to graduates as well as current students.

8. Your careers service
Most careers services will continue to offer help after graduation. If you return home after studies, you may be able to use your nearest careers service under the Mutual Aid scheme. Check with the individual service for details.

 Tim Bradshaw is a ULCS careers adviser

webTitle: Employers to suit every taste and palate

fields.headline: Employers to suit every taste and palate
fields.trailText: In case you hadn't noticed, it's the 21st century and the cyberspace revolution has begun in earnest. Where the job market is concerned, developments in IT and internet technology have led to a boom in opportunities for qualified programmers, web developers and systems engineers.
fields.body:
In case you hadn't noticed, it's the 21st century and the cyberspace revolution has begun in earnest. Where the job market is concerned, developments in IT and internet technology have led to a boom in opportunities for qualified programmers, web developers and systems engineers.

Trouble is, where are they all?

Current trends indicate a severe lack of suitably trained and experienced candidates to fill the record numbers of jobs in the IT industry. The Prince PerfectFit programme, backed by Microsoft as part of its Skills 2000 initiative, has been established specifically to meet what its organisers describe as "the insatiable demand for qualified IT professionals in the UK".

This statement is confirmed by a quick glance at the exhibitor list for the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair, Europe's largest graduate recruitment exhibition. As well as Prince PerfectFit, the event can boast the participation of such companies as Freeserve, EDS and Logica UK. In addition to these IT giants, first-time exhibitors at the fair include Buildonline.com, Esoft Global, Power X and Seagate Software from the computing and dot.com marketplace.

But it's not only in the IT and internet industries that graduate recruiters are stepping up their recruitment drive. The traditionally competitive and elitist City and financial sectors will also have their biggest presence at the Fair since the late 80s. Alongside major accountancy and consulting firms Arthur Andersen, Deloitte and Touche, Ernst & Young and PricewaterhouseCoopers - all regular exhibitors at the event - graduates will this year be able to meet employers such as Andersen Consulting, the Bank of England, Bloomberg, Dow Jones International and Lehman Brothers.

As well as the traditional graduate employers, there are many new organisations exhibiting. First Conferences stress that it is a "dynamic, fun and continually evolving company" and promises graduates a company culture with "no dress code, no set hours of work and a non-hierarchical team environment". Graduates interested in this kind of workplace should check out its seminar entitled "Discover the tricks of getting a job in a non-traditional company".

While the government might be split over Europe, the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair wholeheartedly embraces employers from across the channel. If the idea of a career in Europe turns you on then the fair plays host to some tantalising names including the European Commission, French-based consultancy Europstat, the European Patent Office and German bio-engineering firm Epigenomics.

Indeed with 170 exhibitors on both days of the fair, almost every sector can boast an impressive list of names. Fancy a career in retail? Then come along and find out about such diverse companies as Arcadia Group, Waitrose and Decathlon UK, alongside top trio Asda, Sainsburys and Tesco. Or, maybe you're more geared towards the communications industry. Choose from the Carphone Warehouse, Motorola, One2One or Syntegra.

So make sure you're there to stake your claim.

 Phil Howe is marketing services officer for fairs at ULCS

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Restaurants
fields.standfirst: Andrew Pitman-Wallace, co-owner of the Southwark restaurant Sixty-Two, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Andrew Pitman-Wallace, co-owner of the Southwark restaurant Sixty-Two, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
I know it's a hackneyed cliché, but the most accurate description of the food we serve is modern European. We opened Sixty-Two three years ago after renovating the building ourselves, and since then we have managed to build up a regular clientele.

As chef I'm purely responsible for the food while my co-owner Clare Horrell takes care of the business side. Although the restaurant can seat up to 40 diners there are only three of us in the kitchen - even during the busiest periods.

The day starts at around 9am, checking the ingredients that have been delivered overnight to make sure they're of sufficient quality. From there we look over the menu to make sure we've got everything we need for the day's cooking and order anything we lack. We're lucky to have very good local suppliers and if there's a problem they're usually round quickly with replacements.

At around 10.30am the front-of-house staff arrive to prepare for lunch and I'll take them through the menu. We generally offer eight starters and main courses including two fish dishes and a vegetarian option. If the morning's cooking has gone smoothly we'll stop at around 11.30am for that all-important coffee.

Lunch customers often want to be served quickly so starters and vegetables are prepared earlier in the day - typical starters are risotto or a red onion tart. The fish or meat is generally portioned and prepared ready to be cooked as it's ordered. Because lunch is concentrated into a short period of time it can get very busy and very hot. But unlike some kitchens, there's no hierarchy and we tend to divide the jobs up according to who likes doing what.

As soon as lunch is over we clean the pots and pans and wash everything down for dinner. Depending on what time we finish, I'll either nip home for a bowl of cereal and a rest or prepare for the evening. In some ways it's easier to pick yourself up again for dinner if you don't leave.

Because we offer a pre-theatre dinner, we are open from 6pm and the kitchen generally stays open until 10.30pm. Once the last diner has been served I'll cook a meal for the staff and, again, everything is washed down. The last task is to order the ingredients for the following day and I generally leave between 11 and midnight.

The hours are long and it's often frenetic, but there's no better sight than empty plates returning to the kitchen. The only problem is winding down and my dinner is often a sandwich bought from a garage on the way home.

webTitle: How to... make the most of your day at the fair

fields.headline: How to... make the most of your day at the fair
fields.standfirst: And don't come back without a job
fields.trailText: And don't come back without a job
fields.body:
Whether you've just graduated and are looking for that all important first job, or thinking of moving on to your second or maybe even third position since graduation, you'll be pleased to know that the graduate market is more buoyant than it's been for a very long time. It's a great time to make that move.

Some 170 top graduate recruiters will be represented at the London Graduate Recruitment Fair, which is organised by the University of London Careers Service (ULCS). These employers will be offering immediate positions in a huge variety of industry sectors and information on career and training opportunities. So, arrive early and give yourself plenty of time to make full use of all the services available.

Due to the large number and variety of organisations exhibiting you will need to focus your search. What do you want from the fair? What kind of career interests you? And what do you have to offer?

But don't do what I did - having just graduated, I visited the London Graduate Recruitment Fair and picked up brochures and application forms from virtually every company, most of which ended up under my bed gathering dust.

So be prepared. It's worth researching employers through the hot-links on the fair website at www.careers.lon.ac.uk/lgrf Not only can you find out what they actually do, you can often get inside information on the type of people they look for and what it's like to work for them.

And if you haven't already sent off for a catalogue, you can buy one when you arrive at the fair. Priced at £1.50 it contains full details of all exhibitors and the vacancies they are offering. It also contains a plan so you can navigate your way around the fair, and the complete seminar programme. Use the catalogue to target specific companies that interest you, but also those which have appropriate vacancies that maybe you hadn't considered before.

It's important to make a good first impression, so dress smartly and treat the fair as an interview situation. For example, don't ask PricewaterhouseCoopers "What do you do?" - if you've researched the companies beforehand you should know already. Think up some relevant and intelligent questions, and try to pre-empt questions they may ask you. The fair will be very busy and you will have only a short time to make an impact, so make sure it's a good one.

Some organisations will be taking CVs, so bring along plenty of copies. If you have time before the fair get one of your college careers advisers to check it over. They will be able to offer ideas and tips on layout, wording and how to sell yourself.

If an employer gives you an application form, don't rush to fill it in. Take it home with you and complete it in your own time. If you haven't heard from an employer by about three weeks after the fair, follow it up with a phone call or letter. It will show the employer that you are still interested in them and their vacancy.

If you want to attend any of the seminars you should plan ahead, as some are running on one day only. These will provide you with more in-depth information on some of the organisations exhibiting. There are also presentations by other organisations from industry sectors which are less well represented: these include advertising, environmental sciences, television and journalism.

Careers seminars covering a broad range of topics, and seminars specifically for perfecting your applications and CVs complete the programme. The full listing can be found in the fair catalogue and is also on the website.

If you really haven't got a clue which direction you are heading, do not despair. There is still plenty for you to gain from your visit to the fair.

Try the computer-aided careers guidance package Adult Directions which will match your preferences to job descriptions. Careers advisers are available for one-to-one Quick Query sessions, and to look over CVs and applications to offer advice on how to improve them.

Whatever subject you've spent the last three years studying, it's now time to enter the working world. There will be something for everyone at the fair. It is simply a case of finding it. As the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair is bigger than ever this year there is even more reason to plan ahead.

Decide your plan of action, be confident and impress the recruiters with your knowledge. You never know, you may even be offered a job on the spot.

 Cara Griffith is marketing services manager for fairs at ULCS.

If you haven't heard from an employer by about three weeks after the fair, follow it up with a phone call or letter. It will show the employer that you are still interested in them and their vacancy. If you want to attend any of the seminars you should plan ahead, as some are running on one day only. These will provide you with more in-depth information on some of the organisations exhibiting. There are also presentations by other organisations from industry sectors which are less well represented: these include advertising, environmental sciences, television and journalism. Careers seminars covering a broad range of topics, and seminars specifically for perfecting your applications and CVs complete the programme. The full listing can be found in the fair catalogue and is also on the website. If you really haven't got a clue which direction you are heading, do not despair. There is still plenty for you to gain from your visit to the fair. Try the computer-aided careers guidance package Adult Directions which will match your preferences to job descriptions. Careers advisers are available for one-to-one Quick Query sessions, and to look over CVs and applications to offer advice on how to improve them. Whatever subject you've spent the last three years studying, it's now time to enter the working world. There will be something for everyone at the fair. It is simply a case of finding it. As the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair is bigger than ever this year there is even more reason to plan ahead. Decide your plan of action, be confident and impress the recruiters with your knowledge. You never know, you may even be offered a job on the spot.  Cara Griffith is marketing services manager for fairs at ULCS.

webTitle: Graduates have never had it so good

fields.headline: Graduates have never had it so good
fields.trailText: There are almost as many ways to get a graduate job as there are jobs to be won. One relatively pain-free way is to visit the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair. Among the many benefits is that you will get an immediate feel for the graduate labour market as it currently stands - which sectors are growing and have vacancies to fill, which sectors are struggling and which are so popular that their books were full last Christmas.
fields.body:
There are almost as many ways to get a graduate job as there are jobs to be won. One relatively pain-free way is to visit the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair. Among the many benefits is that you will get an immediate feel for the graduate labour market as it currently stands - which sectors are growing and have vacancies to fill, which sectors are struggling and which are so popular that their books were full last Christmas.

So, if you've spent the past year concentrating on exam results, trying not to think about life after university and are now feeling a little unsure - even possibly a touch panicky - worry not. Breathe deeply and rejoice in the knowledge that there are more employers wanting to recruit you at the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair than at any fair since 1990.

The ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair is Europe's most prestigious graduate recruitment event but what will really interest you is that this year a record number of employers representing a broad range of employment sectors will attend and they are keen to harness your talents. For those of you looking for a traditional 'graduate' career, there are financial institutions, government agencies, retail and engineering companies including the Bank of England, the European Commission, Arcadia and Motorola.

Meanwhile Rutherford Appleton Laboratories, Wyeth and Epigenomics are all seeking scientists. As always the IT industry is well represented with many new media companies as well as the more traditional system support companies. The fair provides you with the opportunity to meet these people, speak to them about their organisation and impress them with your skills and personality. Some may even want to interview you on the spot.

Have you set your heart on a more 'creative' job, where every position has several hundred applicants? We can't promise that any of these recruiters will be hiring at the fair but we can offer some inside information at our Professional Bodies and Information seminars where representatives from television, PR, radio, publishing and advertising (among others) will speak about what they do, how they got there and perhaps give you some ideas on how you can do the same.

If you still aren't sure what you want to do, the fair has even more to offer. Speak to the many professional bodies on hand to find out more about working in their industries. A comprehensive seminar program also runs throughout the two days with help on how to begin (and complete!) your job search successfully.

Careers advisers from the University of London will also be available to help with short advice sessions and a CV surgery to improve your applications.

With more than 12,000 visitors expected at the fair, this can only ever be a brief emergency assistance. So if you feel you need more in-depth advice, hurry along to your university careers service before you leave.

If you'd prefer something more impersonal or you want more than one opinion, visit the fair's Cyber Centre and try the computer-aided careers guidance programme which matches your job preferences with careers - it may give you a few ideas to work on.

However you feel about your current job prospects, be realistic but also be optimistic. Graduate employment is rising and there are opportunities out there.

If you do decide to attend the ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair come prepared. Wear a suit, bring copies of your CV and try to find out more about the organisations you are interested in before you make the journey to the fair.

No one ever claimed that finding a job would be easy. The ULCS London Graduate Recruitment Fair makes it as easy as it can be - but you have to put in a little bit of hard work in order to reap the highest dividends.

 Anne-Marie Martin is director of the University of London Careers Service.

webTitle: How to ... negotiate your first salary slip

fields.headline: How to ... negotiate your first salary slip
fields.standfirst: Don't cash in your chips until you have played your final card
fields.trailText: Don't cash in your chips until you have played your final card
fields.body:
The question that strikes fear into the heart of every interviewee. "Can you give us some idea of your salary expectation?" Just how do you answer? Pitch it too high and you look unrealistic and overly confident, pitch it too low and you undervalue both yourself and your ability to do the job. For most of us, salary is one of the most important factors in taking a job - and yet it is often the subject that is hardest to discuss.

"I never know how to tackle the subject of salary," admits Ian Brinkworth, who works as design editor on a glossy magazine. "I always research how much other companies pay and go into an interview armed with the relevant knowledge, but somehow I always come out with a bad deal. I got my last job through an agency and there was £5,000 difference between the top and bottom end of the salary offered. I promised myself I'd ask for a figure at the top end of the range, but when it came to it I found myself asking for only £1,000 more than their lowest figure. Which of course they agreed to, readily."

"Research is essential when it comes to proposing a reasonable salary, says Mark Hastings, head of policy at the Institute of Management. "Look around at job advertisements, websites, newspapers - there is a vast amount of information out there about jobs and relevant salaries. And research the company which is interviewing you - a big company will probably offer a far different salary package to a smaller one."

The most important thing to remember when discussing your salary is that it is a negotiation. The first figure you mention probably won't be the figure you agree on; but it is a figure from which you will only negotiate down. "The key is to negotiate from a position of strength," says business consultant Richard Owen. "In other words you have to believe that you are bringing something to the table. Even as a recent graduate you still have individual, unique skills to offer and it's important to bear that in mind.

"My problem is that I never really see it as an equal discussion," says Brinkworth. "I feel like they've got a figure in mind and unless I say the same amount or below then they won't give me the job. It never occurs to me that they might not have a set figure, that they might be flexible according to who they want to give the job to."

In fact, this is often the case. All employers know that finding the right person for the job isn't easy; if they offer you the position and they really want you for the job, then they will adjust the package accordingly. "Asking for a slightly higher salary will not affect the interviewer's decision to give you the job," says Owen.

"If an employer indicates a salary range, they will pay the top figure if they find the right person for the job. If you're not comfortable asking for the top amount, then go for just above mid-range; it's important to give the impression that you are worth a decent salary."

It's equally important to be flexible about the figure that is finally offered to you; if the company cannot pay the salary you want, there may be other parts of the package that can bring it up to a more acceptable level. "When I left university I was offered a dream job as a production assistant in a TV company," says Joely Clarke, "but the money was appalling. I asked for more and they simply said they were offering me the going rate. At first I was going to turn it down, but they offered to send me on all sorts of courses and would ensure I was an assistant producer in a year's time. And they stuck to their word: a year later I was earning £10,000 more and on a fast-track to being a producer. It was a fantastic opportunity - and although I was utterly skint for a year, the money I am earning now and will earn in the future more than makes up for it."

"Every job is a mixture of earning, learning and opportunity - salary is only one part of it," believes Mark Hastings. "If the salary is less than you want - and non-negotiable - then suggest other benefits the company might give you: training courses, help with further study, extra holiday or a guarantee of promoting you, and increasing your salary, after a certain period, if your work is of a sufficiently high standard. Some people focus exclusively on salary when there may be other opportunities on offer that are far more valuable than an extra couple of grand."

If you don't remember anything else...

A salary negotiation is a two-way conversation. You want to fill the position, they want the position filled. Focus on your strengths and your skills and suggest a salary that really reflects your worth.

webTitle: Learn to juggle if you want a life as well as a good job

fields.headline: Learn to juggle if you want a life as well as a good job
fields.standfirst: But it might mean making sacrifices
fields.trailText: But it might mean making sacrifices
fields.body:
A 'work-life balance' is, by its very nature, subjective. Balance for you will vary depending on your personality and the job you do. But one thing is certain: juggling personal and professional commitments is becoming more important to graduates. In fact, it is now one of the main criteria in determining whether to accept or reject a new job according to the Association of Graduate Recruiters.

"What we have found", says chief executive officer Carl Gilleard, "is that graduates really do live to work, not work to live."

A PricewaterhouseCoopers survey recently reinforced this point. Fifty seven per cent of respondents rated the work-life balance a "top priority for their future career".

At least, that's what graduates say on questionnaires. What about in practice? "The reality is that most of them are still working long and hard, sometimes very long and very hard," says Linda Collins, information manager for the pressure group New Ways of Working. She stresses, however, "some are taking a more level approach".

Arguably this is because they can. Peninah Thomson of executive coaching specialist The Change Partnership explains further. "There is a select group of graduates out there now who are so in demand that they are able to ask for what they want." And if what they want is a better work-life balance, then that is precisely what they can have. "In certain sectors of the economy, some graduates can effectively dictate their own terms," confirms Fin O'Hara from management consultancy Ceridian.

But what if you are not one of the chosen few? "You will do almost anything just to get the job you want and then you will do anything just to keep it," says Kara Wescombe. She graduated from the Winchester School of Art in 1997 and is now the education officer for London's Courtauld Gallery.

Before being properly employed to do this job she actually did it on a voluntary, part-time basis, working during her weekends for nothing more than the opportunity to improve her chances of getting an in - and, all the while, holding down a regular full-time position elsewhere. These choices, insists Kara, were made willingly. "I really wanted to get started in my career", she says. "Right now, that does mean putting other things on hold".

Giulio Quaggiotto recognises this equation. He is also choosing to forgo nights out with friends for nights in at the office. With a MA in communication from Westminster University he recently started working as a researcher for Paradigm, a new media company based in London. Here Quaggiotto is "very much in charge" of managing his own time. "It's great," he says. "At least when I've finished I can actually leave. You don't have to hang around to 10 or 11 just for the sake of it, something I've seen happen in other places."

Peer pressure and economic conditions are not the only factors that determine graduates' work-life balance. There are also the graduates themselves. Some may feel nervous in their position and, according to a new report from Cambridge University, this insecurity can lead to a tendency to work more intensely. Others just push themselves regardless. Dr Desmond Kelly from the Royal College of Psychiatrists argues that some workers "have a little terrorist in their brain that just flogs them on, day in, day out".

London College of Fashion graduate Dominic Shortle freely confesses to possessing a "strong" work ethic. He puts in a full day as a menswear designer for Corbins in Piccadilly. Once home he starts working on his own collection, finishing up around 11pm most nights. Friday is an exception. He drives up to York and parties until 3am. After a few hours sleep he then drives to Leeds to help out at his parents' specialist collectors shop. After trading hours he drives back to York and goes out till the wee hours once more. Shortle returns to London on Sunday evening in time to start the cycle all over again.

So, in the end, just what does the work-life balance mean to graduates? Clearly it depends who you ask. Some are discovering that they have more control over their lives. Others are finding they have less. Could we be witnessing the emergence of choice-rich and choice-poor graduates when it comes to the work-life balance? Or perhaps we're just realising it has always been like this.

webTitle: Don't leave home without a gap year plan

fields.headline: Don't leave home without a gap year plan
fields.standfirst: What will you be able to offer on your return?
fields.trailText: What will you be able to offer on your return?
fields.body:
Now is the time for travelling. But what are the risks to graduates who set off for their season in the sun without a clear idea of what they could be doing when they return?

"I made the classic mistake," says Luke Dent. "I knew I was going to do a few ski seasons in Grenoble after I graduated, mixed in with summer camp work in France and America, so I didn't pay too much attention to the opportunities in my final year. This made it much more difficult to find a good job when I came back."

However much you think you're going to enjoy the worlds of back-packing and seasonal employment abroad - and even if you think you're going to be doing it for the foreseeable future - it's likely that one day you are going to want a job that reflects your education.

The first problem is timing. If you are looking for a graduate traineeship, selection is timed to the academic year: applications in by January, interviews and tests in February and March, offers in May-June, start in September. If you arrive back at the wrong time, it could be 18 months before you start work.

All of which presumes that you can get a traineeship. As you haven't secured a job before going, employers are going to question your commitment to themselves, the industry, and to a more settled lifestyle - the latter being one of the most important problems, as many employers will worry that you have itchy feet.

"When employers ask you if you have got the wanderlust out of your system, it is vital that you have a convincing answer to this question," says Dent. "And if they don't ask, you should volunteer it. In order to carry conviction you have to be convinced yourself. I learned this the hard way. After I came back I went for a number of interviews in media sales and though they liked me, they reported back that their concern was that I would be off again as soon as the ski season started."

By the time it came to an interview for the logistics arm of Boots, he had his answer down pat. "I told them quite truthfully that I had run out of challenges. I could do the ski job in my sleep, I was bored of living in hotels and found the fact that I was only forming friendships that lasted a few months dispiriting. I was ready for home, and for new opportunities."

Unlike smaller companies that may just make appointments on gut instincts (once a traveller always a traveller), big graduate recruiters like Boots are wary of writing anyone off, and were pleased to offer Dent the job.

"We look at people like Luke because everyone demonstrates their vitality and energy in different ways," says Alan Kerr, recruitment marketing manager with Boots. "For some it is academic work, for others it is extra-curricular activities, while for others it may be the challenge of an alien environment. As to worrying whether people will wander off, our attitude is that the best people do need challenges, so it is up to us as an organisation to convince them that their next year with us will be just as invigorating."

But big name recruiters of course require far more than to be convinced that you are not about to disappear again. What they are looking for is transferable skills.

"We are looking for specific answers to specific competency questions," says Jane Brundle, graduate recruitment manager with KPMG. "In a way it does not really matter what you have done, whether travelling, a voluntary project, or seasonal employment. It is what you have learned that matters. I would, however be very doubtful of someone who didn't have any work experience these days."

It is, of course, far easier to demonstrate transferable skills if you have already thought about this aspect and built it into your itinerary.

Sophie Matthews spent six months in Chile, three of which were on a Raleigh Expedition where she helped build a community centre and a bridge. "I would highly recommend this type of activity," she says. "It was superb for a number of reasons. But in terms of employment benefits, there is no doubt that building a bridge across a river is an organisational and logistical challenge which naturally gives you the sort of team-building and leadership skills that employers are looking for. I will definitely keep it on my CV."

Matthews, however, already had a job with Andersen Consulting on hold when she left for Chile, and her case highlights the great Catch 22 of travelling. It is much easier to focus on what you can get out of an experience if you know what you will be doing at the end of it. But for many, much of the attraction of foreign travel is the fact that its open-ended nature allows them to focus on what it is they want while being well away from family and friends.

Luke Dent occasionally attends recruitment fairs on behalf of his company and finds that he is often fielding questions from students who want to plan their get-up-and-going so they don't return to find career prospects have gone AWOL as well.

"I tell them it really is best to use the careers service resources available to them in university," he says, "and to think about what sort of job they want now rather than later. However, if they do head off without a job, it is important to think about the experience they do have in terms of key competencies."

Unlike smaller companies that may just make appointments on gut instincts (once a traveller always a traveller), big graduate recruiters like Boots are wary of writing anyone off, and were pleased to offer Dent the job. "We look at people like Luke because everyone demonstrates their vitality and energy in different ways," says Alan Kerr, recruitment marketing manager with Boots. "For some it is academic work, for others it is extra-curricular activities, while for others it may be the challenge of an alien environment. As to worrying whether people will wander off, our attitude is that the best people do need challenges, so it is up to us as an organisation to convince them that their next year with us will be just as invigorating." But big name recruiters of course require far more than to be convinced that you are not about to disappear again. What they are looking for is transferable skills. "We are looking for specific answers to specific competency questions," says Jane Brundle, graduate recruitment manager with KPMG. "In a way it does not really matter what you have done, whether travelling, a voluntary project, or seasonal employment. It is what you have learned that matters. I would, however be very doubtful of someone who didn't have any work experience these days." It is, of course, far easier to demonstrate transferable skills if you have already thought about this aspect and built it into your itinerary. Sophie Matthews spent six months in Chile, three of which were on a Raleigh Expedition where she helped build a community centre and a bridge. "I would highly recommend this type of activity," she says. "It was superb for a number of reasons. But in terms of employment benefits, there is no doubt that building a bridge across a river is an organisational and logistical challenge which naturally gives you the sort of team-building and leadership skills that employers are looking for. I will definitely keep it on my CV." Matthews, however, already had a job with Andersen Consulting on hold when she left for Chile, and her case highlights the great Catch 22 of travelling. It is much easier to focus on what you can get out of an experience if you know what you will be doing at the end of it. But for many, much of the attraction of foreign travel is the fact that its open-ended nature allows them to focus on what it is they want while being well away from family and friends. Luke Dent occasionally attends recruitment fairs on behalf of his company and finds that he is often fielding questions from students who want to plan their get-up-and-going so they don't return to find career prospects have gone AWOL as well. "I tell them it really is best to use the careers service resources available to them in university," he says, "and to think about what sort of job they want now rather than later. However, if they do head off without a job, it is important to think about the experience they do have in terms of key competencies."

webTitle: Save the pound, lose the euro-dividend

fields.headline: Save the pound, lose the euro-dividend
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report

Portugal Summit
fields.trailText: Summer's here and the summit season is upon us. As they clink glasses in the sun-kissed capitals of the world, politicians might care to reflect on their increasing marginalisation in the global economy.
fields.body:
Summer's here and the summit season is upon us. As they clink glasses in the sun-kissed capitals of the world, politicians might care to reflect on their increasing marginalisation in the global economy.

The British government's leading figures chose to land in Portugal this week on the same plane - a PR lesson learned from the previous EU summit and a convenient opportunity to paper over their internal divisions on the euro. They returned with a tongue-lashing from Wim Duisenberg - spittle off a duck's back - and a victory in the siege warfare over withholding tax.

All in all, a solid week's work. But one unlikely to put many credits in the electoral piggybank. The withholding tax triumph will reinforce chancellor Gordon Brown's already solid standing in the eyes of the City. However, it was hardly the guts and glory stuff of acrimonious summits past.

In many respects this must be a good thing. One could argue that the best chancellors are those with the lowest profiles - provided they have not been neutered by overbearing premiers. The world's major developed economies are managed by governments with a commitment to capitalism. When times are good, they should be allowed to roll with a minimum of interference.

Times right now are undeniably good for the global economy. This is partly a cyclical phenomenon, partly a function of the new technology revolution, but partly also a consequence of a transfer of power from politicians to bureaucrats.

This power transfer has been most pronounced in Europe. Although the quantum of politicians has increased - witness Britain with its new devolved assemblies - the influence of politicians individually and collectively has diminished considerably. This is especially true in the area of economic management.

The American and German economies have long relied upon monetary policy that is independent of direct influence by politicians. One consequence was a higher regard from the financial markets and, in turn, a lower cost of money than might otherwise have prevailed.

This model is now employed throughout Europe, including Britain, and has proven reassuringly uncontentious during the recent phase of interest rate tightening. Politicians have displayed suitable restraint as rates have risen - it is nice, after all, for someone else to carry the can - but this will only truly be tested at a time of economic crisis.

It is tempting to ask whether politics matters at all, then, for financial markets. The American presidential election is only five months away. Can it really carry no risk for markets? A British election may be less than a year away. Surely, the choice of the British electorate must have some economic impact? Few would deny the clustering of political parties in the US and the Britain around the same points on the policy spectrum.

It is difficult to envisage what new economic policy issues might yet burst on to the US political scene to influence the outcome of this autumn's election. Two existing issues could create ripples: the high oil price and protectionism. Neither, though, have make or break potential.

President Bill Clinton's political survival in the face of great adversity - of his own making - must be due in large part to the blissful state of America's economy. Neither Al Gore nor George Bush will dare tinker with the machinery that Alan Greenspan has so painstakingly tuned.

Tony Blair's UK administration has - under the chancellor's tutelage - taught itself similar restraint. The nation's coffers may swell, but only a Labour slump in the polls could induce the government to loosen its purse strings.

This is all just dandy for financial markets on both sides of the Atlantic. Prudent fiscal policy and predictable monetary policy is the ideal combination for local markets and leaves equity investors free to focus on stock selection.

Which - in Britain - just leaves the euro. This is the one economic policy issue with the potential to fracture the government and polarise the electorate.

The Tories' focus on the single currency is timely, precisely because conditions may never be more propitious for the adoption of the euro than they are today. In driving the government on to the back foot, William Hague can capture swaths of political ground and "save" the pound for at least another economic cycle.

Britain's financial markets will care increasingly about this debate.

There is still perceived to be a juicy dividend of lower interest rates and higher asset prices to be triggered by euro entry. The old "conservative good, labour bad" market mantra is now obsolete.

Whether it will be revived depends on just how Labour resolves the wrangle between Tony Blair's European heart and his political head.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: Union plea on euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Jackson, the engineering union leader, yesterday became the first senior Labour figure openly to call on Gordon Brown to make a public assessment before the election of the Treasury's five economic tests on joining the single currency.
fields.body:
Ken Jackson, the engineering union leader, yesterday became the first senior Labour figure openly to call on Gordon Brown to make a public assessment before the election of the Treasury's five economic tests on joining the single currency.

The move is being supported in private by cabinet figures who believe they cannot go through the election campaign insisting the government will make no assessment of the tests until after the election.

They fear the government will be accused of a hidden agenda, as a series of other bodies make their own judgments on whether the British economic cycle has aligned in a sustained way with that of Europe, the central plank of the five tests.

Even pro-European ministers believe the assessment before the election would show the British economy had not yet converged with Europe in a sustained way and the tests therefore had not yet been met, but was on course to do so.

Speaking on BBC radio, Mr Jackson agreed an assessment should be made before the election.

"We have got to have an ongoing debate and keep people abreast of what is happening with the five criteria," Mr Jackson said.

But Mr Brown, speaking in Birmingham yesterday, insisted the government's policy will not change.

fields.headline: Elian to return to Cuba
fields.standfirst: The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy who provoked an international legal battle, could be back in Havana by next Wednesday after a decision by the second highest court in the United States.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy who provoked an international legal battle, could be back in Havana by next Wednesday after a decision by the second highest court in the United States.

A unanimous ruling by the 12-judge appeal court in Atlanta, Georgia clears the way for the ending of a saga that began when Elian was rescued from the sea off Florida on November 23 last year, after his mother and 10 others fleeing Cuba drowned when their boat capsized.

The judges in the Circuit Court of Appeal in Atlanta yesterday turned down an appeal by Elian's Miami relatives, who had wanted to keep him in the US against the wishes of his father. They had claimed he was eligible for political asylum because he came from Cuba.

The 12 judges made their views clear in a unanimous judgment that indicated that they did not even consider the Miami relatives' arguments worth hearing again. In a strongly-worded ruling, they warned the relatives: "Expect no motions to stay the issue."

The relatives were set a deadline of 4pm eastern time next Wednesday to make any final appeal to the supreme court, but the general legal view was that the endgame was fast approaching and Elian and his father could start packing for their return to Cuba. An earlier injunction banning Elian's father from removing the boy from the US expires at 4pm on Wednesday.

None of the Miami relatives were present in court although they had previously indicated that they would appeal the judgment if it went against them. The atmosphere was tranquil at the court but the decision is a major blow for the relatives and they will be aware that to pursue the case to the Supreme Court is almost certainly fruitless.

The Supreme Court is not obliged to hear the case and, given the overwhelming legal judgments against the relatives so far, is unlikely to do so. The relatives had already lost an appeal to a panel of three judges on June 1.

A United States marshall outside the home in which Elian is staying with his father and stepmother in a wealthy area of north west Washington said that she had been out buying grapes for Elian and his schoolfriends from Cuba who had joined him in April while he waited for the decision. His father Juan Miguel Gonzalez has already thanked the American people for their support and made no immediate comment on the decision. He arrived in April from Cuba in a bid to take his son back. The opinion polls have increasingly indicated that the American public should go back to Cuba with his father and the Miami relatives have become isolated. There have been few recent pictures of Elian available in contrast to his time with the Miami relatives when he was shown almost daily with new toys or clothes.

Asked about the issue while campaigning yesterday Republican candidate George W Bush would only say that he always felt that the matter should have been dealt with by a family court and not in the way that the Clinton administration had done. The attorney general Janet Reno was praised by some and criticised by others for ordering the removal by federal agents of the boy from the Miami home of the reltiaves who refused requests to hand him over to his father.

Almost all the legal decisions so far have now gone against the relatives who lost the argument with the Immigration and Naturalisation Service over who should speak for the boy. International human rights organisations have argued that holding the boy in the US against his and his father's will amounts to a breach of human rights law. The Clinton administration have argued that they want to resolve the situation according to the law.

In Cuba there will be celebrations at the news. The issue has resulted in demonstrations by tens of thousands in favour of his return. One by-product of the saga is that there may be a loosening of the American embargo against Cuba as American public opinion has changed as a result of the debate. Many commentators have suggested that the Clinton administation has operated double standards by embracing trade with commmunist China while attempting to destablise Cuba with an embargo.

The world has not heard the last of the six-year-old. At least two films about the story are underway.

webTitle: Two charged as inquest hears of migrants' last hours

fields.headline: Two charged as inquest hears of migrants' last hours
fields.standfirst:
As two people are charged over the Dover deaths, the Dutch Chinese community says the cross-Channel tragedy was not the first

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The 58 Chinese people who died in a sealed lorry trailer at Dover docks frantically banged on its inside walls with their shoes in a fruitless attempt to get help when they realised their air supply had been cut off, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The 58 Chinese people who died in a sealed lorry trailer at Dover docks frantically banged on its inside walls with their shoes in a fruitless attempt to get help when they realised their air supply had been cut off, an inquest heard yesterday.

The coroner's officer, Graham Perrin, told the inquest in Dover that a vent at the side of the trailer had been closed before the lorry was loaded on to a ferry at Zeebrugge on Sunday. This shut off the air supply to the 56 young men and four women inside. Five hours after the vent was closed, all but two of the group were dead.

Mr Perrin said the two survivors, both men, had lived only because more oxygen became available for them to breathe as those around them died. Both were unconscious when they were found.

The inquest heard that boxes of tomatoes had been stacked at the back of the container to hide the people on board and make it look as though the trailer was full.

The lorry had left the Belgian port at 7.30pm local time, aboard the P&O vessel European Pathway. It arrived four and a half hours later at 11pm.

"It would appear that 90 minutes into the journey and realising the situation they were in, attempts were made by the occupants of the trailer to raise the alarm. This happened as they slowly became short of breath, hot and sweaty," Mr Perrin said.

"They tried to open the vent from within and moved the tomatoes to attempt to open the door. All the deceased had consumed some tomatoes, probably to keep their spirits going," Mr Perrin said.

The migrants had not been allowed to take bags with them and some wore as many as five layers of clothing. They all started to remove some of their clothes. "They were banging on the walls of the container in an attempt to be heard. This proved fruitless. Without air to breathe they were now inhaling their own respiratory waste, namely carbon dioxide," said Mr Perrin.

He said that death would have been fairly rapid once the carbon dioxide built up to critical levels. There was no evidence of dehydration or excessive heat despite exceptionally hot weather on the day.

Details of the deaths of the migrants, whose bodies have been simply numbered one to 58 in the absence of proper identification, were heard after the Dutch lorry driver, Perry Wacker, aged 32, made his first appearance before Folkestone magistrates, where he was charged with 58 counts of manslaughter, facilitating the entry of two people illegally into the country on June 18 and attempting to facilitate the entry of a further 58 people on the same date. He was remanded in custody for seven days. Magistrates made an order banning the publication of pictures of him as identification is an issue in the case.

Possible identities for three of the dead were given to the Home Office yesterday by a solicitor, Wah-Piow Tan, but he warned officials there would be little progress towards identifying the rest without an amnesty for British-based relatives who feared deportation.

The solicitor is in contact with seven families who believe their relatives may be among the victims. He wants the Home Office to give those who come forward permission to stay in Britain on compassionate grounds if they identify the bodies.

"We do not want to see a situation where 58 corpses lie in a mortuary because nothing can be done to identify them," he said. Last night the Home Office said talks would take place to try to resolve the issue.

Kent police said last night that fingerprints had revealed the group in the lorry were not the same people as those filmed by a Belgian TV crew two months ago.

Dover deaths: two charged

A Chinese woman and man have been charged with conspiracy to smuggle illegal immigrants into Britain after 58 bodies were found in a lorry at Dover, Kent police said last night.

Interpreter Ying Guo, 29, and chef You Yi, 38, from South Woodford, Essex, are to appear at Dover magistrates court today.

webTitle: In Rotterdam it is another vanishing, another consignment gone wrong

fields.headline: In Rotterdam it is another vanishing, another consignment gone wrong
fields.standfirst:
As the Dover deaths inquest opens, the Dutch Chinese community says the cross-Channel tragedy was not the first
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Those left behind call them the vanished, a steady stream of young men and women who arrive in Rotterdam, board a truck for England, and are never heard of again.
fields.body:
Those left behind call them the vanished, a steady stream of young men and women who arrive in Rotterdam, board a truck for England, and are never heard of again.

The first sign that something is wrong comes after a few days, sometimes weeks, when the concern of relatives in Britain and China courses through the grapevine.

As the silence continues so the relatives' anxiety deepens. They demand details about the truck and ferry, but Rotterdam's Chinese community can tell them only so much. The pleas for information slacken as reality dawns. Another consignment has gone wrong.

Monday's discovery of 58 corpses in a tomato truck at Dover was the biggest cross-channel smuggling tragedy, but not the first. According to the legal and illegal Chinese community in the Netherlands, there has been a series of deaths in containers over the past few years. But the trucks were not intercepted by customs and smugglers secretly disposed of the bodies.

"Two guys who worked here went to London two years ago, but they never contacted anyone. Their families phoned us. They are dead, we think," said a 19-year-old waitress in one of the two dozen Chinese restaurants on Rotterdam's Westkruiskade street.

They left for Dover in a sealed truck with around five other Chinese people. No one dared challenge the smugglers. "Once these things happen there is no point."

Debtors who fall foul of the Chinese gangs routinely disappear, but swirling through this port are anecdotes of others who paid for passage to England and joined the vanished.

They were accidentally poisoned, suffocated, frozen or baked to death by the vagaries of a route and trucks designed for produce, not humans, it is assumed.

In addition to the waitress, four others - three restaurant workers and a shopowner - said they knew of individuals who had died en route. Loi Che Chan, who runs a nightly 30-minute Chinese programme on Dutch radio, has news for the British customs officials who said they were surprised a tragedy had not happened sooner. "For years we've heard stories of people not making it over alive."

David Engelhard, whose Valentine Foundation hosts young asylum seekers, said: "I believe it. Everything points to it."

No statistics are recorded because silence cloaks the trade. Smugglers do not tell police lest they are charged with manslaughter, like Perry Wacker, the driver of the tomato truck. Survivors and relatives of the dead do not speak lest they be deported, since they too are usually illegal, said Paul Geense, an expert on Chinese affairs at Rotterdam University.

Aftershocks from the Dover discovery are rippling through Rotterdam, from where the 18-metre white refrigerated truck departed on Sunday.

Convoys of lorries continue to hiss through this sprawling port, where the Rhine and Maas rivers meet the North sea, but despite the bustle in Chinatown it is not business as usual.

The spotlight is not familiar to this community, even though it has long been identified as the last leg of a 12,000-mile journey from China to Britain. Police are searching houses and restaurants for the eight people denied places on the overcrowded lorry.

Rumours bubble: Wacker's alleged accomplice, Arjan van der Spek, was indebted to a gambling syndicate and took the job to pay off his debts; an influx from Fujian tempted a gang, anxious for payment, into taking excessive risks.

Gone to ground

Police complain that their contacts have gone to ground. Fewer Chinese faces were on the streets, festooned with orange for the European championship, and at the Holland Casino's roulette wheels.

Yet of that long, twisting trail from China, fewer cities are more secure for the smugglers. In Rotterdam they have a freedom which their colleagues in Italy, Slovenia and Russia can only envy. "In the past two years the gangs have got bolder," said Mr Geense . "It is not out of control, but the situation is much more chaotic."

Alleged police laxity is compounded by the refusal of victims to complain. They are afraid of reprisals and of exposing their businesses to scrutiny, a police officer said.

Last September the Chan family, which owns several restaurants in Rotterdam and the Hague, was hailed for heroism after daring to complain about extortion. Two weeks later the Chans dropped all charges.

Unlike the Moroccans and Surinamese, Holland's 80,000 Chinese are not classified as an official minority, denying them privileges, said Mr Engelhard.

Exulting in this isolation and lawlessness are the snakeheads, the smuggling gangs. Typically, they assemble clusters of new arrivals until there are enough for a large consignment. At any one time 200 to 300 are waiting to cross to Britain, said a police officer.

The doomed group was not unusual in waiting for up to two months, during which time they would probably have been rotated around different cities while working as skivvies in restaurants.

"Here. Always here," smiled a gap-toothed teenager peeling potatoes, looking up from his stool at the doorway of a kitchen which opened on to Westkruiskade. A red mat folded beneath a trolley was his bed.

"It's a form of slavery," said Monique Verkerk, of the national catering trade union. Secret passageways from the kitchens to neighbouring houses have been used by illegals during police raids, she said.

Despite the fallout from Dover, it is unlikely the deaths will have a long-term impact. The route opened after the fall of communism in Russia and eastern Europe is too well established.

"They have stepping stones all the way. They have been built quite systematically," a police officer said.

The flight from Beijing to Moscow is safe, if liable to glitches during occasional crackdowns. Flying from Moscow to safe-houses in Prague, and then travelling by foot and truck into the European Union, is considered the deluxe route.

When the snakeheads twist south the risks multiply. A 55-year-old Croatian trafficking boss, married to a Chinese woman, routinely robs his clients as they enter Italy from Slovenia. Women are forced into prostitution during longeurs.

Even riskier is the Adriatic crossing. Under cover of darkness Albanian gangs send semi-inflatables with 300-horsepower engines roaring from the beaches of Vlore to the Italian coast.

Propped in a bar two months ago, Ilyr, a veteran smuggler, grinned when explaining his preference for the Chinese. "They're smaller and lighter. You can fit 60 of them for 40 Kurds or Romanians."

Sometimes smugglers miscalculate. Last New Year's Eve, in an incident virtually unreported outside Italy, a 12-metre dinghy designed for 30 flipped 59 passengers and crew into freezing waters off Vlore. All died. Thirty-nine were Chinese.

Those that do make it are occasionally abandoned. Taxi firms in Bari receive calls in the early hours requesting fleets of cars at the beach. Rome's Termini train station disgorges exhausted, bewildered Chinese among tourists.

The 60 young men and women who boarded the container last Sunday probably thought they were among the lucky ones. Despite an arduous trek through mountains in the Czech republic, they had avoided most of the potential horrors.

According to a cousin in Britain who spoke by telephone to 19-year-old Chen Lin, spirits were high on the eve of the last leg of the trip. They had no bags, no money, no documents, and no water, but the worst appeared to be behind them.
