fields.headline: Female flight attendants win victory
fields.trailText: Female flight attendants who were required to be thinner than their male colleagues won a court judgment yesterday, entitling them to compensation from their employer, United Airlines.
fields.body:
Female flight attendants who were required to be thinner than their male colleagues won a court judgment yesterday, entitling them to compensation from their employer, United Airlines.

However, the airline immediately said it intended to appeal against the decision about the practice which was in place between 1980 and 1994. Up to 16,000 stewardesses are reported to be affected by the judgement, which overturned an earlier decision by a court. They were forced to keep their weight 1.5 stones lower than their male colleagues and are said to have undergone punishing regimes to keep their weight down. As part of their battle to maintain an "attractive weight", some of the stewardesses are said to have given a pint of blood a day and starved themselves. The airline argued yesterday that the practice was "in line with industry practices during that time frame".

"In fact United implemented this policy with the approval of its flight attendant union," the airline said. Speaking on behalf of the stewardesses, Edith Benay said: "They wanted attractive, sexy flight attendants. It was just lack of respect for women who were doing their job well, in some cases for many years". According to reports, air stewardess who were considered to be overweight had their pay docked or lost their jobs.

The airline insisted yesterday that a district court judge had reviewed its weight requirements in 1979, the year before they were introduced, and deemed them legal. The programme was phased out in August 1994, at a time when concern about eating disorders was mounting. The airline said "changing social attitudes" had prompted the abolition of the scheme and a change in its own culture which followed the introduction of an employee stock ownership plan. The move by the airline, which refused to disclose how much compensation it might be forced to pay out, to appeal against the decision is likely to fuel the debate about pressures on women to stay slim.

Airlines have been notorious for their attitude to female stewardesses, who in the past have been required to be immaculate in their appearance at all times. United Airlines used to produce tables estimating the appropriate weight of a stewardess according to their height. For instance a 50 year old, 5 foot 11 inches tall woman was required to weigh no more than 11 stone eight pounds while a man could weigh more than 13 stone. In their ruling, the judges of the ninth US circuit court of appeals said: "United made no showing that to have disproportionately thinner female flight attendants bears a relation to their ability to greet passengers, push carts, move luggage and, perhaps most important, provide assistance in emergencies".

fields.headline: Pennines premiere for Hughes
fields.trailText: Ted Hughes's last play is poised for a world premiere in the Pennine valley of his birth with the help of a £74,000 Arts Council grant.
fields.body:
Ted Hughes's last play is poised for a world premiere in the Pennine valley of his birth with the help of a £74,000 Arts Council grant.

Barrie Rutter, who heads a Halifax-based theatre company, was personally given the manuscript of the late poet laureate's last play, Alcestis, before he died, with the express wish it be performed in the Calder Valley.

The poet had completed the work, based on an unfinished text by Euripides, in what Rutter describes as a "surge of creative activity" after he was diagnosed with cancer. It is set for a premiere in Halifax before playing in other northern towns and London.

The £74,429 grant awarded for the tour is part of a total handout of nearly £5m for innovative stage projects.

All 132 awards went to travelling shows as part of the first ever round of the national touring programme.

As artistic director of the Northern Broadsides Theatre Company, Rutter has made his name staging plays in unusual venues across the UK.

He said yesterday: "I wrote to Ted Hughes once to congratulate him on one of his works and he wrote back saying his tuning fork had always been in the Calder Valley. After that, we kept corresponding until his death."

Alcestis will kick off at The Viaduct, on September 14, be fore moving to Nottingham, London, Cumbria and Salford.

Other ventures to receive grants include a show in which the audience become the "performers" by interacting with the cast. The production, Desert Rain by the London company Blast Theory, was awarded £32,160.

Steven Berkoff's operatic collaboration with Mark-Anthony Page, Greek, gets £72,492.

Press Association

fields.headline: Love letter virus hit ministries
fields.trailText: The I Love You email computer virus affected a third of government departments and the cost of response and repair is likely to be be significant, according to a Cabinet Office report.
fields.body:
The I Love You email computer virus affected a third of government departments and the cost of response and repair is likely to be be significant, according to a Cabinet Office report.

The long term impact on departmental business is "almost impossible to quantify", the report stated.

Ministers are being urged to carry out rapid precautionary steps to prevent a repetition and improve the integrity of the government computers.

Some government departments were extensively affected with the main impact on availability on email systems, the report said. "Systems were generally unavailable for several hours: some systems were taken down for several days."

The report revealed that Whitehall updated its anti-virus protection software at least once a day

webTitle: People power can win the day

fields.headline: People power can win the day
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: This is yesterday's editorial comment in the national Zimbabwean newspaper, the Financial Gazette:
fields.body:
This is yesterday's editorial comment in the national Zimbabwean newspaper, the Financial Gazette:

Zimbabwe's cornered government has spurned all pleas from friend and foe to end unrelenting political violence and the occupation of farms which have seriously undermined the validity of the weekend's general election.

For all the imperfections, exacerbated by an uneven playing field under which only Zanu-PF uses taxpayers' funds and state machinery for its campaigns and has an unfair advantage of 30 unelected seats, Zimbabweans should embrace this opportunity to vote en masse and without fear for their chosen parties.

They cannot and must not remain silent and in despair, hoping that somehow they will miraculously be rescued from their mounting crises by the angels of mercy.

No, they should use people power to redefine the political landscape they want, because this is their God-given right. Every vote counts and by turning out in large numbers only one verdict will be possible: the people will win.

Zimbabweans owe it to themselves, to use the words of South Africa's President Thabo Mbeki, to nurture and jealously guard democratic governance in their own land and to show whoever is in power that violations of their rights are intolerable and a dismissible offence.

Whichever party wins the election, it faces a daunting task of quickly pulling Zimbabwe out of its economic quagmire that has been born and fuelled by 20 years of naked arrogance and astonishing misrule.

Harsh measures will have to be taken to reverse the slide. Only when government spending has been brought under control and the notion of giving jobs to the boys thoroughly disabused will Zimbabwe's swelling budget deficit come down, along with its attendant rampant inflation and interest rates.

A redirection of hard-earned taxpayers' funds will urgently have to be made to stave off total collapse of the health sector and social services. Then the new government will have to work overtime to create and nurture an investment-friendly climate to attract both local and foreign money into Zimbabwe in a highly competitive global market.

Because of the poisoned race relations that now exist the new government will have to take swift steps to mend the damage and make each and every Zimbabwean, whatever his or her colour, creed or religion, feel that they once more belong.

Zimbabwe's tattered image, born out of years of mindless confrontation with all who wanted to help the country, will also need urgent repair.

Let no one attempt further to rig the election - the violence and farm seizures and the registration of dead voters are part of this strategy - because this will be the surest road to bloody civil strife and anarchy that is blighting much of Africa.

We want to believe that no sane Zimbabwean would want this ever to happen to the motherland. Over to you, the voters.

fields.headline: Belgium jails England soccer thug
fields.standfirst:
Football violence: special report

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: An England football fan accused of sparking riots in Brussels in which he is said to have assaulted several policemen was yesterday given a one year jail sentence.
fields.body:
An England football fan accused of sparking riots in Brussels in which he is said to have assaulted several policemen was yesterday given a one year jail sentence.

Mark Forrester, of Birmingham, who denied that he caused any serious trouble, was led away in handcuffs after the Belgian judge read out the verdict. His lawyers said he would appeal against the sentence in two weeks time.

Forrester, 33, and married with a two-year-old child, is the first England fan to be given a custodial sentence in Belgium.

He is one of some 900 England fans to have been detained by the Belgian authorities during Euro 2000.

Most of the hooligans have since been released, however, and apart from Forrester, only one other England fan is being held on remand in Belgium.

Forrester, a company manager, was one of 450 rampaging England supporters arrested by the police after a chaotic night of pitched battles in Brussels before the England v Germany match.

The trouble became so serious at one point that police used tear gas and baton charged fans who were brawling with local youths, German fans and the police.

Judge Regine Claeys told Forrester that there was "very clear and detailed evidence" that he had instigated riots in Brussels on the night of June 16.

Police witnesses had previously described how he had kicked and punched their colleagues and encouraged other fans to attack the massed ranks of heavily armed riot police. He was also spotted making offensive gestures and moving round behind police lines when the serious trouble kicked off.

The court was told that he was eventually arrested by a plain clothes police officer whose job it was to spot hardcore hooligans. "You were very provocative and very aggressive. That has been proven. I must tell you that football hooliganism will not be tolerated in any form," the judge told Forrester.

The judge did show leniency, however, and suspended six months of the one-year jail sentence for three years to ensure that Forrester would serve only a maximum of six months.

Forrester had previously argued that he had only been wandering about "to see where the atmosphere was". He said that, split up from his friends, he had unwittingly wandered into the heart of the trouble.

The behaviour of the England fans was described by the mayor of Brussels as "disgusting" and, combined with subsequent trouble in Charleroi, prompted the governing body of European football, Uefa, to threaten to expel England from the tournament if the violence were repeated.

webTitle: Bored by Bush, Feiffer gives up his strip

fields.headline: Bored by Bush, Feiffer gives up his strip
fields.standfirst:
Voice of liberal America for 44 years to focus on life 'outside six panels'

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: One of America's most celebrated political cartoonists is putting down his pen because he feels there is no humour to be found in George W Bush or Al Gore. The breakfast tables of much of liberal America this weekend will not be graced by Jules Feiffer, the subtle chronicler of his some of his country's most turbulent moments for nearly half a century.
fields.body:
One of America's most celebrated political cartoonists is putting down his pen because he feels there is no humour to be found in George W Bush or Al Gore. The breakfast tables of much of liberal America this weekend will not be graced by Jules Feiffer, the subtle chronicler of his some of his country's most turbulent moments for nearly half a century.

Feiffer has already alerted his devoted band of readers on both sides of the Atlantic to his departure. One of his characters, a dancer, upbraids him in a strip for giving up and he replies: "I'm a political cartoonist and it's become a real problem. The material I have to work with - Al Gore, George W Bush - when I grew nostalgic over Bill Clinton, I knew it was time to go."

The dancer - based on a very early girlfriend - tells him: "You were a young man dating girls when you started drawing this comic strip." He replies in the cartoon: "And now, three children and a grandchild later, I'm giving it up. Don't you think I have a life outside these six panels?"

Feiffer, whose cartoon had run every Sunday in the Los Angeles Times, the Miami Herald and the Chicago Tribune, as well as more than 100 US Sunday papers and the Observer, started drawing for New York's Village Voice in 1956. He articulated the voice of perplexed liberal America in much the same way that Posy Simmonds later did for perplexed liberal Britain in the Guardian.

Before the arrival of Gary Trudeau's Doonesbury it was Feiffer who exposed the hypocrisies of US politicians and satirised the times of LBJ and Nixon, of Reagan and Clinton. He said he had learnt his "contempt for abusive authority" in the army.

His departure not long after the death of Charles Schulz, the creator of Peanuts, ends another era of American cartooning. He has explained on his website that he wants to spend more time on other projects and escape the "drumbeat of deadlines".

"I was no longer having fun," said Feiffer, 71, who teaches a course in "humour and truth" at Long Island University's Southampton College. He said he had made his decision about three months ago and wanted to quietly fade from view.

But he decided to say a long goodbye to his readers, some of whom have followed the Sunday strip since it started.

Feiffer will not be idle. There are screenplays, children's books, plays, teaching and one-off cartoons for the New York Times, the New Yorker and Rolling Stone.

fields.headline: Tories 'spend public cash on campaigning'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague faces a Commons inquiry into allegations that the Tories are misusing £3.4m of taxpayers' money as the party suffers a funding crisis.
fields.body:
William Hague faces a Commons inquiry into allegations that the Tories are misusing £3.4m of taxpayers' money as the party suffers a funding crisis.

The public administration select committee is to consider a proposal on Tuesday to investigate claims that the Tories are spending much of their £3.4m "Short money", intended for parliamentary purposes, to finance the party's election campaign.

Lord Ashcroft, the Tories' treasurer, could be grilled in public for the first time if the committee agrees to widen an investigation into the role and funding of government special advisers to cover state aid for political parties.

Tory accounts published in March last year disclosed a £13.5m debt with income down to just £8m, leaving the party dependent on Lord Ashcroft, who has given more than £3m, and the taxpayers' support.

Conservative MPs and House of Commons authorities are seeking to block the inquiry, but the committee, chaired by Labour MP Tony Wright, has a Labour majority.

"Short money", introduced 25 years ago by then Labour leader of the Commons, Edward Short, is to allow opposition parties to scrutinise the government. The Liberal Democrats also receive support.

The cash is supposed to be spent on researchers for shadow ministers, opposition whips' office and the leader of the opposition's staff to cover "parliamentary business relating to procedures at the House".

But Michael Ancram, the Tory party chairman, has conceded that a significant proportion is spent on Conservative central office's "war room" to fight the election.

Staff in the war room, modelled on Labour's Millbank operation, have doubled from 30 to 60 though Mr Ancram insists the expenditure is allowed within the rules.

The Commons fees office, however, is reviewing the regulations and Tory auditors PricewaterhouseCoopers contacted Commons authorities some half-a-dozen times to check details before signing off the Conservative accounts.

Labour MP Fraser Kemp, who has been seeking an inquiry, said: "Taxpayers' money should not be used to fund the Conservatives' general election campaign. The rules are quite clear on what it can be spent on, and those rules are being flouted by the Tories."

Details of the row emerged after the Guardian revealed last week that Labour is struggling to raise cash for its election campaign.

Donations from companies to the Conservatives are at a post-war low and in the year ending March 1999 totalled £605,315 - a 76% drop on the previous year.

A trawl of the accounts of 3,000 public and private companies by the union-funded Labour research department found only 38 cash gifts, compared with 100 during the previous 12 months.

Weetabix gave £25,000 against £274,000 the year before, while Haymarket, the publishing group chaired by Michael Heseltine, cut its donation from £50,000 to £1,000.

Yorkshire eurosceptic Paul Sykes has promised to back the Tories, but Mr Hague fears the money will have unacceptable strings attached.

A Tory spokesman said: "We spend the money perfectly properly and in accordance to the rules.

"If they have an inquiry, that is exactly what they will discover."

webTitle: Zimbabwe's south becomes a zone of fear

fields.headline: Zimbabwe's south becomes a zone of fear
fields.standfirst:
Opposition activists kidnapped on eve of weekend election
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: A wave of state-sponsored abductions, beatings and death threats against the opposition Movement for Democratic Change swept through Zimbabwe yesterday, on the eve of parliamentary elections which President Robert Mugabe's ruling party fears it might lose for the first time.
fields.body:
A wave of state-sponsored abductions, beatings and death threats against the opposition Movement for Democratic Change swept through Zimbabwe yesterday, on the eve of parliamentary elections which President Robert Mugabe's ruling party fears it might lose for the first time.

In this brutal drive to terrify the opposition, MDC supporters in the rural south and south-west are missing in Bulawayo and the Mataga area after being kidnapped by Zanu-PF supporters. The polling station in the small town of Mataga was burned down yesterday by militants of the ruling party, apparently to prevent voting in the national poll today and tomorrow.

"Mataga is a 'no-go area'. I don't see how any opposition or observers can get there," said an international observer.

Fourteen MDC supporters had travelled on Thursday to Mataga, about 250 miles (400km) south of Harare. They wanted to register as polling agents and monitors for their party's candidate, Sekai Holland.

As they approached Mataga they were dragged from their van and beaten by Zanu-PF supporters, according to foreign observers in the area.

One MDC supporter got away and is in hospital in the southern city of Zvishavane. The other 13 are missing. They had already been beaten and their homes had been destroyed a few weeks ago.

"The ruling party is free to campaign but we are not," said Lewellin Sibanda earlier this week. Mr Sibanda is believed to be among those missing in Mataga. "We have been beaten and all our property destroyed, but we are determined to work for democracy in Zimbabwe and to support the party of our choice."

In Bulawayo, one MDC activist, Patrick Nabanyama, is missing after being abducted by a Zanu-PF agent on Monday. "We know who abducted him and we have reported the incident to the police," said the MDC's legal secretary, David Coltart. "We are searching for him but we cannot find him. We fear for his safety."

Mr Coltart, an MDC candidate in Bulawayo, said that earlier this week 14 other MDC workers were taken captive, seriously beaten and then held by police. They have now been released. Mr Coltart got a death threat this week and Zanu-PF supporters threatened to firebomb his house.

"They are targeting polling agents particularly in the rural areas because it then makes it easier to rig the elections," he said. "It is obvious the environment for the elections is not free and fair. But in my constituency and in others the intimidation and violence have only served to make people more determined to vote this monstrous regime out."

In the central area of the country, the MDC said its candidate for the city of Masvingo was in a coma last night in a Harare hospital. The party said that Zachariah Rioga was severely beaten by Zanu-PF thugs while campaigning on Thursday.

Thirty-two people, mostly MDC supporters, have died in political violence linked to the elections and the invasions of hundreds of white-owned farms by pro-government militants since February. Mr Mugabe's supporters appear to be responsible for almost all the violence.

"Mugabe is clearly resorting to desperate acts to try to win this election," John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe, said. "Zanu-PF is using everything, every force available, to try to rig the elections.

"Even as we talk Mugabe and his agents are fine-tuning their rigging. The violence is only the most visible aspect, but there is plenty of non-violent rigging going on behind the scenes."

Yesterday the authorities eased their resistance to having the voting extensively watched by foreign diplomatic observers. Election accreditation was issued to about 100 foreign diplomats based in Harare. About 22 US diplomats got clearance to observe the balloting, as well as scores from other embassies.

But British diplomats - their government considered hostile by Mr Mugabe - were refused accreditation.

The diplomats able to monitor the elections will significantly add to the 300 international observers. More than 200 international observers were refused accreditation earlier this week.

In Zimbabwe in the past, voting days have usually been quiet, but Mr Makumbe feared this time things might be different: "Zanu-PF is so desperate that they may resort to violence on polling days."

The days afterwards could be even more dangerous: "If Zanu-PF wins then they may go on the rampage against those who dared to oppose them, as they have done following previous elections. If Zanu-PF loses they may go out and violently protest the results," he said.

He predicted a big MDC victory, perhaps 80 of the 120 parliamentary seats up for election. "If it weren't for the violence and the rigging, I think the MDC would win 100 seats," said Mr Makumbe.

webTitle: Mugabe keeps enemy in his sights

fields.headline: Mugabe keeps enemy in his sights
fields.standfirst:
White farmers get an offer they cannot refuse

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: It takes a special kind of leader to invite the objects of his ire to sit in the front row of the VIP tent at his political rallies. It takes a special kind of victim to agree to such humiliation.
fields.body:
It takes a special kind of leader to invite the objects of his ire to sit in the front row of the VIP tent at his political rallies. It takes a special kind of victim to agree to such humiliation.

Escorted into the stadium here yesterday, almost like prisoners, the 11 white farmers looked as uncomfortable as they were probably intended to feel. When officials of Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF gave them sun-visors emblazoned with the party slogan and they put them on, the absurdity was compounded.

"The Commercial Farmers' Union was invited to attend this rally, and we wanted to support our union," one of the farmers said.

Was it an offer you could not refuse? "You could say that," he replied. Would he give his name? "Not today."

It was a stark illustration of the grotesque chasm that still separates political and economic power in Zimbabwe.

In the stadium, among 10,000 Africans awaiting the arrival of President Mugabe on the last campaigning day before parliamentary elections this weekend, the farmers were pathetic figures of submission. Outside, in the rich cattle and wheatlands surrounding Chinhoyi, they live like emperors in comparison with the men and women they employ.

Plunging into the VIP tent before doing a circuit of the field as the crowds chanted his name, Mr Mugabe carefully avoided shaking the farmers' hands as though he had not seen them.

But in his speech he used their presence with a passion that has not flagged through out the campaign. His theme at every one of the six rallies he has addressed this week is simple: the struggle that brought political independence in 1980 must be completed with economic liberation, ending minority rule over agriculture and white control of Zimbabwe's best land.

Chinhoyi was the site of the first serious exchange of fire in the liberation war in April 1966, when seven Zanu guerrillas died in an encounter with Rhodesian troops supported by helicopter gunships. Never before had armed fighters penetrated so far into the colony, and April 28 has become the official Chimurenga (Freedom Struggle) day.

Mr Mugabe began his speech in Shona, referring to the martyrs, before launching into English. Outwardly defiant, his vigour as he charged round the stadium belied his 76 years.

At least 32 people, mostly opposition supporters, have died in political violence since Mr Mugabe authorised the seizure of scores of white-owned farms. Fourteen of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change's election monitors were reportedly abducted from the Bulawayo area on Thursday night. House burnings and beatings have been widespread.

Mr Mugabe told yesterday's rally he deplored the violence, but jeered at the Movement for Democratic Change. "We call the MDC the Movement for the Destruction of the Country. Of course we know it is going to win on CNN and in the British media but they will never win in this country, as long as they are stooges of the British and defend the interests of white people."

The whoops of appreciation seemed genuine, but who knows whether in everyone who put on the free Zanu-PF T-shirts yesterday will vote for him in the polling booth?

In Chinhoyi most Africans are likely to support Mr Mugabe's party, since the contrast in this part of Zimbabwe between white wealth and majority poverty is stark here. In spite of 20 years of failing to tackle it, Mr Mugabe's trick in this election has been to blame Britain for it.

Even Zanu-PF spokesmen expect the opposition will do well in the urban areas, and some concede it could win there. In the rural areas the vote is more likely to go to Zanu-PF although no independent analyst is willing to hazard a guess. The MDC has been guilty of intimidation, but the bulk of it has come from Zanu-PF campaigners.

Whether the intimidation will backfire no one can be sure. But many people in the country, particularly the middle-aged and elderly, may genuinely prefer Zanu-PF. Rural people are conservative and there is concern, among older people at least, that a Zanu-PF defeat could somehow produce another war. This election is still wide open.

fields.headline: MoD calls in 200,000 rifles
fields.trailText: Two thirds of the 300,000 standard rifles used by British armed forces are to be withdrawn from service in an extensive £80m modification programme, the Ministry of Defence announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Two thirds of the 300,000 standard rifles used by British armed forces are to be withdrawn from service in an extensive £80m modification programme, the Ministry of Defence announced yesterday.

It is the latest twist in a saga which has caused the ministry acute embarrassment. Soldiers have been complaining since the 1991 Gulf war that the ministry-designed SA 80 rifle is prone to jamming

It was also described as "unreliable and insufficiently robust" in a leaked report from British commanders in Kosovo last year.

In 1995, the MoD ordered full-scale tests to be carried out. Heckler & Koch was asked to study the weapon and reported back in 1998. A final report was handed to the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, last December after what the MoD described as comprehensive climatic trials.

The weapons will be stripped in Britain but are likely to be remade by Heckler & Koch's plant in Oberndorf, Germany, which designed the modifications. Changes will be made to the weapon's barrel, bolt head, hammer, firing pin, magazine, springs, and cocking lever.

Heckler & Koch is a subsidiary of Royal Ordnance, which is owned by the British company BAE Systems. The rifle entered service in the mid-1980s when Royal Ordnance was part of the MoD. Critics of the weapon blame the problems partly on the ministry's determination to produce a British-made gun rather than buy foreign models.

Baroness Symons, the defence procurement minister, said that 22,000 of the modified weapons will be delivered by the end of next year.

webTitle: Head quit 'over refusal to ban pupils'

fields.headline: Head quit 'over refusal to ban pupils'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The head of one of the government's flagship fresh start schools resigned because he was prevented from excluding a gang of unruly pupils, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The head of one of the government's flagship fresh start schools resigned because he was prevented from excluding a gang of unruly pupils, it was claimed yesterday.

A regional official for the National Union of Teachers said he believed that Tony Garwood, who unexpectedly resigned from his £70,000 post as head of East Brighton arts and media college in March, had not been supported by the local education authority or the governing body in his attempts to improve discipline.

The claims, which were not denied by Brighton and Hove education authority, were the first which appeared to explain Mr Garwood's decision to resign six months into his job at the newly reopened school.

Yesterday, Dick Boland, an official for the NUT, said: "I have heard the suggestion made that one of the reasons for Tony Garwood's departure was the fact that he wasn't supported in his efforts to exclude pupils by the LEA or the school's governors. There were a number of highly disruptive pupils at the school and their continued presence made things very difficult." It is understood that a core of at least 15 pupils was to blame for regular disruption to lessons and playground activities.

The college was put on emergency "special measures" earlier this month after a critical report from the schools watchdog, the Office for Standards in Education, which said teachers were failing to tackle discipline.

Mr Garwood was unavailable for comment yesterday. But in a lengthy statement, Brighton and Hove LEA said: "Permanently excluding pupils from a school should always be seen as a last resort when other strategies to manage behaviour have failed."

fields.headline: 12-year-old dealt crack and heroin
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old boy caught by police with a packet of sweets in one pocket and £500 worth of heroin, 18 rocks of crack cocaine and £400 in cash in the other while cycling between customers was yesterday ordered to be detained for two years.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old boy caught by police with a packet of sweets in one pocket and £500 worth of heroin, 18 rocks of crack cocaine and £400 in cash in the other while cycling between customers was yesterday ordered to be detained for two years.

The slightly built boy, now 13 and believed to be Britain's youngest convicted crack dealer, cried out for his mother yesterday as he was dragged screaming from the dock of Inner London crown court .

A "horrified and sad" Judge Quentin Campbell said he had no option but to detain the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons.

While he accepted that the boy had not been the prime mover in the drug dealing, and that he had almost certainly been used by older men as a courier, the judge said there was no doubt he was a "perfectly willing participant".

As the door leading to the cells was opened, the boy turned towards his mother and began screaming: "I want to see my mummy, I want my mummy," before kicking out at the officers trying to force him from court. He eventually fell to the floor, still struggling violently, and was carried out.

The boy was arrested after being stopped and searched by four plain clothes policemen in September last year. As they tried to stop him the boy slid off his bike and tried to run away. A further escape attempt followed as officers tried to search him. The drugs and the money were found crammed into his tracksuit pockets.

The boy was handcuffed and led to a nearby police car. More crack cocaine, a small amount of cannabis and a further £1,600 was found shortly afterwards at a friend's flat, which the boy had moved into after a row with his mother.

The judge, who was reduced to tears at an earlier hearing when a jury returned guilty verdicts against the boy for possession of heroin and crack cocaine with intent to supply, warned the boy that had he been an adult he would have been facing five years in jail. He said society had to respond not only to the commission of crime but to its causes.

"One cause of crime is that youngsters are not at school and it does seem a great pity -and I make no further comment as to whether anybody is to blame - that no educational authority took up the fact that you were not effectively going to school at all for quite a long period of time."

The judge said that while he had taken into account various mitigating factors, the seriousness of the case meant "deterrence is paramount" and the boy had to be imprisoned.

"Any sentence that might be looked on as an encouragement to very, very young defendants to deal in drugs or encourages older and unscrupulous dealers to make use of very young persons as a tool in their trade, would cause complete havoc."

After the verdicts the boy's mother, who brought him up alone, said that while she felt "terrible", nothing about her son's behaviour aroused any suspicions and insisted that he had been bullied into acting as a courier for older boys.

fields.headline: Hague embraces Lords reform
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague is poised to outflank Labour on democratic reform by embracing a largely elected second chamber and sweeping changes designed to make the executive fully accountable to parliament.
fields.body:
William Hague is poised to outflank Labour on democratic reform by embracing a largely elected second chamber and sweeping changes designed to make the executive - and specifically the prime minister - fully accountable to parliament.

The Tory leader is preparing in the next fortnight to publish a 25,000-word report prepared for him by a commission headed by the distinguished political scientist Lord Norton.

The report, "Strengthening Parliament", is intended to make the Commons - currently often deserted - the focal point of British political life again.

The Norton commission will recommend:

 stronger select committees free of the control of party whips;

 new powers for the Lords to block the fast-growing use of subsidiary legislation;

 a requirement that the prime minister regularly open set-piece debates;

 television cameras to be given more freedom to film inside parliament and interview MPs inside the Palace of Westminster;

 the prime minister to be required to appear in front of select committees;

 prime minister's questions, which were made weekly by Tony Blair, to revert to a twice-weekly event;

 MPs to be given powers to scrutinise and even block items of departmental spending.

The commission may also propose reform of the finance bill, which implements the Budget, so that scrutiny of technical and political issues is divided.

More draft government bills would be subject to full scrutiny by experts cross-examined by MPs.

The commission is also expected to recommend that select committees be given more resources so they are more closely modelled on US congressional committees.

Committee reports would also be regularly debated in the Commons, forcing the government to give a full response to criticisms expressed by all-party bodies.

Party whips would be banned from controlling membership of committees, giving MPs an alternative to seeking a career as a minister.

Rules to ensure that ministers only made substantial announcements to the Commons, rather than on television or radio, would also be tightened.

In a separate move, the Conservatives are now expected to support a second chamber in which half the members are elected.

Sir George Young, shadow leader of the Commons, said this week that the Tories would support a higher percentage of elected members than the 30% maximum proposed by the Wakeham commission. Conservative MPs expect Mr Hague to increase the figure to 50%.

Labour, fearing undue conflict between the Commons and a democratic upper house, appears to favour only 100 elected members.

Although there will be some cynicism about Mr Hague's plans in view of Lady Thatcher and John Major's treatment of parliament, the Tory leader believes the Commons' scrutiny role can be improved.

Labour sources said it was easy for political parties to promise in opposition to make life difficult for themselves if elected, but then not to act on their promises. The current decline in parliament's importance is partly a function of the government's large majority.

Lord Norton himself said: "The idea is to have a full programme of reform ready which could be implemented right at the start of the parliament. History shows that reform has to be implemented at the start of parliament, or else the impetus falters."

Mr Hague has promised to implement the broad reform package within weeks if he were elected.

webTitle: Chinese jets ground British microlight champion

fields.headline: Chinese jets ground British microlight champion
fields.trailText: A British microlight pilot who braved a broken exhaust over Jordan, red tape in India, and monsoons in Bangladesh, yesterday encountered the most persuasive argument to stop his attempt to fly around the world - a squad of jet fighters over China.
fields.byline: David Hearst  and John Gittings  in Hong Kong
fields.body:
A British microlight pilot who braved a broken exhaust over Jordan, red tape in India, and monsoons in Bangladesh, yesterday encountered the most persuasive argument to stop his attempt to fly around the world - a squad of jet fighters over China.

Blown 100 miles off the authorised track by a storm, world microlight champion Colin Bodill found himself over a military area and surrounded by fighters, who forced him to land by firing flares.

Fellow British pilot Jennifer Murray, who is attempting to fly a helicopter solo around the world, spoke to Mr Bodill by mobile phone as he was surrounded by a crowd of curious peasants in a paddy field 10 miles from Nanning.

She said: "It seems he strayed over a military area. He said he suddenly had fighters all around him and they fired flares to force him down.

"When we spoke to him, there were fighters circling in the air and he was surrounded by hundreds of peasants."

Mrs Murray said he was being detained, but he and the plane were unharmed, though she added: "It's caused a bit of a diplomatic incident."

Mr Bodill, 49, a microlight instructor from Nottingham, was on his way from Hanoi to Hong Kong and had taken off two hours before Mrs Murray. She had sought take-off clearance from the Hanoi control tower but was told it had been denied as the Chinese would not allow her to fly into their airspace.

China has a venerable tradition of frustrating attempts to circumnavigate the globe. In December 1998, Chinese air traffic authorities initially refused permission to Richard Branson's round-the-world balloon trip to alter its route across Chinese airspace.

Permission was given just in time for the flight to continue, but only after extra fuel had been used. After the Branson attempt failed, the Chinese foreign ministry announced it was suspending permission for three other round-the-world balloon teams until further "notification".

Yesterday the Chinese foreign ministry was said to be working with the British embassy in Beijing to obtain the release of Mr Bodill.

The Chinese government last night said two aircraft had been escorting the microlight through the country's airspace, as a courtesy. When the microlight got into difficulty, the aircraft launched flares to help him land at an airfield, but the storm forced him down.

webTitle: French sue Robinson for £3.6m tax bill

fields.headline: French sue Robinson for £3.6m tax bill
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: French tax authorities have obtained a legal order to seize and sell two luxurious Cannes apartments owned by Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, over a claim that he owes them up to £3.6m in unpaid taxes, the Guardian learned last night.
fields.byline: David Hencke in London and  Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
French tax authorities have obtained a legal order to seize and sell two luxurious Cannes apartments owned by Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, over a claim that he owes them up to £3.6m in unpaid taxes, the Guardian learned last night.

The apartments - which were bequeathed to the former Treasury minister by his close business associate, Joska Bourgeois, in her £35m will in 1994 - have been used for holiday visits by the prime minister's wife, Cherie Blair, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and his team of political advisers, including Ed Balls and his former aide Charlie Whelan.

Last night Cannes tax office confirmed that it had taken legal action. A spokesman for the French bailiffs, SCP Nicholas Eric, told the Guardian: "The claim is for unpaid taxes in 1978, 1979 and 1980."

The tax liability was incurred by Bourgeois, but has been inherited by Mr Robinson along with her estate.

The spokesman confirmed that the order had been served under French law and that Mr Robinson's solicitors had been holding urgent talks with the bailiffs over the proposed seizure of the properties. But they and the high court in London refused to comment any further on the case. They said they had passed the dossier on Mr Robinson on to the authorities.

Sources close to the Guardian who have seen the document say it is a judicial order for the sale after seizure of property in Cannes owned by the Labour millionaire, who owns the New Statesman and was once a business partner of the disgraced Mirror Group tycoon Robert Maxwell.

The exact figure requested is said to be 36,228,613 French francs and 40 centimes. Court charges of 1,600 francs (approximately £160) have been added. The French tax authorities applied to a court in Grasse to obtain it.

Last night it was said that court officials were poised to serve it on the ex-minister in England.

The Guardian yesterday tried to contact him at his luxury apartment at the Grosvenor House hotel in Park Lane, London, his large Lutyens mansion at Munstead Heath in Surrey, and in his constituency at Coventry, but he did not return calls.

The disclosure comes after it was revealed that Belgian tax authorities were reportedly seeking some £4.5m of unpaid taxes from the former Labour minister.

The dispute dates back to 1978 when Mr Robinson advised Bourgeois, who was living in Belgium at the time, how to sell her huge Japanese car franchise to the British firm Inchcape, for £15m.

The money was banked in Switzerland and Bourgeois left Belgium with the authorities pursuing her for unpaid tax on the sale. The Belgians were said to be pursuing Mr Robinson under their tax laws because he was reportedly the sole beneficiary of her will.

Last night it was not clear whether the French action was connected to the move by the Belgians, although both disputes cover the same period.

However, Olivier Mesmin, a property tax specialist at Ernst & Young France, said the amount of tax owed by Mr Robinson could be "very considerable", possibly even approaching the value of the Cannes property.

"French tax authorities can order a multimillion franc asset sold to recoup a minimal debt, but in practice that just doesn't happen," he said.

"It is theoretically possible that in this case the amount owing is not huge, and the property is being sold simply because it is the only asset in France - but on balance I would think that unlikely. I think we must be talking about a fairly colossal amount of unpaid tax here."

According to Mr Mesmin, the tax authorities would probably not have confiscated the property merely because of unpaid property taxes, which even on a luxurious apartment in Cannes would be unlikely to exceed £3-4,000 a year.

The apartments involved in the tax dispute are particularly luxurious. They are situated in a prime location, the Avenue Hesperides in Cannes. With an unobstructed view of the bay and a huge terrace, the seventh floor main apartment was worth nearly £1m three years ago.

They were a favourite destination for Bourgeois who died there in 1994. Geoffrey Robinson arranged her funeral in Cannes, after which he learned of his huge inheritance.

Mr Robinson resigned from the government two years ago after the Guardian exposed that he had lent another cabinet minister, Peter Mandelson, £373,000 to buy a house in Notting Hill, west London. Mr Mandelson, who also resigned, subsequently returned to the government.

Mr Robinson was very generous towards his colleagues, allowing Tony Blair's family to stay at his £3m Tuscan villa as well as entertaining Mr Brown and his advisers at his various homes in England and the Cannes apartments on a regular basis.

webTitle: Trimble faces troubles in fight for Antrim

fields.headline: Trimble faces troubles in fight for Antrim
fields.standfirst:
Paisley scents blood as the gruff face of unionism flies home to fly the flag for the No camp in a byelection

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Burnside, the gruff face of Ulster Unionism in London for the past 20 years, is upset. Why, he growls, does everyone insist on summing up his career in PR as the public face of BA's "dirty tricks" campaign against Virgin Airways? Copies of his lengthy CV are despatched at regular intervals to demonstrate his far greater achievement in helping to mastermind the privatisation of British Airways in the early 1980s.
fields.body:
David Burnside, the gruff face of Ulster Unionism in London for the past 20 years, is upset. Why, he growls, does everyone insist on summing up his career in PR as the public face of BA's "dirty tricks" campaign against Virgin Airways? Copies of his lengthy CV are despatched at regular intervals to demonstrate his far greater achievement in helping to mastermind the privatisation of British Airways in the early 1980s.

If Mr Burnside is upset about his image in London as a sour-faced Ulsterman, he has no such qualms about making a similar impression in Northern Ireland, where he has just been selected as the Ulster Unionist candidate in the South Antrim byelection. To the consternation of his old university friend David Trimble, Mr Burnside is returning home to fly the flag of the UUP's No camp in the byelection caused by the death of the veteran MP Clifford Forsythe.

On paper, Mr Burnside, 48, should sweep to victory when the election is held in September. Mr Forsythe's votes in the fiercely Protestant stronghold used to be weighed rather than counted - at the last general election he won with a majority of 16,611, the second highest in the province.

But Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists, who did not contest the seat in 1997 under an anti-nationalist pact, have scented blood and are fielding the Rev Willie McCrea, who was unseated by Sinn Fein as MP for Mid Ulster at the general election. Unionists do not come more hardline than "Singing Billie" McCrea - once dubbed Mr Paisley's "flesh-creeping sidekick" - which means Mr Burnside will face intense pressure to toughen his opposition to Sinn Fein's presence in government.

For the moment at least there is no hope of a reconciliation with Mr Trimble, who suffered a setback when Mr Burnside beat his chief of staff to secure the UUP nomination for South Antrim. Mr Burnside, a supporter of the Good Friday agreement who defied his leader to vote against Sinn Fein's return to government last month, believes that republicans should be kept at a distance as long as the IRA refuses to disarm.

In an interview with the Guardian, he said: "I voted Yes in the referendum on the Good Friday agreement on the basis that anyone linked to a terrorist organisation who threatened violence would be excluded from government. That has not happened and as a party we have lost the high ground by backing away from our 'no guns no government' policy."

Such remarks will go down well with many UUP voters who have threatened to flock to the DUP in protest at Mr Trimble's decision to sit down in government with the former IRA leader Martin McGuinness ahead of disarmament. Mr Burnside will no doubt be hoping in private that he will protect his other flank by winning the support of moderate "middle Ulster" voters who will turn a blind eye to the name on the ballot paper and effectively vote for Mr Trimble.

Divisions

However, Mr Burnside's unashamed criticism of his party leader serves as another powerful reminder of the divisions in unionism which play into the hands of nationalists. Mr Burnside says he is "sick to death with unionist in-fighting" which he promises to fight against.

But he offers no hope of a reconciliation with Mr Trimble, who was close to him from the early days of the troubles right through to the first years of Mr Trimble's leadership in the mid 1990s. "I admire David's many good qualities and if he delivers credible decommissioning and the end of paramilitary organisations I will be happy to say I was a merchant of doom and he took the risk. I fear, however, David will prove to have been wrong."

The split between the two men power fully illustrates how far Mr Trimble has moved to the centre. Both men were leading lights in the hardline Unionist Vanguard movement of the 1970s, a period Mr Trimble prefers to overlook but of which Mr Burnside is still fiercely proud.

Vanguard, a militant group with links to loyalist paramilitaries, helped to bring down the Sunningdale power-sharing agreement of 1974. Nationalists remain deeply suspicious of Vanguard, which had its own legal but questionable security wing, which Mr Burnside defends.

Threatening

"Northern Ireland was close to a real civil war at the time," Mr Burnside said. "The Southern Irish army was threatening to cross the border and groups of people defended their own areas."

After the collapse of Vanguard in the late 1970s, Mr Burnside headed to London, where he launched his successful career in PR. But he never lost interest in Northern Ireland. He spends weekends with his wife, Fiona, at the family farm in Ballymoney, Co Antrim, and he was an important force behind the scenes in rallying Tory opposition to the 1985 Anglo-Irish agreement and the 1995 framework document, which laid the basis for the Good Friday agreement.

Mr Burnside's finest hour, in the eyes of unionists, came in 1995 when he organised the leak of sections of the framework document to the Times, which came close to scuppering the peace process. Tory ministers at the time have never forgiven him, saying his partial leak of "green" sections of a carefully balanced agreement set back unionist opposition to the process.

Mr Burnside remains unrepentant. "I am immensely proud of what I did. The leak cemented the principle of consent into the entire process by ensuring that any agreement had to pass the 'triple lock' of people, parties and parliament."

With such an operator at Westminster, Tony Blair and Mr Trimble would have to be on their guard.

Such remarks will go down well with many UUP voters who have threatened to flock to the DUP in protest at Mr Trimble's decision to sit down in government with the former IRA leader Martin McGuinness ahead of disarmament. Mr Burnside will no doubt be hoping in private that he will protect his other flank by winning the support of moderate "middle Ulster" voters who will turn a blind eye to the name on the ballot paper and effectively vote for Mr Trimble. Mr Burnside says he is "sick to death with unionist in-fighting" which he promises to fight against. But he offers no hope of a reconciliation with Mr Trimble, who was close to him from the early days of the troubles right through to the first years of Mr Trimble's leadership in the mid 1990s. "I admire David's many good qualities and if he delivers credible decommissioning and the end of paramilitary organisations I will be happy to say I was a merchant of doom and he took the risk. I fear, however, David will prove to have been wrong." The split between the two men power fully illustrates how far Mr Trimble has moved to the centre. Both men were leading lights in the hardline Unionist Vanguard movement of the 1970s, a period Mr Trimble prefers to overlook but of which Mr Burnside is still fiercely proud. Vanguard, a militant group with links to loyalist paramilitaries, helped to bring down the Sunningdale power-sharing agreement of 1974. Nationalists remain deeply suspicious of Vanguard, which had its own legal but questionable security wing, which Mr Burnside defends. Threatening "Northern Ireland was close to a real civil war at the time," Mr Burnside said. "The Southern Irish army was threatening to cross the border and groups of people defended their own areas." After the collapse of Vanguard in the late 1970s, Mr Burnside headed to London, where he launched his successful career in PR. But he never lost interest in Northern Ireland. He spends weekends with his wife, Fiona, at the family farm in Ballymoney, Co Antrim, and he was an important force behind the scenes in rallying Tory opposition to the 1985 Anglo-Irish agreement and the 1995 framework document, which laid the basis for the Good Friday agreement. Mr Burnside's finest hour, in the eyes of unionists, came in 1995 when he organised the leak of sections of the framework document to the Times, which came close to scuppering the peace process. Tory ministers at the time have never forgiven him, saying his partial leak of "green" sections of a carefully balanced agreement set back unionist opposition to the process. Mr Burnside remains unrepentant. "I am immensely proud of what I did. The leak cemented the principle of consent into the entire process by ensuring that any agreement had to pass the 'triple lock' of people, parties and parliament." With such an operator at Westminster, Tony Blair and Mr Trimble would have to be on their guard.

webTitle: Seoul sings a new tune as war becomes taboo

fields.headline: Seoul sings a new tune as war becomes taboo
fields.standfirst: Korea: special report
fields.trailText: South Korea prepares to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Korean war tomorrow in subdued tones which would have been inconceivable before the success of last week's North-South summit.
fields.body:
South Korea prepares to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Korean war tomorrow in subdued tones which would have been inconceivable before the success of last week's North-South summit.

Those taking part in the slimmed-down ceremony will sing songs "that aspire to peace and unification", says the Seoul government, rather than the martial Song of the Korean War.

President Kim Dae-jung, fresh from his triumph in Pyongyang, met a group of bemused veterans from the foreign contingents who fought under the UN flag from 1950 to 1953. He thanked them for their contribution to the defence of freedom and democracy and then praised the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, for his "difficult decision" to hold the summit.

Kim Jong-il is the son of the Northern communist leader Kim Il-sung who precipitated the three-year war when his troops crossed the 38th parallel on June 25 1950.

Decades of confrontation along this line seemed forgotten as the South Korean ministry of defence announced that the North Korean army would no longer be referred to as "communist puppets".

South Korea also announced agreement with the North to set up a military hotline to avoid accidental clashes, raising the hope that there could ultimately be a reduction in the huge forces - a million in total - ranged along the 155-mile border.

There has been lively speculation that the two Kims already have a personal hotline. This was sparked by a report that they had discussed the names given to the prize dogs which they presented to each other.

The Korean war, at a conservative estimate, led to the deaths of 1m Chinese and North Korean soldiers, 400,000 soldiers on the South Korean and UN side, and 2m civilians North and South. Yet in this week's post-summit euphoria it has almost become the war which no one wants to mention.

A spokesman for the South Korean president said that they had considered cancelling tomorrow's ceremony but decided not to because of the foreign veterans who had already been invited.

The big event in Seoul is Luciano Pavarotti's appearance on June 30 in a special concert to mark the summit, called "Peace forever, unite as one".

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, who arrived in South Korea on a hastily arranged visit yesterday, has also had to accustom herself to the new view of the North Korean leader.

She told journalists in Beijing that Kim Jong-il appeared to have been "jovial and forthcoming and knowledgeable and different than we had all been led to believe".

The abrupt change of mood has bewildered some older South Koreans, who still see the North as a threat. A report in the Korea Herald said: "A growing number of young people are insisting that the people of North Korea are not the enemy, but brethren with whom the South should join hands."

A new sense of impatience with the American forces in South Korea - until now seen by the majority in their historical role as liberators - has spread among the young.

"They should not behave like a conquering army," a Korean journalist said during the summit. "They are the guests and we are the host."

Protests against a US bombing range on an island near the west coast village of Maehyang-ri have increased. Thousands of demonstrators tried to occupy the island before the US resumed bombing and shooting exercises on Monday.

Meanwhile, North Korea has switched off its cross-border loudspeakers and refrained from anti-South propaganda since the summit was held.

During the summit, Kim Jong-il is said to have turned to a senior North defence official, Jo Myong-rok and instructed him to make sure that there was "no military conflict whatsoever". By contrast to last year's naval clashes over fishing rights, the North allowed a Southern fishing boat which strayed into its waters last week to return home.

webTitle: UFF suspends threat to end ceasefire after peace plea for peace

fields.headline: UFF suspends threat to end ceasefire after peace plea for peace
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The loyalist terror group the Ulster Freedom Fighters yesterday suspended its threat to end its ceasefire and shoot anyone attacking Protestant homes.
fields.body:
The loyalist terror group the Ulster Freedom Fighters yesterday suspended its threat to end its ceasefire and shoot anyone attacking Protestant homes.

In an announcement, the UFF said that while "we state clearly that attacks on Protestant homes cannot be tolerated, we affirm our desire to have this problem resolved peacefully."

Tuesday's surprise statement threatening the ceasefire is thought to have been more of an attempt by the UFF to assert authority in the Protestant areas they control than a genuine attack on the peace process.

Its withdrawal came after appeals from politicians and the organisation's political wing, the Ulster Democratic Party to suspend the threat.

In the past few months the UFF in some areas of Belfast had changed tack and had even provided "security" to prevent clashes between loyalists and nationalists during marches.

But for months there has been tension between loyalist paramilitary groups as each seeks to exert control in certain areas of the city.

Tuesday's threat was seen as a flexing of muscles by the UFF.

Yesterday's statement also said: "The onus is on community leaders to engage seriously to find a resolution to the issue."

John White, chairman of the Ulster Democratic Party, said: "This is a very positive statement and it gives us an opportunity to resolve this issue peacefully."

Throughout the 30 years of the troubles in Northern Ireland there has been sectarian intimidation on both sides.

However, the Northern Ireland housing executive said that all of the 21 complaints of sectarian intimidation in the last months had come from Catholics.

Sinn Fein assemblyman Gerry Kelly claimed that the suspension of the UFF's threat to break the ceasefire proved that "it should never have been made."

Mr Kelly said that "despite this apparent public withdrawal of the threat to kill Catholics, I would urge everyone to remain vigilant." He pointed out that the UFF has suspended, not withdrawn, the threat.

Over the past week the build-up to the traditional Orange marching season has heightened tensions between the two communities.

There is major concern about this weekend's Orange march through the mainly Catholic Springfield Road in west Belfast. Sinn Fein has called on the Parades Commission to ban the march.

webTitle: Why I paid £4 to share a floor with cockroaches

fields.headline: Why I paid £4 to share a floor with cockroaches
fields.trailText: Nobody expects backpacking to be comfortable. In fact, the lack of comfort is part of its allure.
fields.body:
Nobody expects backpacking to be comfortable. In fact, the lack of comfort is part of its allure.

Backpackers in Australia travel the huge, spectacular country by bus, or in an old banger; they pick fruit to make enough money to keep going; and they are content to grab a few hours' sleep wherever there is enough space to roll out a sleeping bag. This life is a far cry from school, university or the office. It is easy to romanticise it.

In a sense, the fire at Childers was a tragedy waiting to happen. During my round-the-world trip, the dodgiest accommodation I stayed in all year was in Australia.

In Asia, money goes further, and, outside the major cities, it is easy to afford a hotel room at a price which, in a developed country, would barely get you a bunk in an 18-bed dormitory.

Every backpacker in Australia swiftly gets used to sharing a room with strangers. My most unsettling moment came when, on getting into bed, I discovered that a European roommate had put his trousers to bed between my sheets.

Many hostels are clean and well tended. Some are not. Some do not bother maintaining smoke alarms, and block their fire escapes.

Many lock all the doors to the outside world at night because they are wary of non-paying guests nipping in to share their friends' dorms. Windows are often barred. The buildings are often wooden.

Owners like to pack in as many people as possible, particularly when they are oversubscribed during the fruit-picking season.

Once I phoned a hostel to book a bed. "Haven't got any left," the proprietor explained cheerfully, "but come along anyway - we'll get you a mattress." I paid £4 to sleep on the kitchen floor. It was just me and the cockroaches.

A friend of mine, Toby, stayed in Childers last year. He is horrified by the tragedy. "There's no reason to go there except for the fruit picking," he says. "Hostels in those places can be cheap and nasty. They cram in as many people as they can.

"We didn't like the look of the Palace hostel, so we stayed in the campsite. It looked like a rough old dive."

Until now, I'd thought back to the uncomfortable antipodean nights with the fondness of hindsight. The experience, I thought, was character-forming, and I wouldn't be doing it again. For me, and for Toby, and for countless others like us, backpacking was a fantastic experience of freedom that broadened our horizons and added to our confidence.

For those caught in the fire, and their families, it has become something grotesquely different.

 Emily Barr's book, Backpack, will be published by Headline early next year

fields.headline: Arson suspected in hostel blaze
fields.standfirst: Queensland police wait to enter burnt-out building to recover bodies of backpackers trapped on second floor
fields.trailText: The sound of glass shattering from the heat was the first sign of the ferocity of the inferno that engulfed the Palace backpackers hostel as its residents slept. Within minutes, the flames swept through the 94-year-old wooden building, reaching up to 40ft to illuminate the night sky over the small town of Childers, Queensland.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd  and  Christopher Zinn  in Sydney
fields.body:
The sound of glass shattering from the heat was the first sign of the ferocity of the inferno that engulfed the Palace backpackers hostel as its residents slept. Within minutes, the flames swept through the 94-year-old wooden building, reaching up to 40ft to illuminate the night sky over the small town of Childers, Queensland.

Of the 15 people who are missing or dead, 10 are believed to be from the UK. Embassy officials from Spain, Holland, Korea, New Zealand, Israel and Canada were last night waiting to hear if their citizens were among those killed.

The dangerous state of the burnt-out hostel, built in 1906 to replace a pub burnt down in a blaze that destroyed much of Childers, meant the bodies lying mainly on the second storey could not be recovered or even counted. Miraculously, 69 people survived, including an estimated 20 Britons.

"I heard a tremendous sound of cracking glass - it sounded like somebody was trying to break into the place - and I screamed at the four other girls in my dorm," Emma, a Briton, told Australian radio. "One of the girls woke up and screamed fire, another tried to open the door but her hand got burnt. We ran out on to the veranda... [and] escaped on to the roof of the shop next door. The other people that were getting out were starting to scream."

From around the world backpackers stop in Childers on the Queensland coast to earn money picking vegetables. The work helps to fund their trips around Australia in search of adventure and self-discovery. When the fire broke out, at 12.30am yesterday, 84 mainly young people were asleep in the hostel. They were to rise at six to be bussed to fields full of tomatoes, courgettes and snow peas.

Revenge threat

Police, forensic experts and arson investigators are now waiting to enter the shell of the hostel to start investigating the fire's cause, amid intense local speculation that it was started by a former resident. Some survivors said a man thrown out of the hostel a week ago had threatened to take revenge.

Police said they were treating the fire as "suspicious", but could not comment on whether they were hunting for a suspect.

One survivor, Keith O'Brien, from Wigan, had been in Childers for a month and had just celebrated his 22nd birthday. He said his escape from the burning building had been hampered by bars on some windows which he squeezed through, after kicking down a door and taking a British woman to safety.

"All you could hear was the fire and things crackling; the floorboards, walls, paint - it was just crazy," he said. "I dragged a Welsh girl out of bed, picked her up and walked out. You couldn't see your hand in front of your face.

"I went to the window which had bars on it, horizontal and vertical, pretty much we were trapped. But there was a gap about a foot and a half by a foot. I picked her up, put her through the window. I tried to squeeze through the window and the boys [firefighters) pulled me through."

Across Britain, anxious parents waited yesterday for phone calls telling them their children were safe. The growth in the number of young people undertaking long-haul trips has been marked, and last year more than one in four of the backpackers visiting Australia was a Briton.

Kelly Symonds, 23, who called her mother Dianne in Aberfan, south Wales, had been staying at the hostel with two friends with whom she was taking a round-the-world trip. She told her mother she feared her friends were dead.

Another survivor, who declined to be named, told how he had stumbled through a smoke-filled corridor with his arms out to feel his way. He was greeted by the arms of other terrified residents as they reached out in search of safety.

"There were people banging on doors who couldn't get out and smashing doors," said one Dutch woman.

Louise Brewster, 19, from Hertfordshire, said she feared that at least two of her friends had died in the blaze. "I worked with them both yesterday, so it's such a shock," said Ms Brewster, who was camping near the hostel. "We were all supposed to go on to the Great Barrier Reef from here, but I don't think any of us will bother now."

Joey Woods lives 50ft from the hostel. She was the first to ring the fire brigade after being woken up by the shattering glass. "I thought someone was breaking into a shop and smashing it up," she said.

"I saw a glow from the hostel from one window. Within 90 seconds it was all going up. People were climbing down fire exits and the veranda. I could hear people inside calling out for help and a lot of banging on walls and banging as if they were trying to break down doors."

Her husband Martin had known the Australian backpacker alleged to have threatened the hostel after a row with its management. "He told two women to tell to other people at the hostel to sleep next to open windows and the fire escape," Mr Woods said.

Jock Gardner, who ran the Palace until 15 months ago, also strongly suspects arson. He said the wiring had been renewed in 1993 and that the kitchen, the most obvious starting point for an accidental fire, would have been locked at 9pm.

Last year he sold his lease to two young Australians, John Dobe and Christian Atkinson, both former geologists who had fancied a change of lifestyle and were last night said to be shocked by the disaster.

The hostel was subjected to tough fire safety checks, experts say. Jeff Wright, the fire commissioner, said the building had been equipped with smoke detectors.

Those who survived the blaze were offered clothing and food by townspeople. The stench of burning hung over Childers as trauma counsellors were drafted in.

The community of 3,000 last night held a barbecue for backpackers, farm workers and residents. At a memorial service at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic church, many linked arms as they sang the hymn Bind us Together. Local authorities were housing the survivors at two motels away from the large media contingent, giving them access to internet facilities to contact relatives.

The town's mayor, Bill Trevor, said the travellers had been a welcome part of the community, replacing the local young generation who had left town in search of jobs and to study. "It's traumatic," he said. "The survivors, and there's 69 been identified, are looking around to see which of their mates are unaccounted for."

A quarter of the backpackers who visited Australia last year were from the UK, the country's tourist commission said yesterday

Last year 102,700 young travellers from Britain visited out of more than 404,000 in total, it said. This was more than from any other country

The British backpackers stay for an average of 73 nights and spend £177.3m, compared with the 32,800 Germans who visit for 43 nights and spend £45.9m

The number of working holiday visas granted by Australia has increased from around 35,000 in 1994-95 to almost 65,000 in 1998-99. More than 34,000 of the visas granted in 1998-99 were to people from the UK. In 1999-2000 around 78,000 are expected to be granted

79% of backpackers visit Sydney, 48% Melbourne and 42% Brisbane. Half go to north Queensland and 38% to the Northern Territory

The town's mayor, Bill Trevor, said the travellers had been a welcome part of the community, replacing the local young generation who had left town in search of jobs and to study. "It's traumatic," he said. "The survivors, and there's 69 been identified, are looking around to see which of their mates are unaccounted for." A quarter of the backpackers who visited Australia last year were from the UK, the country's tourist commission said yesterday Last year 102,700 young travellers from Britain visited out of more than 404,000 in total, it said. This was more than from any other country The British backpackers stay for an average of 73 nights and spend £177.3m, compared with the 32,800 Germans who visit for 43 nights and spend £45.9m The number of working holiday visas granted by Australia has increased from around 35,000 in 1994-95 to almost 65,000 in 1998-99. More than 34,000 of the visas granted in 1998-99 were to people from the UK. In 1999-2000 around 78,000 are expected to be granted 79% of backpackers visit Sydney, 48% Melbourne and 42% Brisbane. Half go to north Queensland and 38% to the Northern Territory
