webTitle: Big advances are often pure fiction

fields.headline: Big advances are often pure fiction
fields.standfirst:
It's all a plot to get free publicity for new writers. Ask the bus driver

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: There's a cruelly amusing scene in Martin Amis's novel, The Information, in which a novelist is forced by a wife disgruntled at his long absences in the study to divide the money he earns from each book by the time it takes to write one. It turns out that the author's hourly rate is substantially less than that of the woman the couple pay to dust the bookshelves.
fields.body:
There's a cruelly amusing scene in Martin Amis's novel, The Information, in which a novelist is forced by a wife disgruntled at his long absences in the study to divide the money he earns from each book by the time it takes to write one. It turns out that the author's hourly rate is substantially less than that of the woman the couple pay to dust the bookshelves.

As The Information was the novel for which Amis was reported to have received a £500,000 advance, the artistic maths seems unlikely to have been autobiographical. But a Society of Authors report this week establishes that it was accurately biographical for most other writers in Britain. The survey found that just over 10% of those who write books were able to live on their income from publishing, while almost half earned less than the national minimum wage. You live better with toilet cleaner on your fingers than with ink.

Given that the dream of full-time writing remains the cultural equivalent of winning the lottery - and that the news pages most weeks contain another man or woman supposedly made a Rockefeller by selling their novel - these statistics will have created the kind of chill usually only achieved by the last few pages of a Stephen King thriller. Why is book-writing so bad for book-keeping?

One answer is that the potential rewards of literature are frequently a journalistic fiction. Magnus Mills - always called "the bus driver" - is still widely reported to have earned a million-pound advance for his first novel, The Restraint Of Beasts. In fact, he later admitted that the true sum was around £10,000. Mills invented the seven-figure payment in collusion with a Sunday journalist whose news desk's favourite arts piece was the literary lottery one.

Although there is some big-cheque fiction, this deceit about fees is surprisingly common. The publicist inflates the advance in order to make the book news. Because the dream of every journalist is to escape with a vast book advance, news editors are liable to be encouraged by the suggestion that publishing a novel is a kind of legal bank robbery. And so, while most authors take the bus to deliver their manuscripts, newspaper readers are learning of a world in which every wry and bleak bildungsroman is a down-payment on a yacht.

Financial reality means that most writers need secondary employment. This week's report encourages us to read this statistic as a tragedy. But, in fact, it can be seen as a happy ending. Interviews with authors suggest that few are able to write for more than three hours a day. The great dilemma for the writer is what to do in the afternoon. Many of the great Americans drank. Jeffrey Archer ran for London mayor. Taking a paid job might be a healthier option.

Anthony Trollope's long hours in the post office never hindered his ambitions as a man of letters. Two of the greatest poets of the 20th century - Philip Larkin and TS Eliot - were salaried employees throughout their writing careers, in a library and a bank and publishing house respectively. Admittedly the time spent at a desk for a poem (even a great poem) is substantially less than the long nights and typing called for by a novel, but there is still compelling evidence that a writer's second life gives books a richer life.

The most reliable literary prize-winners of recent times - Seamus Heaney and JM Coetzee - were teaching in universities throughout the composition of their most acclaimed works. It's true that the university system - especially in America - is set up to subsidise the work of serious creative writers. The college gets prestige; the novelist gets an office and a light teaching schedule. Yet it's hard to argue that the works of these part-time authors are worse for this interaction with others.

The dream of the full-time author - never needing to leave the house except to fly to Stockholm to collect the Nobel - may in fact be inimical to creativity. A surprising number of those few writers who could live like royalty on their royalties soon seem to try movie scripts or seek journalistic commissions in search of the experience of offices and people.

It's also wrong to assume that the minimum-wage literati revealed by the Society of Authors report are all failures. Many of them may be poor because they're bad, but poverty in an artist can also result from radicalism, risk, perfectionism or unseen achievement.

Serious culture has usually had to be subsidised. The state attends to opera and theatre; the licence fee to television. There should be no shame if literature is being underwritten by universities, newspapers or indeed supermarkets and banks.

What the novelist's wife in Amis's The Information didn't understand was that he wrote his books not for the payment per page, but because he was driven to do it - it was how he felt most alive. The truth is that the cleaning lady who out-earned him was probably writing a novel at home for far less than her per diem. Living through writing does not only mean earning money from it.

webTitle: Fiji agreement should free hostages within days

fields.headline: Fiji agreement should free hostages within days
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Fiji's military rulers and the gunmen holding 31 members of the former government hostage reached a deal yesterday by which the captives should be released within days.
fields.body:
Fiji's military rulers and the gunmen holding 31 members of the former government hostage reached a deal yesterday by which the captives should be released within days.

A rebel spokesman and an official involved in the negotiations said the two sides had agreed to the terms under which Fiji's next government would be formed - the final hurdle to the release of the hostages.

Joe Brown, a government official involved in the negotiations, said the military commander, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, and the rebel leader, George Speight, would sign an accord today which would finally end the 36-day hostage crisis.

The rebels' spokesman, Jo Nata, confirmed that an agreement had been reached.

Mr Speight, the businessman who led an armed raid on parliament on May 19 and took the prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and his government hostage, held talks with the military authorities for the sixth day running yesterday.

The military assumed executive power and imposed martial law 10 days after Mr Speight and his gang stormed parliament.

This week's talks were aimed at sorting out details of an interim civilian government which will presumably lead Fiji to new elections within two years.

Both sides said the sticking points were the make-up of the government and the scope of the amnesty to be given to Mr Speight and his men.

It was not immediately clear when the hostages will be released, but it is expected to be soon after the accord is signed. Neither Mr Brown nor Mr Nata gave any details of the agreement.

Mr Speight's main demands - that the 1997 multi-racial constitution should be thrown out and Mr Chaudhry, Fiji's first prime minister of Indian descent, fired - had already been met.

The stand-off has set Fiji's poor indigenous majority against its relatively affluent Indian minority, and spurred accusations in the international community that the once-idyllic island state had descended into racist strife and intolerance.

Because of the country's break with democracy, Australia, New Zealand and the US have threatened economic sanctions. And the refusal of Australian trade unions to handle cargo to and from Fiji has paralysed much of the country's exports.

The New Zealand foreign minister, Phil Goff, said that his country and Australia, or the EU alone, could cripple Fiji's economy with the stroke of a pen by imposing sanctions. The EU spends about £40m a year on Fijian sugar, paying up to three times the world market price under a preferential trade agreement.

"No country in their right mind would invest in another country that looks like a banana republic, and that's exactly what Fiji looks like," Mr Goff said.

Meanwhile many of the Indo-Fijians, who make up about 44% of the population of 812,000, say they want to leave because of Mr Speight's coup, which was accompanied by widespread attacks on them.

"We Indians are not secure in Fiji," Shakeel Tobrez, 17, said outside a mosque during sabbath prayers yesterday.

"It's cancerous, this ethnic violence, this ethnic cleansing," said Mohamed Rafiq, 60, a businessman. He called on Australia to open its doors to Indo-Fijians seeking refuge.

Mr Speight has repeatedly said that he staged the coup in the name of the indigenous majority, whose rights, he said, were trampled upon by Mr Chaudhry.

During his one-year tenure, Mr Chaudhry came under fire for his arrogant style and for allegedly favouring Indian sugar-cane farmers over the indigenous Fijians who own the land on which the crop is grown.

Mr Speight allowed journalists from the Fiji Times to see the hostages from a distance on Thursday.

The paper described Mr Chaudhry as looking "haggard and dejected".

webTitle: Slumping Gore hit by inquiry body-blow

fields.headline: Slumping Gore hit by inquiry body-blow
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore's bid to win the presidency was in dire trouble yesterday after confirmation that a senior US justice department official had recommended an independent inquiry into whether he misled investigators over his campaign fundraising efforts in 1996.
fields.body:
Al Gore's bid to win the presidency was in dire trouble yesterday after confirmation that a senior US justice department official had recommended an independent inquiry into whether he misled investigators over his campaign fundraising efforts in 1996.

Even before news of a possible new investigation leaked, the vice-president had been struggling to reinvigorate his campaign against the Republican contender, George W Bush. Yesterday's Los Angeles Times gave Mr Bush a 10-point lead over his rival, a slight increase on last month.

An investigation into whether Mr Gore broke electoral rules while fundraising for the 1996 election would be a heavy burden to carry into the last few months of the presidential campaign. It would lend substantial weight to Mr Bush's strategy of portraying his opponent as fatally tainted by the scandals which have enveloped the Clinton White House.

The decision about whether to appoint an independent investigator, a "special counsel", is now on the desk of the attorney-general, Janet Reno. She has overruled two previous recommendations for an investigation of Mr Gore.

At a press conference yesterday, Ms Reno, who was reported to be furious at the leak of news about a potential fresh inquiry, insisted that she would not be rushed into making a decision.

The recommendation to appoint a special counsel came from Robert Conrad, the head of a justice department task force which has been looking into the 1996 fundraising.

Mr Gore had long been under scrutiny for a visit he made to a Buddhist monastery where campaign contributions were solicited in contravention of federal rules banning fundraising at religious sites. Mr Gore has claimed he did not know the event was a fundraiser.

He had also been investigated for 45 fundraising telephone calls made from his office, and for about 100 coffee meetings at the White House arranged for top campaign contributors. A 19th century civil service law prevents the use of government offices to raise federally-regulated campaign funds.

According to reports yesterday, Mr Conrad's decision was influenced by interviews with Mr Gore, including a four-hour interrogation at the vice-presidential residence on April 18.

The interview appears to have provoked angry reactions from Mr Gore. "It was sure as hell a different approach. It was real confrontational and put him on the spot," said one unnamed official quoted in the New York Times.

Justice department investigators are reportedly dissatisfied with Mr Gore's claims that he was unaware of the distinctions between the sort of fundraising that was permissible from White House telephones. He had claimed in a 1998 interview with FBI agents that he drank a lot of iced tea at staff meetings and might therefore have gone to the toilet when the matter was discussed.

One source quoted in the New York Times said that investigators were "punching holes in the iced tea defence". Another official said the FBI "are really pushing the perjury stuff, because they are convinced he lied to them".

Mr Gore was campaigning in Minnesota when news of the justice department recommendation emerged, and appeared to have been taken by surprise. His aides claimed that the information had been leaked for political purposes and insisted that Mr Gore had fully cooperated with the fundraising inquiry.

Ms Reno could once more turn down the call for an independent inquiry, but such a decision would provoke damaging Republican claims of a cover-up.

Meanwhile, Mr Gore's aides are concerned about the emergence of Ralph Nader as a serious election concern on the left. He is expected to win the Green party nomination, and although his support remains in single-digit figures, he appeals to core Democrats, particularly environmentalists and union members who are unhappy with Mr Clinton's trade deal with China.

Mr Gore has been on a nationwide "prosperity tour" aimed at capitalising on the healthy state of the economy and presenting his ideas on bolstering social security and government-sponsored health care programmes.

But even before news emerged of a possible special counsel investigation, he was still trailing several points behind Mr Bush, especially among men and married couples, for whom the vice- president appears to carry the moral taint of his close friendship with Bill Clinton.

Republican posters have focused on that perceived weakness, showing the two men locked in a warm embrace.

webTitle: Festival weekend is child's play for Emily

fields.headline: Festival weekend is child's play for Emily
fields.standfirst:
Glastonbury 2000: special report

Quiz: Find yourself at the festival
fields.trailText: There cannot be many little girls who grow up with a world renowned rock festival at the bottom of their garden.
fields.body:
There cannot be many little girls who grow up with a world renowned rock festival at the bottom of their garden.

For Emily Eavis, the daughter of the Glastonbury festival host Michael, it seemed quite normal to be into Bob Dylan and Elvis Costello when all her classmates liked Bros. Now the 20-year-old is being touted as the heir to her father's creation.

As the three-day smorgasbord of music got under way at Worthy Farm, in Somerset yesterday, Emily recalled how she became one of the festival's youngest performers.

"I was five and I remember playing Twinkle Twinkle Little Star on the violin in the house. Then next minute, mum said I should play on the stage.

"I think it was more so that my mum and dad could laugh at me. I really was not aware of what was happening and before I knew it I had played it four times."

She went on: "I was quite scared of the festival when I was little. My whole house would be invaded by this entourage of people. Then, when I was about 12, I started really enjoying it.

"At school I was into Elvis Costello and Bob Dylan and everyone else was into Bros.

"However, one year Shakespear's Sister came and that was my big moment at school when I told everyone: 'Shakespear's Sister are coming and you like them don't you?'."

Emily, who left school three years ago, is still reluctant to shoulder the enormous responsibility for the festival, for which 100,000 revellers arrived yesterday.

She said: "Every year I am being taught more. My dad wants to know that if needed I could do it. It's a huge responsibility. I don't know whether I want to take the reins, and my dad feels like it's his little baby, so I don't think he could bear letting go of it."

She does however get stuck into the organisation, including every music fan's dream of helping to pick bands to play the festival. There are even amicable rows with her father over who will best suit the Glastonbury vibe.

"I remember last year it was the Corrs. My dad said 'Come on Emily, we've got to take a bit of a risk' and they went down quite well. He was like: 'That's mine'.

"I pushed him into booking Robbie Williams. Dad was saying no to that, but he went down really well."

Last minute changes to the line-up this year include a cancellation from the veteran easy listening star Burt Bacharach, due to a persistent shoulder problem following a broken collarbone.

The soul diva Macy Gray was yesterday confirmed as this year's surprise Glastonbury guest and was due to take the main stage last night.

Mr Eavis himself emerges from behind the scenes this year to perform for the first time. The normally shy farmer, who is the son and grandson of Methodist preachers, will be singing a hymn, accompanied by Jools Holland on piano.

Mr Eavis yesterday helped to launch one of the festival's many worthy causes, the Drop the Debt campaign.

It is hoped that stars including Sunday's headline act David Bowie and Macy Gray will agree to send an email to world leaders asking them to cancel the developing world's debt burden by logging on to www.dropthedebt.org

Meanwhile, the threat that this year would be another washout lifted overnight as drizzle was replaced by warm sunshine. Hippies in saffron robes mingled with pale skinned students and tattooed lads who would look more at home on a football terrace.

Glastonbury's police presence again managed to keep a low profile but announced a victory over tent thieves when a man was caught sneaking into one of their "undercover" canvasses.

These tents bristle with monitoring equipment, and the man's would-be crime led to a swift encounter with Avon and Somerset officers.

A force spokeswoman said: "He was found in possession of a large quantity of drugs and at the moment he's not enjoying himself very much, sitting in our police custody suite at Glastonbury."

Today's Glastonbury highlights include Ocean Colour Scene, The Pet Shop Boys, Travis, Elastica, Death in Vegas, Leftfield, Femi Kuti and Positive Force, Morcheeba, Artful Dodger, Bentley Rhythm Ace and Fat Boy Slim.

Sunday's acts include The Happy Mondays, Embrace, David Bowie, Muse, Beta Band, Basement Jaxx, Faze Action, Gil Scott-Heron, Ozomatli, Kelis, DJ Krush, EZ Rollers, Mickey Finn and Aphrodite and MC Fearless.

It is hoped that stars including Sunday's headline act David Bowie and Macy Gray will agree to send an email to world leaders asking them to cancel the developing world's debt burden by logging on to www.dropthedebt.org Meanwhile, the threat that this year would be another washout lifted overnight as drizzle was replaced by warm sunshine. Hippies in saffron robes mingled with pale skinned students and tattooed lads who would look more at home on a football terrace. Glastonbury's police presence again managed to keep a low profile but announced a victory over tent thieves when a man was caught sneaking into one of their "undercover" canvasses. These tents bristle with monitoring equipment, and the man's would-be crime led to a swift encounter with Avon and Somerset officers. A force spokeswoman said: "He was found in possession of a large quantity of drugs and at the moment he's not enjoying himself very much, sitting in our police custody suite at Glastonbury." Today's Glastonbury highlights include Ocean Colour Scene, The Pet Shop Boys, Travis, Elastica, Death in Vegas, Leftfield, Femi Kuti and Positive Force, Morcheeba, Artful Dodger, Bentley Rhythm Ace and Fat Boy Slim. Sunday's acts include The Happy Mondays, Embrace, David Bowie, Muse, Beta Band, Basement Jaxx, Faze Action, Gil Scott-Heron, Ozomatli, Kelis, DJ Krush, EZ Rollers, Mickey Finn and Aphrodite and MC Fearless.

fields.headline: Officers cleared as judge attacks 'errors'
fields.trailText: Two detective colleagues of Superintendent Ray Mallon were yesterday cleared of petty theft by a judge who criticised senior officers of Cleveland police for "a catalogue of errors".
fields.body:
Two detective colleagues of Superintendent Ray Mallon were yesterday cleared of petty theft by a judge who criticised senior officers of Cleveland police for "a catalogue of errors".

The fresh embarrassment for the force, following the collapse of a two-and-a-half year inquiry into alleged corruption in Mr Mallon's Middlesbrough CID unit earlier this week, raised further questions about the handling of bitter divisions between officers.

Mr Justice Henriques singled out for criticism a former leading figure in the Mallon inquiry, Chief Supt Kevin Pitt, for submitting an "unsolicited" 94-page statement with 300 pages of appendices only a few days before the trial had been due to start.

The judge said: "His decision to commit his thoughts to a witness statement has resulted in both public expense and judicial delay."

Det Insp Russ Daglish and Det Con Brendon Whitehead, who both worked closely with Mr Mallon, had been accused of stealing a £20 central heating boiler from a store of crime-related property at Middlesbrough police station.

They remain suspended from duty and subject to disciplinary procedures, which the judge said should take place "as soon as possible".

The collapse of the case followed three days of legal argument at Hull crown court, and also comes three days after the £5m inquiry, known as Operation Lancet, cleared Mr Mallon and seven other officers of wrongdoing. Staying the proceedings, due to abuse of judicial process, Judge Henriques said: "It has become increasingly clear that a fair trial would be impossible."

He criticised the mistakes by Cleveland police and added that the huge publicity over Mr Mallon would have made the case untenable.

Mr Pitt said that his statement had been made after legal advice, following claims at a pre-trial hearing by another Cleveland superintendent, Dick Mead, who headed the inquiry into the alleged boiler theft.

Mr Mead told the hearing that he felt there had been a "campaign" to undermine his inquiries and to protect the interests of Operation Lancet.

A spokesman for Cleveland police said: "We will be reviewing what the judge has had to say and the reasons for it. We cannot comment further because there are separate disciplinary matters to be dealt with."

webTitle: Lammy is new baby of house

fields.headline: Lammy is new baby of house
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: David Lammy, the 27-year-old victor in the Tottenham byelection, yesterday became the youngest MP, taking the unofficial title of baby of the house from Christopher Leslie, his senior by three weeks.
fields.body:
David Lammy, the 27-year-old victor in the Tottenham byelection, yesterday became the youngest MP, taking the unofficial title of baby of the house from Christopher Leslie, his senior by three weeks.

Mr Lammy, a barrister, will take his seat next week. He takes over from Bernie Grant, the leftwing MP whose sudden death triggered the contest.

Labour will be relieved that it won more than half the vote, even if the low turnout will concern all parties. Mr Lammy took 53% of the vote, suffering a 12% swing away from Labour to the Liberal Democrats, who snatched second position from the Conservatives.

Only one in four voters bothered to go to the polls, but Labour pointed out that Tottenham traditionally is not given to high turnouts. Cherie Blair was brought in to campaign, to increase interest.

The Liberal Democrat candidate, Duncan Hames, 22, said: "We've nearly doubled our share of the vote and shown Liberal Democrats are the clear alternative to Labour in the heartland cities of this country."

The Conservatives never had high expectations for the seat, although they may be concerned that Mr Hague's recent tough line on asylum and crime did not persuade working class white Londoners to swing behind him.

Polling by the Conservatives shows the Tories doing well in starting to pick up C2 and D voters; traditionally the bedrock of Lady Thatcher's popular success.

Mr Lammy, from a low income, single parent family, said he knew what it was like to grow up disadvantaged in Tottenham and he pledged to work towards improving his constituency's employment, schools and housing.

He said: "The heartlands of Tottenham are safe in the hands of New Labour."

Mr Grant first won the seat by 4,000 votes in 1987, but by 1997 his personal popularity had increased his majority to 20,200, making the seat one of Labour's safest. The increase in the Labour majority also reflected demographic changes.

webTitle: MPs tell Straw not to force Kosovans home

fields.headline: MPs tell Straw not to force Kosovans home
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: An all-party group of MPs has warned the home secretary, Jack Straw, not to press ahead with the forced return of Kosovans who fled to Britain when the deadline for them to leave expires tomorrow night.
fields.body:
An all-party group of MPs has warned the home secretary, Jack Straw, not to press ahead with the forced return of Kosovans who fled to Britain when the deadline for them to leave expires tomorrow night.

After the last official voluntary return flight to Kosovo left Leeds yesterday, 2,396 of the 4,500 refugees who came to Britain as part of the United Nations humanitarian evacuation programme had gone home.

Home office figures show that a further 1,932 have either applied to be given exceptional leave to remain in Britain on humanitarian grounds or have lodged a formal application for asylum. Those who are refused face deportation if they do not leave voluntarily. Only about 20 have yet to declare their intentions and face possible expulsion if they remain in Britain beyond Sunday. Nearly half of those still in Britain are either under 18 or over 60.

Last night the Labour MP Neil Gerrard, chairman of the all-party group on refugees, who has just returned from a refugee council delegation to Kosovo, called upon Mr Straw not to act upon his promise to take enforcement action against those who are unwilling to go back voluntarily.

He particularly did not want to see Britain going down the road of Germany and Australia, which have deported thousands of Kosovans by handcuffing them, moving them to detention centres and flying them to Pristina, where they were left at the airport.

Mr Gerrard said: "The UK has a continuing duty and a particular obligation to those picked out as the most vulnerable and evacuated here during the conflict. We should stick to the fundamental principle underlying international law that people returning home should do so in dignity and safety. It is quite clear that if vulnerable people are sent back now, the current structures will not be able to support them."

The all-party group of MPs, including Sir Peter Lloyd, the former Conservative immigration minister, and Simon Hughes, of the Liberal Democrats, said the situation of some of the families they had met in Kosovo who had been in Britain was unsustainable and raised concerns about their ability to survive the next few months.

One elderly couple had spent the first two months back in Kosovo living in a tent beside their damaged house while it was rebuilt by their son.

The MPs' report shares the view of the UN high commissioner for refugees that conditions in Kovoso are such that most families can return in safety. But they add that all the relief agencies working in the area are concerned that the process of rebuilding the province is fragile and large-scale uncoordinated returns will be damaging and counter-productive.

The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, said that it had been made clear at the time the Kosovan evacuees had come that it was only for 12 months and they would be expected to return as soon as it was safe.

A Home Office spokeswoman said she did not anticipate that enforcement action would start after tomorrow. Those who had not yet left would be given the opportunity to go voluntarily although they would not be eligible for a £400 repatriation grant.

Britain mounted a programme of "prepare and return" flights for Kosovans in Britain so they could see the exact condition of their homes and villages before they went home.

webTitle: GMC 'failed GP and dead boy's father'

fields.headline: GMC 'failed GP and dead boy's father'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The General Medical Council was guilty of "serious and disturbing failures" in not following correct procedures before rejecting a misconduct complaint made against a GP by the father of a dead child, a high court judge said yesterday.
fields.body:
The General Medical Council was guilty of "serious and disturbing failures" in not following correct procedures before rejecting a misconduct complaint made against a GP by the father of a dead child, a high court judge said yesterday.

Both the GP, David Jarman, and the father, Arpad Toth, were victims of those failures, said Mr Justice Lightman in ordering a reconsideration of the complaint. The GMC had agreed to reopen the case because of admitted procedural errors, but Dr Jarman, who is still practising, argued such a course would be unfair to him.

The judge ruled that the stress and consequent ill-health suffered by the doctor because of what had happened, and the fact that his reputation continued to be under a cloud, were outweighed by the legitimate interest of Mr Toth and the public in securing an investigation according to the rules.

Mr Toth's son, Wilfred, 5, who suffered from glycogen storage disease, went into a hypoglycaemic seizure on October 9, 1993, at his home in Wallingford, Oxfordshire. Mr Toth called Dr Jarman. He claimed Dr Jarman ignored his appeal to treat the boy's condition with glucose.

Mr Toth took his son to hospital, where glucose was administered, but Wilfred died a week later.

Dr Jarman said it was he who arranged for the child's admission to hospital.

In 1998, Mr Toth's complaint questioning the doctor's fitness to practise was rejected when a GMC "screener" decided not to refer it to the preliminary proceedings committee.

Later that year, after Mr Toth had launched judicial review proceedings, the same screener reaffirmed his initial decision that no question of serious misconduct arose.

In settlement of the proceedings launched by Mr Toth, the GMC admitted the screener had applied the wrong legal test in the first instance and had no power to make the second decision.
Press Association

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Supermodel's ex PA arrested
fields.body:
Supermodel's ex PA arrested

Naomi Campbell's former personal assistant has been arrested in connection with an alleged attempt to blackmail the supermodel, it emerged yesterday.

Vanessa Frisbee, 25, was interviewed and bailed to return in July to Fulham police station, south-west London, in connection with an allegation of demanding money with menaces

Race row teacher resigns

A teacher who was suspended after being seen on TV saying he did not want his son to be taught at his school because he would be in a white minority has resigned. Richard Smith, 48, a language teacher, had been at Denbigh high school in Luton, Bedfordshire, for 21 years.

BBC sorry for radio failure

The BBC yesterday apologised to listeners after FM services across London and the south-east were cut off by a transmitter fault. Radios 1 to 4 were affected between 7.02am and 7.46am.

Eviction led to arson attempt

A pensioner was so distraught after being evicted from his Hammersmith and Fulham council flat that he wanted to start a fire to highlight his plight, the Old Bailey heard yesterday. Billy Kadry, 69, poured petrol around himself and lit a match in one of the west London council's offices. He was due to be sentenced yesterday, after pleading guilty to affray and arson. The case continues.

Reeboks cure rebuffed youth

An 18-year-old who threatened to throw himself off Hammersmith bridge, west London, after splitting up with his girlfriend was eventually persuaded to come down when police bought him a new pair of trainers. He was due to appear at West London magistrates' court charged with breach of the peace.

Mint burglar jailed

A burglar was yesterday jailed for two years at Hove crown court, East Sussex, for stealing a chocolate mint in a raid at a residential care home in Hove. Jayne Maynard, 32, of Brighton, was arrested after breaking into a 97-year-old resident's room. Maynard, of Brighton, admitted the offence but said she was so drunk she could not remember going into the home. She was sentenced to a further year for other offences

fields.headline: Smokers in manslaughter inquiry
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: A Milan prosecutor has begun investigating whether an asthma sufferer died from passive smoking, with a view to charging her employers and colleagues with manslaughter.
fields.body:
A Milan prosecutor has begun investigating whether an asthma sufferer died from passive smoking, with a view to charging her employers and colleagues with manslaughter.

The victim, identified by Italian newspapers as Stefania C, 25, collapsed at her desk in a Milan bank 10 months ago and died of an acute asthma attack.

Employers have in the past been ordered to pay compensation for the effects on health of passive smoking, but this would be the first time in Italian legal history that anyone had been charged with culpable homicide in such a case.

The woman, who suffered from chronic bronchial asthma, had been hired under a scheme that gives tax incentives to employers who take on staff with physical handicaps. But her family say she was forced to work in a small, windowless room, surrounded by habitual smokers.

Her repeated written requests to be transferred to a healthier environment were allegedly ignored by her employers.

The prosecutor, Luca Poniz, is investigating whether those who continued to smoke around her and those who ignored her pleas for help should be charged with manslaughter.

The intervention of trade union officials achieved no improvement in Mrs C's working conditions.

She returned from work every day with her clothes reeking of smoke and feeling humiliated by the insensitivity of her colleagues, her husband told the prosecutor.

Her anxiety at having to work in an airless, smoke-filled room often caused her to break down in tears, he said.

Medical experts say passive smoking can increase the chances of developing a lung tumour by 20%, as well as aggravating respiratory illnesses, particularly asthma.

According to Francesco Bacchini, a researcher on labour rights at the University of Modena, the entire bank hierarchy could be liable to prosecution.

"There is still no law against passive smoking in Italy, but using an extensive interpretation of other laws on safety in the workplace, there is no doubt that this case has serious penal implications," he said.

Four years ago the constitutional court established that smoking should only be allowed in the workplace in specially designated rooms or adequately ventilated smoking areas.

Mr Poniz will decide if he should go ahead with charges against the bank staff after questioning all those involved in Mrs C's case. His decision is expected by the end of the month.

webTitle: EU anger as Bush allows execution

fields.headline: EU anger as Bush allows execution
fields.standfirst: Which state kills the most?
fields.trailText: The execution of the Texas convict Gary Graham, despite the fear that he had not received a fair trial, brought a storm of international criticism yesterday. France threatened to make the US death penalty one of the themes of its impending EU presidency.
fields.body:
The execution of the Texas convict Gary Graham, despite the fear that he had not received a fair trial, brought a storm of international criticism yesterday. France threatened to make the US death penalty one of the themes of its impending EU presidency.

Graham, who protested his innocence throughout his 19 years on death row, fought every step of the way to the execution chamber, where he was given a lethal injection.

Guards had to subdue him when they came to take him from a holding cell a few feet away at 8.20 pm on Thursday evening, after a last ditch attempt by his legal team to win a stay of execution failed.

His last words were: "The truth will come out . . . They are killing me tonight. They are murdering me."

According to witnesses he died with one eye shut and one eye open, staring at the Rev Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader, whom he had invited to be present.

Bianca Jagger, representing Amnesty International, was also present, as was the grandson of Bobby Lambert, for whose 1981 murder he was convicted.

Graham admitted a string of armed robberies in the week after the murder, but denied shooting Lambert. There was no scientific evidence against him and he was convicted on the testimony of a sole witness.

Witnesses who said Graham did not resemble the killer were not called.

The French foreign ministry spokeswoman, Anne Gazeau-Secret, said the French consul in Houston, speaking for all 15 EU states, had tried to intervene, but the Texas governor, George W Bush, had ignored the appeal for clemency.

"We are dismayed by the execution," she said. "We especially regret that the authorities in Texas knowingly took the risk of putting an innocent man to death. We will make the campaign for a moratorium on executions in the US one of the themes of our presidency of the EU."

Mary Robinson, the UN high commissioner for human rights, said the execution "ran counter to widely accepted international principles".

Guards had to subdue him when they came to take him from a holding cell a few feet away at 8.20 pm on Thursday evening, after a last ditch attempt by his legal team to win a stay of execution failed. His last words were: "The truth will come out . . . They are killing me tonight. They are murdering me." According to witnesses he died with one eye shut and one eye open, staring at the Rev Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader, whom he had invited to be present. Bianca Jagger, representing Amnesty International, was also present, as was the grandson of Bobby Lambert, for whose 1981 murder he was convicted. Graham admitted a string of armed robberies in the week after the murder, but denied shooting Lambert. There was no scientific evidence against him and he was convicted on the testimony of a sole witness. Witnesses who said Graham did not resemble the killer were not called. The French foreign ministry spokeswoman, Anne Gazeau-Secret, said the French consul in Houston, speaking for all 15 EU states, had tried to intervene, but the Texas governor, George W Bush, had ignored the appeal for clemency. "We are dismayed by the execution," she said. "We especially regret that the authorities in Texas knowingly took the risk of putting an innocent man to death. We will make the campaign for a moratorium on executions in the US one of the themes of our presidency of the EU." Mary Robinson, the UN high commissioner for human rights, said the execution "ran counter to widely accepted international principles". fields.headline: Hoover's dark secret is revealed
fields.standfirst: FBI chief who hounded Martin Luther King had black ancestors, author says
fields.trailText: J Edgar Hoover, the head of the FBI who worked relentlessly to undermine Martin Luther King and others in the civil rights movement in the 1960s, had black ancestors whose existence he desperately tried to keep secret, according to a new book.
fields.body:
J Edgar Hoover, the head of the FBI who worked relentlessly to undermine Martin Luther King and others in the civil rights movement in the 1960s, had black ancestors whose existence he desperately tried to keep secret, according to a new book.

Millie McGhee, the author of Secrets Uncovered, J Edgar Hoover - Passing For White? is an African-American who says she was told as a little girl in McComb, Mississippi, of her family's links with Hoover.

She writes in the book that her grandfather told of her of this "very powerful" man in Washington who was related to the family but did not want the links to be known and passed himself off as white.

Ms McGhee, a former teacher in Los Angeles, explains that she contacted a genealogist in Salt Lake City, Utah, for help in tracing her family's history back 200 years.

She says her research shows that Hoover's grandfather and great-grandfather lived in a segregated black area of Washington and were classified in a census as "coloured".

Hoover, who was born in 1895 and died while still head of the FBI in 1972, was apparently anxious that no one should know of his origins.

According to Ms McGhee, relatives were warned of dire consequences if they spoke publicly of his background. As a little girl she believed that they would be killed if they mentioned the secret.

"Is this man so ashamed of his race that he would spend his whole life passing for white?" she asks. "How has our race offended him?"

She believes that his obsession with King and other black civil rights leaders stemmed in part from his repressed anger about his secret life.

She told the Guardian yesterday that members of the Hoover family who had contacted her had not been angry about the disclosures, but that her own family were unhappy with her decision to go public. "They're very upset."

"I never wanted to be related to him," she said. "I never even liked him."

Hoover came from a family that had always worked in government service in Washington. He entered the justice department after graduating in law, became acting director of the FBI in 1929 and was confirmed as director shortly afterwards.

He was associated throughout his career with a fierce paranoia about the left and the civil rights movement, and an obsession with pursuing what were seen to be enemies of the United States. A powerful figure during his life, he became the subject of much mockery after his death, when it was claimed that he had enjoyed cross-dressing.

Hoover's wire-tapping and hidden surveillance practices took the FBI's involvement in the private lives of US citizens to new levels.

After his death it was accepted that no FBI director should ever have such power again.

Ms McGhee says that the book is not an exposé of Hoover's dishonesty, but more of a cross between "Roots and Danielle Steel", in that it catalogues her search to discover the family's secrets.

fields.headline: Adoption bedevils beatification
fields.trailText: A row over the forced adoption of a Jewish boy by a pope 142 years ago could threaten the delicate relationship between the Vatican and Israel.
fields.body:
A row over the forced adoption of a Jewish boy by a pope 142 years ago could threaten the delicate relationship between the Vatican and Israel.

Jewish groups in the US are fighting plans to beatify Pius IX, and the case has been likened to that of the Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez.

In June 1858 Vatican officials arrived at the home of the Jewish Mortara family in Bologna and removed the six-year-old Edgardo because an illiterate servant woman had sprinkled holy water on him and this was considered to pass for baptism.

Despite the protests of the family, Edgardo was taken off to be brought up as the adopted son of the pope. He went on to become a priest, and died in 1940.

Now, with plans for the beatification of Pius IX going ahead, scholars and members of the Mortara family are campaigning against any attempt to gloss over what happened in 1858.

In the US, the B'nai B'rith International has written to the Vatican to criticise the plan. The letter refers to "unspeakable pain" caused by the pope.

The Vatican has responded by saying that the pope's actions have to be seen in the context of a different period.

The case has been likened by some commentators to that of Elian Gonzalez, the Cuban boy whose relatives in Miami have been trying to keep him from his father.

The row comes at a delicate time for relations between the Vatican and Israel, in the wake of John Paul II's visit to Israel.

fields.headline: Thinking globally but acting locally
fields.standfirst:
Brands, as Nike and Levi's know, can be fragile entities. Richard Watney on how e-commerce will affect firms' relations with their customers
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Brands, as Nike and Levi's know, can be fragile entities. Richard Watney on how e-commerce will affect firms' relations with their customers.
fields.body:
As pop music aficionados will tell you, a band is far more than the sum of its members. Big pop group names still tour the clubs and pubs of Britain well after the last original musician has left. Fights between managers and musicians over who really owns a band's identity continue in courtrooms all over the world.

And if CEOs were asked which one corporate asset they would take with them when leaving an organisation, chances are that the majority would choose their company's brand. The value of brands such as Virgin, Microsoft and Coca-Cola cannot be over-estimated.

In the e-business age, brand value has once again come under the spotlight. Companies that have long led the world in terms of brand strength are struggling to transfer that value to the virtual world. You can be a top ten global player in the traditional business paradigm but you need to work very hard to ensure that you build a cyber-presence that is not diluted in the eyes of customers and shareholders.

Yet that's exactly what is happening, according to a study by research group Forrester. It says that favourite brands such as Nike and Levi's are not registering enough traffic to show up on internet audience ratings.

But it's not just traditional companies that are struggling. A hefty slice of capital investment funds is devoted to making everybody aware of the latest new dot.com on the block, via public relations and mass media advertising.

The challenge is that customers shopping on the internet are driven not by brand loyalty but low prices and excellent customer service. According to Forrester, 73% of satisfied online book purchasers will buy their next book from another internet vendor. And even when organisations do manage to build a relationship with on-line customers, it can be wrecked in a moment by poor service and missed delivery dates.

The rules of marketing and brand management have changed because of e-commerce. The customer is in the driving seat. It won't be too long before customers routinely publish a requirement on the web and invite suppliers to bid for the business.

Will brands still be important in this new paradigm? The answer is yes, for two reasons. The psychological response to a brand will always be driven by more than just a low price. Given three options for a mortgage, all at the same price and with the same conditions, how will a customer choose?

The second reason is that despite the massive impact of e-commerce, there are more communications channels than the internet. Customers are unlikely to commit to large purchases like a house or car without a visit or test drive.

History has proven that the brands that survive long-term are those which build recognition early. This is why Amazon and Yahoo are investing massive sums today, so they can reap the benefits of brand leadership for years into the future.

There are two main challenges associated with communicating a brand globally. The first is that no single company can manage a global sales and distribution network on its own. A company that sells "physical" rather than "digital" products will work with partners who specialise in a niche vertical or geographical marketplace. It is vital that those partners are seen as an extension of the core company, and that sales materials follow corporate standards and "look and feel".

Partners focused on niche markets will understandably want to ensure that marketing materials are relevant to their prospective customers. When it comes to brand management, organisations such as car manufacturers and electronics companies need to "think global", but allow their partners to "act local".

With new software tools, companies can now build electronic libraries of company materials on a central website. Partners can access templates using a browser and produce customised versions to be printed locally. This means they have a bespoke range of materials that still conform to agreed standards and designs.

Companies taking this approach have identified a number of further benefits. First, they can avoid going through the laborious process of approving designs for leaflets, brochures and advertisements for each country. Instead, they can get broad agreement on options that can be used to meet local requirements.

The second benefit is that companies save time and money by simplifying the logistics process. Ordering, printing and delivering documentation is transformed from a time-consuming central function to a quick and simple local routine. Organisations can also support highly targeted, short-run marketing campaigns.

But the key benefit is that while customers can deal with a large organisation almost on a personal basis, the organisation itself strengthens its brand and image.

While there isn't a sales director in the land who doesn't recognise the commercial potential of the web, the marketing director is still struggling to ensure that the web does not dilute the brand he or she has fought so hard to build.

Marrying these two propositions will be the aim of every company that hopes to achieve success in the internet age.

Richard Watney is CEO of leading edge technology company Elateral

webTitle: Channel Islands to dispose of toxic waste on mainland

fields.headline: Channel Islands to dispose of toxic waste on mainland
fields.trailText: The government has given the go-ahead to a plan which will allow the Channel Islands to start disposing of hazardous waste in mainland Britain.
fields.body:
The government has given the go-ahead to a plan which will allow the Channel Islands to start disposing of hazardous waste in mainland Britain.

Michael Meacher, the minister who takes the lead on green issues in government, has allowed the move despite his public commitment to switching 25% of rubbish from landfill dumps to recycling by 2005.

The minister has also agreed to greatly expand the types of toxic waste which the Isle of Man will be able to export to the mainland.

The hazardous waste is to be taken to incinerators in Pontypool, South Wales, and Southampton. The toxic materials are being limited to 60 tonnes each for the Channel Islands and Isle of Man.

Mr Meacher said yesterday that he had "reluctantly" agreed to the sending of hazardous waste from the Channel Islands, following a deal with the Isle of Man to expand the types of waste that can be sent to Britain because of a lack of suitable facilities for disposal there.

Disclosure of the transportation of hazardous waste from the Channel Islands emerged after documents were leaked from the Isle of Man over plans to build a £122m incinerator. A decision on the incinerator was deferred yesterday by the Manx parliament, the Tynwald, after the island's public health department raised environmental and health concerns.

The business plan for the new incinerator included plans to export waste to the United Kingdom that had not been agreed with Mr Meacher. This proposal follows a row between the minister and the Isle of Man government over plans to start dumping thousands of tonnes of domestic waste in Britain.

In a confidential letter sent by Mr Meacher to David North, Isle of Man trade minister, and obtained by the Guardian, he reveals that the Isle of Man asked to start dumping domestic waste in Britain last year. In 1998 Mr Meacher had agreed to a large increase in the types of hazardous waste which the Isle of Man government could send to the United Kingdom.

This agreement tripled from 70 to 205 the number of hazardous waste products which could be dumped in Britain.

Among the new products that could be dumped in Britain included arsenic-based wood preservative, diesel oil, crude oil, and methanol.

Last December Mr North asked to extend its exports to cover domestic waste, and had a frosty response from Mr Meacher. His officials drafted a letter saying the Manx government could ship waste to the UK so they could recover and recycle some of the products, but "it was highly unlikely the UK will be able, as a matter of law, to meet your request to accept domestic waste".

This was consistent, it said, with UK policies of encouraging countries to be self-sufficient in the disposal of wastes, as the Isle of Man did not have the facilities to dispose of the waste in question in an environmentally sound manner.

webTitle: Diamonds buy peace for Sierra Leone city

fields.headline: Diamonds buy peace for Sierra Leone city
fields.standfirst:
Business is business in government-held Kenema, even if that means allowing rebel fighters to sell their gems

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The rebels are easy to spot. The three young men huddled together in stylish clothes and wearing sunglasses in the light drizzle quickly catch the eye of the Lebanese businessman. He beckons them toward an array of chrome-enhanced stereos twinkling invitingly behind the counter.
fields.body:
The rebels are easy to spot. The three young men huddled together in stylish clothes and wearing sunglasses in the light drizzle quickly catch the eye of the Lebanese businessman. He beckons them toward an array of chrome-enhanced stereos twinkling invitingly behind the counter.

"What have you got?" Kamal Jawad asks them. "We pay more than the others. Let me see your diamonds."

Sierra Leoneans have long cursed diamonds for fuelling and funding their brutal civil war, but they are a mixed blessing in the government-held city of Kenema.

Far beyond the city boundaries, rebels and members of the excitable Kamajor pro-government militia dig diamonds side by side and set war aside for the sake of wealth. When the young rebels have enough to sell they slip into Kenema in search of the Lebanese buyers whose shops line the main street.

It is no secret. Almost anyone can spot the rebels. Until a few weeks ago they stayed in town overnight to make the most of the bars and nightclubs before returning to the bush. But the war is approaching Sierra Leone's diamond areas, so the Revolutionary United Front fighters now confine their visits to selling their gems and buying supplies to take back to the rebel bases.

"They are too busy mining diamonds to want to fight," says Kenema's provincial secretary, Richard Freeman. "But it is not a good situation. Unfortunately, many ordinary citizens help the rebels sell their diamonds, and sell them supplies. They do not look at it that they are betraying their country; they look at it that they are making some money. That's why you see diamond shops all over the city."

Kenema is a drab city of about 150,000 people. Not many of its buildings have seen fresh paint in the past decade, except the brightly decorated shops along the main streets. Many of their signs include a picture of a diamond, for those that cannot read the words "Friend of the diamond miner", or "Supporter of the diamond trade".

Mr Jawad sits in front of his shop on a white plastic chair eyeing the passers-by. Anyone whose attention lingers for more than a moment on the array of stereos, watches and fans is coaxed in.

But the electronic goods are merely the bait for other business, and his favourite clients are those with the tell-tale signs of rebellion. The RUF fighters who wander into town are not in uniform and do not carry their guns, but that is no disguise. They may be dressed a little smarter. New jeans are a good clue. Rarely do they move alone. Virtually any resident can point out the rebels arriving on the back of a pick-up truck taxi.

The young men at Mr Jawad's shop do indeed have diamonds to sell, but they want to do it in private. Twenty minutes later they emerge. They are not keen to talk. The three - all apparently in their late teens - look blank on being asked where they are from.

Are they rebels? How much did they get for their diamonds? What will they do with the money? Eventually one of them gruffly breaks the silence.

"Foday Sankoh [the captured rebel chief] is our leader and he says he wants peace," he says. "We do not want to fight anymore. This country needs peace, so the government should leave us to mine in peace. Then there will be no trouble." He thinks about it and then gives his name as "Man Killer".

Mr Jawad does not like to speak of his clients as rebels, or to discuss the scale of his business with them. But he does admit that the gems are what keep him and the rest of the dealers in business.

"It's not my job to ask where the diamonds come from. It's my job to be able to know who is here to sell diamonds and to give him a price we are both happy with," he says. "How can I control what he does with the money? That's the government's business. The government lets these people walk into the city and out again."

Mr Freeman disagrees. "We can't stop everyone coming into the city and a diamond is a product that is difficult to control. A man can easily hide a diamond even if you search him all over The whole diamond business is a mafia business. It encourages people to deal with the rebels. We cannot control it," he says.

But he concedes that the government has taken few concrete measures, such as withdrawing the dealers' licences. The diamond buyers say they receive visits from government officials who expect to be paid off. Mr Freeman admits that the Lebanese are sometimes asked to "contribute to the war effort".

"Our forces are guarding the hydroelectric plant. Once in a while we go to the diamond dealers to solicit contributions for their upkeep," he says.

The truth is that Kenema survives in more ways than one on the rebel diamond miners. They not only generate money for the city but helps to stave off an RUF assault. The rebels rely on the city as a market for their gems and a source supplies.

"They've enjoyed the diamond mining, they don't want to be disturbed. They need to keep the city running as it is," says Captain Mana Amponsom-Boateng, intelligence officer of the Ghanaian UN peacekeepers in Kenema. "In the north they prefer to attack, so they can loot to survive, but here they have diamonds."

Rising tension

But that cosy set up is threatened as the war spreads from the north. Tension has risen as government troops press toward the rebel headquarters at Makeni and pledge to seize their diamond areas.

It is possible that many rebels from the northern areas - more used to murder, rape and looting than mining - will move down to protect the RUF's diamond supplies. There are also sighns that the President Charles Taylor of Liberia plans to ensure that the rebels defend the mines, from which he, too, has profited.

But for now Mr Freeman says he does not believe that the rebels around the city want to join the fight. "Some of these rebel commanders have relatives in the city here, so we send them to talk to them. They are indicating that they don't want to go on fighting, they don't see any gains after all those years," he says. "They are still holding on to their guns, but a lot of the rebels have wives in the city. If they attack, we will take control of their families. They know that."

The equilibrium was almost upset three weeks ago during a visit to Kenema by Sierra Leone's deputy defence minister, Samuel Hinga Norman. He is also the leader of the Kamajor militia and promised to rearm them and send them to attack the RUF. The city government and the UN were horrified.

"It wasn't a wise pronouncement," Capt Amponsom-Boateng says. "It incensed the RUF and made things very tense for a few days. We tried to do some negotiation. We wrote a letter, gave it to the chairman of the bus drivers' union and told him to deliver it to the RUF commander who used to call himself 'Man O'War'. Now he says he's called 'Man O'Peace'. The letter said we weren't planning to attack."

Militia disarmed

If it comes to a fight, Kenema will be in trouble. For years it relied on Nigerian troops of the west African intervention force Ecomog and the Kamajor to keep the rebels at bay. But Ecomog has gone and most of the Kamajors were disarmed under the collapsed peace accords.

There are 548 Sierra Leone army soldiers in Kenema, but not one has a gun. So the city looks to the nearly 800 UN peacekeepers for protection. But after the woeful performance of UN troops in other parts of Sierra Leone last month, when hundreds surrendered to the rebels without firing a shot, the residents are wary.

"Ecomog protected the city," Mr Freeman says. "I cannot say people have faith in the UN to do the same. People ask the question: how do you allow the rebels to surround you and take you prisoner?"

The lack of faith may be misplaced. The Ghanaians were previously with Ecomog near Freetown, and inflicted casualties on the rebels. In April, soon after they arrived in Kenema, the RUF attacked one of their posts. "They thought as soon as we heard pistol fire we would evacuate," Capt Amponsom-Boateng says. "That's when we made it clear we would fight. They haven't done it again."

But the Ghanaians are quietly reassembling the guns taken from the Kamajors for the day when the order comes to rearm the militia.
fields.bodyText: The rebels are easy to spot. The three young men huddled together in stylish clothes and wearing sunglasses in the light drizzle quickly catch the eye of the Lebanese businessman. He beckons them toward an array of chrome-enhanced stereos twinkling invitingly behind the counter. "What have you got?" Kamal Jawad asks them. "We pay more than the others. Let me see your diamonds." Sierra Leoneans have long cursed diamonds for fuelling and funding their brutal civil war, but they are a mixed blessing in the government-held city of Kenema. Far beyond the city boundaries, rebels and members of the excitable Kamajor pro-government militia dig diamonds side by side and set war aside for the sake of wealth. When the young rebels have enough to sell they slip into Kenema in search of the Lebanese buyers whose shops line the main street. It is no secret. Almost anyone can spot the rebels. Until a few weeks ago they stayed in town overnight to make the most of the bars and nightclubs before returning to the bush. But the war is approaching Sierra Leone's diamond areas, so the Revolutionary United Front fighters now confine their visits to selling their gems and buying supplies to take back to the rebel bases. "They are too busy mining diamonds to want to fight," says Kenema's provincial secretary, Richard Freeman. "But it is not a good situation. Unfortunately, many ordinary citizens help the rebels sell their diamonds, and sell them supplies. They do not look at it that they are betraying their country; they look at it that they are making some money. That's why you see diamond shops all over the city." Kenema is a drab city of about 150,000 people. Not many of its buildings have seen fresh paint in the past decade, except the brightly decorated shops along the main streets. Many of their signs include a picture of a diamond, for those that cannot read the words "Friend of the diamond miner", or "Supporter of the diamond trade". Mr Jawad sits in front of his shop on a white plastic chair eyeing the passers-by. Anyone whose attention lingers for more than a moment on the array of stereos, watches and fans is coaxed in. But the electronic goods are merely the bait for other business, and his favourite clients are those with the tell-tale signs of rebellion. The RUF fighters who wander into town are not in uniform and do not carry their guns, but that is no disguise. They may be dressed a little smarter. New jeans are a good clue. Rarely do they move alone. Virtually any resident can point out the rebels arriving on the back of a pick-up truck taxi. The young men at Mr Jawad's shop do indeed have diamonds to sell, but they want to do it in private. Twenty minutes later they emerge. They are not keen to talk. The three - all apparently in their late teens - look blank on being asked where they are from. Are they rebels? How much did they get for their diamonds? What will they do with the money? Eventually one of them gruffly breaks the silence. "Foday Sankoh [the captured rebel chief] is our leader and he says he wants peace," he says. "We do not want to fight anymore. This country needs peace, so the government should leave us to mine in peace. Then there will be no trouble." He thinks about it and then gives his name as "Man Killer". Mr Jawad does not like to speak of his clients as rebels, or to discuss the scale of his business with them. But he does admit that the gems are what keep him and the rest of the dealers in business. "It's not my job to ask where the diamonds come from. It's my job to be able to know who is here to sell diamonds and to give him a price we are both happy with," he says. "How can I control what he does with the money? That's the government's business. The government lets these people walk into the city and out again." Mr Freeman disagrees. "We can't stop everyone coming into the city and a diamond is a product that is difficult to control. A man can easily hide a diamond even if you search him all over The whole diamond business is a mafia business. It encourages people to deal with the rebels. We cannot control it," he says. But he concedes that the government has taken few concrete measures, such as withdrawing the dealers' licences. The diamond buyers say they receive visits from government officials who expect to be paid off. Mr Freeman admits that the Lebanese are sometimes asked to "contribute to the war effort". "Our forces are guarding the hydroelectric plant. Once in a while we go to the diamond dealers to solicit contributions for their upkeep," he says. The truth is that Kenema survives in more ways than one on the rebel diamond miners. They not only generate money for the city but helps to stave off an RUF assault. The rebels rely on the city as a market for their gems and a source supplies. "They've enjoyed the diamond mining, they don't want to be disturbed. They need to keep the city running as it is," says Captain Mana Amponsom-Boateng, intelligence officer of the Ghanaian UN peacekeepers in Kenema. "In the north they prefer to attack, so they can loot to survive, but here they have diamonds." Rising tension But that cosy set up is threatened as the war spreads from the north. Tension has risen as government troops press toward the rebel headquarters at Makeni and pledge to seize their diamond areas. It is possible that many rebels from the northern areas - more used to murder, rape and looting than mining - will move down to protect the RUF's diamond supplies. There are also sighns that the President Charles Taylor of Liberia plans to ensure that the rebels defend the mines, from which he, too, has profited. But for now Mr Freeman says he does not believe that the rebels around the city want to join the fight. "Some of these rebel commanders have relatives in the city here, so we send them to talk to them. They are indicating that they don't want to go on fighting, they don't see any gains after all those years," he says. "They are still holding on to their guns, but a lot of the rebels have wives in the city. If they attack, we will take control of their families. They know that." The equilibrium was almost upset three weeks ago during a visit to Kenema by Sierra Leone's deputy defence minister, Samuel Hinga Norman. He is also the leader of the Kamajor militia and promised to rearm them and send them to attack the RUF. The city government and the UN were horrified. "It wasn't a wise pronouncement," Capt Amponsom-Boateng says. "It incensed the RUF and made things very tense for a few days. We tried to do some negotiation. We wrote a letter, gave it to the chairman of the bus drivers' union and told him to deliver it to the RUF commander who used to call himself 'Man O'War'. Now he says he's called 'Man O'Peace'. The letter said we weren't planning to attack." Militia disarmed If it comes to a fight, Kenema will be in trouble. For years it relied on Nigerian troops of the west African intervention force Ecomog and the Kamajor to keep the rebels at bay. But Ecomog has gone and most of the Kamajors were disarmed under the collapsed peace accords. There are 548 Sierra Leone army soldiers in Kenema, but not one has a gun. So the city looks to the nearly 800 UN peacekeepers for protection. But after the woeful performance of UN troops in other parts of Sierra Leone last month, when hundreds surrendered to the rebels without firing a shot, the residents are wary. "Ecomog protected the city," Mr Freeman says. "I cannot say people have faith in the UN to do the same. People ask the question: how do you allow the rebels to surround you and take you prisoner?" The lack of faith may be misplaced. The Ghanaians were previously with Ecomog near Freetown, and inflicted casualties on the rebels. In April, soon after they arrived in Kenema, the RUF attacked one of their posts. "They thought as soon as we heard pistol fire we would evacuate," Capt Amponsom-Boateng says. "That's when we made it clear we would fight. They haven't done it again." But the Ghanaians are quietly reassembling the guns taken from the Kamajors for the day when the order comes to rearm the militia.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: It was an ultra-militant docker of the 1960s who, faced with a well-meaning government scheme to end casual labour on the waterfront, called on his brothers to "fight this diabolical threat of permanent unemployment".
fields.body:
 It was an ultra-militant docker of the 1960s who, faced with a well-meaning government scheme to end casual labour on the waterfront, called on his brothers to "fight this diabolical threat of permanent unemployment". Gordon Brown now knows what he meant. His own constituency contains the Rosyth dockyard, a troubled zone regarding employment opportunities for many decades. In the mid-1980s, a social club was set up for those seeking work, a concrete piece of community action to inspire the labour movement. Fifteen years on, and the honourable member is a chancellor presiding over dwindling dole queues and a booming economy. The Rosyth club, having seen most of its members return to gainful employment, is shutting its doors. It seems the last straw was when even the club secretary found work.

 The Royal Automobile Club foundation, meanwhile, has been investigating the types of music played on in-car stereo systems, with special reference to the different tastes of the owners of different vehicles. Do not accept a lift from anyone driving a Renault Espace - "a combination of Teletubbies and Lynyrd Skynyrd" - a Peugeot 306GTi-6 - "very, very loud dance music" - an Alfa GTV - "Dire Straits and Chris Rea" - or a Jaguar XJ8 - "Ride of the Valkyries". More menacing still are Mondeo LX owners - "a combination of personal motivation tapes and heavy rock music so that the owners can psyche themselves up to 'be first' and 'win, win, win'." The briefest entry comes next to the product of troubled Cowley, the Rover 75. It reads simply: "The blues."

 On a similarly tart note, one email doing the rounds allegedly relates to the latest business breakthrough. You have heard of e-commerce, you have heard of m-commerce - that is e-commerce with mobile phones - now meet "s-commerce". This, we learn, is truly revolutionary and involves the consumer in visiting conveniently located premises or "shops" in which the goods are actually on display. Two-dimensional viewing surfaces, "mirrors", are available, allowing consumers to "try on" clothes. Most radically, you take the goods away with you, right there and then. A pity it will never catch on.

 Elsewhere on the frontiers of technology, Unisys, the computer group, has collided with traditional British cynicism with the result that a staff incentive scheme is not working as planned at the company's extensive British operations. Unisys routinely invites nominations for "achievement awards", and those judged worthy under this internal honours list then have their names gazetted far and wide as examples to follow. Regrettably, the Brits find the whole thing unutterably naff, and treat it as an enormous joke. Worse, there have been cases of star performers begging their colleagues and chiefs not to nominate them lest it damage their reputation. Perhaps Unisys ought to supply its British workers with Mondeo man's "win, win, win" motivation tapes.

 KPMG, meanwhile - alias "the accountants formerly known as Peats" - is experimenting with a different type of motivation. As of July 1, the company is permanently dumbing down - sorry, that ought to have read "dressing down". The new with-it policy will replace a lot of boring accountants in suits with a lot of boring accountants trying to look casual. Funnily enough, as the news broke, an important figure in the business dress debate, Sir Richard Branson, was on the wireless enthusing about Europe's new super jumbo jet. Back in 1986, when Sir Richard's Virgin group was floated, personnel at adviser Morgan Grenfell rolled up at the Waldorf Hotel in crumpled jeans and Supertramp T-shirts, the better to empathise with Virgin's groovy young directors and swinging client base. Sir Richard and his colleagues stole the show in full morning dress.

 And just a word of warning on that super jumbo. Brother Yank, it seems, has decided not to build a similar aeroplane - just as, 30 years ago, he decided not to proceed with the SST, the American version of Concorde. We Europeans, of course, knew better. From an original worst case estimate of £170m in 1962, Concorde went nearly 12 times over budget, costing £2bn by late 1978. Only 16 of the planned 400 Concordes were ever built, and in 1977 alone, British Airways lost £17m on its Concorde operations. Doubtless the Airbus A3XX will be a tremendous success, but European taxpayers ought to keep a tight hold on their wallets.

fields.headline: Parents call child deaths helpline
fields.trailText: Parents of 80 children rang a helpline set up by detectives investigating the involvement of a paediatric nurse in the deaths of 18 of her patients, police revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Parents of 80 children rang a helpline set up by detectives investigating the involvement of a paediatric nurse in the deaths of 18 of her patients, police revealed yesterday.

Almost all of the calls came on Thursday following revelations that police were scrutinising the records of a 47-year-old woman, who works for the South Essex mental health and community care NHS trust.

Detectives, who launched the investigation last October, are looking at whether nine boys and nine girls in her care were given overdoses of morphine.

The children were terminally ill and were treated during home visits.

Detective Superintendent Ian McNeill, who is in charge of the investigation, said yesterday the work was "amazingly complex" and thought that it could be months before the truth was known. He added: "Children may have met their deaths from perhaps unnatural means. That could be one outcome. At the other end of the scale, we may uncover no evidence of any wrong doing."

The nurse, from Southend, Essex, has not been questioned, arrested or charged.

She has denied any wrong doing and has offered to help the inquiry in any way that she can. Yesterday she left Essex for a pre-planned holiday abroad.

An injunction bans the identification of her and the families involved in the case.

Police wanted to keep the investigation a secret and had not informed the families of the children, or the nurse, that it was ongoing.

The nurse is likely to be suspended from the profession by the UKCC, the regulatory body for nursing, at a hearing in two weeks.
