webTitle: Patently, BT has spoken too soon

fields.headline: Patently, BT has spoken too soon
fields.standfirst:
Why the lawyers are happy

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Who owns the new economy? If you believe BT, it does - or at least a large slice of cyberspace. On Tuesday the company announced it had unearthed a patent to one of the building blocks of the worldwide web. "Hyperlink technology" - BT was keen to tell the market - allowed surfers to move effortlessly from one page to another by clicking on text or pictures.
fields.body:
Who owns the new economy? If you believe BT, it does - or at least a large slice of cyberspace. On Tuesday the company announced it had unearthed a patent to one of the building blocks of the worldwide web. "Hyperlink technology" - BT was keen to tell the market - allowed surfers to move effortlessly from one page to another by clicking on text or pictures.

Everybody who boots up and logs on uses it, and more important to the company's bottom line is that somebody might have to pay for the privilege of offering users the technology.

The rumblings are that BT intends to use the full weight of patent law to squeeze US internet service providers for "hundreds of millions of pounds". Altavista has already hit out, saying: "BT should focus on innovation and creativity rather than [on] profits."

Such notions, which echo the internet's early enthusiasm for free, unpatented software, are becoming increasingly rare. Ideas are often the only assets companies in the knowledge economy have. So internet companies - and biotech ventures - are rushing to patent their ideas.

The effect has been dramatic. The United States patent office awarded more than 160,000 last year - nearly twice as many as a decade ago. Dell now has around 80 patents protecting different aspects of the building and testing process involved in assembling comput ers. IBM raked in $1.5bn last year from its patents. Priceline.com, a billion-dollar web operation, sprang from a patent for reverse auctions where customers set a price they are willing to pay and suppliers decide whether to meet it.

So BT thinks it is on to a winner. However, the courts are becoming clogged with cases dealing with lawyers dealing with licences. Amazon is already suing Barnes and Noble, claiming it has copied its one-click shopping program.

It is by no means clear, either, that BT could claim royalties from its "hyperlink" patent. The net's bulletin boards have buzzed with claim and counter-claim since BT went public. Some cite Apple's HyperCard system in 1985 as the first sighting of hyperlinks - four years before BT had its patent approved. Others point out that Project Xanadu - a forerunner of the web - beat BT to the punch by 20 years. It may be good to talk, but BT may have spoken too soon.

Leap in the dark

The final plunge into the unknown has been taken by Airbus. Some time in the middle of the decade, the world's largest aircraft, the A3XX, will be flying with upwards of 550 passengers on board.

The European consortium of Britain, France, Germany and Spain has combined to seize the advantage from its great rival, Boeing, to launch the new monster of the skies complete with bars, gyms and duty free shops.

Airbus said yesterday that eight airlines are ready to place their orders and that the first working plane could be ready by the end of next year.

It is an exciting and terrible concept. While it is very different in size to Boeing's tried and trusted 747, the world's biggest jumbo, its potential is awesome. It can carry up to 900 passengers but the shake-out from a crash is difficult to comprehend. It has been kept in place as a project only because it has gained a commercial momentum.

Yet the reaction to the launch has been mixed. Typically, Sir Richard Branson was first up there, saying he would like Airbus to wrap up six of the best, while more cautiously British Airways backed away. It said it was in no hurry to get involved and that it is going for small aircraft for the moment.

This is clearly a terrific gamble for Airbus. Flying is no longer a glamorous means of transport, and for many people it is a drudge trip. If the project fails, the jobs of 22,000 people will be at risk, not to mention the loans thrown at it by the four governments backing it.

EMI mystery

Strange happenings surrounding EMI. Five months have passed since it emerged that the music group planned to merge with the music division of Time Warner.

Shareholders whinged about the terms of the deal but nonetheless applauded the business logic, and they were expected to nod the deal through on Monday.

The meeting - which is planned for 11am, at the Waldorf - now promises to be rather more exciting after the appearance of two apparently authoritive reports saying a consortium of new media companies is planning a counterbid and has asked EMI's chief executive, Eric Nicoli, to postpone the vote.

But EMI issued a statement yesterday saying that it had received no such approach.

The company seems completely mystified and has asked the takeover panel to look into the matter. Perhaps it should contact the insider dealing police at the same time.

fields.headline: Shifting sands
fields.standfirst: Erosion fear on Gower peninsula
fields.trailText: For Brian Richards the beach below his home at Horton on the southern tip of the Gower peninsula was the ideal playground.
fields.body:
For Brian Richards the beach below his home at Horton on the southern tip of the Gower peninsula was the ideal playground.

But the wide expanses of golden sand he remembers from his childhood have begun to disappear, exposing large jagged rocks in places where he and his friends once ran unimpeded.

Like many on the Gower, Mr Richards, 64, believes the cause of this erosion lies a few kilometres offshore in the Bristol Channel, where dredgers have for years been extracting from the Helwick sandbank off Worms Head.

The dredging companies operating there, and on the more intensively worked Nash bank further to the east, say there is no evidence that their activities are responsible for sand loss on the Gower and at Porthcawl. They blame other factors such as changing weather patterns.

But bodies as diverse as surfers, wildlife groups, the tourist industry, and the Women's Institute have expressed concern about the possible long term impact of dredging on the Gower, the first area in Britain to be designated an area of outstanding natural beauty.

Richard Lewis, 61, a Swansea councillor, who lives in Horton, said: "There has been a huge deterioration in the the past two or three years. Sand is disappearing and no new sand is coming in. I would like to see dredging stopped immediately for at least a five year period to see if the sand builds up again."

But, according to David Harding, a spokesman for Hanson, one of three companies in the consortium dredging the Nash bank, sand dredged from the two banks is vital to the south Wales economy. Around 90% of the sand used in the region's construction industry came from the Bristol Channel and projects such as the Second Severn Crossing and Cardiff's Millennium Stadium were constructed using marine sand.

"Erosion and sand loss occurs all around the UK even in areas where there is no dredging. I think people need to look at nature itself and at weather conditions in the area. Helwick and Nash contain huge volumes of sand and we are only scratching the elephant's back."

fields.headline: Ex-Tory minister cleared of assault
fields.trailText: Former Tory minister Rod Richards was yesterday cleared of causing grievous bodily harm to a young woman who claimed he had punched her in the face and broken her arm.
fields.body:
Former Tory minister Rod Richards was yesterday cleared of causing grievous bodily harm to a young woman who claimed he had punched her in the face and broken her arm.

A jury at Kingston crown court in south west Londontook nearly five hours to find the 53-year-old Welsh assembly member not guilty of attacking Cassandra Melvin, 23, after he had wined and dined her and her sister last July.

Mr Richards, a married father-of-three and former Welsh Office minister in John Major's government, resigned as leader of the Tory group in the assembly to fight the allegation. He claimed he had "behaved like the perfect gentleman" towards the sisters.

He showed no emotion as the jury of eight women and four men gave their majority verdict but moments later waved to his 21-year-old son Rhodri who had attended throughout the five-day trial. Neither Ms Melvin nor her sister Tiffini was was in court.

Outside court, Mr Richards issued a statement saying he was "delighted" the case was over and said he wished to resume his political career with "renewed enthusiasm".

It had been claimed that Mr Richards, of Radyr, Cardiff, had assaulted Ms Melvin on July 27 last year outside her sister's flat in Kew, south-west London.

Mr Richards, a former Royal Marine, had travelled to London on business and was staying with his friend Nigel Evans, Tory MP for Ribble Valley. He met Ms Melvin and her 31-year-old sister Tiffini in the Victoria Inn pub in Richmond and later invited them to dinner at a nearby Pizza Express restaurant. After he paid for the £41 meal, the three travelled by taxi to the sisters' flat where the alleged assault was said to have taken place.

He admitted to the jury that he had tried to chat the two sisters up and had been less than frank to the police.

He also admitted to having a previous conviction for assaulting a taxi driver in 1974 and a police caution in 1997 for failing to mention the conviction when he applied for a firearm and shotgun certificate.

The prosecution, led by Nick Wood, alleged that Mr Richards had become violent and abusive when he was asked to leave the flat for making sexually offensive remarks towards the women.

But Baroness Ann Mallalieu QC, defending, described the evening as "the very stuff of middle-aged fantasies" and a "classic cautionary tale for a middle-aged man at a loose end in London".

Mr Richards said he was "shocked and embarrassed" at being arrested and claimed he had been invited back for coffee by the sisters when the atmosphere suddenly changed and Cassandra Melvin attempted to force him out of the flat.

After the verdict, Mr Richards's solicitor, George Keppe, read a statement in which the former minister thanked his wife, children, family and friends for "their unwavering support throughout what has been an emotionally draining and personally stressful time of his life" and wished Ms Melvin well for the future. He was "immensely relieved" at the jury's verdict.

Mr Keppe brushed off questions about a return to the leadership of the Welsh Tories, saying: "Everything is always possible." The Tory whip was withdrawn from Mr Richards in February following a dispute with his colleagues but he remains an assembly member.

A spokesman for Conservative central office said: "We are pleased for Rod Richards and his family that he has been cleared of the charges."

The Tory chief whip at the Welsh assembly, David Davies, a character witness for Mr Richards in court, said after the verdict: "I never had any doubt whatsoever he would be found not guilty. It is just not within his character to behave in that fashion."

fields.headline: Hospital attack trio face jail
fields.trailText: Three members of a family who attacked two doctors they had accused of trying to kill their sick nephew as he lay in hospital were yesterday facing jail.
fields.body:
Three members of a family who attacked two doctors they had accused of trying to kill their sick nephew as he lay in hospital were yesterday facing jail.

The boy's uncle Raymond Davis, 43, and his aunts Julie Hodgson, 37, and Diane Wild were convicted by a jury at Portsmouth crown court of violent disorder and attacking Mark Ashton at St Mary's hospital, Portsmouth, Hampshire, in October 1998, causing actual bodily harm.

Wild, 42, was also found guilty of attacking Joanne Walker on the same date.

The violence began when the family disagreed with doctors over the treatment of David Glass, 12, who was profoundly disabled.

Judge Roger Shawcross warned the three defendants that they may be facing prison following the convictions.

"Any court that has to deal with people who have committed assaults on people of the medical or nursing staff, or anyone like that, might immediately be bound to say you are likely to face custodial sentences."

He added: "I have got to warn that that is certainly in my mind."

Davis, of Waterlooville, Portsmouth, and Wild and Hodgson, of Buckland, Portsmouth, were remanded on bail and the case was adjourned until July 14, when all three are due to be sentenced.

Press Association

fields.headline: Time nearly up for £1m winners
fields.trailText: The holders of four winning lottery tickets which scooped £1m or more in draws over the new year period have just a week to claim their prizes.
fields.body:
The holders of four winning lottery tickets which scooped £1m or more in draws over the new year period have just a week to claim their prizes.

Camelot is urging anyone who bought tickets in Cumbria, Bolton, Hampshire or Northampton over the new year to check any old or forgotten tickets before the deadline runs out and the money is handed over to good causes.

Two £1m tickets from the New Year's Eve big draw remain unclaimed. It is estimated that the holders have already lost £26,000 each in interest.

Two jackpot winning tickets each worth £1.17m from the New Year's Day draw have remained unclaimed at a loss of more than £30,000 in interest.

Dianne Thompson, Camelot's commercial operations director, said: "National Lottery players have a multitude of places to hide their tickets.

"So we would recommend they search everywhere to avoid losing out on these huge prizes.

"National Lottery winners have been known to hide their winning tickets in their underwear, under floorboards and even in their bibles."

Three £1m-plus prizes have been left unclaimed in the lottery's six-year history.

The winning players have until 11pm on Thursday, June 29, to claim their prizes.

The winning numbers from the New Year's Day draw were 2, 5, 14, 23, 27 and 48. The bonus number was 38.

The unclaimed prizes for the New Year's Eve big draw are for game two, which was based on years, not the usual six numbers.

The two winning years were 1575 and 2832.

fields.headline: Roman coin haul worth £265,000
fields.trailText: Britain's largest hoard of Roman silver denarius coins, gathered in a bucket by a welder and a farmer's son, has been valued at £265,000, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's largest hoard of Roman silver denarius coins, gathered in a bucket by a welder and a farmer's son, has been valued at £265,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

The 9,213 coins were discovered by Kevin Elliott, 33, whose family owns the farm, with a metal detector in a field of barley stubble in Somerset. He and his cousin Martin Elliott, 33, found the hoard at Northbrook Farm, near Glastonbury, in 1998.

The Somerset coroner Michael Rose ruled in November that the haul was treasure, and so belonged to the finders.

A spokesman for Somerset county museum, Stephen Minnitt, gave the value in Taunton as he launched an appeal to acquire the coins. The museum has until September to raise the £265,000, a figure approved by the independent Treasure Valuation Committee.

Press Association

webTitle: Papas, beloved Guardian cartoonist, dies aged 72

fields.headline: Papas, beloved Guardian cartoonist, dies aged 72
fields.trailText: Bill Papas, the much loved Guardian political cartoonist and illustrator during the 1960s, is reported to have died aged 72, swimming ashore after his boat plane crashed in British Columbia, Canada.
fields.body:
Bill Papas, the much loved Guardian political cartoonist and illustrator during the 1960s, is reported to have died aged 72, swimming ashore after his boat plane crashed in British Columbia, Canada.

Papas arrived at the Guardian in 1959 with a mission that would have given anybody less confident nightmares: to share the political cartooning slot with the legendary David Low. By the time that Low died well into his 70s in 1963, Bill had overcome a diffident start to shoulder the major part of the job.

Papas was born in South Africa of Greek extraction, and his most baleful cartoons focused on South Africa in the time of Verwoerd and Rhodesia at the time of its unilateral declaration of independence.

But political satire was not Papas's true metier. Even his most savage cartoons were decorated in the end by his graphic alter ego, a signature mouse.

In latter years Papas worked in Greece and in the US, where he was living at the time of his death.

fields.headline: Cathedral snubs stars of architecture
fields.standfirst: Salisbury dean and chapter determined to wait for 'absolute excellence' after rejecting every design for a centre to house Magna Carta
fields.trailText: The dean and chapter of Salisbury Cathedral have caused consternation among a group of star architects by turning down all their plans for a modern centre to house the Magna Carta within the church's 800-year-old precincts.
fields.body:
The dean and chapter of Salisbury Cathedral have caused consternation among a group of star architects by turning down all their plans for a modern centre to house the Magna Carta within the church's 800-year-old precincts.

The Wiltshire cathedral's refusal of blueprints submitted by a shortlist of six architects - including the world famous Daniel Libeskind - was attacked as "a snub" yesterday by the professional magazine Building Design. It accused the dean and chapter of wasting thousands of pounds of architects' money.

The magazine reported the decision as "Rejection at the cathedral", a headline with deliberate echoes of TS Eliot's play Murder in the Cathedral. A total of 86 architects originally entered the running for the design contract.

Last night, the cathedral authorities were unrepentant. Their project manager, Chris Watson, said they were determined to wait for a design that would match "one of the great architectural and building opportunities of the world".

The Magna Carta centre would be the only modern object - apart from Elisabeth Frink's tiny, celebrated statue of a hurrying nun - in the huge medieval cathedral close.

"The site is worthy of a design of absolute excellence," Mr Watson said. "It is a terrifically exciting scheme, but it is very difficult.

"We have not seen anything which matches its complexity. The challenge is to choose a building in today's architecture which will sit with buildings which have been there for 800 years. We want it to be harmonious. The dean and chapter are not going to proceed unless they are absolutely over the moon about what is put forward.

"It's not time-sensitive. Salisbury cathedral has been there for 800 years. We are prepared to wait until we have absolutely the right scheme."

The site for the visitors' centre, which will store the finest surviving copy of the Magna Carta, is next to cloisters on the south side of the cathedral, which dominates the city. Among architects rejected for the contract were:

Mr Libeskind, architect of the Victoria & Albert museum extension, in London, and the Imperial War Museum of the North, in Manchester.

Steve Marshall, of the partnership Munkenbeck and Marshall, which recently won the Stephen Lawrence prize for its sculpture gallery at Roche Court, near Salisbury. The firm also designed the futuristic Marina 1 on the Regent's Park canal, in London.

David Chipperfield, an award-winning younger architect who re-planned Museum Island in Berlin. He recently displayed models at the Venice Biennale of ambitious new buildings that he is creating on the cemetery island of San Michele, on the Venetian lagoon.

The firm Allies and Morrison, which earlier this month won an award for its use of extruded aluminium at Stratford underground station on the Jubilee line, in London.

The others rejected were the partnership Evans and Shalev and the architect Ian Ritchie.

Each was given about £3,000 for preparatory work for the cathedral centre. Some, however, are understood to have spent £10,000 or more on their schemes.

Yesterday Daniel Libeskind's wife and professional partner Nina Libeskind said she was deeply disappointed: "There is an old saying in the academic world - if all the students fail, the teacher has failed.

"With this competition, it seems to us that if we have come up with the wrong answer, the wrong question has been asked. Daniel is not exactly someone who fails to deal with these questions.

"I think they might have had the grace to say something along the lines that their thinking had changed after they asked for submissions."

Mr Libeskind's design is for a circle-topped building next to the cloisters, which spreads down to a traditional square shape of the kind his wife said Leonardo da Vinci had used.

Explaining this symbolism, their written submission to the dean and chapter said: "Like the rectilinear document of the Magna Carta itself, with the circular seal of King John signalling agreement, the building's measure, structure, light and function communicate to the visitor the intertwining of pragmatic and conceptual levels ...

"[This] will give simultaneous access to both the temporal and the eternal; connecting old forms... with the evolving horizons of a democratic world and world citizenship."

Steve Marshall said his plan was "possibly the most radical" on the shortlist. It was an attempt to recreate the uncluttered view of the cathedral which John Constable shows in one of his paintings.

Mr Marshall's scheme puts the centre underground, beneath a lake of reflective glass, with an entrance modelled on Runnymede, where the Magna Carta was signed.

Yesterday he said: "Everyone who entered the competition is disappointed. If no one gets it, you are left with a slightly empty feeling. I think there might be some illusion on the cathedral authorities' part that an architect can only come up with one idea.

"We have another 10 ideas. Now that we have heard what they have said, we would like to have another go at it."

fields.headline: US 'supported anti-left terror in Italy'
fields.standfirst: Report claims Washington used a strategy of tension in the cold war to stabilise the centre-right
fields.trailText: The United States was accused of playing a large part in the campaign of anti-communist terrorism in Italy during the cold war, in a report released yesterday by the Left Democrat party.
fields.body:
The United States was accused of playing a large part in the campaign of anti-communist terrorism in Italy during the cold war, in a report released yesterday by the Left Democrat party.

The explicit accusation is contained in a draft report to a parliamentary commission on terrorism.

The formerly communist LDP is the biggest party in Giuliano Amato's centre-left government, and the report could sour relations between Italy and the United States and unleash a storm of domestic political controversy.

The 300-page report says that the United States was responsible for inspiring a "strategy of tension" in which indiscriminate bombing of the public and the threat of a rightwing coup were used to stabilise centre-right political control of the country.

Those who carried out the attacks were rarely caught, it said, because "those massacres, those bombs, those military actions had been organised or promoted or supported by men inside Italian state institutions and, as has been discovered more recently, by men linked to the structures of United States intelligence".

Valter Bielli, a Left Democrat member of parliament and one of the authors of the report, said his party's conclusions were based on recent judicial discoveries and a re-elaboration of information that had been available for many years but had not been adequately understood.

"I am convinced that the intervention of the Americans in Italy is now a historically proven fact," he said.

"They interfered to prevent the Communist party from achieving power by democratic means. The communist threat no longer exists and it would be appropriate if the Americans themselves helped us to clarify what happened in the past."

Mr Bielli said he was worried about the possible implications of the report for relations between Italy and the US, but he hoped it would contribute to the creation of a new Nato in which all countries enjoyed equal weight and dignity.

"During the cold war the east was under communist domination, but the west too had become, in a certain sense, an American colony," he said.

The report claims that US intelligence agents were informed in advance about several rightwing terrorist bombings, including the December 1969 Piazza Fontana bombing in Milan and the Piazza della Loggia bombing in Brescia five years later, but did nothing to alert the Italian authorities or to prevent the attacks from taking place.

It also alleges that Pino Rauti, a journalist and founder of the far-right Ordine Nuovo (new order) subversive organ isation, received regular funding from a press officer at the US embassy in Rome.

"So even before the 'stabilising' plans that Atlantic circles had prepared for Italy became operational through the bombings, one of the leading members of the subversive right was literally in the pay of the American embassy in Rome," the report says.

Mr Rautinow heads the small rightwing MSI Fiamma-Tricolore party, and suggestions that he and other rightwing politicians still actively involved in parliamentary politics had failed to cut their links to terrorist extremists have drawn furious rebuttals from the centre-right opposition.

The National Alliance leader, Gianfranco Fini, described the document as a "miserable report" and the centrist Republican party said it was worthy of a 1970s Maoist group.

"These are allegations that have come up over the last 20 years and there is absolutely nothing to them," a source at the US embassy in Rome said.

To Aldo Giannuli, a historian who works as a consultant to the parliamentary terrorism commission, the release of the Left Democrats' report is a manoeuvre dictated primarily by domestic political considerations.

"Since they have been in power the Left Democrats have given us very little help in gaining access to security service archives," he said.

"This is a falsely courageous report. The real issue today is gaining access to Nato's archives. There has been no impulse on this front from the government."

webTitle: Woman who killed disabled sons is freed

fields.headline: Woman who killed disabled sons is freed
fields.standfirst: Judge calls on social services to launch inquiry into their conduct
fields.trailText: A mother who drugged and suffocated her two profoundly disabled sons walked free from court last night after pleading guilty to manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility.
fields.body:
A mother who drugged and suffocated her two profoundly disabled sons walked free from court last night after pleading guilty to manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility.

Janquil Turnbull, 52, killed her sons Robert, 23, and Richard, 20, both of whom suffered from cerebral palsy, in October 1998 in the family home at Bembridge on the Isle of White. The court heard that Mrs Turnbull, who denied murder, killed the boys after becoming depressed by the immense care burden.

Both men were blind, immobile, incontinent, incapable of speech and had the mental capacity of six-month-old children. One of the men was epileptic and prone to screaming in pain all night.

Winchester crown court heard that Mrs Turnbull and her husband Ronald, who had cared for their sons from birth, had become increasingly frustrated by what they saw as the inadequacies of successive social services departments. At a meeting with authorities on the Isle of White, Mrs Turnbull was told they might have to be taken into care.

Faced with the prospect of the break-up of the family, Mr Turnbull left the Isle of White on October 19, 1998, to seek accommodation in Kent, leaving Mrs Turnbull alone with her sons overnight for the first time.

The court heard that Mrs Turnbull was in a state of depression, suffering from panic attacks and severe paranoia brought on by her fears that her sons would be taken away.

This led to her drastic decision to kill her children, giving them doses of painkillers then smothering them.

Michael Parroy QC, prosecuting, told the court that Mrs Turnbull then dialled 999 and waited for the police to arrive. "She told the arresting officers that she loved the boys very much but she was very tired and they couldn't suffer anymore," he said.

Lady Anne Mallilieu QC, defending, told the court that the Turnbulls had endured a series of disputes with social services culminating with the meeting on the Isle of White.

Presiding judge Mr Turner criticised social services and called on them to launch an inquiry into their conduct. "I think I should feel I was failing if I did not invite the authorities to start some form of inquiry to see that all was done that reasonably, in a humanitarian manner, was done for this family."

The court also heard that Isle of White MP Peter Brand told the Turnbulls at a meeting that "they were a drain on the island's resources".

Sentencing Mrs Turnbull, who is suffering from a degenerative neurological condition thought to be Parkinson's disease in addition to continuing depression and post traumatic stress disorder, Mr Turner said: "I need not and I will not pass a custodial sentence in your case as you have already punished yourself. You have already been punished by spending six weeks in Holloway prison on remand and are being punished now by the process that brought you to this court. "

Recommending Mrs Turnbull receives treatment for her depression, he added: "Because of the 20 years of struggle you have faced I am confident it will take many years to attain semblance of normality to your life. Go from this court and try to regain for yourself from your declining years something of which you can be proud."

James Lowe, director of social services on the Isle of Wight, said: "They lived for their children and nothing was too much for them. They had a complete bond of trust with the boys and were absolutely dedicated. I think she just hit a brick wall.

"I feel great sympathy for Mrs Turnbull but I think he [Mr Turnbull] was ill-advised to leave her on her own. Had we known he was going we would have arranged for a night sitter to stay with her, but we're not camped on the doorstep."

Night when a devoted mother told herself 'I just can't take any more'

When Melody and Ronald Turnbull moved to the Isle of Wight in November 1998 they thought they had at last found a peaceful environment in which to continue their life's work - the care of their profoundly disabled sons Robert, 23, and Richard, 20.

Instead, the Turnbulls' stay on the island ended in tragedy.

In the early hours of October 20, last year, Melody Turnbull administered a sedative to her sons before smothering them until they were dead. She then dialled 999 and waited.

Two hours later at 3.30am, Mr Turnbull, who had left the couple's secluded rented house in Bembridge the previous day for the mainland, was woken at his daughter's house in Kent by police and told the news. Later that morning, he identified his dead sons.

Both sons had suffered from cerebral palsy since birth and required constant care and attention. For 23 years, the Turnbulls had provided that care, assisted by their two daughters, Paula and Nicola.

Cerebral palsy is a physical impairment that primarily affects motor responses, and its effects are varied and unpredictable. It is caused by the failure of a part of the brain to develop fully during childbirth or early childhood, prompted by complications in labour, a blocked blood vessel, insufficient oxygen, extreme prematurity or a genetic defect.

With two children both suffering from profound CP, the Turnbulls bore a huge emotional, physical and financial toll. The Turnbulls, who have been married for 33 years, refused to put the boys into a home, convinced that no one could match the attention they received at home.

Desperate to find what they saw as a sympathetic health authority the family shuttled around the country over eight years, setting up home in six towns.

Their lawyer, Michael Holmes, said the Turnbulls encountered "great hostility" from neighbours. "People found themselves embarrassed in the presence of their sons. The boys were incontinent, they had to be bathed, fed and entertained. When they came to die, one was totally blind, the other partially blind."

Mr Holmes said that the couple eventually ran out of places to go and their savings ran dry.

In October 1998 the family moved to the Isle of Wight to be close to Ronald Turnbull's brother Keith, who ran an electrical wholesalers, and under an authority with an excellent reputation for disabled care.

They rented a house just outside Bembridge, and contacted social services to begin the search for authority-funded housing. After being assessed by a care manager, the Turnbulls agreed to put the boys into a day care centre. The South Wight Housing Association set about finding them a home in March 1999.In July, a bungalow in Newport was approved for conversion and the finance agreed.

In mid-September the Turnbulls told the housing association they had to move out of their cottage on November 20, and indicated they wanted to move straight into their new home.

Any delay in moving in would mean Richard and Robert had to go into care.

It was this uncertainty about the future that persuaded Mr Turnbull to visit the mainland and look once more for a fresh start. When he boarded the ferry, it was the first time he had ever left his wife alone with the boys overnight.

In interviews with police and doctors Mrs Turnbull described the night on which she killed her children. After emptying powder from painkillers she had been prescribed for back pain, she poured it into two glasses.

"All I thought was I just can't take any more," she said.

Once the boys were in bed she gave them the drugs, and asked both of them to forgiveher.

She then put a pillow over their faces until they were dead. She lay down next to one of them and fell asleep. When she woke up she poured herself a large brandy, and called police. When they arrived she was sobbing and shaking.

She later told police: "They were just two poor little people who have suffered enough."

fields.headline: Your beer in his hands
fields.standfirst: Hugo Powell, chief executive, Interbrew
fields.trailText: Hugo Powell cradles a bottle of Bass ale as he poses for photographs outside his office. "This little baby cost £2.3bn," he says. "It was like giving birth - I knew it would come eventually, but it was hard work."
fields.body:
Hugo Powell cradles a bottle of Bass ale as he poses for photographs outside his office. "This little baby cost £2.3bn," he says. "It was like giving birth - I knew it would come eventually, but it was hard work."

Powell has good reason to feel triumphant. He has become Britain's most powerful brewer by masterminding the purchase of a third of the country's beer industry. Interbrew, best known for making Stella Artois, is paying £2.7bn in total for the Whitbread Beer Company and Bass Brewers. So how does it feel to be the king of the British pint?

"We've been a little bit too busy to do any celebrating," says Powell. "But we're having a gathering of employees next week to sample all the new products."

The tasting session will kick off at Interbrew's head office in Leuven, a canal town east of Brussels. Several hundred Belgian staff will try some of Britain's best loved beers - including Boddingtons, Flowers, Worthington and Carling.

Interbrew will then ship samples to its sites in 13 other countries, allowing all its other employees to revel in the group's dominance. "This has changed the face of Interbrew," enthuses Powell.

An Englishman, he is more familiar with British beer than most of his colleagues and well aware of its heritage. "I found an old Bass calendar the other day from 1951. It had been in the family for years. I never knew things would come full circle like this."

Hitting the target

Born in India and educated at Charterhouse, Powell joined Interbrew when the group bought John Labatt, the Canadian brewer, for £3bn in 1995. He maintains a home in Toronto, where he built a fully functional pub in his front room.

"It's modelled on an English pub, with 300-year-old oak beams, horse brasses and six taps," he says. The place has a pinball machine and is "a commercial operation in every sense except that you can't just walk in - it's by invitation only".

Powell was given the top job in Leuven a year ago and has been targeting Bass and Whitbread ever since. "We showed our bankers a slide a year ago with Bass and Whitbread on it. We knew this was what we wanted to do."

With breweries consolidating worldwide, Interbrew needed to buy to compete with the marketing power of players such as Carlsberg-Tetley and Anheuser-Busch, the American owner of Budweiser.

Britain was the obvious direction in which to expand, says Powell. "It's a very attractive market - it's one of the biggest in the world. It's got terrific brands and great beer heritage, deep in the local fabric of the country."

The problem is that demand is, at best, static. Young drinkers are turning to wine, alcopops and spirits, preferring vodka and Red Bull to Fuggles Imperial.

"All the existing brewery owners in Britain were leaving - that was the flag for me to pay attention," says Powell. "We've always gone into new markets when it's been unglamorous to go, and when the cost has been affordable."

The group was accused of overpaying for Labatt, but made a success of the business. More recent moves into eastern Europe, Russia and Korea bucked the industry trend.

So can Interbrew stimulate British thirsts? "Let's not try to be King Canute, sitting on the beach and telling the tide to turn away," says Powell. "I'm not going to say we can or we can't change things.

"Many say the market is mature and declining and I understand why they say that. But we're in particular segments which are exciting."

Talk of "segments" upsets real ale enthusiasts, who fear Interbrew will concentrate on volume lagers like Carling and Tennent's at the expense of traditional brews such as Welsh Smooth, Whitbread Best, Caffreys and Mackeson.

Stuart Neame, chairman of the Independent Family Brewers of Britain, fears the arrival of the Belgians will "bring forward the day when you can go into a pub and the only thing available on tap will be Stella Artois".

This vision is emphatically rejected by Powell. "That's a complete misconception of what Interbrew is. The way the corporation is built is on a series of local brands. There's an absolute belief here that beer is a local, as opposed to a global business."

By segments, he means that drinking habits vary regionally. "In aggregate the UK market is declining but, if you concentrate on local products in different regions, it's a different story."

He insists British drinkers have nothing to fear. Interbrew already owns 180 different brands - in contrast to the hand ful each of the large American and Danish groups.

"What we are not is an international company which sits in the middle and says 'thou shalt have this'," Powell says.

Interbrew's roots go back to 1366, when brewing began in Leuven. Its recent success is down to Stella Artois, cooked up as a Christmas brew in 1926.

The company is controlled by three families - the de Spoelberch, Van Damme and de Mevius clans - who will loosen their grip slightly by floating off a minority stake later this year.

"None of the family members have offices in the building," says Powell. "But we meet them regularly - they're on the board, and the board has to approve all long-term plans."

Powell is something of an outsider, although he insists: "I think of myself as an international citizen. I carry both British and Canadian passports."

The son of a textiles merchant, he was born in India in 1945. He was sent to boarding school in Surrey, then won a place to study politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford but chose instead to become a Unilever management trainee.

"I used to be blessed with an ability at sports. I knew if I went to university I'd probably collect a few blues and have a good time," Powell says. "But I was offered the opportunity of professional training, and I decided to take that instead."

His career has been on a steady trajectory ever since.

Asked his favourite tipples, Powell diplomatically lists most of Interbrew's brands but picks out Hoegaarden as "very refreshing on a hot day".

The next few months will be busy - Interbrew has appointed Merrill Lynch and Fortisbank to co-ordinate a public offering to replenish its coffers - stretched after shelling out £2.7bn. It is unclear, as yet, where the shares will be traded but the main listing could be in London.

Powell also has to convince the competition authorities that Interbrew's 32% of the British beer market is acceptable. He points out that the market leader in Germany has 82%, in France 40% and in Denmark, Carlsberg-Tetley has 71%. He argues, therefore, that it would be unfair for the European commission to rule Interbrew's position excessive.

Thinking British

For the British drinker, Powell claims, Interbrew's arrival could actually increase the choice of brands as the group nurtures innovation. "We must respect local cultures, local brands and local management. If we get that right, we'll almost definitely have successful local companies."

Powell avoids the question of brewery closures, saying the group has not had detailed figures for long enough to determine how many sites it will need.

As far as Bass and Whitbread's brewing staff are concerned, Powell says: "I hope they'll feel some pleasure that they're joining a winner. This is a funny business - people care about brewing in a weird way. But we have a track record. I think when people understand how we do business, they'll appreciate it."

fields.headline: Cezanne may sell for £12m
fields.trailText: A painting by Cezanne is expected to fetch up to £12m at auction next week.
fields.body:
A painting by Cezanne is expected to fetch up to £12m at auction next week.

Still Life with Fruit and Pot of Ginger is one of the most important still life works by the artist, according to Christie's.

"This painting is a vintage Cezanne oil," said Jussi Pylkkanen, senior director of Impressionist art.

The work, dating from around 1895, will be on sale for the first time on the open market when it goes under the hammer at Christie's next Wednesday.

It is being sold by descendants of Bruno Cassirer, a Berlin publisher who began dealing in art in 1898 and was one of the first to champion Cezanne's work.

One Cezanne still life sold for £18.5m at Sotheby's last December after it had been estimated to fetch between £9m and £12m.

The record price paid for a Cezanne was $60.5m (£37m) by an anonymous buyer at Sotheby's, in New York, in May 1999 for Still Life with Curtain, Pitcher and Bowl of Fruit - the fourth highest price for any painting.

Press Association

fields.headline: Object of desire for tycoons
fields.standfirst: Gucci
fields.trailText: Think Farrah Fawcett and Deborah Harry with a touch of Gwyneth Paltrow's chic style and you have the Gucci look for women's wear this year.
fields.body:
Think Farrah Fawcett and Deborah Harry with a touch of Gwyneth Paltrow's chic style and you have the Gucci look for women's wear this year.

That's the view of Tom Ford, the Italian fashion group's creative director. Ford wanted the spring and summer range for women to look strong, sexy, feminine and classic with an edge.

It's a far cry from the ugly corporate battle for control of Gucci being waged by two of France's leading businessmen, Bernard Arnault of the LVMH luxury goods group and Francois Pinault of the Pinault Printemps Redoute stores and distribution chain.

The two have been arguing for the past 15 months over who should have full control of Gucci, with each blaming the other for the failure to reach an agreement.

The business was started by Guccio Gucci in Florence in 1923. Guccio developed an eye for luxury goods while working abroad at the turn of the century. He had been, for a time, a liftman at the Savoy hotel in London.

He opened his first shop in Florence, at first selling luggage and saddlery made by local craftsmen and then the handbags which were to make the Gucci name famous.

Under the fascist government, Gucci experimented with hemp, linen, jute and bamboo to offset shortages in traditional raw materials.

This led to the classic Gucci handbag with a bamboo handle, launched in 1947. Another classic product was the flowered Flora silk scarf created for Grace Kelly in 1967.

Guccio Gucci reshaped the business in 1939, bringing in three sons - Aldo, Ugo and Vasco - as partners. A fourth son, Rodolfo, joined them later.

Gucci's trademark striped webbing reflects the company's origins in saddlery: the webbing was derived from the saddle girth.The GG logo, representing the founder's initials, was used to decorate a cotton fabric used in its luggage and in its first clothing, which was introduced in 1968.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: While Vivendi chief executive Jean-Marie Messier was waxing lyrical about the combination of old and new media through the company's takeover of Canada's Seagram the markets were enthusing about the drinks industry he is intending to exit.
fields.body:
While Vivendi chief executive Jean-Marie Messier was waxing lyrical about the combination of old and new media through the company's takeover of Canada's Seagram the markets were enthusing about the drinks industry he is intending to exit.

Scottish & Newcastle was among the leading performers in the top flight with shares in the company 30p higher at 518p ahead of results due to be reported at the beginning of next month. Allied Domecq was 16p higher at 359p as investors speculated that the drinks group may be keen to snatch the Seagram drinks side if the deal between Vivendi and Seagram is given the green light.

Where once the link to all things internet provoked a positive response from investors, it seems the opposite is now true.

Continuing worries over the cost of sustaining an online version of their businesses proved a drag on the shares of the banks. Barclays was 52p lower at £15.67, Lloyds TSB was off 7p at 603.5p and Abbey National closed 21p down at 750.5p.

Barclays came under additional pressure from investment bank UBS Warburg which downgraded its recommendation to hold from strong buy on the stock and cut its price target to £18 from £20 a share.

A strong performance on Wall Street in early trading underpinned the FTSE 100 index of leading shares which closed 22.3 points lower at 6391.5.

Marks & Spencer fell back 7p to 235p after the retailer launched its summer sale - a move which sparked fears that continued poor trading has forced it to begin discounting early.

Analysts were suggesting that like-for-like clothing sales are still on the decline despite attempts to refresh the retailer's offer. "We are hearing that in the last three weeks clothing sales are down 7%-8%," said one.

The marketing services industry continued on a high after French agency Publicis snapped up the most famous name in British advertising, Saatchi & Saatchi, earlier this week.

Cordiant , which owns the Bates agency and demerged from Saatchi, was 12.5p up at 350.5p, Chime Communications which includes the HHCL brand was 1p up at 187.5p and WPP , more likely a buyer than a target, closed 23.5p up at 978.5p.

webTitle: Passing of the bug leaves profits hangover for ICM

fields.headline: Passing of the bug leaves profits hangover for ICM
fields.trailText: The hangover in information technology spending after the completion of contracts to bust the millennium bug yesterday forced ICM Computer Group to admit that profits growth will fall below expectations.
fields.body:
The hangover in information technology spending after the completion of contracts to bust the millennium bug yesterday forced ICM Computer Group to admit that profits growth will fall below expectations.

Shares in the IT systems and service provider fell almost 20% to 435p after peaking in March at £11.67.5.

The news came on the heels of profit warnings from rivals in the service sector including Computacenter, whose shares fell 35% to a year low of 417p earlier this month.

Warnings have also been issued by Compel, Synstar and Parity Group.

ICM's explanation of a slower than expected recovery in spending mirrored those of Computacenter and Compel.

The company also pointed to delays in contracts being signed and said that both large and small clients were slow to confirm business.

A number of companies in the sector have expressed concern that larger clients are stalling decision-making on projects while they re-evaluate their IT and e-commerce strategies.

When clients do commit, many of the contracts are for short-term pilot schemes which do little to ease the drop in revenues.

A spokesman for ICM said: "Clients are now having to address their IT requirements in the context of the new economy, not the old, and this makes the decision-making process more complex."

ICM said another contributory factor was the soaring cost of recruiting and training the skilled staff who could react to rapidly changing customer expectations, including dealing with the unprecedented developments in new growth areas such as mobile communications such as Wap (wireless application protocal) technologies.

The spokesman said: "Customer demand is driving the need to recruit a new skills base and it is proving much more expensive than first anticipated."

However, ICM said that it would show modest growth in pre-tax profits for the year - which ends next week, exceeding last year's £4.3m, but falling short of the £5m figure forecast by analysts.

Analysts are now forecasting £5m for 2001 and ICM has said that it expects a number of contracts to be signed in the first quarter.

ICM's portfolio of clients includes Compaq, BT and Cisco Systems.

fields.headline: Charlton has £10m to spend
fields.standfirst:
Relegation cuts £4.5m from TV and gate receipts

Charlton Athletic
fields.trailText: Charlton Athletic, the London football club recently promoted to the Premier League, said it planned to raise £5.74m to fund the purchase of two to three new players for the coming season.
fields.body:
Charlton Athletic, the London football club recently promoted to the Premier League, said it planned to raise £5.74m to fund the purchase of two to three new players for the coming season.

The club said the funds raised would give it a total cash position of just over £10m. The shares are being placed at 55p apiece.

Charlton Athletic chairman Richard Murray, whose company Avesco owns a big stake in the hit television programme Who Wants to be a Millionaire, is expected to take up a quarter of the placing.

He owns just under 25% of the London club and other directors own a further 64%. The club's shares rose 0.25p to 54p yesterday.

Peter Varney, Charlton's chief executive, admitted that £10m would still limit the quality of the players it could recruit - but insisted that it was competitive with other clubs at the bottom of the Premier League.

His aim was to give Alan Curbishley, the team manager, "the best possible chance. It's a lot bigger sum than some other clubs are able to give their managers."

Mr Varney said he remained confident of Charlton's commercial success. The club had almost sold out its 18,000 season tickets and had signed a three-year £2.5m shirt sponsorship deal with Redbus - the investment business set up by Cliff Stanford, the founder of Demon Internet.

"From the club's point of view this is a golden year for Charlton," Mr Varney said. "The bank manager takes us for lunch instead of us taking him for lunch."

The club's turnover fell by about £4.5m because of the fall in television and gate receipts after last year's relegation to the first division.

But the club expects an improvement in its fortunes following the return to Premier League football. The television deals recently awarded by the Premiership for the three seasons 2001 to 2004 will provide significant extra revenue for all the clubs involved.

Charlton was listed on AIM in 1997.

fields.headline: The window closes
fields.standfirst:
Hopes for Middle East peace fade - again

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Middle Eastern peace process, that ongoing quarrel between Jews and Arabs about the future of the region, never quite comes to an end.
fields.body:
The Middle Eastern peace process, that ongoing quarrel between Jews and Arabs about the future of the region, never quite comes to an end. There may be no agreement, but there can be no return to open hostilities either. The combination of the strength of Israel, the commitment of the United States, the weakness of the Palestinians and, to a lesser extent, the Syrians, means that, however bad things look now, the chances are that the parties will be back at the table sooner rather than later.

Yet this is a depressing moment. Ehud Barak, who had seemed to be the Israeli leader who could deliver peace with both Syria and the Palestinians, has failed in his first objective, and could conceivably fail in the second. Peace with Syria is now off the agenda until that country has a more settled leadership. Certainly there is even less chance now of a Syrian concession on the key territorial question of access to the Galilee shoreline, as the Syrian foreign minister made clear yesterday. As for the Palestinians, they are still likely to accept any halfway reasonable offers as they move toward what was supposed to be the final phase of negotiations.

The real question is whether the Israeli government now possesses enough coherence and common purpose to make those offers. The fact that Israel is negotiating from strength has always been the central difficulty. That makes it hard to craft a consensus for compromise in the shaky coalition governments which Israel's political system now always seems to produce. Recalcitrant parties can always argue that peace can be deferred, insist on hardening the terms for settlement, or blackmail the prime minister into giving way in other areas. That is what the Shas party has done this week to Mr Barak, forcing him to finance and legitimise the mini-state within the state to which they aspire, and to kick out of his coalition the liberal secular party which had stood in their way. Worse, Shas has not even given a clear pledge that it will support the prime minister in the peace negotiations.

So much in these matters depends on momentum, the authority of leaders, and the creation of a climate of inevitability. This is all now disrupted. Mr Barak's room for manoeuvre in his dealings with the Palestinians has been narrowed - and the divisions in Israeli society created by orthodox movements that want near complete control of their constituencies have been widened.

webTitle: Rio Tinto bids £1bn for Australian iron rival

fields.headline: Rio Tinto bids £1bn for Australian iron rival
fields.trailText: The British-owned mining group, Rio Tinto, yesterday made a £1.16bn hostile takeover bid for Australian-based competitor North which, if successful, would make it the world's second biggest iron ore producer.
fields.body:
The British-owned mining group, Rio Tinto, yesterday made a £1.16bn hostile takeover bid for Australian-based competitor North which, if successful, would make it the world's second biggest iron ore producer.

Rio Tinto snapped up a 14.5% stake in North before launching its full bid, priced at £1.58 a share. The company was prevented from buying more than 15% of North because doing so would entail gaining approval from Australia's foreign investment review board.

The bid's success is also subject to Rio Tinto - which is the world's largest mining company - gaining more than 50% of North's shares. North rejected the offer yesterday as "inadequate", but said its board would meet to consider the terms of the offer.

However, analysts expected the bid would be successful.

"I think it's a fairly full price that is out of the reach of anyone else competitively," said David Bird, an analyst at ABN Amro. "There will be some good synergies with [Rio Tinto] able to cut costs in the head office, exploration and the West Angelas project [in Western Australia]."

Mr Bird said the bid would also thwart merger plans by North, which had been in discussions with other second tier iron ore producers to create a company to rival Rio Tinto's iron ore operations.

Leigh Clifford, chief executive of Rio Tinto, said: "The acquisition of North provides the opportunity to combine Rio Tinto and North's mining operations and to pursue capital and operating efficiencies, wherever they might exist. The bid strengthens the Australian iron ore mining industry and export base in the face of increasing global competition."

Rio Tinto was in talks with BHP last year for both companies to put their iron assets into a joint venture. However, this was abandoned after both companies failed to reach agreement on its structure.

Shares in Rio Tinto rose 28p to £10.18 yesterday. The bid represents a 30% premium on North's closing price of 122p on Thursday.

webTitle: Poor countries face $50bn bill for tax havens

fields.headline: Poor countries face $50bn bill for tax havens
fields.standfirst: Debt relief: special report
fields.trailText: Tax havens cost poor countries at least $50bn a year in lost revenues - equivalent to the entire aid budget of the West, a new report from Oxfam will say on Monday.
fields.body:
Tax havens cost poor countries at least $50bn a year in lost revenues - equivalent to the entire aid budget of the West, a new report from Oxfam will say on Monday.

The charity says money desperately needed to fight poverty is being diverted into the financial "black holes" created by tax havens.

Oxfam's report comes as the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development prepares to release a list of the worst tax offenders this Monday. It says the debate on tax havens has missed the fact that poor countries suffer the most - because they lack the resources to track down where rich individuals and companies hide their money.

"Poor country governments are being denied at least $50bn a year - roughly equivalent to the entire global aid budget - because large corporations and rich individuals are escaping their tax obligations," the report says.

Oxfam is calling for a "poverty focused" rethink of the system that provides tax sanctuary for elite corporations and individuals.

"Tax havens exist simply to help the wealthy thrive. No thought is being given to the poor they weaken," says Oxfam's head of advocacy, Phil Bloomer. The report says:

 Tax havens allow rich companies and individuals to avoid tax, to under-report profits and to move vast sums of capital. This limits the ability of governments to raise revenues and invest in social services. Poor countries are forced into a race to offer foreign investors ever-lower tax rates.

 Many tax havens provide sanctuary for the proceeds of crime and corruption. Much of the $55bn looted from Nigeria remains in European bank accounts today.

 Tax havens are central to the operation of global financial markets, with currency instability and rapid surges and reversals of capital flows. This volatility contributed to the Asian financial crisis; nearly three years on, the economies of Thailand and Indonesia continue to struggle under the public debt the crisis created.

Western action had concentrated on smaller tax havens such as Jersey, the Caymans, Bahamas and the Seychelles, ignoring London, New York, Singapore, Hong Kong and Switzerland.

"If there is going to be a blacklist, these centres should figure prominently. They should be named, shamed and changed as well." said Mr Bloomer.

fields.headline: Among the electors
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy declared that the only success at Tottenham (Labour coasts to victory, June 23) was down to the Liberal Democrats, even though Labour still scored a massive majority considering the turn out.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy declared that the only success at Tottenham (Labour coasts to victory, June 23) was down to the Liberal Democrats, even though Labour still scored a massive majority considering the turn out. Presumably, when the Lib Dems win seats, he will then suggest that the only success should go to the other parties?

Then there are the Tories who are still holding on to the sad dream that all the Labour voters hate their party and are defecting, whereas all the Tories stayed at home at the byelection. Hardly an indication of devoted party support, if the Tories won't even stand up and make their voices count in a Labour majority area.

Some basic education in observation and awareness skills are needed, folks.
Jason Wood
Leicester
jason.wood@ntlworld.com

 If elections were held on a Saturday or Sunday there would be a far larger turn-out. What reason is there for holding them on a Thursday?
Norman T Shepherd
Bristol

fields.trailText: It's a pity that Lord Jenkins has taken to the barricades (Oxford denies Blair degree in revenge for elitism row, June 23), but the prime minister might draw some comfort from Ramsay MacDonald's view of Oxford: "A painted lady, from whom Labour has nothing to expect."

Dr Ken Bray
Bath

 Lord Jenkins tells us: "The examiners of Magdalen are a very progressive body of men." And not a hint of irony . . .
Tom Freeman
Cambridge
tomafreeman@hotmail.com

 First Peter Lampl of the Sutton Trust, and now (June 21) your leader writer, refer without explanation to "Britain's top 13 universities". To invent such a category is arbitrary and invidious, likely to encourage rather than reduce elitism. Why exclude, for example, Sussex or East Anglia, no less accomplished by reasonable criteria at teaching and research? Of course it would then have to be admitted that these two universities already each have an intake of more than 80% from state schools, something missed by the proponents of the "war of Laura's place".
Robin Milner-Gulland

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In our report, "Robocop" hits back as zero tolerance policing damned, page 3, June 23, we completely changed the sense of comments made by the chief constable of the Cleveland police force, Barry Shaw.
fields.body:
 In our report, "Robocop" hits back as zero tolerance policing damned, page 3, June 23, we completely changed the sense of comments made by the chief constable of the Cleveland police force, Barry Shaw.

What he actually said was: "Detective Superintendent Mallon knows better than most people the procedures that will have to be followed and the decisions that will have to be made before any consideration can be given to the return to duty of any suspended officer. We totally dissociate ourselves with [sic] unwarranted criticism made by him of other agencies and statutory bodies." (The Guardian report said: ". . . made of him by other agencies . . .")

In addition, towards the end of our report, Page 6, June 21, we referred to allegations which had "fingered an astonishing 600 other officers". The actual figure was 60 officers. We concluded by saying that crime rates had risen to "pre-Mallon levels". They have not. They have fallen. Crime rates in Cleveland as a whole are at their lowest for nine years. Apologies for those inaccuracies.

 Homophone corner, from page 8, G2 (Women), June 22, "The eggs are still there . . . the dried yokes are the only evidence of several ugly things that have recently been hurled . . ."

fields.headline: Bad news, boys
fields.trailText: Simon Hoggart (Vindaloo, Vindaloo, June 21) expresses scepticism about my statement in the Commons that one third of men in this country will have a criminal conviction by the time they reach the age of 30, and asks for details.
fields.body:
Simon Hoggart (Vindaloo, Vindaloo, June 21) expresses scepticism about my statement in the Commons that one third of men in this country will have a criminal conviction by the time they reach the age of 30, and asks for details.

In fact, I gave details of some of the research in the same debate (Hansard, June 20). For a cohort of men born in 1968, 26% had convictions by the age of 24, and 10% had convictions for violence against the person, sexual offences or robbery. By comparison, of a cohort of men born in 1953, 34% had some convictions by the age of 40.
Jack Straw
Home secretary

fields.headline: Bland view of the Beeb
fields.trailText: At last the BBC's chairman has admitted that its TV programmes have not been reaching a "high enough level of quality and ambition" (BBC1 controller under fire, June 22).
fields.body:
At last the BBC's chairman has admitted that its TV programmes have not been reaching a "high enough level of quality and ambition" (BBC1 controller under fire, June 22). For years the same Sir Christopher Bland and the BBC's previous director general, Lord Birt, had been dismissing viewers and listeners who complained that they were dumbing down BBC programmes by requiring them to be cheap and undemanding. Now we have a complete about turn. Who are those responsible for the BBC's decline? Anyone spring to mind? (Don't forget the name Hussey, by the way.)
Graham Webb
Rickmansworth, Herts

 Yesterday I bought two parsnips from Sainsbury's. They cost me £1.05. You can't even buy a couple of parsnips with the government's 75p rise in pensions.
M Davis
Paisley

 England's defeat by Romania must be put down to the referee. He was clearly unaware of the most important of football laws: no penalty must ever be awarded against a Man United player.
John Clarke
London

 If Germans want a "half-kilo" of something, they ask for " ein Pfund " - in English, "a pound". Curiously, weight-wise, they have almost got it right.
Bill Glynn
London

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Double-decker assault on SWT
fields.body:
Double-decker assault on SWT

The Dutch rail operator NS has joined FirstGroup, Britain's train and bus operator, in an attempt to operate double-decker trains between London and the south-west.

They intend to bid for the South West Trains franchise held by Stagecoach. One of the most lucrative parts of the rail system, it serves London suburbs like Wimbledon, Surbiton and Richmond.

FirstGroup runs services from London to Cornwall and South Wales while NS runs a high density rail network in the Netherlands which is being used to full capacity.

The move towards double decker trains has been examined by several rail companies, including Railtrack. It would mean lowering the track and raising some bridges on approaches into London.

Alternatively, Waterloo station could be lengthened to accommodate longer trains. But space is confined so the idea of double decker trains becomes very attractive. However, with tests still in progress, it would be at least another five years before they could be introduced.

Johns Manville sold for $3bn

US building products maker, Johns Manville Corp, which was nearly destroyed in the 1980s by asbestos litigation, has agreed to be sold to an investor group for $3bn.

Texas buy-out firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. is teaming up with the merchant banking unit of Bear Stearns to buy the company in a deal which is based on about 155m shares, on a fully diluted basis, plus assumed liabilities and expenses.

Troubled Citrix ousts founder

US computer company Citrix Systems has ousted founder and chairman, Edward Lacobucci, following a profit warning and a share price drop. The company specialises in server software for corporate networks - the application service provider market - working with companies such as IBM and Microsoft.

Two weeks ago the shares slumped by 45%. Shares were trading below $23 on Nasdaq yesterday, against a 52-week high over $122.

Since then, more than a dozen lawsuits have been filed by shareholders acusing the company of lying about its financial condition and growth potential.

Lottery delay to improve bids

News of which applicant has won the right to run the National Lottery has been delayed by two months in an effort to improve the bids. The licence runs out in November 2001.

Camelot, which has run it since it started in 1994, is up against a consortium called The People's Lottery led by Virgin chairman Sir Richard Branson.

Vivendi floats to reduce debts

Vivendi Environment is to float 30% to 35% of its share capital at 35 euro to 40 euro (£21 to £24). Chairman Henri Proglio said Vivendi Environnment's forthcoming initial public offering would increase shareholders's equity to over 5bn euro from 412m euro.

He said the listing would cut debts at the firm, which provides waste and water treatment, energy services, transport and construction, to under 12bn euro from 16.8bn euro.

fields.headline: Take a healthy attitude
fields.trailText: We are the nursing staff in the six-bedded unit to which Theodore Dalrymple refers (TV fairies at the end of the bed, June 20) and we would like to point out that the care of our patients is our first priority.
fields.body:
We are the nursing staff in the six-bedded unit to which Theodore Dalrymple refers (TV fairies at the end of the bed, June 20) and we would like to point out that the care of our patients is our first priority. The hospital day can be long and laborious, and television is a form of media which both informs and entertains our patients (a large majority of whom are illiterate).

We find the comment that "nurses don't seem to be able to concentrate at their desks without the aid of pop music", both denigrating and undermining of our professionalism. The staff working on the unit are hard-working and have very little time to sit at a desk.

Perhaps Mr Dalrymple would like to spend a 15-hour shift on the unit to appreciate the broader picture.
J Searjeant
Ward manager Nuneaton, Warks

 Theodore Dalrymple holds out the hope that putting TV sound on earphones would solve the problem of the stay of other patients in hospital being made hell on earth by intrusive television noise. I can tell him it doesn't. I recently spent three days in a ward of the Whittington hospital, where the sound of some of the TV channels is provided on each patient's earphones (which also have some radio programmes).

My stay was made much more horrible than it should have been because the one person on the ward who had rented a TV set refused to listen on the earphones. It seems that we have produced a nation of people who are insecure unless they can hear background TV sound or piped music the whole time. The Royles are not a joke.
Elkan Allan
London
elkan@mac.com

 Yet again we are offered, this time by Jon Henley (France serves up first-class treatment - but at a price, June 21), the unthinking assumption that "we" as citizens cannot afford good publicly funded services yet "we" as customers can afford expensive private services.

Yes, at 9.8% of GNP the French do pay a lot for their health service, but it does deliver the best health care in the world; the Americans pay 14.2% of a far larger GNP (mainly as customers) and come 37th in the world league table on health care, after Costa Rica - which is 36th. As for making economies in the French system, this would be best done (as Henley hinted) by adopting the British system of "free at the point of delivery" for medical consultations and a one-price prescription charge, so cutting out the vast bureaucratic effort that goes into making individual refunds for the millions of initial payments the patient is required to make.
Alan Mathison
Harrow, Middx
alan.mathison@ntlworld.com

 The National Institute for Clinical Excellence, after much consultation, has concluded that beta interferon's benefits are severely outweighed by its cost-effectiveness (MS drug to be put beyond reach of NHS patients, June 21).

Firstly, have they really exhausted all consultations with those involved? It seems they have barely consulted many of the national organisations dealing with MS, if recent interviews have been correct. And, if they are really concerned with clinical excellence, why exactly do their findings contradict those in other countries? Is it because our health service is exceptionally better than others? I think not, given current findings. Or is it that they are purely concerned with cost-effectiveness and that treating an MS patient is far too expensive?
James Odell
London

 I have just been in hospital to have tests which have confirmed that I have MS. I was somewhat comforted before going in to be told that symptoms could be alleviated by treatment. Then on my first night in hospital, it was announced that the NHS was likely to ban beta interferon prescriptions - which is possibly the only drug to improve my, and other sufferers quality of life.

I feel let down. I thought more money was being pumped into the NHS. Not much evidence of that here. Martin Kelly
Wirral

 Your article on the WHO league table for overall health care in 191 countries made interesting reading. Did you realise that this was one of the two most important factors in determining the success of teams in the group stages of Euro 2000?

Tactics? Formations? Team selections? All are unimportant. It's a combination of being in the WHO top six - and geography.
Geoff Bartholomew
Grimsby

fields.headline: Agreeing to disagree
fields.trailText: Hugo Young (Pious words that hide a double penalty for the poor, June 22) is, of course, absolutely right. If this "nasty" piece of legislation goes through, I will cancel my small direct debit to the Labour party and I will tear up my membership card.
fields.body:
Hugo Young (Pious words that hide a double penalty for the poor, June 22) is, of course, absolutely right. If this "nasty" piece of legislation goes through, I will cancel my small direct debit to the Labour party and I will tear up my membership card. Unfortunately it is not quite so straightforward for me to turn my back on what has been a long career in the probation service. Thank God (hopefully) for the House of Lords . . . and I never thought I would hear myself say that!
David Maynard
Swansea

 Hugo Young criticises our proposals to stop benefit for people who break the terms of their community service order. Surely it is not unreasonable to say to someone if they enter into an agreement they should stick to it? Hugo Young argues that these individuals do not know what they are doing and this represents double punishment. Such a view is patronising. We are all responsible for our actions. Society is built on a contract. There are rights, yes, but there are responsibilities too.
Alistair Darling
Secretary of state, Department of Social Security

fields.headline: Fly the euro
fields.standfirst: Europe's A3XX is a sign of confidence
fields.trailText: Yesterday's decision to authorise construction of the A3XX European superjumbo jet, capable of carrying 555 or more passengers, is a bold act of faith that may tell us more about the direction Europe is travelling than all the ditherings of our politicians combined.
fields.body:
Yesterday's decision to authorise construction of the A3XX European superjumbo jet, capable of carrying 555 or more passengers, is a bold act of faith that may tell us more about the direction Europe is travelling than all the ditherings of our politicians combined. Last year the Airbus won 50% of global aircraft orders, and is hoping to do even better this year. Suddenly Boeing, whose global dominance once looked impregnable, is in danger of being overtaken. And this time Europe isn't playing catch up. It is setting the pace. The new plane, which will have some of the facilities of an ocean liner (including gyms, jacuzzis and lounges) is leapfrogging over the 747, entering a market for bigger aircraft that Boeing didn't even think existed until recently.

This resurgence of European aircraft manufacture is happening at the same time that Europe is preparing a separate challenge to the US over its leadership of the information revolution, as web-friendly mobile phones (in which Europe has a leading edge) take over from personal computers as the most popular means of accessing the internet. These are early days but Europe is at least a couple of years ahead of the US and intends to keep it that way. Interestingly, both of these successes are due to unfashionable interventions by governments. If market forces alone had ruled, the European airbus would never have got off the ground in the first place; and had Europe allowed mobile phone standards to be left to market forces, then it might have been landed with several incompatible standards, of the kind that are now hampering innovation in the US. Instead, it agreed on the GSM (global system for mobile communications) hammered out by European governments - which has since proved a key ingredient in the runaway success of Europe's mobile phone industry.

Environmentalists may have reservations about ever bigger aircraft filling our skies and burning up scarce fuel (which gets extremely favourable tax treatment). But, given that airline traffic is expected to triple by 2014, it is clear that bigger jets with improved fuel efficiency - the A3XX claims to use 20% less fuel per passenger - will be more environmentally friendly than smaller ones. They may also reduce the need to expand existing airports in an environmentally unfriendly way, because bigger planes need fewer landing slots. Flying is already the safest way to travel and, in theory, bigger planes will be safer still; even though, when an accident does happen with a super-jumbo, the consequences will be truly horrendous.

The project remains risky. No one can be sure that the market Airbus predicts, nor the economic growth it presumes, will materialise. British Airways, for one, says it has no plans to place orders. But the consortium itself, in which British Aerospace (BAe) has a 20% stake, is confident enough to risk its own money in addition to the (repayable) loans it will receive from member governments. The A3XX will have the added advantage that it could last at least 30, or even 50, years while the 747 may soon be approaching the end of its useful life.

If there is one lesson from the experiences of Europe's aircraft and mobile phone industries, it is that such activities are best carried out by the private sector but that governments have a vital role in planning the infrastructure, technological and financial, to create the conditions for success. It remains to be seen whether Europe will be able to boast a similar success with the single currency.
