fields.headline: Images up in smoke
fields.trailText: Eating disorders are not the only threat to the health of young women posed by their desire to be fashionably slender (TV plan to monitor images of ultra-thin women, June 22).
fields.body:
Eating disorders are not the only threat to the health of young women posed by their desire to be fashionably slender (TV plan to monitor images of ultra-thin women, June 22). One of the main reasons many girls take up smoking is the belief (not without validity - female smokers on average weigh 7lb less than their abstemious sisters) that it will reduce appetite and thus control weight.

The frequent depiction of smoking by glamorously slim young actresses must encourage this tendency and should surely be tackled by a media campaign to address the problem.
Dr Bob Heys
Halifax

 Dea Birkett (Fat chance, June 23) quite rightly points out the increased incidence and serious health problems associated with obesity. However, it must not be forgotten that obesity is self-inflicted and voluntary - at least in the sense that driving a car, smoking tobacco or drinking alcohol are voluntary.

fields.headline: Trade gap widens to £2.5bn
fields.standfirst: Exporters start to feel benefits from sterling's fall
fields.trailText: Higher oil prices and imports of aircraft pushed Britain's global trade gap to its widest for three months in April, official figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Higher oil prices and imports of aircraft pushed Britain's global trade gap to its widest for three months in April, official figures showed yesterday.

The global goods deficit widened to £2.5bn in April from £1.9bn in March. This was the result of falling exports and record monthly imports, according to the Office for National Statistics.

Despite the deterioration in the headline figures, economists said that Britain's trading position with the rest of the world was showing signs of improvement.

"The widening in the deficit was entirely accounted for by erratic items such as oil, aircraft and precious stones," said Richard Iley, UK economist with ABN Amro.

"The underlying deficit, which excludes these items, continued on its modest upward trend."

There are signs that exporters are starting to feel the benefits of sterling's recent fall on the foreign exchanges - even though recent business surveys suggest that companies remain gloomy about the outlook.

Export volumes over the last three months are 12% higher than over the corresponding period last year.

Mr Iley said there were three explanations for the strength of export growth so far this year: buoyant demand - particularly from the booming US economy, price cutting by exporters to offset sterling's strength and the fact that the pound has weakened dramatically against the dollar.

"Volumes are up strongly outside the EU but stagnating to the EU," said Mr Iley.

More up-to-date figures for non-EU trade showed a fall in the deficit from £2.3bn in April to £1.8bn in May, which was below market expectations.

"Sterling's weakening may have started to come through in the figures but it's really quite early days yet," said Peter Warburton, economist at Robert Fleming.

"More likely, the start of the slowdown in the UK economy and destocking have been the predominant factors," he added.

Signs that the trade deficit is starting to narrow may help to persuade the Bank of England that the economy is slowing down - reducing the risk of further interest rate rises. A widening trade gap is a feature of an overheating economy.

fields.headline: Goodyear jobs threatened
fields.standfirst:
Strong pound blamed for planned shutdown of Wolverhampton plant

Goodyear
fields.trailText: A leaked company memo revealed yesterday that Goodyear has threatened to close a 3,000-job British tyre plant, blaming a "very strong sterling" and low productivity for the Wolverhampton complex's difficulties.
fields.body:
A leaked company memo revealed yesterday that Goodyear has threatened to close a 3,000-job British tyre plant, blaming a "very strong sterling" and low productivity for the Wolverhampton complex's difficulties.

The letter discloses that a total shutdown - which would devastate the midlands town - is the third "intention" under a phased run-down being considered by the US-based rubber corporation.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has "expressed concern" and, according to the note, "explained the possibility of governmental support to preserve employment".

The firm is seeking big job losses, wage cuts, new working practices and a 25% productivity rise to save at least part of the operation. Unions have offered a three-year wage freeze and entered into talks over job losses in a desperate bid to save the plant.

Goodyear's claims about the impact of the high pound will strengthen the hand of the cabinet's pro-euro group - in cluding Mr Byers - who are pressing the prime minister to step up the government's campaign to join the single currency. Sixty per cent of last year's production was shipped to the European mainland, the US and the Middle East.

The group's senior UK executives have privately told MPs in the West Midlands for months that the pound's fluctuations were undermining a plant that has exported more than 300m tyres since it opened in 1927.

Goodyear is merging its European business with Dunlop, which operates a tyre plant in Birmingham where 600 job cuts were recently announced.

Ken Purchase, Labour MP for Wolverhampton North East and an aide to pro-euro foreign secretary Robin Cook, said yesterday: "The workforce are the victims of the high pound as much as anyone else on the industrial scene.

"It is a major, major factor, and Goodyear has been paying a currency penalty it cannot afford." Shutting Wolverhampton is the final step of three in the memo written by Vernon Dunckel, Goodyear's senior vice-president for global product supply, to David Ritchie, the director of the government's West Midlands office.

Under step one, 515 jobs would go as car tyre production was reduced from 17,000 to to 12,000 a day, and that of truck tyres from 2,100 to 1,450. Step two would slash another 650 jobs, ending truck output, reducing the number of farm tyres made and ceasing all exports. Step three states: "Close plant and supply from other UK location and from the continent." Goodyear closed plants in Argentina and Italy last year and Mr Dunckel wrote: "In all cases, it is in Goodyear's interest to salvage a troubled operation and all the involved employees.

"We realise that to do less is very painful in terms of lives and families and in cost to the company. In short, we restructure only after much thought, study, time and as a last resort."

 Electrical group Morphy Richards yesterday blamed the strong pound and cheap foreign imports for the loss of 120 jobs at its Mexborough factory in south Yorkshire.

webTitle: Airbus super jumbo given go-ahead but BA will not buy

fields.headline: Airbus super jumbo given go-ahead but BA will not buy
fields.trailText: Europe launched its most sustained assault on US supremacy in the global aircraft industry yesterday when Airbus, the four-nation consortium, gave the go-ahead for the 555-seater A3XX to take on Boeing's jumbo jets and turned itself into a fully-fledged corporation.
fields.body:
Europe launched its most sustained assault on US supremacy in the global aircraft industry yesterday when Airbus, the four-nation consortium, gave the go-ahead for the 555-seater A3XX to take on Boeing's jumbo jets and turned itself into a fully-fledged corporation.

But the prospect of capturing a large slice of the long-haul market suffered a blow when British Airways, one of the 20 original launch partners of the European super-jumbo, said it had no plans to buy it - in contrast to the welcome from Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic for a plane that can fly 15,000km from Los Angeles to Sydney non-stop.

Airbus said the £8bn A3XX project would create or sustain 160,000 jobs across Europe, including 22,000 in the UK, but BAE Systems cast a serious doubt over its plans to build the wings at a new plant at its Broughton factory in north Wales and create 1,400 jobs.

BAE executives said the wings could be assembled at its Filton complex near Bristol, other UK locations or elsewhere in Europe unless the national assembly for Wales agreed to put up £25m in aid for the new plant in Flintshire. First secretary Rhodri Morgan has so far turned down the request.

British Airways said: "Our strategy is to reduce capacity by 12% over the next three years and to buy long-range aircraft which are smaller than the 747-400 series." It merely held out the chance of buying the A3XX in the longer term.

At the Paris launch of the Airbus Integrated Company, chief executive Noel Forgeard said the European super-jumbo could enter service late in 2005 or early 2006 and eight airlines had shown firm interest in buying 52 aircraft.

Sir Richard said the plane would make Virgin more competitive by offering cheaper seats and services akin to those on a cruise ship.

Airbus said the A3XX, to be assembled in Toulouse, offered operating costs 15 to 20% lower than with a Boeing 747, 40% more volume and 35% more passengers. Maurice Flanagan, managing director of Emirates, the airline with options to buy ten jets, said there was an immediate demand for such a plane and "simple arithmetic" justified its cost.

BAE has won £530m from the government in repayable loans to launch the super-jumbo but Brian Fleet, head of its Broughton operation, said the national assembly's rejection of regional aid left a £25m hole in the group's business plan.

Mr Morgan's advisers said extra information given by BAE in support of its application for aid "still does not provide the detail to enable a decision which would be sound in terms of public accountability ... the application has not been rejected and remains open."

The UK group emerged as the clear winner of the protracted negotiations to turn the Airbus consortium into AIC. BAE retains its 20% stake, with the rest held by Eads, the group formed from the merger of Italy's Aerospatiale Matra, Germany's Dasa and Spain's Casa.

Eads, under pressure to reach a deal before its part-float on July 10, has agreed to surrender 5% of its stake to Alenia if the Italian company wants it. The UK group, which retains a veto on four key areas of AIC's business and two seats on the seven-strong board, said that in 1999, on a pro forma basis, Airbus would have earned 1.03bn euro on sales of 15.7bn euro - giving BAE consolidated operating profits of 207m euro on sales of 3.3bn euro.

webTitle: New setback for British Biotech in drugs trials

fields.headline: New setback for British Biotech in drugs trials
fields.standfirst: British Biotech
fields.trailText: British Biotech, the embattled drug development company, suffered a fresh setback yesterday when its cancer drug marimastat failed in a fourth successive clinical trial.
fields.body:
British Biotech, the embattled drug development company, suffered a fresh setback yesterday when its cancer drug marimastat failed in a fourth successive clinical trial.

The drug, which was once tipped as a revolutionary cure for all types of cancer, showed little benefit over a placebo in a study involving 160 patients with terminal brain tumours.

British Biotech's shares slumped 5p to 19.25p - their lowest point for nearly a year.

Finance director Tony Weir said: "It's disappointing for both us and the patients. Marimastat did perform better than the placebo, but the difference wasn't statistically significant."

Marimastat is supposed to surround malignant tumours and cut off the blood supply to them, making them shrink and eventually disappear. However, it has failed to work in a series of trials on gastric and pancreatic cancer.

Mr Weir said the company was still hopeful marimastat could work in a study to report later this year on patients with small-cell lung cancer - tumours in these cases tend to be much smaller: "If marimastat is going to give us a positive result, it will be in that study." However, he admitted there was a significant possibility that the drug would never reach the market.

In the trial results revealed yesterday, 90% of the patients taking a placebo died, against a slightly smaller proportion of deaths on marimastat. However, the difference between the death rates needed to be 17.5% to be statistically significant - a hurdle which the drug did not cross.

Analysts were not surprised by yesterday's news. Erling Refsum of Nomura said he believed the value of marimastat was equivalent to just 2p a share for British Biotech.

The company's prospects now depend on the progress of other drugs in its development portfolio. These include a follow-up to marimastat called BB-3644, a product for heart disease, and on several antibiotics.

However, there are fears that British Biotech's poor reputation is handicapping its efforts to license in further products. A dissident scientist, Andrew Millar, caused a collapse in the group's shares two years ago by predicting the demise of several key drugs - predictions which have turned out to be accurate.

webTitle: Postmaster shocked at armed robber's death

fields.headline: Postmaster shocked at armed robber's death
fields.trailText: A postmaster who stabbed an armed robber during a bungled raid on his rural shop said yesterday that he was shocked that the man had died.
fields.body:
A postmaster who stabbed an armed robber during a bungled raid on his rural shop said yesterday that he was shocked that the man had died.

Richard Watkins grappled with the intruder, who was armed with a sawn-off shotgun, and defended himself with a knife during the attempted hold-up at the isolated post office in Wolverley, near Kidderminster, Worcestershire, on Tuesday.

The raider, Scott Griffiths, 28, from Kingswinford, West Midlands, was later found fatally wounded in a car which is thought to have been used as a getaway vehicle.

Mr Watkins, 50, who was praised by police for his bravery, said he was grateful for the backing of many members of the public. He said in a statement: "I was shocked to learn that one of those involved later died from the injuries he received during the incident."

West Mercia police were yesterday still questioning three men in connection with the raid, having obtained extensions from magistrates for a further detention of 36 hours.

Four men and a woman were arrested in the West Midlands area after the attempted robbery. One man appeared at Wolverhampton crown court on Thursday on a separate matter and was remanded in custody, a West Mercia police spokesman said. The woman was released on police bail.

webTitle: Skipton is ruled out of court

fields.headline: Skipton is ruled out of court
fields.trailText: The Court of Appeal has ruled against the Skipton Building Society in a case which may help homeowners who have suffered repossessions at the hands of mortgage lenders.
fields.body:
The Court of Appeal has ruled against the Skipton Building Society in a case which may help homeowners who have suffered repossessions at the hands of mortgage lenders.

John Stott was sued by the Skipton when his business was unable to repay a loan secured on a warehouse in the Wirral. The Skipton took possession and sold it to the owner of adjoining premises for £122,500.

After deducting expenses that left just £118,000 to credit Mr Stott's account. However, by then there was £135,000 owing on the mortgage. In the Skipton's claim for the shortfall of £17,000, the same principles applied as if it had been his home that had been repossessed.

Mr Stott's defence was that the Skipton had sold the property at an undervalue. This argument, often raised by dispossessed homeowners, has been notoriously difficult to sustain in the courts. Properties that are the subject of forced sales may only fetch a proportion - typically about 85% - of what they would be worth if owner-occupied.

The Building Societies Act 1986 does, though, require the seller to take reasonable care to ensure the price is "the best that can reasonably be obtained". The judge found that in this case the Skipton had breached this duty, which it had actually delegated to Barclays Bank, which had been appointed receivers of the business.

Barclays hadn't advertised the property. Nor, when the bank received the approach from the neighbour, had it taken into account the "marriage" value of the two properties that made the warehouse particularly valuable to that would be-buyer.

Despite that finding, the judge was prepared to knock just £2,500 off the monies claimed by the Skipton, and gave it judgment for the remaining £15,500. He reasoned that it was far from certain that marketing the property more positively would actually have led to an increased price. All Mr Stott had lost was a smallish chance of selling it for more.

That parsimonious approach is in keeping with how the courts have previously approached disputes of this sort, making many lawyers reluctant to encourage their clients to contest "negative equity" cases.

However, the Court of Appeal took a different view, and disallowed the Skipton's entire claim. There had been clear evidence that the property was worth £152,000 on the market. To reduce that, because there was a forced sale, was not appropriate in a situation where the buyer might have been willing to pay over that market price, as the property was uniquely important to him.

Once there is evidence that a property had been sold at an undervalue, the courts should no longer assume that the fact of the forced sale reduced the price. The lender would still have to have taken reasonable steps to secure that value.

Anyone being chased by a lender for arrears that existed after their home was repossessed should rely on this case if they are not satisfied. It may be that lenders will have to adjust their arrears figures in cases where the price was suspiciously low.

If estate agents were used to sell the property, they would need to show they marketed it in the same way that they did other properties. Some will simply take the first offer that comes along where there is a sale in these circumstances.

If the property was left in a poor condition by owners forced to leave, that will reduce the value, and the lender is under no obligation to repair it. However, the fact of the forced sale itself often won't affect the value at all. Indeed, the fact that there is no owner-occupier means that there is no chain and that the seller can be flexible about completion dates. This, in turn, might actually slightly increase the price that should be obtained.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

That parsimonious approach is in keeping with how the courts have previously approached disputes of this sort, making many lawyers reluctant to encourage their clients to contest "negative equity" cases. However, the Court of Appeal took a different view, and disallowed the Skipton's entire claim. There had been clear evidence that the property was worth £152,000 on the market. To reduce that, because there was a forced sale, was not appropriate in a situation where the buyer might have been willing to pay over that market price, as the property was uniquely important to him. Once there is evidence that a property had been sold at an undervalue, the courts should no longer assume that the fact of the forced sale reduced the price. The lender would still have to have taken reasonable steps to secure that value. Anyone being chased by a lender for arrears that existed after their home was repossessed should rely on this case if they are not satisfied. It may be that lenders will have to adjust their arrears figures in cases where the price was suspiciously low. If estate agents were used to sell the property, they would need to show they marketed it in the same way that they did other properties. Some will simply take the first offer that comes along where there is a sale in these circumstances. If the property was left in a poor condition by owners forced to leave, that will reduce the value, and the lender is under no obligation to repair it. However, the fact of the forced sale itself often won't affect the value at all. Indeed, the fact that there is no owner-occupier means that there is no chain and that the seller can be flexible about completion dates. This, in turn, might actually slightly increase the price that should be obtained.  Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Art boom reaching political cartoons
fields.standfirst: Prints by James Gillray may not stay cheap, so a sale featuring a examples of his work is worth a look, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Prints by James Gillray may not stay cheap, so a sale featuring a examples of his work is worth a look, says Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
Illustrators have been enjoying a well-publicised boom in recent years. This is particularly true of illustrators of children's books. Original pen and ink drawings by Arthur Rackham and EH Shepherd of Winnie-the-Pooh fame have been known to fetch tens of thousands of pounds.

Less elevated, but also popular, are political cartoons - they can realise thousands of pounds. Many people think the political cartoon properly began with Punch magazine. Punch, which was founded in 1841, was the Victorian periodical with consistently the funniest and most finely drawn cartoons. Radical at first, it later reflected establishment views.

John Leech was the first notable cartoonist for Punch and he was affectionately satirical. When Punch entered its second decade in 1851 he was joined by John Tenniel, later Sir John Tenniel, who adopted his styles. Originals by these two can cost anything thing from a few hundreds of pounds to a few thousand.

But although Punch might be thought of as introducing the modern definition of "cartoon" as a comic drawing, the political cartoon in Britain had much earlier provenance. During the reigns of George III and IV at the turn of the 19th century were a group of artists known as the caricaturists. Their drawings were comic portrayals of famous politicians, personalities and royal figures of the day. They distorted and exaggerated, with humans coming out of snail shells and gargoyle-like portrayals.

William Hogarth (1697-1764) is generally recognised as throwing off French and Italian influence and establishing an English visual style.

Among the best-known of the caricaturists are Thomas Stothard (1755-1834), Thomas Rowlandson (1736-1827) and Isaac Cruikshank (1764 -1811). But considered to be the most important and influential caricaturist of his day was James Gillray (1757-1815).

On Monday June 26 Phillips is holding a sale of prints. There will be a wide choice of etchings and lithographs from Picasso, Rembrandt, Salvador Dali and other famous printmakers. But the centrepiece of the sale is a rare collection of caricatures by Gillray.

There are more than 200 prints which were originally housed in two separate albums and collectively they are expected to fetch around £50,000. Robert Kennon, specialist at Phillips, says: "It is very rarely you see this kind of collection. The last time a large number of Gillray prints came on to the market was 10 years ago. Gillray was very much the master. You can still see his influence today in the work of Gerald Scarfe and Ralph Steadman."

I am reminded how relevant Gillray is to modern times every time I go to my doctor. He is a Gillray buff and behind his desk is a print entitled simply "Gout". It is a blue monster octopus figure with grotesque eyes sinking its teeth into a gnarled foot. Gout attacks the joints, usually the toe joints and is very painful. The Gillray cartoon captures the affliction better than volumes of words and is often used to illustrate articles even now.

Gillray's prints were published by Mrs Hannah Humphrey, whose shop was at 37 New Bond Street. New prints were pasted in the windows and contemporary images of the time show crowds jostling to get a look at the latest print. In an age when there was no television and newspapers contained few images, prints were all the rage. Customers would buy or collect them or even rent them out for an evening as a source of amusement for guests at a dinner party.

Likely to be the most expensive at the Phillips sale is Plumb Pudding in Danger (1805), caricaturing Napoleon and William Pitt sitting down to a feast in the shape of the globe, which they are about to carve up between them. This is estimated at £1,000-£1,500 but should easily realise £2,000.

Another example, The Loyal Toast (1798), refers to the London Correspondence Society, a radical group that closely followed the ideology of Thomas Paine, author of The Rights of Man. The society consisted mainly of tradesman who were fighting for the right to vote. Gillray represents them with subhuman, ape-like features. This is estimated at £300-£400.

If these sound cheap compared to the prices of Rackham and Shepherd I have quoted above, well, they are. It is because they are etchings. They were made before wood carvings or lithographs were invented and certainly before photocomposition allowed the use of original pen and ink drawings in illustration.

Gillray would often run off hundreds in one day - the equivalent of a Steve Bell cartoon in the Guardian today. Gillray only illustrated one book and his work can be even cheaper than his contemporary Stothard, who painted watercolours.

But they might not remain cheap. They are becoming increasingly rare with the passage of time, even though printed in volume. Next year the Tate Modern is planning an exhibition of Gillray's work. This always does wonders for prices.

 Phillips, tel: 020-7495-0227.

webTitle: A picnicker's guide to the world of wicker

fields.headline: A picnicker's guide to the world of wicker
fields.standfirst: Summer is here at last, bringing with it the urge for open-air dining. Richard Nelsson looks at the range of hampers available
fields.trailText: Summer is here at last, bringing with it the urge for open-air dining. Richard Nelsson looks at the range of hampers available.
fields.body:
It only takes a few rays of sunshine to appear and people get the urge to have a picnic. Whether it's on a windswept beach with the family or sitting on the lawn at Glyndebourne, the outing is one of those great British traditions enjoyed by all ages and classes.

Dictionaries define a picnic as an excursion on which people bring food to be eaten in the open air - no matter that it often ends up being interrupted by rain.

The hamper is the traditional way to carry all the plates and glasses as well as the smoked salmon or, if you prefer, fish paste sandwiches. It is usually made from willow, although sometimes rattan is used.

Hampers probably originated from a time when the rich travelled long distances without knowing if there would be a suitable place to eat on the way.

The design has not changed much over the years although they may now contain a Thermos flask and a wine cooler.

Picnic purists insist on real glass and china, but items made from plastic or melamine are unbreakable, lighter and certainly cheaper. Baskets are also sold on their own without fittings.

The world leader in hamper manufacturing, Optima, based in west Sussex, has been making them for more than half a century. It produces 60,000 each year and has an annual turnover of nearly £3m.

Its hampers are available from shops such as John Lewis. As well as ceramic plates, stainless steel cutlery and co-ordinating napkins, all the hampers come with a five-year guarantee.

The original design, the Epsom, which is available in two-, four- and six-person sizes (£120 for four-person) includes bistro glasses in a willow tray, while the popular Brittany (£69) is a basket with a large wicker handle and three designs of crockery from which to choose.

For those yearning for a romantic cycle ride along country lanes, it even produces a picnic basket (£75) - complete with all the fittings - that attaches to the front of your bike.

W Gadsby and Son, which has been in the basket business since 1864, produces a wide range of classic hampers. Its two-person Essential model costs around £52, but for a real open-air feast, there is the luxury Majestic. The eight-person set (£480) includes china cups in their own basket and stainless steel flasks.

Perhaps the most famous name associated with the hamper is Fortnum and Mason. Its baskets come either packed with food from the famous food halls or fitted with top-quality hardware. Four-person sets range in price from £225 to £775 for one with crystal glasses and china crockery. It also sells baskets on their own, with prices starting at £15.

For special occasions, such as a regatta or the opera, there is a hiring service which provides a fully equipped hamper plus food. The Enclosure which, naturally, includes Champagne and Chablis is £140 plus £150 deposit.

There again, if all you're after is a few unbreakable plates and something to pour a cold drink into, there are numerous basic picnic sets to choose from. Woolworths has 20-piece traditional looking hampers starting at £20, while Next (through the Next Directory) offers a stylish four-person semi-circular hamper for £29.99.

If you can't decide what type of hamper you need, consider a spot of e-picnicking. Classic Hampers has a wide selection of baskets both with and without food, that can be ordered over the internet and delivered anywhere in the UK. The Fitted Picnic Hamper costs £188, which includes food, while buying just the basket and hardware will set you back £151.

While they're objects of desire for the traditionalist, a heavy hamper is totally impracticable for carrying across rough terrain. They were obviously de signed with a strong chauffeur in mind.

To reach a secret picnic spot that involves more than a gentle stroll, picnic backpacks have been developed.

Country Harvest, which is based in Ingleton, sells an insulated pack that stands vertically for maximum protection and easy access to the contents (£60 for a deluxe four-person set).

Optima's Voyager range is insulated too and its picnic packs come complete with melamine plates and plastic glasses but real cutlery (£45 for the two-person basket).

A simple yet adequate set is a plastic duffle bag from Bhs (£10) that contains lightweight plastic crockery for four people.

Optima also produces a picnic stroller (£195), which at first glance looks like one of the wheeled shopping baskets favoured by the older generation. However, it is unbeatable for transporting large amounts of food and picnicking equipment across a field, even in cluding insulated sections to keep your food and drinks chilled.

It may sound romantic to have a bottle cooling in a babbling brook, but to ensure the wine is at just the right temperature it's advisable to take an insulated carrier. John Lewis sells a neoprene cool bag with carrying strap for £17.50.

For afternoon tea or ice-cold soft drinks, a Thermos flask is essential. These now come in hi-tech unbreakable designs with a lifetime guarantee. The Aladdin (£31 from John Lewis) includes a shoulder strap and is a cool green colour.

To bring that final touch of civilisation to the wilds, invest in a rug such as the woollen ones (£16) made by W Gadsby. Alternatively, Tesco sells a wool rug that's waterproof on one side for £30.

Who to contact

Optima: 01903-744111, www.optima-co.co.uk/
W.Gadsby & Son: 01823-698259, www.gadsby.co.uk/
Fortnum: 020-7734-8040, www.fortnumandmason.com
Classic Hampers: 020-7813-1003, orders.mkn.co.uk/ hampers/classic/en
Country Harvest: 015242-42223, www.country-harvest.co.uk/
Next: 0845-600-7000.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Since first spotting their basal leaves nestling close to the ground, as far back as last November, I have been checking regularly on some orchids growing on an area of so-called derelict land down by the canal.
fields.body:
South Yorkshire

Since first spotting their basal leaves nestling close to the ground, as far back as last November, I have been checking regularly on some orchids growing on an area of so-called derelict land down by the canal.

Last week they identified themselves - as delicate, but spectacular, bee orchids came into flower. And not just the three plants originally seen, but eight flower spikes in all, scattered among the building rubble of an old foundry site.

Our native orchids are fickle plants. Despite their delicate nature - the roots must not dry out and they need symbiotic fungi to aid the take up of nutrients, they often turn up in unusual places. Fifteen years ago a common spotted orchid flourished in the tiny front garden of an empty terraced house close to Rotherham town centre. The next occupant built a three-foot high wall, and that was the end of the orchids.

At the back of an industrial estate by the River Rother, a colony of southern marsh and common spotted hybrids thrives on a slope of old colliery spoil, while further south, bee orchids have popped up in the middle of a filled in sand bunker on our local golf course.

Our best orchid site locally used to be a bean field. It grew poor crops of beans and so was left fallow for a couple of years. Now, bee, common spotted and greater-butterfly orchids are all in flower at this moment. There is even a white-flowered bee orchid, as opposed to the more usual lilac and deep red and yellow lipped bloom, which are supposed to mimic bumblebees.

If the markings and colours of the blooms are part of the plant reproduction strategy, then the white variety ought to die out. We must not get too fixated with orchids, beautiful though they are. The meadow has many competing attractions. Wild liquorice, for example, lies tucked away in a corner and there is lots and lots of yellow rattle, St John's wort and yellow loosestrife.

Not bad for a field that never exactly amounted to a hill of beans.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: President's relatives flee
fields.body:
President's relatives flee

The family of the Guatemalan president, Alfonso Portillo, have left the country because they received kidnap threats after he refused to grant clemency to two criminals from the so-called Los Pasaco gang in jail awaiting execution.

The gang specialises in kidnapping for ransom. The two condemned men abducted a distillery heiress in 1997, took the ransom money then killed her. The president's mother, sister and other relatives have flown to Canada.
Duncan Campbell, Los Angeles

Rare victory for Serb opposition

The general manager of the Yugoslav state news agency, Tanjug, has been fined for libelling two opposition leaders, the agency said yesterday - a rare conviction against a loyal official of President Slobodan Milosevic's government.

Dusan Djordjevic was ordered by a local judge to pay about £350 after Zoran Djindjic and Vladan Batic sued, saying their rights had been violated by a Tanjug article accusing them of raising political tension.

But the fine was small compared those imposed on the independent and opposition media. Unpopular and facing an election, Mr Milosevic has stepped up pressure on dissenters.

Yesterday the government launched legal proceedings against the main printing press used by independent newspapers and non-government publications in Serbia.
AP, Belgrade

Work-to-death firm pays family

Japan's biggest advertising company, Dentsu, admitted liability yesterday for the suicide of an overworked employee and agreed to pay the man's parents 168m yen (about £1m).

The supreme court ruled against Dentsu in March: the first time a company had been found liable for a case of karoshi - death from overwork.

Ichiro Oshima killed himself in 1991 at the age of 24 after working an average of 80 hours a week, sometimes on shifts from 9am until 6am the next day.
Reuters, Tokyo

Kennedy crash was pilot error

Nearly a year after John Kennedy Jr's plane crashed into the sea, killing him, his wife and her sister, transport investigators have decided that their initial suspicions were correct: the son of the late US president became disoriented in the night sky and lost control of the plane.

Sources said pilot error caused the crash off Massachusetts.
AP, Washington

webTitle: Amazon falls as analysts pile on gloom

fields.headline: Amazon falls as analysts pile on gloom
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Amazon.com was pummelled on Wall Street yesterday with the on-line retailer's shares losing more than 20% of their value after two leading analysts issued warnings about its long-term prospects.
fields.body:
Amazon.com was pummelled on Wall Street yesterday with the on-line retailer's shares losing more than 20% of their value after two leading analysts issued warnings about its long-term prospects.

The most damning of the reports was issued by analysts at Lehman Brothers, who questioned its high debt, negative cash flow and poor working capital management.

Those comments added to an already negative sentiment caused by influential internet analyst Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter who said she saw little potential for improvement in the shares.

Until now, Amazon.com had been considered one of the dot.com companies with a strong chance of survival. A recent report by Barron's, the leading Wall Street publication, calculated that Amazon had enough cash to last 35 months, a relatively long period in internet time. The company is also an investor in other internet companies.

However, the analysts at Lehman advised investors to avoid a new bond issue - essentially a loan - to the company. fields.headline: Philip Windsor
fields.standfirst: Devoted scholar of world affairs whose subtle approach left its mark on generations of LSE students
fields.trailText: The lasting reputation of Philip Windsor, who has died aged 64, is as a brilliant, subtle and idiosyncratic international relations teacher at the London School of Economics. fields.body:
The lasting reputation of Philip Windsor, who has died aged 64, is as a brilliant, subtle and idiosyncratic international relations teacher at the London School of Economics. In his heyday in the 1960s and 1970s, he left a deep intellectual mark on generations of students, in front of whom he turned the sometimes mundane and orthodox subject of strategic studies into an exciting field of intellectual endeavour - and a key to understanding the 20th century.

His approach, influenced by a remarkable breadth of reading which began when he was a child, was based, above all, on imagination, intuition and an interest in big issues. In his lectures (always a high-wire act delivered without notes), and in discussions over a drink, he displayed a gift for understanding the different intellectual traditions and national mental frameworks that are at the heart of most international problems.

Already in the 1960s, more than two decades before the collapse of the Soviet empire, he sensed that the decline in communist ideology, the growth of diversity in eastern Europe and the skilful pursuit of detente could all lead to fundamental change. He also knew that the process would be marked by two features that were central to his vision of the world and, indeed, to his own life: tragic reverses and absurd paradoxes.

Windsor was born in India. Both his parents were fundamentalist Christians. His father, William, was in the Indian army - becoming an officer through the ranks - and his mother, Winifred, had been in the Salvation Army. Following his father's peripatetic career, he attended the City of Norwich grammar school, and then the Royal grammar school, High Wycombe, where he was deeply influenced by the history teacher, Joe Ashford, and encouraged to apply to Oxford.

Securing a scholarship, quaintly called a postmastership, at Merton College, he studied modern history in 1954-57. An apparently reserved undergraduate, he got a good second-class degree. His curiously angular handwriting, which necessitated getting his scripts typed, baffled the examiners - as, later, it was to baffle others.

With the encouragement of one of his Merton teachers, John Roberts, Windsor then migrated across Oxford to the more cosmopolitan environment of St Antony's College, where he took the BPhil in European history. He benefited there from the guidance of James Joll, whose recommendation secured him a graduate scholarship at the Free University Berlin for 1959-60.

In a letter to Joll from Berlin in November 1959, Windsor wrote: "This city is so confusing that the longer one stays, the more contradictory one's impressions become." The following month, he noted: "I don't think I have the stability for an academic life." These letters convey his enduring sense that the more one knows, the less one knows, or at least the less certainty there can be; and that there are more interesting things to do than write plodding academic theses on small subjects.

Windsor's first book, written after his return to England, was City On Leave: A History Of Berlin 1945-1962, published in 1963. Its central conclusion stands the test of time. In the aftermath of the building of the Berlin Wall in August 1961, he had the boldness to write: "The essential preliminary to an eventual Soviet withdrawal from eastern Europe is an initial acknowledgement of the division of Germany."

His next book, Arms And Stability In Europe, was also published in 1963. This was co-authored with Alastair Buchan, the first director of the Institute for Strategic Studies, where Windsor worked as a research assistant in 1961-64. The study helped point the young institute in the direction of tough-minded advocacy of detente, which became its hallmark. In late 1964, Windsor got a one-year Rockefeller Foundation grant to work on a study of Germany and eastern Europe.

In 1965, he was appointed to a lecturership in the LSE's international relations department. That October, when he arrived, I had just been admitted as a research student. As supervisor, he was a technical failure, at least by today's wretched, quango-imposed standards based on completion of doctorates.

Progress on my thesis was deferred by our joint authorship of the book, Czechoslovakia: 1968. Windsor wrote most of his part of the book in a single night, fortified by a liberal supply of typing paper, coffee and scotch. We also collaborated on other projects, one fictional, one fictitious. When I eventually wrote a sort of thesis, he was no more interested than I was in seeing it submitted for a doctorate; the important thing was to publish it as a book.

I owe him an enduring debt of gratitude for acting in accord with his belief that the subject-matter of international relations mattered more than academic titles and procedures. He himself never applied for a professorship; he remained a reader in international relations, and plain Mr Windsor.

He was in great demand outside LSE as a commentator and lecturer, especially with military audiences. Although he had missed national service because of his student status, he enjoyed his meetings with officers, especially in the British forces; they, in turn, valued his unique style and understanding of strategic issues.

For some years, Windsor wrote productively, mainly on the themes of German reunification and detente, on which he published books in 1969 and 1971. His interests expanded to many other countries which had known tragedy in the 20th century, whether as victims or perpetrators or both - the Soviet Union, Israel, Poland and Japan. He wrote and broadcast about them with elegance and passion.

On Britain, in a memorable Personal View on Radio 3 in 1969, he argued with characteristic insight and prejudice that the tradition of radical dissent, which had once been concerned with improving the world, had become "a means of introspection pure and simple".

Windsor's own life was not free of tragedy and paradox. He believed that being an intellectual involved smoking, drinking, trouble with the bank manager - and more. At times, he could be surprisingly dismissive of individuals. He was not close to his immediate relatives, and some of his relationships were tumultuous. However, he often showed extraordinary warmth and sensitivity, and sustained many long friendships. In March 1979, he married Rina Efrat, but from 1987 they lived apart.

By the time of the collapse of communism and the reunification of Germany in 1989-91, Windsor had become less productive, at least with the written word. However, his former students, inheriting something of his qualities of subtlety and sensitivity, were in positions of influence in many countries, and helped to shape events.

In the last three years, he was in a frail physical state, the final year being spent in a nursing home. His conversation retained its sparkle, wit and element of gallows humour to the end.

fields.headline: Sohrab Godrej
fields.trailText: From the 1970s, the industrialist Sohrab "Soli" Godrej, who has died aged 88, headed the vast Indian combine, the Godrej group. He was also, as India's president KR Narayanan observed, a philanthropist with a sense of social commitment, and a man who focused on the problem of population explosion. His interests also took in scientific management, the environment, archaeology and conservation.
fields.body:
From the 1970s, the industrialist Sohrab "Soli" Godrej, who has died aged 88, headed the vast Indian combine, the Godrej group. He was also, as India's president KR Narayanan observed, a philanthropist with a sense of social commitment, and a man who focused on the problem of population explosion. His interests also took in scientific management, the environment, archaeology and conservation.

The Godrej Group was born more than a century ago, when the firm's founder, Ardeshire Godrej, began making locks. The empire over which Sohrab came to preside was part of Indian life, taking in soaps, safes, insecticides, refrigerators - and, in the 1990s, global collaboration with companies like General Electric and Sarah Lee. The Godrej dynasty, meanwhile, established a reputation for paternalistic benevolence as one of the great industrial families of the sub-continent.

A Parsi (Zoroastrian) by religion, Sohrab took a science degree from St Xavier College in Mumbai (Bombay). After his father's death in 1973, he became chairman of Godrej Soaps and Godrej & Boyce. He was president emeritus of the World Wildlife Fund for Nature (India) - he was presented with the white pelican award by Prince Philip - and a governor of India's Population Foundation. In 1999, he was awarded the prestigious Padma Bhushan.

He never married. The best philosophy, he observed, is "to do the best one can."

fields.headline: Adolph Hofner
fields.standfirst: Spinning old Europe's folk music into an all-American country sound
fields.trailText: The American melting pot boils particularly hot in south Texas. Few musicians demonstrated its effects more dramatically than the bandleader Adolph Hofner, who has died aged 83. In a career extending over more than half a century, he produced a unique, all-American alloy of country crooning, polkas and western swing.
fields.body:
The American melting pot boils particularly hot in south Texas. Few musicians demonstrated its effects more dramatically than the bandleader Adolph Hofner, who has died aged 83. In a career extending over more than half a century, he produced a unique, all-American alloy of country crooning, polkas and western swing.

He was born in Moulton, between Houston and San Antonio. His father was part-German and his mother Czech; he spoke Czech as his first language, and the first music he remembered was that of polka bands playing for community dances. Soon the gramophone introduced him to more mainstream idioms, including the then popular Hawaiian music.

"That's what got me and my brother started on strings," Hofner recalled, "Hawaiian guitars." He and Emil, who was two years younger, took a guitar course, called themselves the Hawaiian Serenaders and began playing in San Antonio clubs, where the family had moved, for 40 or 50 cents a night.

"My main object," said Hofner, "was to sing." He listened to the records and broadcasts of the new crooners, Bing Crosby and Russ Columbo. Then, in the mid-1930s, he was inspired by the fresh, and deeply Texan, sound of western swing, especially the brilliant band led by Fort Worth's Milton Brown.

"I even changed my style of singing to try to sound like Milton," said Hofner. "So I got into this western [music] because that's what was paying off, but I kept my popular right along with it." He joined another swing band, Jimmie Revard's Oklahoma Playboys, and toured with them through the Rio Grande valley - but their music was too jazzy and modern for small-town taste, and they ended up, as he remembered feelingly 40 years later, eating "boloney for breakfast, dinner and supper."

For a couple of years, Hofner bobbed up on various bands' records as rhythm guitarist and featured vocalist. His 1938 recording of It Makes No Difference Now, with Tom Dickey's Showboys, was a jukebox hit in Texas, and he was signed to the same label, RCA Victor's Bluebird, as a bandleader in his own right - though the Bluebird scout saw his future mainly as a singer of western-flavoured pop songs.

The scout, Hofner recalled, aimed to make another Crosby out of him - and, indeed, his recording of Maria Elena had the same ambience of wide, sunlit plains as Bing's Don't Fence Me In. At the same 1940 session, Hofner made polka recordings for Bluebird's foreign-language catalogue, the band's up-to-date sound of twin fiddles and amplified steel guitar curiously contrasting with Adolph and Emil's close-harmony duets in Czech.

In 1941, Hofner made what he believed to be the first record of the exuberant Texas dance tune, Cotton-Eyed Joe. That, and other hit records, put him on the circuit of dance-halls around Los Angeles, catering to the thousands of Americans who had deserted the southwest for war work in the shipyards and munitions factories of southern California.

Concerned about the effect of his name, he carefully billed his personal appearances as by Dolph Hofner & His San Antonians, but his new label, Okeh Records - after initially promoting him as the "husky he-man, leader of one of the west's outstanding string bands" - nervously cut back his releases, and soon let him go.

The late 1940s and early 50s saw a revival of polka music in Polish, Czech and German communities throughout the United States, and Hofner, back in San Antonio, concentrated on playing the tunes of his youth, in settings that evoked his varied musical experi ence, partnered, as ever, by Emil, playing his little Rickenbacker steel guitar.

In 1950, he gained the sponsorship of Pearl Beer, and, for the next 30-odd years, his Pearl Wranglers band-bus was one of the familiar sights of San Antonio. He broadcast on station KTSA, put out records of both swing tunes and polkas on the local Sarg label (giving an early recording opportunity to the teenaged Doug Sahm), and played regularly at the Farmer's Daughter.

It was in that beautifully preserved, 50s-styled dance-hall that he and the Wranglers were filmed in 1986 for a Channel 4 series, The A To Z Of C&W. The band's great days were plainly far behind them, but when Hofner sang, or talked on camera to the presenter Hank Wangford, he exuded the charm that had once made him a hillbilly heartthrob.

Hofner continued to play until incapacitated by a stroke in 1993. He leaves his wife Susan, a son and two daughters.

fields.headline: What future for father?
fields.standfirst: Face to Faith
fields.trailText: The Jewish and, therefore, also the Christian story, says that humanity is made in God's image. We are mysteriously cloned from a divine model. We are not God but - though flawed - we are like God. On that assumption, Christians have built a composite picture of God, modelled on the human race. If we are like God, then God must be something like us.
fields.body:
The Jewish and, therefore, also the Christian story, says that humanity is made in God's image. We are mysteriously cloned from a divine model. We are not God but - though flawed - we are like God. On that assumption, Christians have built a composite picture of God, modelled on the human race. If we are like God, then God must be something like us.

The Jewish lyricist, EY "Yip" Harburg, saw the problem: does God make us, or do we make God?

Poems are made by fools
like me
But only God can make a
tree;
And only God who makes
the tree
Also makes the fools like
me.
But only fools like me, you
see,
Can make a God, who
makes a tree.

Jewish spirituality began the process of imagining God by creating a father figure. However, the Jews were forbidden to make images of God - no picture, no sculpture. Christians abandoned this reasonable constraint, as the art in churches and galleries shows.

To bridge the chasm between the father-creator and the real world, the Christian story takes Judaism a step further, bringing God down to earth as the young rabbi, Jesus of Nazareth. God is still God, but is now also fully human, doing away with our need to recreate him by an act of the imagination. Jesus is real: a brother, both human and divine, son of God and the son of man, prototype of perfect humanity.

But how do you assure people that both the father and the son are ever present? By the affirmation that their spirit permanently sustains the whole creation. So, the Christian deity comes to be worshipped in three forms, father, son and spirit: the Holy Trinity. The church was not truly constituted until the followers of Jesus were spirit-filled. The feast of Pentecost, popularly called Whitsuntide, celebrates God's ever present and enlivening soul.

Folk religion in Britain now hangs on a very thin thread. Christmas survives, largely thanks to its commercialisation. Easter hangs on with its barely-remembered message of death and resurrection. But Pentecost, as a secular holiday, has gone. Holy days, if they survive at all, are called bank holidays.

Clearly, God needs to be rehabilitated if Christian faith is to have a future. Hitherto, the image-makers have virtually all been men. Like much of our culture, church history is patriarchal. That needs to change. If humanity is made in God's image, then surely God must be both male and female. The father and son images are too deeply ingrained, through their biblical context, to be credibly complemented with mother and sister images.

But there simply is no excuse for going on worshipping a male Holy Spirit. She, as the wisdom of God, Sophia, constantly revitalises all that is. And if, as tradition has it, her presence is symbolised by the descent of a white dove, why, oh why, a male dove? Simple: the patriarchs could not admit that women, not men, personify so much that is best in life: beauty, grace and love.

At least some great medieval artists dared to break the mould. Michelangelo's wonderful image of the father, stretching out his hand to create man, has a beautiful woman at the father's shoulder, inspiring him. And, in 1923, an enchanting mural emerged in the Bavarian village church of Urschalling. Painted around 1400, it was probably whitewashed over after the harsh decrees of the Council of Trent.

A woman cleaner found it as the paint began to peel off: a depiction of the Holy Trinity, Father and Son embracing, between them, a young woman, the Holy Spirit. So there be no mistake, the unknown artist even added, at the feet of the Trinity, where their cloaks meet, the unambiguous image of her labia, the entrance to the womb.

Could the Trinity really embrace sexuality? Never, never, declared the church. But it had to redress its male image to satisfy popular piety, so it declared Mary, the mother of Jesus, to be the immaculate, sexless Queen of Heaven, to be adored, but not worshipped, not on equality with her son. Popular Orthodox and Catholic piety ignored the fine distinction, but theologians decreed that Mary was neither god nor priest. These were male preserves.

That the son - the radical rabbi who counter-culturally never married, but publicly treated women with exceptional respect - may, just may, have been gay (as Bishop Montefiore once tentatively suggested to widespread horror) would further broaden our vision of an all-embracing, universal God.

With art and poetry coming to the rescue, this God may yet have a popular future in our culture, a God who reflects our total human condition, male and female, a God who personifies justice, freedom and peace, casting every esoteric sect into sentimental irrelevance. Such a God may yet rekindle the world's faith, hope and love: a God of much, much more than our imagining.

fields.headline: Baroque breakdance
fields.standfirst: Montalvo-Hervieu's new work is eye-boggling, says Keith Watson
fields.trailText: Montalvo-Hervieu's new work is eye-boggling, says Keith Watson
fields.body:
Stumbling in on a performance by French dance company Montalvo-Hervieu, you could be forgiven for thinking you are under the influence of some very strong psychedelic drug. Humans turn into flamingos, a flamenco trio segues into Queen's We Will Rock You.

The effect is like channel surfing through 100 TV stations, each showing a different style of dance. Breakdance collides with ballet in a scratch-edit of movement that makes the unlikeliest of connections seem plausible: maybe Vivaldi was a hip hop renegade master after all. That may sound gimmicky, and Montalvo-Hervieu's style is unashamedly crowd-pleasing; indeed, the accessible, engaging troupe has become one of France's most successful exports. But there is a method in the madness of the company's latest work, Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito.

It is a "happy eulogy to cosmopolitanism," according to choreographer José Montalvo, a man much given to lyrical flights of fancy about his work and inspired by the dance festivals of his childhood. "An amazing multi-colour tribe participated. At night, in the heart of drunkenness and the hide-and-seek of desire, the dancing and singing transformed everyone.

Each individual became virtuosos for one moment." Taking that as his starting point, Montalvo has assembled a line-up of 18 performers who are all expert in their varied fields. His trick is to throw acrobats and baroque stylists on stage together and exploit the flying sparks. It could turn out an unholy mess. But such is the company's exuberance that Montalvo succeeds in rolling back the years using dance as a metaphor for the innocence of youth.

Most remarkable are the connections between apparently disparate forms. Using the kind of call-and-response interplay more readily associated with old soul records, dancers from contrasting styles bounce moves off each other as proof that dance is an international language. Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito's title is drawn from the curious collages of surrealist master Max Ernst, and his sense of deranged imagery is at play in the film sequences that are intercut with the dancers.

Animals on screen compete in a curious posing contest with their human partners; balancing acts combine live and filmed performers. The result is a skewed take on the world that can throw in Wiseguys dance anthem Ooh La La La, US wrestling star Scotty Too Kool Taylor's trademark "worm" move (or maybe I was just seeing things) and a breakdancing Christmas tree, without pausing for breath. As Montalvo puts it: "It's a poetry of juxtaposition at the service of movement, desire, fantasy, dreams and childhood."

fields.headline: Now we are old
fields.standfirst: The Kirov's bright, technically brilliant young dancers make Judith Mackrell feel her age
fields.trailText: The Kirov's bright, technically brilliant young dancers make Judith Mackrell feel her age
fields.body:
As an artform, dance exists only at the moment of performance, but it is lovingly embalmed in the memories of its public. In the life of all fans there comes a point when they start to believe that dancers don't (and can't) perform the way they used to. This is a position of infuriating smugness to others. Young dancers rage at being judged by the ghosts of the past, while novice dance-goers are made to feel they are seeing only a dim echo of what was granted their elders.

The Kirov, as the world's greatest living ballet museum, inspires this generational oneupmanship all the time. When the company visited Britain in 1988 after 18 years' absence, older fans were quick to compare it with remembered glory days. Now those of us who became besotted with the company 12 years ago are showing our age by fretting over certain changes, especially among the company's youngest ballerinas.

The 24-year-old Diana Vishneva, for instance, is a dancer of exhilarating speed and attack who has developed a style that looks far more international than previous generations. Her power and personality illuminate comedy ballets such as Don Quixote and the 20th-century repertory (she has been outstanding this season in Balanchine's Rubies), but in the more classical context of Sleeping Beauty her qualities can jar, especially when compared with the very traditional Aurora danced by Zhanna Ayupova.

At 33, Ayupova is one of the few remaining principals trained in what has become old-school Kirov. This is a style more sculptural than linear, in which movements are embellished by a contrapuntal activity of head, eyes, shoulders and hands. Its beauties can be breathtakingly flukey, because they combine so many nuances of style and expression. It is also highly sociable, because each move connects spatially and dramatically to everything else on stage. When Ayupova dances, the focus of her gestures and her glance is always directed outside her: she isn't isolated within her own technical prowess.

By contrast, Uliana Lopatkina, 26, is a one-woman phenomenon whose boneless fluency and eerily extended line have become the ideal of her generation. Lopatkina moves as if her body were tuned by a far more sophisticated technology than the rest of us. But her exquisitely long lines are achieved at a cost. She is a dancer who is all limbs and feet, and her torso, which should be a radiant and responsive focus of energy, is a blank.

There are dramatic and musical dead points in her style as a consequence. So while her Nikiya in Monday's Bayadère was a marvel of supple control, it felt monochrome compared with performances I remember from Altynai Asylmuratova (who dances the role tonight). At 39, Asylmuratova may be in decline as far as technique goes, but she can still work the musical and dramatic alchemy by which familiar, even hokey, classical roles are made profound. A new ballerina coming through the ranks is 21-year-old Veronika Part, who closely resembles Lopatkina in the near-frictionless action of her legs and arms (although she lacks the absolute control that produces Lopatkina's peculiar grace). In Sleeping Beauty, Part has been a Lilac Fairy of some charm, but as Odette/Odile she moves in an introverted trance. This new breed of superballerinas have honed and glossed their techniques to awesome extremes, but at the expense of personality and imagination.

This season has given fewer opportunities to the Kirov's men - most of them have gone to Igor Zelensky, a freelance who returns to the Kirov, his home company, whenever his schedule allows. Zelensky started the season looking jetlagged and distracted, and when he danced Swan Lake with Part their pas de deux looked under-rehearsed. On Monday though, as Solor to Lopatkina's Nikiya, he was dancing as well as I've seen him.

The humming power of his pirouettes and the arrowy length of his jumps were imposing in themselves, but they also sang with the music. Among the soloists, standards have looked uneven. The best are still beautiful enough to make other companies weep but there's a tendency among the less gifted to force their effects so that their dancing looks choppy. The corps de ballet, though, remain the Kirov's treasure.

Physically they look as if they've all come off the same assembly line (barely a deviant calf muscle in sight), yet the unison with which they move is not blindly drilled but a harmony of style and tradition. The other enduring treat is the Kirov's mime artist, Vladimir Ponomarev, performing a sublimely testy King Florestan, a madly infatuated priest and a rampant Shah. With his Rasputin glare and his baroque gift for melodrama, it is impossible to imagine the Kirov's 19th-century repertory without him.

 The Kirov is at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020 - 7304 4000), till June 27 and returns from July 31 to August 19.

fields.headline: Flying into a literary storm
fields.standfirst:
Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, author of The Little Prince, was born 100 years ago. The celebrations, however, have been marred by his
                      widow's bitter account of their marriage. Paul Webster reports
fields.trailText: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, author of The Little Prince, was born 100 years ago. The celebrations, however, have been marred by his widow's bitter account of their marriage. Paul Webster reports
fields.body:
The summer sun was at its zenith in a cloudless sky when Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's French air force reconnaissance plane tumbled into the Mediterranean in July 1944, killing the author of The Little Prince, and creating a necessary hero in a country humbled by defeat and collaboration.

As the centenary of his birth on June 29 approaches, the mystery of his final moments has yet to be solved - no body nor plane was found - but his reputation as the greatest cultural figure to die "pour la France" in the second world war has spiralled far beyond the sun to orbit alongside The Little Prince's asteroid.

The Panthéon in Paris has a six-month exhibition to commemorate his exploits as a pioneer pilot, and his reputation as a humanist author of five slim books plus the philosophical-religious message published posthumously as Wisdom Of The Sands. He was born in south-eastern Lyon and the city's airport will be named after him during forthcoming months of intense national commemorations that coincide with a flood of books, broadcasts and conferences.

The chateau at Saint-Maurice de Reméns, central to his idyllic recollections of childhood, will become the seat of an international foundation to complement another institute in Paris and a rash of renamed avenues, schools and public buildings. Saint-Exupéry is the only 20th-century writer to figure on a French banknote and will soon have his own set of stamps.

Some may feel that all this is a little extravagant for an author who had not the intellectual capacity of Jean-Paul Sartre, nor the story-telling skill of François Mauriac, nor the charisma of André Malraux: three of the many rivals trailing behind in the glory stakes. Adulation for Saint-Exupéry, the repentant supporter of the wartime Vichy regime [which operated during the Nazi occupation], who sacrificed his life to regain his honour, arouses extravagant homage. To his great-niece, Nathalie des Vallières, who runs the Paris institute, he is "the archangel". To his mistress, Nelly de Vogüé, now 92, he remains "Christ-like", and as far as his literary executor, Frédéric d'Agay, is concerned:

"You will never understand Saint-Exupéry unless you see him as a modern knight-errant of the highest moral principles." So far so good. Except there is a ghost hovering over this canoni sation ceremony. His widow, the exuberant Latin-American Consuelo Suncin, who died in 1979, is attracting almost as much attention with the posthumous publication of her vitriolic memoirs and the first biography tracing the transformation of an amoral woman into Saint-Exupéry's idealised representation of femininity, the Rose, in the classic children's book, The Little Prince (1943).

"My greatest regret is not dedicating the book to you," Saint-Exupéry wrote after completing his fable while in American exile, during a reconciliation with his estranged wife. Decoded, the central theme of the allegory parallels Saint-Exupéry's own wanderlust, his contempt for the consumer age, his meeting with other "roses", and his recognition that he had made a commitment to take care of the unique flower on asteroid B-612, for all her vanity.

"I should have judged her by her deeds not her words," he writes in the book, which is less a childlike fantasy than a parable about the obligations of conjugal love. "Tonio" and Consuelo, a literary groupie who saw herself as the Alma Mahler of Central America, met in 1930 in Buenos Aires. He was a mail-service pilot living out the adventures that inspired his 1931 novel, Night Flight, and she was there to collect the widow's pension for her second husband, Enrique Gomez Carrillo, a Guatemalan writer and Argentina's consul-general in Paris.

She was nearly 30 and Saint-Exupéry was nine months older. Both had led reckless lives. Antoine, who was three when his father died, had been fascinated by aviation since his first flight at the age of 12 and had qualified as a pilot during national service. In 1926, he joined the Aéropostale service, and between then and his marriage in April 1931, he survived spectacular crashes, desert storms, rebel attacks and pioneered the airline route from Buenos Aires to Patagonia, all of which provided material for his 1938 collection of newspaper articles, Wind, Sand and Stars. Consuelo, daughter of a Pipil Indian coffee planter in El Salvador, was 19 years old when she abandoned a 60-year-old poet-lawyer fiance, before marrying a dashing Mexican captain in the US.

She was widowed a few months later during the civil war with Pancho Villa: then dumped another lover to become the mistress of Jose Vasconcelos, a Mexican intellectual and failed presidential candidate who nicknamed her a "tropical Scheherazade". During an exile in Paris where Consuelo joined him, Vasconcelos assembled the notes for the middle volume of his autobiography, The Torment, in which he describes his passion for a woman "with a viper's tongue and a musical body" who drove him wild with jealousy.

After she left him for the bisexual Gomez Carrillo, Vasconcelos, in revenge, immortalised her under the nickname of Charito, Spain's most notorious striptease artist. Only after Consuelo had assuaged another passion with the erotically supercharged Italian author, Gabriele d'Annunzio, did she marry Tonio on the recommendation of the Belgian writer, Maurice Maeterlinck.

He saw the aristocratic pilot as potentially "the best French writer of the 20th century". This was remarkable prescience. Saint-Ex still tops the all-time national best seller list with The Little Prince, which has been translated into about 100 languages, and has a million international sales a year; it was voted France's most popular 20th-century book in a millennium media poll. Three of his books are in French all-time top 20.

André Gide, Saint-Exupéry's literary godfather, had no time for Consuelo, who was also dismissed by one of her in-laws, Simone de Saint-Exupéry, as a "tart" and a "Comtesse du cinéma". The denigration has not decreased 20 years after her death. "Marrying a foreigner was considered worse than marrying a Jew," one of Saint-Exupéry's family told me, summing up the monarchist, anti-semitic and fiercely xenophobic family whose nobility dates back to the 12th century.

Saint-Exupéry broke away from many of its suffocating principles, not least the anti-semitism: his wartime work, Flight To Arras, was banned by both the Nazis and the Vichy government because he had praised the courage of a Jewish officer. Marrying Consuelo, after a coup de foudre while he was taking her for a spin over Buenos Aires, was another break from convention.

Family embarrassment at his defiance of aristocratic tradition can be inferred from the first biography, written by Nelly de Vogüé in 1949 under the pen-name Pierre Chevrier. Nelly, one of France's richest women, dismisses Consuelo in a dozen words, and Consuelo disappeared from subsequent books on Saint-Exupéry's life until I "rehabilitated" her in my 1993 biography. To Saint-Exupéry purists, that book was iconclastic. Mentioning some of his weaker characteristics, including compulsive womanising, unimpressive aviation skills, childishness and egoism, often causes a rumpus during public debates where Saint-Ex fans are as zealous as religious fundamentalists. But a frank assessment of character caused less reaction then revelations about his attachment to the wartime Vichy regime and his hatred for De Gaulle, whom he described as a "new Hitler", thus offending the Free French leader so deeply that De Gaulle joined the Nazis and Vichy in banning Saint-Exupéry's writings.

The author's distant support for Vichy in the first three years of the war still enrages both Gaullists and the left, who consider Saint-Exupéry little more than a outmoded sentimental reactionary. But the debate has been eclipsed by accusations of hypocrisy: he preached solidarity among men while treating women with contempt.

"Why can't you be here to wipe my brow and make me tea?" he complained in a letter to Consuelo; he accused her of wrecking his life by constant party-going. It seems that Consuelo's belated answer has come with the publication of a long-forgotten manuscript - now published as The Rose's Memoir - giving her view of the 13-year marriage. In this, she accuses her husband of making her suffer all the evils of absences and love affairs that she was supposed to have inflicted on him.

According to the typescript, finished in 1947, he was cruel, negligent, greedy, self-centred and wasteful. He abandoned her in a psychiatric hospital; and, when they were living separately, tricked her into letting him sleep in her house to scupper divorce proceedings, because he depended on the fortune she inherited from Gomez Carrillo. The work is an ugly account by a very embittered widow. She had second thoughts about releasing it, and never showed it to a publisher; but 21 years after her death, her heirs have the satisfaction of seeing at the top of the non-fiction list.

It has begun a feud with the Saint-Exupéry family, which feels justified in excluding Consuelo's photo from bookshop centenary exhibitions and conferences sponsored by the family. Almost at the last minute, the Saint-Exupéry supporters have been given a remarkable weapon - the accusation that Consuelo did not, in fact, write the book. At best, it is argued, she dictated the work to her lover, Denis de Rougement, the Swiss author of L'Amour Et L'Occident (Consuelo rejected his offers of marriage because he was "too Protestant").

He is the voice of the wise Fox in The Little Prince. Curtis Cate, an American biographer who knew Consuelo, is among those who believe that the book is a really a fiction, recalling that she was a "born liar" who constantly rewrote her life story to make herself out a victim. Even more damaging for the book's credibility is an investigation by a Swiss journalist, Christian Campich, who published a police analysis showing that a page of the manuscript released as a proof that Consuelo was the author was in the handwriting of De Rougement.

There are enough inconsistencies and fabricated sequences in the memoirs to make them merely interesting documents rather than true accounts, but from a literary point of view there is a worse betrayal than that of the disgruntled rose. De Rougemont was a close friend of Saint-Exupéry, helping him create The Little Prince, and yet he seems to have collaborated in the writing of these 275 pages of character assassination.

The boycott is justified by Nathalie des Vallières, bywho says that Consuelo was "not a Saint-Exupéry". There are many reasons to believe that Saint-Exupéry, missing in action, would not approve of the boycott of his wife's memory. If I am wounded, I have the one who will take care of me. If I am killed I will have the one I want to wait for in eternity. Consuelo, all our legal wranglings, all our disputes are dead." Or so he thought.
fields.bodyText: The summer sun was at its zenith in a cloudless sky when Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's French air force reconnaissance plane tumbled into the Mediterranean in July 1944, killing the author of The Little Prince, and creating a necessary hero in a country humbled by defeat and collaboration. As the centenary of his birth on June 29 approaches, the mystery of his final moments has yet to be solved - no body nor plane was found - but his reputation as the greatest cultural figure to die "pour la France" in the second world war has spiralled far beyond the sun to orbit alongside The Little Prince's asteroid. The Panthéon in Paris has a six-month exhibition to commemorate his exploits as a pioneer pilot, and his reputation as a humanist author of five slim books plus the philosophical-religious message published posthumously as Wisdom Of The Sands. He was born in south-eastern Lyon and the city's airport will be named after him during forthcoming months of intense national commemorations that coincide with a flood of books, broadcasts and conferences. The chateau at Saint-Maurice de Reméns, central to his idyllic recollections of childhood, will become the seat of an international foundation to complement another institute in Paris and a rash of renamed avenues, schools and public buildings. Saint-Exupéry is the only 20th-century writer to figure on a French banknote and will soon have his own set of stamps. Some may feel that all this is a little extravagant for an author who had not the intellectual capacity of Jean-Paul Sartre, nor the story-telling skill of François Mauriac, nor the charisma of André Malraux: three of the many rivals trailing behind in the glory stakes. Adulation for Saint-Exupéry, the repentant supporter of the wartime Vichy regime [which operated during the Nazi occupation], who sacrificed his life to regain his honour, arouses extravagant homage. To his great-niece, Nathalie des Vallières, who runs the Paris institute, he is "the archangel". To his mistress, Nelly de Vogüé, now 92, he remains "Christ-like", and as far as his literary executor, Frédéric d'Agay, is concerned: "You will never understand Saint-Exupéry unless you see him as a modern knight-errant of the highest moral principles." His widow, the exuberant Latin-American Consuelo Suncin, who died in 1979, is attracting almost as much attention with the posthumous publication of her vitriolic memoirs and the first biography tracing the transformation of an amoral woman into Saint-Exupéry's idealised representation of femininity, the Rose, in the classic children's book, The Little Prince (1943). "My greatest regret is not dedicating the book to you," Saint-Exupéry wrote after completing his fable while in American exile, during a reconciliation with his estranged wife.
