fields.headline: Crime does pay
fields.standfirst: "The 50,000-lire note transformed itself in the palm of the taxi driver's hand into a 5,000-lire note, which he showed me with outrage"
fields.trailText: "The 50,000-lire note transformed itself in the palm of the taxi driver's hand into a 5,000-lire note, which he showed me with outrage"
fields.body:
There is nothing worse than feeling responsible for your own misfortunes. You suffer, but you feel you deserve to suffer more. You want sympathy, but you feel too guilty to accept it. And this is despite the fact that you haven't actually done anything wicked; you have just been, in your own estimation, unforgivably foolish.

This has happened to me twice in the past couple of weeks. On the first occasion, I was paying a visit to Rome, a city I know well, having lived and worked there for five years. I arrived at the airport and sallied forth in search of a taxi to take me into town. Inside the terminal, I was besieged by "abusivi", the unlicensed drivers who prey on foreigners and whom anyone at all familiar with Italian airports knows to avoid. I brushed past them haughtily to join the authorised taxi queue outside, where I was quickly invited to board an official-looking white taxi equipped with a proper metre and licence number. I suppose I should have been put on my guard by the fact that the driver not only looked like a gangster in dark glasses but was seated in the front beside another man in dark glasses looking like a gangster, too.

I should also have been made suspicious by his repeated volunteering that the drive into the centre of Rome would cost me only 50,000 lire (about £17), which is substantially less than usual. Why should he bother to tell me this when the taxi had a metre? During the 40-minute journey, the driver didn't utter a word and his companion spent most of the time on a mobile telephone threatening violence against his wife or girlfriend.

It was only as we approached my hotel that they started to make friendly conversation, asking about the weather in London and how long I proposed to stay in Rome. Desperate to believe that, despite their enormous size and menacing appearance, they were normal taxi drivers whose honesty had been rigorously verified by the municipal authorities, I let myself be reassured by this, and I didn't even feel uneasy when they stopped well short of the hotel to let me out. It was then that they told me I owed them nearly 200,000 lire (about £68).

The secret of being a successful conman is to believe your own lies. The indignation they expressed at my doubting their honesty appeared totally unfeigned. They pointed furiously at the metre as proof of the justice of their demand, although it showed less than one third of the sum they were asking.

When I insisted I would pay no more than the 50,000-lire maximum promised at the airport and handed the driver a banknote for this amount, he performed an impressive bit of magic. The 50,000-lire note transformed itself in the palm of his hand into a 5,000-lire note, which he showed me with outrage. So I gave him another 50,000-lire note, and the same thing happened again.

So convincing was this conjuring trick that it took me quite a while to realise that I could never have given him a 5,000-lire note for the simple reason that I didn't possess one. When I had bought Italian currency at London Airport, the only notes they gave me were for either 50,000 or 10,000 lire. As soon as I remembered this, I walked off in a huff, with the driver still protesting loudly that I had diddled him. Once safely inside the hotel, I counted my money and found that I was 200,000 lire down. The swine had somehow got what they wanted.

A few days later, I told this story to a London taxi driver who commented that it was odd of me to talk as if it were all my fault when it was obvious that the crooks were really to blame. He was right, I suppose, but I could not be so easily consoled. I had made a complete idiot of myself, and this to me was by far the graver offence. I just considered myself lucky to have been swindled for so little.

Shortly after this, I committed a second act of foolishness, for which the punishment has been much more severe. Ignoring the Government's improbable discovery that staircases are among the country's greatest killers, I rushed recklessly down a flight of stairs at home, tripped at the bottom, and fell heavily against the corner of a shelf sticking out into the hall. The result has been a damaged rib and indescribable spasms of pain, causing me to howl and whimper like a wounded animal.

Even this, I feel, has not been punishment enough. So, in the spirit of the medieval flagellants, I am at the moment abstaining from both smoking and drinking as a form on penance.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Katie-Jane Garside
fields.trailText: Katie-Jane Garside
fields.body:
Katie Jane Garside, 30, grew up in Salisbury. When she was 12, her father took the family sailing round the world for four years. She moved to London at 17 and went on to become lead singer of Daisy Chainsaw. The band made an impact on the London scene in the early 90s, but Katie had a nervous breakdown and left the music industry. Today, she fronts Queen Adreena, who will play live at festivals this summer.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Ocean and white noise.

What is your greatest fear?
The screeching traffic of my inner city.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
A sneaking suspicion that I am the chaos that creates all chaos.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
When people manipulate another's vulnerability.

What vehicles do you own?
My magic carpet.

What objects do you always carry with you?
A good intention.

Where would you like to live?
In a tumultuous ocean.

What makes you depressed?
When I can't come up for air.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
The scared and fearful look in my eyes.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Deep-sea diving in the sewer.

What is your favourite smell?
Diesel on water out of ski boats.

Do you believe in monogamy?
I'm always kicking both sides of the door.

Which living person do you most despise?
Only those who reflect back the bits of me that I would rather not see.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
I always mean it but have been misconstrued.

When and where were you happiest?
I'm scared of this question, for life in the past tense is certain death.

How often do you have sex?
Morning, noon and night - eroticism rules.

More eroticism.

Who's to say there'll be anyone here to remember me?

fields.bodyText: Katie Jane Garside, 30, grew up in Salisbury. When she was 12, her father took the family sailing round the world for four years. She moved to London at 17 and went on to become lead singer of Daisy Chainsaw. The band made an impact on the London scene in the early 90s, but Katie had a nervous breakdown and left the music industry. Today, she fronts Queen Adreena, who will play live at festivals this summer. What is your idea of perfect happiness? Ocean and white noise. What is your greatest fear? The screeching traffic of my inner city. What is the trait you most deplore in yourself? A sneaking suspicion that I am the chaos that creates all chaos. What is the trait you most deplore in others? When people manipulate another's vulnerability. What vehicles do you own? My magic carpet. What objects do you always carry with you? A good intention. Where would you like to live? In a tumultuous ocean. What makes you depressed? When I can't come up for air. What do you most dislike about your appearance? The scared and fearful look in my eyes. What is your most unappealing habit? Deep-sea diving in the sewer. What is your favourite smell? Diesel on water out of ski boats. Do you believe in monogamy? I'm always kicking both sides of the door. Which living person do you most despise? Only those who reflect back the bits of me that I would rather not see. Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it? I always mean it but have been misconstrued. When and where were you happiest? I'm scared of this question, for life in the past tense is certain death. How often do you have sex? Morning, noon and night - eroticism rules. What single thing would improve the quality of your life? More eroticism. How would you like to die? There will be ocean upon my inner city and the traffic noise will finally cease. Do you believe in life after death? Energy cannot be extinguished. How would you like to be remembered? Who's to say there'll be anyone here to remember me? fields.headline: Pang at C&A
fields.standfirst: "The fact is that English dullness is actually more interesting, attractive and affecting than American know-how or European savoir faire"
fields.trailText: "The fact is that English dullness is actually more interesting, attractive and affecting than American know-how or European savoir faire"
fields.body:
I've been feeling a peculiar pang all week about C&A closing, though I can't have been inside one since I was 12. It was the sort of place my mother used to drag me round on a Saturday afternoon in the very early 70s, looking for holiday clothes to wear on the annual Butlin's beano, and we'd invariably row because I wanted sludge-coloured midi-skirts from Chelsea Girl and she wanted me to wear acrylic turquoise minis. "Why are you trying to make me dress like a child prostitute, Mother?" I would invariably hiss, to be answered by a resounding slap around the ear and a triumphant hiss of, "Wait till I get thee 'ome!" Happy days.

My mother didn't want me to look like a child prostitute, of course; she only wanted me to carry on being Her Little Girl for a bit longer, a bit of a fool's errand once Marc Bolan, ambition and masturbation were in the frame. C&A was good at making little girls look very little, and the middle-aged look very middle-aged; it wasn't hot on the perennial teen look, and when it tried to do "swinging", it ended up as the Panda Pops version of Coke. But nostalgia has a funny way of getting to you, and if I concentrate very hard I find I can bring myself to the verge of tears (not all the way - Good Lord, let's keep a sense of proportion here) just thinking about those bri-nylon shirts with matching tie and hanky on men who smelled of Hai Karate; and those acrylic, Jacquard tunics on ladies called Audrey and Avril, blushing beneath their Max Factor Creme Puff as they danced slow with their next door neighbour to Can't Take My Eyes Off You. Those were innocent, heady days, after the Pill but before Aids, and it hit our parents for six. And it was C&A that dressed them for their brief shining place in the sun.

I don't care that C&A is Dutch; look at William of Orange. The point is that it, like he, made us more English. My blood runs cold when I try to imagine what they're going to put in our big C&A building in Brighton. When Liberty closed here - okay, Liberty is a crap shop, but it had a brilliant Muji concession and carried Rifat Ozbek and English Eccentrics - they built a Gap For Kids (which my friend Emma always says sounds really obscene) over the whole three floors! We already have at least half-a-dozen American coffee shops within two minutes' walk of each other, one of them on the site of a fantastic toy shop. Isn't it weird how the flight from perceived dullness ends up installing a much more profound and insidious type of monotony?

I yearn for decent dullness, properly done; no half measures and no cut corners. Two Way Family Favourites. A Sunday roast, even on a blinding hot day in July, followed by Bartlett pears and Ideal Milk. The torpor and dread of Sunday afternoon, with no shops open. The classic serial on BBC1, and tinned salmon for tea. Sing Something Simple and packing your satchel and wanting to die, right here, right now. And what have we got instead? Non-stop sex on TV, a ciabatta in every oven and a population who don't understand why they're not as happy as they used to be. It's because thing's aren't dull, that's why.

The fact is that English dullness is actually far more interesting, attractive and affecting than American know-how or European savoir faire. I can't imagine any country but England producing Alan Bennett, for instance, and any country that can't produce Alan Bennett is no country I'd want to salute the flag of. And it was our very lack of know-how and savoir faire that made him possible. Bennett himself has a lovely, sad story about how, as a bright, working-class lad, he felt impatient with his parents' provincialism. Eager to please him, they set about sophisticating themselves, and when he came back home from university his mother announced, "We've found an alcoholic drink we like. It's called bitter lemon." Later, they learned to like wine, by which time Bennett was grown up and appreciated the purity and sweetness of their initial unworldliness: "All I wanted was for them to be the way they had been. But by then of course it was too late."

For dullness is such a delicate flower - so easy to destroy, so impossible to recapture. I experienced the Bitter Lemon Effect with my own parents. When I was growing up, I was a right royal predictable pain in the ass on social matters, virulently in favour of sex, drugs and horrible loud music, anti-religion, anti-capital punishment - the whole boring works. But I thought I was Che Guevara. I would rant on at my parents about their provincialism, their dullness - and though at the time I thought it was water off a duck's back, they were actually mad enough to take some of it on board.

When I'd go home to visit them in the 80s, my mother would wheel out some new, daring social attitude: "He's gay, of course," she said casually over ginger nuts one day of her new hairdresser. "I've met his partner . Lovely couple." "She's got a toyboy," she'd shrug of her married friend. "Each to his own, I say." This Bedlam came to a head over faggots and peas one Sunday, when my father casually announced that he no longer believed in God! I moped over my Instant Whip, remembering what the neighbourhood had been like before it became bloody Liberty Hall: clandestine affairs, twitching curtains, vicious gossip, closed minds - brilliant, dirty fun, in fact, like Peyton Place-on-Avon. And now, here they were, letting it all hang out.

In fact, I can just imagine my parents laughing themselves rigid (if they weren't already) at that awful Keith Chegwin smutfest the other night, which my worldly friends and I found so appalling. They were thoroughly "with it" by the end - they thought the Lottery was better than premium bonds, the car-boot sale superior to the bring-and-buy, and pounds and pence better than shillings - so it was left to Muggins here to mourn the arcane glory of the thrupenny bit and the half-crown.

But just you wait and see. I believe that dullness will rise again, and triumph. On the internet, for instance, you can spend many happy hours gazing at cornfields in Iowa, streets in Scunthorpe or long stretches of many a motorway. The most mesmerising song of the year so far is the mighty Black Box Recorder's The English Motorway System - "The English motorway system is beautiful and strange/ It's been there forever, it's never going to change/ It eliminates all diversions, it eliminates all emotions/ All you've got to do to stay alive is drive." This is the voice of a generation in search of their birthright; not rioting, but queueing.

fields.headline: How to be polite
fields.trailText: Being polite is a combination of saying please, thank you and letting other people do things before you do. If at any time you slip up and accidentally do something you want to do, you must make up for this by sending a thank-you card immediately.
fields.body:
Being polite is a combination of saying please, thank you and letting other people do things before you do. If at any time you slip up and accidentally do something you want to do, you must make up for this by sending a thank-you card immediately.

Passing tasty food items to others before you help yourself is a very good way of showing how polite you are, and also of rapidly losing weight.

For men, giving up your seat to a woman is frowned upon in these days of sexual equality, so if you really want to be polite to a woman, why not give up your job instead.

Holding doors open is also another minefield. Obviously, if it's a swing door or revolving door, any attempt to hold it open is going to make you look like a complete tool. If you've held a door open for one person and the entire population of the UK seems to be following them through, eventually you'll have to let it go. This will inevitably coincide with the arrival of the pregnant lady vicar on crutches.

The underlying principle of politeness is putting the desires and wishes of others before your own. Where this goes terribly wrong is in the bedroom. There is no such thing as a polite erection.

Politeness used to revolve around the placing of doilies under everything. The verbal equivalent of a doily is to preface everything you say with 'I wonder' and to include the concept of 'not minding' in the sentence. Doing this means it's almost impossible to be rude: 'I wonder if you wouldn't mind not being such an arse,' sounds positively friendly.

In life-threatening situations, politeness can be a mixed blessing. When you're trying to get out of a burning aircraft, holding the door open for others to escape is a good way of finishing yourself off. On the other hand, if you're on Death Row, giving your seat up to someone else has the opposite effect.

When two polite people meet, nothing happens, and you're just left with a pool of anti-matter; no doors can be held open, chairs sat in, food eaten or initiatives taken - there is just a quivering of latent energy ready to be turned into thank-you cards.

Really, really polite people may seem to be dull, but they all have a little secret. Once you have the reputation for being polite, you can get away with saying things such as, 'My word, what an interesting story', to people who could bore a new Channel Tunnel.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Curtain call
fields.standfirst: 'Neck throbs like Led Zeppelin, and have started to fart in chords - B-flat minor'
fields.trailText: 'Neck throbs like Led Zeppelin, and have started to fart in chords - B-flat minor'
fields.body:
I want to join the Women's Institute now they are turning into Maenads: hurling off their clothes and ripping innocent young prime ministers to pieces. But not sure if I am fit enough even for a slow handclap. Extensive DIY has left me black and blue. I have a pain in my guts the shape of Africa, a throb in my neck like Led Zeppelin, and I have started to fart in chords - B-flat minor, if you must know.

"Dulcie? I wonderrr if I might put up currtains in my bedrrroom? It seems to get light, these days, shorrrtly after midnight." Great-Aunt Elspeth's room faces east, and we have never got around to installing her curtains. Experience tsunami of guilt.

"I think they're in one of those boxes under the stairs. I'll get them right away, Elspeth." At least I am younger than aunt, although these days I am a lot stiffer.

Why was I so obsessed with changing my room? Why have I thrown out all my perfectly serviceable old furniture and acquired a flat-pack computer work-station, canvas wardrobe and futon? Why do I want a blue space in which perilous structures of canvas and wood totter and loom? Does it betray a subconscious desire to escape from my family and be shipwrecked on a desert island? You bet.

The work-station is taking shape - although what shape exactly remains unclear. So far, we have wielded screwdrivers over it for more than eight hours. It looks like a block of flats after an earthquake. At least it doesn't smell, though. The canvas wardrobe and the futon are emanating mysterious fumes, despite their eco-image. I long for a low-odour universe.

Must prevent aunt getting hernia, so haul heavy Caledonian curtains into daylight. The curtains swirl with more primary colours than I ever thought existed. Being a child of my time, I now want trendy curtains - limp slumps of linen with little shoulder straps, although nobody ever warns you that that they simply won't pull, but just get stuck on the poles.

Another thing nobody has warned us about is that when you awake from your nightmare of being tortured by the Inquisition, you discover that it is not the Inquisitor's bradawl up your nostril but the pillowcase's cute buttons. Buttons on pillows. What next? A bra to hold the loo rolls?

The auld aunt is happy to be reunited with her auld curtains. "They smell a bit mouldy, auntie."

"Och, I don't think so, dearrr." She has lost her sense of smell - which makes personal hygiene something of a minefield. But who am I to sneer - I who have broken wind in Waitrose? At least it was in the organic section.

Ex-Spouse arrives and anxiously begins to assist. He is scared Elspeth will die in a curtain-hanging accident, her son Alistair will return from Australia to claim his inheritance, and we will be homeless. The curtains are hung to aunt's satisfaction, but stink so much that I fear they may have brought E. coli south with them - rather as the plague arrived at Eyam in a box of cloth.

Harriet is painting her room red. Never mind filling holes with Polyfilla and sanding down - she hasn't even picked her clothes up off the floor and is painting over Blu-Tac, spiders and fragments of poster still Sellotaped to the wall. Soon the carpet is covered with bloodstains. At least we are doing our best to make the house repulsive. If Alastair ever puts it on the market, he won't have a snowflake's chance in hell of selling it.

Retire to my desert island of a bedroom, sprawl moodily on my redolent futon and recall the days when I had a whole fragrant cottage all to myself, surrounded by clean country air. Glare at half-erected work-station and wish I had an axe. Speck of dust spirals down through sunbeam, lands on work-station, and it collapses. Perhaps there is a God after all.

Phone rings. It is Jonathan, who bought my cottage, inviting us to a gay barbecue. He is not happy, though. "They're sending lorries up from Bristol and spraying the fields with human shit, Dulcie!" he laments. Feel brief pang of guilt, even though I have never contributed to Bristol's archive of excrement. Experience acute desire for aromatherapy, but doubt whether lighting cinnamon candle is going to be more than a futile gesture.

fields.headline: The Cosmos Cheapy
fields.standfirst: 'There was another north-south divide that day - and it was full of dung'
fields.trailText: 'There was another north-south divide that day - and it was full of dung'
fields.body:
Back in 1981, the market for holiday boozathons for the young, free and simple could not have been more buoyant. There was Club 18-30 at its riotous Thatcherite peak. But there were also Twenties, its daring older sister, and Buddies, its slightly puerile younger brother. None of these excursions could be said to be expensive. But there was a less costly option yet. There was the Cosmos Cheapy.

The Cosmos Cheapy was in many ways ahead of its time. You paid over your paltry sum, turned up at the airport and prayed for a lucky break. You would have no idea of the destination until you got there, other than the broadest of broad hints - southern Spain; Greek Islands; North Africa. North Africa was always, even by Cheapy standards, the cheapest.

I and three pals got a week in Tunisia for £39, all-in. On arrival, we were greeted by two Mateys. Helen Matey was the boss, while Roger Matey (from Totnes) did the gurning. The Mateys were to be our redcoats, and they threw themselves into their work with an ardour that bordered on insanity. I can still summon up Roger from Totnes's facial expression as he told us how mad everyone was at this resort. Those Mateys loved their job, and they loved their charges, madly.

One reason why Cosmos Cheapies were so cheap is that they flew out from Blighty at 4.30am. This was perfectly timed to pitch us, white and blinking, outside the hotel complex in time for the alfresco beer breakfast. Punters who had been there a few days would rush up to the mesh perimeter fence, goading their full-fare fellows to join them, whereupon they would point and, faces contorted with disdain, start to chant: "Cosmos Cheapies! Cosmos Cheapies!"

We soon found out that our cheapo status was to make us immensely popular - or it would have done had we been prepared to throw ourselves into the pool fully-clothed or eat dates until we were sick. Some of our fellow holidaymakers complained that we were not the genuine article. We weren't mad enough.

In an attempt to avoid ostracism, we lamely tagged along for the Beach Olympics. Again, Roger was to the fore, grinning like a lunatic and loudly announcing that this was going to be "the dog's gonads". Not quite, Roger - although the camels might have been impressed by his whey-faced army of pooper-scoopers. Years before other travel operators became eco-friendly, Roger had his merry pranksters dig a ditch in the middle of the beach into which they would deposit camel droppings - which were plentiful. Alas, this was no slick PR exercise to endear the bullish Brits to the put-upon Tunisians. This was the climax of the Beach Olympics. This was the Dung O'War.

I was corralled into the Northern team. I can all too easily recall myself teetering on the edge of a pit full of camel cack as a dozen brawny bakers from Kent tugged and heaved with ruthless efficiency. You paid over your paltry sum, turned up at the airport and prayed for a lucky break. fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Dried and tested: herbs
fields.trailText: Dried and tested: herbs
fields.body:
The subject
Dried leaves used to give flavour and aroma to food. They are the under-rated ornaments of the kitchen and dining table, overshadowed by their fresh counterparts.

The basics
Any culinary herb can be dried - gently, with plenty of air circulating around it - and used in cooking. It will not perform the same tricks of which it's capable when fresh, of course - and, in some cases, it won't so much dry as die . When used right, however, they can give a lift and a gift to any dish in which they are deployed.

The details
It's easy to forget about dried herbs in the frenzy for their moist, green counterparts. Some, The Knowledge admits, don't cut it after drying; even those that do dry well can't be used in exactly the same way. But some are nearly as good after taking the air. Top-drawer dryers: rosemary, tarragon, thyme, oregano. Debatable dryers: marjoram, sage. Never-say-dryers: dill, basil, mint, parsley, coriander. Essential standby item: herbes de Provence, which the Knowledge uses in three out of five home-cooked dishes. A pinch in marinades, in the cavity of a roast chicken, in gravy - now you're talking! Dried herbs come with a Cook's Caveat: use sparingly, because their flavour is concentrated. And a Keeper's Caveat: you can't store them at home forever and ever. They change in time, losing pungency, and after a year or so lose most of whatever they had to begin with and are about as useful as dried grass, which they resemble in flavour. Chuck 'em and buy fresh (I mean fresh dried) supplies. The cost won't kill.

Where to buy
Supermarkets carry the big brands, led by Schwartz. It's more expensive than buying bags from a health-food or specialist shop, but the Keeper's Caveat makes buying in bulk a bad idea.

The easy way out
This is it.

fields.headline: Summer loving
fields.standfirst: The coming months hold some dazzling rewards for the tender care you have put into your borders. But, says Christopher Lloyd, you'll have to keep up the attention to ensure a continuing display
fields.trailText: The coming months hold some dazzling rewards for the tender care you have put into your borders. But, says Christopher Lloyd, you'll have to keep up the attention to ensure a continuing display
fields.body:
June 24, midsummer's day, and many gardens may be judged to have reached their peak for the year. Their shrub roses are in full blow; the hybrid teas and floribundas - depending on when and how hard they were pruned - are not far off it. Must a slow decline from now on be a garden's fate?

In many cases, it is, but what a shame to accept it. Only now can we rely on the evenings being warm enough for a soirée without the need to don extra layers. Only now has the sharpness of spring truly yielded to a beguiling, 24-hour-long softness in the air. So why allow it to be wasted on a scene of ever-increasing slovenliness and decay. It need not be so, but the decision is up to each of us.

In the first place, we need to be vigilant over upkeep. Dead-heading may seem a chore, but it makes all the difference to appearances. Kniphofias whose pokers have run their course, look terrible if simply left to decay visibly. The larger-flowered day-lilies really need to have their deads removed every morning if the newly-opened blooms are not to be seen in a sordid setting. Many roses are even more obtrusive. If you cannot cope with this situation, admit it and grow fewer of these delinquents.

Lupins run to seed - their spikes are easily removed - but their foliage will almost certainly become unsightly with mildew. Our solution at Dixter is to grow them as biennials, sowing seed for next year now and chucking out the flowered plants now or very soon. That leaves us with a clean space in which to enjoy new plantings for the rest of the summer, such as dahlias, zinnias, or gaily-coloured coleus plants, all of which can be raised in readiness from May sowings.

Even easier would be bedding nasturtiums, which need not be sown till this month, as they come on so quickly. Poke a couple of seeds of comparatively compact bedding types into a number of pots and the plants will be ready to bed out when you want them.

Always think ahead, even when you are ordering seeds in the winter. Around now, we are planting up our exotic garden in readiness for an exciting August-to-October display. True, you need some greenhouse space in which to bring many of the plants on, but a lot of British gardeners have that.

If your delphiniums are soon threatening you with a wreckage of cut-back stems, plant some annual climbers to grow over them. Morning glory, Ipomoea 'Heavenly Blue', offers a fresh revelation every day. As charming in its way is I. quamoclit, better known as Mina lobata, with racemes of tubular flowers graded through red to yellow and white. But one of the best is Rhodochiton atropurpureum, with garlands of purple bells over a long season. Best policy with that is to sow it in September and bring the seedlings on under glass.

Dahlias, of course, are a wonderful mainstay from July on. There is such a range of different kinds that even if you loathe some of them there must surely be others that will please you. Late-struck cuttings will provide plants that are just right for planting out now, to replace biennials such as foxgloves and sweet williams.

I grow early-flowering chrysanthemums in a row. They are seedlings (you can either sow in spring or save old plants). When we can see their relative heights, and colour enough in their buds to gauge how best to group them, we move them to replace annuals, perhaps in late August or in September. Given a good soaking before and after the move, they take it without flinching. So do Michaelmas daisies.

Perennials and shrubs must play their part. Hydrangeas have, between the different kinds, a tremendously long season that has already started. Some varieties flower almost continuously, both from shoots off last year's old wood and from young shoots made this year. You can help them with generous waterings (feeding is better reserved for the run-up to flowering) and by dead-heading the earlier trusses.

The border phloxes - most of them cultivars of Phlox paniculata - flower in July and August. We are interplanting them with tulips for earlier interest. Some phloxes - generally the earliest flowerers - give a repeat performance. So do other perennials, such as Helenium 'Moerheim Beauty' and Salvia x superba. But a dead-heading in between crops will greatly help.

If you are visiting Wisley in the coming weeks, don't forget to have a look at the trial ground in the Portsmouth Field, where there is currently a trial of heleniums and other sunflower-related perennials, such as heliopsis and coreopsis. Seeing plants actually growing is a much better way to decide which would be suitable for your garden than looking at them on a show bench.

There are certain stalwart bedding plants with a long flowering season. They are great allies, though it can happen that you get bored with them. Some marigolds I can do without, but there are others making big enough plants to have personality; they make good living companions. And you'll need fewer plants. Choose your fibrous-rooted bedding begonias (Begonia semperflorens types) carefully. Those with a free habit are the easiest to integrate into mixed plantings.

Among ageratums, by far the best as a freely growing, long-flowering mixed border plant is 'Blue Horizon'. Grow it yourself from seed, next year.

fields.headline: Spirit in the sky
fields.standfirst: High in the mountains of southern France, an artist dreamed of building the perfect house. He didn't have a blueprint - just an idea in his head. Riki Simons saw the remarkable results.
fields.trailText: High in the mountains of southern France, an artist dreamed of building the perfect house. He didn't have a blueprint - just an idea in his head. Riki Simons saw the remarkable results.
fields.body:
Up on the ridge of the the Vidourle valley, in the southern French province of Gard, is one of a few houses in the country regarded as a work of art. La Muse was built from memory by the artist, designer and carpenter Michel Roubinet. Everything in the house is hand-made, according to the dream in its creator's head.

Anybody who sets off from the valley to try to find the house will have a similar experience. Along the dirt road, winding up the mountain under the chestnut trees, things quickly start to look as if they are going nowhere. As you get higher, the road gets smaller and darker, there are no signs of life. You begin to feel that you're well and truly lost when suddenly you will come to a breathtaking view of long rows of valleys to the south. At the same time, there is the house in front of you, curving along the side of the mountain-top on the other side of the road.

The present owners are Frank and Patricia Dubiez. They are writers, designers and publishers of children's books, and have lived here for seven years. Before he found La Muse in 1993, Frank, a Parisian, had already made several attempts to find a house that he liked in the south. He bought La Muse, he says, after a careful 15 minutes' consideration. "It was the most beautiful house I had ever seen," he remembers, "and it still is. You cannot be neutral towards this house. We see this happen to all the people who visit us here: you either fall for it, like we did, or you hate it. There is nothing in between."

Two years before the couple's arrival on this Cévennes mountain top, Michel Roubinet, the designer and builder of La Muse, was killed in an accident when building material fell from the crane he was using to finish the house. Roubinet was from the Atlantic coast region of Bordeaux, and specialised in designing and building boat interiors. He was a great admirer of the Spanish architect Antonio Gaudí and of Spanish-Moorish architecture, and his house was going to form the first part of an artist's colony.

In 1985, without any drawings, Roubinet began building his house and laid the first stone on the mountain-top: a pentagon, now in the middle of the floor of the central space of the house. Right above it in the ceiling is a similar shape, and from there the house was constructed in a spiral, wind-ing outwards and upwards.

All the floor-tiles radiate out, like sun rays, from the pentagon to the outer walls, as do the roof-beams and the roof-tiles. There are also round, dome-like ceilings, such as the one in the bathroom, attached to the central pentagon. Straight walls are set with bricks; curved walls are constructed from a skeleton of welded ironwork filled with straw, polystyrene and chicken wire, then plastered with cement.

La Muse is like the spiral shell of a snail: it grew in an organic way, without any planning permission - slowly, room after room, as the money and ideas emerged. The local planning department had so little understanding of what was going on that at one point Roubinet had to ask an architect to draw up official-looking building-plans for a house that was already well underway. But when the house was declared a work of art by the authorities, Roubinet's emerging problems with the planning powers quickly disappeared.

Two years after Roubinet's death, his widow, Helene, a psychoanalyst, sold La Muse to Frank for a price he could afford because he was a "kindred spirit". She felt he would finish it sympathetically.

"The first year I was not able to do anything," Frank says. "The personality of the house was too strong. Then I got used to it. In the beginning, I first showed all my plans to Helene, who lived nearby in Nimes. Every time, it turned out that Roubinet had had exactly the same ideas. The house looks complicated, maybe even improvised, but it is built according to the very clear pentagon concept. Once you understand the concept you can develop any addition in a logical way from what is already there.

La Muse is totally hand-made: walls, doors, windows, cupboards, sink, stairs, the bathtub in a bean shape, and the basin in the bathroom. "Even the shower head is a special design," says Frank. "That makes it very beautiful, but also very difficult. When I have to repair something, I cannot go out and buy parts. I have to actually make everything myself.

"As a boat-interior builder, Roubinet was a very refined, specialised craftsman. I have worked as a lumberjack and a mason, but next to his skills mine are rough and primitive. I have to face up to that difference all the time. His boats can also be found in the very compact way he uses space. And in little jokes like portholes in some corridors."

On the ground level, Roubinet built a kitchen, two bedrooms and a toilet in which the shape of the house is mirrored in a brick spiral that decorates the wall and the window. The central space with the pentagon is a hallway, for which Roubinet designed a pendulum clock in the wall. Next to the kitchen, there is a larger, inside/outside area lined with slim, elegant columns and Moorish arcades that overlooks the valleys. In winter it can be partly closed with glass windows that are removed in spring time.

On the first floor, the two designers have now made their studio in one room; there is also the master bedroom and the bathroom. The staircase curls up to the top of the house, which is taken up by a large terrace with a view in all directions over the rolling hills - on a clear day this stretches right up to the Mediterranean. The contrast of the warm intimacy of this house and the spectacular, wide space and rippling hills surrounding it, gives the feeling of standing on a boat in the middle of the ocean.

Frank and Patricia Dubiez are adding their dreams to that of the artist and boatbuilder. "We have almost finished Roubinet's original house. Then we will build our own additions: first a large studio and a large living room. Especially in winter we need these," says Frank. "The spiral shape can be easily expanded. It will not be hard to keep the spirit of the house. La Muse did cost Roubinet his life, but it is very much une maison vivante "

fields.headline: Make mine a...
fields.standfirst: ... Chartreuse
fields.trailText: ... Chartreuse
fields.body:
Chartreuse apparently contains 130 different herbs, or 'substances végétales', as the French nicely put it. Not that anyone can check, as only three monks have the recipe and they're only allowed to talk to each other on a Monday afternoon. But the green Chartreuse, the most commonly found version, certainly tastes pretty herby. Or toothpasty, if I'm brutally honest. That's if you drink it neat, of course.

Bartenders are encouraged to use it to make pointlessly silly cocktails, but I prefer the simpler serving suggestions on the back of the label: Chartreuse Chocolat (two teaspoons in a mug of hot chocolate), and Chartreuse and tonic (surprisingly refreshing, though add a slice or two of lime).

So who drinks it, really? Anyone who needs the Dutch courage that a shot of 55% alcohol can provide. Cross-channel swimmers and bungee jumpers come to mind. People suffering from hangovers should try the 71% version, the Elixir Végétal, recommended for weariness, queasiness or indisposition. (Call 01442 870900 for stockists).

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya attempts the transition to love goddess
fields.body:
Official: Guardian readers don't wear sandals. In fact, you are terrifyingly pragmatic and Clintonesque in your advice. So far, your votes favour a liaison with Sir K (by less than 10%, though), which forces me to consider an adulterous affair (there is a Lady K somewhere in Buckinghamshire). Since I've never been involved with a married man before, I consulted the net for advice. There are a lot of sites, but I was attracted by www.facereality.com, managed by the lovely Elissa Gough, which includes a book store on infidelity and runs a Betrayed Wives Workshop in Las Vegas.

However, I needed The Other Woman angle, which I found in www.gloryb.com (entitling me to $115 in vouchers for e-shopping).

Ffion Hague, Becks: so many icons of modern marital bliss have blonde hair that to be a Wrecker I decided I needed to be brunette; so I made an appointment with Patrick to change my look; now I have shoulder-length (extended) hair as dark as my desires.

Next, I had to get a siren wardrobe: I tried www.vogue.co.uk, but I found the range very limited. However, one of my fans alerted me to www.asseenonscreen.com. where you can buy objects or clothes as seen in movies. Although they have some fun things, I did not find anything really suitable for my purpose, but you can leave your request, so I asked them to find me the sort of clothes they wear in Sex In The City, something classy and yet sluttish to suit my new image.

In fact, I also checked www.therealmonicainc.com, Monica Lewinsky's site, where she sells tote bags and purses (made of real silk, not sows' ears), but no dresses (not even a blue one). It is far from easy to transform yourself in to a love goddess.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck longs for a herb-and-spice garden
fields.body:
Curiosity often compels me to read lonely-hearts columns, but never have I come across the ultimate turn-on advertisement: owner of herb-and-spice garden wishes to meet crusty wine writer, etc.

Herbs and spices litter the food prepared in my household, but they do not - rosemary and the ubiquitous mint apart - litter my garden. What would I do if I met such a herb-and-spice gardener? Open a bottle of Charles Heidsieck Blanc de Blancs Champagne 1982, since it is the perfect bubbly for once-in-a-lifetime occasions.

Having written a few weeks ago of the rarity of 20-out-of-20-point wines, here is one: as sublime as it is possible for chardonnay to become with bubbles. It is perfectly mature, rich and complex, dry and delicate on the finish. It is of an elegance that defines what great sparkling wine is all about. Of course, it costs a fortune - £89.99, to be precise (that final 99p is Waitrose's idea of a joke) - and is only available from the joker's mail-order operation, Waitrose Direct. You can freephone it on 0800 188881, or access the website: www.waitrose.com

Or you can spend the money elsewhere on the spicy whites and herby reds that the theme of this week's food-and-drink special demands. I have found six spicy whites. Asda's Baron de Turckheim Gewürztraminer 1998 (16 points, £7.49) is deliciously, thickly textured, has the regulation lychee-and-rose-petal fruit, and is great with robust Chinese food. It is also a wine that is marvellous to gulp while preparing food (indeed, it is as charmingly indispensable in this role as is Radio 3).

On the other hand, Sainsbury's has, from Chile, Canepa Winemaker's Selection Gewürztraminer 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), which offers a similar flavour profile, but with greater crispness on the finish. It is, at its price, a bargain.

Majestic has Australian Capel Vale Verdelho 1999 (16 points, £7.99 a bottle, or £6.99 if you buy, as part of a case or mixed case, two bottles or more). This is a wonderful, concentrated vintage, resulting in a warmly coated, subtly spicy wine of polished demeanour and great cellaring potential. It is also available at Safeway.

Two delightfully spicy Alsatian whites at Majestic are Bott-Geyl Gewürztraminer Schlosselreben de Beblenheim 1998 (17 points, £12.99) and Bott-Geyl Gewürztraminer Grand Cru Sonnenglanz 1998 (17.5 points, £15.99). These are two hugely impressive wines of majesterial complexity and potency. The Schlosselreben has great richness and half-sweet spiciness that will only develop over time. My guess is that it will rate 20 points if cellared for some years: 10? 12? 15? God knows. I don't.

The Sonnenglanz is about as assertive as a young, frisky gewürz can get, offering, as it does, pears, peaches, rose petals, raspberries, honey and intriguing minerally acids. Left for seven to eight years, it'll rate 20 points, too. For opening when one meets the perfect herb-and-spice gardener, perchance.

Also at Majestic, and at 77 branches of Safeway (01622 712926 for details) is Oxford Landing Limited Release Viognier 1999 (17 points, £5.99), from Australia. The lingering apricot fruit and subtle spiciness are remarkably insistent and sensory.

Herby reds? I can offer you four: Vacqueyras Domaine de l'Oiselet 1999 (16.5 points, £5.99, Asda) is rousingly warm and ripe, with rivulets of plump, blackcurrant fruit with eager tannins.

Tesco has a non-vintage Minervois that also fits the bill. Rating 14 points and costing £2.99, it is very blackcurrant-jammy, with a hint of the Midi scrub and earth.

Sainsbury has Stowells of Chelsea Merlot Vin de Pays d'Oc in a three-litre box. True, the herbs are slight, but it is a dry, subtly leathery wine with a hint of earthiness and, though normally £13.79, is on offer at £11.79 until July 1. A 15-point wine at 49p a glass has to be a bargain.

Last of all, a wine with herbs and spice: Sainsbury s non-vintage, own-label South African Pinotage, rating 16 points. It parades hints of burnt rubber, cassis/plum fruit, a herby, savoury tannic presence, a coriander herbiness and a cinnamon and cardamom touch on the finish. Quite a mouthful for £4.29.

fields.headline: Crop of ages
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort opens our Summer Food & Drink Special on herbs with a look at how they've been used through history - and finds that we could learn a culinary trick or two from our ancestors, judging from the starters he's uncovered.
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort opens our Summer Food & Drink Special on herbs with a look at how they've been used through history - and finds that we could learn a culinary trick or two from our ancestors, judging from the starters he's uncovered.
fields.body:
What, I wonder, would John Evelyn (1620-1706), diarist, herbalist and cook, make of the fruit-and-veg display in the average modern-day supermarket? He'd be a tad disappointed, in all likelihood. Some of the things on offer might seem a bit weird and wonderful to him, sure - not least that they may be out of season - and he might not recognise all the fruits. But as for the herbs - what a pitiful range! What miserable bundles! And how much?

The use of herbs is as old as history. The Egyptians of 5,000 years ago obligingly left prescriptions on clay tablets and papyrus scrolls. The Assyrians, Chaldeans and Chinese all had schools of herbalists. And what is known as the Ebers papyrus of 1,500BC gives around 700 remedies.

By 500BC, Hippocrates, and then Aristotle and a chap called Theophrastus, set about codifying contemporary knowledge of herbs, before Dioscoredes, a Greek doctor in the Roman army, wrote the first herbal round about 200AD.

Up to this point, herbs had been used - for official purposes, at any rate - for treating various ailments. We don't know much about the way herbs were used in cookery until The Life Of Luxury, by Archestratus, who lived in Gela, Sicily, during the fourth century BC, and even he didn't tell us that much, because only fragments of his work survive today. In fact, we had to wait until somewhere around the fifth century AD, and De Re Coquinaria (On Cookery), by Apicius, to get a real picture of culinary herbs. As students of Gladiator, not to mention Ben Hur, will know, the Romans loved something with a bit of kick in it, and a good many of the recipes that Apicius rattles off are, by modern standards, pretty potent in their use of spices, vinegar, honey and fish essence. Oregano, parsley, rocket, sweet cicely, chervil, sage, thyme, fennel, mint and bay all add their bit from time to time.

The habit of spicing food highly is generally thought to be the result of the need to disguise fish or meat that had gone off. Spices were far too expensive for all but the richest houses, but herbs, which grow wild and free, had the advantage of being more generally available. Also, herbals, which detailed the medical and culinary uses of herbs, became widely used after the invention of printing.

The use of herbs has a long and exceptionally vigorous tradition in Britain. Once, there wasn't a garden of a great house or monastery that did not have a substantial space devoted to growing a wide range, all of which had practical uses in the communities for which they were grown. Typically, there would be thyme, rosemary, parsley, mint, borage, chervil, coriander, dill, tansy, camphor, balm, garlic, lemon verbena, fennel, sorrel, catmint, marjoram, golden and common sage, lovage, summer and winter savory, sweet cicely, lavender, hyssop and tarragon.

We should also remember that, whatever people may think about the euro and the bogey men in Brussels, when it comes to food, the British have always been quick to pick out the best ideas from across the water and adapt them to our own purposes.

The Dean of Wells, William Turner, travelled widely in Italy and Germany, and was well acquainted with both herbs and herbals before writing the New Herbal, which appeared in three volumes during the mid-16th century. Even better known was Gerard's Herball, or Generall Historie Of Plantes, published in 1597, in which John Gerard of Holborn catalogued and described all the herbs in "the little plot of myne owne".

By the time John Evelyn came to write Acetaria, A Discourse Of Sallets, in 1699, we were familiar with all manner of European herbs, dishes and cooking techniques. Evelyn refers to "sweet, aromatick Spanish chervile"; to fennel, "the sweetest of Bologna"; avers that the best sorrel "is of Greenland"; and refers to tarragon as being "of Spanish extraction". This shows a degree of sophistication that few would be able to match today, even with all the resources of the internet at their command.

Since then, herbs have been a central part of British cookery. We may tend to think of many of them as ingredients in foreign dishes, but even a cursory study of such cookery writers as Patrick Lambe, Hannah Glasse, Elizabeth Raffald and Eliza Acton is to trace the use and influence of herbs in our own distinctive dishes. At the same time, great and beautiful gardens celebrating herbs were created century by century, from that of Lytes Cary Manor in Somerset, created in the 16th century by Sir Henry Lyte, author of the Niewe Herball, to Gertrude Jekyll's quincunx herb garden at Knebworth in Hertfordshire and the thyme walk at Highgrove, Prince Charles's country hideaway.

But perhaps we are, at long last, beginning to rediscover our love of herbs. It wasn't so very long ago that if you had wanted basil, you would have had to grow it yourself. Now, thanks to our passion for Italian food, we have basil by the bush-load. And perhaps we have the French to thank for the sprigs of tarragon, the Greeks for the oregano, and the Poles for the dill. No matter - they are all back in our kitchens, and we should be grateful for that.

I am not talking, here, about dried herbs - they have always been with us: little bottles of dull green bits of uncertain provenance carrying the ghost of the flavour of the fresh plant, which you throw away once a year, unloved, unused. There have been attempts to improve herb-preserving technology, what with "freeze drying" and plain freezing (actually, not a bad way of having tough herbs such as parsley and tarragon ready to hand all year, but it tends to reduce the more delicate items, such as chervil, basil or marjoram, to black and bitter cud), but in reality they are nothing when compared with the fresh, unsullied article.

Which is why we are devoting this Food & Drink Summer Special to celebrating herbs, in a great many, if not quite all, their variety - where to buy them, how to grow them, how to cook them, even how to drink them. This is the season of the fresh herb, after all. If you are grand, you can grow them in a traditional knot garden. If you're not at all grand, you can grow them, as I do, on the small patch at the back of the house. You can grow them in pots. You can grown them in window-boxes, and plunder them at will. And, of course, if you are desperate, you can pick up the packets at your local superstore or, if you're lucky, find them at a farmers' market.

And once you have them, toss them into salads, sprinkle them over barbecued bits and bobs, infuse drinks with them, turn them in jellies, or just sniff and nibble them, if you have a mind to. But, whatever you do, heap them "with unsparing hand", to quote Evelyn quoting Milton. Parsimony has no place when it comes to herbs. Or in anything to do with food and drink, come to that.

Mounchlet

From Curye On Inglysch (14th/15th century), adapted by Maggie Black. 'Take veel other(wise) motoun and smyte it to gobettes. Seeth it in gode broth; cast thereto erbs yhewe gode won, and a quantitie of onyouns mynced, powdour fort and safroun, and alye it with ayren and vaerious; but notlet it seeth after.'

900g stewing lamb, mutton (or veal)

425ml chicken stock

2 medium onions, chopped

1 tbsp chopped parsley

-1 tsp each of fresh rosemary leaves, thyme leaves, and savory or marjoram leaves, bruised

tsp each ground ginger, cumin and coriander

Salt to taste

225ml white wine

2 eggs

2 tsp lemon juice

Cut the meat into 5cm cubes. Put the stock into a stewpan and bring to the boil. Add the meat and bring back to the boil. Skim if needed, then add the onions, herbs, spices, salt and wine.

Reduce the heat, cover the pan, and cook gently until the meat cubes are cooked through and tender (about one to one and a half hours). Beat the egg with the lemon juice until blended, then take the pan off the heat and stir the egg mixture gradually into the stew to thicken it slightly. Do not re-boil.

Salat

From John Russell's Boke Of Nurture (c1460) - unfortunately, I have been unable to trace the modern translations of some of the ingredients, but you should get the general idea, nonetheless.

'Take parsel [parsley], sawge [sage], garlec [garlic], chichollas [spring onions], onions [sweet onions], leek, borage, myntes [mint], porrectes, fenel [fennel], and ton tressis, rew [rue], rosemarye, purslane, lave and waisshe them clene. Pike hem, pluk hem small with thyn hond and myng hem wel with rawe oile. Lay on vynegar and salt and serve it forth.'

Wash and clean the vegetables and herbs, and dry thoroughly. Slice the vegetables as thinly as possible. Chop the garlic finely. Tear the herbs into small pieces. Mix and moisten with just enough oil to coat them. Sprinkle with vinegar and salt.

To farce all things

From The Good Housewife's Jewel, by Thomas Dawson (1596).

'Take a good handful of thyme, hyssop, and three or four yolks of eggs, hard roasted, and chop them, with herbs, small. Then take white bread, grated, and raw eggs with sweet butter, a few small raisins or barberries; seasoning it with pepper, mace, cinnamon and ginger; working it together as paste. Then may you stuff with it what you will.'

To dresse a rabbet

From Receipts Medicinal, by John Evelyn (1695).

'Set a rabbet well in a pot, with the liver, then take him out and cut him in four or five, then put him in a faire dish with a good handfull of parsley minced small with a litle bundle of time and three or four apples quartered, some sugar, four blades of large mace, halfe a pinte of clarret wine, one handfull of currants, one or two ounces of butter; then fill it up with water and set it astewing together, until it be tender, keeping it very close covered, then put in an whole onyon, and so serve it upon sippetts with a garnish.'

An herb pie for Lent

From The Experienced English Housekeeper, by Elizabeth Raffald (1769).

'Take lettuce, leeks, spinach, beets and parsley, of each a handful. Give them a boil, then chop them small, and have ready boiled in a cloth one quart of groats with two or three onions in them. Put them in a frying pan with the herbs and a good deal of salt, a pound of butter and a few apples cut thin. Stew them a few minutes on the fire, fill your dish or raised crust with it, one hour will bake it. Then serve it up.'

Broiled mackerel

From The London Art Of Cookery, by John Farley (1783).

'Having cleaned your mackerel, split them down the back, and season them with pepper and salt, some mint, parsley, and fennel chopped very fine. Flour them and broil [grill or barbecue] of a fine light brown, and put them on a dish and strainer. Let your sauce be fennel and butter, and garnish them with parsley.'

Savoury potato balls

From The Dinner Question, Or How To Dine Well And Economically, by Tabitha Tickletooth (1860).

'Mash with a little pepper and salt some well boiled potatoes, first with butter (an ounce to each pound), and then with three tablespoonfuls of milk, or two of cream, in the same proportion.

Add two sprigs of chopped parsley, one sprig or marjoram and another of lemon thyme. Make the paste into balls, roll them in flour or egg and breadcrumbs, and fry them with either butter or good dripping until they are light brown'

But perhaps we are, at long last, beginning to rediscover our love of herbs. It wasn't so very long ago that if you had wanted basil, you would have had to grow it yourself. Now, thanks to our passion for Italian food, we have basil by the bush-load. And perhaps we have the French to thank for the sprigs of tarragon, the Greeks for the oregano, and the Poles for the dill. No matter - they are all back in our kitchens, and we should be grateful for that. I am not talking, here, about dried herbs - they have always been with us: little bottles of dull green bits of uncertain provenance carrying the ghost of the flavour of the fresh plant, which you throw away once a year, unloved, unused. There have been attempts to improve herb-preserving technology, what with "freeze drying" and plain freezing (actually, not a bad way of having tough herbs such as parsley and tarragon ready to hand all year, but it tends to reduce the more delicate items, such as chervil, basil or marjoram, to black and bitter cud), but in reality they are nothing when compared with the fresh, unsullied article. Which is why we are devoting this Food & Drink Summer Special to celebrating herbs, in a great many, if not quite all, their variety - where to buy them, how to grow them, how to cook them, even how to drink them. This is the season of the fresh herb, after all. If you are grand, you can grow them in a traditional knot garden. If you're not at all grand, you can grow them, as I do, on the small patch at the back of the house. You can grow them in pots. You can grown them in window-boxes, and plunder them at will. And, of course, if you are desperate, you can pick up the packets at your local superstore or, if you're lucky, find them at a farmers' market. And once you have them, toss them into salads, sprinkle them over barbecued bits and bobs, infuse drinks with them, turn them in jellies, or just sniff and nibble them, if you have a mind to. But, whatever you do, heap them "with unsparing hand", to quote Evelyn quoting Milton. Parsimony has no place when it comes to herbs. Or in anything to do with food and drink, come to that. Mounchlet From Curye On Inglysch (14th/15th century), adapted by Maggie Black. 'Take veel other(wise) motoun and smyte it to gobettes. Seeth it in gode broth; cast thereto erbs yhewe gode won, and a quantitie of onyouns mynced, powdour fort and safroun, and alye it with ayren and vaerious; but notlet it seeth after.' 900g stewing lamb, mutton (or veal) 425ml chicken stock 2 medium onions, chopped 1 tbsp chopped parsley -1 tsp each of fresh rosemary leaves, thyme leaves, and savory or marjoram leaves, bruised tsp each ground ginger, cumin and coriander Salt to taste 225ml white wine 2 eggs 2 tsp lemon juice Cut the meat into 5cm cubes. Put the stock into a stewpan and bring to the boil. Add the meat and bring back to the boil. Skim if needed, then add the onions, herbs, spices, salt and wine. Reduce the heat, cover the pan, and cook gently until the meat cubes are cooked through and tender (about one to one and a half hours). Beat the egg with the lemon juice until blended, then take the pan off the heat and stir the egg mixture gradually into the stew to thicken it slightly. Do not re-boil. Salat From John Russell's Boke Of Nurture (c1460) - unfortunately, I have been unable to trace the modern translations of some of the ingredients, but you should get the general idea, nonetheless. 'Take parsel [parsley], sawge [sage], garlec [garlic], chichollas [spring onions], onions [sweet onions], leek, borage, myntes [mint], porrectes, fenel [fennel], and ton tressis, rew [rue], rosemarye, purslane, lave and waisshe them clene. Pike hem, pluk hem small with thyn hond and myng hem wel with rawe oile. Lay on vynegar and salt and serve it forth.' Wash and clean the vegetables and herbs, and dry thoroughly. Slice the vegetables as thinly as possible. Chop the garlic finely. Tear the herbs into small pieces. Mix and moisten with just enough oil to coat them. Sprinkle with vinegar and salt. To farce all things From The Good Housewife's Jewel, by Thomas Dawson (1596). 'Take a good handful of thyme, hyssop, and three or four yolks of eggs, hard roasted, and chop them, with herbs, small. Then take white bread, grated, and raw eggs with sweet butter, a few small raisins or barberries; seasoning it with pepper, mace, cinnamon and ginger; working it together as paste. Then may you stuff with it what you will.' To dresse a rabbet From Receipts Medicinal, by John Evelyn (1695). 'Set a rabbet well in a pot, with the liver, then take him out and cut him in four or five, then put him in a faire dish with a good handfull of parsley minced small with a litle bundle of time and three or four apples quartered, some sugar, four blades of large mace, halfe a pinte of clarret wine, one handfull of currants, one or two ounces of butter; then fill it up with water and set it astewing together, until it be tender, keeping it very close covered, then put in an whole onyon, and so serve it upon sippetts with a garnish.' An herb pie for Lent From The Experienced English Housekeeper, by Elizabeth Raffald (1769). 'Take lettuce, leeks, spinach, beets and parsley, of each a handful. Give them a boil, then chop them small, and have ready boiled in a cloth one quart of groats with two or three onions in them. Put them in a frying pan with the herbs and a good deal of salt, a pound of butter and a few apples cut thin. Stew them a few minutes on the fire, fill your dish or raised crust with it, one hour will bake it. Then serve it up.' Broiled mackerel From The London Art Of Cookery, by John Farley (1783). 'Having cleaned your mackerel, split them down the back, and season them with pepper and salt, some mint, parsley, and fennel chopped very fine. Flour them and broil [grill or barbecue] of a fine light brown, and put them on a dish and strainer. Let your sauce be fennel and butter, and garnish them with parsley.' Savoury potato balls From The Dinner Question, Or How To Dine Well And Economically, by Tabitha Tickletooth (1860). 'Mash with a little pepper and salt some well boiled potatoes, first with butter (an ounce to each pound), and then with three tablespoonfuls of milk, or two of cream, in the same proportion. Add two sprigs of chopped parsley, one sprig or marjoram and another of lemon thyme. Make the paste into balls, roll them in flour or egg and breadcrumbs, and fry them with either butter or good dripping until they are light brown'

fields.headline: Where thyme stands still
fields.standfirst: Chelsea Physic Garden started life as a living library of plants, in particular herbs, and of their culinary and medical uses. Over the centuries, it has evolved into one of the most important herb patches in the world. So how come so few people know it's there, asks Gardeners' World presenter, Rachel de Thame
fields.trailText: Chelsea Physic Garden started life as a living library of plants, in particular herbs, and of their culinary and medical uses. Over the centuries, it has evolved into one of the most important herb patches in the world. So how come so few people know it's there, asks Gardeners' World presenter, Rachel de Thame
fields.body:
Sandwiched between one of the most fashionable shopping areas in London and the River Thames is a truly secret garden - even to most locals. The Chelsea Physic Garden is a true oasis: four magical acres in the heart of the big smoke. It's the sort of place that you plan to visit for an hour or two, only to find that four have slipped by before you've even noticed. But, enchanting as it is, there is a practical history behind this most secluded corner of London.

From the Middle Ages onwards, the plants you grew - if you were fortunate enough to have your own land, that is - depended to a great extent on your level in society. The gardens of the lower ranks would be filled predominantly with common salads and vegetables. Those belonging to wealthy households, however, in addition to growing a far wider choice of vegetables, would also contain a selection of medicinal plants - henbane, for example, a powerful poison if taken in large quantities, but much used as a tranquilliser and to allay pain; or agrimony, which was used as a gargle to relax sore throats, or sipped to treat diarrhoea; and hyssop, which was used to treat a wide range of ailments, from coughs, colds and asthma to black eyes and stomach complaints.

Other herbs, meanwhile, were cultivated purely for their culinary value, and contributed greatly to the palatability of the often bland and repetitive dishes of the time. And in the houses of the upper orders, posies of aromatic herbs were used as decoration, in the belief that their perfume would have a sanitising effect, cleansing the air and warding off potentially fatal diseases.

At that time, the importance of herbs in treating illness was absolutely vital. It is hard for us today - with our armoury of prescription medicines, antibiotics and a pharmacist on every high street - to remember just how fragile life can be. As is still the case in many parts of the world, the simplest ailments and infections were often fatal, and herbal remedies offered the only chance of survival. Many of those herbs were native to Britain, and grew wild (as they still do today), and as such poorer families would collect and use them in an attempt to stave off disease.

There were privately-owned herb gardens, but these were usually very small. As a result, apothecaries were hindered in the practice of their art by poor access to a sufficiently wide range of plants, and by a lack of training. As a result, by the 17th century the large physic gardens became vital as places where an enormous range of herbs could be collected, studied, and their medicinal and culinary effects recorded. As new plants were introduced from abroad, the gardens took on the role of living reference libraries.

Founded in 1673 by the Society of Apothecaries, the Chelsea Physic Garden is the oldest still in existence in London. Its original purpose was to gather in one place a full range of medicinal herbs and plants, thereby at last giving medical students the opportunity to study at first hand the plants they would later use to treat the sick. Today, the garden still collects and collates a vast range of plants, adding continually to the 5,000 or so species already there and exchanging seed with other botanic gardens all over the world. The garden is renowned for its mild microclimate - the olive tree, for example, fruits regularly, and many tender species survive outside all year round with only the simplest protection - and plants are arranged by family, by their use or by their region of origin.

The large area that is devoted to culinary herbs and medicinal plants is a particular inspiration. Enter the garden from Swan Walk, and you are greeted by an avenue of lavender, the enduring Lavandula 'Hidcote'. To the right of this are the herbal beds. One of these, The Garden Of World Medicine, contains plants used by ancient cultures and indigenous tribal peoples. Another displays naturally-occurring analgesics: tall opium poppies ( Papaver somniferum ), with their glaucous, blue-green foliage and seductive, papery blooms swaying gently above Mandragora officinarum , better known as mandrake. Plants used in modern herbal medicine, such as Arnica montana , now an endangered alpine herb, are in another section. With the recent resurgence in interest in alternative and homeopathic treatments, the repository of knowledge in this garden has proved a vital resource.

The garden also plays an important role in discovering and developing modern mainstream medicines: the Madagascar periwinkle, for example, has been found to contain a drug that is used in the treatment of cancer. Such naturally-occurring plant remedies remain a largely untapped area - only a fraction of the world's flora has been investigated - so the potential for exciting developments is enormous.

In the 17th century, "laundry gardens" were common, planted with aromatic thymes and lavender on which household linens would be laid out to dry, so becoming suffused with scent. One area of Chelsea is still devoted to plants used in perfumery and aromatherapy: a huge clump of Salvia officinalis , smothered in mauve flowers with deeper purple bracts, pumps out a strong and, to my nose, not entirely pleasant aroma. It was a favourite of the Romans, and is used today in the pharmaceuticals and cosmetics industry, as well as in the production of vermouth.

And then there are the culinary herb beds. Chelsea has one vast bed devoted to these beauties, and it fair buzzes with bees, not to mention fragrance. It contains rosemary, bay and several deliciously-named thymes - caraway, lemon and orange-scented varieties, blanketed in thousands of tiny flowers in soft mauves and pinks - that hail from the sun-baked hills around the Mediterranean. These grow alongside purple-leaved basils, tarragon and flat-leaf parsley, all so important to Italian cookery. Golden-leaved marjoram, widely used in Greece, joins chives, chervil, dill and parsley, all traditional herbs of the northern European kitchen. A collection of mints, grown in individual terracotta pots, are plunged up to their rims into the soil to contain their invasive growth habit.

Elsewhere, vibrant orange swathes of pot marigolds ( Calendula officinalis ) glow in the sun. Originally grown for its mildly antiseptic properties in the treatment of ulcers and wounds, marigold petals and stamens are now used to colour foods, in much the same way as saffron - indeed, many an unwitting traveller has bought what seemed like a bargain bag of "saffron" in the east Mediterranean, unaware that it was full of marigold. Butterflies dart around the herb blooms, which grow among red orache and pink-flowered red valerian, adding to a cocktail of colours that is brought to order by an edging of santolina, punctuated by a clipped box ball at each corner.

It's enough to inspire anyone to plant a small herb garden of their own. After all, popping vacuum-packed herbs into your supermarket trolley may be convenient, but it's not the same as strolling into your garden, enjoying the sight, scent and texture of the plants, and then the enhanced taste that comes with freshness. Once you've tasted tea made with freshly-picked mint, say, and enjoyed the delicate colour and intense flavour, you'll never buy a box of mint teabags again.

 Chelsea Physic Garden, 66 Royal Hospital Road, London SW3, 020-7352 5646. Open Weds, 12 noon-5pm, Sun, 2-6pm.
