I haven't retained much of an impression of her in National Velvet, although if I blink I can see her in jodhpurs, her hair tied up with a bow, the beauty spot on her cheek - already too sophisticated to look like a real little girl who loved horses. I can visualise her more clearly in Jane Eyre, although she had a tiny part. She played Helen, the angelic child who befriends Jane in the orphanage and dies beautifully. I remember her dark eyes gazing out of an unearthly white face. She was, of course, too good to be true - and probably would have been better cast as one of Jane's nasty, spoiled relatives. But I loved her satiny voice and believed in her sweetness. The films that stand out for me are the ones in which she was a poor little rich girl. Or, sometimes, the beautiful rich bitch. They were all made between the early 50s and the mid-60s, when she was at her swooning loveliest. Watching her was like basking in the reflected glory of her shimmering youthfulness. When I look back at those films now, as a body of work, I am struck by how dark they were. There was often the suggestion of something corrupt about her beauty, that it was both damaged and damaging; a hint of moral decay behind the succulent peachiness. She is a siren of doom, driving the men around her to murder or self-destruction. I rather think it was this sickness behind the bloom that I liked. There was also a frisson - a sort of fag-haggy appeal - in acknowledging the relationship between her status as a gay icon and her friendships with her leading men, who tended to be homosexual: Montgomery Clift in A Place In The Sun and Suddenly Last Summer; Rock Hudson and James Dean in Giant. But I don't think I would have responded to Liz so viscerally if she had been merely camp. There is a dangerous undertow to these films; a sense in which some sort of malign energy, which both emanates from her and is beyond her control, is propelling the protagonists to their downfall. Her kind of brittle shallowness can kill. The film that sums up this quality for me is, oddly, not A Place In The Sun - in which the rich girl's new boyfriend drowns his discarded pregnant girlfriend, which might seem to fit the bill more neatly - but Suddenly Last Summer. It still strikes me as astonishing that such an overtly homosexual theme could have been tackled on the screen as early as 1959. Here, the sickness is almost tangible. Young Liz in her white bathing suit - the fleshy bait to lure penniless young beach boys into the arms of her homosexual cousin; his harridan mother (Katharine Hepburn) in her throne-like chair on the veranda ordering a lobotomy for her hysterical niece in order to obliterate the memory of what happened on the day her son died; the ending - even now it makes me shiver to recall it: the boys who had been preyed upon by the cousin chasing him up the hill, joined by other children on the way to the top, tearing his immaculate white suit to shreds, and then his flesh. There was a time, at the height of her stardom, when Liz's fans - in their eagerness to steal a part of her lustre for themselves - were in danger of ripping her apart. They would grab at her hair, her mink coats, her fabulous jewels. There was something about her appeal that was as universal as the strange kinship the public felt for Princess Diana. When Liz was taken to hospital with pneumonia in 1961 and was reported as being close to death, fans pulled their cars to the side of the road and prayed for her recovery. If Liz had died then, she would have become a Marilyn or a Princess Di. Like them, she was a goddess who could pull us into her orbit. Her battle with weight, her weaknesses for a bad man and a good frock, were our own little lives writ large. You could even forgive her ostentatious displays of wealth and her excessive habits, since they so evidently did not bring her happiness. It is a peculiar quirk of fame that such an untypical woman can also, at some level, be an Everywoman. When I started to write this piece, I was concerned that it might sound deranged to be exploring the idea that I felt a personal connection with Liz because someone once said that I bore a passing resemblance to her. I reminded myself of the old bag in a film I once saw, who thrust a photograph of Princess Diana in front of her hairdresser and announced, "I want to look like that." But I have come across other women who also have been told that they look like Liz - and none of them looks like me. My children's middle-aged nanny - one of the old guard in a tweed skirt and sensible shoes - used to tell me that people said she had Liz Taylor's eyes. A former colleague, an alluring scruff with unkempt hair, was often persuaded - particularly by men who wanted to kiss them - that she had Liz Taylor's lips. And I have the tip of her nose. Perhaps this is how we divide Liz up for ourselves, so that we all own a bit of her. A few months ago, I was sent a postcard by an acquaintance. It is split into two halves. On one side is Liz in the pink towelling turban, the one when she was 33. On the other is Liz in the same headgear, at 60. Her eyes look as though they have been widened; her lips seem to be puffed up by silicone. Her oval face has lost its definition. I'm not sure whether any message was intended - but, anyway, she still looks wonderful to me. This won't, however, be going on any noticeboards. That moment has passed © Ginny Dougary. This article appears in OK You Mugs: Writers On Movie Actors, edited by Luc Sante, to be published by Granta on July 20, priced £10.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: As a woman with advanced breast cancer who has been fighting the disease since the age of 30 - and having always been suspicious of my physical response to the Pill - I was horrified by the casual comment made by Professor Guillebaud in relation to the Pill and breast cancer (A Daily Help, June 17). Many of my own consultants have commented on the sudden increase in the number of younger women dying of breast cancer. Guillebaud's dismissive remark concerning the age at which the risks from the Pill decreases was very worrying.
fields.body:
As a woman with advanced breast cancer who has been fighting the disease since the age of 30 - and having always been suspicious of my physical response to the Pill - I was horrified by the casual comment made by Professor Guillebaud in relation to the Pill and breast cancer (A Daily Help, June 17). Many of my own consultants have commented on the sudden increase in the number of younger women dying of breast cancer. Guillebaud's dismissive remark concerning the age at which the risks from the Pill decreases was very worrying.

Perhaps he ought to consider a room full of 1,000 women 30 years ago, all of them aged 35 and under, and a similar room today. How many more women in that latter room would be facing an early death from breast cancer? (Incidentally, the risk of dying from breast cancer reduces with age.)
Amanda O'Leary
Nottingham

As a long-term Pill-user recovering from a hysterectomy to treat endometrial cancer, it was with concern that I read in Tania Unsworth's article that the Pill reduces the risk of this disease by 60%.
Name and address supplied

I once saw Derek Jarman interviewed on TV when he was already ill, and was so moved that I sent him a donation for an Aids charity (The Last Reel, June 17). To my surprise, I received a postcard of one of his paintings from him: 'Will send cheque on to Positive Youth, an organisation for people under 21 with HIV. What a nightmare: at least I feel I've lived my life fully. Bless you.' That card and another he sent subsequently are still on my noticeboard, seven years on, and I will always keep them.

His ability to reach out to me, a straight woman in a Cornish village, taught me a lot about humanity. I will never forget him.
Catherine Lang
Liskeard, Cornwall

Andrew Wilson claims that Christopher Lloyd is not a garden designer (Dear Weekend, June 10). Funny, last time I was at Great Dixter it appeared to have a design. Gardens were being designed well before the rise of the qualified 'garden designer' - they needed to know a bit about plants back then, though.
John Hook
West Sandford, Crediton, Devon

Horticulturalists and garden designers are, broadly speaking, in the same business. But only in the sense that Fyodor Dostoevsky and Jeffrey Archer are in the same business.
John Cornelius
London E7

If CJ Stone's journey on the Hippy Trail (On The Road Again, June 10) was his 'first time out of England', how come he attended Cardiff University? Transcendentally, perhaps?
Ken Green
Caerphilly

Why, not even one recipe for English mustard (Food, June 10)? Oh, Jeremy Lee, this doesn't quite cut it. (How about Elizabeth David's cider sausages with potatoes in mustard mayonnaise?)
Jeanne Symonds
Lewes, East Sussex

Julie Burchill's strength is that she can write about anything (June 17). Her weakness is that she does.
Ronald Morris
Beeston, Notts

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: Herb pudding recipes
fields.standfirst: Mint tea sorbet, rosemary jellies, lavender syllabub, bayleaf junket and rose-geranium and almond torte: Elizabeth Luard shares some of her favourite recipes
fields.trailText: Mint tea sorbet, rosemary jellies, lavender syllabub, bayleaf junket and rose-geranium and almond torte: Elizabeth Luard shares some of her favourite recipes
fields.body:
Mint tea sorbet with chocolate mint leaves

A refreshing sorbet, finished with mint leaves brushed with dark chocolate - peppermint crisps are the easy way out. Serves four.

1 large handful fresh mint

1 tbsp green tea

100g white sugar lumps

Juice of 2 lemons

1 egg white

To finish

8 large, perfect mint leaves

3-4 squares bitter chocolate

Rinse the mint and cram it into a jug with the tea. Pour in 300ml boiling water and leave to infuse for five minutes. Add the sugar, stir thoroughly and leave to cool. Strain and add the lemon juice. Freeze for an hour or so, until ice crystals have formed but the mixture is not yet hard. Scoop into the liquidiser, add the egg white and process until pale and frothy. Freeze again until solid. It'll be ready in three to four hours, but can be left for longer, if required.

To finish, melt the chocolate gently in a small bowl over boiling water. Brush the undersides of the mint leaves with the melted chocolate, transfer to a plate lined with cling- film and set briefly in the freezer to firm. Scoop the sorbet into well-chilled glasses, and tuck in a pair of mint leaves per serving. A trickle of crème de menthe would serve to gild the lily.

Rosemary, vodka and orange jellies

A grown-up dessert - put childish things behind you, but don't lose the plot. Serve with a crisp little biscuit - something sophisticated, such as an almond tuile. Serves six.

2-3 small sprigs fresh rosemary

25g gelatine (leaf or powder)

100g caster sugar

600ml fresh orange juice

Zest of 1 orange, cut into fine strips

150ml vodka

In a small pan, bring 150ml water and the rosemary sprigs (save any flowers or tips of sprigs for decoration) up to the boil, switch off the heat and leave to cool and infuse. Remove the rosemary, sprinkle in the gelatine (if using leaf-gelatine, soften first in cold water and tear into small pieces), leave for about 10 minutes to swell, then stir over a gentle heat until the gelatine dissolves completely.

Meanwhile, in another pan, heat the orange juice and vodka with the zest and sugar, stirring till the crystals dissolve. Remove the zest with a draining spoon and reserve. Off the heat, combine the two liquids, whisking to blend thoroughly. Allow to cool a little before dividing between six stemmed glasses - cocktail glasses for retro-chic. Finish with the reserved orange-zest and rosemary.

Lavender syllabub with lavender caramel

Very Barbara Cartland, this. If fresh lavender eludes you, use flowering thyme instead. Serves four to six.

For the syllabub

2-3 fresh lavender spikes

150ml white wine

2 tbsp caster sugar

Juice of 1 lemon

300ml chilled double cream *

1 tbsp eau-de-vie or brandy

For the caramel

3 tbsp caster sugar

1 tsp fresh lavender flowers

Heat the wine in a small pan, removing it just before it comes to the boil, and add the lavender spikes. Leave to infuse for 10 minutes, strain, and stir in the sugar, lemon juice and eau-de-vie. Whisk the cream until it begins to hold its shape - don't overwhip, or it'll turn to butter. Whisk in the lavender-wine infusion, and refrigerate.

Meanwhile, make the finishing caramel. Heat a heavy frying pan over a medium heat, and sprinkle in the sugar. Watch carefully as it melts and then caramelises - don't let it burn. As it cooks, shake the pan every now and then, to distribute the crystals evenly, but do not stir. As soon as the sugar melts to a warm brown, remove from the heat and stir in the lavender flowers. Pour on to a lightly oiled marble slab or plate, and leave to cool and set. Once hardened, place the caramel between two sheets of clingfilm, bash it with a rolling pin to break into small pieces. Fold these into the syllabub just before serving.

Bayleaf junket

Fresh bayleaf - peppery, spicy, an underlying sweetness - is the perfect perfume for a delicate junket, which is the soft curd that forms when rennet, a digestive enzyme present in the stomachs of all mammals including ourselves, is added to warm milk. A delicate emulsion that splits all too easily into curds-and-whey, junket is never likely to be found loitering among the mousses and low-fat fromage frais in the supermarket's chill cabinet - which is a recommendation in itself. Serves four.

600ml full-cream milk

1 tsp rennet (if you can't get it from the supermarket, try the local health-food store)

2 fresh bayleaves, torn in half

To serve

Single cream

Demerara sugar

Leave the bayleaves to infuse in the milk in a pan for an hour or two. Gently warm the milk to just below boiling point - test the heat with a clean finger. Remove the bayleaves and stir in the rennet. Pour immediately into four small earthenware pots or glass tumblers. Cover with a cloth, and leave to set in a cool place for a couple of hours, until the surface is firm to the touch. To serve, trickle with a thin layer of cream and a generous crust of crunchy sugar. Delicious with a ripe fig - a fruit to which bayleaf, with its faint flavour of liquorice, has a particular affinity.

Rose-geranium and almond torte with rosewater syrup

When bruised or crushed, rose- geranium leaves release an astonishingly powerful scent. Elusively exquisite in a fruit salad or, as here, used to perfume a simple sponge-cake - no flour, nothing fancy, just fragrant. You're not likely to find rose-geranium down at the local greengrocer's, so head for the garden centre and add a potful to your window-box. Lemon balm makes an equally fragrant substitute. Serves six to eight.

3-4 rose-geranium leaves, rinsed and dried

Butter for greasing

4 medium eggs

175g caster sugar

250g ground almonds

To finish

2-3 rose-geranium leaves, shredded

2 tbsp rose-water

2 tbsp honey

Juice of 1 lemon

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Butter an 18cm sponge-cake tin and arrange the rose-geranium leaves on the base. Whisk the eggs, whites and yolks together, until frothy. Still whisking, sprinkle in the sugar, and whisk until the mixture is white, stiff and holds its shape in soft peaks - this will take twice as long as you expect. With a metal spoon, lightly fold in the ground almonds. Spoon over the leaves in the tin, and bake for 45-50 minutes, until well-risen and firm to the finger. Wait for 10 minutes before turning out on to a plate - lacking flour, it shrinks alarmingly. No matter, since it tastes delicious.

Meanwhile, put all the finishing ingredients in a small pan, along with six tablespoons of water, bring to the boil, then simmer until reduced to half volume. Pour the hot syrup over the warm cake - it'll absorb it like a sponge. Exquisite with summer berries and crème fraiche

fields.headline: Public man, private passions
fields.standfirst: Son of a celebrated composer, he joined a rock band before becoming a successful broadcaster, arts administrator and part-time farmer. But, says Stephen Moss,  Michael Berkeley's new opera reflects his real ambition - to follow in his father's footsteps
fields.trailText: Son of a celebrated composer, he joined a rock band before becoming a successful broadcaster, arts administrator and part-time farmer. But, says Stephen Moss, Michael Berkeley's new opera reflects his real ambition - to follow in his father's footsteps
fields.body:
'I'd know that voice anywhere," said the man standing behind Michael Berkeley in the queue at Cardiff station. Berkeley's is one of the few voices - deep, lilting, seductive - that could make asking for a ticket to Ludlow so striking. But would the man, who confessed to being an amateur singer, have known Berkeley's music? Probably not: it is the conundrum at the heart of Michael Berkeley's life.

Berkeley is a composer of, for want of a better term, serious contemporary music. He has written more than 50 orchestral and chamber scores, and next Friday will unveil his second opera, Jane Eyre. His first, Baa Baa Black Sheep, was staged in 1993. His output is diverse; his reputation is growing; he considers himself a "late developer" and says the best is yet to come. Yet, despite his protestations, he is still better known as a broadcaster and administrator than as a composer; many of his works have not been recorded and too many of those that were put on disc have been deleted.

His music, especially his vocal music, is very accessible; melodies come readily to him (sometimes too readily, he says) and lodge in the listener's head; yet he is lazily lumped together with avant-gardists and minimalists by audiences who write off new music in its entirety as unlistenable. Talking a couple of years ago about Private Passions, the Desert Island Discs-style programme he presents on Radio 3, he said: "It has disconcerted me that we've still got such a long way to go with really intelligent people in terms of contemporary music." That gap, despite his efforts as composer and communicator, is still huge, the residual fear of the new and dissonant palpable.

"The problem with contemporary music - and its magic - is that it's as if it came from another planet," Berkeley once said. He went on to make a clever point about Bernard Herrmann's music in Hitchcock's Psycho: that in the concert hall, audiences would find it jarring and difficult, but because it comes clothed with images its demands are accepted. "If only people could approach music with a completely open mind and allow it to build a landscape in the mind with dramatic and visual images, then it becomes a much more enriching experience."

Berkeley is best known for presenting Private Passions and for having been thrust into the role of spokesman for the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, when it faced financial and administrative meltdown in 1998 ("I joined the board expecting to go to eight or nine meetings a year and ended up in there every other day, trying to hold everything together," he recalls ruefully). Whenever a major job in the small, hothouse classical-music world comes up, Berkeley's name is put in the frame. He was tipped to take over from Nicholas Kenyon as controller of Radio 3 in 1998, and will no doubt be mooted as a possible successor to Michael Kaiser when he steps down next year as chief executive of the Opera House. There is just one problem: despite public perceptions, he doesn't want to be a bureaucrat.

"There's no way I would give up the daytime of my life to be an administrator," he says. "It's ridiculous. It's like saying to David Hockney 'you should be running BBC2'. It's not compatible with being a creative artist. Composing occupies by far the largest part of my life and anything else I do has to fit around it."

What if Covent Garden, which has managed to get through four chief executives in as many years, came calling? "There are moments of temptation, but if you want to be a serious composer you have to eschew them. It's not just the money that is tempting; you could do a lot if you were head of Radio 3 or the Opera House, you could do a lot about the things that you believe in. But I want to be an artist rather than a mandarin. All my life I've fought to retain large pockets of time in which to compose.

"Michael Kaiser and I got on very well because he is utterly committed to both opera and ballet, and I'm sorry to see him go. He leaves the place in very good working order. We are financially more stable now than at any time since I joined the board in 1996, the rebuilding of the house has been completed and the artistic direction of both companies is very happily in place. There is an exciting job for a new chief executive, but that person won't be me. I am pleased to be able to help on the artistic side, but I am, and always will be, a composer."

Composing is in the blood. He is the son of Sir Lennox Berkeley, a composer of great economy and elegance, whose music has fallen out of favour; he is also the godson of Benjamin Britten, one of the commanding figures of 20th- century British music. Berkeley junior knew from the age of six that he wanted to be a composer, and his determination has never wavered. He worked at London Weekend Television in the mid-70s and then joined the staff of Radio 3, but the media always played second fiddle to his artistic impulse.

He has shown an admirable commitment to the muse, but some critics are less than convinced that the muse has kept her side of the bargain. "Because of his father there was an expectation that he would be a creative person," says one. "He is a brilliant communicator, broadcaster and festival organiser, but his music never really attains that level of excellence. It's an example of the Sullivan syndrome: just as Sir Arthur was dissatisfied with all the Gilbert and Sullivan stuff and wanted to write grand opera, so Michael is dissatisfied with being a great communicator and wants to be a great composer. "His misfortune is to be one of a generation of prodigious talents - Oliver Knussen, Colin Matthews, George Benjamin. He just doesn't have the same individuality of voice as them."

That verdict might have held true a decade ago, but is unfair now. In the 80s, Berkeley was striving to find a voice, and was locked into an English lyrical tradition that seemed passé and derivative. In the past 10 years, he has discovered a harder edge and a more personal style that combines rawness and dissonance with his natural lyricism.

He is not fazed by criticism of his music, because he is his own severest critic. "I'm a late developer like my father," he says. "I've only written a handful of pieces that I really like. While he admired his father, the relationship became a little distant, and it is tempting to read into his thoughts on the repressiveness of Sir Lennox's music a critique of his rarefied upbringing. The illness did, however, concentrate the mind. He went to study with the composer Richard Rodney Bennett, now best known for his film scores but at that point regarded as a rising avant-garde talent, who started to temper Berkeley's natural lyricism with greater rigour.

As well as leaving Broadcasting House for the uncertain life of a freelance (he felt his music would never get a fair hearing on the station if he remained on the staff), he also got married - to Deborah Rogers, now one of the UK's leading literary agents - and bought (for £5,000) a farmhouse in Powys, just a few miles across the border from Hereford but very isolated, tranquil and beautiful - a bolt-hole, a place to compose. He met a local farm labourer, Steven Morgan, and they went into partnership, rearing cattle and sheep. The event hit the headlines; he was interviewed on the Today programme; appeals were made; rewards offered; but the briefcase containing the manuscript was never found. Berkeley was devastated. "He went through torment. He was in despair," says his friend, the critic and broadcaster Robert Sandall. "He had struggled to get it going and then he lost it. He suffered a terrific crisis of confidence."

"I was completely shell-shocked at first," recalls Berkeley. "There were 60 pages of full score, plus sketches and the piano reduction - the template of the whole opera. What I felt I could do was pick it up from the point I had got to dramatically. I did eventually go back to the beginning, and I thought in the end it was tighter and stronger as a result."

"It's the only piece that has been commissioned from me while I've been there. We sorted this out very early on: I was going as a composer and I think it's a strength to have a practising composer running a festival and contributing pieces every now and again, just as Michael Tippett did at Bath. I didn't go there as an administrator; I went as a composer. You have to be careful not to abuse it, but I've put on 25 or so new pieces every year and I don't feel I've shortchanged anybody."

The production will be staged by Music Theatre Wales, which specialises in contemporary opera, and after Cheltenham it will go on tour, reaching Covent Garden's Linbury Studio in early November. It is a chamber piece for five voices and small orchestra, similar in mood to Britten's Turn Of The Screw and combining lyrical expressiveness with brooding menace.

Berkeley and Malouf have stripped the book down to its essentials. "What I like about Jane Eyre is the Bluebeardian aspect," says Berkeley. "You have to get rid of everything that is superfluous - the childhood, St John Rivers, even Grace Poole. You have to do that in opera: you cut it down to what you really need, and end up with something which is quite lean. Ultimately a libretto has to be something that needs music to breathe; if it's all there in the libretto as a satisfactory literary experience, then why bother to put music to it? The libretto that David produced clearly does need music; he once said that a libretto in itself is a poor thing. The libretto must take second place to the music."

He is intrigued by the different displays of female sexuality in the novel: "the frightening sexuality of Mrs Rochester, the flirtatious Jane, the homely Mrs Fairfax, and the young but knowing Adele, all with Rochester in the middle. The whole concept of a madwoman upstairs ululating is very operatic. Also the concept of a story which is predicated on telepathic voices - that's music, that's the thing that music can do which nothing else can do. Literature can tell you about the idea of hearing voices, but in music you can do it."

Berkeley, a romantic writing in an unromantic age, hopes that Jane Eyre will be a happy marriage of lyricism and emotional intensity. "There is a romantic side and a melodic element to the opera, but there is always something turbulent underneath. You can't do an opera about Jane Eyre and deny the romantic side of it, but there is also a dark side, and I like the friction between the two.

"I like the idea of something in which you can allow yourself to be melodically expressive, and yet there is a friction, so the audience is on the one hand seduced by the romantic-ness but on the other hand is disturbed by those things which are probably in all of us but which we don't entirely understand - to what extent is Jane being manipulative, to what extent is Rochester being truthful? I remember one or two people I trust saying to me, your language is developing but don't forsake the natural lyricism. I find lyricism in a lot of quite complex music."

In Baa Baa Black Sheep, for example, there are powerful undercurrents about the way in which children are treated. He is a vulnerable, sensitive soul, and that's all there in his work, especially in his operas where emotions are undisguised."

Berkeley is aware of the disparity between his smooth public persona and his darker musical personality, but is unable or unwilling to account for it. "We all have a dark side," he says. "Just as people assume that because you broadcast you must be socially incredibly at ease, so they assume that because you sound comfortable interviewing people that everything is at a certain level, but there are different layers. For many years I felt rather socially inept, and some of the frustrations that I felt in my relationships with people led to violent outbursts in the music as a form of release. Music gives me an outlet for things I find it difficult to articulate verbally, socially or perhaps even emotionally."

Life at a glance: Michael Fitzhardinge Berkeley

Born: May 29 1948, son of Sir Lennox and Elizabeth (née Bernstein) Berkeley.

Educated: The Oratory School, Reading; Westminster Cathedral Choir School; Royal Academy of Music; studied privately with Richard Rodney Bennett.

Married: 1979 Deborah Rogers (one daughter, Jessica).

Career: LWT; Radio 3 announcer 1974-79; composer and freelance radio and TV presenter since 1979.

Some compositions: Or Shall We Die? (1983); For The Savage Messiah (1985); Organ Concerto (1987); Entertaining Master Punch (1991); Baa Baa Black Sheep (1993); Viola Concerto (1994); Torque And Velocity (1997); The Garden Of Earthly Delights (1998); Jane Eyre (2000).

 Jane Eyre is premiered at the Everyman Theatre in Cheltenham at 8pm on 30 June.

You have to do that in opera: you cut it down to what you really need, and end up with something which is quite lean. Ultimately a libretto has to be something that needs music to breathe; if it's all there in the libretto as a satisfactory literary experience, then why bother to put music to it? The libretto that David produced clearly does need music; he once said that a libretto in itself is a poor thing. The libretto must take second place to the music." He is intrigued by the different displays of female sexuality in the novel: "the frightening sexuality of Mrs Rochester, the flirtatious Jane, the homely Mrs Fairfax, and the young but knowing Adele, all with Rochester in the middle. The whole concept of a madwoman upstairs ululating is very operatic. Also the concept of a story which is predicated on telepathic voices - that's music, that's the thing that music can do which nothing else can do. Literature can tell you about the idea of hearing voices, but in music you can do it." Berkeley, a romantic writing in an unromantic age, hopes that Jane Eyre will be a happy marriage of lyricism and emotional intensity. "There is a romantic side and a melodic element to the opera, but there is always something turbulent underneath. You can't do an opera about Jane Eyre and deny the romantic side of it, but there is also a dark side, and I like the friction between the two. "I like the idea of something in which you can allow yourself to be melodically expressive, and yet there is a friction, so the audience is on the one hand seduced by the romantic-ness but on the other hand is disturbed by those things which are probably in all of us but which we don't entirely understand - to what extent is Jane being manipulative, to what extent is Rochester being truthful? I remember one or two people I trust saying to me, your language is developing but don't forsake the natural lyricism. I find lyricism in a lot of quite complex music." Michael McCarthy, director of Jane Eyre, says he is a welcome presence in rehearsals. "His ego has never got in the way, and he lets us question the work and ask how and why. He knows what he is doing and where he is going, what depths he is plumbing emotionally. His music can take him into darker places than you might imagine or that he could ever describe in words. In Baa Baa Black Sheep, for example, there are powerful undercurrents about the way in which children are treated. He is a vulnerable, sensitive soul, and that's all there in his work, especially in his operas where emotions are undisguised." Berkeley is aware of the disparity between his smooth public persona and his darker musical personality, but is unable or unwilling to account for it. "We all have a dark side," he says. "Just as people assume that because you broadcast you must be socially incredibly at ease, so they assume that because you sound comfortable interviewing people that everything is at a certain level, but there are different layers. For many years I felt rather socially inept, and some of the frustrations that I felt in my relationships with people led to violent outbursts in the music as a form of release. Music gives me an outlet for things I find it difficult to articulate verbally, socially or perhaps even emotionally." Life at a glance: Michael Fitzhardinge Berkeley Born: May 29 1948, son of Sir Lennox and Elizabeth (née Bernstein) Berkeley. Educated: The Oratory School, Reading; Westminster Cathedral Choir School; Royal Academy of Music; studied privately with Richard Rodney Bennett. Married: 1979 Deborah Rogers (one daughter, Jessica). Career: LWT; Radio 3 announcer 1974-79; composer and freelance radio and TV presenter since 1979. Some compositions: Or Shall We Die? (1983); For The Savage Messiah (1985); Organ Concerto (1987); Entertaining Master Punch (1991); Baa Baa Black Sheep (1993); Viola Concerto (1994); Torque And Velocity (1997); The Garden Of Earthly Delights (1998); Jane Eyre (2000).  Jane Eyre is premiered at the Everyman Theatre in Cheltenham at 8pm on 30 June.

fields.headline: The last word on   Faith
fields.standfirst: Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and even from these dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope.  - Herman Melville
fields.trailText: Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and even from these dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope. - Herman Melville
fields.body:
Last week a bomb went off in the marketplace of Mascara in Algeria, killing over 40 people. It was another incident in the tragic war being waged by religious fundamentalists against a society which they see as too secular and tolerant.

At just the time this happened, the Southern Baptist Convention met in the United States to reaffirm its traditionalist stance - against unmarried sex and homosexuality, requiring women to remain in traditional roles, including being subject to their husbands, accepting the Bible as literally true and "error-free" and - a resolution adopted last week - reaffirming its belief that only men can be pastors. The Convention announced that it was thereby "putting the brakes" on America's slide into immorality.

To date, Southern Baptists (apart from those who kill doctors who perform abortions) have not felt so embattled and embittered by rejection of their cherished beliefs that they have resorted to indiscriminate mass murder, as happens wherever religious fanaticism mixes with resentment and ignorance to produce the hateful brew of what is done in the name of belief. "Faith is what I die for, dogma is what I kill for," as the saying has it; and the trouble is that all faith is based on dogma.

It is curious that responsible enquiry, of the kind conducted by scientists and expected in courts of law, is careful in drawing its conclusions, and open-minded about the possibility of contrary future evidence, whereas matters of faith are tenaciously regarded as inviolable, irrefutable, and unrevisable.

The careful and open-minded procedures of science have given us electric light, antibiotics, central heating, television and computers. Science has often been perverted to bad uses - bombs and gas-chambers - but it is politics and politicians, not science and scientists, who do that. Religious belief, meanwhile, whatever it might do in comforting the fearful in the dark, has always and everywhere brought war, intolerance, and persecution with it, and has distorted human nature into false and artificial shapes.

Some try to palliate or even excuse the monstrous crimes committed by religion in human history by invoking the glorious art and music it has produced; to which the answer is that Greek mythology and secular avocations have done the same, without burning anyone at the stake in the process.

Faith is a negation of reason. Reason is the faculty of proportioning judgment to evidence, after first weighing the evidence. Faith is belief even in the face of contrary evidence. Soren Kierkergaard defined faith as the leap taken despite everything, despite the very absurdity of what one is asked to believe.

When people can doggedly choose to believe that black is white, and can, in their utter certainty, go so far as to shoot you because you do not agree, there is little room for debate. "Faith, fanatic Faith, once wedded fast to some dear falsehood, hugs it to the last," says Thomas Moore's Veiled Prophet of Khorassan.

In the branch of philosophy called epistemology (the theory of knowledge) knowledge is defined as belief which is both true and justified. One theory describes knowledge as a relationship between a state of mind and a fact. The content of the mental state is a judgment responsibly made, and the fact is (for example) some arrangement of the world that, when the judgment is true, is what makes it so.

Belief differs from knowledge in that, whereas the latter is controlled by the facts, and depends upon the right kind of relationship between mind and world, the former is all and only in the mind, and does not rely on anything in the world. One can, in short, believe anything: that pigs fly, that grass is blue, and that people who do not believe either are wicked.

This is what makes St Augustine's remark that "faith is to believe what you do not see; the reward for faith is to see what you believe" so sinister; for if one can believe anything, one can "see" anything - and feel entitled to do anything accordingly: to live like an Old Testament patriarch, which is silly, or even to kill another human being, which is vile.

webTitle: How to grow herbs at home

fields.headline: How to grow herbs at home
fields.standfirst: Don't waste your money on those expensive, short-lived plastic packets of herbs, says Paul Thompson. They are a real cinch to grow at home - whether you've got a garden or not
fields.trailText: Don't waste your money on those expensive, short-lived plastic packets of herbs, says Paul Thompson. They are a real cinch to grow at home - whether you've got a garden or not
fields.body:
Afew sprigs or a small handful of chopped herbs is the amount you'd normally expect to use in a recipe. But buy your herbs from a shop or supermarket, and such quantities will make only the merest dent in what is more often than not a large and expensive bunch or plastic packet. At 60p-£1 per herb, that can end up costing as much, if not more, than the other main ingredients in a meal for which four or five herbs are required.

Leftover herbs face one of two fates: either a heap of once-aromatic leaves will spend a limp week in the fridge before going in the bin; or the remains of the bunch will sit in a glass of water by the sink until the water becomes a gluey, green soup of stringy, rancid stems.

But it needn't be that way. Herbs are very easy to grow at home, be that on just a window-sill or in a larger outdoor space. That's because most herbs are highly independent plants that require none of the cosseting of more rarefied species. Herbs rely for their flavour and aroma on a high distillation of essential oils, which is best achieved by growing them in full sun. However, you can still get worthwhile results in partial shade.

In the wild, herbs are toughened by harsh conditions, so over-tending them in the domestic environment will only create weak plants with diminished culinary potential. You don't even need to be picky about soil types. But the one thing all herbs need is good drainage (although a few, such as mint and parsley, will tolerate moisture-retentive soil). To assess your soil's drainage capacity, pour water on to the surface until it forms a puddle - it should then disappear fairly quickly. If it does not, then improve the drainage by digging in pea shingle to break up the topsoil and speed the flow of water from the surface to the subsoil, where it will not waterlog roots.

If your soil is highly acidic or an impenetrable clay pancake - common in cities, where spoil from house building constitutes the base of many a garden - or if you have no soil at all, a herb garden will do just as well in pots or raised beds. Wooden boxes, window-boxes and terracotta pots are ideal. (If you are a minimalist/modernist who insists on galvanised or stainless steel, line the container first with polystyrene sheeting to insulate the roots from extreme heat.) Put a good 6-10cm layer of drainage material (broken crock, pebbles or broken polystyrene) in the base of your chosen container, then add a mixture of 60% soil-based compost with 40% multi-purpose (also add drainage material - pea-shingle or perlite - at a rate of one good handful per spadeful of compost, to prevent the fine composts from suffocating roots.) Give your new plants space to grow, and water them well as they establish. And that's all there is to it. Honest.

When planting herbs in a bed, put tall herbs such as fennel, lovage and rosemary at the back, so that they do not overshadow low-growing species such as thyme, parsley and marjoram. For a less formal approach, use your herbs to plug any gaps in an established garden, and they'll happily take up whatever space is available. However, it's best not to plant mint in open ground, as it will take over in no time, so keep it restrained, in a pot, say.

In our climate, basil alone needs special attention. It loathes the wind and the wet, so, unless you can provide a really sheltered position, it is best grown on a sunny window-sill, or in a greenhouse or conservatory. It is most important that you provide a light, rich compost and water the plant at the base of its stem at midday, so that any excess water has a chance to evaporate. Basil loses its delicate sweet scent if allowed to flower or grow too large, so harvest plants when young and sow at regular intervals to maintain a crop through the summer.

Perennial or woody herbs such as lavender, rosemary and sage are best purchased as small plants, whereas most other herbs can quickly be grown from seed. If you do buy your herbs as plants, get them from a nursery, where they are more likely to be well-rooted. Those pots of "growing" herbs you see at the supermarket are invariably crowded with shallow-rooted seedlings that, when cut, will not have the vigour to put on any further worthwhile growth.

Which brings us back to where we started - what to do with left-over shop-bought fresh herbs? You could try freezing them, in which case you'd be better off using the soggy defrosted result in the cooking pot, not the salad bowl (basil, incidentally, must be blanched before freezing; or, if you have lots, fill a jar with lightly-salted layers of leaves, and pour over olive oil). Best of all, though, is to use them fresh, in a salad or omelette.

fields.headline: Mind games
fields.standfirst: Gerald Edelman and Giulio Tononi dodge the question of free will in Consciousness
fields.trailText: Gerald Edelman and Giulio Tononi dodge the question of free will in Consciousness
fields.body:
Consciousness: How Matter Becomes Imagination
Gerald Edelman and Giulio Tononi
Allen Lane, £20, 274pp
Buy it at BOL

What is water? We would expect a scientist to be able to give two sorts of explanation: one descriptive and one causal. The first would describe water as a collection of hydrogen and oxygen atoms. But that wouldn't be enough to explain our ordinary experience of water. We should further want to know why a bunch of water molecules makes a puddle rather than a lump on our kitchen floor.

To put it spectacularly crudely, wetness is to water as consciousness is to neuronal activity in the brain. Few people these days seriously doubt that consciousness arises solely from physical activity inside our skulls. But the big question is how this happens. Why does matter arranged in this way, and not others, give rise to minds?

This is a question that Gerard Edelman and Giulio Tononi signally fail to answer, despite the grand promise of their subtitle. Hardly surprising, since it is probably the toughest problem known to science. But they do sketch a hypothesis which, if experimentally verified, would go a long way towards answering a smaller but still important question - not how consciousness arises, but what kinds of brain activity are necessary to produce consciousness.

Along the way they are careful mostly to avoid the sorts of materialistic canard that have enraged philosophers such as John Searle and Jerry Fodor. Consciousness, they insist, is not an object but a process. The brain is not a computer, processing encoded information - because who would have encoded the information in the first place? And crucially, the mind is not located in any particular area of the brain but is invoked by a "dynamic core".

The core is an enormously complex set of neuronal interactions whose physical constitution changes from moment to moment. Perturbation of part of the core will very quickly alter its entire state, but activity outside the core (such as routines that regulate blood pressure) need not affect it at all. Such external routines, however, may still deliver results to the core: I am not aware of the firing of neurons in my visual cortex, but they enable my consciousness to recognise that this light is red. Similarly, the core may affect the rest of the brain by giving instructions for external automatic routines to begin.

So far, so good. This hypothesis is bolstered by an idea of brain "selectionism". Darwinian selection occurs not only in the evolution of the human brain, argue the authors, but also within each brain over its lifetime. The more successful (more "fit") neuronal routines become habitually grooved circuits so as to enable certain desired practices more easily in future.

Now hang on: who is doing the deciding? What makes certain neuronal routines fitter than others? Edelman and Tononi nominate "value systems". Some value systems are morphological: the fact that we have hands of a certain shape, with a propensity to grasp in a certain way, selects for certain motor routines above others when we are trying to raise a glass to our lips. Other "values" are provided by a large network of hormonal transmitters that, according to external stimuli, can very quickly flood the brain with, say, noradrenaline or dopamine, and thus select for different neuronal processes.

But here we reach the crux of Consciousness. Its silence throughout on the problem of will is deafening. For how does the brain decide to do anything? How does the value system itself decide what selectional constraints it is going to impose on the rest of the brain? Sometimes Edelman and Tononi imply that we are all mere automata, as when they write carelessly that conscious states "lead to" behavioural outputs, or that aspects of a visual scene "control behaviour and planning".

In one sense, we are indeed slaves to our own brains. In writing this review, I am a hostage to unconscious neuronal routines inside my head. I cannot decide to have a thought: I must simply sip my coffee, draw on my cigarette and have faith that one will come, delivered ribbon-wrapped to my dynamic core. Yet we are not controlled by our environment in the way that the authors sometimes seem to suggest; we can rebel against and even change it. It is hard to see, on the authors' model, where such decisions can come from. Further, there seems to be no obvious way to explain human beings' potential for maladaptive behaviours, such as smoking or suicide, unless you ascribe them to genetic defects in the hormonal value system.

What is the intended readership of this book? Edelman and Tononi illuminate their theories with a few excellent analogies, and yet as a whole Consciousness is extremely dense, peppered with bizarre diagrams, formulae of higher maths and, at crucial explanatory points, endnote instructions to refer to their previous publications.

As I am not a neuroscientist, I can only review Consciousness within its presumably intended genre: popular science. Well, the authors do not provide an objective survey of competitive research; their project is to promote their own work. And while they laudably insist that philosophers must base their work in neuroscience, they might have acknowledged the huge influences in the other direction. Their introductory shopping list of features of consciousness (it is unitary, coherent and private) owes everything to philosophers, yet they go on to attack philosophical straw men - hard-core Cartesians or behaviourists - who bear no relation to current work in the philosophy of mind.

Most importantly, they claim that Schopenhauer called the problem of consciousness the "world knot", and adopt this lovely image as their catchphrase. But that is not what Schopenhauer said. What he calls the "world knot", in On the Fourfold Root of the Principle of Sufficient Reason, is "the identity of the subject of willing with that of knowing". Edelman and Tononi give a remarkably rich and provocative hypothesis of the subject of knowing, but the will soars free, as yet untethered by physical explanation.

Before I get on with the review, I should declare an interest. This is, in a very loose sense, the book I weaselled out of writing. Years ago, another publisher altogether suggested that I write a book about fatherhood. I procrastinated and then, my attention span having been reduced to 45-second periods - owing, of course, to fatherhood - I let someone else take over the project, which turned into a book of essays on the subject, to which I duly made a lunatic and babbling contribution.

Could this be the anthology alluded to in the blurb on the back which states that "Books about fatherhood are either chipper, no-nonsense handbooks or collections of introspective essays, bowing under the weight of their own sensitivity"? It certainly is the one described by Charles Jennings on page 94 as having been written by "a load of hacks".

Jennings, author of Up North, a shrewd and amusing book about north/south relationships in this country, has done baffled fathers everywhere a service. For with this book he addresses the reluctant father, the one who fails miserably in the Fathers' Race on sports day, who knows that sharing the childcare right down the line is important but still doesn't like it, and who tries to weasel out of his responsibilities whenever he thinks he can get away with it. (That word "weasel" again. As Homer Simpson - the unchallengeable role model for sloppy fathering - put it, weaselling out of things is what distinguishes us from animals; apart, as he pointed out, from the weasel.)

This is why the book is commendable: its honesty. Jennings admits to his rages, the infrequent but shaming occasions when he whacks his boys (poor man - two male children), his fights with his wife, and his nebulous understanding that something in the rules of parenting has changed since his own parents' day, but without any concrete or comprehensive clue as to the precise nature of the change.

Aetas parentum, pejor avis, tulit nos nequiores mox daturos progeniem vitiosiorem, as Horace put it; or, in simple English, our parents were worse than our grandparents and we're worse than them, so wait till you get a load of our horrible children. And the whole thing is written in a perfectly acceptable, intelligent demotic, which strains a bit when it tries to communicate real thought, but on the whole delivers a good, steady stream of gently humorous verbiage - a sort of English Bill Bryson, or the way Nick Hornby would write if he hadn't been so viciously trapped by his own success. (The quote from Horace isn't in there. I just put it in to show off.) Sometimes he is very funny, particularly in the early days of pregnancy and babies, when it is easier to make panicky jokes - they're jokes about oneself, mainly.

As to whether men who are not fathers will want to buy this book - well, don't be daft, not in a million years they won't, but then fatherhood has a way of sneaking up when you least expect it. And if you have a suspicion that you might not be superdad, the kind of nauseating chap who has no trouble emoting and who can organise a great day out at the drop of a hat (as opposed to nightmarish anti-holidays), then you could do worse than look at this for consolation.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: A generous biography of the great actor-manager, plus At Home with the Marquis de Sade
fields.body:
Garrick
Ian McIntyre
(Penguin, £12.99)

Buy it at BOL

Eighteenth-century England as benign theatre: the Stratford Jubillo initiates the Shakespeare industry with sputtering fireworks by an Avon in muddy flood; Peg Woffington is paralytically stricken delivering Rosalind's epilogue and then is heard no more; patriotic riots erupt in the pit and hooligans pitch punters from the galleries of Drury Lane. And Garrick, that bantamweight actor-manager with Augustan bottom, embodies the age of reason and good humours, despite his gallstones, toothless leading ladies and imperative, importunate monarchs. Written so generously, to match its time and subject, that it might pass for a Fielding novel.

At Home with the Marquis de Sade
Francine du Plessix Gray
(Pimlico, £15)
Buy it at BOL

Eighteenth-century France as malign theatre. Acting is central to de Sade's imagination - the operative verb in "staging an orgy" is, after all, stage. "Two or three extra cocks might be needed," he notes as a direction to his sexual charades, strenuously choreographed as Feydeau farces. Indeed, de S reads here as a movie director before cinema - megalomania, inverted religiosity, sadism (natch). Fab account of the festival he puts on in his Provençal chateaux. He invites Comédie Française stars but they decline; de S goes on anyway to an audience of peasants - as the gentry wouldn't come either.

fields.headline: Fishy tales
fields.standfirst: Michèle Roberts weaves together a watery web of stories in The Looking Glass
fields.trailText: Michèle Roberts weaves together a watery web of stories in The Looking Glass
fields.body:
The Looking Glass
Michèle Roberts
Little, Brown, £15.99, 277pp
Buy it at BOL

"She was half-woman, and half-fish, a beauty who was also a monster. She seemed to promise men pleasure and then turned dangerous." In this tale, recounted to the servant girl Geneviève by her charismatic employer Madame Patin, the mermaid is brutally slaughtered by a man who manages to escape her "snare of enchantment". With her throat slit and streaming blood, she is transformed into the coil of seaweed that assumes folkloric significance, being hung outside back doors to determine the nature of oncoming weather.

"Turning dangerous" is precisely what Geneviève both fears and desires; having developed a bond with Madame Patin that sits uncomfortably between love for her absent mother and romantic passion, she is unable to accommodate the arrival of a suitor for the older woman. The calamity that ensues provokes both terror and guilt in her, and she makes an inevitable dash for the sea in order to drown herself.

The experience is described in highly charged, psychosexual vocabulary, the sea "a great mouth spitting me out" and "a green-veined tunnel", Geneviève's rescuer solicitously bending down, her mouth "a wide red o of astonishment". Fleeing what she erroneously believes to be her destructive powers, Geneviève has stumbled on solace and protection, ushering in the next phase of her life and of the novel.

These preliminary details, coloured by mythology, sexual politics, desire and appetite both repressed and sated, might lead the reader to think that Michèle Roberts's new novel is desperately overwritten, at once self-consciously lyrical and striving for both sensuousness and significance. And at times one does feel jaded by her artfulness, drenched in the continual employment of the sea, indeed of water of any kind - rivers, rain, sweat, tears - as a metaphor for oceanic, ungovernable emotions. But while the novel does stray occasionally towards portentousness, it is saved by passages of extraordinarily evocative, intensely imagined descriptive writing, and an authorial deftness that infuses both plot and character with wit, humour and intelligence.

Roberts's language is almost painterly in its determination to show light and shade, revealing a densely patterned world that assails the senses: crab shins, "flecked red and white, flaring with bristly hairs", a long-necked woman who resembles "a wader pecking elegantly along the shore", blossom like "a dream of shivery whiteness". These picturesque fragments exist alongside an arch tale of romantic rivalry that comes close to a comedy of manners.

The setting is provincial France shortly before the outbreak of the first world war. Geneviève now finds herself in a household of women covertly competing for the affections of one man. He is a poet, and the women are his mother, an English governess, his young niece and Geneviève herself. Held at a distance is Isabelle, a dressmaker who deceives her lumpish husband to enjoy illicit romps in a hotel bedroom.

Geneviève, Isabelle and the governess Millicent each get their crack at telling us the story: Geneviève in her characteristically fraught manner, leaking shame and guilt; Millicent in a series of achingly naive and fervent diary entries ("My soul has flown out with him to walk beside him, invisible in the fragrant salty night"); and Isabelle in a brisk, business-like fashion, outlining her pragmatic adaptation to the role of mistress. Gradually, as each of them darts in front of the looking glass, their stories become mingled; the one figure we can hardly catch sight of is that of the romantic poet himself.

Each character is beguiled by her own story, and embroiled in the business of creating a coherent narrative out of recalcitrant experience. The woman are also hobbled by their ignorance of one another until, at the novel's climax, their paths converge. The story of that meeting is given to a marginal character who proves herself unexpectedly perceptive and outspoken on the matter of the promiscuous poet. "In my view," she confides to an unknown interviewer, "he was no different from any other bourgeois male complacently assuming he was entitled to large doses of female adoration." Quite correctly, she notes that the lovers' meeting was "worthy of the most crude type of melodrama", a frenzied whirl of desire and self-deception quite absent from any of the participants' accounts.

Fishy tales, all of them, and expertly marshalled by Roberts, who effortlessly mixes tragedy with comedy, authenticity with flamboyant artifice and brooding sentiment with subversive irony.

fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: Welsh literature rarely gets its due, and here is something that really deserves notice.
fields.body:
The Invocation of Manawydan
Evan Gwyn Williams
(24pp, Shoestring Press, £3)

Welsh literature rarely gets its due, and here is something that really deserves notice. Evan Gwyn Williams began writing poetry in the 1960s, and for a while was a member of the so-called "Group" that included Peter Porter, Peter Redgrove and Philip Hobsbaum. The Group was said to have some influence on Seamus Heaney. This latest pamphlet show Williams to be quite a star, whether following the "Spoor of Pity" in the South Wales Coal Field or, in the title poem, invoking the "mad Prince of the Kingdoms".

fields.headline: Rhododendrons
fields.trailText:
They were brought under sail
from a red-tinged east,
carried down gangplanks
in dockers' arms. Innocent
and rare...
fields.body:
They were brought under sail
from a red-tinged east,
carried down gangplanks
in dockers' arms. Innocent
and rare. Their thick leaves
bore a salt-damp gleam,
their blooms a hidden gargle
in their green throats.

Shuddering on trains
to Poolewe, or Arduine,
where the head gardener leaned
across the factor's desk. On a hill
above the sparkling loch
he spoke to his hands,
and terraces were cut,
sites marked, shallow holes dug

before they were turned out.
- Such terribly gentle
work, the grasping of the fat
glazed pots, the fertile
globe of the root-ball
undisturbed, Yunnan
or Himalayan earth
settled with them.

So we step out from their shade
to overlook Loch Melfort
and the bare glens, ready now
to claim this flowering, purple
flame-bright exotica as our own;
a commonplace, native
as language or living memory,
to our slightly acid soil.

On a hill above the sparkling loch he spoke to his hands, and terraces were cut, sites marked, shallow holes dug before they were turned out. - Such terribly gentle work, the grasping of the fat glazed pots, the fertile globe of the root-ball undisturbed, Yunnan or Himalayan earth settled with them. fields.headline: Stories from the cigar box
fields.standfirst: Lyn Gardner talks to Allan Ahlberg about grown-up writing for children
fields.trailText: Lyn Gardner talks to Allan Ahlberg about grown-up writing for children
fields.body:
Allan Ahlberg tells the story of the woman who cornered Einstein at a party. "Of course," said the woman airily, "I have dozens of ideas every day." "Do you?" replied Einstein. "I've only ever had one."

Ahlberg has an abundance of ideas, as befits a man who has become one of the best-known and prolific writers for children. He keeps his in an old cigar box. But like Einstein, he is wise enough to know that it is quality and selection that really matter. "The real skill is in the choosing which of your ideas you are going to develop. It is like being in a lifeboat and deciding which ones you are going to haul inside," he says.

For the last 25 years he's been doing pretty well. Since the day that his wife Janet, an artist who died of breast cancer in 1994, asked him to come up with a story that she could illustrate, Ahlberg has been enlivening children's bedtimes with books that range from the simplicity of that nursery classic Each Peach Pear Plum, through the truthful observations of everyday school life in the poems Please Mrs Butler, to the comic delights of The Giant Baby and Woof!

For plenty of children, books such as Peepo!, the Happy Families series and The Jolly Postman are as much a rite of passage as losing a first baby tooth or starting school - about which, incidentally, there is a lovely, witty book.

Ahlberg, who worked as a grave-digger and for 10 years as a primary-school teacher, still doesn't feel entirely comfortable being labelled a children's writer. "Ideally I would simply choose to be a writer. But the truth is that when I get up in the morning and sit down to write it is some kind of children's book that comes out."

Or is it? Ahlberg's latest book, My Brother's Ghost, a slim 10,000 words that he describes as "a bonsai novel" is a marvellous evocation of a working-class 1950s childhood amid the stinking canals and factories of the Black Country, and a spine-tingling ghost story. Although I've tangible proof that the book has appeal to eight and nine-year-olds, who are drawn by its miniature format and gold-blocked binding, its spare, grave prose and aching sense of loss are entirely grown-up.

Ahlberg agrees that there is something different about My Brother's Ghost from his previous work. "I wrote it to please myself. I had hopes that some children would get to it and read it, but to be brutal I didn't care," he says, pointing out that when writing for children there is curb and restraint in the same way that if you are playing table tennis with a child, you take account of their height.

The only restraint in My Brother's Ghost is in the delicate writing. Its emotional territory - coming to terms with death and life - is as painful as a graze of the skin. There is something quite defenceless about it. Perhaps that is because it springs from both recent hurts and older wounds. The death of his wife and collaborator, Janet, is clearly one, but Ahlberg has also dug deep into the scars of his own childhood.

"It is a cliché to say that as writers get older they are drawn back to their childhoods, but I would write about that time all the time if anyone would read it," says Ahlberg, who was adopted as a baby. In the book, the narrator Frances and her baby brother Harry and older brother Tom, who has a fatal encounter with a milk float on page one, are orphans being brought up by their aunt Marge, a woman without maternal instinct who hits the children one minute and begs their forgiveness the next.

"It would be a libel to say that Auntie Marge is my mother. Working-class life was hard in those days, but my mother was more violent than many," recalls Ahlberg. Yet he now feels he understands her. "We moved four times in six years. I went to four different schools. It was awful. It was only later I realised that what she was trying to do was to get us a house with an inside bathroom."

The novel is littered with autobiographical references: the geography and the names of the streets are based on the town of Oldbury where Ahlberg grew up, and the cemetery in the book is the same one where he worked after A levels and where the superintendent of parks, puzzled that a lad with qualifications should work as a grave-digger, persuaded him to apply to become a teacher.

All the best writers for children have the rare ability to recall what it felt like to be a child, but part of the pleasure and pain of My Brother's Ghost is the way those feelings are filtered through the perspective of an adult, the middle-aged Frances who is recalling events of 40 years previously.

The result is something that is tinged not by nostalgia but an overwhelming sense of loss, made all the more poignant because it was not a happy childhood, and the crippled Frances is not a child with winning ways.

Since he has always thought of himself as a comic writer, Ahlberg is slightly surprised to find he has written this serious book. But he believes that stories choose their own form and shape.

"It's like the way a piece of knitting is defined by the first row of stitches on your needle. It is the first three or four sentences that establish the feel and rhythm of a book. The assumption is that writing a story is about coherence, logic and planning. For me it is about the sense and the sound of the words. It is like finding the perfect pair of gloves to go with the coat."

But like Einstein, he is wise enough to know that it is quality and selection that really matter. "The real skill is in the choosing which of your ideas you are going to develop. It is like being in a lifeboat and deciding which ones you are going to haul inside," he says. For the last 25 years he's been doing pretty well. Since the day that his wife Janet, an artist who died of breast cancer in 1994, asked him to come up with a story that she could illustrate, Ahlberg has been enlivening children's bedtimes with books that range from the simplicity of that nursery classic Each Peach Pear Plum, through the truthful observations of everyday school life in the poems Please Mrs Butler, to the comic delights of The Giant Baby and Woof! For plenty of children, books such as Peepo!, the Happy Families series and The Jolly Postman are as much a rite of passage as losing a first baby tooth or starting school - about which, incidentally, there is a lovely, witty book. Ahlberg, who worked as a grave-digger and for 10 years as a primary-school teacher, still doesn't feel entirely comfortable being labelled a children's writer. "Ideally I would simply choose to be a writer. But the truth is that when I get up in the morning and sit down to write it is some kind of children's book that comes out." Or is it? Ahlberg's latest book, My Brother's Ghost, a slim 10,000 words that he describes as "a bonsai novel" is a marvellous evocation of a working-class 1950s childhood amid the stinking canals and factories of the Black Country, and a spine-tingling ghost story. Although I've tangible proof that the book has appeal to eight and nine-year-olds, who are drawn by its miniature format and gold-blocked binding, its spare, grave prose and aching sense of loss are entirely grown-up. Ahlberg agrees that there is something different about My Brother's Ghost from his previous work. "I wrote it to please myself. I had hopes that some children would get to it and read it, but to be brutal I didn't care," he says, pointing out that when writing for children there is curb and restraint in the same way that if you are playing table tennis with a child, you take account of their height. The only restraint in My Brother's Ghost is in the delicate writing. Its emotional territory - coming to terms with death and life - is as painful as a graze of the skin. There is something quite defenceless about it. Perhaps that is because it springs from both recent hurts and older wounds. The death of his wife and collaborator, Janet, is clearly one, but Ahlberg has also dug deep into the scars of his own childhood. "It is a cliché to say that as writers get older they are drawn back to their childhoods, but I would write about that time all the time if anyone would read it," says Ahlberg, who was adopted as a baby. In the book, the narrator Frances and her baby brother Harry and older brother Tom, who has a fatal encounter with a milk float on page one, are orphans being brought up by their aunt Marge, a woman without maternal instinct who hits the children one minute and begs their forgiveness the next. "It would be a libel to say that Auntie Marge is my mother. Working-class life was hard in those days, but my mother was more violent than many," recalls Ahlberg. Yet he now feels he understands her. "We moved four times in six years. I went to four different schools. It was awful. It was only later I realised that what she was trying to do was to get us a house with an inside bathroom." The novel is littered with autobiographical references: the geography and the names of the streets are based on the town of Oldbury where Ahlberg grew up, and the cemetery in the book is the same one where he worked after A levels and where the superintendent of parks, puzzled that a lad with qualifications should work as a grave-digger, persuaded him to apply to become a teacher. All the best writers for children have the rare ability to recall what it felt like to be a child, but part of the pleasure and pain of My Brother's Ghost is the way those feelings are filtered through the perspective of an adult, the middle-aged Frances who is recalling events of 40 years previously. The result is something that is tinged not by nostalgia but an overwhelming sense of loss, made all the more poignant because it was not a happy childhood, and the crippled Frances is not a child with winning ways. Since he has always thought of himself as a comic writer, Ahlberg is slightly surprised to find he has written this serious book. But he believes that stories choose their own form and shape. "It's like the way a piece of knitting is defined by the first row of stitches on your needle. It is the first three or four sentences that establish the feel and rhythm of a book. The assumption is that writing a story is about coherence, logic and planning. For me it is about the sense and the sound of the words. It is like finding the perfect pair of gloves to go with the coat."

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A beautiful map of the heart, plus Impromptu In Moribunda, Shape-shifter and The Silent Sentry
fields.body:
Come Back, Paddy Riley
Carol Birch
(Virago, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

This is no prosaic tale of marital infidelity, but equally Birch does not allow her heroine to become a tragic Emma Bovary with mod cons. Switching between Anita's past as the child of a Jewish father and an Irish mother with gypsy blood, her adolescence as part of the Quack Fair, doing drugs and wandering through England, and her seemingly tranquil present in small-town motherhood, Birch plots the deliberations that lead to unfaithfulness. Engrossing, tinged with Angela Carter's otherworldliness and adept at portraying Anita's conflicting desires for the predictability of her husband, Charley, and the danger of her lover, Michael. A beautiful map of the heart.

Impromptu In Moribunda
Patrick Hamilton
(Trent Editions, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

First published at the outbreak of the second world war, Hamilton's satire on social complacency and the growing power of mass media was at once outdated, and this reissue's only point seems scholarly completeness. A sci-fi allegory that mocks Wells and Huxley, it rockets a young man to Moribundia, a place which is England copied from the clichés of newspaper-speak, a land where the upper-class men play a straight bat and the women are fragrant while the working classes are naturally feckless. Despite its crude mechanics, this is a readable historical curiosity, and readers can play at translating Hamilton into modern times.

Shape-shifter
Pauline Melville
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

A dozen tales describing moments when the ground shifts beneath your feet and jumbles old patterns into new forms: Melville has created a modern-day Metamorphoses. From the day Shakespeare McNab falls foul of the Comrade Vice President to McGregor's break-out from a building site and a cabaret artist who creates a monstrous act, Melville has an acute eye for detail. There is both the exoticism of her native Guyana, a place where devils lurk and the ghosts of hundreds of years of colonialism flit through the eyes of her characters and, in contrast, the coldness of England. Melville describes worlds that are both frighteningly unpredictable and wonderfully full of possibility.

The Silent Sentry
Chris Paling
(Vintage, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Maurice Reid is a radio producer and - guess what? - his life is in a mess. He carries the expected scars of middle age: job neurosis, broken marriage, weekend parenting and a shaky ego - miseries shared by his friends at the Corporation. Paling marshals fag-hazed pubs, after-hours dissatisfactions and bleary mornings-after to compound his hero's sense of failure. This is just the kind of novel that you would expect mid-career BBC staff to write when not bitching about dumbing down and management. As a hero Reid engages on all the right levels, and The Silent Sentry is a well-written, gentle satire; its trouble is its utter predictability.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText:
An old man dying of cancer prays to see his son find a partner, plus Pete McCarthy hankering for Hibernia in McCarthy's Bar
Hear an extract from As it is in Heaven
Hear an extract from McCarthy's Bar
fields.body:
As It Is in Heaven
Niall Williams
(Macmillan, £8.99,180mn)
Buy it at BOL

Hear an extract

Old man in final cancer throes prays to live long enough to see his gauche 32-year-old son find a girlfriend. No obvious laughs here, other than in Williams's compulsion to spurious mysticism and his relentless flogging of similes. Something cracks loudly like a breaking communion host; something else glistens like a chalice. John Lynch lards it with a soulful voice, but in vain.

McCarthy's Bar
Pete McCarthy
(Hodder, £8.99,120mn)
Buy it at BOL
Hear an extract

Meant to be funny, this succeeds nicely. Like many second-generation Irish-British, travel writer McCarthy hankers for Hibernia. "I feel as if I've come home - or am I just a sentimental fool?" His rule - never pass a bar that has your name on it - makes a simple and pleasing frame. Authors should never record their own books, except autobiography, which this is, and McCarthy gets away with it.
