fields.headline: The forgotten past
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi  assays an uneven anthology of new black writing, IC3
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi assays an uneven anthology of new black writing, IC3
fields.body:
IC3: The Penguin Book of New Black Writing in Britain
ed by Courttia Newland and Kadija Sesay
Hamish Hamilton, £9.99, 462pp
Buy it at BOL

Only a decade ago, publishers appeared to favour the first-generation migrant’s backward glance at “exotic” landscapes - the Rushdies and Okris - over those writers who were black and British but whose territory was closer to home. Since the mid-1990s, that bias has been eroded, with a wave of fiction-writers joining the poets of stage and page who were so crucial in the 1980s to the revival of British poetry.

There are many possible reasons for the belated entry of major publishers into this growing area of British creativity. The commercial successes of ventures such as X Press, launched with Victor Headley’s bestselling Yardie, helped overturn lazy assumptions about which books sold and who their readers were. The Saga Prize for unpublished first novels by people of African descent gave a fillip, launching the careers of Diran Adebayo and Joanna Traynor. And while visibly successful writers breed aspirant ones, a demographic factor may also be at work: half a century after the Empire Windrush docked at Tilbury, the pioneers’ children and grandchildren have a relative ease of presence, bringing increased confidence to pursue the precarious vocation of writing.

This anthology of almost 100 contributors testifies both to the proliferation of aspiring British writers of African descent and to a growing willingness to tap that talent. Its title, IC3, is police shorthand for black (IC1, 2 and 4 being code - with scant regard for science or geography - for “Caucasian”, “Mediterranean” and “Asian” respectively).

In his introduction, Courttia Newland solemnly argues that IC3 is the only collective term for Britons of African descent, since “black British” is “political and refers to Africans, Asians, West Indians, Americans and sometimes even Chinese”. He could rather glory in the fertile irony of the title: its promise of a subversive and heterogeneous creativity that flies by the nets of rigid expectations, thumbing its nose at the powers that seek to define and rule.

Sadly, the promise of the title is only partially fulfilled. Ambitious in size and scope, the book is divided into three sections, each encompassing poetry, essays, stories and memoirs. Headed “Settlers”, “Explorers” and “Crusaders”, the three parts are said loosely to reflect first, second and third generations, although since this is an anthology of “almost exclusively brand-new black writing”, those who seek a sampler of the Windrush generation’s literary greats might turn instead to Onyekachi Wambu’s Empire Windrush: 50 Years of Writing about Black Britain (Gollancz, 1998).

Not only is the writing new, but many of the names are too. Some more established poets, such as Linton Kwesi Johnson, Lemn Sissay, Patience Agbabi and Jackie Kay, are represented by previously published work. Other relatively prominent writers are featured, including Ferdinand Dennis, Buchi Emecheta, Benjamin Zephaniah and Bernardine Evaristo, and some contributors - such as Floella Benjamin - are well known, but not necessarily as writers. But this is largely a compilation of lesser-known names - with a marked absence of such heavy hitters of the second or third generation as Caryl Phillips, Fred D’Aguiar or Andrea Levy.

There are some excellent short stories, including Patrick Wilmot’s quirkily humorous “The Train to Walthamstow”, in which Ronnie the Rat observes the “human infestation” of King’s Cross, and “MOT Time”, in which Hope Massiah movingly charts an estranged daughter’s discovery that her young step-mother is pregnant, while Allister Harry’s “T e Headmas er’s Off ce” (sic) sees a man return to school to confront past demons.

Among memoirs, Joanna Traynor stands out for her buoyant verve and voice, as does Margaret Busby, whose light touch whets the appetite for her forthcoming memoirs. Musician Labi Siffre’s meditative essay, “Choosing the Stick They Beat You With”, searingly contrasts his boyhood discovery of gay sexuality with how he came to an awareness - imposed by others - of being black.

While the decision to classify a piece of prose as “memoir” or “essay” seems at times puzzlingly arbitrary, some of the most engaging writing is non-fiction that takes off from a personal passion. Colin Babb’s “Cricket, Lovely Cricket” describes the importance of West Indian victories for him as a south London boy, delineating shifting identities through sporting affiliations, while Kevin Le Gendre’s “Father of Freeform”, on unsung British jazz pioneer Joe Harriott, indicts invisibility and erasure through enthusiasm.

There are fine poems from Linton Kwesi Johnson (the ironic “If I Woz A Tap-Natch Poet”), Jackie Kay, Dorothea Smartt and Uju Asika. Yet, for consistency of quality, I would sooner recommend The Fire People: A Collection of Contemporary Black British Poets (Payback, 1998), edited by Lemn Sissay.

For while there are gems here, the quality is troublingly uneven. IC3, according to Newland, presents “an amazing amalgamation of all the talents Black British writing has to offer”, without regard to “the writer’s politics, gender, age or even class”. But it is not clear what the criteria for inclusion are. Was the intention to showcase the best of literary talent or to chronicle a changing community and its concerns?

Perhaps understandably, given the pressure to produce a “landmark” Penguin volume, IC3 seeks to do it all. Essays and articles sit uneasily with the creative writing; once again, my preferred recommendation for a discursive anthology would lie elsewhere, with Black British Culture and Society (Routledge, 2000), edited by Kwesi Owusu. Moreover, some of the writing that directly, rather than obliquely, explores identity is neither new nor well expressed.

Sesay makes a sound point in her introduction about literary forerunners paving the way for younger authors. But one is at times left wondering about the reading habits of some of these aspiring writers. There is a whole essay constructed around the argument that while black Britons riot, they do not demonstrate on a national scale, which makes no mention of the Black People’s Day of Action in response to the 1981 New Cross fire - about which Linton Kwesi Johnson has written poems.

Perhaps such lapses are symptomatic of the national amnesia about Britain’s black history that deprives both black and white Britons of part of their heritage. But an unawareness of literary forebears can only limit the claim of these writers to being “new”.

fields.headline: Cyberfunk
fields.standfirst: Jeff Noon starts Needle in the Groove much as any other novel, but then the bass kicks in...
fields.trailText: Jeff Noon starts Needle in the Groove much as any other novel, but then the bass kicks in...
fields.body:
Needle in the Groove
Jeff Noon
Anchor, £9.99, 287pp

Buy it at BOL

Some writers swim within the language, and what we agree to call reality, like goldfish in a bowl, graceful and unperturbed. Others are like birds in a greenhouse: banging against the glass, desperate to spread their wings. There's no doubt which group Jeff Noon falls into. When he leads his readers along Manchester's highways and alleys, through its squats and curry houses, it's usually to somewhere between the cyberspace of William Gibson and the junkie dreams of William Burroughs. In his early novels, Vurt and Pollen, you reached that world by sucking on a feather (so much more romantic than a pill, prettier than a computer). And with it you gulped down puns, wordplay, Noon's chafing against the bit of dull old English.

In Automated Alice Noon even tried to top the trickery of Lewis Carroll with his civil serpents and his windscreen vipers. In Nymphomation he imagined a race of "blurbflies", winged advertising slogans that mated and mutated and twisted their programmed soundbites into something wilder and dizzyingly more beautiful. Noon's books are published in 10 languages; God knows what gets lost in translation.

As if this weren't enough, Noon, former punk guitarist, is fascinated by music. "I listen to Schubert and I play the banjo and I write cyberpunk novels," is how he once put it. What dance acts do with sound, he is increasingly doing with his own text: chopping it up, shuffling it around, banging up the bass. This is the drive behind Needle in the Groove, allegedly written in "analogue flowtext" with "occasional use of iambic digitalis" and a spot of "cobralingus filtering".

Past that kidding, the book starts like any other but fast turns into something more like a disc, or a night at a club. Slashes break up paragraphs/like lines of lyrics/and choruses repeat and blur/like a gentle remix. It gets harder just to read the text: you start subvocalising it, almost singing it. Like all good music, it speaks of love, not least of the medium itself.

Noon's theme is music and the people who make it. The hero/narrator is burnt-out bassist Elliot, a "child of the Buzzcocks" who falls for a singer called Donna and gets a second chance at fame with her group. (They rehearse on Ian Curtis Boulevard, named after the late, great singer of Manchester band Joy Division.) Just when you think you've got the plot pinned down as boy meets girl and eventually makes beautiful music, the focus shifts to Elliot's friendship with 2spot - the band's drummer and Donna's boyfriend - then to 2spot's mysterious past, to Elliot's own parentage, to the origins of the band's music, to the nature of inspiration, "the lustre, the quiver, the spark and the play"...

These strands are layered and intercut; Elliot and friends even start to move through time, scratched back and forth like that needle in a groove. No feathers this time; instead, a sky-blue fluid that is both drug and recording medium: "liquid music", "analogue heaven".

This is not a book for the linear-minded, or for the deaf of heart. But if you like your fiction to test you, you won't be disappointed. As one of Elliot's band mates puts it,"the more you shake it, the deeper the mix".

fields.headline: The truth is stranger
fields.trailText: Winner of the Bad Sex Award turns his back on fiction, plus the great jacket-copy tournament enters its final phase
fields.body:
 From Cassell, news that the debonair gastronaut and neophyte novelist AA Gill is to turn his attentions - briefly, we fervently hope - away from fiction. For the traditional "substantial six-figure sum", Gill will write three books. One is a collection of longer journalism, another a scholarly study of food and gastronomy. Finally, we are to be treated to Gill's travels through Britain. For a man whose progress typically describes a triangle between west London, the Ivy and the Savoy, such exertions might prove difficult. We, however, applaud Gill's guts.

 We may not even proceed to further rounds of the great jacket-copy tournament, such is the calibre of this entry. A re-issue of The Diary of Eva Braun, from Spectrum International, presents the human side of Hitler's sexy sidekick, pointing out that she took more of an interest in her man's happiness than in world events. "Yet, the reader may not feel any real hostility towards this woman who gained so little from her association, but more likely experience the kind of discomfort that one suffers when the family dog licks the burglar." Yes, quite, damned annoying, that.

 A review in the Observer must have made uncomfortable reading for the paper's literary editor and former Faber employee Robert McCrum. Cressida Connolly, remarking on the scandal of novelist Mavis Cheek's relative obscurity, wrote that Faber "represent a sort of white man's grave for women writers".

Faber points out that it has just welcomed the bestselling Jane Smiley aboard, and also publishes Reggie Nadelson and PD James, alongside first-timers Julia Leigh and Helen Falconer. Most have been signed up since McCrum's tenure, when Faber was indeed known as something of a boys' club. So we can only admire his dedication to editorial non-intervention on his books pages. Or perhaps he simply has his mind on higher things - such as the biography of PG Wodehouse that he has just been contracted to write for Penguin.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski rounds up the latest releases
fields.body:
With Demolition Angel (Orion, £12.99), Robert Crais is shooting for the big time with all guns blazing. A veteran scriptwriter who worked on LA Law and Hill Street Blues, Crais is responsible for eight Elvis Cole novels to date. This witty, inventive series, featuring a hipper-than-hip Californian private eye, last year reached a high with the moving LA Requiem. He has now set aside his trademark series and penned a big thriller-by-numbers in an attempt to conquer the bestseller lists.

Carol Starkey was the queen of the bomb-disposal squad until an explosion that scarred her badly and killed her partner and lover: she is relegated to the sidelines, bitter and lonely. Now a bomb alert turns into a charred murder scene, and the breathless chase for the perpetrator brings her past rushing back.

The plot ticks away like clockwork, with every ingredient carefully calibrated - the master criminal, the inevitable MacGuffin, the heroine's alcoholism and lack of love-life, the technical detail and FBI computer knowhow - but, for all its relentless pace, the book lacks soul. There is no doubt that it will be a bestseller, and so will bring many new readers to Crais. One can only hope that these converts will move on to his earlier books. Not a sell-out, just a brilliant exercise in style.

Jeffery Deaver reached the mythical shores of film fortune with his first Lincoln Rhyme novel, The Bone Collector. He follows it with The Empty Chair (Hodder & Stoughton, £10), in which his paraplegic investigator returns with policewoman sidekick Amelia. Travelling to north Carolina for an operation, he is drafted in by the local cops when two women are kidnapped by a neighbourhood psychotic. Soon his world is turned upside down when Amelia joins the madman and they go on the run. His beliefs sorely questioned, Rhyme must draw on unfamiliar resources to survive and conquer. Slick, breathless stuff from a master of suspense in full flight.

Jerry Raine is a British author who prospers within the thin ranks of domestic miserablism noir. Slaphead Chameleon (Gollancz, £9.99) combines the small-time desperation of his earlier books with a glimpse into the shadowy borderlines of the music business. This is suburban crime at its most unassuming, and packs a mean punch as its unshowy virtues accumulate. Raine has a gift for recreating the ordinariness of daily crime, and much empathy for his collection of losers.

In Marc Blake's Hiaasen-esque 24 Carat Schmooze (Flame, £12), every London character is eminently dodgy. This is a romp of a thriller with all the charm of an alligator, as it follows a band of Dickensian modern geezers through a web of extortion. Guaranteed to cheer you up and worry you no end, as you ponder the world you and Blake's characters somehow share.

Lauren Henderson is the instigator of Tart Noir, a group of female crime writers with attitude (see the hilarious tartcity.com); her heroine, sculptor Sam Jones, has a knack of being in the wrong place at the wrong time, and usually in the wrong outfit. Her latest caper, Chained (Hutchinson, £10), is another racy set of misadventures in medialand as our involuntary sleuth gets handcuffed, beaten up and touched up - and that's only the beginning of her problems. Forget the angst and enjoy the ride.

fields.headline: A woman scorned
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit on Alexis Lykiard's fond memoir Jean Rhys Revisited
fields.trailText: Chris Petit on Alexis Lykiard's fond memoir Jean Rhys Revisited
fields.body:
Jean Rhys Revisited
Alexis Lykiard
Stride, £11.95, 281pp
Buy it at BOL

Although now more widely read and popular than her once better-known literary mentor and lover Ford Madox Ford, Jean Rhys spent most of her life forgotten. Alexis Lykiard's fond memoir is fascinated with the process by which authors slip out of memory, often undeservedly, and is littered with tantalising references to other vanished writers (Mina Loy, Anna Kavan), the famously overlooked (Henry Green), and those who willed themselves into obscurity through a refusal to compromise - a process Lykiard himself is qualified to write about, having abandoned his own career as a novelist.

Writing at a difficult time - the 1960s - when the English novel was an unfashionable thing for a young man to aspire to, Lykiard also missed out on the comfortable advances and literary prizes available to the generation after him, which produced careers as secure and dull as anything in the civil service.

Lykiard met Jean Rhys when he was a young writer in his twenties and she was getting on, reduced to fairly ghastly circumstances and stuck in a part of Devon she described as "really one of the dullest places under heaven". Their attraction was based on mutual exile (Lykiard had fled London for the west country) and the fact that they were both outsiders. Lykiard was Greek, filtered through public school, while Rhys had been raised in Dominica, beyond the usual constraints of English society, until sent to finish her education in England.

Because of her late arrival, Rhys's work escaped the network of defensive irony on which so much English literature depends. Lykiard's portrait presents her as being in all respects intensely unironic, and therefore intensely difficult. Stella Bowen, the third party in the ménage with Ford and Rhys, described her as "a doomed soul, violent and demoralised". The critic Claire Tomalin has marked her down as "as much monster as victim".

In the current jargon, Rhys suffered from low self-esteem ("I had a complete conviction that I was a useless person"), dysfunctional relationships and an addictive personality. But her neuroses were prescient of today's, and the template of her novels anticipated the contemporary interior landscape. Her work also deals with sexual and financial transactions in a recognisably modern way; it is attuned to emotional short-changing and its by-products, the humiliation and excitement of masochism. No one has written so well on the nature of careless lives.

Rhys's own sense of displacement - what Diana Trilling, in a rejoinder to the argument about her masochism, called her emotional "isolateness" - came out of her unsteady progress through the rackety world of the chorus line, Bohemian circles and the dubious world of masculine patronage. Her failure to adopt, and adapt to, Europe resulted in fiction that can, like her emigration, be read as a movement away from the light. Nowadays her English depressions would probably be diagnosed as seasonal affective disorder.

Lykiard paints Rhys as a haunted figure (and as such unreasoning), who through her upbringing related to ancient local Caribbean traditions of superstition and magic. He points out how crucial the dream state was to her. Her surreality was not dissimilar to Buñuel's in its startling juxtaposition; its collision of dreams, weather, ghostly eroticism and bourgeois reality, in the shape of money and architecture. "One day the fierce wolf that walks by my side will spring on you and rip your abominable guts out," she wrote matter-of-factly in Good Morning, Midnight.

Her work's timeless quality stands in contrast to her own life, which too often saw her stuck. In 1949 she wrote complaining that "my bitter enemy next door" was broadcasting that she was impersonating a dead writer called Jean Rhys, to which she added a rueful PS: "You think: perhaps I am!" This phantom life was given an ironic succinctness in Bowen's account of how she and Ford finally managed to get rid of Rhys - getting her "a job to 'ghost' a book for someone on the Riviera".

The richness of Lykiard's book depends on it offering more than just a memoir. The danger with Rhys is that she can be downgraded into a Merchant Ivory costume piece, when, as Lykiard knows, she is better represented by Lewton and Tourneur's I Walked With a Zombie. He is alert to the sharpness of Rhys's inner voice, her psychological acuity and the torpor of her stories in contrast to the exactness of her prose; he, like Rhys, is drawn to careless lives.

As well as being a meditation on the nature and business of writing, Jean Rhys Revisited is a piece of literary archaeology and a book of enthusiasms (Hamsun, Gissing, George Moore) that performs a useful act of referral. It is also a considered work about old age and beyond - Lykiard writes movingly about Rhys's fear of her approaching death - written by a man who was young when he knew Rhys, and is now approaching his own old age.

fields.headline: Postcards from prehistory
fields.standfirst: Richard Fortey investigates his personal obsession in Trilobite!
fields.trailText: Richard Fortey investigates his personal obsession in Trilobite!
fields.body:
Trilobite! Eyewitness to Evolution
Richard Fortey
HarperCollins, £15.99, 269pp
Buy it at BOL

Palaeontologists read the world as if it were a book, a planet's memoir. Where the rest of us see the Yorkshire Dales, they see a narrative. They find in the strata of limestone, sandstone and shale a succession of vanished oceans, beaches and estuaries. We see vague little shapes and shadows in the rock; they see claws that once scuttled across the floors of silent seas.

Every so often, the world completes a chapter in its history, writes finis, and starts a new episode. The evidence is real enough: the red rocks from the Devonian period shout of heat and dust and coral-filled lagoons; the shales of the Ordovician period tell of icesheets and mudslides and dark deeps; the beds of the Cretaceous period speak of oceans so fertile that the bones and shells of tiny creatures are piled into cliffs as high as Beachy Head. But these are only outlines for episodes.

Time's prose has been smudged and scrumpled: rubbed out by glacial erosion, blotted by volcanic cataclysm, folded and torn by the collision of continents. For a more detailed account of what happened - and when, how and why - earth scientists call on mute eyewitnesses, spectators with the minor disadvantage of being dead. In 1815, canal builder William Smith published a map matching certain fossils to particular strata (which came to be called Cambrian, Devonian and so on). He did this to establish a way of identifying tell-tale beds of rocks when they popped up again, but his literally epoch-making work helped others begin to understand the evolution of life. Palaeontology became the science that looked at stone and saw its precursor, mud, crawling with things covered in chitinous shells.

Among these were trilobites, three-lobed arthropods that were around when complex life began in the Cambrian period 540m years ago. They survived until the end of the Permian, 300m years later, long before the emergence of the dinosaurs. They lived only in the sea, growing shells and moulting them. Some were tiny, barely a millimetre across. Some were huge, the size of a teatray. Some clung to the darkness of sulphurous muds, some prowled across sandy sea-floors, some swam in clear waters.

And - alone in creation - they had glass eyes. Their shells grew crystals of pure calcite, skylights that conducted light in one precise, measurable axis, and that survived, along with the shells - something to goggle at for ever. Looking at them, palaeontologists can see how a creature saw 300m years ago. The fossils turn up everywhere, in Wales and the Urals, the Baltic and the Americas, China, the Himalayas and Australia, in their thousands of species.

With the help of their testimony, scientists are rewriting the history of the continents: tracking the inexorable inching of vast land masses around the globe 500m years ago. When Richard Fortey is asked by fellow commuters what he has done that day, he says, he has been known to reply: "I moved Africa 600km to the south."

Fortey, the Natural History Museum expert who wrote the knockout Life: An Authorised Biography, has followed it up with something more intense, more personal and in the long run probably more enlightening.

Trilobites are his obsession. He has used their story to tell a number of other stories: of the revelations of evolution, of how science is done, and of the strange people who do it. If there is any justice, Trilobite! will do for palaeontology what Longitude did for navigation. These mysterious little beasts played a key role in the discovery of time; in the gradual realisation, among 19th-century scientists, that life on earth was not just old, but enormously, unimaginably old, and that the processes that shape the earth now had shaped and reshaped it over and over again.

Trilobites began as part of the question, early in the so-called "Cambrian explosion" in which complex lifeforms appeared, as if from nowhere, after a 2bn-year reign of microbes. They stayed long enough to become part of the answer, by revealing the detail and fecundity of evolutionary speciation within one family. Their eyes alone could keep evolutionary theorists happy for lifetimes.

Calcite is transparent, but also refractive; so different rays travel different distances through a convex lens, according to their trajectory. What the trilobite saw would have been out of focus, but for a neat evolutionary trick: a layer of magnesian impurities that varied across the lens just enough to correct the spherical aberration.

But if trilobite eyes were so perfectly attuned to trilobite lifestyle, why did nature invent clear crystalline calcite lenses only once? Science still has plenty of questions, says Fortey, to be addressed with imagination and rigour, about the vision of a series of tiny creatures who lived in the dark for more than 240m years. There is sight, and there is insight.

webTitle: What Would You Like To See?

fields.headline: What Would You Like To See?
fields.standfirst: Raymond Carver divided his life into two parts - Bad Raymond, the drinking  years, and Good Raymond, the later years, many of which he spent looking  back, thinking how his past might have worked out otherwise. As a writer, his  output was fairly small, and the stories themselves are spare - honed down to a  lean perfection. It seemed that everything he had written was in the public  domain, mulled over, cherished. Then, following his death in 1988, a few more discoveries were made. The story we publish here, in a world exclusive, What  Would You Like To See?, is the last of the last. Carver wrote it, probably in the  early to mid 80s, and it harks back to 1977, the year when he was on the cusp of turning from 'Bad' to 'Good'. Soon after, he sold it, unheralded, with a batch of other documents to a university library - maybe because he  needed the money.
